original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One

original: Saṃyuttanikāye🔽Sagāthāvaggaṭīkā
analyzed: saṃyutta nikāye  sa gāthā vagga ṭīkā
translated: In the Connected Discourses🔽The Commentary on the Sagāthāvagga

original: Ganthārambhakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Beginning of the Text

original: 1. Saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayavandanā saṃvaṇṇetabbassa dhammassa pabhavanissayavisuddhipaṭivedanatthaṃ,
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe ratana taya vandanā saṃvaṇṇetabbassa dhammassa pabhava nissaya visuddhi paṭivedana attham
translated: In the beginning of the commentary, the paying of homage to the Three Jewels is for the purpose of announcing the purity of the source of the Dhamma that is to be commented on,

original: taṃ pana dhammasaṃvaṇṇanāsu viññūnaṃ bahumānuppādanatthaṃ, taṃ sammadeva tesaṃ uggahaṇadhāraṇādikkamaladdhabbāya
analyzed: tam pana dhamma saṃvaṇṇanāsu viññūnam bahu māna uppādana attham tam sammat eva tesam uggahaṇa dhāraṇa ādi kama laddhabbāya
translated: and for the purpose of arousing great respect in the wise for that Dhamma commentary, which can be properly received, retained, etc.,

original: sammāpaṭipattiyā sabbahitasukhanipphādanatthanti. Atha vā maṅgalabhāvato, sabbakiriyāsu
analyzed: sammā paṭipattiyā sabba hita sukha nipphādana tthanti atha vā maṅgala bhāvataḥ sabba kiriyāsu
translated: and for the purpose of producing the happiness of all welfare through right practice. Or else, because of its auspicious nature,🔽because of its being the preliminary work in all undertakings, because of its being practiced by the wise,

original: pubbakiccabhāvato, paṇḍitehi samācaritabhāvato, āyatiṃ paresaṃ diṭṭhānugatiāpajjanato
analyzed: pubba kicca bhāvataḥ paṇḍitehi samācarita bhāvataḥ āyatim paresam diṭṭha anugati āpajjanato
translated: and because of its leading others in the future to follow the example seen,

original: ca saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ ratanattayapaṇāmakiriyāti. Atha vā ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇaṃ pūjanīyapūjāpuññavisesanibbattanatthaṃ,
analyzed: ca saṃvaṇṇanā ayam ratana ttaya paṇāma kiriyā ati atha vā ratana ttaya paṇāma karaṇam pūjanīya pūjā puñña visesa nibbattana attham
translated: the paying of homage to the Three Jewels is done in the commentary. Or else, the paying of homage to the Three Jewels is for the purpose of producing the special merit of paying homage to what is worthy of homage,

original: taṃ attano yathāladdhasampattinimittakassa kammassa balānuppadānatthaṃ, antarā ca
analyzed: tam attanaḥ yathā laddha sampatti nimittakassa kammassa bala an uppadāna attham antarā ca
translated: for the purpose of not allowing the power of one's own kamma to arise that has the nature of the attainments one has received, and for the purpose of not being interrupted🔽in the middle by the arising of defilements.

original: tassa asaṃkocāpanatthaṃ, tadubhayaṃ anantarāyena aṭṭhakathāya parisamāpanatthanti
analyzed: tassa a saṃkoca āpana tham tat ubhayam anantarāyena aṭṭhakathāya parisamāpana tham ti
translated: and for the purpose of not contracting and bending it, and for the purpose of completing the commentary without interruption, both of these.

original: idameva ca payojanaṃ ācariyena idhādhippetaṃ. Tathā hi vakkhati “iti me pasannamatino…pe…🔽tassānubhāvenā”ti. Vatthuttayapūjā hi niratisayapuññakkhettasaṃbuddhiyā aparimeyyapabhāvo
analyzed: idam eva ca payojanam ācariyena idha adhippetam tathā hi vakkhati iti me pasanna matinā upe  tassa anubhāvena ati vatthuttaya pūjā hi niratisaya puñña kkhetta saṃbuddhiyāḥ aparimeyya pabhāvaḥ
translated: This is the purpose that the teacher has in mind here. For he says: “Thus, for those whose minds are clear in this way … and so on up to …

original: puññātisayoti bahuvidhantarāyepi lokasannivāse antarāyanibandhanasakalasaṃkilesaviddhaṃsanāya🔽pahoti, bhayādiupaddavañca nivāreti. Yathāha “pūjārahe pūjayato”tiādi, tathā “ye,
analyzed: bahuvidha antarāye api loka sannivāse antarāya nibandhana sakala saṃkilesa viddhaṃsanāya  bhaya ādi upaddavam ca nivāra iti yathā āha pūjā rahe pūjayatā itiādi tathā ye
translated: by the power of that.” For the worship of the three objects is able to destroy all defilements that are the cause of obstacles, even in the world of men, which is full of many kinds of obstacles, and to bring about the incomparable radiance of the fruit of merit, which is an incomparable field of merit.

original: bhikkhave, buddhe pasannā, agge te pasannā, agge kho pana pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hotī”tiādi.
analyzed: bhikkhave buddhe pasannāḥ agge te pasannāḥ agge kho pana pasannānam aggaḥ vipākaḥ hoti itiādi
translated: And it prevents the dangers of fear, etc., as it is said: “For one who worships the worshipful” and so on. And: “Bhikkhus, those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the best, and for those who have confidence in the best, the best result can be expected” and so on.

original: “Buddhoti kittayantassa, kāye bhavati yā pīti;
analyzed: buddhā uti kittayantassa kāye bhavati yā pi iti
translated: “The rapture that arises in one who recites the word ‘Buddha’

original: Varameva hi sā pīti, kasiṇenapi jambudīpassa;
analyzed: varam eva hi sā kasiṇena api jambudīpassa
translated: Is worth more than the rapture that comes from the earth sign in the kasiṇa of the earth,

original: Dhammoti…pe…, saṅghoti…pe…, jambudīpassā”ti. ;
analyzed: dhamma utipe saṅgha utipe jambudīpassa ati
translated: The rapture that arises in one who recites the word ‘Dhamma’ … in one who recites the word ‘Saṅgha’ … is worth more than the rapture that comes from the earth sign in the kasiṇa of the earth, the kasiṇa of the kasiṇa master who has made the kasiṇa of the earth in the great earth, the world with its gods, its Māras and Brahmās, this generation with its ascetics and brahmans, its princes and people.”

original: Tathā “yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ
analyzed: tathā yasmin mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ tathāgatam anussarati na iva assa tasmin
translated: Likewise: “Mahānāma, when a noble disciple recollects the Tathāgata …🔽on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust,

original: samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosa…pe… na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hotī”tiādi.
analyzed: samaye rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosape na moha pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti itiādi
translated: or obsessed by hate, or obsessed by delusion; his mind has rectitude on that occasion, being inspired by the Tathāgata” .

original: “Araññe rukkhamūle vā…pe… bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso na hessatī”ti ca.🔽Tattha yassa vatthuttayassa vandanaṃ kattukāmo, tassa guṇātisayayogasandassanatthaṃ
analyzed: araññe rukkha mūle vāpe bhayam vā chambhi tattam vā lomahaṃsaḥ na hessati iti ca  tattha yassa vatthuttayassa vandanam kattu kāmo tassa guṇa atisaya yoga sandassana attham
translated: “In the forest or at the foot of a tree or in an empty place … fear or terror or horror will not arise” .

original: “karuṇāsītalahadaya”ntiādinā gāthattayamāha. Guṇātisayayogena hi vandanārahabhāvo,🔽vandanārahe ca katā vandanā yathādhippetaṃ payojanaṃ sādhetīti. Tattha yassā desanāya
analyzed: guṇa ati saya yogena hi  vandanā rahe ca katā vandanā yathā adhippetam payojanam sādheti iti tattha yassā desanāya
translated: Herein, in order to show the excellence of the qualities of the one who is to be worshipped, he said the three stanzas beginning, “Whose heart is cool with loving-kindness” . For it is because of the excellence of his qualities that he is worthy of worship,

original: saṃvaṇṇanaṃ kattukāmo, sā na vinayadesanā viya karuṇāppadhānā, nāpi abhidhammadesanā
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanam kattu kāmo sā na vinaya desanā viya karuṇā ppadhānā na api abhidhamma desanā
translated: and worship of one who is worthy of worship accomplishes the desired purpose. Herein, the teaching that he wants to comment on is not a teaching of the Discipline that is concerned with loving- kindness, nor is it a teaching of the Abhidhamma that is concerned with understanding.

original: viya paññāppadhānā, atha kho karuṇāpaññāppadhānāti tadubhayappadhānameva tāva sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: paññā appadhānā atha kho karuṇā paññā appadhānā ti tad ubhaya ppadhānam eva tāva sammāsambuddhassa
translated: On the contrary, it is concerned with both loving-kindness and understanding. So he first of all shows the excellence of the qualities of the Fully Enlightened One, who is concerned with both loving-kindness and understanding,

original: thomanaṃ kātuṃ tammūlakattā sesaratanānaṃ “karuṇāsītalahadaya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: thomanam kātum sesa ratanānam vuttam tattha
translated: and the other jewels are rooted in it, it is said, “Whose heart is cool with the sword of compassion.” Herein

original: kiratīti karuṇā, paradukkhaṃ vikkhipati apanetīti attho. Atha vā kiṇātīti karuṇā,🔽paradukkhe sati kāruṇikaṃ hiṃsati vibādhatīti attho. Paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ kampanaṃ
analyzed: kirati iti karuṇā para dukkham vikkhipati apaneti iti atthaḥ atha vā kiṇāti iti karuṇā  para dukkhe sati kāruṇikam hiṃsati vibādhati iti attho para dukkhe sati sādhūnam kampanam
translated: “It cuts” is compassion . The meaning is that it cuts away, removes, another’s suffering. Or alternatively, “It is cut” is compassion .🔽The meaning is that it is cut, injured, damaged, by another’s suffering. Or compassion is that which causes trembling,

original: hadayakhedaṃ karotīti vā karuṇā. Atha vā kamiti sukhaṃ, taṃ rundhatīti karuṇā. Esā
analyzed: hadaya khedam karoti iti vā karuṇā atha vā kam iti sukham tam rundhati iti karuṇā esā
translated: a heart’s distress, in the good when there is another’s suffering. Or alternatively, “It is kam” is happiness . It is “run” by compassion .

original: hi paradukkhāpanayanakāmatālakkhaṇā attasukhanirapekkhatāya kāruṇikānaṃ sukhaṃ rundhati🔽vibandhatīti attho. Karuṇāya sītalaṃ karuṇāsītalaṃ, karuṇāsītalaṃ hadayaṃ assāti
analyzed: hi para dukkha apanayana kāma tā lakkhaṇā atta sukha nirapekkha tāya kāruṇikānam sukham rundhati  vibandhati iti karuṇāya sītalam karuṇā sītalam karuṇā sītalam hadayam assa ati
translated: For this has the characteristic of wanting to remove another’s suffering. It “runs” , prevents, happiness in those who are compassionate because it is indifferent to its own happiness.

original: karuṇāsītalahadayo, taṃ karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ.
analyzed: tam karuṇā sīta lahadayam
translated: The meaning is that it prevents it. The heart that is cool with the sword of compassion is “whose heart is cool with the sword of compassion.” That is “whose heart is cool with the sword of compassion.”

original: Tattha kiñcāpi paresaṃ hitopasaṃhārasukhādiaparihānicchanasabhāvatāya, byāpādāratīnaṃ
analyzed: kiñca api paresam hita upasaṃhāra sukha ādi a parihāni chana sabhāva tāya byāpāda aratīnam
translated: Herein, although it has the nature of wanting to bring about the welfare and pleasure of others and so on, it is called “sword” because it cuts away defilements and suffering, and it is called “cool” because it is the opposite of the heat of defilements.

original: ujuvipaccanīkatāya ca sattasantānagatasantāpavicchedanākārapavattiyā mettāmuditānampi
analyzed: uju vipaccanīka tāya ca satta santāna gata santāpa vicchedana ākāra pavattiyā
translated: And because of the directness of its opposition, and because of its occurrence with the mode of severing the fever of suffering in the mental continuity of others, loving-kindness and gladness are also found to be the cause of the mental coolness of the Blessed One’s mind.

original: cittasītalabhāvakāraṇatā upalabbhati, tathāpi paradukkhāpanayanākārappavattiyā parūpatāpāsahanarasā
analyzed: citta sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā upalabbhati tathā api para dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavattiyā parūpa tāpa āsahana rasā
translated: Nevertheless, because of its occurrence with the mode of removing the suffering of others, compassion has the characteristic of removing the suffering of others. Its function is to drive out the suffering of others. It is manifested as the abandoning of cruelty.

original: avihiṃsābhūtā karuṇāva visesena bhagavato cittassa cittapassaddhi viya sītibhāvanimittanti
analyzed: avihiṃsā bhūtā visesena bhagavato cittassa citta passaddhi viya sīti bhāva nimittanti
translated: It is the cause of the mental coolness of the Blessed One’s mind, like the mental tranquillity of his mind, and it is the sign of his mental coolness, like the coolness of his body.

original: vuttaṃ “karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti. Karuṇāmukhena vā mettāmuditānampi hadayasītalabhāvakāraṇatā vuttāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: vuttam karuṇā sītala hadayanti karuṇā mukhena vā mettā muditānam pi hadaya sītala bhāva kāraṇa tā vuttā iti daṭṭhabbā
translated: Therefore it is said that he has a heart cool with compassion. Or alternatively, it can be regarded as said with reference to loving- kindness and gladness that they are the cause of the mental coolness of his heart through compassion.

original: Atha vā chaasādhāraṇañāṇavisesanibandhanabhūtā sātisayaṃ niravasesañca sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ
analyzed: atha vā sa atisayam niravasesam ca sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: Or again, just as the knowledge of omniscience, which is the cause of the six kinds of distinctive knowledge not held in common by others, is possessed by the Blessed One in a special way with its object and range fully developed,

original: viya savisayabyāpitāya mahākaruṇābhāvamupagatā karuṇāva bhagavato abhisayena hadayasītalabhāvahetūti
analyzed: sa visaya byāpitāya mahā karuṇā bhāvam upagatā bhagavataḥ abhisayena hadaya sītala bhāva hetu uti
translated: so too compassion, which has become possessed of the state of great compassion, is the cause of the special mental coolness of the Blessed One’s heart.

original: āha “karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti.
analyzed: āha
translated: Therefore it is said that he has a heart cool with compassion.

original: Atha vā satipi mettāmuditānaṃ sātisaye hadayasītibhāvanibandhanatte sakalabuddhaguṇavisesakāraṇatāya
analyzed: atha vā satipi sa atisaye sakala buddha guṇa visesa kāraṇatāya
translated: Or alternatively, though loving-kindness and gladness are causes for the heart’s coolness, still

original: tāsampi kāraṇanti karuṇāva bhagavato “hadayasītalabhāvakāraṇa”nti vuttā. Karuṇānidānā
analyzed: tāsam pi kāraṇanti vuttā karuṇā nidānā
translated: compassion is called the Blessed One’s “cause for the heart’s coolness” because it is the cause for the special qualities of a Buddha.

original: hi sabbepi buddhaguṇā, karuṇānubhāvanibbāpiyamānasaṃsāradukkhasantāpassa hi bhagavato🔽paradukkhāpanayanakāmatāya anekānipi asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānaṃ akilantarūpasseva niravasesabuddhakaradhammasambharaṇaniyatassa🔽samadhigatadhammādhipateyyassa ca sannihitesupi sattasaṅghāṭasamupanītahadayūpatāpanimittesu
analyzed: hi sabbe api buddha guṇā karuṇā anubhāva nibbāpiyamāna saṃsāra dukkha santāpassa hi bhagavato  para dukkha apanayana kāma tāya anekāni api asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānam a kilanta rūpassa iva niravasesa buddha kara dhamma sambharaṇa niyatassa  samadhigata dhamma ādhipateyyassa ca sannihitesu pi satta saṅghāṭa samupanīta hadaya upatāpa nimittesu
translated: For all the special qualities of a Buddha have compassion as their source. The Blessed One’s heart is cooled by compassion,🔽and he is not wearied by the suffering of the world, which is being extinguished by the power of his compassion.🔽And he has no thought of turning away from his task of gathering the requisites for enlightenment, which are still incomplete, even though he has already spent countless aeons in doing so without turning away.🔽And he is not in the slightest degree affected by the sight of the world’s suffering, which is brought to his presence by the multitude of beings who come to him.

original: na īsakampi cittasītibhāvassa aññathattamahosīti. Etasmiñca atthavikappe tīsupi avatthāsu🔽bhagavato karuṇā saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: na īsakam pi citta sīti bhāvassa aññathattam ahosi iti etasmin ca attha vikappe tīsu pi avatthāsu 🔽bhagavato karuṇā saṅgahitā iti daṭṭhabbā
translated: And in this interpretation compassion should be regarded as included in all three states.

original: Pajānātīti paññā, yathāsabhāvaṃ pakārehi paṭivijjhatīti attho. Paññāva ñeyyāvaraṇappahānato
analyzed: pajānāti iti paññā yathā sabhāvam pakārehi paṭivijjhati iti attho paññā va ñeyya āvaraṇa pahānato
translated: Understanding is the act of understanding. The meaning is that it penetrates by way of the specific characteristics of the real nature of dhammas. Understanding is the light because it is the abandoning of the hindrance of unknowing.

original: pakārehi dhammasabhāvajotanaṭṭhena pajjototi paññāpajjoto. Savāsanappahānato visesena
analyzed: pakārehi dhamma sabhāva jotana ṭṭhena pajjoto ti paññāpajjoto sa vāsanā pahānataḥ visesena
translated: It is the light of understanding because it is the illumination of the real nature of dhammas by way of the specific characteristics.🔽It is the darkness of delusion because it is the darkness of delusion that is destroyed by the light of understanding.

original: hataṃ samugghāṭitaṃ vihataṃ. Paññāpajjotena vihataṃ paññāpajjotavihataṃ. Muyhanti🔽tena, sayaṃ vā muyhati, mohanamattameva vā tanti moho, avijjā. Sveva visayasabhāvapaṭicchādanakaraṇato
analyzed: hatam samugghāṭitam vihatam paññāpajjotena vihatam paññāpajjota vihatam muyhanti  tena sayam vā muyhati mohana mattam eva vā mohaḥ avijjā svā iva visaya sabhāva paṭicchādana karaṇato
translated: Delusion is the darkness of delusion. It is the darkness of delusion that is destroyed by the light of understanding because it is the darkness of delusion that is destroyed by the light of understanding.

original: andhakārasarikkhatāya tamo viyāti tamo. Paññāpajjotavihato mohatamo etassāti paññāpajjotavihatamohatamo,🔽taṃ paññāpajjotavihatamohatamaṃ. Sabbesampi hi khīṇāsavānaṃ satipi paññāpajjotena
analyzed: andhakāra sa rikkha tāya tamaḥ viyā ati tamo paññā pajjota vihataḥ moha tamo etassa ati paññā pajjota vihata moha tamo  tam paññāpajjota vihata mohatamam sabbesam pi hi khīṇāsavānam sati pi paññāpajjotena
translated: The darkness of delusion that is destroyed by the light of understanding is the darkness of delusion that is destroyed by the light of understanding.

original: avijjandhakārassa vihatabhāve saddhādhimuttehi viya diṭṭhippattānaṃ sāvakehi paccekasambuddhehi
analyzed: avijja andhakārassa vihata bhāve saddhā adhimuttehi viya diṭṭhippattānam sāvakehi paccekasambuddhehi
translated: For although the darkness of unknowing is destroyed by the light of understanding in all those who are cankers-destroyed, yet the darkness of delusion is not destroyed by the light of understanding in disciples and Paccekabuddhas who have reached view but are not devoted to faith, as it is in Perfect Buddhas.

original: ca savāsanappahānena sammāsambuddhānaṃ kilesappahānassa viseso vijjatīti sātisayena
analyzed: ca sa vāsanā pahānena sammāsambuddhānam kilesa ppahānassa visesaḥ vijjati iti sa atisayena
translated: and there is a difference between the destruction of defilements by the Fully Enlightened Ones and the destruction of defilements by others, since the latter is accompanied by a residue of defilements.

original: avijjāppahānena bhagavantaṃ thomento āha “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti.
analyzed: avijjā ppahānena bhagavantam thomentaḥ āha paññā pajja uta vihata moha taman ti
translated: So, in praising the Blessed One for the destruction of ignorance, he said “The darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of wisdom.”

original: Atha vā antarena paropadesaṃ attano santāne accantaṃ avijjandhakāravigamassa nibbattitattā,
analyzed: atha vā antarena para upadesam attano santāne accantam avijja andhakāra vigamassa
translated: Or alternatively, the Blessed One is to be praised above all others for the destruction of the darkness of delusion because he has himself produced the utter destruction of the darkness of ignorance in his own continuity without the help of another’s instruction,

original: tathā sabbaññutāya balesu ca vasībhāvassa samadhigatattā, parasantatiyañca dhammadesanātisayānubhāvena
analyzed: tathā sabbaññutāya balesu ca vasībhāvassa samadhigata ttā para santatiyam ca dhamma desanā atisaya anubhāvena
translated: and because he has himself attained the state of omniscience and mastery of the powers, and because he has himself brought about the occurrence of that in the continuity of another by the special potency of his teaching of the Dhamma.

original: sammadeva tassa pavattitattā bhagavāva visesato mohatamavigamena thometabboti āha🔽“paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti. Imasmiñca atthavikappe “paññāpajjoto”ti padena bhagavato
analyzed: sammat eva tassa pavatti tattā bhagavā ava visesataḥ moha tama vigamena thometabbaḥ iti āha  imasmin ca attha vikappe paññāpajjota uti padena bhagavataḥ
translated: So he said “The darkness of delusion dispelled by the light of wisdom” in order to praise the Blessed One for the destruction of the darkness of delusion.

original: paṭivedhapaññā viya desanāpaññāpi sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesanayena vā saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: paṭivedha paññā viya desanā paññā api sāmañña niddesena ekasesa nayena vā saṅgahitā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: And in this interpretation the words “the light of wisdom” should be regarded as including the Blessed One’s teaching wisdom as well as his penetrating wisdom, either by way of the general statement or by way of the specific statement.

original: Atha vā bhagavato ñāṇassa ñeyyapariyantikattā sakalañeyyadhammasabhāvāvabodhanasamatthena
analyzed: atha vā bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa ñeyya pariyantika ttā sakala ñeyya dhamma sabhāva avabodhana samatthena
translated: Or else, since the Blessed One’s knowledge is bounded by the knowable, it is able to penetrate the individual essences of all the knowable dhammas.

original: anāvaraṇañāṇasaṅkhātena paññāpajjotena sabbañeyyadhammasabhāvacchādakassa mohandhakārassa🔽vidhamitattā anaññasādhāraṇo bhagavato mohatamavināsoti katvā vuttaṃ “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti.🔽Ettha ca mohatamavidhamanante adhigatattā anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ kāraṇūpacārena sasantāne
analyzed: anāvaraṇa ñāṇa saṅkhātena paññāpajjotena sabba ñeyya dhamma sabhā avacchādakassa moha ndhakārassa  vidhamita ttā anañña sādhāraṇaḥ bhagavataḥ moha tama vināsaḥ ti katvā vuttam paññāpajja uta vihata moha taman ti  ettha ca moha tama vidham anante adhigata ttā anāvaraṇa ñāṇam kāraṇa upacārena sa santāne
translated: And since the darkness of delusion that conceals the individual essences of all the knowable dhammas is dispelled by the light of his knowledge called “non-obstruction,”🔽which is the condition for the penetration of the individual essences of all the knowable dhammas, the Blessed One’s destruction of the darkness of delusion is not shared by others. Thus it is said: “The darkness of delusion is dispelled by the light of knowledge.”

original: mohatamavidhamananti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Abhinīhārasampattiyā savāsanappahānameva hi kilesānaṃ🔽ñeyyāvaraṇapahānanti, parasantāne pana mohatamavidhamanassa kāraṇabhāvato phalūpacārena
analyzed: mohatama vidhamananti daṭṭhabbam abhinīhāra sampattiyā sa vāsanā pahānam eva hi kilesānam  ñeyya āvaraṇa pahānanti para santāne pana moha tama vidhamanassa kāraṇa bhāvato phala upacārena
translated: And here the knowledge called “non-obstruction” should be regarded as the dispeller of the darkness of delusion in the Blessed One’s own mental continuum by way of cause, since it is the cause for the destruction of the darkness of delusion.

original: anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ “mohatamavidhamana”nti vuccatīti.
analyzed: anāvaraṇa ñāṇam moha tama vidham ananti vuccati iti
translated: For the destruction of the darkness of delusion in the mental continuums of others is spoken of by way of effect, since the knowledge called “non-obstruction” is the condition for the destruction of the darkness of delusion in the mental continuums of others.

original: Kiṃ pana kāraṇaṃ avijjāsamugghātoyeveko pahānasampattivasena bhagavato thomanānimittaṃ
analyzed: kim pana kāraṇam pahāna sampatti vasena bhagavataḥ thomanā nimittam
translated: But why is the destruction of the darkness of delusion spoken of as the Blessed One’s light of knowledge by way of cause and effect?

original: gayhati, na pana sātisayaṃ niravasesakilesapahānanti? Tappahānavacaneneva tadekaṭṭhatāya🔽sakalasaṃkilesagaṇasamugghātassa jotitabhāvato. Na hi so tādiso kileso atthi, yo
analyzed: gayhati na pana sa atisayam niravasesa kilesa pahānan ti tad pahāna vacanena iva tad ekaṭṭhatāya  sakala saṃkilesa gaṇa samugghātassa jotita bhāvataḥ na hi so tādisaḥ kileso atthi yaḥ
translated: Because of the statement about the destruction of the dark side,

original: niravasesaavijjāppahānena na pahīyatīti.
analyzed: niravasesa avijjā pahānena na pahīyati iti
translated: there is no such defilement that is not destroyed by the destruction of ignorance without remainder.

original: Atha vā vijjā viya sakalakusaladhammasamuppattiyā niravasesākusaladhammanibbattiyā🔽saṃsārappavattiyā ca avijjā padhānakāraṇanti tabbighātavacanena sakalasaṃkilesagaṇasamugghāto
analyzed: atha vā vijjā viya sakala kusala dhamma samuppattiyā niravasesa akusala dhamma nibbattiyā  saṃsāra ppavattiyā ca avijjā padhāna kāraṇan ti tad bighāta vacanena sakala saṃkilesa gaṇa samugghātaḥ
translated: Or, just as ignorance is the principal cause for the arising of all unwholesome states and for the occurrence of the round of rebirths,🔽so the destruction of the dark side is stated by the statement about the destruction of ignorance.

original: vutto eva hotīti vuttaṃ “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti.🔽Narā ca amarā ca narāmarā, saha narāmarehīti sanarāmaro, sanarāmaro ca so loko cāti
analyzed: vuttaḥ eva hoti iti vuttam  narā ca amarā ca nara amarā saha nara amara ihi iti sa nara amaraḥ sa nara amaraḥ ca saḥ lokaḥ ca ati
translated: Therefore it is said: “The darkness of delusion is dispelled by the light of wisdom.”

original: sanarāmaraloko, tassa garūti sanarāmaralokagaru, taṃ sanarāmaralokagaruṃ. Etena devamanussānaṃ
analyzed: sa nara amara lokaḥ tassa garu uti sa nara amara loka garu tam sa nara amara loka garum etena deva manussānam
translated: “Gods and men” are narāmarā. “Together with gods and men” is sanarāmara. “The world of gods and men” is sanarāmaraloka. “Honored by the world of gods and men” is sanarāmaralokagaru. “That honored by the world of gods and men” is sanarāmaralokagaruṃ. By this,

original: viya tadavasiṭṭhasattānampi yathārahaṃ guṇavisesāvahatāya bhagavato upakārataṃ dasseti.
analyzed: viya tad avasiṭṭha sattānam pi yathāraham guṇa visesa āvahatāya bhagavataḥ upakāra tam dasseti
translated: and he shows how they are a benefit to the Blessed One by their producing special qualities in the remaining beings.

original: Na cettha padhānāppadhānabhāvo codetabbo. Añño hi saddakkamo, añño atthakkamo. Edisesu
analyzed: na ca ittha padhāna appadhāna bhāvaḥ codetabbaḥ aññaḥ hi sadda kkamaḥ aññaḥ attha kkamaḥ edisesu
translated: And here the question of whether or not there is predominance should not be raised. For the order of the words is different and the order of the meaning is different.

original: hi samāsapadesu padhānampi appadhānaṃ viya niddisīyati yathā “sarājikāya parisāyā”ti.
analyzed: hi samāsa padesu padhānam pi appadhānam viya niddisīyati yathā sa rājikāya parisāya ati
translated: For in such a compound as this, the predominant term is exhibited as if it were the subordinate term, as in the case of the expression “the whole city with the king” .

original: Kāmañcettha sattasaṅkhārokāsavasena tividho loko, garubhāvassa pana adhippetattā🔽garukaraṇasamatthasseva sattalokassa vasena attho gahetabbo. So hi lokīyanti ettha
analyzed: kāmañca ittha satta saṅkhāra ukāsa vasena tividhaḥ lokaḥ garu bhāvassa pana adhippeta ttā  garu karaṇa samatthassa iva satta lokassa vasena atthaḥ gahetabbaḥ saḥ hi lokīyanti ettha
translated: And although the world is threefold here according to the distinction of the three kinds of being consisting of beings of the kinds of generation, beings of the kinds of destiny, and beings of the kinds of element,🔽the meaning should be taken here according to the being-world that is capable of honouring, since it is that which is intended as weighty.

original: puññapāpāni tabbipāko cāti “loko”ti vuccati. Amaraggahaṇena cettha upapattidevā adhippetā.
analyzed: puñña pāpāni tad vipāko ca ati loko ti vuccati amara ggahaṇena ca ittha upapatti devāḥ adhippetā
translated: For that is called “the world” in the sense of “it goes ” , since it goes to merit and demerit and to the result of merit and demerit.🔽And by the expression “the immortals” , the gods of the fine-material and immaterial realms are intended.

original: Atha vā samūhattho loka-saddo samudāyavasena lokīyati paññāpīyatīti. Saha narehīti
analyzed: atha vā samūha atthaḥ loka saddo samudāya vasena lokīyati paññāpīyati iti saha narehi iti
translated: Or alternatively, the word “world” has the sense of a collection, since it is “gone about ” , is “gone through” , by the knowledge of a Buddha, a Paccekabuddha, or a disciple.

original: sanarā, sanarā ca te amarā cāti sanarāmarā, tesaṃ lokoti sanarāmaralokoti purimanayeneva
analyzed: sa narā sa narā ca te amarā ca ati sa nara amarā tesam loka uti sa nara amara loka uti purima nayena iva
translated: With the humans, the world of the immortals is the world of gods.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Amara-saddena cettha visuddhidevāpi saṅgayhanti. Te hi maraṇābhāvato
analyzed: yojetabbam amara saddena ca ittha visuddhi devā api saṅgayhanti te hi maraṇa abhāvato
translated: and the gods of the Pure Abodes are included by the word “immortal.” For they are immortal in the ultimate sense,

original: paramatthato amarā, narāmarānaṃyeva gahaṇaṃ ukkaṭṭhaniddesavasena yathā “satthā devamanussāna”nti.🔽Tathā hi sabbānatthapariharaṇapubbaṅgamāya niravasesahitasukhavidhānatapparāya niratisayāya🔽payogasampattiyā sadevamanussāya pajāya accantamupakāritāya aparimitanirupamappabhāvaguṇavisesasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: paramatthataḥ amarāḥ gahaṇam ukkaṭṭha niddesa vasena yathā satthā  tathā hi sabba anattha pariharaṇa pubbaṅgamāya niravasesa hita sukha vidhāna tad parāya niratisayāya  payoga sampattiyā sa deva manussāya pajāya accantam upakāritāya aparimita nirupama ppabhāva guṇa visesa samaṅgi tāya
translated: in the sense of being free from death. The words “men and immortals” include only men and gods, as is shown by the fact that the phrase is a mere amplification of the word “men.”🔽For the Blessed One is the most venerable being in the whole world of men and gods, because he is the supreme benefactor of the world of men and gods, who are endowed with the highest excellence of immeasurable and incomparable virtue, which consists in the accomplishment of the means of attaining the highest happiness, which is preceded by the removal of all misfortune.

original: ca sabbasattuttamo bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ uttamaṃ
analyzed: ca sabba sattuttamaḥ bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam uttamam
translated: For the Blessed One is the most venerable being in the whole world of men and gods, because he is the supreme benefactor of the world of men and gods, who are endowed with the highest excellence of immeasurable and incomparable virtue, which consists in the accomplishment of the means of attaining the highest happiness, which is preceded by the removal of all misfortune.

original: gāravaṭṭhānaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “sanarāmaralokagaru”nti.
analyzed: gārava ṭṭhānam tena vuttam sa nara amara loka garun ti
translated: Therefore it is said that he is “venerated in the world with its gods.”

original: Sobhanaṃ gataṃ gamanaṃ etassāti sugato. Bhagavato hi veneyyajanupasaṅkamanaṃ ekantena
analyzed: sobhanam gatam gamanam etassa ati sugataḥ bhagavataḥ hi veneyya jana upasaṅkamanam ekantena
translated: He has gone to beauty, thus he is a sugata . For the Blessed One’s approach to those who are to be trained is exclusively beautiful,

original: tesaṃ hitasukhanipphādanato sobhanaṃ, tathā lakkhaṇānubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitarūpakāyatāya
analyzed: tesam hita sukha nipphādanato sobhanam tathā lakkhaṇa anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍita rūpa kāya tāya
translated: because it produces their welfare and happiness. And it is beautiful because his physical form is adorned with the major and minor characteristics.

original: dutavilambitakhalitānukaḍḍhananippīḷanukkuṭikakuṭilākulatādi- dosarahitamavahasitarājahaṃsavasabhavāraṇamigarājagamanaṃ
analyzed: duta vilambita khalita anukaḍḍhana nippīḍa nukkuṭika kuṭila ākula tā ādi dosa rahitam avahasita rājahaṃsa vasabha vāraṇa miga rāja gamanam
translated: and free from the faults of waddling, dragging the feet, stumbling, dragging the feet along, pressing down, looking askance, crookedness, confusion, etc., and is like the gait of a king, a swan, an elephant, a bull, and a lion.

original: kāyagamanaṃ ñāṇagamanañca vipulanimmalakaruṇāsativīriyādiguṇavisesasahitamabhinīhārato
analyzed: kāya gamanam ñāṇa gamanam ca vipula nimmala karuṇā sati vīriya ādi guṇa visesa sahitam abhinīhārato
translated: The bodily going and the going by knowledge, accompanied by the special qualities of vastness, purity, compassion, mindfulness, energy, etc., are beautiful because of being faultless, from the time of the aspiration

original: yāva mahābodhi niravajjatāya sobhanamevāti.
analyzed: yāva mahā bodhi sobhanam eva ati
translated: up to the Great Awakening.

original: Atha vā sayambhūñāṇena sakalamapi lokaṃ pariññābhisamayavasena parijānanto ñāṇena
analyzed: atha vā sayambhu ñāṇena sakalam api lokam pariññā abhisamaya vasena parijānantaḥ ñāṇena
translated: Or else, he is well-gone (sugata) because he has gone well (sammā gata), understood (avagata), by means of his own knowledge, the entire world by way of the realization of full understanding (pariññābhisamaya).

original: sammā gato avagatoti sugato, tathā lokasamudayaṃ pahānābhisamayavasena pajahanto🔽anuppattidhammataṃ āpādento sammā gato atītoti sugato, lokanirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena
analyzed: sammā gataḥ avagataḥ iti sugataḥ tathā loka samudayam pahāna abhisamaya vasena pajahanto  an uppatti dhamma tam āpādento sammā gataḥ atītaḥ iti sugataḥ loka nirodham nibbānam sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena
translated: Similarly, he is well-gone because he has gone well, passed beyond, by way of the realization of abandoning (pajahānābhisamaya) the origin of the world (lokasamudaya).🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well, attained, by way of the realization of verification (sacchikiriyābhisamaya) of the cessation of the world (lokanirodha), which is Nibbāna.

original: sammā gato adhigatoti sugato, lokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ bhāvanābhisamayavasena🔽sammā gato paṭipannoti sugato. “Sotāpattimaggena ye kilesā pahīnā, te kilese na puneti
analyzed: sammā gataḥ adhigataḥ iti sugataḥ loka nirodha gāminim paṭipadam bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena 🔽sammā gataḥ paṭipannaḥ ti sugataḥ sotāpatti maggena ye kilesā pahīnā te kilese na puneti
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well, practiced, by way of the realization of development (bhāvanābhisamaya) of the way leading to the cessation of the world (lokanirodhagāminī paṭipadā).🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well, not returned, by way of the realization of full understanding (pariññābhisamaya) of the world (loka), having abandoned the defilements (kilesa) by means of the path of stream-entry.

original: na pacceti na paccāgacchatīti sugato”tiādinā nayena ayamattho vibhāvetabboti.
analyzed: na pacceti na paccāgacchati iti sugataḥ iti ādinā nayena ayam atthaḥ vibhāvetabbaḥ ti
translated: and does not return again, he is Sugata.

original: Atha vā sundaraṃ ṭhānaṃ sammāsambodhiṃ, nibbānameva vā gato adhigatoti sugato. Yasmā
analyzed: atha vā sundaram ṭhānam sammāsambodhim nibbānam eva vā gataḥ adhigataḥ iti sugataḥ yasmai
translated: Or alternatively, he has gone to a good place, to the supreme enlightenment, or to Nibbāna, thus he is Sugata.

original: vā bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ veneyyānaṃ yathārahaṃ kālayuttameva ca dhammaṃ bhāsati,
analyzed: vā bhūtam taccham attha saṃhitam veneyyānam yathāraham kāla yuttam eva ca dhammam bhāsati
translated: Or he is Sugata because he speaks well, he speaks rightly, he speaks truth, he speaks in season, he speaks what is relevant to the occasion, he speaks what is suitable to the person addressed, he speaks of the goal, and he speaks of the Dhamma, since he speaks the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning and phrasing, and reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: tasmā sammā gadati vadatīti sugato da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā. Iti sobhanagamanatādīhi
analyzed: tasmā sammā gadati vadati iti sugataḥ dakārassa takāram katvā iti sobhana gamana tā ādīhi
translated: Thus he is Sugata because of his good going, good speaking, and so on.

original: sugato, taṃ sugataṃ.🔽Puññapāpakehi upapajjanavasena gantabbato gatiyo, upapattibhavavisesā. Tā pana nirayādivasena
analyzed: sugataḥ tam sugatam  puñña pāpakehi upapajjana vasena gantabbataḥ gatiyaḥ upapatti bhava visesā tāḥ pana niraya ādi vasena
translated: He is the Sugata, the One of Good Going,🔽The destinies are the kinds of existence, which are the destinations to be reached by rebirth due to merit and to demerit. They are of five kinds as hell, animal realm, etc.,

original: pañcavidhā. Tā hi sakalassapi bhavagāmikammassa ariyamaggādhigamena avipākārahabhāvakaraṇena
analyzed: pañcavidhā tā hi sakalassa api bhava gāmi kammassa ariya magga adhigamena a vipāka araha bhāva karaṇena
translated: For by attaining the noble path he has turned away from all kamma that leads to existence and has made it incapable of producing any more kamma-result.

original: nivattitattā bhagavā pañcahipi gatīhi suṭṭhu mutto visaṃyuttoti āha “gativimutta”nti.
analyzed: nivatti tattā bhagavā pañcahi api gatīhi suṭṭhu muttaḥ visaṃyuttaḥ iti āha gati vimuttam ti
translated: Thus the Blessed One is “freed from all destinies” because he is completely dissociated from the five kinds of destinies.

original: Etena bhagavato katthacipi apariyāpannataṃ dasseti, yato bhagavā “devātidevo”ti vuccati. Tenāha –
analyzed: etena bhagavato katthacipi a pariyāpanna tam dasseti yatas bhagavā devātidevaḥ iti vuccati tena āha
translated: By this he shows the Blessed One’s non-inclusion in any class, since he is called “the deva above devas.” Hence it is said:🔽“By which I might be reborn a deva,

original: “Yena devūpapatyassa, gandhabbo vā vihaṅgamo;
analyzed: yena deva upapatyassa gandhabbaḥ vā vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: Or a gandhabb, or a bird,

original: Yakkhattaṃ yena gaccheyyaṃ, manussattañca abbaje;
analyzed: yakkhattam yena gaccheyyam manussattam ca abbaje
translated: Or a yakkha, or a man,🔽My cankers are destroyed,

original: Te mayhaṃ āsavā khīṇā, viddhastā vinaḷīkatā”ti. ;🔽Taṃtaṃgatisaṃvattanakānañhi kammakilesānaṃ aggamaggena bodhimūleyeva suppahīnattā
analyzed: te mayham āsavā khīṇāḥ vid hastāḥ vinaḷīka tā ati  taṃ taṃ gati saṃvattanakānaṃ hi kamma kilesānam aggamaggena bodhi mūleya iva su ppahīna ttā
translated: For I have cut them off and smashed them.”🔽For the Blessed One, by the supreme path, destroyed at the foot of the tree of enlightenment all the kamma-formations that lead to the various destinies.

original: natthi bhagavato gatipariyāpannatāti accantameva bhagavā sabbabhavayonigativiññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsasattanikāyehi
analyzed: natthi bhagavataḥ gati pariyāpanna tā ti accantam eva bhagavā sabba bhava yoni gati viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattāvāsa satta nikāyehi
translated: Therefore he is absolutely free from all kinds of becoming, destiny, station of consciousness, substratum of existence, and abode of beings.

original: suparimutto. Taṃ gativimuttaṃ. Vandeti namāmi, thomemīti vā attho.🔽Atha vā gativimuttanti anupādisesanibbānadhātuppattiyā bhagavantaṃ thometi. Ettha
analyzed: su parimuttaḥ tam gati vimuttam vandeti namāmi thomemi iti vā attho  atha vā gati vimuttam ti anupādisesa nibbāna dhātu pattiyā bhagavantam thometi ettha
translated: He is free from all destinies. The meaning is: I praise, I revere, I worship him.

original: hi dvīhi ākārehi bhagavato thomanā veditabbā attahitasampattito parahitapaṭipattito
analyzed: hi dvīhi ākārehi bhagavataḥ thomanā veditabbā atta hita sampattitaḥ para hita paṭipattitaḥ
translated: Or else, by the attainment of the Nibbāna element without residue he praises the Blessed One as free from destinies. Herein, the praise of the Blessed One should be understood in two ways: as the fulfilment of his own welfare and as the undertaking of others’ welfare.

original: ca. Tesu attahitasampatti anāvaraṇañāṇādhigamato, savāsanānaṃ sabbesaṃ kilesānaṃ🔽accantapahānato, anupādisesanibbānappattito ca veditabbā. Parahitapaṭipatti lābhasakkārādinirapekkhacittassa
analyzed: ca tesu atta hita sampatti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa adhigamato sa vāsanānam sabbesam kilesānam  accanta pahānataḥ anupādisesa nibbāna ppattitaḥ ca veditabbā para hita paṭipatti lābha sakkāra ādi nirapekkha cittassa
translated: The fulfilment of his own welfare should be understood as the attainment of unobstructed knowledge, the complete abandonment of all defilements together with their residues, and the attainment of the Nibbāna element without residue left. The fulfilment of the welfare of others should be understood as the teaching of the Dhamma by one whose mind is free from the desire for gain, honour, and renown, and from the expectation of future rewards.

original: sabbadukkhaniyyānikadhammadesanato, viruddhesupi niccaṃ hitajjhāsayavasena ñāṇaparipākakālāgamanato
analyzed: sabba dukkha niyyānika dhamma desanataḥ viruddhesu pi niccam hita ajjhāsaya vasena ñāṇa paripāka kāla āgamanato
translated: Herein, the fulfilment of his own welfare should be understood as follows: by the attainment of unobstructed knowledge, by the complete destruction of all the defilements together with their residues, and by the attainment of the Nibbāna-element without residue left. The practice of welfare for others should be understood as follows: by the teaching of the Dhamma, which leads to the escape from all suffering, with a mind free from concern for gain, honour, etc., and by the arrival at the time of the ripening of his knowledge through his constant intention to benefit others even in the face of opposition.

original: ca. Sā panettha āsayato payogato ca duvidhā parahitapaṭipatti, tividhā ca attahitasampatti🔽pakāsitā hoti, kathaṃ? “Karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti etena āsayato parahitapaṭipatti, sammāgadanatthena🔽sugata-saddena payogato parahitapaṭipatti, “paññāpajjotavihatamohatamaṃ gativimutta”nti
analyzed: ca sā pana ittha āsayataḥ payogataḥ ca duvidhā para hita paṭipatti tividhā ca atta hita sampatti  pakāsitā hoti katham etena āsayato para hita paṭipatti sammā gadana tthena  sugata saddena payogataḥ para hita paṭipatti paññā pajjota vihata mohatamam gati vimuttanti
translated: This practice of welfare for others is twofold as intention and as activity, and the fulfilment of his own welfare is threefold as the three kinds of knowledge.

original: etehi catusaccapaṭivedhatthena ca sugata-saddena tividhāpi attahitasampatti, avasiṭṭhatthena
analyzed: etehi catu sacca paṭivedha atthena ca sugata saddena tividhā api atta hita sampatti avasiṭṭha tthena
translated: How so? By the words “whose heart is cool with compassion” the practice of welfare for others as intention is shown. By the word “well gone” in the sense of right-going the practice of welfare for others as activity is shown. By the word “well gone” in the sense of the penetration of the four truths the fulfilment of his own welfare is shown as threefold by the words “whose darkness has been rent by the light of wisdom” and “who is free from the round of becoming.” By the remaining words the practice of welfare for others is shown as twofold.

original: tena “paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti etena ca sabbāpi attahitasampatti parahitapaṭipatti pakāsitā hotīti.
analyzed: tena etena paññā pajjota vihata moha tamanti etena ca sabbā api atta hita sampatti para hita paṭipatti pakāsitā hoti iti
translated: and by the words “whose darkness of delusion is dispelled by the light of wisdom” all the fulfilment of his own welfare and the practice of his others’ welfare are also revealed.

original: Atha vā tīhi ākārehi bhagavato thomanā veditabbā – hetuto phalato upakārato ca. Tattha
analyzed: atha vā tīhi ākārehi bhagavataḥ thomanā veditabbā hetutaḥ phalataḥ upakārato ca tattha
translated: Or alternatively, the Blessed One’s praise should be understood in three ways, as due to cause, fruit, and service. Herein,

original: hetu mahākaruṇā, sā paṭhamapadena dassitā. Phalaṃ catubbidhaṃ ñāṇasampadā pahānasampadā🔽ānubhāvasampadā rūpakāyasampadā cāti. Tāsu ñāṇapahānasampadā dutiyapadena saccapaṭivedhatthena🔽ca sugata-saddena pakāsitā honti, ānubhāvasampadā pana tatiyapadena, rūpakāyasampadā
analyzed: hetu mahākaruṇā sā paṭhama padena dassitā phalam catubbidham ñāṇa sampadā pahāna sampadā  ānubhāva sampadā rūpa kāya sampadā ca ati tāsu ñāṇa pahāna sampadā dutiya padena sacca paṭivedha tthena  ca sugata saddena pakāsitāḥ honti ānubhāva sampadā pana tatiya padena rūpa kāya sampadā
translated: his cause is the great compassion, which is shown by the first phrase. His fruit is fourfold as the fulfilment of knowledge, the fulfilment of abandoning,🔽the fulfilment of influence, and the fulfilment of the material body. Of these, the fulfilment of knowledge and the fulfilment of abandoning are revealed by the word “well-farer” in the sense of penetration of the truths,🔽while the fulfilment of influence is revealed by the second phrase. The fulfilment of the material body is revealed by the word “well-farer” in the sense of the beauty of the Blessed One’s going,

original: yathāvuttakāyagamanasobhanatthena sugata-saddena lakkhaṇānubyañjanapāripūriyā vinā
analyzed: yathā vutta kāya gamana sobhana atthena sugata saddena lakkhaṇa anubyañjana pāripūriyā vinā
translated: but not by the fulfilment of the primary and secondary characteristics.

original: tadabhāvato. Upakāro anantaraṃ abāhiraṃ karitvā tividhayānamukhena vimuttidhammadesanā.
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ upakāraḥ anantaram abāhiram karitvā tividha yāna mukhena vimutti dhamma desanā
translated: His service is the teaching of the way to deliverance by the three-fold vehicle without making it external.

original: So sammāgadanatthena sugata-saddena pakāsito hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: so sammā gadana tthena sugata saddena pakāsitaḥ hoti iti veditabbam
translated: This should be understood as revealed by the word “well-farer” in the sense of right guidance.

original: Tattha “karuṇāsītalahadaya”nti etena sammāsambodhiyā mūlaṃ dasseti. Mahākaruṇāya
analyzed: tattha etena sammāsambodhiyāḥ mūlam dasseti mahā karuṇāya
translated: Herein, by the words “whose heart was sharpened by compassion” he shows the root of the Supreme Perfect Enlightenment.🔽

original: sañcoditamānaso hi bhagavā saṃsārapaṅkato sattānaṃ samuddharaṇatthaṃ katābhinīhāro
analyzed: sañcodita mānasaḥ hi bhagavā saṃsāra paṅkataḥ sattānam samuddharaṇa attham kata abhinīhāraḥ
translated: Herein, by the words “whose heart was drenched with the moisture of compassion” he shows the root of the supreme perfect enlightenment. For the Blessed One, his mind urged on by great compassion, made his aspiration for the purpose of rescuing beings from the mire of saṃsāra,

original: anupubbena pāramiyo pūretvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ adhigatoti karuṇā sammāsambodhiyā
analyzed: anupubbena pāramiyaḥ pūretvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim adhigataḥ iti karuṇā sammāsambodhiyā
translated: and in due course, fulfilling the pāramīs, he reached the supreme perfect enlightenment. So compassion is the root of the supreme perfect enlightenment.

original: mūlaṃ. “Paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti etena sammāsambodhiṃ dasseti. Anāvaraṇañāṇapadaṭṭhānañhi
analyzed: mūlam etena sammāsambodhim dasseti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam hi
translated: By the words “whose darkness was dispelled by the light of wisdom” he shows the supreme perfect enlightenment. For the knowledge of the path is based on unobstructed knowledge,

original: maggañāṇaṃ, maggañāṇapadaṭṭhānañca anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ sammāsambodhīti vuccatīti. Sammāgamanatthena🔽sugata-saddena sammāsambodhiyā paṭipattiṃ dasseti līnuddhaccapatiṭṭhānāyūhanakāmasukhallikattakilamathānuyoga-sassatucchedābhinivesādi-antadvayarahitāya
analyzed: magga ñāṇam magga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam ca anāvaraṇa ñāṇam sammāsambodhī iti vuccati iti sammāgamana tthena  sugata saddena sammāsambodhiyā paṭipattim dasseti līn uddhacca patiṭṭhāna āyūhana kāma su khalli katta kilamatha anuyoga sassatu cheda abhinivesa ādi anta dvaya rahitāya
translated: and unobstructed knowledge is based on the knowledge of the path. This is called the supreme perfect enlightenment.🔽By the word “well-gone” he shows the practice for the supreme perfect enlightenment, which is the middle practice free from the two extremes of indulgence in sensual pleasure and self-mortification, free from the two extremes of eternalism and annihilationism, and embraced by compassion and wisdom.

original: karuṇāpaññāpariggahitāya majjhimāya paṭipattiyā pakāsanato sugata-saddassa. Itarehi
analyzed: karuṇā paññā pariggahitāya majjhimāya paṭipattiyā pakāsanato sugata saddassa itarehi
translated: The word “well-gone” is used because it shows the middle practice.

original: sammāsambodhiyā padhānāppadhānabhedaṃ payojanaṃ dasseti. Saṃsāramahoghato sattasantāraṇañhettha
analyzed: sammāsambodhiyā padhāna appadhāna bhedam payojanam dasseti saṃsāra mahoghato satta santāraṇam ha ittha
translated: He shows the difference between striving and striving well, and the purpose of each. The purpose of striving is to rescue beings from the great flood of saṃsāra.

original: padhānaṃ payojanaṃ, tadaññamappadhānaṃ. Tesu padhānena parahitapaṭipattiṃ dasseti,🔽itarena attahitasampattiṃ, tadubhayena attahitāya paṭipannādīsu catūsu puggalesu
analyzed: padhānam payojanam tad aññam appadhānam tesu padhānena para hita paṭipattim dasseti  itarena atta hita sampattim tad ubhayena atta hitāya paṭipanna ādīsu catūsu puggalesu
translated: The purpose of striving well is the opposite of that. By the former he shows the practice of benefitting others,🔽by the latter the attainment of one’s own benefit. By both he shows that the Exalted One is the fourth kind of person among those who practice for the benefit of others,

original: bhagavato catutthapuggalabhāvaṃ dasseti. Tena ca anuttaradakkhiṇeyyabhāvaṃ, uttamavandanīyabhāvaṃ,
analyzed: bhagavato catuttha puggala bhāvam dasseti tena ca anuttara dakkhiṇeyya bhāvam uttama vandanīya bhāvam
translated: and that he is worthy of the highest offerings, worthy of the highest veneration.

original: attano ca vandanakiriyāya khettaṅgatabhāvaṃ dasseti.🔽Ettha ca karuṇāgahaṇena lokiyesu mahaggatabhāvappattāsādhāraṇaguṇadīpanato bhagavato
analyzed: attano ca vandana kiriyāya khettaṅgata bhāvam dasseti  ettha ca karuṇā gahaṇena lokiyesu mahaggata bhāva ppatta asādhāraṇa guṇa dīpanataḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: And he shows that he himself is a field of merit for the act of veneration.

original: sabbalokiyaguṇasampatti dassitā hoti, paññāgahaṇena sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānamaggañāṇadīpanato
analyzed: sabba lokiya guṇa sampatti dassitā hoti paññā gahaṇena sabbaññuta ññāṇa padaṭṭhāna magga ñāṇa dīpanato
translated: And here, by mentioning compassion, he shows the Exalted One’s perfection in all mundane virtues, since it reveals his uncommon qualities that are attained in the course of reaching the heights of the mundane. By mentioning wisdom, he shows the perfection of all supramundane virtues, since it reveals the path knowledge that is based on the knowledge of omniscience.

original: sabbalokuttaraguṇasampatti. Tadubhayaggahaṇasiddho hi attho “sanarāmaralokagaru”ntiādinā
analyzed: tad ubhaya ggahaṇa siddhaḥ hi atthaḥ sa nara amara loka garunti ādinā
translated: For the meaning established by the mention of both is shown by the words “honored by gods and men.”

original: vipañcīyatīti. Karuṇāgahaṇena ca upagamanaṃ nirupakkilesaṃ dasseti, paññāgahaṇena
analyzed: vipañcīyati iti karuṇā gahaṇena ca upagamanam nirupakkilesam dasseti paññā gahaṇena
translated: and it is extended. And by the mention of compassion he shows the Blessed One’s approach without defilement, and by the mention of understanding he shows his departure.

original: apagamanaṃ. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena lokasamaññānurūpaṃ bhagavato pavattiṃ dasseti lokavohāravisayattā
analyzed: apagamanam tathā karuṇā gahaṇena loka samaññā anurūpam bhagavato pavattim dasseti loka vohāra visaya ttā
translated: And likewise by the mention of compassion he shows the Blessed One’s occurrence in conformity with the world’s designation, since compassion is the province of worldly usage,

original: karuṇāya, paññāgahaṇena samaññāya anatidhāvanaṃ. Sabhāvānavabodhena hi dhammānaṃ
analyzed: karuṇāya paññā gahaṇena samaññāya an atidhāvanam sabhāva an avabodhena hi dhammānam
translated: and by the mention of understanding he shows that he does not outrun the designation, for it is by not understanding the individual essences of states that one outruns the designation and misapprehends such things as a being.

original: samaññaṃ atidhāvitvā sattādiparāmasanaṃ hotīti. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena mahākaruṇāsamāpattivihāraṃ
analyzed: samaññam atidhāvitvā sattā ādi parāmasanam hoti iti tathā karuṇā gahaṇena mahākaruṇā samāpatti vihāram
translated: And likewise by the mention of compassion he shows the Blessed One’s abiding in the attainment of great compassion,

original: dasseti, paññāgahaṇena tīsu kālesu appaṭihatañāṇaṃ catusaccañāṇaṃ catupaṭisambhidāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: dasseti paññā gahaṇena tīsu kālesu appaṭihata ñāṇam catu sacca ñāṇam catu paṭisambhidā ñāṇam
translated: and by the mention of understanding he shows the knowledge unobstructed as to the three periods of time, the knowledge of the four truths, the knowledge of the four discriminations,

original: catuvesārajjañāṇaṃ, karuṇāgahaṇena mahākaruṇāsamāpattiñāṇassa gahitattā sesādhāraṇañāṇāni
analyzed: catu vesārajja ñāṇam karuṇā gahaṇena mahākaruṇā samāpatti ñāṇassa gahita ttā sesa ādhāraṇa ñāṇāni
translated: and the knowledge of the four kinds of intrepidity, since the knowledge of the attainment of great compassion is included by the mention of compassion.

original: cha abhiññā aṭṭhasu parisāsu akampanañāṇāni dasa balāni cuddasa buddhañāṇāni soḷasa
analyzed: cha abhiññāḥ aṭṭhasu parisāsu akampana ñāṇāni dasa balāni cuddasa buddha ñāṇāni soḷasa
translated: The other kinds of knowledge in common with disciples are the six kinds of direct-knowledge, the kinds of knowledge that are unshaken as to eight assemblies, the ten powers, the fourteen kinds of knowledge distinctive to a Buddha, the sixteen

original: ñāṇacariyā aṭṭhārasa buddhadhammā catucattālīsa ñāṇavatthūni sattasattati ñāṇavatthūnīti🔽evamādīnaṃ anekesaṃ paññāpabhedānaṃ vasena ñāṇacāraṃ dasseti. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena🔽caraṇasampattiṃ, paññāgahaṇena vijjāsampattiṃ. Karuṇāgahaṇena attādhipatitā, paññāgahaṇena
analyzed: ñāṇa cariyāḥ aṭṭhārasa buddha dhammā catucattālīsa ñāṇa vatthūni satta sattati ñāṇa vatthūni iti  evamādīnam anekesam paññā apabhedānam vasena ñāṇa cāram dasseti tathā karuṇā gahaṇena  caraṇa sampattim paññā gahaṇena vijjā sampattim karuṇā gahaṇena attā adhipati tā paññā gahaṇena
translated: He shows the way of knowledge by means of the many kinds of knowledge classed as the eighteen principal dhammas of a Buddha, the forty-four kinds of knowledge, the seventy-seven kinds of knowledge, and so on.

original: dhammādhipatitā. Karuṇāgahaṇena lokanāthabhāvo, paññāgahaṇena attanāthabhāvo. Tathā🔽karuṇāgahaṇena pubbakāribhāvo, paññāgahaṇena kataññutā. Karuṇāgahaṇena aparantapatā,🔽paññāgahaṇena anattantapatā. Karuṇāgahaṇena vā buddhakaradhammasiddhi, paññāgahaṇena
analyzed: dhamma adhipati tā karuṇā gahaṇena loka nātha bhāvo paññā gahaṇena atta nātha bhāvo tathā  karuṇā gahaṇena pubba kāri bhāvaḥ paññā gahaṇena kataññu tā karuṇā gahaṇena aparantapa tā  paññā gahaṇena anattantapa tā karuṇā gahaṇena vā buddha kara dhamma siddhi paññā gahaṇena
translated: Likewise, by the mention of compassion he shows the perfection of conduct, and by the mention of wisdom the perfection of clear vision. By the mention of compassion he shows the supremacy of self, and by the mention of wisdom the supremacy of the Dhamma. By the mention of compassion he shows the state of being a protector of the world, and by the mention of wisdom the state of being one’s own protector. Likewise,

original: buddhabhāvasiddhi. Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena paresaṃ tāraṇaṃ, paññāgahaṇena sayaṃ tāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tathā karuṇā gahaṇena paresam tāraṇam paññā gahaṇena sayam tāraṇam
translated: by the mention of compassion he shows the state of being a benefactor, and by the mention of wisdom the state of being grateful. By the mention of compassion he shows the state of being a benefactor in the future, and by the mention of wisdom the state of being a benefactor in the present. By the mention of compassion he shows the accomplishment of the requisites for Buddhahood, and by the mention of wisdom the accomplishment of Buddhahood. Likewise, by the mention of compassion he shows the state of being a deliverer of others, and by the mention of wisdom the state of being one’s own deliverer.

original: Tathā karuṇāgahaṇena sabbasattesu anuggahacittatā, paññāgahaṇena sabbadhammesu virattacittatā dassitā hoti.
analyzed: tathā karuṇā gahaṇena sabba sattesu anuggaha citta tā paññā gahaṇena sabba dhammesu viratta citta tā dassitā hoti
translated: Likewise, by the mention of compassion, the state of mind that is helpful to all beings is shown, and by the mention of wisdom, the state of mind that is detached from all things.

original: Sabbesañca buddhaguṇānaṃ karuṇā ādi tannidānabhāvato, paññā pariyosānaṃ tato uttari
analyzed: sabbesam ca buddha guṇānam karuṇā ādi tad nidāna bhāvato paññā pariyosānam tatas uttari
translated: And of all the Buddha-qualities, compassion is the beginning, since it is the cause of them, and wisdom is the end, since there is nothing further

original: karaṇīyābhāvato. Iti ādipariyosānadassanena sabbe buddhaguṇā dassitā honti. Tathā
analyzed: karaṇīya abhāvataḥ iti ādi pariyosāna dassanena sabbe buddha guṇāḥ dassitāḥ honti tathā
translated: beyond it that needs to be done. Thus by showing the beginning and the end, all the Buddha-qualities are shown. Likewise,

original: karuṇāgahaṇena sīlakkhandhapubbaṅgamo samādhikkhandho dassito hoti. Karuṇānidānañhi
analyzed: karuṇā gahaṇena sīla kkhandha pubbaṅgamaḥ samādhi khandho dassitaḥ hoti karuṇā nidānam hi
translated: by the mention of compassion, the concentration aggregate is shown, since it is preceded by the virtue aggregate. For virtue has compassion as its source,

original: sīlaṃ tato pāṇātipātādiviratippavattito, sā ca jhānattayasampayoginīti. Paññāvacanena
analyzed: sīlam tatas pāṇātipāta ādi virati ppavattito sā ca jhāna ttaya sampayoginī iti paññā vacanena
translated: since it occurs as abstention from killing living beings, etc., and that is associated with the three jhānas. By the mention of wisdom, the wisdom aggregate is shown.

original: paññākkhandho. Sīlañca sabbabuddhaguṇānaṃ ādi, samādhi majjhe, paññā pariyosānanti🔽evampi ādimajjhapariyosānakalyāṇadassanena sabbe buddhaguṇā dassitā honti nayato
analyzed: paññā kkhandho sīlañca sabba buddha guṇānaṃ ādi samādhi majjhe paññā pariyosānanti  evam pi ādi majjha pariyosāna kalyāṇa dassanena sabbe buddha guṇāḥ dassitāḥ honti nayataḥ
translated: And virtue is the beginning, concentration the middle, and wisdom the end of all the Buddha- qualities.🔽Thus by showing the good beginning, middle, and end, all the Buddha-qualities are shown. They are shown by implication,

original: dassitattā. Eso eva hi niravasesato buddhaguṇānaṃ dassanupāyo, yadidaṃ nayaggahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: dassita ttā esaḥ eva hi niravasesataḥ buddha guṇānam dassan upāyaḥ yat idam naya ggahaṇam
translated: for this is the only way of showing all the Buddha-qualities without exception, namely, by mentioning the implications.

original: aññathā ko nāma samattho bhagavato guṇe anupadaṃ niravasesato dassetuṃ. Tenevāha –
analyzed: aññathā kaḥ nāma samatthaḥ bhagavataḥ guṇe anupadam niravasesataḥ dassetum tena iva āha
translated: For who else is there able to describe the Blessed One’s special qualities in their entirety and without remainder? That is why it is said:

original: “Buddhopi buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇaṃ,
analyzed: buddhaḥ api buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇam
translated: Even if the Enlightened One were to speak in praise of the Enlightened One,

original: Kappampi ce aññamabhāsamāno;🔽Khīyetha kappo ciradīghamantare,
analyzed: kappam pi ce aññam a bhāsamāno  khīyetha cira dīgham antare
translated: And if he were to speak for an aeon,

original: Vaṇṇo na khīyetha tathāgatassā”ti. –
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ na khīyetha tathāgatassa ati
translated: The aeon would come to an end but the Enlightened One’s praise would not.

original: Teneva ca āyasmatā sāriputtattherenapi buddaguṇaparicchedanaṃ pati anuyuttena “no hetaṃ, bhante”ti paṭikkhipitvā “api ca me, bhante, dhammanvayo vidito”ti vuttaṃ.🔽2. Evaṃ saṅkhepena sakalasabbaññuguṇehi bhagavantaṃ abhitthavitvā idāni saddhammaṃ
analyzed: tena iva ca āyasmatā sāriputta therena api buddha guṇa paricchedanam anuyuttena no ha etam bhante iti paṭikkhipitvā api ca me bhante dhamma anvayaḥ viditaḥ iti vuttam  evam saṅkhepena sakala sabbaññu guṇehi bhagavantam abhitthavitvā idāni saddhammam
translated: That is why the venerable elder Sāriputta, who was devoted to the delimitation of the Blessed One’s special qualities, replied, “No, indeed, venerable sir,” and then said, “But, venerable sir, the method of the True Idea is known to me” .

original: thometuṃ “buddhopī”tiādimāha. Tattha buddhoti kattuniddeso. Buddhabhāvanti kammaniddeso.
analyzed: thometum buddhaḥ api iti ādim āha tattha buddhaḥ iti kattu niddesaḥ buddha bhāvanti kamma niddeso
translated: Having thus extolled the Blessed One in brief with all the special qualities of omniscience, he now said, “Even if the Enlightened One were to speak in praise of the Enlightened One,” in order to extol the True Idea. Herein, the Enlightened One is the nominative case of the verb to praise. The Enlightened One’s praise is the verbal action.

original: Bhāvetvā sacchikatvāti ca pubbakālakiriyāniddeso. Yanti aniyamato kammaniddeso. Upagatoti
analyzed: bhāvetvā sacchikatvā iti ca pubba kāla kiriyā niddesaḥ yanti aniyamataḥ kamma niddesaḥ upagataḥ ti
translated: Having realized, having made to occur, is the time of the action in the past. Even if is a nominative case of the verb to speak. Were to speak is the verbal action.

original: aparakālakiriyāniddeso. Vandeti kiriyāniddeso. Tanti niyamanaṃ. Dhammanti vandanakiriyāya
analyzed: apara kāla kiriyā niddeso vandeti kiriyā niddeso vandana kiriyāya
translated: This is the description of the time of the act. The word “worships” is the description of the act. The word “but” is a restrictive particle. The word “Dhamma” is the description of the action of worshipping.

original: kammaniddeso. Gatamalaṃ anuttaranti ca tabbisesanaṃ.
translated: The words “unsurpassed” and “glory” are its specification.

original: Tattha buddhasaddassa tāva – “bujjhitā saccānīti buddho, bodhetā pajāyāti buddho”tiādinā🔽niddesanayena attho veditabbo. Atha vā savāsanāya aññāṇaniddāya accantavigamato,
analyzed: tattha buddha saddassa tāva bujjhitā saccāni iti buddhaḥ pajāyāti buddha uti ādinā  niddesa nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ atha vā sa vāsanāya aññāṇa niddāya accanta vigamato
translated: Herein, as to the word “Buddha”: its meaning should be understood in the first place in the way stated in the Niddesa thus: “He is a Buddha because he has become awakened to the truths , he is a Buddha because he has awakened the people” .🔽Or alternatively, he is a Buddha because he has gone to the end of the destruction of all the sleep of ignorance together with the tendencies to it,

original: buddhiyā vā vikasitabhāvato buddhavāti buddho jāgaraṇavikasanatthavasena. Atha vā
analyzed: buddhiyā vā vikasita bhāvataḥ buddhavāti buddhaḥ jāgaraṇa vikasana attha vasena atha vā
translated: or because he has blossomed with the blossoming of understanding. Or alternatively,

original: kassacipi ñeyyadhammassa anavabuddhassa abhāvena ñeyyavisesassa kammabhāvena aggahaṇato🔽kammavacanicchāya abhāvena avagamanatthavaseneva kattuniddeso labbhatīti buddhavāti
analyzed: kassaci pi ñeyya dhammassa anavabuddhassa abhāvena ñeyya visesassa kamma bhāvena aggahaṇato  kamma vacanicchāya abhāvena avagamana attha vasena iva kattu niddesaḥ labbhati iti
translated: he is a Buddha because he has become awakened to the distinction of what is to be known that is not known by anyone else, since he has not taken up the state of being a doer by the function of a doer,

original: buddho yathā “dikkhito na dadātī”ti. Atthato pana pāramitāparibhāvito sayambhūñāṇena
analyzed: buddhaḥ yathā dikkhitaḥ na dadāti iti atthataḥ pana pāramitā paribhāvito sayambhu ñāṇena
translated: but only the state of being a knower by the function of knowing. Thus the nominative case is used in the sense of the instrumental case. He is a Buddha because he has become awakened in the way stated thus: “He does not give as one directed” . But in the sense of the meaning he is a Buddha because he has become awakened by self-evolved knowledge that is perfected by the perfections.

original: saha vāsanāya vihataviddhastaniravasesakileso mahākaruṇā sabbaññutaññāṇādiaparimeyyaguṇagaṇādhāro🔽khandhasantāno buddho. Yathāha – “buddhoti yo so bhagavā sayambhū anācariyako pubbe
analyzed: saha vāsanāya vihata viddhasta niravasesa kilesaḥ mahā karuṇā sabbaññu taññāṇa ādi aparimeyya guṇa gaṇa ādhāraḥ  khandha santānaḥ buddhaḥ yathā āha buddhaḥ ti yaḥ saḥ bhagavā sayambhu an ācariyako pubbe
translated: The term “Buddha” signifies the continuum of aggregates that has destroyed the taints together with their residues, that is, the continuum of aggregates that is the basis for the immeasurable qualities such as great compassion, omniscience, etc.

original: ananussutesu dhammesu sāmaṃ saccāni abhisambujjhi. Tattha ca sabbaññutaṃ patto balesu
analyzed: an anussutesu dhammesu sāmam saccāni abhisambujjhi tattha ca sabbaññu tam pattaḥ balesu
translated: As it is said: “‘Buddha’: he who is the Blessed One, the Self-becoming One, the One without a Teacher, who has awakened by himself to the truths that were not heard by others. Having attained omniscience in regard to those truths, he has gained mastery over all that is to be known.”

original: ca vasībhāva”nti. Api-saddo sambhāvane. Tena “evaṃ guṇavisesayutto sopi nāma bhagavā”ti🔽vakkhamānaguṇe dhamme sambhāvanaṃ dīpeti. Buddhabhāvanti sammāsambodhiṃ. Bhāvetvāti🔽uppādetvā vaḍḍhetvā ca. Sacchikatvāti paccakkhaṃ katvā. Upagatoti patto, adhigatoti
analyzed: ca api saddaḥ sambhāvane tena evam guṇa visesa yuttaḥ saḥ api nāma bhagavā iti  vakkhamāna guṇe dhamme sambhāvanam dīpeti buddha bhāvanti sammāsambodhim bhāvetvā ati  uppādetvā vaḍḍhetvā ca sacchikatvā ati paccakkham katvā upagataḥ ti pattaḥ adhigataḥ ti
translated: The word “also” expresses respect. It shows respect for the qualities that are about to be stated, indicating that “The Blessed One is endowed with such and such special qualities.”🔽The “state of a Buddha” is the supreme enlightenment. “Having developed” means having given rise to and having increased. “Having realized” means having made it manifest. “Has attained” means has reached, has achieved. The meaning is: “He has attained the state of a Buddha.”

original: attho. Etassa “buddhabhāva”nti etena sambandho. Gatamalanti vigatamalaṃ, niddosanti
analyzed: etassa buddha bhāvanti etena sambandhaḥ gata malanti vigata malam niddosanti
translated: “The taint-free” means the one who is free from taints. The meaning is: the one who is free from defilements.

original: attho. Vandeti paṇamāmi, thomemi vā. Anuttaranti uttararahitaṃ, lokuttaranti attho.
analyzed: attho vandeti paṇamāmi thomemi vā anuttaram ti uttara rahitam lokuttaram ti
translated: I pay homage, I bow down, I praise. “Unsurpassed” means free from what is higher, free from what is supramundane.

original: Dhammanti yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne apāyato saṃsārato ca apatamāne dhāretīti dhammo.
analyzed: dhammanti yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne apāyataḥ saṃsārataḥ ca a patamāne dhāreti iti dhammaḥ
translated: Dhamma: it bears up those who practice in accordance with the teaching from the states of loss and from saṃsāra, thus it is dhamma .

original: Ayañhettha saṅkhepattho – evaṃ vividhaguṇagaṇasamannāgato buddhopi bhagavā yaṃ ariyamaggasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: ayam ha ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ evam vividha guṇa gaṇa samannāgataḥ buddhaḥ api bhagavā yam ariya magga saṅkhātam
translated: The meaning of this verse in brief is as follows. The Blessed One, the Buddha, who is endowed with such a multitude of various special qualities,

original: dhammaṃ bhāvetvā phalanibbānasaṅkhātaṃ pana dhammaṃ sacchikatvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ🔽adhigato, tametaṃ buddhānampi buddhabhāvahetubhūtaṃ sabbadosamalarahitaṃ attano uttaritarābhāvena
analyzed: dhammam bhāvetvā phala nibbāna saṅkhātam pana dhammam sacchikatvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim  adhigataḥ tam etam buddhānam pi buddha bhāva hetu bhūtam sabba dosa mala rahitam attanaḥ uttaritara abhāvena
translated: having developed the Dhamma called the noble path, and having realized the Dhamma called the fruit of liberation,🔽attained the supreme perfect enlightenment. I pay homage to that supreme Dhamma of penetration, which is the cause of the Buddhas’ Buddhahood, which is free from all faults and blemishes, and which is supreme in the sense that there is no other Dhamma higher than it.

original: anuttaraṃ paṭivedhasaddhammaṃ namāmīti. Pariyattisaddhammassapi tappakāsanattā idha🔽saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Atha vā “abhidhammanayasamuddaṃ adhigacchi, tīṇi piṭakāni sammasī”ti
analyzed: anuttaram paṭivedha saddhammam namāmi iti pariyatti saddhammassa api tad pakāsana ttā idha  saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo atha vā abhidhamma naya samuddam adhigacchi tīṇi piṭakāni sammasi iti
translated: Since the Dhamma of the scriptures is also included here,🔽it should be regarded as included. Or else, since it is said in the commentary:🔽“He mastered the ocean of the Abhidhamma system, and he penetrated the three Piṭakas,”

original: ca aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttattā pariyattidhammassapi sacchikiriyasammasanapariyāyo labbhatīti
analyzed: ca aṭṭhakathā ayam vutta ttā pariyatti dhammassa api sacchikiriya sammasana pariyāyaḥ labbhati iti
translated: the Dhamma of the scriptures also has a mode of realization and penetration.

original: sopi idha vutto evāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ api idha vuttaḥ eva ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: Therefore it should be regarded as included here as well.

original: Tathā “yaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvetvā sacchikatvā”ti ca vuttattā buddhakaradhammabhūtāhi pāramitāhi
analyzed: tathā yam dhammam bhāvetvā sacchikatvā iti ca vutta ttā buddha kara dhamma bhūtāhi pāramitāhi
translated: And because it is said, “Having developed and realized the Dhamma,” the perfections are the Dhamma that leads to Buddhahood.

original: saha pubbabhāge adhisīlasikkhādayopi idha dhamma-saddena saṅgahitāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saha pubba bhāge adhi sīla sikkhā ādayaḥ pi idha dhamma saddena saṅgahitā iti veditabbam
translated: And since it is said, “having developed and realized the Dhamma,” it should be understood that the training in the higher virtue, etc., in the prior stage, which is the Dhamma that leads to Buddhahood, is also included here under the word “Dhamma.”

original: Tāpi hi malapaṭipakkhatāya gatamalā anaññasādhāraṇatāya anuttarā cāti. Tathā hi sattānaṃ
analyzed: tā api hi mala paṭipakkha tāya gata malā anañña sādhāraṇa tāya anuttarā ca ati tathā hi sattānam
translated: For these too are “stainless” in the sense of being the opposite of the stains of defilement, and “unsurpassed” in the sense of being not common to disciples.

original: sakalavaṭṭadukkhanissaraṇatthāya katamahābhinīhāro mahākaruṇādhivāsapesalajjhāsayo🔽paññāvisesaparidhotanimmalānaṃ dānadamasaññamādīnaṃ uttamadhammānaṃ satasahassādhikāni🔽kappānaṃ cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni sakkaccaṃ nirantaraṃ niravasesānaṃ bhāvanāpaccakkhakaraṇehi
analyzed: sakala vaṭṭa dukkha nissaraṇa atthāya kata mahā abhinīhāraḥ mahā karuṇā adhivāsa pesala jjhāsayaḥ  paññā visesa paridhota nimmalānam dāna dama saññama ādīnam uttama dhammānam sata sahassa adhikāni  kappānam cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni sakkaccam nirantaram niravasesānam bhāvanā paccakkha karaṇehi
translated: For this is how it is: the great aspiration made for the sake of the deliverance of all beings from the suffering of the entire round of rebirths, the disposition to be the host of great compassion,🔽the four incalculable aeons and a hundred thousand aeons besides, in which the unsurpassed Dhamma of giving, virtue, etc., purified by the special knowledge of the four noble truths, is carefully and uninterruptedly developed to the point of realization,🔽the mastery over action, etc., attained by the practice of the four foundations of mindfulness, etc., the wonderful, inconceivable, and mighty power,

original: kammādīsu adhigatavasibhāvo acchariyācinteyyamahānubhāvo adhisīlādhicittānaṃ paramukkaṃsapāramippatto
analyzed: kamma ādīsu adhigata vasi bhāvaḥ acchariya acinteyya mahā anubhāvaḥ adhi sīla adhicittānam param ukkaṃsa pārami ppatto
translated: the perfection of the perfection of virtue and the perfection of the perfection of concentration,

original: bhagavā paccayākāre catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassamukhena mahāvajirañāṇaṃ pesetvā anuttaraṃ
analyzed: bhagavā paccaya ākāre catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa mukhena mahā vajira ñāṇam pesetvā anuttaram
translated: The Blessed One, having sent forth the Great Diamond Knowledge with its two hundred and forty koṭis of methods,

original: sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti.
analyzed: sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ iti
translated: awakened to the Supreme Perfect Enlightenment.

original: Ettha ca “bhāvetvā”ti etena vijjāsampadāya dhammaṃ thometi, “sacchikatvā”ti etena
analyzed: ettha ca bhāvetvā iti etena vijjā sampadāya dhammam thometi sacchikatvā iti etena
translated: And here, by “having developed” he extols the Dhamma as the equipment of knowledge, and by “having realized” he extols it as the equipment of deliverance.🔽Or alternatively, by the first he extols it as the equipment of jhāna, and by the second as the equipment of the liberations.

original: vimuttisampadāya. Tathā paṭhamena jhānasampadāya, dutiyena vimokkhasampadāya. Paṭhamena🔽vā samādhisampadāya, dutiyena samāpattisampadāya. Atha vā paṭhamena khayeñāṇabhāvena,
analyzed: vimutti sampadāya tathā paṭhamena jhāna sampadāya dutiyena vimokkha sampadāya paṭhamena  vā samādhi sampadāya dutiyena samāpatti sampadāya atha vā paṭhamena khayeñāṇa bhāvena
translated: Or by the first he extols it as the equipment of concentration, and by the second as the equipment of attainment. Or the first shows the state of knowledge of destruction,

original: dutiyena anuppādeñāṇabhāvena. Purimena vā vijjūpamatāya, dutiyena vajirupamatāya.
analyzed: dutiyena anuppāde ñāṇa bhāvena purimena vā vijju upamatāya dutiyena vajiḥ upamatāya
translated: and the second the state of knowledge of non-arising. Or the first is like the simile of the flash of lightning, and the second is like the simile of the diamond.

original: Purimena vā virāgasampattiyā, dutiyena nirodhasampattiyā. Tathā paṭhamena niyyānabhāvena,
analyzed: purimena vā virāga sampattiyā dutiyena nirodha sampattiyā tathā paṭhamena niyyāna bhāvena
translated: Or the first is the accomplishment of fading away, and the second is the accomplishment of cessation. And the first shows the state of deliverance,

original: dutiyena nissaraṇabhāvena. Paṭhamena vā hetubhāvena, dutiyena asaṅkhatabhāvena. Paṭhamena
analyzed: dutiyena nissaraṇa bhāvena paṭhamena vā hetu bhāvena dutiyena asaṅkhata bhāvena paṭhamena
translated: and the second shows the state of escape. Or the first shows the state of cause, and the second shows the unformed element. Or the first shows the state of the path,🔽and the second shows the state of the fruit. Or the first shows the state of the supramundane, and the second shows the state of the mundane. Or the first shows the state of the noble person, and the second shows the state of the ordinary man. Or the first shows the state of the noble Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the Dhamma of the ordinary man. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non-Dhamma. Or the first shows the state of the Dhamma, and the second shows the state of the non

original: vā dassanabhāvena, dutiyena vivekabhāvena. Paṭhamena vā adhipatibhāvena, dutiyena🔽amatabhāvena dhammaṃ thometi. Atha vā “yaṃ dhammaṃ bhāvetvā buddhabhāvaṃ upagato”ti🔽etena svākkhātatāya dhammaṃ thometi, “sacchikatvā”ti etena sandiṭṭhikatāya. Tathā
analyzed: vā dassana bhāvena dutiyena viveka bhāvena paṭhamena vā adhipati bhāvena dutiyena  amata bhāvena dhammam thometi atha vā yam dhammam bhāvetvā buddha bhāvam upagataḥ iti  etena su ākkhāta tāya dhammam thometi sacchikatvā iti etena sandiṭṭhika tāya tathā
translated: or by the first in the sense of seeing, by the second in the sense of seclusion. Or by the first in the sense of predominance, by the second in the sense of deathlessness. Or he extols the Dhamma as well-proclaimed by the first in the sense of “having developed this Dhamma he reached Buddhahood,”

original: purimena akālikatāya, pacchimena ehipassikatāya. Purimena vā opaneyyikatāya, pacchimena🔽paccattaṃ veditabbatāya dhammaṃ thometi. “Gatamala”nti iminā saṃkilesābhāvadīpanena🔽dhammassa parisuddhataṃ dasseti. “Anuttara”nti etena aññassa visiṭṭhassa abhāvadīpanena
analyzed: purimena akālikatāya pacchimena ehipassikatāya purimena vā opaneyyikatāya pacchimena  paccattam veditabba tāya dhammam thometi gata malan ti iminā saṃkilesa abhāva dīpanena  dhammassa parisuddha tam dasseti anuttaran ti etena aññassa visiṭṭhassa abhāva dīpanena
translated: and by the second in the sense of “having realized it.” Likewise, by the first he extols the Dhamma as immediately effective, and by the second as timeless. Or by the first he extols the Dhamma as timeless, and by the second as inviting one to come and see for oneself. Or by the first he extols the Dhamma as leading onwards, and by the second as to be experienced for oneself.

original: vipulaparipuṇṇataṃ. Paṭhamena vā pahānasampadaṃ dhammassa dasseti, dutiyena sabhāvasampadaṃ.
analyzed: vipula paripuṇṇa tam paṭhamena vā pahāna sampadam dhammassa dasseti dutiyena sabhāva sampadam
translated: By the phrase “gone to the end of the world” he shows the Dhamma’s purity by revealing the absence of defilements. By the phrase “unsurpassed” he shows its greatness and fullness by revealing the absence of anything superior to it. Or by the first he shows the Dhamma’s excellence in abandoning, and by the second its excellence in its true nature.

original: Bhāvetabbatāya vā dhammassa gatamalabhāvo yojetabbo. Bhāvanābalena hi so dosānaṃ
analyzed: bhāvetabba tāya vā dhammassa gata mala bhāvaḥ yojetabbaḥ bhāvanā balena hi so dosānam
