original: gāthāya attho. Abhirūpeti uḷārarūpe sampannarūpe.🔽Kañcanasannibhattacatā suvaṇṇavaṇṇaggahaṇena gahitāti adhippāyenāha “chaviya”nti.
analyzed: gāthāya atthaḥ abhirūpā iti uḷāra rūpe sampanna rūpe  kañcana sannibha ttaca tā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇa ggahaṇena gahitā iti adhippāyena āha chaviyan ti
translated: With surpassing beauty: with a very high beauty, with a complete beauty.🔽Since the word “complexion” is included by the word “golden-coloured,” he said “complexion” with the intention of including it.

original: Chavigatā pana vaṇṇadhātu eva “suvaṇṇavaṇṇo”ti ettha vaṇṇaggahaṇena gahitāti apare.🔽Vaṇṇanaṃ kittiyā ugghosananti vaṇṇo, thuti. Vaṇṇīyati asaṅkarato vavatthapīyatīti
analyzed: chavi gatā pana vaṇṇa dhātu eva suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ ti ettha vaṇṇa ggahaṇena gahitā ati apare  vaṇṇanam kittiyāḥ ugghosananti vaṇṇo thuti vaṇṇīyati asaṅkarataḥ vavatthapīyati iti
translated: But others say that the “golden-coloured” is included by the word “complexion” in the sense of the “colour element in the complexion.”🔽“Praise” is the announcement of a person’s good qualities. “Complexion” is the announcement of a person’s good qualities without confusion,

original: vaṇṇo, kulavaggo. Vaṇṇīyati phalaṃ etena yathāsabhāvato vibhāvīyatīti vaṇṇo, kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ kula vaggaḥ vaṇṇīyati phalam etena yathā sabhāvataḥ vibhāvīyati iti vaṇṇaḥ kāraṇam
translated: or it is the announcement of a person’s good qualities by means of a class, or it is the announcement of a person’s good qualities by means of a cause.

original: Vaṇṇanaṃ dīgharassādivasena saṇṭhahananti vaṇṇo, saṇṭhānaṃ. Vaṇṇīyati aṇumahantādivasena
analyzed: vaṇṇanam dīgha rassa ādi vasena saṇṭhahananti vaṇṇo saṇṭhānam vaṇṇīyati aṇu mahanta ādi vasena
translated: “color” is measure, that is, the mode of being small, large, etc.;

original: pamīyatīti vaṇṇo, pamāṇaṃ. Vaṇṇeti vikāraṃ āpajjamānaṃ hadayaṅgatabhāvaṃ pakāsetīti🔽vaṇṇo, rūpāyatanaṃ. Evaṃ tena tena pavattinimittena vaṇṇasaddassa tasmiṃ tasmiṃ atthe🔽pavatti veditabbā. Iddhiṃ māpetvāti vatthālaṅkārakāyādīhi obhāsamuñcanādivasena dibbaṃ
analyzed: pamīyati iti vaṇṇaḥ pamāṇam vaṇṇeti vikāram āpajjamānam hadayaṅgata bhāvam pakāseti iti  vaṇṇaḥ rūpa āyatanam evam tena tena pavatti nimittena vaṇṇa saddassa tasmin tasmin atthe  veditabbā iddhim māpetvā ati vattha alaṅkāra kāya ādīhi obhāsa muñcana ādi vasena dibbam
translated: “color” is the visible-form base, that is, the mode of being manifest as change, which reveals the state of being in the heart;🔽thus the word “color” should be understood to occur in these various senses according to the different contexts in which it is used.🔽Having manifested psychic power: having created divine psychic power by means of the manifestation of the requisites, ornaments, body, etc., and by means of the emission of light, etc.

original: iddhānubhāvaṃ nimminitvā. Kāmāvacarā anabhisaṅkhatenapi āgantuṃ sakkonti oḷārikarūpattā.🔽Tathā hi te kabaḷīkārabhakkhā. Rūpāvacarā na sakkonti tato sukhumatararūpattā. Tenāha
analyzed: iddha anubhāvam nimminitvā kāmāvacarāḥ āgantum sakkonti oḷārika rūpa ttā  tathā hi te kabaḷīkāra bhakkhāḥ rūpāvacarāḥ na sakkonti tatas sukhumatara rūpa ttā tena āha
translated: The beings of the sense sphere are able to come there without being conceived, because their material form is gross.🔽For they feed on material food. The beings of the fine-material sphere are not able to come there, because their material form is more subtle. Therefore it is said:🔽“Their material form is too subtle” . Here he speaks with reference to the material form of the basic rebirth-linking.

original: “tesaṃ hī”tiādi. Tattha “atisukhumo”ti mūlapaṭisandhirūpaṃ sandhāya vadati. Na tena
analyzed: tesam hi itiādi tattha ati sukhumaḥ ti mūla paṭisandhi rūpam sandhāya vadati na tena
translated: By that they are not able to assume postures.

original: iriyāpathakappanaṃ hotīti etena brahmalokepi brahmāno yebhuyyena nimmitarūpeneva
analyzed: iriyāpatha kappanam hoti iti etena brahma loke pi brahmānaḥ yebhuyyena nimmita rūpena iva
translated: By this he shows that in the Brahma-world also the Brahmas are able to assume postures only by means of the created material form.

original: pavattantīti dasseti. Itarañhi ativiya sukhumaṃ rūpaṃ kevalaṃ cittuppādassa nissayādhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ
analyzed: pavattanti iti dasseti itarat hi ativiya sukhumam rūpam kevalam cittuppādassa nissaya adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: he shows that it is the materiality that occurs. For the other kind of materiality is extremely subtle. It is only the support and the basis for the arising of consciousness.

original: saṇṭhānavantaṃ hutvā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: saṇṭhānavantam hutvā tiṭṭhati
translated: It is present as shape.

original: Anavasesattaṃ sakalatā. Yebhuyyatā bahulabhāvo. Abyāmissatā vijātiyena asaṅkaro.
analyzed: anavasesa ttam sakala tā yebhuyya tā bahula bhāvaḥ a byāmissa tā vijātiyena asaṅkaraḥ
translated: “Without remainder” is all of it. “In the majority” is in the abundance. “Without admixture” is without confusion with what is unlike it.

original: Sukhena hi avokiṇṇatā tattha adhippetā. Anatirekatā taṃparamatā visesābhāvo. Kevalakappanti
analyzed: sukhena hi avokiṇṇa tā tattha adhippetā anatireka tā taṃparama tā visesa abhāvaḥ
translated: For what is intended here is that it is not interrupted by pleasure. “Without excess” is without distinction, without superiority. “In the absolute sense”

original: kevalaṃ daḷhaṃ katvāti attho. Saṅghabhedāyāti saṅghe vivādāya, vivāduppādāyāti attho.
analyzed: kevalam daḷham katvā ati saṅgha bhedāya ati saṅghe vivādāya vivāda uppādāya ati
translated: means “in the sense of being made solely strong.” “For the schism of the Order”: for the dispute in the Order; the meaning is, for the arising of the dispute.

original: Kevalaṃ vuccati nibbānaṃ sabbasaṅkhatavivittattā, etassa taṃ atthīti kevalī, sacchikatanirodho
analyzed: kevalam vuccati nibbānam sabba saṅkhata vivitta ttā etassa tam atthi iti kevalī sacchikata nirodhaḥ
translated: Only is said of Nibbāna because it is secluded from all formed things. He who has that is a “solitary one” . One whose cankers are destroyed has realized cessation.

original: khīṇāsavo. Tenāha “visaṃyogo attho”ti.🔽Kappasaddo panāyaṃ saupasaggo anupasaggo cāti adhippāyena okappaniyapade labbhamānaṃ
analyzed: khīṇa āsavaḥ tena āha visaṃyogaḥ attho ti  kappa saddo pana ayam sa upasaggaḥ an upasaggaḥ ca ati adhippāyena okappaniya pade labbhamānam
translated: He is “solitary” in the sense of isolation from the defilements.

original: kappasaddamattaṃ dasseti, aññathā kappapadaṃ anidassanameva siyā. Samaṇakappehīti
analyzed: kappa sadda mattam dasseti aññathā kappa padam a nidassanam eva siyā samaṇa kappehi iti
translated: The word “kappa” is used both with a prefix and without a prefix. He shows the mere word “kappa” as found in the phrase “okappaṇīya” with the intention of showing the meaning of “kappa” as a prefix. Otherwise the word “kappa” in the phrase “okappaṇīya” would not be shown. “In the sense of a recluse”

original: vinayasiddhehi samaṇavohārehi. Niccakappanti niccakālaṃ. Paññattīti nāmaṃ. Nāmañhetaṃ🔽tassa āyasmato, yadidaṃ kappoti. Kappitakesamassūti kattarikāya cheditakesamassu.
analyzed: vinaya siddhehi samaṇa vohārehi niccakappanti niccakālam paññattī iti nāmam  tassa āyasmataḥ yat idam kappoti kappita kesa massu ati kattarikāya chedita kesa massu
translated: The word “always” means “at all times.” “The name” means the name.🔽This is the name of that venerable one, namely Kappa. “Having had his hair and beard shaved”: having had his hair and beard cut with a razor.

original: Dvaṅgulakappoti majjhanhikavelāya vītikkantāya dvaṅgulatāvikappo. Lesoti apadeso.
analyzed: dvaṅgula kappo ti majjhanhika velāya vītikkantāya dvaṅgula tā vikappaḥ lesaḥ ti apadesaḥ
translated: “Two fingerbreadths”: the measure of two fingerbreadths after midday. “The rest”: the place.

original: Anavasesaṃ pharituṃ samatthassapi obhāsassa kenacipi kāraṇena ekadesapharaṇampi siyā,
analyzed: anavasesam pharitum samatthassa api obhāsassa kenacipi kāraṇena eka desa pharaṇam pi siyā
translated: Even one who is able to illuminate without remainder may illuminate only a part for some reason,

original: ayaṃ pana sabbasova pharatīti dassetuṃ samantattho kappa-saddo gahitoti āha “anavasesaṃ
analyzed: ayam pana sabbaso va pharati iti dassetum samanta atthaḥ kappa saddaḥ gahitaḥ ti āha anavasesam
translated: but this one illuminates all, without remainder. In order to show this, the word kappa is taken in the sense of “all around.” Therefore he says, “without remainder,🔽all around.” “The rest”: the remainder, the whole, or the whole only.

original: samantato”ti. Īsaṃ asamattaṃ, kevalaṃ vā kevalakappaṃ. Bhagavato ābhāya anobhāsitameva
analyzed: samantataḥ ti īsam a samattam kevalam vā kevala kappam bhagavataḥ ābhāya anaḥ bhāsitam eva
translated: For the place that is not illuminated by the Blessed One’s radiance,

original: hi padesaṃ devatā attano pabhāya obhāsenti. Na hi bhagavato pabhā kāyaci pabhāya
analyzed: hi padesam devatāḥ attanaḥ pabhāya obhāsenti na hi bhagavataḥ pabhā kāyaci pabhāya
translated: the deities illuminate with their own radiance. For the radiance of the Blessed One

original: abhibhuyyati, sūriyādīnampi pabhaṃ sā abhibhuyya tiṭṭhatīti.
analyzed: sūriya ādīnam pi pabham sā abhibhuyya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: is not surpassed by any radiance, and it stands surpassing even the radiance of the sun and so on.

original: Yena vā kāraṇenāti hetumhi idaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Hetuattho hi kiriyāya kāraṇaṃ, na
analyzed: yena vā kāraṇena ati hetumhi idam karaṇa vacanam hetu atthaḥ hi kiriyāya kāraṇam na
translated: “For what reason?” This is a locative case in the sense of cause. For the meaning of “cause” is the reason for an action, not

original: karaṇaṃ viya kiriyattho, tasmā nānappakāra-guṇavisesādhigamanatthā idha upasaṅkamanakiriyāti
analyzed: karaṇam viya tasmā nānā pakāra guṇa visesa adhigamana tthā idha upasaṅkamana kiriyā ti
translated: the meaning of an instrument, as in the case of the locative case in the sense of instrument. Therefore, the action of approaching here is for the purpose of attaining various kinds of special qualities.🔽Thus, just as in the case of the locative case in the sense of cause in such expressions as “he dwells with food,” “he dwells with knowledge,”

original: “annena vasati, vijjāya vasatī”tiādīsu viya hetuatthameva taṃ karaṇavacanaṃ yuttaṃ
analyzed: annena vasati vijjāya vasati itiādīsu hetu attham eva tam karaṇa vacanam yuttam
translated: it is appropriate for that locative case to have the meaning of cause,

original: na karaṇatthaṃ tassa ayujjamānattāti vuttaṃ “yena vā kāraṇenā”tiādi. Bhagavato satatappavattaniratisaya-sāduvipulamatarasa-saddhammaphalatāya🔽sāduphalaniccaphalitamahārukkhena bhagavā upamito. Sāduphalūpabhogādhippāyaggahaṇeneva
analyzed: na karaṇa attham tassa ayujjamāna ttā ti vuttam yena vā kāraṇena atiādi bhagavato satata ppavatta nirati saya sādu vipula mata rasa saddhamma phala tāya  sādu phala nicca phalita mahā rukkhena bhagavā upamitaḥ sādu phala upabhoga adhippāya ggahaṇena iva
translated: not the meaning of instrument, because the latter is inappropriate. Therefore it is said “for what reason?” and so on. The Blessed One is compared to a great tree with sweet fruits that are always available, delightful, excellent, abundant, and of many flavors,🔽because of the sweetness of the fruit of the Blessed One’s true Dhamma, which is always available, delightful, excellent, abundant, and of many flavors.🔽For by mentioning the enjoyment of sweet fruits,

original: hi mahākāruṇikassa sāduphalatā gahitāti. Upasaṅkamīti upasaṅkantā. Sampattakāmatāya
analyzed: hi mahā kāruṇikassa sādu phala tā gahitā ati upasaṅkamīti upasaṅkantā sampatta kāma tāya
translated: the sweetness of the fruit of the one of great compassion is included.🔽“Approached” means approached, gone. For one who is going to a certain place with the desire to reach it,

original: hi kiñci ṭhānaṃ gacchanto taṃtaṃpadesātikkamanena upasaṅkami, upasaṅkantoti vattabbataṃ
analyzed: hi kiñci ṭhānam gacchanto tad tad padesa atikkamanena upasaṅkami upasaṅkanto ti vattabba tam
translated: by the act of passing beyond each place, he approaches, and it is proper to say he has approached.

original: labhati. Tenāha “gatāti vuttaṃ hotī”ti, upagatāti attho. Upasaṅkamitvāti pubbakālakiriyāniddesoti
analyzed: labhati tena āha gatā iti vuttam hoti iti upagatā ati atthaḥ upasaṅkamitvā iti pubba kāla kiriyā niddeso ti
translated: He says, “The meaning of ‘approached’ is expressed by the word ‘went.’ ”🔽“Having approached” is the description of the action in the previous time.🔽“The word ‘approached’ shows the end of the action of approaching.”

original: āha “upasaṅkamanapariyosānadīpana”nti. Tatoti yaṃ ṭhānaṃ pattā “upasaṅkamī”ti vuttā,
analyzed: āha upasaṅkamana pariyosāna dīpanam ti tatas ti yam ṭhānam pattā upasaṅkamīti vuttā
translated: “From there” is the place where she went after approaching.

original: tato upagataṭṭhānato.
analyzed: tatas upagata ṭṭhānataḥ
translated: “From that place where she approached.”

original: Gatinivattiatthato sāmaññato āsanampi ṭhānaggahaṇena gayhatīti vuttaṃ “āsanakusalatāya
analyzed: gati nivatti atthataḥ sāmaññataḥ āsanam pi ṭhāna ggahaṇena gayhati iti vuttam āsana kusala tāya
translated: “Because of the meaning of ‘returning from the destination’ and because of the similarity, the seat is also included by the word ‘place.’ ”🔽“Because of skill in seats” is said.

original: ekamantaṃ tiṭṭhantī”ti. Nisinnāpi hi gamanato nivattā nāma honti ṭhatvā nisīditabbattā,
analyzed: ekamantam tiṭṭhanti iti nisinnā api hi gamanataḥ nivattāḥ nāma honti ṭhatvā nisīditabbattā
translated: “Standing at one side” is said. Even though they were sitting, they were returning from the destination because they had to sit down after standing up.🔽The place mentioned and so on are also included by the word “seat.”

original: yathāvuttaṭṭhānādayopi āsaneneva saṅgahitāti. Atidūraaccāsannapaṭikkhepena nātidūranaccāsannaṃ
analyzed: yathā vutta ṭṭhāna ādayaḥ api āsanena iva saṅgahitā ati atidūra acca āsanna paṭikkhepena na atidūra nacca āsannam
translated: “Not too far and not too near” is said by the exclusion of too far and too near.

original: nāma gahitaṃ. Taṃ pana avakaṃsato ubhinnaṃ pasāritahatthasaṅghaṭṭanena daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Gīvaṃ pasāretvāti gīvaṃ parivattanavasena pasāretvā.
analyzed: nāma gahitam tam pana avakaṃsataḥ ubhinnam pasārita hattha saṅghaṭṭanena daṭṭhabbam  gīvam pasāretvā iti gīvam parivattana vasena pasāretvā
translated: But that should be seen by the contact of the outstretched hands of both.🔽“Having stretched out her neck” is said by the turning of the neck.

original: Kāmaṃ “katha”nti ayamākārapucchā, taraṇākāro idha pucchito. So pana taraṇākāro atthato
analyzed: kāmam kathanti ayam ākāra pucchā taraṇa ākāro idha pucchito saḥ pana taraṇa ākāraḥ atthato
translated: “How?” is a question about the mode. The mode of crossing is asked about here. But that mode of crossing is seen in the meaning of “having crossed.”

original: kāraṇamevāti āha “kathaṃ nūti kāraṇapucchā”ti? Pākaṭo abhisambodhiyaṃ mahāpathavīkampanādianekacchariyapātubhāvādinā.🔽Marisanaṭṭhena pāpānaṃ rogādianatthānaṃ abhibhavanaṭṭhena māriso, dukkharahito. Tenāha
analyzed: kāraṇam eva iti āha katham nu iti kāraṇa pucchā ati pākaṭaḥ mahā pathavī kampana ādi aneka chariya pātubhāva ādinā  marisana ṭṭhena pāpānam roga ādi anatthānam abhibhavana ṭṭhena mārisaḥ dukkha rahitaḥ tena āha
translated: The earth’s trembling at the time of enlightenment, the manifestation of the various kinds of supernormal power, etc., were evident to the people.🔽The word “hero” is derived from the word for “evil” , and it is a hero because it overcomes evil, that is, the various kinds of misfortune such as sickness, etc. It is free from suffering. Hence he says:🔽“What is meant is free from suffering.”

original: “niddukkhāti vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Nirayapakkhe piyālapanavacanavasena upacāravacanañcetaṃ
analyzed: niddukkhā iti vuttam hoti iti niraya pakkhe piyā lapana vacana vasena upacāra vacanam ca itam
translated: This is a figurative expression in the sense of “speaking affectionately” in the context of hell.🔽“Beloved of the gods” is like “beloved of the gods.” Therefore he says “if only,” etc.

original: yathā “devānaṃ piyā”ti. Tenevāha “yadi eva”ntiādi. Saṅkunā saṅkūti matthakato samakoṭṭitena🔽yāva hadayapadesā nibbijjhitvā otiṇṇena saṅkunā pādatalato samakoṭṭito saṅku nibbijjhitvā
analyzed: yathā tena iva āha yadi evantiādi saṅkunā saṅkūti matthakato sama koṭṭitena  yāva hadaya padesāḥ nibbijjhitvā otiṇṇena saṅkunā pāda talataḥ sama koṭṭitaḥ saṅku nibbijjhitvā
translated: A spike is a spike that is struck down from the top.🔽It pierces down to the heart. A spike struck down from the bottom pierces up to the heart.

original: ārohanto hadaye hadayassa padese samāgaccheyya, atha nesaṃ saṅkūnaṃ samāgamasamakāle
analyzed: ārohantaḥ hadaye hadayassa padese samāgaccheyya atha nesam saṅkūnam samāgama sama kāle
translated: If the two spikes were to meet at the heart,

original: naṃ yathātikkantasaṅkukaraṇakālaṃ jāneyyāsi. Kiñci nimittaṃ upādāya kismiñci atthe
analyzed: nam yathā atikkanta saṅku karaṇa kālam jāneyyāsi kiñci nimittam upādāya kismiñci atthe
translated: you would know the time when the spikes had passed through. Taking some sign as a basis, in some matter

original: pavattassa saddassa tannimittarahite pavatti ruḷhī nāma gamanakiriyārahite sāsanādimati
analyzed: pavattassa saddassa tad nimitta rahite pavatti ruḷhī nāma gamana kiriyā rahite sāsana ādimati
translated: The occurrence of a sound in the absence of its cause is called “disappearance” .

original: paṭipiṇḍe yathā gosaddassa.🔽Oghamatarīti yesaṃ oghānaṃ taraṇaṃ pucchitaṃ, te gaṇanaparicchedato sarūpato ca dassetuṃ
analyzed: paṭipiṇḍe yathā gosaddassa  yesam oghānam taraṇam pucchitam te gaṇana paricchedato sarūpataḥ ca dassetuṃ
translated: In the case of a reply, it is like the sound of a cow.🔽As to “the four floods”: the four floods whose surmounting is asked about are shown by the number and the individual essence in the words “Four floods” and so on.

original: “cattāro”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kasmā panettha cattāro eva oghā vuttā, te ca kāmādayo evāti?
analyzed: cattāraḥ tiādi vuttam kasmā pana ittha cattāraḥ eva oghāḥ vuttā te ca kāma ādayaḥ eva ati
translated: But why are only four floods stated, and why are they stated as craving for sensual desires and so on?

original: Na codetabbametaṃ, yasmā dhammānaṃ sabhāvakiccavisesaññunā bhagavatā sabbaṃ ñeyyaṃ🔽yāthāvato abhisambujjhitvā ettakāva oghā desitā, ime eva ca desitāti. Vaṭṭasmiṃ ohananti🔽osīdāpentīti oghā, ohananti heṭṭhā katvā hananti gāmenti, tathābhūtā satte adho gāmenti
analyzed: na codetabbam etam yasmā dhammānam sabhāva kicca visesaññunā bhagavatā sabbam ñeyyam  yāthāvataḥ abhisambujjhitvā oghāḥ desitāḥ ime eva ca desitā ati vaṭṭasmin ohananti  osīda apenti iti oghāḥ ohananti heṭṭhā katvā hananti gāmenti tathābhūtā satte adhas
translated: This should not be pressed, since the Blessed One, who knows the specific characteristics of things, has fully awakened to all that is to be known🔽and has taught just this many floods and has taught them in this way.🔽They flow in the round of rebirths,

original: nāma. Ayañca attho “sabbopi cesā”tiādinā parato aṭṭhakathāyameva āgamissati. Kāmanaṭṭhena
analyzed: nāma ayam ca attho sabbaḥ api ca isa ati ādinā paratas aṭṭhakathāyam eva āgamissati kāmanaṭṭhena
translated: they cause beings to flow downwards, to sink down, to go down, to be destroyed, to be lost, to be annihilated, to be consumed, to be burnt up, to be done away with, to be abolished, to be scattered, to be destroyed, to be vanquished, to be overthrown, to be swallowed up, to be lost, to be ruined, to be annihilated, to be burnt out, to be extinguished, to be dried up, to be dried out, to be finished, to be done for, to be gone, to be departed, to be lost, to be vanished, to be ended, to be concluded, to be completed, to be fulfilled, to be exhausted, to be destroyed, to be scattered, to be destroyed, to be vanquished, to be overthrown, to be swallowed up, to be lost, to be ruined, to be annihilated, to be burnt out, to be extinguished, to be dried up, to be dried out, to be finished, to be done for, to be gone, to be departed, to be lost, to be vanished, to be ended, to be concluded, to be completed, to be fulfilled, to be exhausted, to be destroyed, to be scattered, to be destroyed, to be vanquished, to be overthrown, to be swallowed up, to be lost, to be ruined, to be annihilated, to be burnt out, to be extinguished, to be dried up, to be dried out, to be finished, to be done for, to be gone, to be departed, to be lost, to be vanished, to be ended, to be concluded, to be completed, to be fulfilled, to be exhausted, to be destroyed, to be scattered, to be destroyed, to be

original: kāmo, kāmo ca so yathāvuttenatthena ogho cāti, kāmesu oghoti vā kāmogho. Bhavogho
analyzed: kāmo kāmo ca so yathāvuttena atthena ogho ca ati kāmesu ogho iti vā kāma oghaḥ bhava oghaḥ
translated: and it is a flood in the way already stated. Or alternatively, it is a flood in the case of sense desires, thus it is the flood of sense desires.

original: nāma bhavarāgoti dassetuṃ “rūpārūpabhavesu chandarāgo jhānanikanti cā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Sumaṅgalavilāsinīādīsu pana “sassatadiṭṭhisahagatarāgo cā”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha paṭhamo
analyzed: nāma bhava rāgaḥ ti dassetum rūpa arūpa bhavesu chanda rāgaḥ jhāna nikanti ca ati vuttam  sumaṅgala vilāsinī ādīsu pana sassata diṭṭhi sahagata rāgaḥ ca ati vuttam tattha paṭhamaḥ
translated: The flood of becoming is called the “lust for becoming” in order to show that it is the craving for the becoming consisting in the kinds of existence in the fine-material and immaterial spheres.

original: upapattibhavesu rāgo, dutiyo kammabhave. Bhavadiṭṭhivinimuttassa diṭṭhigatassa abhāvato.🔽“Dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhiyo diṭṭhogho”ti vuttaṃ, catusaccantogadhattā sabbassa ñeyyassa “catūsu
analyzed: upapatti bhavesu rāgaḥ dutiyaḥ kamma bhave bhava diṭṭhi vinimuttassa diṭṭhi gatassa abhāvato  dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭha oghaḥ ti vuttam sabbassa ñeyyassa catūsu
translated: But in the Sumaṅgala-vilāsinī, etc., it is said to be the lust associated with the eternalist view . Herein, the first is lust for the kinds of existence in rebirth-process becoming, and the second is lust for the kinds of existence in kamma-process becoming.🔽Because one who is free from the view of becoming is devoid of the perversions of view.🔽The sixty-two views are called the flood of views because they are scattered about in the four noble truths.

original: saccesu aññāṇaṃ avijjogho”ti āha.🔽Idāni tesaṃ oghasaṅkhātānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ uppattiṭṭhānaṃ dassetuṃ “tatthā”tiādi vuttaṃ,
analyzed: saccesu aññāṇam avijjogho ti āha  idāni tesam ogha saṅkhātānam pāpa dhammānam uppatti ṭṭhānam dassetum tattha atiādi vuttaṃ
translated: The ignorance about the four truths is called the flood of ignorance because it is scattered about in all that is to be known.🔽Now, in order to show the source of these states of vice called floods, it is said, “Herein, what is the flood of sensuality? Sensual desire for the five kinds of sensual pleasure” .

original: pavattiṭṭhānaṃ pana kāmaguṇādayo dassitā eva. “Pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chandarāgo kāmogho”ti
analyzed: pavatti ṭṭhānam pana kāmaguṇa ādayaḥ dassitāḥ eva pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chanda rāgo kāmogho ti
translated: The source of the flood of sensuality is shown by the words “sensual desire for the five kinds of sensual pleasure.”

original: ettha bhavoghaṃ ṭhapetvā sabbo lobho kāmoghoti yuttaṃ siyā. Sassatadiṭṭhisahagato
analyzed: ettha bhava ogham ṭhapetvā sabbaḥ lobho kāma oghaḥ ti yuttam siyā sassata diṭṭhi sahagato
translated: Herein, it is proper to say that all greed is the flood of sensuality except the flood of existence.

original: rāgo bhavadiṭṭhisampayuttattā bhavoghoti aṭṭhakathāsu vutto, bhavogho pana diṭṭhigatavippayuttesu
analyzed: rāgaḥ bhava diṭṭhi sampayutta ttā bhava oghaḥ ti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaḥ bhava oghaḥ pana diṭṭhi gata vippayuttesu
translated: The greed associated with the eternalist view is called the flood of existence in the Commentaries because it is associated with the view of existence. But the flood of existence arises only in the kinds of consciousness that are dissociated from the false view of individuality, etc.,

original: eva uppajjatīti pāḷiyaṃ vutto. Tenevāha – “bhavogho catūsu diṭṭhivippayuttalobhasahagatacittuppādesu🔽uppajjatī”ti. Tasmā diṭṭhisahagatalobhopi kāmoghoti yuttaṃ siyā. Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikadukkhānañhi
analyzed: eva uppajjati iti pāḷiyam vutto tena iva āha bhava ogho catūsu diṭṭhi vippayutta lobha sahagata cittuppādesu  uppajjati iti tasmā diṭṭhi sahagata lobhaḥ api kāmoghaḥ ti yuttam siyā diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika dukkhānam hi
translated: as stated in the text. Therefore it is said: “The flood of existence arises in the four kinds of consciousness associated with greed that are dissociated from the false views” .🔽So it is proper to say that the greed associated with the false views is the flood of sensuality. For the cankers of sensuality, etc., which are the cause of suffering in this life and the life to come, are also stated in two ways, and the cankers are the floods.

original: kāraṇabhūtā kāmāsavādayopi dvidhā vuttā, āsavā eva ca oghā. Kāmāsavaniddese ca kāmesūti
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtā kāma āsava ādayaḥ api dvidhā vuttā āsavāḥ eva ca oghā kāma āsava niddese ca kāmesu iti
translated: And in the description of the canker of sensuality, the words “in the sense-desire element”

original: kāmarāgadiṭṭhirāgādīnaṃ ārammaṇabhūtesu tebhūmakesu vatthukāmesūti attho sambhavati.
analyzed: kāma rāga diṭṭhi rāga ādīnam ārammaṇa bhūtesu tebhūmakesu vatthu kāmesu iti atthaḥ sambhavati
translated: can be taken to mean “in the sense desires of the three planes that are the objects of the lust for sense desires and the lust for existence.”

original: Tattha hi uppajjamānā sāyaṃ taṇhā sabbāpi na kāmacchandādināmaṃ na labhatīti.
analyzed: tattha hi uppajjamānā sāyam taṇhā sabbā api na kāmacchanda ādi nāmam na labhati iti
translated: For all craving that arises there does not get the name “lust for sense desires,” etc.

original: Yadi pana pañcakāmaguṇiko ca rāgo kāmoghoti vuttoti katvā brahmānaṃ vimānādīsu rāgassa🔽diṭṭhirāgassa ca kāmoghabhāvo paṭisedhitabbo siyā, evaṃ sati kāmoghabhavoghavinimuttena
analyzed: yadi pana pañca kāma guṇiko ca rāgo kāmogho ti vutto ti katvā brahmānam vimāna ādīsu rāgassa  diṭṭhi rāgassa ca kāma ogha bhāvo paṭisedhitabbaḥ siyā evam sati kāma ogha bhava ogha vinimuttena
translated: But if it be argued that lust for the five strands of sensual desire is called the flood of sensual desire, and that therefore lust for the Brahmā-world and lust for views should be excluded from the flood of sensual desire, then it follows that the lust that is the flood of existence must be excluded from the flood of sensual desire.🔽And in that case it would be necessary to assume that there is a kind of greed that is not included in the flood of sensual desire or the flood of existence.

original: nāma lobhena bhavitabbaṃ. So yadā diṭṭhigatavippayuttesu uppajjati, tadā tena sampayutto
analyzed: nāma lobhena bhavitabbam so yadā diṭṭhi gata vippayuttesu uppajjati tadā tena sampayuttaḥ
translated: And when that occurs in association with the kinds of consciousness dissociated from the false view of individuality, then the ignorance that is associated with it must be dissociated from the flood of existence.

original: avijjogho oghavippayuttoti domanassavicikicchuddhaccasampayuttassa viya tassapi oghavippayuttatā
analyzed: avijja oghaḥ ogha vippayutto ti domanassa vicikicchu ddhacca sampayuttassa viya tassa api ogha vippayutta tā
translated: And it must be said that it is dissociated from the flood of existence just as it is from the flood of doubt and from the flood of ill will.

original: vattabbā siyā “catūsupi diṭṭhigatavippayuttalobhasahagatesu cittuppādesu uppanno🔽moho siyā oghasampayutto siyā oghavippayutto”ti. “Kāmogho aṭṭhasu lobhasahagatesu
analyzed: vattabbā siyā catūsu pi diṭṭhi gata vippayutta lobha sahagatesu cittuppādesu uppannaḥ  moho siyā ogha sampayutto siyā ogha vippayutto ti kāmoghaḥ aṭṭhasu lobha sahagatesu
translated: And it must be said that the delusion that occurs in the four kinds of consciousness associated with greed but dissociated from the false view of individuality🔽is sometimes associated with a flood and sometimes dissociated from a flood.🔽And it must be said that the flood of sensual desire occurs in the eight kinds of consciousness associated with greed,

original: cittuppādesu uppajjatī”ti, “kāmoghaṃ paṭicca diṭṭhogho avijjogho”ti ca vacanato diṭṭhisahagato
analyzed: cittuppādesu uppajjati iti kāma ogham paṭicca diṭṭha oghaḥ avijja oghaḥ ti ca vacanataḥ diṭṭhi sahagataḥ
translated: and that the flood of views and the flood of ignorance are due to the flood of sensual desire, according to the following passage: “The flood of sensual desire, bhikkhus, has what as its root, what as its source, what as its cause, what as its condition? The flood of sensual desire has passion as its root, its source, its cause, its condition. The flood of existence has ignorance as its root, its source, its cause, its condition” .

original: kāmogho na hotīti na sakkā vattuṃ. Tathā hettha “rūpārūpabhavesu chandarāgo jhānanikanti
analyzed: kāmoghaḥ na hoti iti na sakkā vattum tathā ha ittha rūpa arūpa bhavesu chanda rāgaḥ
translated: It cannot be said that the flood of sensual desire is not a flood.

original: ca bhavogho nāmāti ettakameva vuttaṃ, na vuttaṃ sassatadiṭṭhisahagato rāgo”ti.
analyzed: ca bhava oghaḥ nāma ati ettakam eva vuttam na vuttam sassata diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgo ti
translated: Similarly, here only this much is said: “Delight and lust in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of existence and the delight and lust in jhāna are called the flood of becoming,” but it is not said that lust associated with the eternalist view is the flood of becoming.

original: Adhogamanaṭṭhenāti heṭṭhāpavattanaṭṭhena. Heṭṭhāpavattanañcettha na kevalaṃ apāyagamaniyabhāvena,
analyzed: adhas gamana ṭhena ati heṭṭhā pavattana ṭṭhena heṭṭhā pavattanam ca ittha na kevalam apāya gamaniya bhāvena
translated: In the sense of flowing downwards: in the sense of flowing downwards, i.e. of occurring in the lower part. Here the flowing downwards is not only by way of going to the lower realms,

original: atha kho saṃsāratarakāvarodhanenapīti dassetuṃ “uparibhavañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kāmaṃ🔽nibbānaṃ arūpibhāvā adesaṃ, na tassa ṭhānavasena uparigahaṇaṃ, sabbasaṅkhatavinissaṭattā
analyzed: atha kho saṃsāra taraka avarodhanena api iti dassetum upari bhavan ca atiādi vuttam kāmam  nibbānam arūpi bhāvāḥ adesam na tassa ṭhāna vasena upari gahaṇam sabba saṅkhata vinissaṭa ttā
translated: but also by way of descending again and again into the round of rebirths. In order to show this, it is said: “and the highest existence.”🔽Although Nibbāna is not a material thing, it is not included above,

original: pana sabbassapi bhavassa uparīti vattabbataṃ arahatīti katvā vuttaṃ “uparibhavaṃ
analyzed: pana sabbassa api bhavassa upari iti vattabba tam arahati iti katvā vuttam uparibhavam
translated: but because it has escaped from all formations it is worthy to be called the highest of all kinds of existence. Thus it is said: “Nibbāna, the highest existence.”

original: nibbāna”nti. “Mahāudakogho”tiādīsu rāsaṭṭho ogha-saddoti “mahā heso kilesarāsī”ti
analyzed: nibbānanti mahā udaka oghaḥ ti ādīsu rāsaṭṭhaḥ ogha saddo ti mahā ha eso kilesa rāsī iti
translated: In the passages beginning “a great flood of water” the word ogha is taken in the sense of a heap, thus it is said: “This is a great heap of defilements.”

original: vuttaṃ sesesupīti bhavoghādīsupi.
analyzed: vuttam sesesu pi iti bhava ogha ādīsu pi
translated: So too in the case of the rest, i.e. the flood of becoming, etc.

original: Appatiṭṭhahantoti kilesādīnaṃ vasena asantiṭṭhanto, asaṃsīdantoti attho. Anāyūhantoti🔽abhisaṅkhārādivasena na āyūhanto majjhimaṃ paṭipadaṃ vilaṅghitvā nibbuyhanto. Tenāha
analyzed: appatiṭṭhahanto ti kilesa ādīnam vasena asantiṭṭhantaḥ asaṃsīdantaḥ iti attho anāyūhantaḥ iti  abhisaṅkhāra ādi vasena na āyūhantaḥ majjhimam paṭipadam vilaṅghitvā nibbuyhantaḥ tena āha
translated: ‘Not standing’: not standing by way of defilements, etc.; the meaning is, not sinking. ‘Not striving’:🔽not striving by way of determinations, etc.; not leaping over the middle way, he is ‘going forth’. Therefore it is said,

original: – “avāyamanto”ti, micchāvāyāmavasena avāyamantoti adhippāyo. Gūḷhanti saṃvutaṃ. Paṭicchannanti
analyzed: avāyamanto ti micchā avāyāma vasena avāyamanto ti adhippāyaḥ gūḷhanti saṃvutam paṭicchannanti
translated: ‘not making an effort’: the intention is that he is not making an effort by way of wrong effort. ‘Concealed’: covered up. ‘Hidden’:

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Atthavasena vā saṃvuttaṃ gūḷhaṃ, saddavasenapi apākaṭaṃ paṭicchannaṃ
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam attha vasena vā saṃvuttam gūḍham sadda vasena api apākaṭam paṭicchannam
translated: this is a synonym for the same. Or alternatively, it is ‘concealed’ in the sense of covered up, and it is ‘hidden’ in the sense of not manifest,

original: antaradīpādike ṭhātabbaṭṭhāne. Āyūhantāti hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamantā. Etaṃ atthajātaṃ,
analyzed: antara dīpa ādike ṭhātabba ṭṭhāne āyūhantā ati hatthehi ca pādehi ca vāyamantā etam attha jātam
translated: in a place where one should stand, such as in the middle of the island. ‘Striving’: making an effort with hands and feet. This is the subject-matter,

original: etaṃ vā vissajjanaṃ.
analyzed: etam vā vissajjanam
translated: or this is the explanation.

original: Idāni yenādhippāyena bhagavatā tathāgūḷhaṃ katvā pañho kathito, taṃ dassetuṃ “kiṃ🔽panātiādi vuttaṃ. Niggahamukhenāti veneyyānaṃ vinayaupāyabhūtaniggahavasena. Tenāha
analyzed: idāni yena adhippāyena bhagavatā tathāgūḷham katvā pañho kathito tam dassetum kim  pana atiādi vuttam niggaha mukhena ati veneyyānam vinaya upāya bhūta niggaha vasena tena āha
translated: Now, in order to point out the intention with which the question was asked by the Blessed One after making it so concealed, it is said, ‘But what, friend?’

original: ye paṇḍitamānino”tiādi. Pavayha pavayhāti ophuṇitvā ophuṇitvā.
analyzed: ye ophuṇitvā ophuṇitvā
translated: ‘By way of the injunction’: by way of the injunction which is the means of training for those who are trainable. Therefore it is said, ‘Those who are conceited with conceit’ , and so on. ‘After washing and washing’: after wiping and wiping.

original: Soti devaputto nihatamāno ahosi yathāvissajjitassa atthassa ajānanto. Yathāti aniyamavacanaṃ
analyzed: saḥ ti deva puttaḥ nihata mānaḥ ahosi yathā vissajjitassa atthassa a jānantaḥ yathā iti aniyama vacanam
translated: Yathā is a word of indefinite reference,

original: niyamaniddiṭṭhaṃ hoti, taṃsambandhañca kathanti pucchāvacananti tadubhayassa atthaṃ
analyzed: niyama niddiṭṭham hoti tad sambandham ca kathanti pucchā vacananti tad ubhayassa attham
translated: but here it is defined as definite. And kathā is a word of question.

original: dassento “yathāhaṃ jānāmi, evaṃ me kathehī”ti āha.
analyzed: dassentaḥ yathā aham jānāmi evam me kathehi iti āha
translated: Showing the meaning of both, he said, “Tell me as I understand it.”

original: Yadāsvāhanti yadā su ahaṃ, su-kāro nipātamattaṃ “yadidaṃ kathaṃ sū”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: yadā asu āhanti yadā su aham su kāraḥ nipāta mattam yat idam katham sūti ādīsu
translated: Yadāsvā means “when I.” The word su is a mere particle, as in such passages as “yadidaṃ kathaṃ sū” .

original: Sabbapadesūti “tadāssu saṃsīdāmī”tiādīsu tīsupi padesu. Atarantoti oghānaṃ atikkamanatthaṃ
analyzed: sabba padesu iti tadā assu saṃsīdāmi itiādīsu tīsu pi padesu ataranto ti oghānam atikkamana attham
translated: Sabbapadesu means in all three passages, “tadāssu saṃsīdāmi” . Ataranto means making an effort to cross the floods.

original: taraṇappayogaṃ akaronto. Tatthevāti oghaniyaoghesu eva. Osīdāmīti nimujjāmi oghehi🔽ajjhotthaṭo homi. Nibbuyhāmīti oghehi nibbūḷho homi. Ṭhātuṃ asakkonto asaṃsīdanto.
analyzed: taraṇa payogam a karontaḥ tattha iva ati ogha niya oghesu eva osīdāmi iti nimujjāmi oghehi  ajjhotthaṭaḥ homi nibbuyhāmi iti oghehi nibbūḷhaḥ homi ṭhātum a sakkontaḥ a saṃsīdantaḥ
translated: Tattheva means in the very floods. Osīdāmi means I sink down.🔽Ajjhotthaṭo means I am overwhelmed by the floods. Nibbuyhāmi means I am submerged by the floods. Ṭhātuṃ asakkonto means unable to remain. Asaṃsīdanto means not sinking down.

original: Ativattāmīti anupayogaṃ atikkamāmi, apanidhānavasena sammāpaṭipattiṃ virādhemīti
analyzed: ativattāmi iti anupayogam atikkamāmi apanidhāna vasena sammāpaṭipattim virādhemi iti
translated: Ativattāmī means I go beyond the effort, I fail in the right practice by way of rejection.

original: attho. Ṭhāne ca vāyāme cāti vakkhamānavibhāge patiṭṭhahane vāyāme ca dosaṃ disvāti
analyzed: atthaḥ ṭhāne ca vāyāme ca ati vakkhamāna vibhāge patiṭṭhahane vāyāme ca dosam disvā ati
translated: and the meaning. And seeing the danger in the place and in the effort,

original: patiṭṭhānāyūhanesu saṃsīdananibbuyhanasaṅkhātaṃ taraṇassa vibandhanabhūtaṃ ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: patiṭṭhāna āyūhanesu saṃsīdana nibbuyhana saṅkhātam taraṇassa vibandhana bhūtam ādīnavam
translated: seeing the danger in the slackness and in the agitation that is a hindrance to surmounting,

original: disvāna. Idaṃ bhagavatā bodhimūle attanā pavattita-pubbabhāga-manasikāravasena vuttaṃ.🔽Atiṭṭhanto avāyamantoti patiṭṭhānāyūhanakaraṇakilesādīnaṃ parivajjanena asaṃsīdanto
analyzed: disvāna idam bhagavatā bodhi mūle attanā pavattita pubba bhāga manasikāra vasena vuttam  a tiṭṭhantaḥ avāyamantaḥ iti patiṭṭhāna āyūhana karaṇa kilesa ādīnam parivajjanena a saṃsīdantaḥ
translated: this was said by the Blessed One with reference to his own previous application of mind at the root of the Bodhi tree.🔽Standing firm, not making an effort: not slackening, not giving up, by avoiding the defilements, etc., that are the means of slackening and giving up,

original: anibbuyhanto. Devatāyapi paṭividdho tadattho upanissayasampannatāya vimuttiparipācanīyadhammānaṃ🔽paripakkattā. Na pana pākaṭo vipañcitaññūādīnaṃ, ugghaṭitaññūnaṃ pana yathā tassā
analyzed: a nibbuyhantaḥ paṭividdhaḥ tad atthaḥ upanissaya sampanna tāya vimutti paripācanīya dhammānam  paripakka ttā na pana pākaṭaḥ vipañcita ññū ādīnam ugghaṭita ññūnam pana yathā tassā
translated: and by the deities’ penetration of the meaning, by the ripening of the qualities that ripen in freedom,🔽but not obvious, as it is to the type that is fully analysed, etc., but it is obvious to the type that is penetrated, as it was to that deity.

original: devatāya, tathā pākaṭo evāti. Satta dukā idāni vuccamānarūpā dassitā porāṇaṭṭhakathāyaṃ.
analyzed: devatāya tathā pākaṭaḥ eva ati satta dukā idāni vuccamāna rūpā dassitā porāṇa ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: The seven pairs are shown here in the way stated now. In the old commentary they are shown thus:

original: Kilesavasena santiṭṭhantoti lobhādīhi abhibhūtatāya saṃsāre patiṭṭhahanto sammā appaṭipajjanena
analyzed: kilesa vasena santiṭṭhantaḥ ti lobha ādīhi abhibhūta tāya saṃsāre patiṭṭhahantaḥ sammā appaṭipajjanena
translated: “He stands in the defilements” means that he stands in the round of rebirths by being overcome by greed, etc., and by not practicing rightly.🔽“He sinks in that very place” means that he sinks in that very round of rebirths. “He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.

original: tattheva saṃsīdati nāma. Abhisaṅkhāravasenāti tatthevābhisaṅkhāracetanāya cetento🔽sammāpaṭipattiyogyassa khaṇassa ativattanena nibbuyhati nāma. Iminā nayena sesadukesupi attho veditabbo.🔽Ettha ca vaṭṭamūlakā kilesāti tesaṃ vasena saṃsāre avaṭṭhānaṃ taṃtaṃkammunā tattha
analyzed: tattha iva saṃsīdati nāma abhisaṅkhāra vasena ati tattha iva abhisaṅkhāra cetanāya cetento  sammā paṭipatti yogyassa khaṇassa ativattanena nibbuyhati nāma iminā nayena sesa dukesu pi atthaḥ veditabbo  ettha ca vaṭṭamūlakā kilesā ti tesam vasena saṃsāre avaṭṭhānam taṃ taṃ kammunā tattha
translated: “He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.

original: tattha bhave abhinibbatti, kilesā pana tesaṃ paccayamattaṃ. Tattha tattha bhave aparāparaṃ🔽nibbattento saṃsāre nibbuyhati nāmāti imassa atthassa dassanavasena paṭhamaduko vutto.
analyzed: tattha bhave abhinibbatti kilesāḥ pana tesam paccaya mattam tattha tattha bhave apara aparam  nibbattento saṃsāre nibbuyhati nāma ati imassa atthassa dassana vasena paṭhama dukaḥ vuttaḥ
translated: “He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.

original: Ime sattā saṃsāre paribbhamantā duvidhā taṇhācaritā diṭṭhicaritā cāti tesaṃ saṃsāranāyikabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: ime sattā saṃsāre paribbhamantā duvidhā taṇhā caritā diṭṭhi caritā ca ati tesam saṃsāra nāyika bhūtānam
translated: “He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the current of the kamma he has accumulated, by the current of craving, and by the current of views.🔽“He is carried away by the current” means that he is carried away by the

original: dhammānaṃ vasena santiṭṭhanaṃ, tadaññesaṃ pavattipaccayānaṃ vasena āyūhananti imassa
analyzed: dhammānam vasena santiṭṭhanam tad aññesam pavatti paccayānam vasena āyūhanan ti imassa
translated: “The establishment of dhammas by way of the conditions for their occurrence” means the accumulation by way of the other conditions for their occurrence.

original: atthassa dassanavasena dutiyaduko vutto. Saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assādadassanasabhāvāya
analyzed: atthassa dassana vasena dutiya dukaḥ vutto saṃyojaniyesu dhammesu assāda dassana sabhāvāya
translated: The second dyad is stated to show the meaning of “accumulation” by the power of the other conditions that occur by the power of the states.

original: taṇhāya vasena visesato patiṭṭhānaṃ, amuttimagge muttimaggaparāmāsato tathā āyūhanampi
analyzed: taṇhāya vasena visesataḥ patiṭṭhānam amutti magge mutti magga parāmāsato tathā āyūhanam pi
translated: The third dyad is stated to show the establishment by the power of craving, which has the nature of seeing enjoyment in states that cause bondage, and the accumulation in the same way by the power of views, which is due to the misapprehension of the path to deliverance as the path to deliverance.

original: diṭṭhiyā vasena hotīti dassetuṃ tatiyaduko vutto. Catutthaduke pana adhippāyo aṭṭhakathāya🔽eva vibhāvito. Yasmā “sassato attā”ti abhinivisanto arūparāgaṃ, asaññūpagaṃ vā avimokkhaṃyeva
analyzed: diṭṭhiyāḥ vasena hoti iti dassetum tatiya dukaḥ vuttaḥ catuttha duke pana adhippāyaḥ aṭṭhakathāya  eva vibhāvitaḥ yasmā sassataḥ attā ati abhinivisantaḥ arūpa rāgam asaññu upagam vā a vimokkham yeva
translated: The intention in the fourth dyad is explained in the commentary.

original: vimokkhoti gahetvā saṃsāre eva olīyati. Tenāha “olīyanābhinivesā hi bhavadiṭṭhī”ti.🔽Yasmā pana kāmabhavādīsu yaṃ vā taṃ vā bhavaṃ patvā attā ucchijjati vinassati, na
analyzed: vimokkhaḥ ti gahetvā saṃsāre eva olīyati tena āha olīyana abhinivesā hi bhava diṭṭhī iti  pana kāma bhava ādīsu yam vā tam vā bhavam patvā attā ucchijjati vinassati na
translated: When one misapprehends the immaterial realm or the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling as deliverance, he is attached to the round of rebirths. Therefore it is said: “For the view of existence is the misapprehension of what is not escape as escape.”

original: hoti paraṃ maraṇāti abhinivisanto bhavavippamokkhāvahāya sammāpaṭipattiyā appaṭipajjanena
analyzed: hoti param maraṇā ti abhinivisantaḥ bhava vippamokkha āvahāya sammā paṭipattiyā a paṭipajjanena
translated: But when one misapprehends that the self is annihilated and destroyed after death, and does not exist after death, he does not practice the right way to escape from existence.

original: taṃ ativattati. Tena vuttaṃ “atidhāvanābhinivesā vibhavadiṭṭhī”ti.
analyzed: tam ativattati tena vuttam atidhāvana abhinivesā vibhava diṭṭhī iti
translated: He exceeds it. Hence it was said: ‘The view of annihilation is due to over-looking through over-hastyness.’

original: Līnavasena santiṭṭhantoti kosajjādivasena saṃkocāpajjanena sammā appaṭipajjanto.
analyzed: līna vasena santiṭṭhanto ti kosajja ādi vasena saṃkoca āpajjanena sammā appaṭipajjanto
translated: ‘He stands on the side of contraction’: he does not rightly practice by contracting himself through idleness, etc.

original: Uddhaccavasena āyūhantoti sammāsamādhino abhāvena vikkhepavasena pañcamo duko vutto.
analyzed: uddhacca vasena āyūhanto ti sammāsamādhinaḥ abhāvena vikkhepa vasena pañcamaḥ dukaḥ vutto
translated: ‘He accumulates on the side of agitation’: the fifth dyad is stated by way of distraction through lack of right concentration.

original: Yathā kāmasukhaṃ paviṭṭhassa samādhānaṃ natthi cittassa upakkiliṭṭhattā, evaṃ attaparitāpanamanuyuttassa🔽kāyassa upakkiliṭṭhattā. Iti cittakāyaparikkilesakarā dve antā taṇhādiṭṭhinissayatāya
analyzed: yathā kāma sukham paviṭṭhassa samādhānam natthi cittassa upakkiliṭṭha ttā evam atta paritāpana manuyuttassa  kāyassa upakkiliṭṭha ttā iti citta kāya parikkilesa karā dve antā taṇhā diṭṭhi nissaya tāya
translated: Just as there is no concentration for one who has entered upon sensual pleasure because of the defilement of the mind, so too there is no concentration for one who is devoted to self-mortification🔽because of the defilement of the body. Thus the two extremes, which are the defilements of mind and body, are stated in the sixth dyad as the causes for ‘sinking’ and ‘oscillation’ respectively, because they are the supports for craving and views.

original: saṃsīdananibbuyhananimittā vuttā chaṭṭhaduke. Pubbe sappadesatova saṃkilesadhammā
analyzed: saṃsīdana nibbuyhana nimittā vuttā chaṭṭha duke pubbe sa ppadesataḥ va saṃkilesa dhammā
translated: In the first dyad the states of defilement are shown by way of a good place.

original: “saṃsīdananimitta”nti dassitāti idāni nippadesato dassanavasena, pubbe ca sādhāraṇato
analyzed: saṃsīdana nimittam ti dassitā ati idāni nippadesataḥ dassana vasena pubbe ca sādhāraṇato
translated: ‘The cause for oscillation’ is shown. Now, by way of seeing without a place, and previously by way of the common,🔽the states of formation are shown as ‘the cause for oscillation.’ Now, only the formations of merit and the imperturbable

original: abhisaṅkhāradhammā “nibbuyhananimitta”nti dassitāti idāni puññāneñjābhisaṅkhāre eva
analyzed: abhisaṅkhāra dhammā nibbuyhana nimittan ti dassitā ati idāni puñña aneñja abhisaṅkhāre eva
translated: are shown.

original: “āyūhananimitta”nti dassanavasena sattamaduko vutto. Evañhi duggatisugatūpapattivasena
analyzed: āyūhana nimittan ti dassana vasena sattama dukaḥ vuttaḥ evam hi duggati sugata upapatti vasena
translated: The seventh couplet is stated with reference to the “sign of accumulation.”🔽For thus the falling away and the falling back are shown by way of the bad and good destinations.

original: saṃsīdananibbuyhanāni vibhajja dassitāni hontīti. Tenevāha “vuttampi ceta”ntiādi.🔽Adhobhāgaṃ duggatiṃ gamentīti adhobhāgaṅgamanīyā anunāsikalopaṃ akatvā. Tathā uparibhāgaṃ
analyzed: saṃsīdana nibbuyhanāni vibhajja dassitāni honti iti tena iva āha vuttam pi cetantiādi  adhobhāgam duggatim gamenti iti adhobhāgaṅgamanīyāḥ anunāsika lopam a katvā tathā upari bhāgam
translated: Therefore he says, “And although it has been said,” etc.🔽“Going to the lower part” means “going to the bad destinations” without the nasal sound.

original: gamentīti uparibhāgaṅgamanīyā.
analyzed: upari bhāgaṅgamanīyā
translated: Similarly, “going to the upper part” means “going to the good destinations.”

original: Ettha ca oghataraṇaṃ pucchitena bhagavatā “appatiṭṭhaṃ anāyūha”nti tassa pahānaṅgameva
analyzed: ettha ca ogha taraṇam pucchitena bhagavatā appatiṭṭham tassa pahāna aṅgam eva
translated: And here, when the Blessed One, who was asked about “crossing the flood,” showed the abandoning aspect of the flood by saying, “The unestablished, the unaccumulated,”🔽did he not show the associated aspect?

original: dassitaṃ, na sampayogaṅganti? Na evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, yāvatā yena patiṭṭhānaṃ hoti, yena🔽ca āyūhanaṃ, tadubhayapaṭikkhepamukhena tappaṭipakkhadhammadassanametanti. Na hesa
analyzed: dassitam na na evam daṭṭhabbam yāvatā yena patiṭṭhānam hoti yena  ca āyūhanam tad ubhaya paṭikkhepa mukhena tad paṭipakkha dhamma dassanam etat ti na ha esa
translated: This should not be so regarded, for the purpose of showing the state of things opposed to the established and the accumulated,🔽the Blessed One stated the negation in the first place.

original: a-kāro kevalaṃ paṭisedhe, atha kho paṭipakkhe “akusalā dhammā, ahito, adhammo”tiādīsu
analyzed: akāraḥ kevalam paṭisedhe atha kho paṭipakkhe akusalāḥ dhammāḥ ahitaḥ adhammo ti ādīsu
translated: For the letter “a” is not only a negation, but also a state of things opposed to something else, as in the cases of “unprofitable things,” “unwholesomeness,” “non-Dhamma,” etc.

original: viya, tasmā appatiṭṭhaṃ anāyūhanti patiṭṭhānāyūhanānaṃ paṭipakkhavasena pavattamāno
analyzed: viya tasmai appatiṭṭham an āyūhanti patiṭṭhā an āyūhanānam paṭipakkha vasena pavattamānaḥ
translated: and so it is unestablished and unpropped up. The meaning is that it occurs in opposition to establishment and propping up.

original: tathāpavattihetūvāti ayamettha attho. Khoti ca avadhāraṇatthe nipāto “assosi kho”tiādīsu🔽viya. Tena appatiṭṭhānassa ekaṃsikataṃ dasseti. Soyaṃ kho-saddo “anāyūha”nti etthāpi
analyzed: tathā apavatti hetu uvā ti ayam ettha atthaḥ kho ti ca avadhāraṇa atthe nipātaḥ kho ti ādīsu  viya tena appatiṭṭhānassa ekaṃsikatam dasseti saḥ yam kho saddaḥ ettha api
translated: The word kho is a particle in the sense of limitation, as in the passage beginning, “He heard, ‘

original: ānetvā vattabbo. Anāyūhanampi hi ekaṃsikamevāti tassa paṭipakkho saha vipassanāya
analyzed: ānetvā vattabbaḥ an āyūhanam pi hi ekaṃsikam eva ti tassa paṭipakkhaḥ saha vipassanāya
translated: The word kho should be brought in here too with the word anāyūha. For that is also one-sided. The opposite of that is the noble path with insight,

original: ariyamaggo. Tena hi oghataraṇaṃ hoti, na aññathā. Evamayaṃ yathānusandhidesanā katā,
analyzed: ariya maggaḥ tena hi ogha taraṇam hoti na aññathā evam ayam yathā anusandhi desanā katā
translated: for by that means the flood is crossed, not otherwise. So this is how the teaching was given in accordance with the line of thought.

original: devatā ca sahavipassanaṃ maggaṃ paṭivijjhīti paṭhamaphale patiṭṭhāsi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: devatā ca saha vipassanam maggam paṭivijjhi iti paṭhama phale patiṭṭhāsi tena vuttam
translated: And the deity penetrated the path with insight and was established in the first fruition. Hence it was said above,

original: “imaṃ pañhavissajjana”ntiādi.
analyzed: imam pañha vissajjana ntiādi
translated: “The answer to the question” .

original: “Cirassā”ti iminā samānatthaṃ padantarametanti āha “cirassa kālassā”ti yathā “mamaṃ
analyzed: cirassa ati iminā samāna attham pada antaram etat ti āha cirassa kālassa ati yathā mamam
translated: The words cirassā ti iminā are synonymous with the words cirassa kālassa, as in the passage, “Mamaṃ, bhikkhave, cirassā ti iminā cirassa kālassa

original: vā, bhikkhave”ti ettha “mamā”ti iminā samānatthaṃ padantaraṃ mamanti. Na diṭṭhapubbāti
analyzed: vā bhikkhave ti ettha mama ati iminā samāna attham pada antaram na diṭṭha pubbā ti
translated: “Mamā” is a synonym for “mamanti” in the phrase “mamā devatā na diṭṭhapubbā” .

original: adassāvī. Adassāvitā ca disvā kattabbakiccassa asiddhatāya veditabbā. Aññathā kā
analyzed: a dassāvī a dassāvitā ca disvā kattabba kiccassa asiddha tāya veditabbā aññathā kā
translated: “Adassāvī” means “not seeing.” And “not seeing” should be understood as the non-accomplishment of the duty to be done after seeing. Otherwise,

original: nāma sā devatā, yā bhagavantaṃ na diṭṭhavatī? Tenāha “kiṃ panimāyā”tiādi. Dassanaṃ
analyzed: nāma sā devatā yā bhagavantam na diṭṭhavatī tena āha kim dassanam
translated: what is that deity who has not seen the Blessed One? Therefore he said, “But what is this?”

original: upādāya evaṃ vattuṃ vattatīti yadā kadāci kañci piyajātikaṃ disvā taṃ dassanaṃ upādāya
analyzed: upādāya evam vattum vattati iti yadā kadāci kañci piya jātikam disvā tam dassanam upādāya
translated: It is proper to speak thus on the basis of seeing. Sometimes, after seeing someone who is dear, one says,

original: “cirena vata mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ passāmā”ti adiṭṭhapubbaṃ diṭṭhapubbaṃ vā evaṃ vattuṃ
analyzed: cirena vata mayam āyasmantam passāma ati a diṭṭha pubbam diṭṭha pubbam vā evam vattum
translated: “At long last we have seen the venerable one!” Thus it is proper to speak thus on the basis of seeing someone who has not been seen before or who has been seen.

original: yujjati, ayaṃ loke niruḷhe samudācāroti dasseti. Brahmaṃ vā vuccati ariyamaggo, tassa🔽aṇanato jānanato paṭivijjhanato brāhmaṇo. Kilesanibbānenāti kilesānaṃ accantasamucchedasaṅkhātena
analyzed: yujjati ayam loke niruḷhe samudācāro ti dasseti brahmam vā vuccati ariya maggo tassa  aṇanataḥ jānanataḥ paṭivijjhanataḥ brāhmaṇaḥ kilesa nibbānena ati kilesānam accanta samuccheda saṅkhātena
translated: This shows that this is a common practice in the world. Or “brahma” may refer to the noble path. One who knows that path well and penetrates it is a “brahmin.”🔽“Nibbāna” means the complete destruction of defilements.🔽“Nibbuta” means completely pacified, with all the defilements, griefs, and fevers completely stilled.

original: nibbānena nibbutaṃ sammadeva vūpasanta-sabbakilesadaratha-pariḷāhaṃ. Āsattavisattādīhīti
analyzed: nibbānena nibbutam sammat eva vūpasanta sabba kilesa daratha pariḷāham āsatta visatta ādīhi iti
translated: “Āsattavisattādīhi” means “by the twenty-eight, etc.”

original: ādi-saddena visatādiākāre saṅgaṇhāti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ādi saddena visata ādi ākāre saṅgaṇhāti vuttam ha etam
translated: and so on. For this is said:

original: “Visatāti visattikā, visaṭāti visattikā, visālāti visattikā, visakkatīti visattikā,
analyzed: visatā ati visattikā visaṭā ati visattikā visālā ati visattikā visakkatī iti visattikā
translated: “It is ‘diverse’ because of diversity, it is ‘varied’ because of variety, it is ‘wide’ because of width, it is ‘varied’ because of variety,

original: visaṃvādikāti visattikā, visaṃ haratīti visattikā, visamūlāti visattikā, visaphalāti🔽visattikā, visaparibhogoti visattikā, visālā vā pana sā taṇhā rūpe sadde gandhe rase
analyzed: visaṃvādikā ati visattikā visam harati iti visattikā visa mūlā ati visattikā visa phalā ati  visattikā visa paribhogo ti visattikā visālā vā pana sā taṇhā rūpe sadde gandhe rase
translated: it is ‘varied’ because of deception, it is ‘varied’ because of removal, it is ‘varied’ because of a root, it is ‘varied’ because of fruit,🔽it is ‘varied’ because of enjoyment, it is ‘varied’ because of the diversity of form, sound, odour, flavour,

original: phoṭṭhabbe dhamme kule gaṇe visatā vitthatāti visattikā”ti.🔽Tattha visatāti vitthatā rūpādīsu tebhūmakadhammesu abhibyāpanavasena visaṭāti purimavacanameva
analyzed: phoṭṭhabbe dhamme kule gaṇe visatā vitthatā ati visattikā ati  tattha visatā ati vitthatā rūpa ādīsu tebhūmaka dhammesu abhibyāpana vasena purima vacanam eva
translated: tangible qualities, and mental objects, because of families, and because of groups. It is ‘varied’ because it is spread out in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes, and because it is extended in the various kinds of families and groups.”

original: ta-kārassa ṭa-kāraṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Visālāti vipulā. Visakkatīti parisakkati, sahati🔽vā. Ratto hi rāgavatthunā pādena tāḷiyamānopi sahatīti. Osakkanaṃ vipphandanaṃ vā
analyzed: takārassa ṭakāram katvā vuttam visālā ati vipulā visakkati iti parisakkati sahati 🔽vā rattaḥ hi rāga vatthunā pādena tāḷiyamānaḥ api sahati iti osakkanam vipphandanam vā
translated: Herein, it is “diverse” because of diversity in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of variety in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “wide” because of width in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of variety in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes.🔽It is “varied” because of deception in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of removal in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of a root in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of fruit in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes.🔽It is “varied” because of enjoyment in the various kinds of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of the diversity of form, etc., of the three planes. It is “varied” because of the diversity of families and groups.

original: “visakkana”ntipi vadanti. Aniccādiṃ niccādito. Gaṇhātīti visaṃvādikā hoti. Visaṃ🔽haratīti tathā tathā kāmesu ānisaṃsaṃ passantī vividhehi ākārehi nekkhammābhimukhappavattito🔽cittaṃ saṃharati saṃkhipati, visaṃ vā dukkhaṃ, taṃ harati, vahatīti attho. Dukkhanibbattakakammassa🔽hetubhāvato visamūlā. Visaṃ vā dukkhābhibhūtā vedanā mūlaṃ etissāti visamūlā. Dukkhasamudayattā
analyzed: vadanti anicca ādim nicca ādeḥ gaṇhāti iti visaṃvādikā hoti visaṃ harati iti tathā tathā kāmesu ānisaṃsam passantī vividhehi ākārehi nekkhamma abhimukha ppavattito  cittam saṃharati saṃkhipati visam vā dukkham tam harati vahati iti atthaḥ dukkha nibbattaka kammassa  hetu bhāvataḥ visa mūlā visam vā dukkha abhibhūtā vedanā mūlam etissa ati visa mūlā dukkha samudaya ttā
translated: “Visakkana” is also said. “Unreality” is the taking of the impermanent, etc., as the opposite of the permanent, etc. It is “untruth” because it misleads.

original: visaṃ phalaṃ etissāti visaphalā. Taṇhāya rūpādikassa dukkhasseva paribhogo hoti,
analyzed: visam phalam etissa ati visa phalā taṇhāya rūpa ādikassa dukkhassa iva paribhogaḥ hoti
translated: “It draws away” : seeing the advantages in sensual desires in this way, it draws away the mind from the inclination towards renunciation by various means, and it draws together the mind, contracts it. Or “visaṃ” means suffering. It draws away suffering, carries it off, is the meaning. It is “rooted in poison” because it is the cause of the deed that produces suffering. Or it is “rooted in poison” because the feeling of suffering that is overcome by poison comes to it. It is “poisonous fruit” because it comes to be the origin of suffering.

original: na amatassāti visaparibhogoti vuttā, sabbattha niruttivasena padasiddhi veditabbā.
analyzed: na amatassa ati visa paribhogaḥ ti vuttā sabbattha nirutti vasena pada siddhi veditabbā
translated: Because of craving, the enjoyment is only of suffering, not of the deathless, thus it is said to be “poisonous enjoyment.” The derivation of the words should be understood in all instances according to the method of explanation given.

original: Yo panettha padhāno attho, taṃ dassetuṃ puna “visālā vā panā”tiādi vuttanti evamettha
analyzed: yaḥ pana ittha padhānaḥ attho tam dassetum puna visālā vā pana atiādi vuttan ti evam ettha
translated: “But it is also extensive” is said in order to show the principal meaning here.

original: visattikāpadassa attho veditabbo. Tiṇṇaṃ paṭhamadutiyamaggehi. Nittiṇṇaṃ tatiyamaggena.
analyzed: visattikā padassa attho veditabbo tiṇṇam paṭhama dutiya maggehi nittiṇṇam tatiya maggena
translated: The one who has crossed over by the first and second paths is “the one who has crossed over the three floods.”

original: Uttiṇṇaṃ catutthamaggena.
analyzed: uttiṇṇam catuttha maggena
translated: The one who has crossed over by the fourth path is “the one who has crossed over the four floods.”🔽“Agreed with”: agreed with in the right way. Hence it is said, “had the same aspiration.”

original: Samanuññoti sammadeva katānuñño. Tenāha “ekajjhāsayo ahosī”ti. Antaradhāyīti adassanaṃ
analyzed: samanuñño ti sammat eva kata anuñño tena āha ekajjhāsayaḥ ahosi iti antaradhāyi iti adassanam
translated: “Disappeared”: went out of sight.

original: agamāsi. Yathā pana antaradhāyi, taṃ dassetuṃ “abhisaṅkhatakāya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Mālehīti
analyzed: agamāsi yathā pana antaradhāyi tam dassetum abhisaṅkhatakāyanti ādi vuttam mālehi iti
translated: But in order to show how he disappeared, it is said, “with his body ablaze.”

original: liṅgavipallāsena vuttaṃ, “mālāhī”ti keci paṭhanti, “malyehī”ti vattabbe ya-kāralopaṃ
analyzed: liṅga vipallāsena vuttam mālāhi iti keci paṭhanti malyehi iti vattabbe yakāra lopam
translated: “May he come”: this is said with a change of gender. Some read “mālāhi,” but it should be read “malyehī.”

original: katvā niddeso. Ayaṃ tāva aṭṭhakathāya līnatthavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: katvā niddesaḥ ayam tāva aṭṭhakathāya līna attha vaṇṇanā
translated: The ya-vowel is elided in the locative case. This is the commentary on the literal meaning in brief.

original: Nettinayavaṇṇanā
analyzed: na itti naya vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the method of the guide-lines

original: Idāni pakaraṇanayena pāḷiyā atthavaṇṇanaṃ karissāma. Sā pana atthavaṇṇanā yasmā desanāya
analyzed: idāni pakaraṇa nayena pāḷiyā attha vaṇṇanam karissāma sā pana attha vaṇṇanā yasmā desanāya
translated: Now we shall explain the meaning of the text by the method of the treatise. But that explanation is easy and intelligible when the following five items are discerned in the teaching:🔽1. the source from which the teaching emanates,🔽2. its purpose,🔽3. its container,

original: samuṭṭhānappayojanabhājanesu piṇḍatthesu ca niddhāritesu sukarā hoti suviññeyyā ca,
analyzed: samuṭṭhāna payojana bhājanesu piṇḍatthesu ca niddhāritesu sukarā hoti su viññeyyā ca
translated: 4. its summary meaning, and🔽5. its analysis.

original: tasmā suttadesanāya samuṭṭhānādīni paṭhamaṃ niddhārayissāma. Tattha samuṭṭhānaṃ tāva
analyzed: tasmā sutta desanāya samuṭṭhāna ādīni paṭhamam niddhārayissāma tattha samuṭṭhānam tāva
translated: So we shall first of all determine the source, etc., of the teaching of the sutta. Herein,

original: desanānidānaṃ, taṃ sādhāraṇaṃ asādhāraṇanti duvidhaṃ. Tattha sādhāraṇampi abbhantarabāhirabhedato
analyzed: desanā nidānam tam sādhāraṇam asādhāraṇanti duvidham tattha sādhāraṇam pi abbhantara bāhira bhedato
translated: the source of the teaching is the reason for the teaching. That is twofold as common and uncommon. Herein, the common kind is also twofold as internal and external.

original: duvidhaṃ. Tattha sādhāraṇaṃ abbhantarasamuṭṭhānaṃ nāma lokanāthassa mahākaruṇā. Tāya
analyzed: duvidham tattha sādhāraṇam abbhantara samuṭṭhānam nāma lokanāthassa mahā karuṇā tāya
translated: Herein, the internal common source is the Blessed One’s great compassion.

original: hi samussāhitassa bhagavato veneyyānaṃ dhammadesanāya cittaṃ udapādi, yaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: hi samussāhitassa bhagavataḥ veneyyānam dhamma desanāya cittam udapādi yam sandhāya
translated: For it was owing to that that the Blessed One’s mind inclined to teaching the Dhamma to those who were capable of the right practice. Accordingly it is said:

original: vuttaṃ – “sattesu ca kāruññataṃ paṭicca buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesī”tiādi. Ettha🔽ca hetuavatthāyapi mahākaruṇāya saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo yāvadeva saṃsāramahoghato saddhammadesanāhatthadānehi
analyzed: vuttam sattesu ca kāruñña tam paṭicca buddha cakkhunā lokam volokesi itiādi ettha  ca mahākaruṇāya saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yāvat eva saṃsāra mahoghato saddhamma desanā hattha dānehi
translated: “And he surveyed the world with his Buddha-eye and saw that there were beings who were few in defilement, who were not wrapped in the thick mists of defilement, who were endowed with confidence in the Enlightened One, who were endowed with confidence in the Dhamma, who were endowed with confidence in the Sangha, who had the habit of doing good for him, who were grateful and thankful, who were suitable vessels for the teachings of the Deathless, who would not be upset if they heard the Deathless teachings” .🔽And here the great compassion should be regarded as included in the cause, in the sense that the teaching of the true Dhamma is the giving of a hand to beings in order to pull them out of the great flood of suffering, since it is the cause of that.

original: sattasantāraṇatthaṃ taduppattito. Yathā ca mahākaruṇā, evaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ dasabalañāṇādīni
analyzed: satta santāraṇa attham tad uppattitaḥ yathā ca mahākaruṇā evam sabbaññuta ññāṇam dasa bala ñāṇa ādīni
translated: And just as the great compassion, so too the knowledge of omniscience, the knowledge of the ten powers, etc.,

original: ca desanāya abbhantarasamuṭṭhānabhāvena vattabbāni. Sabbañhi ñeyyadhammaṃ tesaṃ desetabbappakāraṃ
analyzed: ca desanāya abbhantara samuṭṭhāna bhāvena vattabbāni sabbam hi ñeyya dhammam tesam desetabba ppakāram
translated: and they should be told as the internal and external conditions for the teaching. For the Blessed One, knowing as he did all knowable things in all modes that should be taught,

original: sattānañca āsayānusayādiṃ yāthāvato jānanto bhagavā ṭhānāṭṭhānādīsu kosallena veneyyajjhāsayānurūpaṃ
analyzed: āsayā anusaya ādim yāthāvataḥ jānantaḥ bhagavā ṭhāna aṭṭhāna ādīsu kosallena
translated: and knowing the dispositions, latent tendencies, etc., of beings, taught the Dhamma with skill in means by adapting the teaching to the dispositions of those to be trained.

original: vicittanayadesanaṃ pavattesīti. Bāhiraṃ pana sādhāraṇaṃ samuṭṭhānaṃ dasasahassamahābrahmaparivāra-sahampatimahābrahmuno🔽ajjhesanaṃ. Tadajjhesanuttarakālañhi dhammagambhīratāpaccavekkhaṇājanitaṃ appossukkataṃ
analyzed: vicit tanaya desanam pavattesi iti bāhiram pana sādhāraṇam samuṭṭhānam dasa sahassa mahābrahma parivāra sahampati mahābrahmuno  ajjhesanam tad ajjhesana uttara kālam hi dhamma gambhīra tā paccavekkhaṇā janitam appa ussukka tam
translated: The external condition common to all is the request of the Great Brahma Sahampati, who was accompanied by ten thousand Brahmas.

original: paṭippassambhetvā dhammassāmī dhammadesanāya ussāhajāto ahosi. Asādhāraṇampi abbhantarabāhirabhedato🔽duvidhameva. Tattha abbhantaraṃ yāya mahākaruṇāya yena ca desanāñāṇena idaṃ suttaṃ
analyzed: paṭippassambhetvā dhammassāmī dhamma desanāya ussāha jātaḥ ahosi asādhāraṇam pi abbhantara bāhira bhedato  duvidham eva tattha abbhantaram yāya mahākaruṇāya yena ca desanā ñāṇena idam suttam
translated: For when the Blessed One was reflecting on the profundity of the Dhamma, he became disinclined to teach the Dhamma, but when he was requested by Brahma, his disinclination ceased and he became eager to teach the Dhamma.🔽The uncommon condition is twofold, as internal and external.

original: pavattitaṃ, tadubhayaṃ veditabbaṃ bāhiraṃ pana tassā devatāya pucchā, pucchāvasiko
analyzed: pavattitam tat ubhayam veditabbam bāhiram pana tassā devatāya pucchā pucchāvasiko
translated: Herein, the internal condition should be understood as the great compassion and the knowledge of the teaching by means of which this sutta was taught. The external condition is the question of that deity.🔽The question was the occasion for the sutta.

original: hesa suttanikkhepo. Tayidaṃ pāḷiyaṃ āgatameva.
analyzed: ha isa sutta nikkhepaḥ tayidam pāḷiyam āgatam eva
translated: This is the summary of the sutta. And this is given in the text itself.

original: Payojanampi sādhāraṇāsādhāraṇato duvidhaṃ. Tattha sādhāraṇaṃ anukkamena yāva anupādāparinibbānaṃ
analyzed: payojanam pi sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇataḥ duvidham tattha sādhāraṇam anukkamena yāva anupādā parinibbānam
translated: The purpose is twofold, general and specific. Herein, the general purpose is the attainment of the supramundane state, which is the fruit of Stream-entry, etc.,

original: vimuttirasattā bhagavato desanāya. Tenevāha “etadatthā kathā, etadatthā mantanā”tiādi.
analyzed: vimuttiḥ asattā bhagavataḥ desanāya tena iva āha etad atthā kathā etad atthā mantanā atiādi
translated: because the Blessed One’s teaching leads to the plane of deliverance, which culminates in the deathless Nibbāna. Hence it is said: “This talk is for the sake of that, this talk is rooted in that” , and so on.

original: Asādhāraṇaṃ pana tassā devatāya dassanamaggasamadhigamo, ubhayampetaṃ bāhirameva.🔽Sace pana veneyyasantānagatampi desanābalasiddhisaṅkhātaṃ payojanaṃ adhippāyasamijjhanabhāvato
analyzed: asādhāraṇam pana tassā devatāya dassana magga samadhigamaḥ ubhayampetam bāhiram eva  sace pana veneyya santāna gatam pi desanā bala siddhi saṅkhātam payojanam adhippāya samijjhana bhāvato
translated: But the specific purpose is the deity’s seeing of the path and her realization of it. Both these purposes are external to the teaching.🔽But if one were to take the purpose to be the occurrence of the teaching in the disciple’s continuity, which is due to the power of the teaching, and which is called “the success of the purpose,”

original: yathādhippetatthasiddhiyā mahākāruṇikassa bhagavatopi payojanamevāti gaṇheyya, iminā
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikassa bhagavataḥ api payojanam eva ati gaṇheyya iminā
translated: then the Blessed One’s purpose, too, would be the success of the purpose in the sense of the accomplishment of the intended meaning.

original: pariyāyenassa abbhantaratāpi siyā.
analyzed: pariyāyena assa abbhantara tā api siyā
translated: So in this sense the purpose is internal to the teaching.

original: Apica tassā devatāya oghataraṇākārassa yāthāvato anavabodho imissā desanāya samuṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: apica tassāḥ devatāyaḥ ogha taraṇa ākārassa yāthāvataḥ anavabodhaḥ imissāḥ desanāya samuṭṭhānam
translated: Moreover, the non-understanding of the way to cross the flood is the source of this teaching,

original: tadavabodho payojanaṃ. So hi imāya desanāya bhagavantaṃ payojeti tannipphādanaparāyaṃ
analyzed: tad avabodhaḥ payojanam saḥ hi imāya desanāya bhagavantam payojā iti tat nipphādana parāyam
translated: The purpose is the understanding of that, for that is what impels the Blessed One to the teaching, as if it were the teacher’s purpose,

original: desanāti katvā. Yañhi desanāya sādhetabbaṃ phalaṃ, taṃ ākaṅkhitabbattā desakaṃ desanāya🔽payojetīti payojananti vuccati. Tathā devatāya tadaññesañca vineyyānaṃ patiṭṭhānāyūhanavissajjanañcettha
analyzed: desanā ati katvā yat hi desanāya sādhetabbam phalam tam ākaṅkhitabba ttā desakam desanāya  payojā iti iti payojanam ti vuccati tathā devatāya tad aññesam ca vineyyānam patiṭṭhāna āyūhana vissajjanam ca ittha
translated: since it is what is to be accomplished by the teaching. For what is to be accomplished by the teaching is called its purpose because it is what is to be desired by the teacher of the teaching.🔽And likewise the establishment, the arousing, and the giving of the outcome of that are the purpose here for the deity and for the other disciples.

original: payojanaṃ. Tathā saṃsāracakkanivatti-saddhammacakkappavattisassatādimicchācāra-nirākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: payojanam tathā saṃsāra cakka nivatti saddhamma cakka ppavatti sassata ādi micchā ācāra nirākaraṇam
translated: And likewise the purpose here is the refutation of the wrong practice of eternalism, etc., and the setting in motion of the wheel of the True Idea, and the stopping of the wheel of the round of rebirths,

original: sammāvādapurekkhāro akusalamūlasamūhananaṃ kusalamūlasamāropanaṃ apāyadvārapidahanaṃ🔽saggamokkhadvāravivaraṇaṃ pariyuṭṭhānavūpasamanaṃ anusayasamugghātanaṃ “mutto mocessāmī”ti
analyzed: sammāvāda purekkhāraḥ akusala mūla samūhananam kusala mūla samāropanam apāya dvāra pidahanam  saggamokkha dvāra vivaraṇam pariyuṭṭhāna vūpasamanam anusaya samugghātanam muttaḥ mocessāmi iti
translated: and the uprooting of the roots of unprofit and the planting of the roots of profit, and the burning of the door of the states of loss,🔽and the opening of the door of the happy destinies and of the door of Nibbāna, and the allaying of obsession, and the eradication of inherent tendency, and the fulfilling of the promise “I am freed and I teach the way to deliverance,”

original: purimapaṭiññāavisaṃvādanaṃ tappaṭipakkhamāramanorathavisaṃvādanaṃ titthiyasamayanimmathanaṃ
analyzed: purima paṭiññā avisaṃvādanam tad paṭipakkha māra manoratha visaṃvādanam titthiya samaya nimmathanam
translated: and the non-frustration of the resolve of the opponent, and the frustration of the resolve of the sectarians,

original: buddhadhammapatiṭṭhāpananti evamādīnipi payojanāni idha veditabbāni.
analyzed: buddha dhamma patiṭṭhāpanan ti evamādīni pi payojanāni idha veditabbāni
translated: and “the establishment of the Buddha’s Dispensation” , and so on.

original: Yathā devatā oghataraṇe saṃsayapakkhandā, tādisā aññe ca saṅkhātadhammānaṃ sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: yathā devatā ogha taraṇe saṃsaya pakkhandā tādisā aññe ca saṅkhāta dhammānam sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Just as the deities who are doubtful about crossing the flood are the field for the teaching of the four noble truths, so too are others who are not fully enlightened and who do not know the Master’s practice,

original: ca paṭipattiṃ ajānantā asaddhammassavana-dhāraṇa-paricaya-manasikāravipallatthabuddhikā
analyzed: ca paṭipattim a jānantā asat dhamma ssavana dhāraṇa paricaya manasikāra vipallattha buddhikā
translated: who are confused by listening to, retaining, studying, and giving attention to, false Dhamma,

original: saddhammassavana-dhāraṇa-paricayavimukhā ca bhavavimokkhesino vineyyā imissā desanāya bhājanaṃ.
analyzed: saddhamma ssavana dhāraṇa paricaya vimukhā ca bhava vimokkha īsinaḥ vineyyāḥ imissā desanāya bhājanam
translated: and who are averse to listening to, retaining, studying, and giving attention to, true Dhamma, and who are to be trained in order to be liberated from becoming.

original: Piṇḍatthā pana “appatiṭṭhaṃ anāyūha”nti padadvaye catusaccakammaṭṭhānānuyogavasena🔽yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro kusalamūlasamāyogo olīyanātidhāvanāvissajjanaṃ upāyavinibandhavidhamanaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍatthā pana appatiṭṭham pada dvaye catu acca kammaṭṭhāna anuyoga vasena  yoni soma nasikāra bahulīkāraḥ kusala mūla samāyogaḥ olīyana atidhāvana vissajjanam upāya vinibandha vidhamanam
translated: As to the meaning of the text, in the two passages beginning, “Without taking a stand” , the field for the teaching of the four noble truths is the meditator who is devoted to much wise attention by way of the four foundations of mindfulness,🔽who has accumulated the roots of skill, who has avoided slackness and agitation, who has removed the bonds of expedients,

original: micchābhinivesadūrībhāvo taṇhāvijjāvisodhanaṃ vaṭṭattayavicchedanupāyo āsavogha-yoga-ganthāgati-taṇhuppādupādānaviyogo
analyzed: micchā abhinivesa dūrībhāvaḥ taṇhā vijjā visodhanam vaṭṭa ttaya viccheda nupāyaḥ āsava ogha yoga ganthā gati taṇhuppāda upādāna viyogaḥ
translated: who has become remote from wrong adherence, who has purified craving and ignorance, who has the means to sever the three rounds , who is free from the round of craving, the floods, the bonds, the knots, the tendencies, the latent tendencies, and the kinds of clinging.

original: cetokhilavivecanaṃ abhinandananivāraṇaṃ saṃsaggātikkamo vivādamūlapariccāgo akusalakammapathaviddhaṃsanaṃ
analyzed: cetaḥ khila vivecanam abhinandana nivāraṇam saṃsagga atikkamaḥ vivāda mūla pariccāgaḥ akusala kammapatha viddhaṃsanam
translated: The clearing of the mind’s blockages, the prevention of delight, the surmounting of contact, the relinquishing of the roots of dispute, the destruction of the unprofitable courses of action,

original: micchattātivattanaṃ anusayamūlacchedo. Sabbakilesa-darathapariḷāha-sārambhapaṭippassambhanaṃ
analyzed: micchattā ativattanam anusaya mūla chedo sabba kilesa daratha pariḷāha sa ārambha paṭippassambhanam
translated: the transcending of wrong action, the cutting off of the root of the underlying tendencies, the allaying of all defilements, troubles, and fevers, and the undertaking of right action,

original: dassanasavananiddeso vijjūpamavajirūpamadhammāpadeso apacayagāmidhammavibhāvanā pahānattayadīpanā
analyzed: dassana savana niddesaḥ vijjūpama vaji rūpama dhamma apadesaḥ apacaya gāmi dhamma vibhāvanā pahāna ttaya dīpanā
translated: the demonstration of the seen and the heard, the simile of the lightning flash, the non-teaching of the True Idea, the exposition of the idea that leads to diminution, the elucidation of the three kinds of abandoning,

original: sikkhattayānuyogo samathavipassanānuṭṭhānaṃ bhāvanāsacchikiriyāsiddhi sīlakkhandhādipārisuddhīti
analyzed: sikkha tayā anuyogaḥ samatha vipassanā anuṭṭhānam bhāvanā sacchikiriyā siddhi sīlakkhandha ādi pārisuddhi iti
translated: the undertaking of the three trainings, the practice of serenity and insight, the success of the fulfilment of development, and the purification of the categories of virtue, concentration, and understanding,

original: evamādayo veditabbā.🔽Tattha yesaṃ kilesādīnaṃ vasena patiṭṭhāti saṃsīdati, yesañca abhisaṅkhārādīnaṃ vasena
analyzed: evamādayaḥ veditabbā  tattha yesam kilesa ādīnam vasena patiṭṭhāti saṃsīdati yesam ca abhisaṅkhāra ādīnam vasena
translated: should be understood.🔽Herein, the defilements, etc., by means of which it is established and sinks, and

original: āyūhati nibbuyhati, ubhayametaṃ samudayasaccaṃ, tappabhāvitā tadubhayanissitā ca
analyzed: āyūhati nibbuyhati ubhayam etam samudaya saccam tad pabhāvitā tad ubhaya nissitā ca
translated: the determinations, etc., by means of which it is accumulated and emerges, are both of them the truth of the origin of suffering. The categories that are generated by them and that are dependent on them both,

original: khandhā dukkhasaccaṃ, tadubhayamattho, “appatiṭṭhaṃ anāyūha”nti adhippetassa atthassa
analyzed: khandhāḥ dukkha saccam tat ubhayam atthaḥ appatiṭṭham an āyūhanti adhippetassa atthassa
translated: are the truth of suffering. The meaning of both of them is the meaning intended by the words “unestablished, unaccumulated” in the stanza.

original: paṭicchannaṃ katvā desanā upāyo mānaniggaṇhanavasena tassā devatāya saccābhisamayakāraṇabhāvato🔽patiṭṭhānāyūhanapaṭikkhepopadesena caturoghanirattharaṇatthikehi antadvayarahitā
