translated: Because of the many meanings of the word dhatu , the prefix upa is expressive of a particular meaning. Thus he says: “ It is led up to . . .

original: parikkhīyati nirujjhatī”ti. Vinassatīti attho. Upanīyatīti vā saraseneva jīvitassa
analyzed: parikkhīyati nirujjhati iti vinassati iti atthaḥ upanīyati iti vā sarasena iva jīvitassa
translated: It is destroyed, is the meaning. Or else, it is said that it is brought near, in the sense that it is brought near to death by the life faculty itself.

original: maraṇūpagamanaṃ vuttanti āha – “upagacchati vā, anupubbena maraṇaṃ upetīti attho”ti.
analyzed: maraṇa upagamanam vuttanti āha upagacchati vā anupubbena maraṇam upeti iti atthaḥ ti
translated: The meaning is that it is gradually brought to death.

original: Kāmañcettha “upanīyatī”ti padaṃ apākaṭakammavisesaṃ vuttaṃ. Yathā pana “sabbaṃ ārogyaṃ
analyzed: kāmam ca ittha upanīyati iti padam apākaṭa kamma visesam vuttam yathā pana sabbam ārogyam
translated: Although the word “brought near” is here stated with an obscure verbal action,

original: byādhipariyosānaṃ, sabbaṃ yobbanaṃ jarāpariyosānaṃ, sabbaṃ jīvitaṃ maraṇapariyosāna”nti,
analyzed: byādhi pariyosānam sabbam yobbanam jarā pariyosānam sabbam jīvitam maraṇa pariyosānanti
translated: nevertheless, just as “all health ends in sickness, all youth ends in old age, all life ends in death,”

original: “upanīyati jīvita”nti vuttattā “maraṇaṃ upetī”ti vuttaṃ. Kammakattuvasena hetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: upanīyati jīvitan ti vutta ttā maraṇam upeti iti vuttam kamma kattu vasena ha itam vuttam
translated: so too, since it is said that “life is brought near,” it is said that “it is brought to death.” This is said by way of the verbal action.

original: Idāni kammasādhanavasena atthaṃ dassetuṃ “yathā vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gopālena gogaṇo🔽nīyati yathicchitaṃ ṭhānaṃ. Jīvanti tena sattā, sahajātadhammā vāti jīvitaṃ, tadeva
analyzed: idāni kamma sādhana vasena attham dassetum yathā vā ati ādi vuttam gopālena go gaṇaḥ  nīyati yathā icchitam ṭhānam jīvanti tena sattā sahajāta dhammā vāti jīvitam tat eva
translated: Now, in order to point out the meaning by way of the verbal expression, it is said, “Or else, just as,” etc. A herd of cattle is led to the desired place by the cowherd.🔽By that, beings live, and the things that are born together with it live. Therefore, it is life.

original: tesaṃ anupālane ādhipaccasabbhāvato indriyanti āha “jīvitanti jīvitindriya”nti parittanti
analyzed: tesam anupālane ādhipacca sabbhāvataḥ indriyanti āha jīvitanti jīvitindriyanti parittanti
translated: Since it is the dominant condition for the protection of that, it is a faculty. Therefore, it is said that “life” is the life faculty. Limited

original: ittaraṃ. Tenāha “thoka”nti. Pabandhānupacchedassa paccayabhāvo idha jīvitassa maraṇakiccanti
analyzed: ittaram tena āha thokam ti pabandha an upacchedassa paccaya bhāvaḥ idha jīvitassa maraṇa kiccanti
translated: and so it is called “short.” The function of the life faculty here is the condition for the non- interruption of the continuity of the aggregates.

original: adhippetanti āha “sarasaparittatāya cā”tiādi. Āyūti ca paramāyu idhādhippetaṃ, tañca🔽ajjakālavasena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: adhippetanti āha sarasa paritta tāya ca atiādi āyu iti ca parama āyu idha adhippetam tat ca  ajja kāla vasena veditabbam
translated: “And by the slenderness of the thread” and so on. The “life span” is intended here as the maximum life span, and that should be understood as the time of death.

original: Imasmiñhi buddhuppāde ayaṃ kathāti jīvitassa atiittarabhāvadīpanaparā ayaṃ desanā.🔽Jīvitindriyavasena jīvitakkhayaṃ niyamento “ekacittappavattimattoyevā”ti āha, ekassa
analyzed: imasmin hi buddhuppāde ayam kathā ati jīvitassa ati ittara bhāva dīpana parā ayam desanā  jīvitindriya vasena jīvita kkhayam niyamentaḥ āha ekassa
translated: For in this arising of the Buddha, this is the teaching that shows the superiority of life.

original: cittuppādassa pavattikkhaṇamatto evāti attho. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvetuṃ🔽“yathā nāmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha pavattamānanti nemirathīsā vattantī ekeneva nemippadesena
analyzed: cittuppādassa pavatti kkhaṇa mattaḥ evā ti atthaḥ idāni tam attham upamāya vibhāvetum  yathā nāma atiādi vuttam tattha pavattamānanti nemi rathīsā vattantī ekena iva nemi ppadesena
translated: “The moment of the arising of a single consciousness” is said in order to determine the exhaustion of life by means of the life faculty. The meaning is: the moment of the arising of a single consciousness.🔽Now, in order to illustrate that meaning by means of a simile,🔽“Just as, when a wheel is turning” and so on is said. Herein, “when it is turning” means that the wheel is turning with a single point of the rim;

original: pavattati ekasmiṃ khaṇeti adhippāyo. “Ekeneva tiṭṭhatī”ti etthāpi eseva nayo. Ekacittakkhaṇikanti
analyzed: pavattati ekasmin khaṇe ti adhippāyaḥ ekena iva tiṭṭhati iti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ eka citta khaṇikam ti
translated: the meaning is: in a single moment. The same method applies to “when it is standing.” “In the moment of a single consciousness” means

original: ekacittakkhaṇamattavantaṃ. Tasmiṃ citteti tasmiṃ yasmiṃ kismiñci ekasmiṃ citte. Niruddhamatteti
analyzed: eka citta kkhaṇa mattavantam tasmin citta iti tasmin yasmin kismiñci ekasmin citte niruddha matta iti
translated: and it is only for a single moment of consciousness. In that consciousness: in that, in any one of the many kinds of, consciousness. As soon as it has ceased:

original: niruddhabhāvappattamatte. Niruddhoti vuccatīti matoti vuccati taṃsamaṅgī satto paramatthato.
analyzed: niruddha bhāva ppatta matte niruddho ti vuccati iti mataḥ iti vuccati tad samaṅgī satto paramatthato
translated: as soon as it has reached the state of having ceased. It is called “ceased”: it is reckoned that the being who is a mere collection of the states of consciousness is in the ultimate sense dead.

original: Avisesaviduno pana aviññāyamānantarena anusandhānassa niruddhanaṃ nirodhaṃ sallakkhenti.🔽Yathāvuttamatthaṃ suttena vibhāvetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tena tīsupi kālesu sattānaṃ
analyzed: avisesa viduno pana a viññāyamāna ntarena anusandhānassa niruddhanam nirodham sallakkhenti  yathāvuttam attham suttena vibhāvetum yathā āha atiādi vuttam tena tīsu pi kālesu sattānam
translated: But those who are not discerning do not notice the interval and they reckon cessation as cessation of life.

original: paramatthato jīvanaṃ maraṇaṃ cittakkhaṇavasenevāti dasseti.
translated: In order to demonstrate the meaning just stated by means of a sutta he said, “As it is said” , etc. By that he shows that in the three periods of time the living and dying of beings is only by way of the moment of consciousness.

original: Jīvitanti jīvitindriyaṃ. Attabhāvoti jīvitavedanāviññāṇāni ṭhapetvā avasiṭṭhadhammā
analyzed: jīvitanti jīvita indriyam atta bhāvaḥ ti jīvita vedanā viññāṇāni ṭhapetvā avasiṭṭha dhammā
translated: Life: the life faculty. The individual essence: the states of being other than the life faculty, feeling, and consciousness are intended.

original: adhippetā. Sukhadukkhāti sukhadukkhā vedanā, upekkhāpi idha sukhadukkhāsveva antogadhā
analyzed: adhippetā sukha dukkhā ati sukha dukkhā vedanā upekkhā api idha sukha dukkhāsu eva antogadhā
translated: Pleasure and pain: pleasant and painful feeling. Equanimity is included here too, because it is desirable and undesirable.

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhabhāvato. Kevalāti attanā, niccabhāvena vā avomissā. Ekacittasamāyuttāti
analyzed: kevalā ati attanā nicca bhāvena vā avomissā eka citta samāyuttā ti
translated: Only: either by itself or by its continuity. Associated with a single consciousness:

original: ekakena cittena sahitā. Lahuso vattate khaṇoti vuttanayena ekacittakkhaṇikatāya lahuko
analyzed: ekakena cittena sahitā lahusaḥ vattate khaṇo ti vutta nayena eka citta khaṇika tāya lahukaḥ
translated: and it is associated with a single consciousness.🔽The moment of life, etc., is swift,

original: atiittaro jīvitādīnaṃ khaṇo vattati.
analyzed: atiittaraḥ jīvita ādīnam khaṇaḥ vattati
translated: in the way stated thus, “Swiftly it comes to an end, the moment” .🔽Those that have ceased in one who is dying

original: Ye niruddhā marantassāti cavantassa sattassa cutito uddhaṃ niruddhāti vattabbā ye
analyzed: ye niruddhāḥ marantassa ati cavantassa sattassa cutitaḥ uddham niruddhā ati vattabbāḥ ye
translated: are the aggregates that should be called “ceased” after the death of a being who is passing away.🔽Or those that are present here

original: khandhā. Tiṭṭhamānassa vā idhāti ye vā idha pavattiyaṃ tiṭṭhamānassa dharantassa🔽bhaṅgappattiyā niruddhā khandhā, sabbepi sadisā te sabbepi ekasadisā gatā atthaṅgatā
analyzed: khandhāḥ tiṭṭhamānassa vai idha ati ye vai idha pavattiyam tiṭṭhamānassa dharantassa  bhaṅga ppattiyā niruddhā khandhā sabbe pi sadisā te sabbe pi eka sadisā gatā atthaṅgatā
translated: are the aggregates that have ceased by reaching dissolution in the course of an existence here.🔽All are the same🔽All are the same, that is, they are all alike in that they have gone to destruction, in that they have disappeared, in that they have vanished without returning to re-arise.

original: appaṭisandhiyā puna āgantvā paṭisandhānābhāvena vigatā. Yathā hi cutikhandhā na nibbattanti,
analyzed: appaṭisandhiyā puna āgantvā paṭisandhāna abhāvena vigatāḥ yathā hi cuti khandhāḥ na nibbattanti
translated: For just as the aggregates at death do not arise again, so too those that occurred previously.

original: evaṃ tato pubbepi khandhā. Tasmā ekacittakkhaṇikaṃ sattānaṃ jīvitanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: evam tatas pubbe api khandhāḥ tasmai eka citta khaṇikam sattānam jīvitanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: So the meaning intended is that the life of beings lasts for a single conscious moment.🔽Not born without the arisen

original: Anibbattena na jātoti anuppannena cittena jāto na hoti “anāgate cittakkhaṇe na jīvittha
analyzed: a nibbattena na jātaḥ ti anuppannena cittena jātaḥ na hoti anāgate citta kkhaṇe na jīvittha
translated: One is not born without consciousness arisen in the future. In the future conscious moment one does not live.

original: na jīvati jīvissatī”ti vattabbato. Paccuppannena vattamānena cittena jīvati jīvamāno
analyzed: na jīvati jīvissati iti vattabbataḥ paccuppannena vattamānena cittena jīvati jīvamānaḥ
translated: and “he is not living, he will live” . He is living, he is living now, by means of the present, occurring consciousness.

original: nāma hoti, na jīvittha na jīvissati. Cittabhaṅgā mato lokoti cuticittassa viya sabbassapi
analyzed: nāma hoti na jīvittha na jīvissati citta bhaṅgā mataḥ loko ti cuti cittassa viya sabbassa api
translated: He is not living, he did not live, he will not live, by means of the past and future consciousnesses. The world is dead, with the dissolution of consciousness,

original: tassa tassa cittassa bhaṅgappattiyā ayaṃ loko paramatthato mato nāma hoti “atīte
analyzed: tassa tassa cittassa bhaṅga ppattiyā ayam loko paramatthataḥ mataḥ nāma hoti atīte
translated: in the ultimate sense, the world is dead, with the dissolution of that or the other consciousness, as with the death-consciousness.

original: cittakkhaṇe jīvittha na jīvati na jīvissatī”ti vattabbato, niruddhassa appaṭisandhikattā.🔽Evaṃ santepi paññatti paramatthiyā, yāyaṃ taṃ taṃ pavattaṃ cittaṃ upādāya “tisso🔽jīvati, phusso jīvatī”ti vacanappavattiyā visayabhūtā santānapaññatti, sā ettha paramatthiyā
analyzed: citta kkhaṇe jīvittha na jīvati na jīvissati iti vattabbataḥ niruddhassa appaṭisandhika ttā  evam sante pi paññatti paramatthiyā yā ayam tam tam pavattam cittam upādāya tissaḥ  jīvati phussaḥ jīvati iti vacana ppavattiyā visaya bhūtā santāna paññatti sā ettha paramatthiyā
translated: “In the past consciousness-moment he lived, he does not live, he will not live,” because of the non-relinking of the ceased .

original: paramatthabhūtā. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “nāmagottaṃ na jīratī”ti.🔽Na santi tāṇāti jaraṃ upagatassa tato taṃnimittaṃ yaṃ vā pāpakārino pāpakammānaṃ
analyzed: paramattha bhūtā tathā hi vuttam nāma gottam na jīrati iti 🔽na santi jaram upagatassa tatas tad nimittam yam vā pāpa kārinaḥ pāpa kammānam
translated: Even so, the designation is ultimate, and the continuity-designation, which is the objective domain of the statement “Three lives, Phussa lives,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way of the occurrence of the statement, “Three lives, Phussa,” by way

original: upaṭṭhānavasena puññakārino piyavippayogavasena cittadukkhaṃ ubhayesampi bandhanacchedanādivasena🔽vitujjamānaṃ anappakaṃ sarīradukkhaṃ sammohappatti ca hoti, tato tāyantā na santi.
analyzed: upaṭṭhāna vasena puñña kārino piya vippayoga vasena citta dukkham ubhayesam pi bandhana chedana ādi vasena  vitujjamānam anappakam sarīra dukkham sammoha ppatti ca hoti tatas tāyantāḥ na santi
translated: and for the meritorious person through the means of attendance, and for both through the means of separation from the dear person, there is mental suffering,🔽and there is bodily suffering, which is not slight, and there is bewilderment, which is produced by the cutting of the bonds, etc.,🔽and there is no one to take them away.🔽Therefore it is said: “There is no one able to be a refuge, a haven, a place of rest.”

original: Tenāha – “tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ saraṇaṃ bhavituṃ samatthā nāma keci natthī”ti. Bhāyati etasmāti
analyzed: tena āha tāṇam leṇam saraṇam bhavitum samatthāḥ nāma keci na atthi iti bhāyati etasmā iti
translated: Because of fear from this,

original: bhayaṃ, bhayanimittanti āha “bhayavatthū”ti. Taggahaṇena ca cittutrāsalakkhaṇaṃ bhayaṃ
analyzed: bhayam bhaya nimittanti āha tad gahaṇena ca cittu trāsa lakkhaṇam bhayam
translated: fear is a sign of fear. Therefore it is said: “a basis for fear.” And by the taking of that, fear, which has the characteristic of mental trembling,🔽is taken. When there is a sign, there is a foretoken.

original: gahitameva, sati nimitte nemittaṃ santamevāti. Pubbacetananti ekāvajjanavīthiyaṃ🔽nānāvajjanavīthiyaṃ sampavattaṃ upacārajjhānacetanaṃ. Aparacetananti vasībhāvāpādanavasena
analyzed: gahitam eva sati nimitte nemittam santam eva ati pubba cetanam ti ekāvajjana vīthiyam  nānā vajjana vīthiyam sampavattam upacāra jhāna cetanam apara cetanan ti vasībhāva āpādana vasena
translated: The prior volition is the volition of access concentration occurring in a single cognitive process or🔽in a series of cognitive processes. The subsequent volition is the volition of absorption concentration occurring

original: parato samāpajjanavasena ca pavattaṃ samāpatticetanaṃ. Muñcacetananti vikkhambhanavasena
analyzed: paratas samāpajjana vasena ca pavattam samāpatti cetanam muñca cetanan ti vikkhambhana vasena
translated: in the sense of establishing mastery and in the sense of attaining absorption subsequently. The volition of release is the volition occurring in the sense of suppression.

original: pavattaṃ paṭhamappanācetanaṃ. Kusalajjhānassa vipākajjhāneva labbhamānaṃ sukhaṃ jhānasukhaṃ.🔽Iṭṭhapariyāyo cettha sukha-saddo. Jhāne apekkhā jhānanikanti. Jhānassa assādavasena
analyzed: pavattam paṭhama ppanā cetanam kusala jhānassa vipāka jjhānā iva labbhamānam sukham jhāna sukham  iṭṭha pariyāyaḥ ca ittha sukha saddaḥ jhāne apekkhā jhāna nikanti jhānassa assāda vasena
translated: and the first impulsion-cetanā of the process. The pleasure that is found in the jhāna that is the result of profitable jhāna is jhāna pleasure.🔽Herein, the word “pleasure” is in the sense of desirable. Longing is the desire for jhāna.🔽The greed that occurs in the aspect of relishing jhāna is the relish of jhāna. By means of that the Brahmās, on emerging from jhāna, utter the words, “Oh, what pleasure! Oh, what pleasure!”

original: pavatto lobho jhānassādo. Yena te te brahmāno jhānato vuṭṭhāya “aho sukhaṃ aho sukha”nti🔽vācaṃ nicchāresunti. Yathā devā sukhabahulā tihetupaṭisandhikāvāti paṭipajjantā jhānaṃ
analyzed: pavattaḥ lobhaḥ jhāna sādaḥ yena te te brahmānaḥ jhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya aho sukham aho sukhanti  vācam yathā devā sukha bahulā ti hetu paṭisandhikā avāti paṭipajjantā jhānam
translated: because they are pleased with the pleasure of jhāna.🔽Since only gods of the sense sphere who have rebirth- linking with three roots are able to attain jhāna by undertaking it thus, “We shall be possessed of much pleasure,”

original: adhigantuṃ bhabbā, na itareti “kāmāvacaradevesū”ti vuttaṃ. Kāmāvacarā ca uparidevā
analyzed: adhigantum bhabbāḥ na itare iti kāmāvacara devesu iti vuttam kāmāvacarā ca uparidevā
translated: it is said, “Among gods of the sense sphere.” And the gods of the sense sphere and the higher gods are to be regarded as a single group as “gods of the sense sphere.”

original: ca kāmāvacaradevāti ekadesasarūpekaseso daṭṭhabbo. Tena manussānampi ekaccānaṃ sabbesampi🔽vā saṅgaho siddho hoti patthanāparikappanāya visayabhāvato. Tenāha “aho vatime ca…pe…
analyzed: ca kāmāvacara deva ati eka desa sarūpa ikasesaḥ daṭṭhabbo tena manussānam pi ekaccānam sabbesam pi  vā saṅgahaḥ siddhaḥ hoti patthanā parikappanāya visaya bhāvataḥ tena āha aho vatime cape
translated: So the inclusion of human beings is also established, since they are the field for the aspiration and the surmise.🔽That is why it was said above, “May they be … may they remain” .

original: tiṭṭheyyu”nti. Thullāni phusitāni vipphurāni etthāti thullaphusitako, kālo, deso
analyzed: tiṭṭheyyunti thullāni phusitāni vipphurāni ettha ati thullaphusitakaḥ kālaḥ deso
translated: The time and the place where there is much that is swollen, that is, inflated, is called “the time of swelling” .

original: vā. Tasmiṃ thullaphusitake.
analyzed: vā tasmin thullaphusitake
translated: “In the Thullaccaya” .

original: “Puññāni kayirātha sukhāvahānī”ti vuttattā “aniyyānikaṃ vaṭṭakathaṃ kathetī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: puññāni kayirātha sukha āvahāni iti vutta ttā aniyyānikam vaṭṭa katham katheti iti vuttam
translated: “He is expounding a doctrine of futility, a doctrine of nihilism,” because of the words “Let him make merit that brings happiness” .🔽The world is “worldliness” in the sense of being worn away , and it is also “worldliness” in the sense of being soiled by defilements.🔽But the “world” is “worldliness” in the sense of being the world’s bait .

original: Lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena loko, kilesehi āmasitabbato āmisañcāti lokāmisaṃ. Nippariyāyāmisaṃ
analyzed: lujjana palujjana ṭhena lokaḥ kilesehi āmasitabbataḥ āmisam ca ati loka āmisam nippariyāya āmisam
translated: The bait of the world is “worldliness” .🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.

original: pana loke āmisantipi lokāmisaṃ. Pariyāyeti sabhāvato parivattetvā ñāpeti etenāti
analyzed: pana loke loka āmisam loka āmisam pariyāyeti sabhāvataḥ parivattetvā ñāpeti etena ati
translated: The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.

original: pariyāyo, leso, kāraṇaṃ vāti āha “nippariyāyena cattāro paccayā”ti, vaṭṭassa ekantato
analyzed: pariyāyaḥ lesaḥ kāraṇam vā ti āha nippariyāyena cattāro paccayā ti vaṭṭassa ekantato
translated: The four conditions are “without exception” .🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.

original: bālalokeheva āmasitabbabhāvato pariyāyāmisatā vuttā. Idha pari..pe… adhippetaṃ vivaṭṭapaṭiyogino
analyzed: bāla lokehi iva āmasitabba bhāvataḥ vuttāḥ idha paripe adhippetam vivaṭṭa paṭiyogino
translated: The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.

original: icchitattā. Catupaccayāpekkhañhi pahānaṃ. Ekaccassa sakalavaṭṭāpekkhappahānassapi
analyzed: icchita ttā catu paccaya apekkham hi pahānam ekaccassa sakala vaṭṭa apekkha ppahānassa api
translated: The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.

original: paccayo hotīti “vaṭṭatiyevā”ti sāsaṅkaṃ vadati. Vūpasamati ettha sakalavaṭṭadukkhanti🔽santi, asaṅkhatadhātūti āha “nibbānasaṅkhāta”nti.
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti iti vaṭṭatiyā iva ati sa āsaṅkam vadati vūpasamati ettha sakala vaṭṭa dukkham ti 🔽santi asaṅkhata dhātū ti āha nibbāna saṅkhātanti
translated: The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the world.🔽The bait of the world is “worldliness” in the sense of being the bait of the

original: Upanīyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: upanīya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Upanīya Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Accentisuttavaṇṇanā🔽4. Kālayanti khepentīti kālā. Purebhattādayo hi kālā dhammappavattimattatāya paramatthato
analyzed: kālayanti khepenti iti kālā purebhatta ādayaḥ hi kālāḥ dhamma ppavattimattatāya paramatthato
translated: The Commentary on the Accenti Sutta

original: avijjamānāpi lokasaṅketamattasiddhā tassāyeva dhammappavattiyā gatagatāya anivattanato
analyzed: a vijjamānā api loka saṅketa matta siddhā tassāya eva dhamma ppavattiyā gata gatāya a nivattanato
translated: The times are called “kāla” because they “khepanta” or “khepayanti,” i.e., they “throw away” or “throw off” the past and future moments of consciousness. Although the past and future moments of consciousness do not exist in the ultimate sense, they are established by mere conventional usage in the world.🔽The past and future moments of consciousness are “thrown away” or “thrown off” by the present moment of consciousness, which is the only moment of consciousness that exists in the ultimate sense.

original: taṃ taṃ dhammappavattiṃ khepentā vināsayantā viya sayañca tāhi saddhiṃ accentā viya
analyzed: tam tam dhamma ppavattim khepentā vināsayantā viya sayam ca tāhi saddhim accentā viya
translated: The present moment of consciousness “throws away” or “throws off” the past and future moments of consciousness as if it were throwing them away or throwing them off.

original: honti. Tenāha – “kālo ghasati bhūtāni, sabbāneva sahattanā”ti. “Tarayanti rattiyo”ti🔽etthāpi vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo. “Etaṃ bhayaṃ maraṇe pekkhamāno”ti vuccamānattā
analyzed: honti tena āha kālaḥ ghasati bhūtāni sabbān eva tarayanti rattiyā iti  ettha api vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbaḥ etam bhayam maraṇe pekkhamānaḥ iti vuccamāna ttā
translated: Therefore it is said: “Kālo ghasati bhūtāni, sabbāneva sahattanā” .🔽In the phrase “tarayanti rattiyo,” the meaning should be understood in the same way as explained above.🔽The meaning is stated as “they carry the person to the place of death” because it is said: “Etaṃ bhayaṃ maraṇe pekkhamāno” .

original: puggalaṃ maraṇūpagamanāya tarayantīti attho vutto. Vayoguṇāti ettha koṭṭhāsā guṇā.🔽Titthiyānaṃ hi carimacittena sakalacitte vayasamūhe vayasamaññāti āha – “paṭhamamajjhimapacchimavayānaṃ
analyzed: puggalam maraṇa upagamanāya tarayanti iti atthaḥ vuttaḥ vayaḥ guṇā ti ettha koṭṭhāsāḥ guṇā 🔽titthiyānam hi carima cittena sakala citte vaya samūhe vayasamaññā ti āha paṭhama majjhima pacchima vayānam
translated: In the phrase “vayoguṇā,” the “guṇā” are the parts.

original: guṇā, rāsayoti attho”ti. Ānisaṃsaṭṭho guṇaṭṭho “vākaciraṃ nivāsesiṃ, dvādasaguṇamupāgata”ntiādīsu
analyzed: guṇāḥ rāsayo ti ānisaṃsaṭṭhaḥ guṇaṭṭhaḥ nivāsesim dvādasaguṇam upāgata nti ādīsu
translated: and guṇa means quality, as in the passage, “I have lived in the bark garment for twelve years” .

original: viya. “Tandiguṇāhaṃ karissāmi, diguṇaṃ diguṇaṃ vaddheyyā”ti ca evamādīsu pana tabbhāvavuttiattho guṇaṭṭho.
analyzed: viya tat diguṇā aham karissāmi diguṇam diguṇam ca evamādīsu pana tad bhāva vutti atthaḥ guṇa ṭṭhaḥ
translated: In such passages as “I will make a quality of slowness” and “It will increase by a double, a double” the meaning of guṇa is that of a state of being.

original: “Asaṅkhyeyyāni nāmāni, saguṇena mahesino;
analyzed: asaṅkhyeyyāni nāmāni saguṇena mahesino
translated: In such passages as “The great seer’s names are innumerable,

original: Guṇena nāmamuddheyyaṃ, api nāma sahassato”ti. –
analyzed: guṇena nāmam uddheyyam api nāma
translated: And by his quality his name is lifted up Even beyond a thousand” the meaning of guṇa is that of praise.

original: Ādīsu pasaṃsaṭṭho guṇaṭṭho daṭṭhabbo. “Vayoguṇā anupubbaṃ jahantī”ti ettha attho
analyzed: ādīsu pasaṃsaṭṭhaḥ guṇaṭṭhaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ vayaḥ guṇāḥ anupubbam jahanti iti ettha atthaḥ
translated: In the passage, “The qualities of age are gradually lost” the meaning of guṇa is that of

original: “accenti kālā”ti ettha vuttanayo eva. Paṭhamamajjhimavayāti paṭhamaggahaṇañcettha
analyzed: kālā ti ettha vutta nayaḥ eva paṭhama majjhima vayā ti paṭhama ggahaṇam ca ittha
translated: “The times are passing” the method of explanation is the same as that given above.

original: vayassa gatassa apunarāvattidassanatthaṃ kataṃ. Tenevāha – “maraṇakkhaṇe pana tayopi vayā jahantevā”ti.
analyzed: vayassa gatassa apunarāvatti dassana attham katam tena iva āha maraṇa kkhaṇe pana vayā jahantā iva ati
translated: The first and middle ages are mentioned here in order to show that when the age has gone it does not return. That is why it is said, “But at the moment of death all three ages are abandoned” .

original: Ettha ca pāḷiyaṃ “accenti kālā”ti sāmaññato kālassa apagamanaṃ dassitaṃ, puna taṃ
analyzed: ettha ca pāḷiyam sāmaññato kālassa apagamanam dassitam puna tam
translated: And here the passing of time in general is shown in the text by the words, “The times are passing” .

original: visesatopi dassetuṃ itaradvayaṃ vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana mudindriyassa vasena “vayoguṇā
analyzed: visesataḥ api dassetum itara dvayam vuttam aṭṭhakathā ayam pana mud indriyassa vasena vayaḥ guṇā
translated: and the other two are mentioned to show the difference. But in the Commentary it is said with reference to one of dull faculties: “The years and the qualities

original: anupubbaṃ jahantī”ti vuttaṃ, majjhimindriyassa vasena “tarayanti rattiyo”ti vuttanti🔽adhippāyena “kālāti purebhattādayo kālā”ti vuttaṃ. Tasmā tattha ādi-saddena pacchābhattapaṭhamayāma-muhuttakālādi-kālakoṭṭhāso
analyzed: anupubbam jahanti iti vuttam majjhima indriyassa vasena tarayanti rattiyaḥ ti vuttam ti  adhippāyena kāla ati purebhatta ādayaḥ kāla ati vuttam tasmā tattha ādi saddena pacchābhatta paṭhama yāma muhutta kāla ādi kāla koṭṭhāso
translated: are gradually lost,” and with reference to one of medium faculties: “The nights pass by.”🔽So it is with this intention that it is said here: “The time is the times of before-breakfast, etc.” Therefore the beginning should be understood as referring to the divisions of time such as the time of after-breakfast, the first watch of the night, and the moment,

original: eva aṇupabhedo kālavibhāgo gahitoti veditabbo. Sesanti idha dvīsu gāthāsu pacchimaddho.
analyzed: eva aṇupabhedaḥ kālavibhāgaḥ gahito ti veditabbo idha dvīsu gāthāsu
translated: which are the ultimate subdivisions of time. The rest: here the latter of the two verses.

original: So hi idha atthato adhigatattā anantarasutte ca vuttattā atidisito.
analyzed: saḥ hi idha atthataḥ adhigata ttā anantara sutte ca vutta ttā atidisitaḥ
translated: For that is referred to here by implication because it has already been stated in the immediately preceding sutta and because it has already been understood in meaning.

original: Accentisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: accenti sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Accuti sutta is ended.

original: 5. Katichindasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: katichinda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Kati chinda sutta

original: 5. Chindantoti samucchindanto. Kati chindeyyāti kittake pāpadhamme samucchindeyya,🔽anuppattidhammataṃ pāpeyya. Sesapadesupīti sesesupi dvīsu padesu. Jahanto kati jaheyya,
analyzed: chindanto ti samucchindanto kati chindeyya ati kittake pāpa dhamme samucchindeyya 🔽anuppatti dhamma tam sesa padesu pi iti sesesu pi dvīsu padesu jahantaḥ kati jaheyya
translated: Chindanto: cutting off, severing. Kati chindeyya: how many bad states would he cut off, bring to an end?🔽Jahanto kati jaheyya: how many would he abandon, give up?

original: bhāvento kati uttari bhāveyyāti imamatthaṃ “eseva nayo”ti iminā atidisati. Catutthapadassa
analyzed: bhāvento kati uttari bhāveyyāti imam attham iminā atidisati catuttha padassa
translated: “When he has developed how many more should he develop?” — this is the meaning of the question. The Master shows the meaning of the fourth line in the same way as the meaning of the first line.🔽The meaning of the fourth line is shown in the same way as the meaning of the first line.🔽If that is so, then why is it stated in another way?

original: pana attho sarūpeneva dassito. Atthato ekanti bhāvatthato ekaṃ. Yadi evaṃ kimatthaṃ
analyzed: pana atthaḥ sarūpena iva dassitaḥ atthataḥ ekam ti bhāva tthataḥ ekam yadi evam kimattham
translated: The meaning is the same, but the expression is different.

original: pariyāyantaraṃ gahitanti āha “gāthābandhassa panā”tiādi. Atthato ettha punarutti🔽atthevāti āha “saddapunaruttiṃ vajjayantī”ti. Saṅgaṃ atikkamayatīti saṅgātigoti āha “ayamevattho”ti.🔽Oraṃ vuccati kāmadhātu, paṭisandhiyā paccayabhāvena tañca bhajantīti orambhāgiyāni.🔽Tattha ca kammaṃ tabbipākaṃ satte dukkhaṃ, kammunā vipākaṃ, sattena dukkhaṃ saṃyojentīti🔽saṃyojanāni, sakkāyadiṭṭhi-vicikicchā-sīlabbataparāmāsa-kāmarāga-paṭighā. Uddhaṃ
analyzed: pariyāya antaram gahitanti āha gāthābandhassa pana atiādi atthataḥ ettha punarutti  attha iva ati āha sadda punaruttim vajjayanti iti saṅgam atikkamayati iti saṅga atigo iti āha ayam eva atthā iti  oram vuccati kāmadhātu paṭisandhiyā paccaya bhāvena tat ca bhajanti iti orambhāgiyāni  tattha ca kammam tad vipākam satte dukkham kammunā vipākam sattena dukkham saṃyojenti iti  saṃyojanāni sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsa kāma rāga paṭighāḥ uddhaṃ
translated: The expression “lower fetters” is used in the sense of “those that are in the lower part.”

original: vuccati catasso arūpadhātuyo, vuttanayena taṃ bhajantīti uddhambhāgiyāni, saṃyojanāni
analyzed: vuccati catasso arūpa dhātuyaḥ vutta nayena tam bhajanti iti uddhambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni
translated: The expression “higher fetters” is used in the sense of “those that are in the higher part.”

original: rūpārūparāgamānuddhaccāvijjā. Āropitavacanānurūpeneva evamāhāti “pañca chinde pañca
analyzed: āropita vacana anurūpena iva evam āha ati pañca chinde pañca
translated: and sensual desire, resistance, conceit, ignorance.🔽He spoke thus in accordance with the words of the devatā, saying, “Cut off five,🔽Abandon five,” in order that she might easily grasp the meaning.

original: jahe”ti evaṃ kathesi tassā devatāya sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ. Na kevalaṃ tāya devatāya vuttavacanānurūpato🔽eva, atha kho tesu saṃyojanesu vattabbākāratopīti dassetuṃ “atha vā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: jaha iti evam kathesi tassāḥ devatāya sukha ggahaṇa attham na kevalam tāya devatāya vutta vacana anurūpataḥ  eva atha kho tesu saṃyojanesu vattabba ākārataḥ pi iti dassetum atha vā itiādi vuttam
translated: Not only in accordance with the words spoken by the devatā,🔽but also in accordance with the way in which the fetters should be treated.

original: Tena orambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni nāma garūni ducchedāni gāḷhabandhanabhāvato, tasmā tāni
analyzed: tena orambhāgiya saṃyojanāni nāma garūni ducchedāni tasmā tāni
translated: To show this, the following is said: “Or else, the fetters called ‘lower fetters’ are heavy and hard to cut through because they are a thick bondage.

original: sandhāya “pañca chinde”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sandhāya pañca chinda iti vuttam
translated: Therefore, with reference to them, it is said, ‘Cut off five.’

original: Uddhambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni pana lahūni succhedāni heṭṭhā pavattitānukkamena bhāvanānayena
analyzed: uddhambhāgiya saṃyojanāni pana lahūni su chedāni heṭṭhā pavatti tā anukkamena bhāvanā nayena
translated: The fetters called ‘higher fetters’ are light and easy to cut through because they are to be abandoned by the method of development that occurs in the order of the lower and higher fetters.

original: pahātabbato, tasmā tāni sandhāya “pañca jahe”ti vuttaṃ. Tenāha “pādesu baddhapāsasakuṇo
analyzed: pahātabbato tasmā tāni sandhāya pañca jaha iti vuttam tena āha pādesu baddha pāsa sakuṇaḥ
translated: Therefore, with reference to them, it is said, ‘Abandon five.’ Therefore it is said, ‘Like a bird with a snare on its foot’ and so on.

original: viyā”tiādi. Visesanti bhāvanānaṃ visesaṃ vipassanābhāvanaṃ bhāvento uppādento vipaccento
analyzed: viya ati ādi bhāvanānam visesam vipassanā bhāvanam bhāventaḥ uppādentaḥ vipaccentaḥ
translated: ‘Distinction’: the distinction of the developments, that is, the development of insight. Developing, producing, ripening,

original: vaḍḍhento ca. Saṃsārapaṅke sañjanaṭṭhena rāgo eva saṅgo “rāgasaṅgo”. Esa nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: ca saṃsāra paṅke sañjana ṭṭhena rāgaḥ eva saṅgaḥ rāga saṅgaḥ esa nayo sesesu pi
translated: In the sense of binding in the mud of the round of rebirths, it is craving itself that is the fetter, and so it is called “the fetter of craving.” The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: Yasmā ettha rāga-moha-diṭṭhi-tabbhāgiyasakkāyadiṭṭhi-sīlabbataparāmāsa-kāmarāgāvijjā🔽atthato oghā eva, itare tadekaṭṭhā, tasmā bhagavā saṃyojanappahānasaṅgātikkamehi
analyzed: yasmai ettha rāga moha diṭṭhi tabbhāgiya sakkāya diṭṭhi sīla bbata parāmāsa kāma rāga avijjā  atthataḥ oghāḥ eva itare tad ekaṭṭhā tasmai bhagavā saṃyojana ppahāna saṅga atikkamehi
translated: Herein, craving, delusion, false view, the false view of individuality which is a concomitant of these, adherence to rules and vows, sensual desire, and ignorance🔽are the floods in meaning, while the others are included in them.🔽Therefore the Blessed One spoke of crossing the floods by the abandoning of the fetters and by the surmounting of the clingings.

original: oghataraṇaṃ kathesi. Lokiyalokuttarāni kathitāni “bhāvaye”ti pubbabhāgāya maggabhāvanāya adhippetattā.
analyzed: ogha taraṇam kathesi lokiya lokuttarāni kathitāni bhāvaya iti pubbabhāgāya magga bhāvanāya adhippeta ttā
translated: The mundane and supramundane are stated as the “things to be developed” because they are intended for the development of the path in its preliminary stage.

original: Katichindasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: katichinda sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “Questions on the Threads” is finished.

original: 6. Jāgarasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Thread on the Watchful🔽“Watchful” is a word of respect for the heedful. That is why it is said, “When the faculties are watchful” .

original: 6. Jāgaratanti anādare sāmivacanaṃ. Tenāha “indriyesu jāgarantesū”ti. “Vissajjanagāthāyaṃ🔽panā”ti imassa padassa “ayamattho veditabbo”ti iminā sambandho. Pucchāgāthāya pana
analyzed: anādare sāmi vacanam tena āha indriyesu vissajjana gāthāyam  pana ati imassa padassa ayam atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ti iminā sambandhaḥ pucchāgāthāya pana
translated: In the answer verse,🔽the meaning of this word should be understood thus. But the meaning of the question verse

original: attho imināva nayena viññāyatīti adhippāyo. Pañca jāgarataṃ suttāti ettha “suttā”ti
analyzed: atthaḥ iminā ava nayena viññāyati iti adhippāyo pañca jāgaratam suttā ti ettha suttā ti
translated: is understood in this way, is the intention. “Five watchful and five sleeping” : here “sleeping” is a word for

original: padaṃ apekkhitvā pañcāti paccattavacanaṃ “jāgarata”nti padaṃ apekkhitvā sāmivasena
analyzed: padam apekkhitvā pañcāti paccatta vacanam padam apekkhitvā sāmi vasena
translated: “Five” is a distributive expression, depending on the word “awake” as a counterpart.

original: pariṇāmetabbaṃ “pañcannaṃ jāgarata”nti. Tenāha – “pañcasu indriyesu jāgarantesū”ti,
analyzed: pariṇāmetabbam tena āha pañcasu indriyesu jāgarantesu iti
translated: “Five” is a distributive expression. The word “awake” should be construed as a locative in apposition to “five” in the way that “in the five” is construed. Thus it is said: “in the five faculties that are awake.”

original: jāgarantesu baddhābhāvena sakiccappasutatāya sakiccasamatthatāya cāti attho. Sottaṃva
analyzed: jāgarantesu baddha abhāvena sa kicca ppasuta tāya sa kicca samattha tāya ca ati attho
translated: The meaning is: in those that are awake by being bound to their own duties and by being capable of their own duties. “Asleep”

original: suttā pamādaniddābhāvato. Tameva suttabhāvaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānāya kathāya dassetuṃ
analyzed: suttā pamāda niddā abhāvataḥ tam eva sutta bhāvam puggala adhiṭṭhānāya kathāya dassetuṃ
translated: means as if asleep, because of the absence of heedlessness and sleep. In order to show that very state of being asleep by means of a discourse based on persons,

original: “kasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pamajjati, pamādo vā etassa atthīti pamādo, tassa bhāvo pamādatā,
analyzed: kasmā itiādi vuttam pamajjati pamādaḥ vai etassa atthi iti pamādaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ pamāda tā
translated: “Why is it said …?” is said. He is heedless, or he has heedlessness, thus he is heedless; the state of that is heedlessness.

original: tāya, pamattabhāvenāti attho.
analyzed: tāya pamatta bhāvena ati attho
translated: By that, by the state of heedlessness, is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ gāthāya paṭhamassa pādassa atthaṃ vatvā dutiyassa vattuṃ “evaṃ suttesū”tiādi
analyzed: evam gāthāya paṭhamassa pādassa attham vatvā dutiyassa vattum evam suttesu itiādi
translated: Having thus stated the meaning of the first line of the stanza, in order to state the meaning of the second line, “Thus in those asleep” is said.

original: vuttaṃ. Tassattho vuttanayena veditabbo. Yasmā appahīnasupanakiriyāvasena sanīvaraṇassa
analyzed: vuttam tassa atthaḥ vutta nayena veditabbaḥ yasmai appahīna supana kiriyā vasena sa nīvaraṇassa
translated: The meaning of that should be understood in the way already stated. Because of the performance of sleep that has not been abandoned,

original: puggalassa anuppannarāgarajādayo uppajjanti, uppannā pavaḍḍhanti, tasmā vuttaṃ “nīvaraṇeheva
analyzed: puggalassa anuppanna rāga raja ādayaḥ uppajjanti uppannā pavaḍḍhanti tasmā vuttam nīvaraṇehi iva
translated: Lust, hate, etc., that have not arisen in a person arise, and those that have arisen increase. Hence it is said that the defilement-mudd is “dug up by the hindrances.”

original: kilesarajaṃ ādiyatī”ti. Tenevāha “purimā”tiādi. Purimānaṃ pacchimānaṃ aparāparuppattiyā🔽paccayabhāvo hettha ādiyanaṃ. Pañcahi indriyehi parisujjhatīti maggapariyāpannehi
analyzed: kilesa rajam ādiyati iti tena iva āha purima atiādi purimānam pacchimānam apara apara uppattiyā  paccaya bhāvaḥ ha ittha ādiyanam pañcahi indriyehi parisujjhati iti magga pariyāpannehi
translated: Hence he says “the former” , etc. The former are conditions for the latter, which arise successively,

original: saddhādīhi pañcahi indriyehi sakalasaṃkilesato visujjhati. Paññindriyameva hi anaññātaññassāmītindriyādīni,
analyzed: saddhā ādīhi pañcahi indriyehi sakala saṃkilesataḥ visujjhati paññindriyam eva hi
translated: and so they are dug up in the sense of being conditions. “He is purified by the five faculties”: he is purified from all defilement by the five faculties of faith, etc., which are included in the path. For the faculty of understanding is the faculty of final knowledge, etc.,

original: itarāni ca anvayānīti.
analyzed: itarāni ca anvayāni iti
translated: and the other faculties are the faculties of the successive stages.

original: Jāgarasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jāgara sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Jāgara Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Appaṭividitasuttavaṇṇanā🔽7. Pavattinivattitadubhayahetuvibhāgassa dhammassapi catusaccantogadhattā āha “dhammāti
analyzed: appaṭividita sutta vaṇṇanā  pavatti nivatti tad ubhaya hetu vibhāgassa dhammassa api āha dhamma ati
translated: The commentary on the Appaṭividita Sutta

original: catusaccadhammā”ti. Cattāripi hi ariyasaccāni catusaccantogadhāni. Appaṭividdhāti
analyzed: catusacca dhammā ati cattāri pi hi ariya saccāni catu sacca antogadhāni appaṭividdhā ati
translated: The Dhamma too, which is divided into the cause for occurrence, the cause for cessation, and the cause for both, is included in the four truths. Hence he says “The Dhamma is the four noble truths.” For all four noble truths are included in the four truths.🔽“Not penetrated”:

original: pariññābhisamayādivasena anabhisamitā. Diṭṭhigatavādesūti diṭṭhigatasaññitesu vādesu.
analyzed: pariññā abhisamaya ādi vasena anabhisamitā diṭṭhigata vādesu iti diṭṭhigata saññitesu vādesu
translated: They are not penetrated by the penetration of full understanding, etc. In the theories of views: in the theories called “views.”

original: Diṭṭhigatehi te pavattitā. Ito paresanti ito sāsanikehi paresaṃ aññesaṃ. Dhammatāyāti
analyzed: diṭṭhigatehi te pavatti tā itas paresanti itas sāsanikehi paresam aññesam dhamma tāya ati
translated: They occur by way of views. From here on: from the Dispensation here, from others’ .

original: sabhāvena, sayamevāti attho. Gacchantīti pavattanti diṭṭhivādaṃ paggayha tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: sabhāvena sayam eva ati atthaḥ gacchanti iti pavattanti diṭṭhi vādam paggayha tiṭṭhanti
translated: By nature: by their own nature, is the meaning. They go: they occur, they stand up holding to the theory.

original: Parenāti diṭṭhigatikena. Nīyantīti diṭṭhivādasaṅgaṇhane uyyojīyanti. Tenāha “tatthā”tiādi.
analyzed: parena ati diṭṭhigatikena nīyanti iti diṭṭhi vāda saṅgaṇhane tena āha tattha atiādi
translated: By another: by one who has views. They are led: they are directed to the collection of views. Therefore he said “therein” , etc.🔽To wake up: to wake up from the sleep of negligence. The practice is good

original: Pabujjhitunti pamādaniddāya paṭibujjhituṃ. Paṭipadā yathādesitassa dhammassa kathitatāya,
analyzed: pabujjhitum ti pamāda niddāya paṭibujjhitum paṭipadā yathā desitassa dhammassa kathita tāya
translated: because the Dhamma taught is taught as it really is,

original: paṭibujjhituṃ yoniso pavattiyamānattā bhaddikā.
analyzed: paṭibujjhitum yonisaḥ bhaddikā
translated: and because it is rightly practiced in order to wake up.

original: Hetunāti ñāyena. Kāraṇenāti catusaccānaṃ sambodhayuttiyā. Hatthatale āmalakaṃ viya
analyzed: hetunā ati ñāyena kāraṇena ati sambodha yuttiyā hattha tale āmalakam viya
translated: By reason: by the right way. By cause: by the cause of the enlightenment of the Four Noble Truths.

original: sabbaṃ ñeyyaṃ jānātīti sabbaññū, teneva sabbaññutābhisambodhena buddhoti sabbaññubuddho.
analyzed: sabbam ñeyyam jānāti iti sabbaññū tena iva sabbaññu tā abhisambodhena buddhaḥ iti sabbaññu buddhaḥ
translated: He knows all knowables as if they were a myrobalan fruit on the palm of his hand, thus he is omniscient. He is enlightened by that very enlightenment of omniscience, thus he is the omniscient Buddha.

original: Paccekaṃ parehi asādhāraṇatāya visuṃ sayambhuñāṇena saccāni buddhavāti paccekabuddho.🔽Paropadesena catusaccaṃ bujjhatīti catusaccabuddho. Tathā hi so sayambhutāya abhāvato
analyzed: paccekam parehi asādhāraṇa tāya visum sayambhu ñāṇena saccāni buddhavāti paccekabuddhaḥ  para upadesena catu saccam bujjhati iti catu sacca buddhaḥ tathā hi saḥ sayambhu tāya abhāvato
translated: He is a Paccekabuddha because he has awakened to the Truths by his own knowledge, not in common with others.🔽He is a Buddha of the Four Truths because he awakens to the four truths by the advice of others. For he is called a Buddha of the four truths only because he lacks self-madeness.

original: kevalaṃ catusaccabuddhoti vuccati. Sutena sutamayañāṇena khandhādibhedaṃ ñeyyaṃ buddhavāti
analyzed: kevalam catu sacca buddho ti vuccati sutena suta maya ñāṇena khandha ādi bhedam ñeyyam buddhavā ti
translated: He is a Buddha of what is to be known because he awakens to the knowable divided into the aggregates, etc., by means of the knowledge consisting in what is learnt.

original: sutabuddho. Sabbaññubuddhapaccekabuddhe ṭhapetvā avasesā aggasāvakamahāsāvakāpi pakatisāvakāpi
analyzed: sutabuddhaḥ sabbaññu buddha paccekabuddhe ṭhapetvā avasesāḥ agga sāvaka mahā sāvakāḥ api pakati sāvakāḥ api
translated: Excepting the all-knowing Buddha and the Paccekabuddha, the rest, namely, the chief disciples, the great disciples, and the ordinary disciples,

original: vītarāgā avasesā khīṇāsavā. Tayopi purimā vaṭṭanti sambuddhātiādivacanato. Sannivasati
analyzed: vīta rāgā avasesā khīṇa āsavā purimāḥ vaṭṭanti sambuddha ati ādi vacanataḥ sannivasati
translated: and the passionless and the rest who are cankers-destroyed, are all called “awakened” by the words “awakened, fully enlightened” , etc., in the above stanza.🔽He is in the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.

original: etenāti sannivāso, caritaṃ. Lokassa sannivāso lokasannivāso, tasmiṃ. Kāyaduccaritādibhede
analyzed: etena ati sannivāsaḥ caritam lokassa sannivāsaḥ loka sannivāso tasmin kāya duccarita ādi bhede
translated: In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.

original: visame. Satisammosena visame vā sattanikāye. So hi visamayogato visamo. Rāgavisamādike
analyzed: visame sati sammosena visame vā satta nikāye saḥ hi visama yogataḥ visamaḥ rāga visama ādike
translated: In the world’s unevenness, which is the conduct of the world, because he dwells with it.🔽In the world’s unevenness, which is

original: visame vā kilesajāte. Taṃ visamaṃ pahāya taṃ visamaṃ ajjhupekkhitvā samaṃ sadisaṃ
analyzed: visame vā kilesa jāte tam visamam pahāya tam visamam ajjhupekkhitvā samam sadisam
translated: or in the arising of defilements. Having abandoned that unevenness, having looked on at that unevenness, they conduct themselves evenly, in a way that is similar,

original: yuttarūpaṃ, purimakehi vā sambuddhehi samaṃ sadisaṃ caranti vattanti.
analyzed: yutta rūpam purimakehi vā sambuddhehi samam sadisam caranti vattanti
translated: in a way that is the same as the Buddhas of the past.

original: Appaṭividitasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: appaṭividita sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on the Uneven is finished.

original: 8. Susammuṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: susammuṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on the Well-Buried

original: 8. Susammuṭṭhāti suṭṭhu ativiya sammuṭṭhā. Satta sekkhā hi susammusitā vinaṭṭhā.
analyzed: su sammuṭṭhā ati suṭṭhu ativiya sammuṭṭhā satta sekkhā hi su sammusitā vinaṭṭhā
translated: The seven trainees are well-buried, destroyed.

original: Kathaṃ pana te anadhigatā naṭṭhā nāma hontīti āha “yathā hī”tiādi. Adhigatassāti
analyzed: katham pana te anadhigatāḥ naṭṭhāḥ nāma honti iti āha yathā hi itiādi adhigatassa ati
translated: But how are they called destroyed without having attained? He said, “For example,” and so on. “Having attained” means

original: adhigato assa. So vadantoti sambandho. Sesanti “dhammā”tiādi. Purimasadisamevāti
analyzed: adhigataḥ assa saḥ vadanto ti sambandho sesa nti dhamma atiādi purima sadisam eva ti
translated: he has attained. The connection is: he who speaks thus. The rest: “Dhamma,” and so on. “The same as the previous” means

original: anantaragāthāya vuttasadisameva.
analyzed: anantara gāthāya vutta sadisam eva
translated: the same as stated in the preceding verse.

original: Susammuṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: susammuṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on the Well-Buried is finished.

original: 9. Mānakāmasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on One Who Desires Honour

original: 9. Seyyādibhedaṃ mānaṃ appahāya taṃ paggayha vicaranto kāmento nāma hotīti āha “mānaṃ
analyzed: seyya ādi bhedam mānam appahāya tam paggayha vicarantaḥ kāmentaḥ nāma hoti iti āha mānam
translated: Without abandoning the conceit that is divided into the best, etc., he who goes about displaying that is called one who desires honour. He said, “Conceit

original: kāmentassa icchantassā”ti. Damati cittaṃ etenāti damo, satisambojjhaṅgādiko samādhipakkhiko
analyzed: kāmentassa icchantassa ati damati cittam etena ati damaḥ sati sambojjhaṅga ādiko samādhi pakkhiko
translated: “Taming” is concentration, which is a factor of enlightenment beginning with mindfulness.

original: damo. Manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni dametīti damo, indriyasaṃvaro. Kilese dameti pajahatīti🔽damo, paññā. Upavasanavasena kāyakammādiṃ dametīti damo, uposathakammaṃ. Kodhūpanāhamakkhamānādike
analyzed: damaḥ manat śaṭṭhāni indriyāni dama iti iti damaḥ indriya saṃvaraḥ kilese dama iti pajahati iti  damaḥ paññā upavasana vasena kāya kamma ādim dameti iti damaḥ uposatha kammam kodha upanāha makkha māna ādike
translated: “Taming” is the taming of the six faculties beginning with the mind, that is, restraint of the faculties.🔽“Taming” is the abandoning of defilements, that is, understanding.🔽“Taming” is the taming of bodily action, etc., by means of the observance of the Uposatha, that is, the Uposatha observance.🔽“Taming” is the taming, the disciplining, of anger, resentment, contempt, domineering, etc., that is, the patience of acquiescence.

original: dameti vinetīti damo, adhivāsanakhanti. Tenevāti “damo”ti samādhipakkhikadhammānaṃ
analyzed: dama iti vinā iti iti damaḥ adhivāsana khanti tena iva ati damaḥ ti samādhi pakkhika dhammānam
translated: “Taming” is the name given to the states that are factors of concentration,

original: eva adhippetattā. “Na monaṃ atthī”ti ca pāṭho. Asamāhitassāti samādhipaṭikkhepo jotito.
analyzed: eva adhippeta ttā na monam atthi iti ca pāṭhaḥ asamāhitassa ati samādhi paṭikkhepaḥ jotitaḥ
translated: “There is no taming” is a reading. “Not concentrated” is a denial of concentration.

original: Maccudheyyassa pārataraṇassa vuccamānattā “monanti catumaggañāṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Na hi
analyzed: maccudheyyassa pārataraṇassa vuccamāna ttā catu magga ñāṇan ti vuttam na hi
translated: “Taming” is said to be the four paths of knowledge, because it is said to be the crossing over of the realm of death.

original: tato aññena taṃ sambhavati. Jānāti asammohapaṭivedhavasena paṭivijjhatīti attho.
analyzed: tatas aññena tam sambhavati jānāti asammoha paṭivedha vasena paṭivijjhati iti attho
translated: For it is not possible by any other means. “He knows” : the meaning is that he penetrates by means of non-delusion.

original: Maccu dhīyati etthāti maccudheyyaṃ, khandhapañcakaṃ maraṇadhammattā. Tassevāti maccudheyyasseva.
analyzed: maccu dhīyati ettha ati maccudheyyam khandha pañcakam maraṇa dhamma ttā tassa iva ati maccudheyyassa iva
translated: “The realm of death” is the five aggregates, because they are subject to death. “To that” means to the realm of death.

original: Pāraṃ paratīrabhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ. Tareyyāti ettha taraṇaṃ nāma ariyamaggabyāpāroti āha
analyzed: pāram para tīra bhūtam nibbānam tareyya ati ettha taraṇam nāma ariya magga byāpāraḥ ti āha
translated: Nibbana is “the other shore” because it is beyond the far shore of the ocean of existence. “Would cross over” : crossing over is the penetration of the noble path.

original: “paṭivijjheyya pāpuṇeyyā”ti. Tathā hi vakkhati “paṭivedhataraṇaṃ nāma vutta”nti.
analyzed: paṭivijjheyya pāpuṇeyya ti tathā hi vakkhati paṭivedha taraṇam nāma vuttanti
translated: “Would penetrate, would reach” . For it is said: “Penetration is called crossing over” .

original: “Na tareyya na paṭivijjheyya na pāpuṇeyya vā”ti ayamettha pāṭho yutto. Aññathā “idaṃ
analyzed: na tareyya na paṭivijjheyya na pāpuṇeyya vā ti ayam ettha pāṭhaḥ yuttaḥ aññathā idam
translated: “Would not cross over, would not penetrate, would not reach” is the correct reading here. Otherwise the statement “This is what is said” would be contradicted.

original: vuttaṃ hotī”tiādivacanaṃ virujjheyya. Eko araññe viharantoti ekākī hutvā araññe viharantoti attho.
analyzed: vuttam hoti iti ādi vacanam virujjheyya ekaḥ araññe viharanto ti ekākī hutvā araññe viharanto ti attho
translated: “One who lives alone in the forest” : the meaning is, one who lives in the forest, alone by himself.

original: Kāmaṃ heṭṭhimamaggehipi ekaccassa mānassa pahānaṃ labbhati. Aggamaggeneva pana tassa
analyzed: kāmam heṭṭhima maggehi pi ekaccassa mānassa pahānam labbhati agga maggena iva pana tassa
translated: Although the abandoning of some forms of conceit is possible even on the lower paths, it is only on the path of arahatship that it is abandoned without remainder.

original: anavasesato pahānanti āha – “arahattamaggena navavidhamānaṃ pajahitvā”ti. Upacārasamādhipubbako
analyzed: anavasesataḥ pahānanti āha arahatta maggena navavidha mānam pajahitvā ati upacāra samādhi pubbako
translated: “Having abandoned the nine kinds of conceit by the path of arahatship” .

original: appanāsamādhīti vuttaṃ “upacārappanāsamādhīhī”ti, na upacārasamādhimattena samādhimattaṃ
analyzed: appanā samādhi iti vuttam upacāra ppanā samādhīhi iti na upacāra samādhi mattena samādhi mattam
translated: “The concentration of absorption” is said in the words “The concentration of access and of absorption” . But it is not said that concentration is only the concentration of access.🔽For it is not proper to end the sentence with each of the words “access” and “absorption.”

original: sandhāya paccekaṃ vākyaparisamāpanassa ayujjanato. Na hi appanaṃ appattaṃ lokuttarajjhānaṃ🔽atthi. “Sucetaso”ti cittassa ñāṇasahitatāya lakkhaṇavacananti āha “ñāṇasampayuttatāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: sandhāya paccekam vākya parisamāpanassa ayujjanataḥ na hi appanam appattam lokuttara jhānam  atthi su cetaso ti cittassa ñāṇa sahita tāya lakkhaṇa vacananti āha ñāṇa sampayutta tāya atiādi
translated: For there is no supramundane jhāna that does not reach absorption.🔽“With a well-composed mind” is a description of the mind’s being accompanied by knowledge. That is why he said “with the accompaniment of knowledge,” etc.

original: Tathā hi vakkhati “sucetasoti ettha cittena paññā dassitā”ti. “Sabbadhi vippamutto”ti🔽sabbesu bhavādīsu visaṃsaṭṭhacitto sabbaso khandhādīhi visaṃyutto hotīti vuttaṃ “sabbesu
analyzed: tathā hi vakkhati su cetaso ti ettha cittena paññā dassitā ati sabbadhi vippamutto ti  sabbesu bhava ādīsu visaṃsaṭṭha cittaḥ sabbasas khandha ādīhi visaṃyuttaḥ hoti iti vuttam sabbesu
translated: For he says further on: “Herein, ‘with a well-composed mind’ shows the mind with understanding” .

original: khandhāyatanādīsu vippamutto hutvā”ti. Pariññāpaṭivedho sacchikiriyapaṭivedhena vinā
analyzed: khandha āyatana ādīsu vippamuttaḥ hutvā ati pariññā paṭivedho sacchikiriya paṭivedhena vinā
translated: “Freed in every way” : he is freed in every way from the mind’s entanglement in all kinds of becoming, etc., and he is freed altogether from all the aggregates, etc. That is why it is said: “having become freed in every way from the aggregates, bases, elements, etc.”

original: natthīti āha “tebhūmaka…pe… vutta”nti.
analyzed: natthi iti āha tebhūmaka pe vuttan ti
translated: The penetration of full understanding is not without the penetration of realization. That is why he said “The three kinds of full understanding … are stated” .

original: Mānaṃ nissāya duccaritacaraṇato māno nāmāyaṃ sīlabhedano. Tasmāti mānassa sīlapaṭipakkhabhāvato.
analyzed: mānam nissāya duccarita caraṇataḥ mānaḥ nāma ayam sīla bhedanaḥ tasmā ati mānassa sīla paṭipakkha bhāvato
translated: “Conceit” is a term for the practice of misconduct based on conceit. “Therefore” : because conceit is the opposite of virtue.

original: Iminā paṭipakkhappahānakittanena. Adhicittasikkhā kathitā sarūpato evāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: iminā paṭipakkha ppahāna kittanena adhicitta sikkhā kathitā sarūpataḥ evā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: By this praise of the abandoning of the opposite. The training in the higher consciousness is stated in its own nature, is the intention.

original: Ettha cittenāti su-saddena visesitacittena. Tasmāti paññāya dassitattā. Imināti “sucetaso”ti
analyzed: ettha cittena ati su saddena visesita cittena tasmā ati paññāya dassita ttā iminā ati su cetasā ti
translated: Herein, with consciousness means with consciousness specified by the word good. Therefore means because shown by understanding. By this means by this word good-minded.

original: iminā padena. Adhisīlasikkhā adhicittasikkhā adhipaññāsikkhāti sīlādīnipi visesetvā🔽vuttāni. Sambhave byabhicāre ca visesanavisesitabbatāti taṃ dassento “adhisīlañca
analyzed: iminā padena adhi sīla sikkhā adhi citta sikkhā adhi paññā sikkhā ati sīla ādīni pi visesetvā  vuttāni sambhave byabhicāre ca visesana visesitabba tā ti tam dassento adhisīlam ca
translated: The training in the higher virtue, the training in the higher consciousness, and the training in the higher wisdom are stated after specifying virtue, etc.

original: nāma sīle sati hotī”tiādiṃ vatvā tadubhayaṃ vibhāgena dassetuṃ “tasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nāma sīle sati hoti itiādim vatvā tat ubhayam vibhāgena dassetum tasmā itiādi vuttam
translated: Because of the possibility of confusion and the need to specify what is to be specified, he shows that thus. After saying “The higher virtue is virtue that is present,” etc., he says “Therefore,” etc., in order to show both of these by a division.

original: Paṭhamanayo saṅkaravasena pavattoti asaṅkaravasena dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādinā dutiyanayo
analyzed: paṭhama nayo saṅkara vasena pavatto ti asaṅkara vasena dassetum api ca iti ādinā dutiya nayo
translated: The first method occurs by way of confusion. In order to show it by way of non-confusion, the second method is stated by “Moreover,” etc.

original: vutto. “Samāpannā”ti etthāpi “nibbānaṃ patthayantenā”ti ānetvā sambandho. Vipassanāya
analyzed: vuttaḥ samāpannā ti ettha api nibbānam patthayantena ati ānetvā sambandhaḥ vipassanāya
translated: The meaning of “attained” should be brought in here also by “one who is aspiring for Nibbana.” In order to show the meaning of “attained” by way of the path, he says “one who is aspiring for Nibbana.”

original: pādakabhāvaṃ anupagatāpi tadatthaṃ nibbattanādivasena samāpannāti ayamattho purimanayato
analyzed: pādaka bhāvam an upagatā api tad attham nibbattana ādi vasena samāpannā ti ayam attho purima nayataḥ
translated: Although not gone as a basis for insight, he is attained for that purpose by way of rebirth, etc. This meaning is different from the previous method.

original: viseso. Adhipaññāya panettha purimanayato viseso natthīti sā anuddhaṭā. Samodhānetvāti
analyzed: visesaḥ adhipaññāya pana ittha purima nayataḥ visesaḥ natthi iti sā anuddhaṭā samodhānetvā ati
translated: The difference is that there is no difference here in the matter of higher understanding from the method stated above, so that is not mentioned. “Having combined”:

original: pariyāyato sarūpato ca saṅgahetvā. Sakalasāsananti tissannaṃ kathitattā eva sikkhattayasaṅgahaṃ
analyzed: pariyāyataḥ sarūpataḥ ca saṅgahetvā sakala sāsanam ti eva sikkhattaya saṅgaham
translated: having combined by way of the successive order and by way of the individual essence. “The entire dispensation”: because the three have been stated, the entire dispensation, which includes the three trainings,

original: sakalasāsanaṃ kathitaṃ hotīti.
analyzed: sakala sāsanam kathitam hoti iti
translated: is stated.

original: Mānakāmasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: māna kāma sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Mānakāma Sutta is finished.

original: 10. Araññasuttavaṇṇanā🔽10. Santakilesānanti vūpasantakilesapariḷāhānaṃ. Yasmā sīlādiguṇasambhavaṃ tato eva🔽bhayasantañca upādāya paṇḍitā “santo”ti vuccanti, tasmā vuttaṃ “paṇḍitānaṃ vā”ti.🔽Tenāha “santo have”tiādi. Seṭṭhacārīnanti seṭṭhacariyaṃ carantānaṃ. Yasmā puthujjanakalyāṇato
analyzed: arañña sutta vaṇṇanā  sīla ādi guṇa sambhavam eva  bhaya santam ca upādāya paṇḍitāḥ santo ti vuccanti tasmā vuttam paṇḍitānam vā ti  tena āha santaḥ havā itiādi seṭṭha cārīn anti seṭṭha cariyam carantānam yasmā puthujjana kalyāṇato
translated: The Araññasutta🔽“With their defilements calmed”: with their defilements and their fevers calmed. Because they are called “calm” by the wise because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear,

original: paṭṭhāya bhikkhu maggabrahmacariyavāsaṃ vasati nāma, tasmā āha “maggabrahmacariyavāsaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya bhikkhu magga brahmacariya vāsam vasati nāma tasmai āha magga brahmacariya vāsam
translated: therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear.” “The wise” are called “calm” because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear. Therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear.” “The wise” are called “calm” because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear. Therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear.” “The wise” are called “calm” because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear. Therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear.” “The wise” are called “calm” because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear. Therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear.” “The wise” are called “calm” because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear. Therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear.” “The wise” are called “calm” because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear. Therefore it is said: “because of the arising of the qualities of virtue, etc., and because of their being free from fear

original: vasantāna”nti. Ariyānaṃ pana mukhavaṇṇassa pasīdane vattabbameva natthi. Mūlakammaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: vasantānam ti ariyānam pana mukha vaṇṇassa pasīdane vattabbam eva na atthi mūlakammaṭṭhānam ti
translated: But there is no need to say that the colour of the noble ones’ faces becomes clear. ‘Basic meditation subject’:

original: pārihāriyakammaṭṭhānaṃ. Visabhāgasantatīti nānārammaṇesu pavattacittasantati. Sā🔽hi vikkhepabyākulatāya appasannā samāhitacittasantatiyā visabhāgasantati. Okkamatīti
analyzed: pārihāriya kammaṭṭhānam visabhāga santati iti nānā ārammaṇesu pavatta citta santati sā  hi vikkhepa byākula tāya appasannā samāhita citta santatiyā visabhāga santati okkamati iti
translated: the meditation subject for the purpose of obtaining jhāna. ‘Different continuity’: the continuity of consciousness occurring with different objects.🔽That is not clear because it is distracted and disturbed, and it is a different continuity from the continuity of consciousness in one who is concentrated. ‘It is agitated’:

original: samādhisabhāgā cittasantati samathavīthiṃ anupavisati. Cittaṃ pasīdatīti kammaṭṭhānanirataṃ
analyzed: samādhi sabhāgā citta santati samatha vīthim anupavisati cittam pasīdati iti kammaṭṭhāna niratam
translated: the continuity of consciousness that is a companion to concentration does not enter upon the path of serenity. ‘The mind becomes clear’:

original: bhāvanācittaṃ sandhāyāha, taṃ pasannaṃ hutvā pavattati. Lohitaṃ pasīdatīti cittakālussiyassābhāvato
analyzed: bhāvanā cittam sandhāya āha tam pasannam hutvā pavattati lohitam pasīdati iti
translated: he says this referring to the development of consciousness that is occupied with the meditation subject, which occurs when it has become clear. ‘The blood becomes clear’:🔽because there is no sluggishness in the mind, the blood is unturbid. ‘The faculties become purified’:

original: lohitaṃ anāvilaṃ hoti. Parisuddhāni honti kāraṇassa parisuddhabhāvato. Tālaphalamukhassa
analyzed: lohitam anāvilam hoti parisuddhāni honti kāraṇassa parisuddha bhāvataḥ tāla phala mukhassa
translated: they are purified because the cause is purified. ‘The colour of the face becomes like the colour of the palm of the hand’:

original: viya mukhassa vaṇṇo hotīti mukha-saddassa ādimhi pamuttapadena yojetabbo. Evañhi
analyzed: viya mukhassa vaṇṇo hoti iti mukha saddassa ādimhi pamutta padena yojetabbo evam hi
translated: the word ‘face’ should be construed with the word ‘palm’ at the beginning of the next sentence. For

original: cassa pamuttaggahaṇaṃ samatthitaṃ hoti tālaphalamukhassa vaṇṇasampadāsadisattā. Tibhūmako eva tebhūmako.
analyzed: cassa pamutta ggahaṇam samatthitam hoti tāla phala mukhassa ti bhūmakaḥ eva tebhūmakaḥ
translated: The three-plane is just the three planes.

original: Atītaṃ nānusocanti atītaṃ paccayalābhaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ katvā na socanti na anutthunanti.
analyzed: atītam na anusocanti atītam paccaya lābham lakkhaṇam katvā na socanti na anutthunanti
translated: They do not grieve over the past: they do not grieve, they do not lament, taking the past as a condition for the acquisition of gain.

original: Jappanataṇhāya vasena na parikappantīti āha “na patthentī”ti. Yena kenacīti itarītarena.
analyzed: jappana taṇhāya vasena na parikappanti iti āha na patthenti iti yena kenaci iti itarītarena
translated: They do not speculate by way of the craving for talk, thus he said “they do not hope for” . By any means: by the other.

original: Taṅkhaṇe laddhenāti sannidhikāraparibhogābhāvamāha. Tividhenapi kāraṇenāti tippakārena
analyzed: tad khaṇe laddhena ati sannidhi kāra paribhoga abhāvam āha tividhena api kāraṇena ati tis pakārena
translated: What is obtained at the moment: this shows the absence of hoarding and enjoyment. By means of the three reasons: by means of the three kinds of

original: hetunā, tilakkhaṇasantosanimittanti attho.
analyzed: hetunā ti lakkhaṇa santosa nimittan ti attho
translated: causes, the meaning is, by means of the three characteristics, the cause of contentment.

original: Vināsanti vināsanahetuṃ. Vinassanti etehīti vināso, lobhadosā tadekaṭṭhā ca pāpadhammā.
analyzed: vināsanti vināsana hetum vinassanti etehi iti vināsaḥ lobha dosā tad ekaṭṭhā ca pāpa dhammā
translated: Destruction: the cause of destruction. They are destroyed by these, thus they are destructions, greed, hatred, and the evil states that have them as their basis.

original: Arūpakāyassa viya rūpakāyassapi visesato sukkhabhāvakāraṇanti āha “etena kāraṇadvayenā”ti. Lutoti lūno.🔽Araññasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Naḷavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Nandanavaggo🔽1. Nandanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: arūpa kāyassa viya rūpa kāyassa api visesataḥ sukkha bhāva kāraṇanti āha etena kāraṇa dvayena ati lutaḥ ti lūnaḥ 🔽arañña sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽naḷa vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽nandana vaggo 🔽nandana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The cause of the special drying up of the material body, as of the immaterial body, thus he said “by these two reasons” . Dried up: withered.

original: 11. “Tatra bhagavā”ti vutte na tathā byañjanānaṃ siliṭṭhatā, yathā “tatra kho bhagavā”ti
analyzed: tatra bhagavā iti vutte na tathā byañjanānam siliṭṭha tā yathā tatra kho bhagavā iti
translated: When he said “there the Blessed One,” the syllables are not jumbled as they are when he said “there the Blessed One.”

original: vutteti āha “byañjanasiliṭṭhatāvasenā”ti. Parisajeṭṭhaketi parisāya jeṭṭhake, ye🔽tassā desanāya visesato bhājanabhūtā. Parisajeṭṭhake bhikkhūti catuparisajeṭṭhake
analyzed: vuttā iti āha byañjana siliṭṭha tā vasena ati parisa jeṭṭhaka iti parisāya jeṭṭhake ye  tassāḥ desanāya visesataḥ bhājana bhūtā parisa jeṭṭhake bhikkhū iti catu parisa jeṭṭhake
translated: So he said “by way of the jumbling of the syllables.” The senior monks in the assembly: the senior ones in the assembly, those who are vessels for that teaching in particular.

original: bhikkhū. Catunnaṃ hi parisānaṃ jeṭṭhā bhikkhuparisā paṭhamuppannattā. Āmantesīti
analyzed: bhikkhū catunnam hi parisānam jeṭṭhā bhikkhu parisā paṭhama uppanna ttā āmantesi iti
translated: The senior monks in the four assemblies: the monks who are senior in the four assemblies. For the monks’ assembly is senior to the four assemblies because it arose first.

original: sambodhesi, sambodhanañca jānāpananti āha “jānāpesī”ti. Bhadanteti garugāravasappatissavavacanametaṃ,
analyzed: sambodhesi sambodhanam ca jānāpananti āha jānāpesi iti bhadanta iti garu gārava sappati ssava vacanam etam
translated: He addressed: he informed, made known. And informing is making known. So he said “he made them know.”🔽“Venerable Sir”: this is a respectful expression of deference and esteem.

original: atthato pana bhadanteti bhaddaṃ tava hotu attano niṭṭhānapariyosānattā paresañca🔽santatāvahattā. Bhagavato paccassosunti ettha bhagavatoti sāmivacanaṃ āmantanameva
analyzed: atthataḥ pana bhadanta iti bhaddam tava hotu attanaḥ niṭṭhāna pariyosāna ttā paresam ca  bhagavato paccassosunti ettha bhagavato iti sāmi vacanam āmantanam eva
translated: But in meaning “Venerable Sir” is “May there be good fortune for you,” because of the Blessed One’s own consummation and because of the continuation of the welfare of others.

original: sambandhiatthapadaṃ apekkhatīti adhippāyenāha “bhagavato vacanaṃ patiassosu”nti.
analyzed: sambandhi attha padam apekkhati iti adhippāyena āha bhagavataḥ vacanam
translated: “The Blessed One’s word”: here the word “Blessed One’s” is a possessive expression. It is only an address that requires a word in apposition to it in meaning. So with the intention “The Blessed One’s word they listened to” he said “they listened to the Blessed One’s word.”

original: Bhagavatoti pana idaṃ patissavanasambandhena sampadānavacanaṃ yathā “devadattassa
analyzed: bhagavato ti pana idam patissavana sambandhena sampadāna vacanam yathā devadattassa
translated: “Bhagavato” is a term of respect used in connection with the acceptance of the gift, just as in the case of the expression “devadattassa bhagavā” .

original: paṭissuṇātī”ti. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ nidānavaggassa ādisuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ āgamissati.🔽Tāvatiṃsakāyoti tāvatiṃsasaññito devanikāyo. Dutiyadevalokoti chasu kāmalokesu dutiyo
analyzed: paṭissuṇāti iti yam pana ittha vattabbam tam nidāna vaggassa ādi sutta vaṇṇanāyam āgamissati  tāvatiṃsa kāyo ti tāvatiṃsa saññitaḥ devanikāyaḥ dutiya devaloko ti chasu kāmalokesu dutiyo
translated: “The Blessed One”: this is said in the sense of the Blessed One’s acceptance of the invitation, as in the expression “He accepts Devadatta’s invitation” . But what is to be said here will come in the commentary on the first sutta of the Nidāna Vagga .🔽“The Thirty-Three”: the class of gods called the Thirty-Three. “The second divine world”: the second divine world among the six sense-sphere divine worlds.

original: devaloko. Tettiṃsa janā sahapuññakārino tattha uppannā, taṃsahacaritaṭṭhānaṃ tāvatiṃsaṃ,
analyzed: deva loko tettiṃsa janā saha puñña kārino tattha uppannā tad saha carita ṭṭhānam tāvatiṃsam
translated: Thirty-three persons who have made merit together are reborn there, and the place they share is called the Thirty-Three.🔽And the gods who live there are called the Thirty-Three because they share the same life of companionship.

original: tannivāsinopi tāvatiṃsanāmakā sahacaraṇañāyenāti āha “maghena māṇavenā”tiādi. Ayaṃ
analyzed: tad nivāsinaḥ api sahacaraṇa ñāyena ati āha maghena māṇavena atiādi ayam
translated: “By the student Magha” is said.

original: pana kecivādo byāpanno hotīti taṃ arocentena “vadantī”ti vuttaṃ. Byāpannataṃ dassento
analyzed: pana keci vādaḥ byāpannaḥ hoti iti tam a rocentena vadanti iti vuttam byāpanna tam dassento
translated: But this statement is contradicted by some, so in order to correct them it is said “they say.”🔽Showing the contradiction, he says “But since … ” .

original: “yasmā panā”tiādimāha. Tathā hi vakkhati “evaṃ hi niddosaṃ padaṃ hotī”ti. Nāmapaṇṇattiyevāti
analyzed: yasmā pana ati ādim āha tathā hi vakkhati evam hi niddosam padam hoti iti nāma paṇṇattiyā iva ati
translated: For he says “For in this way the expression becomes free from fault.”

original: atthanirapekkhattā niruḷhasamaññā eva.
analyzed: attha nirapekkha ttā niruḷha samaññā eva
translated: “Mere designation by name”: mere established terms, since they are independent of meaning.

original: Taṃ vananti taṃ upavanaṃ. Paviṭṭhe paviṭṭhe dukkhappattepi attano sampattiyā nandayati,
analyzed: tam vananti tam upavanam paviṭṭhe paviṭṭhe dukkha ppatte pi attanaḥ sampattiyā nandayati
translated: It is a pleasure grove because it delights in it. It delights in it in the sense that it delights in the prosperity of those who enter it, even if they are miserable,

original: pageva adukkhappatteti dassetuṃ “pañcasu hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pavesitānanti pakoṭṭhavārena
analyzed: pageva adukkha ppattā iti dassetum pañcasu hi itiādi vuttam pavesitānam ti pakoṭṭha vārena
translated: to say nothing of those who are not miserable. The intention is that it delights in those who enter it by the gate of the park.

original: pavesitānampīti adhippāyo. Cavanakāleyeva thokaṃ dissamānavikārā hutvā cavanti, te🔽sandhāya “himapiṇḍo viya vilīyantī”ti vuttaṃ. Ye pana adissamānavikārā sahasā antaradhāyanti,
analyzed: pavesitānam pi iti adhippāyaḥ cavana kāleya iva thokam dissamāna vikārāḥ hutvā cavanti te  sandhāya hima piṇḍaḥ viya vilīyanti iti vuttam ye pana adissamāna vikārā sahasā antaradhāyanti
translated: They are dissolved even as they enter, having become dissolved to some extent as they enter.🔽With reference to them it is said, “They are dissolved like a lump of salt.”🔽But those who disappear suddenly without any change being apparent are said to vanish like a lamp’s flame.

original: te sandhāya “dīpasikhā viya vijjhāyantī”ti vuttanti vadanti. Nandayati pakatiyā somanassitaṃ🔽domanassitañca. Nandaneti evaṃanvatthanāmake uyyāne. Parivutāti “devatā”ti vacanaṃ🔽upādāya itthiliṅgavasena vuttaṃ. Devaputto hi so.
analyzed: te sandhāya dīpa sikhāḥ viya vijjhāyanti iti vuttan ti vadanti nandayati pakatiyā somanassitam  domanassitam ca nandane ti evaṃanvattha nāmake uyyāne parivutā ati devatā ati vacanam  upādāya itthi liṅga vasena vuttam deva puttaḥ hi so
translated: It delights in the sense of delighting in the natural joy and sorrow of beings.🔽It delights in the sense of delighting in the beings who are reborn there. It is a pleasure grove in the sense of being a pleasure ground.🔽It is surrounded by gods. The feminine form is used because the word “gods” is used.

original: Divi bhavattā dibbāti āha “devaloke nibbattehī”ti. Kāmetabbatāya kāmabandhanehi,
analyzed: divi bhavattā dibbā iti āha deva loke nibbattehi iti kāmetabba tāya kāma bandhanehi
translated: For he is a god’s son. It is divine because it exists in the heavens.🔽It is a pleasure grove because it is desirable.

original: tathā aññamaññaṃ asaṃkiṇṇasabhāvatāya kāmakoṭṭhāsehi. Upetāti upagatā samannāgatā.🔽Paricārayamānāti pariramamānā. Idañhi padaṃ apekkhitvā “kāmaguṇehī”ti kattari karaṇavacanaṃ,🔽purimāni apekkhitvā sahayoge. Ramamānā carantīti katvā vuttaṃ “ramamānā”ti. Paricārayamānāti
analyzed: tathā aññamaññam asaṃkiṇṇa sabhāva tāya kāma koṭṭhāsehi upetā ati upagatā samannāgatā  paricārayamānā ati pariramamānā idam hi padam apekkhitvā kāma guṇehi iti kattari karaṇavacanam  purimāni apekkhitvā saha yoge ramamānā carantī iti katvā vuttam ramamānā ati paricārayamānā ati
translated: and likewise they are not mixed up with one another, as they are with the strands of sensual desire.🔽They were enjoying themselves : they were delighting themselves. For this word is in the accusative case, and the word “sensual desires” is in the instrumental case, with reference to the former.🔽Or the words “enjoying themselves” can be taken as a gerundive expression with reference to the latter.

original: vā parito samantato cārayamānāti atthoti āha “indriyāni sañcārayamānā”ti. Paṭhamanaye🔽hi anubhavanattho paricaraṇasaddo, dutiyanaye parivattanattho. So panāti “tāyaṃ velāya”nti🔽vuttakālo. Adhunāti sampati. So vicarīti sambandho. Kāmaguṇehīti hetumhi karaṇavacanaṃ.🔽Ovutoti yathā taṃ na ñāyati, evaṃ pihitacitto. Nivuto pariyonaddhoti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: vā paritas samantataḥ cārayamānā ati attha iti āha indriyāni sañcārayamānā ati paṭhama naye 🔽hi anubhavana tthaḥ paricaraṇa saddo dutiya naye parivattana tthaḥ saḥ pana ati velāyanti 🔽vutta kālaḥ saḥ vicari iti sambandho kāma guṇehi iti hetumhi karaṇa vacanam 🔽ovutaḥ iti yathā tam na ñāyati evam pihita cittaḥ nivutaḥ pariyonaddhaḥ ti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: They were enjoying themselves, they were delighting themselves, they were amusing themselves, they were amusing themselves in various ways, they were delighting themselves in various ways, original: Tenāha “lokābhibhūto”ti. Āsabhinti seṭṭhaṃ “aggohamasmi lokassā”tiādinā bhāsanto bodhisatto viya.
analyzed: tena āha loka abhibhūtaḥ iti seṭṭham aggaḥ ham asmi lokassa ati ādinā bhāsantaḥ bodhisatto viya
