translated: “Āsabhi” means the best, like the Bodhisatta who spoke thus: “I am the chief in the world”.

original: Kevalaṃ dassanaṃ kimatthiyanti āha – “ye…pe… vasenā”ti, tasmiṃ nandanavane avaṭṭhitakāmabhāgānubhavanavasenāti
analyzed: kevalam dassanam kimatthiyanti āha yepe vasena ati tasmim nandana vane avaṭṭhita kāmabhāga anubhavana vasena ati
translated: “What is the purpose of mere seeing?” He said: “Those who…pe… vasena”, the meaning is: by the method of experiencing the sense pleasures in that Nandana Grove.🔽“Naradevā” means gods who are men. Hence he said: “devapurisā”.

original: attho. Naradevānanti purisabhūtadevatānaṃ. Tenāha “devapurisāna”nti. Appakaṃ adhikaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ naradevānam ti purisa bhūtadevatānam tena āha deva purisānam ti appakam adhikam
translated: “A little, much,🔽or less is not reckoned as a number” . Hence he said: “Three times ten”.

original: ūnaṃ vā gaṇanūpagaṃ nāma na hotīti “tikkhattuṃ dasanna”nti vuttaṃ. “Tettiṃsāna”nti
analyzed: ūnam vā gaṇanūpagam nāma na hoti iti tikkhattum dasannam ti vuttam tettiṃsānam ti
translated: “Thirty-three” should be said, but this is a popular form.🔽The intention is: by the method of retinue, not by the method of fame.

original: hi vattabbe ayaṃ ruḷhī. Parivārasaṅkhātena, na kittisaṅkhātenāti adhippāyo. Sīlācārādiguṇanemittikā
analyzed: hi vattabbe ayam ruḷhī parivāra saṅkhātena na kitti saṅkhātena ati adhippāyaḥ sīla ācāra ādi guṇa nemittikā
translated: For fame is the cause of such qualities as virtue and conduct.

original: hi kitti. “Tāvatiṃsā devā dīghāyukā vaṇṇavanto sukhabahulā”ti evamādivacanena yase
analyzed: hi kitti tāvatiṃsāḥ devāḥ dīgha āyukāḥ vaṇṇavantaḥ evamādi vacanena
translated: “The Thirty-three gods have a long life, are beautiful and have much happiness” .

original: icchite avisesetvāva “yasena sampannāna”nti sakkā vattuṃ.
analyzed: icchite yasena sampannānanti sakkā vattum
translated: By such words, without distinguishing what is desired, it is possible to say: “Endowed with fame”.

original: Ariyasāvikāti sotāpannā. “Sakadāgāminī”ti keci. Adhippāyaṃ vivaṭṭetvāti yathā tvaṃ
analyzed: ariya sāvikā ati sā utāpannā sakadāgāminī iti keci adhippāyam vivaṭṭetvā ati yathā tvam
translated: “Noble female disciple”: stream-enterer. “Once-returner,” according to some.

original: andhabāle maññasi, dhammasabhāvo evaṃ na hotīti tassā devatāya adhippāyaṃ viparivattetvā.
analyzed: andha bāle maññasi dhamma sabhāvaḥ evam na hoti iti tassā devatāya adhippāyam viparivattetvā
translated: “He turned her away from her intention”: he turned away the devatā’s intention by saying: “You foolish woman, the true nature of things is not as you think.”

original: Ekantato sukhaṃ nāma nibbānameva. Kāmā hi dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammāti iminā adhippāyena🔽tassā adhippāyaṃ paṭikkhipitvā. Kāmaṃ catutthabhūmakāpi saṅkhārā aniccā eva, te pana
analyzed: ekantato sukham nāma nibbānam eva kāmāḥ hi dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā ti iminā adhippāyena  tassāḥ adhippāyam paṭikkhipitvā kāmam catuttha bhūmakāḥ api saṅkhārāḥ aniccāḥ eva te pana
translated: “There is no happiness in the world”: the only happiness is Nibbāna. Sensual pleasures are suffering, subject to change. With this intention,

original: sammasanūpagā na hontīti tebhūmakaggahaṇaṃ sammasanayoggena. Hutvāti pubbe avijjamānā🔽paccayasamavāyena bhavitvā uppajjitvā. Etena nesaṃ bhāvabhāgo dassito. Abhāvatthenāti
analyzed: sammasana upagāḥ na honti iti tebhūmaka ggahaṇam sammasana yoggena hutvā ati pubbe a vijjamānā  paccaya samavāyena bhavitvā uppajjitvā etena nesam bhāva bhāgaḥ dassitaḥ abhāva atthena ati
translated: he rejected her intention. “The formations of the fourth jhāna are impermanent, painful, and subject to change”: although the formations of the fourth jhāna are impermanent, they are not subject to change in the sense of being painful.

original: sarasanirodhabhūtena viddhaṃsanabhāvena.🔽Aniccā addhuvā, tato eva “mayhaṃ ime sukhā”ti vā na iccāti aniccā. Uppādavayasabhāvāti
analyzed: sa rasa nirodha bhūtena viddhaṃsana bhāvena 🔽aniccāḥ tatas eva mayham ime vā na icca ati aniccāḥ uppāda vayasa bhāvā ati
translated: “They arise and vanish”: they come to be and vanish. This shows their state of being. “They are not permanent”: they are not permanent in the sense of being subject to destruction by final Nibbāna.

original: khaṇe khaṇe uppajjananirujjhanasabhāvā. Tenāha “uppa…pe… vevacana”nti. Purimassa
analyzed: khaṇe khaṇe uppajjana nirujjhana sabhāvā tena āha purimassa
translated: and it is of the nature to arise and cease from instant to instant. Hence he said, “arising … is a synonym for … ”

original: vā pacchimaṃ kāraṇavevacananti āha “yasmā vā”tiādi. Tadanantarāti tesaṃ uppādavayānaṃ
analyzed: vā pacchimam kāraṇa vevacananti āha yasmai uppāda vayānam
translated: or the latter is a synonym for the former’s cause. That is why he said “because” and so on.🔽In the interval between: between the arising and the cessation of those formations.🔽The middle point: he means the moment of presence.

original: antare. Vemajjhaṭṭhānanti ṭhitikkhaṇaṃ vadati. Ye pana “saṅkhārānaṃ ṭhiti natthī”ti🔽vadanti, tesaṃ taṃ micchā. Yathā hi tasseva dhammassa uppādāvatthāya bhinnā bhaṅgāvatthā
analyzed: antare vemajjha ṭṭhānan ti ṭhiti khaṇam vadati ye pana saṅkhārānam natthi iti  vadanti tesam tam micchā yathā hi tassa iva dhammassa uppāda avatthāya bhinnā bhaṅga avatthā
translated: But those who say that “there is no presence of formations” are wrong.

original: icchitā, aññathā aññaṃ uppajjati, aññaṃ nirujjhatīti āpajjati, evaṃ uppannassa bhaṅgābhimukhāvatthā
analyzed: icchitā aññathā aññam uppajjati aññam nirujjhati iti āpajjati evam uppannassa bhaṅga abhimukhā avatthā
translated: For just as the point of dissolution of that same state is admitted to be different from the point of its arising, otherwise it would follow that one thing arises and another dissolves, so too the point of dissolution of what has arisen must be admitted to be different from the point of arising, and that is the moment of presence.

original: icchitabbā, sāva ṭhitikkhaṇo. Na hi uppajjamāno bhijjatīti sakkā viññātunti. Vūpasamasaṅkhātanti
analyzed: icchitabbā sā ava ṭhiti kkhaṇaḥ na hi uppajjamānaḥ bhijjati iti sakkā viññātunti vūpasama saṅkhātanti
translated: For it cannot be known that what is arising is dissolving.

original: accantaṃ vūpasamasaṅkhātaṃ nibbānameva sukhaṃ, na tayā adhippetā kāmāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: accantam vūpasama saṅkhātam nibbānam eva sukham na tayā adhippetā kāmā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The bliss called “stilling”: the bliss called “complete stilling” is only Nibbāna, not the bliss you have in mind, is the meaning.

original: Nandanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nandana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Nandana Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Nandatisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nandati sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Nandati Sutta

original: 12. Nandatīti ettha nandanaṃ sappītikakāmataṇhākiccanti āha – “tussatī”ti, tasmā
analyzed: nandati iti ettha nandanam sappītika kāma taṇhā kiccanti āha tussati iti tasmā
translated: “Rejoices” : the function of the craving for sensual pleasure accompanied by happiness is rejoicing, thus the Exalted One said “rejoices” .

original: kāmaparitosena haṭṭhatuṭṭho hotīti attho. Puttimāti puttavā. Pahūte cāyaṃ mā-saddoti
analyzed: kāma paritosena haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ hoti iti attho puttimā ati puttavā pahūte ca ayam māsaddaḥ ti
translated: “He delights” : the function of delighting is the sensual craving accompanied by happiness. “He is glad” : therefore the meaning is that he is glad and pleased with sensual joy. “He has sons” : he has children. The word “many” is a word for abundance.

original: āha “bahuputto”ti. Bahuputtatāgahaṇena idaṃ payojananti dassento “tassa hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: āha bahu putto ti bahu putta tā gahaṇena idam payojanam ti dassentaḥ tassa hi itiādim āha
translated: Therefore he says “he has many children.” Showing the purpose of mentioning “many children,” he says “for he who has many children.”

original: Pūrentīti padaṃ apekkhitvā dhaññassāti sāmivacanaṃ. Iti āhāti imamatthaṃ sandhāyāha,🔽evaṃadhippāyo hutvāti attho. Gosāmikoti gomā. Idhāpi pahūte mā-saddo. Gorasasampattinti
analyzed: pūrenti iti padam apekkhitvā dhaññassa ati sāmi vacanam iti āha ati imam attham sandhāya āha  evaṃadhippāyaḥ hutvā ti atthaḥ gosāmiko ti gomā idha api pahūte mā saddaḥ go rasa sampattinti
translated: The word “grain” is a word for master, in view of the word “he fills.” “Thus he says” : he says with reference to this meaning.

original: gorasehi nipphajjanasampattiṃ. Upadhīti paccattabahuvacanaṃ. Hīti hetuatthe nipāto.
analyzed: gorasehi nipphajjana sampattim upadhi iti paccatta bahuvacanam hi iti hetu atthe nipātaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he has such a desire. “He has cattle” : he has cows. Here too the word “many” is a word for abundance. “The abundance of the attainment of the essence of milk” : the abundance of the attainment of the essence of milk. “The fetters” : the plural is a form of address. “For” : the particle “hi” has the meaning of cause.

original: Nandayanti pītisomanassaṃ janayantīti nandanā. Kāmaṃ dukkhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato
analyzed: nandayanti pīti somanassam janayanti iti nandanā kāmam dukkhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato
translated: “Delight” : they delight, they generate happiness and joy. Although suffering is the basis,

original: nippariyāyato kāmā “upadhī”ti vattabbataṃ arahanti, tassā pana devatāya adhippāyavasenāha
analyzed: nippariyāyataḥ kāmāḥ upadhi iti vattabbatam arahanti tassā pana devatāya adhippāya vasena āha
translated: it is proper to call the sensual desires “fetters” in the ultimate sense, but because of the intention of that deity, he says

original: “sukhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato”ti. Kilesavatthuhetukattā sesapadadvayassa kiñcāpi sabbaṃ🔽saṃsāradukkhaṃ kilesahetukaṃ, visesato pana pāpadhammā apāyūpapattiṃ nibbattentīti
analyzed: sukhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato ti kilesa vatthu hetuka ttā sesa pada dvayassa kiñcā api sabbam  saṃsāra dukkham kilesa hetukam visesataḥ pana pāpa dhammāḥ apāyu upapattim nibbattenti iti
translated: “Because they are the basis for pleasure.” Although all suffering in the round of rebirths has its cause in the defilements, still evil states give rise to rebirth in the unhappy destinations.🔽Therefore it is said: “Because the defilements are the basis for the suffering of the unhappy destinations.”

original: āha – “kilesāpi apāyadukkhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato”ti. Upasaṃharamānāti upanentā uppādentā.🔽Manussajātikopi dullabhaghāsacchādanatāya dukkhabahulo peto viyāti manussapeto. Manussajātikopi
analyzed: āha kilesā api apāya dukkhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato ti upasaṃharamānā ati upanentā uppādentā  manussa jātikaḥ api dullabha ghāsa chādana tāya dukkha bahulaḥ petaḥ viyāti manussa petaḥ manussa jātikaḥ api
translated: “Bring to the fore”: cause to arise.🔽The human ghost is one who, though born as a human being, is still full of suffering because of the difficulty of obtaining food and clothing.

original: vuttarūpo anatthapātito parehi hiṃsito samāno nerayiko viyāti manussanerayiko.🔽Phalena rukkhato phalaṃ pātento viya. Tatheva navahākārehīti yathā tīsu kālesu nāsamaraṇabhedanavasena
analyzed: vutta rūpaḥ anattha pātitaḥ parehi hiṃsito samānaḥ nerayikaḥ viyāti manussa nerayikaḥ  phalena rukkhataḥ phalam pātentaḥ viya tathā iva navahā ākārehi iti yathā tīsu kālesu nāsā maraṇa bhedana vasena
translated: The human hell is one who, though born as a human being, is still like a hell being because of the suffering he undergoes when struck by others with sticks, etc., as a result of his evil conduct.🔽“Like a tree bearing fruit for the axe” : just as a tree bears fruit for its own destruction, so too, the man who is a ghost or a hell being suffers because of his own evil deeds.

original: puttimā puttanimittaṃ, tatheva gomā gonimittaṃ socati navappakārehi. Pañca kāmaguṇopadhīpi
analyzed: puttimā putta nimittam tathā iva gomā go nimittam socati nava ppakārehi pañca
translated: “In the same way, in nine aspects” : just as the man who is a ghost suffers because of his own evil deeds in the three times, so too, the man who is a hell being suffers in the same way in nine aspects.🔽“The five cords of sensual pleasure are the fetters” .

original: naraṃ socentīti yojanā. Tassāti yo uttari anugijjhati tassa. Kāmayānassāti jātakāmacchandassa.🔽Jantunoti sattassa. Parihāyanti ce vinassanti ce. Sallaviddhovāti sallena viddho
analyzed: naram socenti iti yojanā tassa ati yaḥ uttari anugijjhati tassa kāmayānassa ati jāta kāmacchandassa  jantunā uti sattassa parihāyanti ce vinassanti ce salla viddhaḥ uvāti sallena viddhaḥ
translated: The construction is: they torment a man. His: the one who goes further. Yearning: for sensual desires.

original: viya. Ruppatīti vikāraṃ āpajjati, socatīti attho. Narassa socanā sokaghaṭṭanapaccayo.
analyzed: viya ruppati iti vikāram āpajjati socati iti atthaḥ narassa socanā soka ghaṭṭana paccayo
translated: Of the creature: of the being. They perish: they are destroyed. As if pierced by a dart: as if pierced by a dart. He suffers: he undergoes a change, is afflicted, is the meaning. The sorrow of a man is a condition for the striking of sorrow.

original: Upadhayo natthīti kāmaṃ kilesābhisaṅkhārūpadhayo tāva khīṇāsavassa nattheva maggādhigamena
analyzed: upadhayaḥ natthi iti kāmam kilesa abhisaṅkhāra upadhayaḥ tāva khīṇa āsavassa nattha iva magga adhigamena
translated: He has no acquisitions: the defilements, which are the acquisitions of formations, are indeed absent in one who is an Arahant, because they have been stopped by the attainment of the path.

original: nirodhitattā, khandhūpadhayo pana kathanti? Tepi tassa saupādisesakālepi aṭṭhuppattihetubhūtā
analyzed: nirodhi tattā khandhūpadhayaḥ pana kathanti te pi tassa aṭṭhuppatti hetu bhūtā
translated: But how can the acquisitions of aggregates be absent in him? They are not absent in him even when he is still subject to the Sotapanna’s eight or more rebirths, because they are the cause for the arising of the eight.

original: na santeva, ayañca anupādisesakāle. Tenāha “so nirupadhi mahākhīṇāsavo”ti.
analyzed: na santā iva ayam ca an upādisesa kāle tena āha saḥ nirupadhi mahā khīṇāsavaḥ iti
translated: But in the state when he is no longer subject to them, they are absent. Therefore it is said: “He is without acquisitions, a great Arahant.”

original: Nandatisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nandati sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Nandati sutta is finished.

original: 3. Natthiputtasamasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Natthiputtasamasutta

original: 13. Puttapemaṃ puttaggahaṇena gahitaṃ uttarapadalopenāti āha “puttapemasama”nti.
analyzed: puttapemam putta ggahaṇena gahitam uttara pada lopena iti āha puttapemasamam ti
translated: is finished. The love of a son is included by the word “son” with the omission of the latter part of the compound. Therefore it is said: “equal to the love of a son.”

original: Gosamitanti gohi samaṃ kataṃ. Tenāha “gohi sama”nti. Sūriyassa samāti sūriyasamā.
analyzed: gosamitam ti go hi samam katam tena āha go hi samanti sūriyassa samā ati sūriya samā
translated: Gosamā means made equal to cows. Hence he said “equal to cows.” Sūriyasamā means equal to the sun.

original: Avayavasambandhe cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Avayavo cettha ābhā evāti viññāyati “anantaraṃ🔽ābhā”ti vuccamānattāti āha “sūriyābhāya samā”tiādi. Mahoghabhāvena saranti savantīti
analyzed: avayava sambandhe sāmi vacanam ca itthā ābhā eva ati viññāyati anantaram  ābhāti āha sūriya ābhāya mahā ogha bhāvena saranti savanti iti
translated: This is a possessive expression in the sense of “having a part in common.” And here the part in common is light. This is understood because it is said immediately after the light.

original: sarā, mahantā jalāsayā. Sabbe te samuddaparamā orimajanehi adiṭṭhaparatīrattā tassa.
analyzed: sarā mahantā jalāsayā sabbe te samudda paramāḥ orima janehi a diṭṭha para tīra ttā tassa
translated: Hence he said “equal to the light of the sun.” Saranti means they flow. The great waters are sarā because they flow. All of them are the ultimate of the oceans because the people on this side of the ocean have never seen the other shore.

original: Natthi attasamaṃ pemanti gāthāya paṭhamagāthāyaṃ vuttanayena attho veditabbo. Attapemena🔽samaṃ pemaṃ nāma natthīti ayamattho. Anudakakantāre ghammasantāpaṃ asahantiyā aṅke🔽ṭhapitaputtakaṃ kandantaṃ bhūmiyaṃ nipajjāpetvā tassa upari ṭhatvā mataitthivatthunā
analyzed: natthi atta samam pemanti gāthāya paṭhama gāthāyam vutta nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ atta pemena  samam pemam nāma natthi iti ayam atthaḥ an udaka kantāre ghamma santāpam a sahantiyā aṅke  ṭhapita puttakam kandantam bhūmiyam nipajjāpetvā tassa upari ṭhatvā mata aitthi vatthunā
translated: Natthi attasamaṃ pemanti. The meaning should be understood in the way stated in the first stanza. The meaning is this: there is no love equal to self-love.🔽This is illustrated by the story of the woman who, unable to bear the heat of the desert, laid her crying child on the ground,

original: dīpetabbaṃ. Tenāha – “mātāpitādayo hi chaḍḍetvāpi puttadhītādayo”ti. Tathā cāha –
analyzed: dīpetabbam tena āha mātā pitā ādayaḥ hi chaḍḍetvā api tathā ca āha
translated: stood on top of him, and died. Hence he said: “For parents and so on, even though they abandon their children, they do so for the sake of their own welfare.” And he said:

original: “Sabbā disā anuparigamma cetasā,
analyzed: sabbāḥ disāḥ anuparigamma cetasā
translated: “Having gone around in all directions with the mind,

original: Nevajjhagā piyataramattanā kvaci;
analyzed: piyatara mattanā kvaci
translated: Nowhere did he find anything dearer than his own self.

original: Evaṃ piyo puthu attā paresaṃ,
analyzed: evam piyaḥ puthu attā paresam
translated: So dear to others is his own self,

original: Tasmā na hiṃse paramattakāmo”ti. ;
analyzed: tasmai na hiṃse paramatta kāmā iti
translated: Therefore one who desires his own happiness should not harm another.”

original: Dhaññena samaṃ dhanaṃ nāma natthi, yasmā tappaṭibaddhā āhārūpajīvīnaṃ sattānaṃ jīvitavutti.
analyzed: dhaññena samam dhanam nāma natthi yasmā tad paṭibaddhā āhāra upajīvīnam sattānam jīvita vutti
translated: There is no wealth equal to grain, since the life and livelihood of beings who subsist on food are bound up with it.

original: Tathārūpe kāleti dubbhikkhakāle. Ekadesaṃyeva obhāsantīti ekasmiṃ khaṇe catūsu mahādīpesu🔽obhāsaṃ pharituṃ asamatthattā sūriyassapi, pageva itaresaṃ. Bodhisattassa udayabbayassa
analyzed: tathārūpe kāle iti dubbhikkha kāle eka desaṃyeva obhāsanti iti ekasmin khaṇe catūsu mahā dīpesu  obhāsam pharitum a samattha ttā sūriyassa api pagā iva itaresam bodhisattassa udaya bbayassa
translated: It illuminates only a part, for the sun too, which is unable to spread its light at one moment over the four great continents,

original: ñāṇānubhāvena sakalajātikhettaṃ ekālokaṃ ahosīti āha “paññā…pe… sakkotī”ti. Tamaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa anubhāvena sakala jāti khettam ekālokam ahosi iti āha paññāpe sakkoti iti tamam
translated: is able to do so by the power of the Bodhisatta’s knowledge of the rise and fall of the world. Therefore it is said: “Wisdom … is able to.”

original: vidhamatīti pubbenivāsañāṇādayo paññā yattha pavattanti, tamanavasesaṃ byāpetvā ekappahārena
analyzed: vidhamati iti pubbenivāsa ñāṇa ādayaḥ paññāḥ yattha pavattanti tam anavasesam byāpetvā eka ppahārena
translated: It dispels darkness, for wherever the wisdom of the knowledge of past lives, etc., occurs, it pervades that place without remainder and occurs all at once,

original: pavattanato. “Vuṭṭhiyā pana pavattamānāya yāva ābhassarabhavanā”ti pacuravasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pavattanataḥ vuṭṭhiyā pana pavattamānāya yāva ābhassara bhavanā ti pacura vasena vuttam
translated: as it is said: “But when the light occurs, it occurs up to the plane of the gods of Radiance.”

original: Natthiputtasamasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: natthiputtasama sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Natthiputtasutta is finished.

original: 4. Khattiyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: khattiya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Khattiyasutta

original: 14. Khettato vivādā satte tāyatīti khattiyo. Vadati devatā attano ajjhāsayavasena.🔽Dvipadādīnanti ādi-saddena catuppadabhariyaputtā gahitā. Buddhādayoti ādi-saddena🔽ājānīyasussūsabhariyassavaputtā. Dvipadānaṃ seṭṭhoti ettha dvipadānaṃ eva seṭṭhoti
analyzed: khettataḥ vivādā satte tāyati iti khattiyaḥ vadati devatāḥ attanaḥ ajjhāsaya vasena  ādi saddena catuppada bhariya puttāḥ gahitāḥ buddha ādayaḥ ti ādi saddena  ājānīya sussūsa bhariyassava puttāḥ dvipadānam seṭṭhaḥ ti ettha dvipadānam eva seṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: “He is a khattiya because he is a warrior (khati) of the gods, he speaks (vadati) according to his own inclination.

original: nāyaṃ niyamo icchito, seṭṭho evāti pana icchito, tasmā sambuddho dvipadesu aññesu
analyzed: na ayam niyamaḥ icchito seṭṭhaḥ evā ti pana icchito tasmā sambuddhaḥ dvipadesu aññesu
translated: “Of bipeds” and so on: the word “and so on” includes quadrupeds, beasts of burden, and their young. “Of Buddhas” and so on: the word “and so on” includes thoroughbreds, pupils, beasts of burden, and their young. “The best of bipeds”: here it is not intended that he is the best of bipeds only,

original: tattha ca uppajjanato seṭṭho eva sabbesampi uttaritarassa abhāvatoti ayamettha attho.🔽Tenāha “uppajjamāno panesā”tiādi. Kāraṇākāraṇaṃ ājānātīti ājānīyo. Gaṇhāpethāti yathā
analyzed: tattha ca uppajjanato seṭṭhaḥ eva sabbesam pi uttaritarassa abhāvato ti ayam ettha attho  tena āha uppajjamānaḥ pana isā atiādi kāraṇa akāraṇam ājānāti iti ājānīyaḥ gaṇhāpetha iti yathā
translated: but that he is the best of all, therefore the meaning here is that he is the best of all because he is the only one who has arisen and will arise in the world.🔽Therefore it is said: “But when he arises” and so on. “He is a thoroughbred (ājānīya) because he knows what is the reason and what is not the reason.” “Make him take the reins” means: make him take the reins in such a way that he will not be confused.

original: udako na temissati, evaṃ vāḷaṃ gaṇhāpetha. “Asussūsā”ti keci paṭhanti. Āsuṇamānoti
analyzed: udakaḥ na temissati evam vāḷam gaṇhāpetha asussūsa iti keci paṭhanti āsuṇamānaḥ iti
translated: Some read “asussūsā” . “Listening” means

original: sappaṭissavo hutvā vacanasampaṭicchako.
analyzed: sa paṭissavaḥ hutvā vacana sampaṭicchakaḥ
translated: listening with approval, being one who assents to the words.

original: Khattiyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khattiya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Khattiya Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Saṇamānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṇamāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Sanamana Sutta

original: 15. Ṭhite majjhanhiketi pubbaddhaṃ nikkhamitvā aparaddhaṃ appatvā ṭhitamajjhanhe.
analyzed: ṭhite majjhanhikā iti pubbaddham nikkhamitvā aparaddham a patvā ṭhita majjhanhe
translated: In the middle of the day when he is standing: having gone out in the morning, before reaching the evening, while standing in the middle of the day.

original: Sannisīvesūti parissamavinodanatthaṃ sabbaso sannisīdantesu. Da-kārassa hi va-kāraṃ🔽katvā niddeso. Tenāha “sannisinnesu vissamamānesū”ti. Sabbasattānanti sabbesañca
analyzed: sannisīvesu iti parissama vinodana attham sabbaso sannisīdantesu dakārassa hi vakāram  katvā niddesaḥ tena āha sannisinnesu vissamamānesu iti sabba sattānam ti sabbesam ca
translated: Let them sit down all together: let them sit down completely, in order to remove their fatigue. For the letter da is replaced by the letter va

original: āhārūpajīvitasattānaṃ ghammatāpane santattakāyānaṃ iriyāpathadubbalyakāloti ṭhānādiiriyāpathassa
analyzed: āhāra upajīvita sattānam ghamma tāpane santatta kāyānam iriyāpatha dubbalya kālo ti ṭhāna ādi iriyāpathassa
translated: in the text. Therefore it is said: “when they are sitting down, when they are fatigued.” All beings: all beings who live by food, whose bodies are heated, whose time of activity is weak in posture. The time of activity, such as standing, etc.,

original: asamatthakālo. Saṇati viyāti saddaṃ karoti viya, yathā taṃ aññampi mahāvanaṃ vakkhamānanayena.
analyzed: asamattha kālo saṇati viya ati saddam karoti viya yathā tam aññam pi mahā vanam vakkhamāna nayena
translated: is the time of weakness. It is as if it were making a sound: it is as if it were making a sound, as if it were another great forest, in the manner of the explanation given.

original: Tenāha “tappaṭibhāgaṃ nāmeta”nti chiddaveṇupabbānanti randhajātakīcakamahāveḷupabbānaṃ.
analyzed: tena āha tad paṭibhāgam nāma etat ti chidda veṇu pabbānam ti randha jāta kīcaka mahāveḷu pabbānam
translated: Therefore it is said: “This is not a substitute for the sound.” In the bamboo grove: in the bamboo grove of the great reeds of the randha-jātaka.

original: Dutiyakaṃ sahāyaṃ alabhantī anabhiratiparitassanāya evamāha. Anappakaṃ sukhanti vipulaṃ
analyzed: dutiyakam sahāyam a labhantī an abhirati paritassanāya evam āha anappakam sukhanti vipulam
translated: Not finding a second friend, she said this because of her dissatisfaction and anxiety. Great happiness: extensive,

original: uḷāraṃ vivekasukhaṃ.
analyzed: uḷāram viveka sukham
translated: excellent, the happiness of seclusion.

original: Ekavihāratāya suññāgāraṃ paviṭṭhassa. Tena kāyavivekaṃ dasseti. Aniccānupassanādīhi🔽niccasaññādippahānena santacittassa. Tena cittavivekaṃ dasseti. Saṃsāre bhayaṃ ikkhanato
analyzed: eka vihāra tāya suññāgāram paviṭṭhassa tena kāya vivekam dasseti anicca anupassanā ādīhi  nicca saññā ādi ppahānena santa cittassa tena citta vivekam dasseti saṃsāre bhayam ikkhanataḥ
translated: “Who has entered an empty place, having gone forth alone”: he shows bodily seclusion by this. “Whose mind is peaceful through the contemplation of impermanence, etc.,🔽by the abandoning of the perception of permanence, and so on”: he shows mental seclusion by this. “Who sees fear in the world”🔽

original: bhikkhuno ubhayavivekasampannassa, tato eva uttariṃ manussadhammato ratiṃ lābhino.🔽Amānusī ratīti bhāvanārati. Puratoti purimabhāge. Pacchatoti pacchimabhāge. Aparoti
analyzed: bhikkhunaḥ ubhaya viveka sampannassa tatas eva uttarim manussa dhammataḥ ratim lābhinaḥ  amānusī ratīti bhāvanā rati puratoti purima bhāge pacchatoti pacchima bhāge
translated: “Who has entered an empty place” : who has entered a secluded place. This shows bodily seclusion. “Whose mind is tranquil” : whose mind is tranquil through the abandoning of the perception of permanence, etc., by means of the contemplation of impermanence, etc. This shows mental seclusion. “The bhikkhu who beholds fear in the world” : the bhikkhu who sees fear in the round of rebirths. He is endowed with both kinds of seclusion and finds delight in the supramundane state that transcends the human level.

original: añño. Puratoti vā anāgate, anāgataṃ ārabbhāti attho. Pacchatoti atīte atītaṃ ārabbha
analyzed: puratas ti vā anāgate anāgatam ārabbha ati attho pacchatas ti atīte atītam ārabbha
translated: “Delight that is not of men” : the delight of development. “In front” : in the earlier part. “Behind” : in the later part. “Another” : a different one. “In front” can also mean in the future; the meaning is: in regard to the future. “Behind” means in the past; in regard to the past.

original: paṭipattiyā vibādhanato. Paroti kodho cittapaṭidussanatāya. Na paroti aparo, lobho,🔽so ce na vijjati. Etena anāgatappajappanāya atītānusocanāya ca abhāvaṃ dasseti. Atīva
analyzed: paṭipattiyāḥ vibādhanataḥ paroti kodho citta paṭidussana tāya na paroti aparaḥ lobho  saḥ ce na vijjati etena anāgata ppajappanāya atīta anusocanāya ca abhāvam dasseti atīva
translated: because it obstructs the practice. “No other” : no anger, because it is a disturbance of the mind. “If there is no other” : no greed,

original: phāsu bhavatīti nīvaraṇajeṭṭhakassa kāmacchandassa vigamena vikkhambhitanīvaraṇassa
analyzed: phāsu bhavati iti nīvaraṇa jeṭṭhakassa kāmacchandassa vigamena vikkhambhita nīvaraṇassa
translated: This shows the absence of longing for the future and of grieving for the past. “He dwells quite at ease” : he dwells with the hindrances suppressed, through the absence of sensual desire, which is the foremost of the hindrances.

original: jhānassa vasena ativiya phāsuvihāro hoti. Ekassa vasato vaneti taṇhādutiyikābhāvena
analyzed: jhānassa vasena ativiya phāsu vihāro hoti ekassa vasataḥ vaneti taṇhā dutiyikā bhāvena
translated: He has a very comfortable abiding by means of jhāna. Alone, he lives in the forest:

original: ekassa araññe vivekavāsaṃ vasato. Sesaṃ tādisamevāti sesamettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: ekassa araññe viveka vāsam vasato sesam tādisam eva ati sesam ettha yat vattabbam tam
translated: he lives alone in the forest, without a companion, because of the absence of a companion in the form of craving. The rest is the same as that

original: paṭhamagāthāyaṃ vuttasadisameva.
analyzed: paṭhama gāthāyam vutta sadisam eva
translated: in the first stanza.

original: Saṇamānasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saṇamāna sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Saṇamāna Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Niddātandīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: niddātandī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Nidda-tandisutta

original: 16. Pacchime māse pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapetvā
analyzed: pacchime māse pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkanto catugguṇam saṅghāṭim paññapetvā
translated: In the last month, after his meal, he returned from his alms round, folded his outer robe in four, and lay down on his right side.

original: dakkhiṇena passena sato sampajānoti ettakaṃ pāṭhaṃ saṅkhipitvā “niddaṃ okkamitā”ti
analyzed: dakkhiṇena passena sataḥ sampajānoti ettakam pāṭham saṅkhipitvā niddam okkamitā ati
translated: He was mindful and clearly comprehending, thinking, “I will not get up until I have attained the destruction of the taints.”

original: vuttaṃ. Kiriyāmayacittehi avomisso bhavaṅgasoto abyākataniddā. Sā hi khīṇāsavānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam kiriyā āmaya cittehi avomissaḥ bhavaṅga sotaḥ abyākata niddā sā hi khīṇa āsavānam
translated: The stream of consciousness, which is not interrupted by functional consciousness, is indeterminate sleep. For that is the kind of consciousness that is ready to arise in those whose cankers are destroyed.

original: uppajjanārahā, tassā pubbabhāgāparabhāgesu…pe… uppannaṃ thinamiddhaṃ idhādhippetā
analyzed: uppajjana arahā tassā pubbabhāga aparabhāge supe uppannam thinam iddham idha adhippetā
translated: The drowsiness and sleep that occur in its prior and subsequent stages are what is meant here by “sleep.”

original: niddā, sā akhīṇāsavānaṃ yebhuyyena aniyatakālā, tabbidhuraniyatasabbhāvaṃ dassento
analyzed: niddā sā akhīṇāsavānam yebhuyyena aniyata kālā tad bidhuḥ aniyata sabbhāvam dassentaḥ
translated: For the most part, sleep is not fixed in time for those whose cankers are not yet destroyed. But in order to show that it is fixed in time for those who are diligent,

original: “aticchāta…pe… āgantukaṃ ālasiya”nti āha. Kāyālasiyapaccayā vīriyassa paṭipakkhabhūtā
analyzed: aticchā ātape āgantukam ālasiyanti āha kāya ālasiya paccayā vīriyassa paṭipakkha bhūtā
translated: “I’m too tired … I’m a newcomer and tired.”🔽Because of physical tiredness, he was opposed to energy.

original: cattāro akusalakkhandhā tandī nāma. Tandīti sabhāvaniddeso. Tandiyanāti ākāraniṃddeso.🔽Tandīmanatāti tandībhūtacittatā. Ālasyanti alasabhāvāharaṇaṃ. Ālasyāyitattanti alasabhāvappatti.
analyzed: cattāro akusala kkhandhā tandī nāma tandī iti sabhāva niddeso ākāra niddeso  tandīmanatā ati tandībhūta citta tā ālasyanti alasa bhāva āharaṇam
translated: “Laziness” is the four unprofitable aggregates that are opposed to energy and are a condition for laziness.🔽“Sluggishness” is a description of the state; “sluggishness-drowsiness” is a description of the mode.🔽“Drowsiness” is the state of the mind’s being sluggish. “Laziness” is the state of the body’s being sluggish. “Laziness-drowsiness” is the state of the body and mind’s being sluggish.

original: Kāyavijambhanāti kāyassa vināmanā. Akusalapakkhā ukkaṇṭhitatāti akusalapakkhiyā anabhirati.
analyzed: kāya vijambhanā ati kāyassa vināmanā akusala pakkhā ukkaṇṭhita tā ati akusala pakkhiyā anabhirati
translated: “Stretching” is the bending of the body. “Discontent” is dissatisfaction with the unprofitable side.

original: Bhattakilamathoti yathāvuttassa bhattavatthukassa āhārassa vasena sarīre uppajjanakakhedo.
analyzed: bhatta kilamatho ti yathā vuttassa bhatta vatthukassa āhārassa vasena sarīre uppajjanaka khedaḥ
translated: “Fatigue” is weariness arisen in the body through the food that has been eaten.

original: Upakkiliṭṭhoti paññāya dubbalīkaraṇena upakkiliṭṭhacitto. Cittassa asamāhitattā nivāritapātubhāvo.🔽Ariyamaggassa jotanaṃ nāma uppajjanamevāti āha “na jotati, na pātubhavatīti attho”ti.
analyzed: upakkiliṭṭhaḥ ti paññāya dubbalīkaraṇena upakkiliṭṭha citto cittassa asamāhita ttā nivārita pātubhāvo  ariya maggassa jotanam nāma uppajjanam eva ati āha na jotati na pātubhavati iti attho ti
translated: “Defilement” is the defilement of the mind by the weakening of understanding. “The mind does not become concentrated” is the prevention of the manifestation of concentration.🔽“The path does not become clear” is the non-arising of the path.

original: Na hi ariyamaggo jotiajotināmo pavattati.
analyzed: na hi ariya maggaḥ joti ajoti nāmo pavattati
translated: The noble path is not called “light” or “clear” when it occurs.

original: Maggasahajātavīriyenāti lokiyalokuttaramaggasahajātavīriyena. Missakamaggo hi idha
analyzed: magga sahajāta vīriyena ati lokiya lokuttara magga sahajāta vīriyena missaka maggaḥ hi idha
translated: “By energy that is born together with the path”: by energy that is born together with the supramundane path.🔽For the mixed path is intended here.🔽“Having removed”: because of the removal. For this word tvā has the meaning of cause,

original: adhippeto. Nīharitvāti nīharaṇahetu. Hetuattho hi ayaṃ tvā-saddo “paññāya cassa disvā”tiādīsu
analyzed: adhippetaḥ nīharitvā ti nīharaṇa hetu hetu atthaḥ hi ayam tvā saddo paññāya cassa disvā iti ādīsu
translated: like the word disvā in the passage, “Having seen with wisdom” (S V 21).🔽Thus the statement, “The path is purified,” is established.

original: viya. Tena “maggo visujjhatī”ti vacanaṃ samatthitaṃ hoti. “Ariyamaggaṃ visujjhatī”ti keci paṭhanti.
analyzed: viya tena maggaḥ visujjhati iti vacanam samatthitam hoti ariya maggam visujjhati iti keci paṭhanti
translated: Some read “The noble path is purified.”

original: Niddātandīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: niddātandī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Nidda-tandasutta is finished.

original: 7. Dukkarasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dukkara sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Difficult Things Sutta

original: 17. Dukkhaṃ titikkhanti duttitikkhaṃ. Tañca dukkhamaṃ dussahanaṃ ārambhavasena dukkaraṃ,🔽anuyuñjanavasena duttitikkhanti. Abyattenāti sāmaññassa upakārānupakāre dhamme jānanasamatthāya
analyzed: dukkham titikkhanti duttitikkham tat ca dukkhamam dussahanam ārambha vasena dukkaram  anuyuñjana vasena duttitikkhanti abyattena ati sāmaññassa upakāra anupakāre dhamme jānana samatthāya
translated: They endure suffering, so they are “endurers of pain.” And that suffering is difficult to endure because it is hard to begin,🔽and it is difficult to endure because it is hard to pursue.

original: veyyattiyasaṅkhātāya paññāya abhāvato na byattena. Tenāha “bālenā”ti. Yasmiṃ dhamme
analyzed: veyyattiya saṅkhātāya paññāya abhāvataḥ na byattena tena āha bālena ati yasmin dhamme
translated: “Not being diligent”: not being diligent because of the absence of the understanding called “diligence” which is the ability to know things that are helpful and not helpful to the life of a recluse.🔽Therefore he said, “by a fool.”🔽The life of a recluse is called “the life of a recluse” because of the existence of this thing.

original: sati samaṇoti vuccati, taṃ sāmaññanti āha “samaṇadhammo”ti. Imināti “dukkaraṃ duttitikkhañca,
analyzed: sati samaṇaḥ iti vuccati tam sāmaññanti āha samaṇa dhammo ti iminā ati dukkaram duttitikkham ca
translated: Therefore he said, “the life of a recluse.” “This”: the difficult things and the enduring of pain,

original: abyattena ca sāmañña”nti iminā gāthaddhena idaṃ dassetīti idaṃ idāni vuccamānaṃ atthajātaṃ
analyzed: abyattena ca iminā gāthaddhena idam dasseti iti idam idāni vuccamānam attha jātam
translated: And with the unvirtuous, the state of recluseship” , he shows this.

original: dasseti. Abhidantanti abhibhavanadantaṃ, uparidantanti attho. So hi itaraṃ musalaṃ
analyzed: dassa iti abhidantam ti abhibhavana dantam upari dantam ti attho saḥ hi itaram musalam
translated: The meaning-class now being spoken of is shown.

original: viya udukkhalaṃ visesato kassaci khādanakāle abhibhuyya vattati. Ādhāyāti nippīḷanavaseneva
analyzed: viya udukkhalam visesataḥ kassaci khādana kāle abhibhuyya vattati ādhāya ati nippīḍana vasena iva
translated: “With the upper teeth” means with the upper teeth that overpower. The meaning is: “with the upper teeth”. For that one acts, having overpowered the other, as it were, a pestle, a mortar, especially at the time of eating someone’s food.🔽“Having placed” means having placed by way of oppressing.

original: ṭhapetvā. Tāluṃ āhaccāti tālupadesamāhanitvā viya. Cetasāti kusalacittena. Cittanti
analyzed: ṭhapetvā tālum cetasā ati kusala cittena cittam ti
translated: “Having closed the palate” means having closed the place of the palate, as it were. “With the mind” means with the wholesome mind. “The mind” means

original: akusalacittaṃ. Abhiniggaṇhitvāti yathā atisamudācāro na hoti, evaṃ vibādhanavasena
analyzed: akusala cittam abhiniggaṇhitvā iti yathā atisamudācāraḥ na evam vibādhana vasena
translated: the unwholesome mind. “Having suppressed” means having suppressed by way of obstructing, so that there is no excessive occurrence.🔽“To the end of the nose” means to the end of the tip of the nose. The meaning is: “to the end of the tip of the nose”.

original: niggahetvā. Āpāṇakoṭikanti pāṇakoṭipariyosānaṃ, parijīvanti attho. Sambādhetīti sambādho,
analyzed: niggahetvā āpāṇakoṭikam ti pāṇa koṭi pariyosānam parijīvanti sambādheti iti sambādhaḥ
translated: “It obstructs” means it is an obstruction, an impediment.

original: antarāyiko. Bahū parissayāti ayoniso kāmavitakkādivasena.
analyzed: antarāyikaḥ ayonisaḥ kāma vitakka ādi vasena
translated: “Many dangers” means by way of the unprofitable sensual-desire-thought, etc.

original: Pajjati cittametthāti padaṃ, ārammaṇaṃ. Iriyāpathaṃ eva padaṃ iriyāpathapadaṃ.
analyzed: pajjati cittam ettha ati padam ārammaṇam iriyāpatham eva padam iriyāpatha padam
translated: “The foot is the place where the mind occurs” means the object. “The foot of the posture” means the posture-foot.

original: Gīvā cattāro pādāti gīvapañcamāni. Samodahanti vā samodhānahetūti ayamettha atthoti
analyzed: gīvā cattāro pādā ati gīva pañcamāni samodahanti vā samodhāna hetu uti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti
translated: The meaning here is this: “Or they are the cause of the combination.”

original: āha – “samodahitvā vā”ti, sammā odhāya anto pavesetvāti attho. Sake ārammaṇakapāleti
analyzed: āha samodahitvā vā ati sammā odhāya antar pavesetvā ati attho sake ārammaṇa kapāle ti
translated: He said: “Or having combined,” the meaning is: having combined them well, having brought them inside.🔽In his own mind’s domain.

original: gocarajjhattaṃ vadati. Samodahanti samodahanto. Anissitoti tebhūmakadhammesu kañcipi
analyzed: gocara ajjhattam vadati samodahanti samodahantaḥ anissitaḥ ti tebhūmaka dhammesu kañcipi
translated: He combines, combining. He is not attached to anything in the dhammas of the three planes of existence.

original: dhammaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhābhinivesavasena anissito. Avihiṃsamāno vihiṃsānimittānaṃ pajahanena.
analyzed: dhammam taṇhā diṭṭha abhinivesa vasena anissitaḥ a vihiṃsamānaḥ vihiṃsā nimittānam pajahanena
translated: He is not attached to any dhamma through craving or views. He is not violent, having abandoned the signs of violence.

original: Ullumpanasabhāvasaṇṭhitenāti sīlabyasanato uddharaṇarūpe saṇṭhitena, karuṇāyuttenāti
analyzed: ullumpana sabhāva saṇṭhitena ati sīla byasanataḥ uddharaṇa rūpe saṇṭhitena karuṇā yuttena ati
translated: He is established in the nature of uplifting, the meaning is: he is established in the nature of rescuing from the misfortune of virtue, he is endowed with compassion.

original: attho. Tenāha “kāruññataṃ paṭiccā”ti.
analyzed: atthaḥ tena āha kāruñña tam paṭicca iti
translated: Therefore he said: “Out of compassion.”

original: Dukkarasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dukkara sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Difficult Discourse is finished.

original: 8. Hirīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: hirī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on Shame

original: 18. Nisedhetīti nivāreti pavattituṃ na deti. Pucchati devatā. Apaharantoti apanento,
analyzed: nisedheti iti nivāreti pavattitum na deti pucchati devatā apaharantaḥ iti apanentaḥ
translated: He restrains: he prevents, he does not allow to occur. The deity asks. He removes: he takes away,

original: yathā sabbena sabbaṃ akkosavatthu na hoti, evaṃ pariharantoti attho. Bujjhati sārathividhaṃ.
analyzed: yathā sabbena sabbam akkosa vatthu na hoti evam pariharantaḥ iti atthaḥ bujjhati sārathi vidham
translated: the meaning is: he avoids, so that the basis for abuse does not happen in any way at all. He is awake, like a charioteer.

original: Attani nipātaṃ na deti, ājānīyo hi yuttaṃ pajānāti. Abhūtena abhūtakkosena parimutto
analyzed: attani nipātam na deti ājānīyaḥ hi yuttam pajānāti abhūtena abhūta kkosena parimuttaḥ
translated: He does not give himself up to the self, for the thoroughbred understands the yoke.

original: nāma natthi bālānañca janānaṃ parāpavāde yuttapayuttabhāvato. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: nāma natthi bālānam ca janānam para apavāde yutta payutta bhāvato tena āha bhagavā
translated: There is no one who is free from the slander of fools, because of their being occupied with the faults of others. Therefore the Blessed One said:

original: “Nindanti tuṇhimāsīnaṃ, nindanti bahubhāṇinaṃ;
analyzed: nindanti tuṇhim āsīnam nindanti bahu bhāṇinam
translated: “They blame one who sits in silence, they blame one who speaks much;

original: Mitabhāṇimpi nindanti, natthi loke anindito”ti. ;
analyzed: mita bhāṇim pi nindanti natthi loke a nindito ti
translated: They blame one who speaks little, there is no one in the world who is not blamed.”

original: Tanuyāti vā katipayā. Tenāha “appakā”ti. Sadā satāti hirinisedhabhāve kāraṇavacanaṃ. Pappuyyāti patvā adhigantvā. Vānato nikkhantattā nibbānaṃ, asaṅkhatadhātu.
analyzed: tanuyā ati vā katipayā tena āha appakā iti sadā satā iti hiri nisedha bhāve kāraṇa vacanam pappuyyā ati patvā adhigantvā vānataḥ nikkhanta ttā nibbānam asaṅkhata dhātu
translated: “Few” means a few. “Always” means in the state of shame and abashment. “Having gone” means having reached, having attained. Nibbāna is the unconditioned element, because it has gone out from the mouth.

original: Hirīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: hirī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Exposition of the Discourse on Shame is finished.

original: 9. Kuṭikāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kuṭikā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Discourse on the Hut

original: 19. Antoti kucchiabbhantare. Vasanaṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti vasanabhāvena. Kulapaveṇinti kulācāraṃ
analyzed: antare iti kucchi abbhantare vasana ṭhāna ṭṭhena ati vasana bhāvena kula paveṇim ti kula ācāram
translated: “Inside” means inside the belly. “As a place of dwelling” means as a state of dwelling. “Family tradition” means the conduct of the family, the family custom.

original: kulatantiṃ. Santānakaṭṭhenāti kulasantatiyā bandhanabhāvena. Evaṃ sabbapadehi pucchitatthassa
analyzed: kula tantim santāna kaṭṭhena ati kula santatiyāḥ bandhana bhāvena evam sabba padehi pucchitatthassa
translated: “Family line” means as a bond of the family continuity. Thus, the meaning of the question in all the passages is this:

original: anujānanavasena “ekaṃsavacane nipāto”ti vuttaṃ. Āpādikā posikā mātucchā mahāpajāpati🔽mātā evāti katvā “pahāya pabbajitattā”ti avisesato vuttaṃ. Pahāya pabbajitattā natthīti
analyzed: anujānana vasena ekaṃsa vacane nipāto ti vuttam āpādikā posikā mātucchā mahāpajāpati  mātā eva ati katvā pahāya pabbajita ttā ti avisesataḥ vuttam pahāya pabbajita ttā natthi iti
translated: is called “mother” and is referred to without distinction as “having gone forth after abandoning her.”🔽Having gone forth after abandoning her, there is no🔽. The connection is made by bringing in the words “having gone forth after abandoning her.”

original: ānetvā sambandho. Puna mātukucchivāsādīnaṃ abhāvavacaneneva vaṭṭamhi bandhanassa🔽abhāvo dīpito hotīti na gahito. Ayaṃ kira devatā yathā puthujjanā buddhānaṃ guṇe
analyzed: ānetvā sambandhaḥ puna mātukucchi vāsa ādīnam abhāva vacanena iva bandhanassa  abhāvaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti iti na gahitaḥ ayam kira devatāḥ yathā puthujjanāḥ buddhānam guṇe
translated: Since the absence of rebirth in the mother’s womb, etc., is shown by the words “there is no,” the absence of bondage in the round of rebirths is also shown and so is not mentioned again.

original: na jānanti, evaṃ na jānāti, tasmā “mayā sannāhaṃ bandhitvā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: na jānanti evam na jānāti tasmai mayā sannā aham bandhitvā ati ādim āha
translated: This deity, it seems, did not know the qualities of the Buddhas as ordinary people do, and so she said: “Having girded up my loins,” etc.

original: Kuṭikāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kuṭikā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Kuṭikāsutta is finished.

original: 10. Samiddhisuttavaṇṇanā🔽20. Tapanabhāvena tapanodakattā tapodāti tassa rahadassa nāmaṃ. Tenāha “tattodakassa
analyzed: samiddhi sutta vaṇṇanā  tapana bhāvena tapana udaka ttā tapodāti tassa rahadassa nāmam tena āha tattodakassa
translated: The commentary on the Samiddhisutta🔽The name of the lake is “Tapoda” because it is hot by nature and because its water is hot. Therefore it is said: “of the lake whose water is hot.”

original: rahadassā”ti. Tatoti nāgabhavane udakarahadato tapodā nāma nadī sandati. Sā hi nadī
analyzed: tatas uti nāgabhavane tapodā nāma nadī sandati sā hi nadī
translated: From that, from the water of the lake in the nāga’s abode, the river called “Tapoda” flows out.

original: bhūmitalaṃ ārohati. “Edisā jātā”ti vacanaseso. Petalokoti lohakumbhinirayā idhādhippetāti
analyzed: bhūmi talam ārohati edisāḥ jātā ati vacana seso peta loko ti loha kumbhi nirayāḥ idha adhippetā ati
translated: he mounts the ground. The remainder of the words is “such as this.” The “petals” are the hell of the iron cauldron, it is said, that is intended here.

original: vadanti. Rahadassa pana ādito pabbatapādavanantaresu bahū petā viharanti, svāyamattho
analyzed: vadanti rahadassa pana āditas bahū petāḥ viharanti
translated: But many ghosts live in the foot of the mountain at the beginning of the lake, and this meaning

original: petavatthupāḷiyā lakkhaṇasaṃyuttena ca dīpetabbo. Yatāyanti yato rahadato ayaṃ. Sātodakoti
analyzed: peta vatthu pāḷiyā lakkhaṇa saṃyuttena ca dīpetabbaḥ yatāyanti yatas ayam
translated: should be illustrated by the Petavatthu and the Lakkhaṇasaṃyutta. “Yatāyaṃ” means “from this lake.” “Sātodaka”

original: madhurodako. Setodakoti parisuddhodako, anāvilodakoti attho. Tatoti tapodānadito.
analyzed: madhura udako seta udako ti parisuddha udako anāvila udako ti attho tatoti tapo dāna dito
translated: means sweet water. “Setodaka” means pure water, the meaning is unclouded water. “Tato” means “from the lake of heat.”

original: Samiddhoti avayavānaṃ sampuṇṇatāya saṃsiddhiyāva sammā iddho. Tenāha “abhirūpo”tiādi.
analyzed: samiddhaḥ iti avayavānam sampuṇṇa tāya sammā iddhaḥ tena āha abhirūpaḥ iti ādi
translated: “Samiddha” means “well-developed” by the fullness of the limbs. Therefore he says “handsome” and so on.

original: Padhāne sammasanadhamme niyutto, taṃ vā ettha atthīti padhāniko. Senāsanaṃ suṭṭhapitadvāravātapānaṃ,
analyzed: padhāne sammasana dhamme niyutto tam va ettha atthi iti padhānikaḥ senāsanam su ṭṭhapita dvāra vāta pānam
translated: He is devoted to the practice of meditation, or it is here, therefore it is a meditation subject. The dwelling is with the door and the windows well closed,

original: tesaṃ pidahanena utuṃ gāhāpetvā.
analyzed: pidahanena utum gāhāpetvā
translated: by closing them he takes the weather into account.

original: Pubbāpayamānoti nhānato pubbabhāge viya vodakabhāvaṃ āpajjamāno gamento. Avattaṃ
analyzed: pubbāpayamānaḥ ti nhānataḥ pubba bhāge viya vodaka bhāvam āpajjamānaḥ gamentaḥ avattam
translated: “Going forward” means going, reaching the state of being without water, as if it were the preliminary part of the bathing.

original: paṭikkhipitvā vattaṃ dassetuṃ “tattha…pe… na otaritabba”nti paṭhamaṃ vuttaṃ. Sabbadisāpalokanaṃ🔽yathā nhāyanaṭṭhānassa manussehi vivittabhāvajānanatthaṃ. Khāṇuādivavatthāpanaṃ cīvarādīnaṃ
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā vattam dassetum na otaritabbam ti paṭhamam vuttam sabba disa apalokanam  yathā nhāyana ṭṭhānassa manussehi vivitta bhāva jānana attham khāṇu ādi vavatthāpanam cīvara ādīnam
translated: and after that he laid down the duties, beginning with “He should not go down without looking in all directions.”🔽Looking in all directions is for the purpose of knowing whether or not there are people in the bathing place.🔽The laying down of the boundaries by means of the stumps, etc., is for the purpose of laying out the robe, etc. The meaning is that it should be near the water.

original: ṭhapanatthaṃ udakasamīpeti adhippāyo. Ukkāsanaṃ amanussānaṃ apagamanatthaṃ. Avakujjaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapana attham udaka samīpe iti adhippāyaḥ ukkāsanam amanussānam apagamana attham avakujja ṭṭhānam
translated: The clearing of the throat is for the purpose of making non-human beings go away.🔽The bending of the body is for the purpose of making the upper part of the body straight at that moment.

original: taṅkhaṇepi uparimakāyassa ujukaṃ avivaṭakaraṇatthaṃ. Cīvarapiṭṭheyeva ṭhapetabbaṃ
analyzed: tad khaṇe api uparima kāyassa ujukam a vivaṭa karaṇa ttham cīvara piṭṭhe iva iva ṭhapetabbam
translated: The robe should be laid out on the back of the bathing place,🔽or anywhere.

original: yattha vā tattha vā aṭṭhapetvā. Udakanteti udakasamīpe. Sinnaṭṭhānanti sedagatapadeso.
analyzed: yattha vā tattha vā aṭṭhapetvā udakantā iti udaka samīpe sinna ṭhānam ti seda gata padeso
translated: In the water means near the water. The place for rubbing is the place where the dirt is rubbed off.

original: Pasāretabbaṃ tassa sukkhāpanatthaṃ. Saṃharitvā ṭhapanaṃ puna sukhena gahetvā nivāsanatthaṃ.
analyzed: pasāretabbam tassa su khāpana attham saṃharitvā ṭhapanam puna sukhena gahetvā nivāsana attham
translated: It should be spread out for the purpose of drying it. The collecting and laying down is for the purpose of putting it on again after drying it comfortably.

original: Nābhippamāṇamattaṃ otaraṇaṃ tāvatā udakapaṭicchādilakkhaṇappattato. Vīciṃ anuṭṭhāpentenātiādi
analyzed: na abhippamāṇa mattam otaraṇam tāvatā udaka paṭicchādi lakkhaṇa ppattataḥ vīcim anuṭṭhāpentena atiādi
translated: Going down knee-deep is because it has the characteristic of being covered by water to that extent. Not making waves, etc., is for the purpose of not disturbing the beings in the water.

original: saṃyatakāritādassanaṃ. Nivāsanaṃ parikkhipitvāti antaravāsakaṃ kaṭippadesassa yathā🔽parito hoti, evaṃ khipitvā parivasitvā.
analyzed: saṃyata kāri tā dassanam nivāsanam parikkhipitvā ati antaravāsakam kaṭi ppadesassa yathā  paritas evam khipitvā parivasitvā
translated: as it is put on round about the region of the hips.

original: Sarīravaṇṇopi vippasīdi sammadeva bhāvanānussatimpi vindantassāti adhippāyo. Samanaṃ
analyzed: sarīra vaṇṇaḥ api sammad eva bhāvanā anussatim pi vindantassa ati adhippāyaḥ samanam
translated: The meaning is that his bodily appearance became clear as he found the recollection of development.🔽To restrain the mind: to restrain his own mind which had fallen into the power of defilements.

original: niggahetunti kilesavasaṃ gataṃ attano cittaṃ niggaṇhituṃ. Kāmūpanītāti kāmaṃ upagatacittā.
analyzed: niggahetum ti kilesa vasam gatam attanaḥ cittam niggaṇhitum kāma upanītā iti kāmam upagata cittā
translated: With thoughts of sensual desire: with thoughts that had gone over to sensual desire.

original: Atha vā kilesakāmena there upanītacittā.
analyzed: atha vā kilesa kāmena there upanīta cittā
translated: Or alternatively, with thoughts that had gone over to the elder because of sensual desire.

original: Aparibhuñjitvāti ananubhotvā. Anubhavitabbanti atthato āpannamevāti āha “pañcakāmaguṇe”ti.
analyzed: a paribhuñjitvā iti an anubhotvā anubhavitabbanti atthataḥ āpannam eva ati āha pañca kāmaguṇa iti
translated: Without enjoying: without experiencing. What is meant is that he had already obtained the five strands of sense pleasure.🔽You beg: you ask.

original: Bhikkhasīti yācasi. Tañca bhikkhācariyavasenāti āha “piṇḍāya carasī”ti. Kāmaparibhogagarugamanakālo🔽nāma visesato paṭhamayobbanāvatthāti āha “daharayobbanakālo”ti. Obhaggenāti majjhe
analyzed: bhikkhasi iti yācasi tat ca bhikkhā cariya vasena ati āha piṇḍāya carasi iti kāma paribhoga garu gamana kālaḥ  nāma visesataḥ paṭhama yobbana avatthā iti āha dahara yobbana kālaḥ iti obhaggena ati majjhe
translated: And that is in the way of begging alms: the meaning is that you go for alms.🔽The time of youth is the time of the first flush of youth in particular.🔽In the middle: in the middle of his body.

original: saṃbhaggakāyena. Jiṇṇakāle hi sattānaṃ kaṭiyaṃ kāyo obhaggo hoti.
analyzed: saṃbhagga kāyena jiṇṇa kāle hi sattānam kaṭiyam kāyo obhaggaḥ hoti
translated: For at the time of old age the body is bent down in the middle.

original: Voti nipātamattaṃ “ye hi vo ariyā”tiādīsu viya. Sattānanti sāmaññavacanaṃ, na manussānaṃ
analyzed: vo ti nipāta mattam ye hi vaḥ ariyā ati ādīsu viya sattānam ti sāmañña vacanam na manussānam
translated: Sattānanti is a collective term, not only for human beings.

original: eva. Dehanikkhepananti kaḷevaraṭṭhapitaṭṭhānaṃ. Natthi etesaṃ nimittanti animittā,
analyzed: eva deha nikkhepananti kaḷevara ṭhapita ṭṭhānam na atthi etesam nimittam ti animittā
translated: Dehanikkhepananti is the place where the corpse is laid.🔽They have no nimitta, thus they are animittā. The meaning is that they are devoid of the nimitta of the knowledge that “This one lives so long.”

original: “ettakaṃ ayaṃ jīvatī”tiādinā sañjānananimittarahitāti attho. Na nāyareti na ñāyanti.
analyzed: ettakam ayam jīvati iti ādinā sañjānana nimitta rahitā ati atthaḥ na na
translated: Na nāyareti is not known.

original: Ito paranti ettha paranti aññaṃ kālaṃ. Tena orakālassapi saṅgaho siddho hoti. Paramāyuno
analyzed: itas paranti ettha paranti aññam kālam tena ora kālassa api saṅgahaḥ siddho hoti para māyunaḥ
translated: Ito paranti here paranti means another time. Thus the inclusion of the time before death is also established.

original: orakāle eva cettha paranti adhippetaṃ tato paraṃ sattānaṃ jīvitassa abhāvato. Vavatthānābhāvatoti
analyzed: ora kāle eva ca ittha paranti adhippetam tatas param sattānam jīvitassa abhāvataḥ vavatthāna abhāvato ti
translated: If, however, the time after the maximum life span is intended here, then it is so because after that there is no life for beings.🔽Vavatthānābhāvatoti means because there is no determination by way of time.

original: kālavasena vavatthānābhāvato. Vavatthānanti cettha paricchedo veditabbo, na asaṅkarato🔽vavatthānaṃ, nicchayo vā. Abbudapesītiādīsu abbudakālo pesikālotiādinā kāla-saddo
analyzed: kāla vasena vavatthāna abhāvataḥ vavatthānanti ca ittha paricchedaḥ veditabbaḥ na asaṅkarato  vavatthānam nicchayaḥ vā abbuda pesī itiādīsu abbuda kālaḥ pesi kālo iti ādinā kāla saddo
translated: Here vavatthāna should be understood as delimitation, not as determination without confusion,🔽or as ascertainment. In the words abbudapesī, etc., the word kāla should be construed separately in each case, as in the expression abbudakālo pesikālo, etc.

original: paccekaṃ yojetabbo. Kāloti idha pubbaṇhādivelā adhippetā. Tenāha pubbaṇhepi hītiādi.
analyzed: paccekam yojetabbaḥ kālaḥ ti idha pubbaṇha ādi velā adhippetā tena āha pubbaṇhe pi hi itiādi
translated: Here kālo means the period of time such as the morning, etc. Therefore it is said: “Even in the morning, etc.”

original: Idheva dehena patitabbanti sambandho. Anekappakāratoti nagare jātānaṃ gāme, gāme
analyzed: idha iva dehena patitabbanti sambandhaḥ aneka ppakārato ti nagare jātānam gāme gāme
translated: The construction is: “One must fall with this body right here.”

original: jātānaṃ nagare, vane jātānaṃ janapade, janapade jātānaṃ vanetiādinā anekappakārato.
analyzed: jātānam nagare vane jātānam janapade janapade jātānam vana iti ādinā aneka ppakārato
translated: “In many ways”: those born in the town die in the village, those born in the village die in the town, those born in the forest die in the country, those born in the country die in the forest, and so on.

original: Ito cutenāti ito gatito cutena. Idha imissaṃ gatiyaṃ. Yante yuttagoṇo viyāti yathā
analyzed: itas cutena ati itas gatitas cutena idha imissam gatiyam yante yutta goṇaḥ viyāti yathā
translated: “Having died from here”: having died from this place. “Here”: in this realm. “Like a harnessed ox”: just as a harnessed ox does not go beyond the yoke,

original: yante yuttagoṇo yantaṃ nātivattati, evaṃ kālo gatipañcakanti evaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: yante yutta goṇaḥ yantam na ativattati evam kālaḥ gati pañcakam ti evam upamā saṃsandanam veditabbam
translated: so time does not go beyond the five realms. This is how the simile should be understood.

original: Ayaṃ kāloti ayaṃ maraṇakālo. Pacchime kāleti pacchime vaye. Tisso vayosīmāti. Paṭhamādikā
analyzed: ayam kālo ti ayam maraṇa kālo pacchime kāle ti pacchime vaye tissaḥ paṭhama ādikā
translated: “This time”: this time of death. “In the last stage of life”: in the last stage of life. “The three boundaries of life”: the three boundaries of life, beginning with the first,

original: tisso vayassa sīmā atikkantena. Purimānaṃ hi dvinnaṃ vayānaṃ sabbaso sīmā atikkamitvā
analyzed: tissaḥ vayassa sīmāḥ atikkantena purimānam hi dvinnam vayānam sabbaso sīmāḥ atikkamitvā
translated: having gone beyond. For having gone beyond the first two stages of life completely,🔽and having gone beyond the first boundary of the last stage, he is called “one who has gone beyond.”

original: pacchimassa ādisīmaṃ atikkanto tathā vutto. “Ayañhi samaṇadhammo…pe… na sakkā kātu”nti
analyzed: pacchimassa ādi sīmam atikkanto tathā vuttaḥ ayan hi samaṇa dhammope na sakkā kātunti
translated: “For this is the recluse’s state…it is not possible to do it.”

original: vatvā tamatthaṃ vitthārato dassetuṃ “tadā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gaṇhitunti pāḷito atthato
analyzed: vatvā tam attham vitthārataḥ dassetum tadā hi itiādi vuttam gaṇhitum ti pāḷitaḥ atthato
translated: Having said this, in order to show the meaning in detail, he said “Then,” etc. “To grasp”: from the text, and from the meaning,

original: ca hadaye ṭhapanavasena gaṇhituṃ. Paribhuñjitunti vuttadhammapariharaṇasukhaṃ anubhavituṃ.
analyzed: ca hadaye ṭhapana vasena gaṇhitum paribhuñjitum ti vutta dhamma pariharaṇa sukham anubhavitum
translated: and to take it by fixing it in the heart. To enjoy: to experience the pleasure of observing the Dhamma stated.

original: Ekassa kathanato paṭhamaṃ gāthaṃ suttaṃ vā ussāreti, tasmiṃ niṭṭhite itaro dhammakathiko
analyzed: ekassa kathanataḥ paṭhamam gātham suttam vā ussāreti tasmin niṭṭhite itaraḥ dhamma kathiko
translated: He recites the first stanza or sutta, and when he has finished, the other, the Dhamma speaker,🔽expounds the Dhamma by elaborating it. This is the “recited Dhamma talk.”

original: taṃyeva vitthārento dhammaṃ katheti, ayaṃ sarabhāṇadhammakathā. Suttageyyānusārena🔽yāva pariyosānā ussāraṇaṃ sarabhaññadhammakathā. “Mā maṃ kālo upaccagā”ti vadanto🔽“samaṇadhammassa karaṇassa ayaṃ me kālo”ti katheti, tato paro “pacchimavayo añño
analyzed: taṃyeva vitthārentaḥ dhammam kathā iti ayam sarabhāṇa dhamma kathā sutta geyyā anusārena  yāva pariyosānā ussāraṇam sarabhañña dhamma kathā mā mama kālaḥ upaccagāti vadantaḥ  samaṇa dhammassa karaṇassa ayam me kālaḥ iti kathā iti tatas paraḥ pacchima vayaḥ añño
translated: The recitation of the sutta, geyya, and so on, up to the end is the “recited Dhamma talk.”🔽Saying, “Let not the time pass,” he says, “This is the time for me to do the recluse’s duties.” The other says, “The time is past.”🔽“The time is another time, the last time.”

original: kālo”ti katheti. “Kālaṃ vohaṃ…pe… tasmā abhutvā bhikkhāmī”ti vadanto attanā kataṃ🔽paṭipattiñca sahetukaṃ sānisaṃsaṃ katheti.
analyzed: kālo ti kathā iti kālam tasmai a bhutvā bhikkhāmi iti vadantaḥ attanā katam  paṭipattim ca sa hetukam sa anisaṃsam kathā iti
translated: Saying, “I will not eat without having given you a share,” he explains his own practice together with its cause and its benefit.

original: Taṃ gāravakāraṇaṃ sandhāya. Etanti “atha kho sā devatā pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhahitvā”ti
analyzed: tam gārava kāraṇam sandhāya etat ti atha kho sā devatā pathaviyam patiṭṭhahitvā ati
translated: This is said with reference to the reason for the respect. “Then that deity, standing on the ground” .

original: etaṃ vuttaṃ. Daharo tvantiādimāha lobhābhibhūtatāya adhigatattā. Sabbasampattiyuttoti
analyzed: etam vuttam daharaḥ tvan ti ādim āha lobha abhibhūta tāya adhigata ttā sabba sampatti yuttaḥ ti
translated: He said this. “But you are young” , etc., because he was overcome by greed and had acquired the wealth. “Endowed with all perfections” ,

original: bhogasampadā parivārasampadāti sabbasampattīhi yutto. Alaṅkāraparihāranti alaṅkārakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: bhoga sampadā parivāra sampadā ati sabba sampattīhi yuttaḥ alaṅkāra parihāranti alaṅkāra karaṇam
translated: endowed with all perfections, such as the perfection of wealth and the perfection of retinue. “Adornment” , the act of adorning.

original: Anikkīḷitāvīti akīḷitapubbo. Kīḷanañcettha kāmānaṃ paribhogoti āha “abhuttāvī”ti.🔽Akatakāmakīḷoti akatakāmānubhavanappayogo. Sayaṃ attanā eva dissantīti sandiṭṭhā,
analyzed: a nikkīḷitāvī iti a kīḷita pubbaḥ kīḷanam ca ittha kāmānam paribhogo ti āha a bhuttāvī iti  akata kāma kīḷaḥ ti akata kāma anubhavana payogo sayam attanā eva dissanti iti sandiṭṭhā
translated: “Not yet enjoyed” , not yet used. Here “enjoyment” is the use of sensual pleasures. Therefore it is said: “not yet eaten.”🔽“Not yet amused” , not yet engaged in the enjoyment of sensual pleasures. “Visible here and now” ,

original: sandiṭṭhā eva sandiṭṭhikā, attapaccakkhato sandiṭṭhikā. Pakaṭṭho kālo patto etesanti kālikā, te kālike.
analyzed: sandiṭṭhāḥ eva sandiṭṭhikāḥ atta paccakkhato sandiṭṭhikā pakaṭṭhaḥ kālaḥ pattaḥ etesanti kālikā te kālike
translated: visible here and now are visible here and now. Visible here and now is visible here and now. The time has come for them. Therefore they are timely.

original: Cittānantaranti icchitacittānantaraṃ, icchiticchitārammaṇākāreti attho. Tenevāha
analyzed: citta anantaram ti icchita citta anantaram icchita icchita ārammaṇa ākārā iti tena iva āha
translated: “Immediately after the thought” , immediately after the desired thought. The meaning is: according to the desired object. Therefore it is said:

original: “cittānantaraṃ icchiticchitārammaṇānubhavanaṃ na sampajjatī”tiādi. Cittānantaraṃ
analyzed: citta anantaram icchiti chita ārammaṇa anubhavanam na sampajjati itiādi citta anantaram
translated: “The enjoyment of the desired object immediately after the thought does not take place.” Immediately after the thought

original: laddhabbatāyāti anantaritasamādhicittānantaraṃ laddhabbaphalatāya. Samohitesupīti
analyzed: laddhabba tāya ati anantarita samādhi citta anantaram laddhabba phala tāya
translated: “Having obtained the boon” , having obtained the fruit immediately after the uninterrupted path. “Even if they are collected” ,

original: sambhatesupi. Sampannakāmassāti samiddhakāmassa. Cittakārā rūpalābhena, potthakārā🔽paṭimākārakā, rūpakārā dantarūpakaṭṭharūpa-loharūpādikārakā. Ādisaddena nānārūpavesadhārīnaṃ
analyzed: sambhatesu pi sampanna kāmassa ati samiddha kāmassa cittakārāḥ rūpa lābhena potthakārāḥ  paṭimā kārakāḥ rūpa kārāḥ danta rūpa kaṭṭha rūpa loha rūpa ādi kārakāḥ ādi saddena
translated: and in the case of those who have assembled. Has his wish fulfilled: has his desire satisfied. Artisans: craftsmen. Sculptors:🔽carvers. Carpenters:

original: naṭādīnaṃ saṅgaho. Sesadvāresūti ettha gandhabbamālākārasūpakārādayo vattabbā.
analyzed: naṭa ādīnam saṅgahaḥ sesa dvāresu iti ettha gandhabba mālākāra sūpakāra ādayaḥ vattabbā
translated: builders. Actors: dancers, etc., who take various parts. In the other doors: here the making of garlands and perfumes, etc., should be mentioned.

original: Soti samiddhitthero. Samohitasampattināti saṅgāhabhogūpakaraṇasampattinā. Pattabbadukkhassāti
analyzed: saḥ ti samiddhi thero samohita sampattinā ati saṅgāha bhogu upakaraṇa sampattinā pattabba dukkhassa ati
translated: He: the Elder Samiddhi. With the attainment of wealth and enjoyments: with the attainment of the requisites for enjoyment. Of suffering that is to be undergone:

original: kāmānaṃ āpajjanarakkhaṇavasena laddhabbassa kāyikacetasikadukkhassa. Upāyāsassāti
analyzed: kāmānam āpajjana rakkhaṇa vasena laddhabbassa kāyika cetasika dukkhassa upāyāsassa ati
translated: of the bodily and mental suffering that is to be undergone for the sake of obtaining and preserving sensual pleasures. Of trouble:

original: daḷhaparissamassa viratassa. “Vissātassā”ti keci. “Paccavekkhaṇañāṇenā”ti keci paṭhanti.
analyzed: daḷha parissamassa viratassa vissātassa ati keci paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena ati keci paṭhanti
translated: of strong affliction. “Of confidence” is read in some places. “By knowledge of reflection” is read in some places.

original: Asukasmiṃ nāma kāle phalaṃ hotīti evaṃ udikkhitabbo nassa kāloti akālo. Etthāti etesu
analyzed: asukasmin nāma kāle phalam hoti iti evam udikkhitabbaḥ nassa kālaḥ ati akālaḥ ettha ati etesu
translated: The time that cannot be pointed to thus, “The fruit will be at such a time,” is the wrong time. In this: in these

original: navasu lokuttaradhammesu. Ehipassavidhinti “ehi passā”ti evaṃ pavattavidhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: navasu lokuttara dhammesu ehipassavidhinti ehi passa ati evam pavatta vidhi vacanam
translated: nine supramundane states. The method of “Come and see”: the statement of the method that occurs thus, “Come and see.”

original: Upanetabboti vā upaneyyo, so eva opaneyyiko. Viññūhīti vidūhi paṭividdhasaccehi.
analyzed: upanetabbaḥ iti vai upaneyyo saḥ eva opaneyyikaḥ viññūhi iti vidūhi paṭividdha saccehi
translated: Or else, what is to be brought is what is to be brought near, and that is what is meant by “conducive to bringing near” .🔽The wise : the discerning, those who have penetrated the Truths.

original: Te ekaṃsato ugghaṭitaññūādayo hontīti āha “ugghaṭitaññūādīhī”ti. “Paccatta”nti etassa
analyzed: te ekaṃsataḥ ugghaṭita ññū ādayaḥ honti iti āha ugghaṭita ññū ādīhi iti paccattanti etassa
translated: They are of the type of those who are quick in understanding, etc., thus it is said, “those who are quick in understanding, etc.”

original: patiattanīti bhummavasena attho gahetabboti āha “attani attanī”ti.
analyzed: pati attani iti bhumma vasena atthaḥ gahetabbo ti āha attani attani iti
translated: The individual : the meaning of this should be taken as “the individual’s own” in the sense of the locative case. Thus it is said, “the individual’s own” .

original: Sabbapadehi sambandhoti “kathaṃ ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo, kathaṃ akāliko”tiādinā sabbehi paccekaṃ sambandho veditabbo.
analyzed: sabba padehi sambandhaḥ iti katham ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyaḥ katham akālikā uti ādinā sabbehi paccekam sambandhaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The connection with all the terms : the connection with all the terms should be understood individually in each case, thus: “How is the danger here greater? How is it not untimely?”

original: Navoti taruṇo na ciravasso. Ye bhikkhunovādakalakkhaṇappattā, te sandhāya “vīsativassato🔽paṭṭhāya thero”ti vuttaṃ. Idha sāsanaṃ nāma sikkhattayasaṅgahaṃ piṭakattayanti āha
analyzed: navaḥ ti taruṇaḥ na cira vassaḥ ye bhikkhunā uvādaka lakkhaṇa ppattā te sandhāya vīsati vassataḥ  paṭṭhāya thero ti vuttam idha sāsanam nāma sikkhattaya saṅgaham piṭakattayanti āha
translated: Nine years : a young man, not one who has been ordained long. Those who have reached the age for being a preceptor for bhikkhunis are referred to when it is said, “One who is ten years old is a senior” .🔽Herein, the Dispensation is the three Piṭakas, which include the three trainings. Thus it is said, “By the Dhamma, by the Discipline” , etc.

original: “dhammena hī”tiādi. Tattha dhammena vinayo ettha vinā daṇḍasatthehīti dhammavinayo.
analyzed: dhammena hi itiādi tattha dhammena vinayaḥ ettha vinā daṇḍa satthehi iti dhamma vinayo
translated: Herein, the Dhamma is the Discipline, since it is without punishment or violence.🔽The Dhamma is the Discipline, since it is not for the sake of material gain.

original: Dhammāya vinayo ettha na āmisatthanti dhammavinayo. Dhammato vinayo na adhammatoti
analyzed: dhammāya vinayaḥ ettha na āmisa atthanti dhamma vinayaḥ dhammataḥ vinayaḥ na adhammato ti
translated: The Dhamma is the Discipline, since it is not for the sake of a teacher.

original: dhammavinayo. Dhammo vā bhagavā dhammassāmī dhammakāyattā, tassa dhammasaññitassa
analyzed: dhamma vinayaḥ dhammaḥ vā bhagavā dhamma ssāmī dhamma kāyattā tassa dhamma saññitassa
translated: the Dhamma and Discipline. The Dhamma is the Blessed One, the Lord of the Dhamma, the body of the Dhamma, the Dhamma-named Master.

original: satthu vinayo, na takkikānanti dhammavinayo. Dhamme vinayo na adhamme vinayo. Dhammo
analyzed: satthu vinayaḥ na takkikānanti dhamma vinayaḥ dhamme vinayaḥ na adhamme vinayaḥ dhammo
translated: His Discipline is the Discipline of the Dhamma, not the Discipline of the logicians. The Discipline is in the Dhamma, not in the non-Dhamma.

original: ca so yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne satte apāyesu apatamāne dhāretīti, sabbe saṃkilesato
analyzed: ca saḥ yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne satte apāyesu a patamāne dhāreti iti sabbe saṃkilesato
translated: The Dhamma is the Discipline for beings who practice in accordance with the advice given. It holds them back from falling into the states of loss.

original: vinetīti vinayo cāti dhammavinayo. Tenāha “ubhayampetaṃ sāsanasseva nāma”nti.🔽Dhammavinayoti dhammena yutto vinayoti dhammavinayo ājaññaratho viya. Dhammo ca vinayo🔽cāti vā dhammavinayo, taṃ dhammavinayaṃ. Dhammavinayānañhi satthubhāvavacanato dhammavinayattasaṃsiddhi
analyzed: vineti iti vinayo ca ati dhamma vinayo tena āha ubhayam petam sāsanassa iva nāman ti  dhamma vinayo ti dhammena yuttaḥ vinayo ti dhamma vinayo ājañña ratho viya dhammo ca vinayo  ca ati vā dhamma vinayo tam dhamma vinayam satthu bhāva vacanataḥ dhamma vinaya tta saṃsiddhi
translated: It disciplines all from defilement, and it is the Discipline. Thus it is the Dhamma and Discipline. Therefore it was said: ‘Both are names for the Dispensation’ .🔽The Dhamma and Discipline: the Dhamma and the Discipline are the Dhamma and Discipline, like a thoroughbred and a chariot. Or the Dhamma and the Discipline are the Dhamma and Discipline. That Dhamma and Discipline. For the Dhamma and Discipline are established as the Dhamma and Discipline by the statement that they are the Master’s own property.

original: dhammavinayānaṃ aññamaññaṃ visesanato. Abhidhammepi vinayavacananti dhammavinayadvayasiddhi,
analyzed: dhamma vinayānam aññam aññam visesanataḥ abhidhamme pi vinaya vacanan ti dhamma vinaya dvaya siddhi
translated: The Dhamma and Discipline are established as the Dhamma and Discipline by the distinction between the Dhamma and the Discipline.🔽The Discipline is also called the Dhamma in the Abhidhamma. Thus the Dhamma and Discipline are established as a pair.

original: desitapaññattavacanato dhammavinayasiddhi. Dhammo catudhā desito sandassana-samādāpana-samuttejana-sampahaṃsanavasena,🔽vinayo catudhā paññatto sīlācārato parājitavasena. Dhammacariyā sakavisayo, vinayapaññatti🔽buddhavisayo. Pariyāyena desito dhammo, nippariyāyena paññatto vinayo. Dhammadesanā
analyzed: desita paññatta vacanataḥ dhamma vinaya siddhi dhammo catudhā desito sandassana samādāpana samuttejana sampahaṃsana vasena  vinayo catudhā paññatto sīla ācārato parājita vasena dhamma cariyā saka visayaḥ vinaya paññatti  buddha visayaḥ pariyāyena desitaḥ dhammaḥ nippariyāyena paññattaḥ vinayaḥ dhamma desanā
translated: The success of the Dhamma and Discipline is due to the fact that the Dhamma has been taught and the Discipline has been laid down. The Dhamma has been taught in four ways: by pointing out, by exhortation, by stimulation, and by consolation.

original: adhippāyatthappadhānā, vinayapaññatti vacanatthappadhānā. Paramatthasaccappadhāno
analyzed: adhippāya ttha ppadhānā vinaya paññatti vacana ttha ppadhānā paramattha sacca ppadhāno
translated: The Discipline has been laid down in four ways: by laying down a rule, by laying down a supplementary rule, by laying down a course of action, and by laying down a verdict of innocence. The Dhamma is the province of the wise; the laying down of the Discipline is the province of the Buddha. The Dhamma is taught in a figurative sense; the Discipline is laid down in a literal sense. The teaching of the Dhamma is based on the meaning of the intention; the laying down of the Discipline is based on the meaning of the words.

original: dhammo, sammutisaccappadhāno vinayo. Āsayasuddhipadhāno dhammo, payogasuddhipadhāno vinayo.🔽Kiriyadvayasiddhiyā dhammavinayasiddhi. Dhammena hi anusāsanasiddhi, vinayena ovādasiddhi.
analyzed: dhammo sammuti sacca ppadhānaḥ vinayo āsaya suddhi padhāno dhammo payoga suddhi padhāno vinayo  kiriya dvaya siddhiyā dhamma vinaya siddhi dhammena hi anusāsana siddhi vinayena ovāda siddhi
translated: The Dhamma is based on the truth of the ultimate sense; the Discipline is based on the truth of the conventional sense. The Dhamma is based on the purification of the mind; the Discipline is based on the purification of conduct.🔽The success of the Dhamma and Discipline is due to the success of the twofold performance. For the success of instruction is due to the Dhamma, and the success of advice is due to the Discipline.

original: Dhammena dhammakathāsiddhi, vinayena ariyatuṇhībhāvasiddhi. Sāvajjadvayaparivajjanato
analyzed: dhammena dhamma kathā siddhi vinayena ariya tuṇhībhāva siddhi
translated: The success of a talk on the Dhamma is due to the Dhamma, and the success of noble silence is due to the Discipline. The success of the Dhamma and Discipline is due to the avoidance of the two kinds of blame.

original: dhammavinayasiddhi. Dhammena hi visesato pakatisāvajjapariccāgasiddhi, vinayena paññattisāvajjapariccāgasiddhi.
analyzed: dhamma vinaya siddhi dhammena hi visesataḥ pakati sāvajja pariccāga siddhi vinayena paññatti sāvajja pariccāga siddhi
translated: and the success of the Dhamma and Discipline. For the success of the relinquishment of what is blameworthy by nature is by means of the Dhamma, and the success of the relinquishment of what is blameworthy by prohibition is by means of the Discipline.

original: Gahaṭṭhapabbajitānaṃ sādhāraṇāsādhāraṇaguṇadvayasiddhi. Bahussutasutapasannadvayato
analyzed: gaha ṭṭha pabbajitānam sādhāraṇa asādhāraṇa guṇa dvaya siddhi bahussuta suta pasanna dvayataḥ
translated: The success of the two kinds of special qualities common and not common to both lay followers and those gone forth is by means of the Dhamma and Discipline.🔽The success of the Dhamma and Discipline is by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,

original: pariyatti-pariyāpuṇana-dhammavihāra-vibhāgato dhammadharavinayadharavibhāgato ca
analyzed: pariyatti pariyāpuṇana dhamma vihāra vibhāgataḥ dhammadhara vinayadhara vibhāgataḥ ca
translated: by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,

original: dhammavinayadvayasiddhi, saraṇadvayasiddhiyā dhammavinayadvayasiddhi. Idha sattānaṃ
analyzed: saraṇa dvaya siddhiyā dhamma vinaya dvaya siddhi idha sattānam
translated: by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,

original: duvidhaṃ saraṇaṃ dhammo attā ca. Tattha dhammo suciṇṇo saraṇaṃ. “Dhammo have rakkhati🔽dhammacāri”nti hi vuttaṃ. Sudanto attāpi saraṇaṃ “attā hi attano nātho”ti vacanato.
analyzed: duvidham saraṇam dhammo attā ca tattha dhammo su ciṇṇaḥ saraṇam dhammo have rakkhati  dhamma cārin ti hi vuttam sudantaḥ attā api saraṇam attā hi attanaḥ nātho ti vacanato
translated: by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,🔽by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the convinced,

original: Tena vuttaṃ “saraṇadvayasiddhiyā dhammavinayasiddhī”ti. Tattha yatassa dhammasiddhi,
analyzed: tena vuttam saraṇa dvaya siddhiyā dhamma vinaya siddhi iti tattha yatassa dhamma siddhi
translated: by means of the two kinds of learning, that of the learned and that of the

original: yato ca vinayasiddhi, tadubhayaṃ dassento āha – “dhammena hettha dve piṭakāni vuttāni,
analyzed: yatas ca vinaya siddhi tat ubhayam dassentaḥ āha dhammena ha ittha dve piṭakāni vuttāni
translated: and when he had done so, he said, “Herein, the two Piṭakas are stated by the True Idea,🔽and the Vinaya Piṭaka by the Discipline.”

original: vinayena vinayapiṭaka”nti. Adhunā āgato idāneva na cirasseva upagato.
analyzed: vinayena vinaya piṭakanti adhunā āgataḥ idānā iva na cirassa iva upagataḥ
translated: “Now come” : he has come now, not long after.

original: Mahante ṭhāne ṭhapetvāti mahesakkhatādassanatthaṃ attano parivārena mahantaṭṭhāne
analyzed: mahante ṭhāne ṭhapetvā ti mahesakkha tā dassana tham attanaḥ parivārena mahanta ṭṭhāne
translated: “In a great place” : he announces that he was placed in a great place by his retinue in order to show his great influence.

original: ṭhapitabhāvaṃ pavedetvā. Mahatiyāti upasaṅkamanavandanādivacanāpajjanavasena samāciṇṇāya.
analyzed: ṭhapita bhāvam upasaṅkamana vandana ādi vacana āpajjana vasena samāciṇṇāya
