analyzed: uppannā apara apara uppattikaḥ ti punappunam uppajjamānakaḥ a laddha patthanā a paṭiladdha vatthumhi
translated: Arisen again and again: arisen again and again. Not having obtained its desired object: not having obtained its sought object.

original: āsatti lobho. Uppāṭetvāti sasantānato uddharitvā.
analyzed: āsatti lobhaḥ uppāṭetvā ati sa santānataḥ uddharitvā
translated: Greed is attachment to that. Taken out: removed from the continuity.

original: Catucakkasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catucakka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Cātuddisa-sutta is finished.

original: 10. Eṇijaṅghasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: eṇijaṅgha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Eṇijaṅgha-sutta

original: 30. Eṇimigassa viyāti eṇimigassa jaṅghā viya. Avayavīsambandhe hi idaṃ sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: eṇimigassa eṇimigassa jaṅghā avayavī sambandhe hi idam sāmi vacanam
translated: Like the leg of an elaphant: like the leg of an elaphant. For this is a word of common usage in the sense of a part related to a whole.

original: Piṇḍimaṃsassa parito samasaṇṭhitattā suvaṭṭītajaṅgho. Kisanti thūlabhāvapaṭikkhepaparājotanā,
analyzed: piṇḍi maṃsassa paritas sama saṇṭhita ttā su vaṭṭīta jaṅghaḥ kisanti thūla bhāva paṭikkhepa parājotanā
translated: Well-rounded legs: his legs are well-rounded because the flesh is evenly distributed all around. Thin: the prefix pari is for the purpose of exclusion,

original: na suṭṭhu kisabhāvadīpanaparāti āha “athūlaṃ samasarīra”nti. Ātapena milātanti tapasā
analyzed: na suṭṭhu kisa bhāva dīpana parā ti āha athūlam ātapena tapasā
translated: not for the purpose of indicating thinness well. Therefore he said, “with a body that is not stout.” Milled by the heat: by the heat of his austerities.

original: milātakāyaṃ indriyasantāpanabhāvato. Tenevāha – “tapo milāta”ntiādi, tathā cāha pāḷiyaṃ🔽“appāhāraṃ alolupa”nti. Yathā “vīrassa bhāvo vīriya”nti vīrabhāvena vīriyaṃ lakkhīyati,
analyzed: milātakāyam tena iva āha tapaḥ milā tanti ādi tathā ca āha pāḷiyam  appa āhāram a lolupanti yathā vīrassa bhāvaḥ vīriyanti vīra bhāvena vīriyam lakkhīyati
translated: and the state of being emaciated is the state of tormenting the faculties. Hence he said, “The ascetic is emaciated” , and so on. And in the text he says: “He is not greedy for food” .🔽Just as “the state of being a hero” is called “heroism” , so the state of being a hero is indicated by heroism;

original: evaṃ vīriyasambhavena vīrabhāvoti āha “vīranti vīriyavanta”nti. “Cattāro pañca ālope,
analyzed: evam vīriya sambhavena vīra bhāvo ti āha cattāro pañca ālope
translated: and just as heroism is the cause of the state of being a hero, so the state of being a hero is the cause of heroism. That is why he said: “The hero is one who is heroic” .

original: abhutvā udakaṃ pive”ti dhammasenāpativuttaniyāmena parimitabhojitāya appāhāratā bhojane
analyzed: a bhutvā udakam piva iti dhamma senāpati vutta niyāmena parimita bhojitāya appa āhāra tā bhojane
translated: “Having eaten four or five mouthfuls” , he drinks no water. In this way, by the method stated by the General of the Dhamma, he is moderate in eating.🔽The state of being moderate in eating is the state of knowing the right amount in eating.🔽Having said “moderate in eating,” he again shows the state of being moderate in eating by the method of eating at stated intervals.

original: mattaññutā. “Mitāhāra”nti vatvā puna paricchinnakālabhojitāyapi appāhārataṃ dassento🔽“vikāla…pe… parittāhāra”nti āha. Catūsu paccayesu loluppavirahitaṃ bodhimūle eva
analyzed: mattaññu tā mita āhāranti vatvā puna appa āhāra tam dassento  vikālape paritta āhāranti āha catūsu paccayesu loluppa virahitam bodhi mūle eva
translated: “At no wrong time” , etc., he eats.🔽He is not greedy for the four requisite conditions.🔽At the foot of the Bodhi Tree he abandoned all greed.🔽“In the four requisite conditions” , he is not greedy.

original: sabbaso loluppassa pahīnattā. “Catūsu paccayesū”ti hi imināva sabbattha loluppavigamo
analyzed: sabbaso loluppassa pahīna ttā catūsu paccayesu iti hi iminā ava sabbattha loluppa vigamo
translated: This is shown by the method stated above.

original: dīpitovāti. Rasataṇhāpaṭikkhepo vā esa “appāhāra”nti vatvā “alolupa”nti vuttattā.
analyzed: dīpitaḥ uvā ti rasa taṇhā paṭikkhepaḥ vā esa appa āhāram ti vatvā a lolupam ti vutta ttā
translated: Or this is a prohibition of craving for taste. Having said “moderate in eating,” he again said “not greedy” .

original: “Sīhaṃ vā”ti ettha ekacarasaddo viya iva-saddo atthato “nāga”nti etthāpi ānetvā,
analyzed: sīham vā ti ettha ekacara saddaḥ viya iva saddo atthataḥ na āganti ettha api ānetvā
translated: “Like a lion” : the word “like” should be brought in here in the same way as in the expression “like a solitary beast,”🔽and the expression “like a solitary beast” should be construed with the expression “like a solitary elephant.”

original: sambandhitabboti āha – “ekacaraṃ sīhaṃ viya, ekacaraṃ nāgaṃ viyā”ti. Ekacarā appamattā ekīkatāya.
analyzed: sambandhitabbaḥ iti āha ekacaram sīham viya ekacaram nāgam viya ati ekacarāḥ appamattāḥ ekīkatāya
translated: “Solitary” means “unaccompanied” and “diligent.”

original: Pañcakāmaguṇavasena rūpaṃ gahitaṃ tesaṃ rūpasabhāvattā. Manena nāmaṃ gahitaṃ manassa
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa vasena rūpam gahitam tesam rūpa sabhāvattā manena nāmam gahitam manassa
translated: Form is included by way of the five strands of sense pleasure, because they have the nature of form. Mind is included by way of the mental object,

original: nāmasabhāvattā. Avinibhuttadhammeti avinābhāvadhamme gahetvā. Ādi-saddena āyatanadhātuādayo
analyzed: nāma sabhāva ttā avinibhutta dhamma iti avinābhāva dhamme gahetvā ādi saddena āyatana dhātu ādayaḥ
translated: because it has the nature of name. “A phenomenon that is inseparable from it” : a phenomenon that is not separate from it. By the word “etc.,” the bases, elements, etc., are included.

original: gahitā. Kāmaguṇaggahaṇena hettha rūpabhāvasāmaññena pañca vatthūni gahitāneva honti,
analyzed: gahitā kāma guṇa ggahaṇena ha ittha rūpa bhāva sāmaññena pañca vatthūni honti
translated: By the inclusion of the strands of sense pleasure, the five bases are included here by way of their commonality of having the nature of form.

original: manogahaṇena dhammāyatanaṃ, evaṃ dvādasāyatanāni gahitāni honti. Iminā nayena dhātuādīnampi
analyzed: manaḥ gahaṇena dhammāyatanam evam dvādasa āyatanāni gahitāni honti iminā nayena dhātu ādīnam pi
translated: By the inclusion of mind, the mental-data base is included. Thus the twelve bases are included. In this way the inclusion of the elements, etc.,

original: gahitatā yojetabbā. Tenāha “pañcakkhandhādivasenapettha bhummaṃ yojetabba”nti. Etthāti
analyzed: gahita tā yojetabbā tena āha pañca kkhandha ādi vasena pa ittha bhummam yojetabbanti ettha ati
translated: should be construed. Therefore it is said: “Here the text should be construed by way of the five aggregates, etc.”

original: pāḷiyaṃ. Kāmavatthu bhummaṃ.
analyzed: pāḷiyam kāma vatthu bhummaṃ
translated: “Here” means in the text. The bases of sensual pleasure are the text.

original: Eṇijaṅghasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: eṇijaṅgha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Eṇijaṅgha Sutta is finished.

original: Sattivaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Satullapakāyikavaggo
analyzed: satti vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  sa tulla pakāyika vaggo
translated: The commentary on the “hundred-factored” chapter is finished.🔽. The chapter on the hundred-factored deities

original: 1. Sabbhisuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . The hundred-factored deities

original: 31. Sataṃ sādhūnaṃ saraṇagamanasīlādibhedassa dhammassa ullapanato, attano vā pubbenivāsānussatiyā
analyzed: satam sādhūnam saraṇa gamana sīla ādi bhedassa dhammassa ullapanataḥ attanaḥ vā pubbenivāsa anussatiyā
translated: . The hundred-factored deities are so called either because they proclaim the Dhamma consisting of the refuges, virtue, etc., a hundred times or because they proclaim the recollection of past lives, which is a hundred-factored Dhamma, by proclaiming it.

original: tassa dhammassa ullapanato kathanato satullapā, devatā, tāsaṃ kāyo samūho, tattha🔽bhavāti satullapakāyikā. Tenāha “sataṃ dhamma”ntiādi. Samādānavasena ullapetvā, na
analyzed: tassa dhammassa ullapanataḥ kathanataḥ sa tullapā devatā tāsam kāyaḥ samūhaḥ tattha  tena āha satam dhammanti ādi samādāna vasena ullapetvā na
translated: They are deities, and their body is a collection of such deities.🔽They are “hundred-factored deities” because they are “in the hundred-factored deities.”

original: vaṇṇanākathanamattena tatrāti tasmiṃ tāsaṃ devatānaṃ satullapakāyikabhāve. Idaṃ vatthūti
analyzed: vaṇṇanā kathana mattena tatra ati tasmin tāsam devatānam sa tulla pakāyika bhāve idam vatthu iti
translated: They proclaim the Dhamma by taking it up in the sense of undertaking it, not merely by proclaiming it in words.🔽In this matter: in this reason.🔽The sea-traders: those who trade by sea.

original: idaṃ kāraṇaṃ. Samuddavāṇijāti saṃyattikā. Khittasaravegenāti jiyāmuttasarasadisavegena,🔽sīghaoghenāti attho. Uppatatīti uppāto. Uppāte bhavaṃ byasanaṃ uppātikaṃ. Patiṭṭhāti
analyzed: idam kāraṇam samudda vāṇijā ati saṃyattikā khitta sara vegena ati jiyā mutta sara sadisa vegena  sīgha oghena ati attho uppatati iti uppātaḥ uppāte bhavam byasanam uppātikam patiṭṭhāti
translated: With the speed of a shot arrow: with the speed of an arrow shot from a bow;🔽the meaning is, with the speed of a swift wind.🔽A disaster is a calamity .🔽A refuge is a protection .

original: hitapatiṭṭhā. Paraloke hitasukhāvahaṃ abhayakāraṇaṃ. Jaṅghasatanti manussasataṃ.
analyzed: hita patiṭṭhā para loke hita sukha āvaham abhaya kāraṇam manussa satam
translated: A hundred men.

original: Jaṅghāsīsena hi manusse vadati sahacāribhāvato. Aggahesi pañcasīlāni. Āsannānāsannesu
analyzed: jaṅghā sīsena hi manusse vadati sahacāri bhāvataḥ aggahesi pañca sīlāni āsanna anāsannesu
translated: He spoke to the people by the name of Jaṅghasīs, because they were his companions. He made them take up the five precepts.

original: āsannasseva paṭhamaṃ vipaccanato “āsannakāle gahitasīlaṃ nissāyā”ti vuttaṃ. Ghaṭāvasenāti samūhavasena.
analyzed: āsannassa iva paṭhamam āsanna kāle gahita sīlam nissāya iti vuttam ghaṭa avasena āti samūha vasena
translated: As regards those who were near and those who were far away, he first ripened those who were near, and then those who were far away. Therefore it is said: “The virtue that he made them take up at the time when they were near.”🔽By the name of Ghaṭa means by the name of a group.

original: Sabbhīti sādhūhi. Te hi saparahitasādhanato pāsaṃsatāya santaguṇatāya ca santoti
analyzed: te hi te hi
translated: The good means the good people. They are called good because they are praiseworthy and have the qualities of the good, since they are engaged in the welfare of others.

original: vuccati. Te pana yasmā paṇḍitalakkhaṇehi samannāgatā honti, tasmā “paṇḍitehī”ti āha.
analyzed: vuccati te pana yasmā paṇḍita lakkhaṇehi samannāgatāḥ honti tasmā paṇḍitehi iti āha
translated: But since they are endowed with the characteristics of the wise, therefore it is said: “by the wise.”

original: Samāsethāti saṃvasethāti ayamettha adhippāyoti āha “sabbairiyāpathe”tiādi. Mittasanthavanti
analyzed: samāsetha ati saṃvasetha ati ayam ettha adhippāyaḥ ti āha sabba airiyāpatha itiādi mitta santhavanti
translated: To live together means to live in association. The intended meaning here is this: “in all postures.”

original: mettisandhānaṃ. Sattānaṃ hitesitālakkhaṇā hi metti, sā ca ñāṇasahitā ñāṇapubbaṅgamāvāti
analyzed: metti sandhānam sattānam hita īsita ālakkhaṇā hi metti sā ca ñāṇa sahitā ñāṇa pubbaṅgamā āvāti
translated: Friendship means the formation of friendship. For friendship is characterized by the desire for the welfare of beings. And it is unadulterated when it is accompanied by knowledge and preceded by knowledge.

original: mittasanthavo asaṃkiliṭṭho, itaro saṃkiliṭṭhoti āha “na kenaci saddhiṃ kātabbo”ti.
analyzed: mitta santhavaḥ a saṃkiliṭṭhaḥ itaro saṃkiliṭṭhaḥ iti āha na kenacid saddhim kātabbo ti
translated: The other is adulterated. Therefore it is said: “should not be formed with anyone.”

original: Saddhammanti diṭṭhadhammikādihitāvahaṃ sundaradhammaṃ. Seyyoti hitavaḍḍhanatādi vuttanti āha “vaḍḍhī”ti.
analyzed: saddhammam ti diṭṭhadhammika ādi hita āvaham sundara dhammam seyyo ti hita vaḍḍhana tā ādi vuttanti āha vaḍḍhi iti
translated: ‘The True Idea’: the lovely True Idea that brings welfare here and now, and so on. ‘And so on’: the increase of welfare, and so on, is what is meant.🔽‘A hundred good men, wise men’: this is the meaning here.

original: Sataṃ sādhūnaṃ, paṇḍitānanti ayamettha attho. Tappaṭiyogavisayattā añña-saddassa🔽vuttaṃ “aññato andhabālato”ti. Sokanimittaṃ sokakāraṇaṃ uttarapadalopena idha sokasaddena
analyzed: satam sādhūnam paṇḍitānam ti ayam ettha atthaḥ tad paṭiyoga visaya ttā añña saddassa  vuttam aññatas andha bāla to ti soka nimittam soka kāraṇam uttara pada lopena idha soka saddena
translated: Because of the connection with the word ‘other’,🔽‘from other blind fools’ is said.🔽The cause of sorrow, the reason for sorrow, is here taken by the word ‘sorrow’ with the elision of the last syllable,

original: gahitanti āha “sokavatthūna”ntiādi. Sokavatthūni nāma corādayo acchindanādivasena
analyzed: āha soka vatthūnaṃ tiādi soka vatthūni nāma cora ādayaḥ acchindana ādi vasena
translated: so it is said ‘the grounds for sorrow’ and so on. The grounds for sorrow are thieves, etc.,

original: paresaṃ sokakaraṇato. Sokānugatā sokappattā.
analyzed: paresam soka karaṇataḥ soka anugatā soka ppattā
translated: because they cause sorrow for others by robbing them, and so on.🔽The elder: the elder Saṅkicca.

original: Therassāti saṃkiccattherassa. Attano bhaginiyā jeṭṭhattā “tumhe”ti āha. Ayaṃ “idha
analyzed: therassa ati saṃkicca therassa attanaḥ bhaginiyā jeṭṭha ttā tumhā iti āha ayam idha
translated: Because his sister was the elder, he said ‘you’.

original: corā paṭipajjiṃsū”ti amhe tiṇāyapi na maññatīti cintetvā ekacce “mārema na”nti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: corā paṭipajjiṃsu iti amhe na maññati iti cintetvā ekacce mārema nanti āhaṃsu
translated: Some said ‘We will not release them’ after thinking ‘This one does not care about us even as much as a blade of grass, saying “Here thieves have been active” ’.🔽Some said ‘We will release them’ out of compassion.

original: Karuṇāya ekacce “vissajjemā”ti āhaṃsu. Mantetvāti bhāsetvā.
analyzed: karuṇāya ekacce vissajjema ati āhaṃsu mantetvā ati bhāsetvā
translated: ‘After discussing the matter’: after speaking about it.

original: Ahu ahosi, bhūtapubbanti attho. Araññasmiṃ brahāvaneti tādise brahāvane, mahāraññe
analyzed: ahu ahosi bhūta pubbanti atthaḥ araññasmim brahāvane iti tādise brahāvane mahāraññe
translated: “There was” means “there was formerly.” In a forest-wilderness means in a forest-wilderness of that kind, in a great forest-wilderness.

original: nivāsīti attho cetoti byādho. Kūṭānīti vākurādayo. Oḍḍetvāti sajjetvā. Sasakanti
analyzed: nivāsī iti kūṭāni iti vākura ādayaḥ oḍḍetvā ati sajjetvā sasakanti
translated: Dwelling means living. Ceto means a disease. Kūṭānī means vākurā and so on. Having seized means having prepared. Sasaka means

original: pelakaṃ ubbiggāti bhītatasitā. Ekarattinti ekaratteneva. Dhanajānīti paribbayavasena
analyzed: pelakam ubbiggā ati bhīta tasitā eka rattin ti eka rattena iva dhana jāni iti paribbaya vasena
translated: pelaka. Terrified means frightened and trembling. In one night means in one night. Dhanajānī means because of the loss of the extra

original: addhikehi laddhabbadhanato hāni, “samaṇampi nāma hanti, kiṃ amhesu lajjissatī”ti
analyzed: addhikehi laddhabba dhanataḥ hāni samaṇam pi nāma hanti kim amhesu lajjissati iti
translated: wealth obtained by trade, “He will kill even an ascetic, what will he be ashamed of in us?”

original: addhikānaṃ anāgamanato ekadivasaṃ laddhabbaparibbayampi na labhissantīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: addhikānam an āgamanataḥ eka divasam laddhabba paribbayam pi na labhissanti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that they will not get even the trade-profit obtained in one day because the extra people will not come.

original: Ñātayopi mātāpitubhātubhaginiādike ñātake. Te kira adhimuttassa bhaginiyā santikaṃ🔽upagacchantā antarāmagge tena samāgatā, adhimutto saccavācaṃ anurakkhanto corabhayaṃ
analyzed: ñātayaḥ api mātā pitu bhātu bhagini ādike ñātake te kira adhimuttassa bhaginiyā santikam  upagacchantā antara āmagge tena samāgatā adhimuttaḥ sacca vācam anurakkhanto cora bhayam
translated: Even his relatives, such as mother, father, brother, sister, and so on. It seems that when they were approaching🔽the sister of Adhimukta, they met him on the way. Adhimukta, protecting his truthful speech, did not announce the danger of thieves

original: tesaṃ nārocesi. Tena vuttaṃ “tesampī”tiādi. Taṃ nissāya pabbajitattā “adhimuttasāmaṇerassa
analyzed: tesam na arocesi tena vuttam tesam pi itiādi tam nissāya pabbajita ttā adhimutta sāmaṇerassa
translated: to them. Therefore it is said “to them” and so on. Because of his going forth based on that, “to the novice Adhimukta

original: santike”ti vuttaṃ, na upasampadācariyo hutvā. Tenāha “attano antevāsike katvā”ti.
analyzed: santike iti vuttam na upasampada ācariyaḥ hutvā tena āha attanaḥ antevāsike katvā iti
translated: “in the vicinity” is said, not as a preceptor who has given the higher ordination. Therefore he says “having made his own pupils.”

original: Saccānurakkhaṇena anuttaraguṇādhigamena ca ñātimajjhe virocati.🔽Sātatanti satataṃ. Sa-saddassa hi idha sābhāvo yathā “sārāgo”tiādīsu. Sātabhāvo vā
analyzed: sacca anurakkhaṇena anuttara guṇa adhigamena ca ñāti majjhe virocati  sātatanti satatam yathā
translated: He shines in the midst of his relatives by the protection of the truth and by the attainment of the unsurpassed qualities.🔽Constantly means always. For the prefix sa- has the meaning of “together” here, as in “with passion” (sārāga) and so on. Or it has the meaning of “continuously.”

original: sātatanti āha “sukhaṃ vā”ti. Kāraṇenāti tena tena kāraṇena. Sabbāsaṃ tāsaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: āha sukham vā ati kāraṇena ati tena tena kāraṇena sabbāsam tāsam vacanam
translated: Constantly means “pleasant,” he says. By reason means by that and that reason. The speech of all these is

original: subhāsitaṃ, bhagavato pana ukkaṃsagataṃ subhāsitameva. Svāyamattho taṃtaṃgāthāpadeneva
analyzed: su bhāsitam bhagavataḥ pana ukkaṃsa gatam su bhāsitam eva taṃ taṃ gāthā padena iva
translated: well-spoken, but the Blessed One’s is the best of well-spoken words. This meaning is understood by each verse-line.

original: viññāyatīti taṃ nīharitvā dassetuṃ “na kevala”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tena sappurisūpasaṃsevasaddhammābhiyogo
analyzed: viññāyati iti tam nīharitvā dassetum na kevala ntiādi vuttam tena sappurisa upasaṃseva sat dhamma abhiyogo
translated: Therefore, in order to show that, “not only” and so on is said. By that, the association with good people and the application to the true Dhamma🔽is the sole cause for the growth of beings and the attainment of wisdom, just as, when there is a condition for sorrow,

original: yathā sattānaṃ vaḍḍhiyā paññāpaṭilābhassa ekantikaṃ kāraṇaṃ, evaṃ sokapaccaye sati
analyzed: yathā sattānam vaḍḍhiyā paññā paṭilābhassa ekantikam kāraṇam evam soka paccaye sati
translated: the state of being without sorrow,

original: visokabhāvassa, ñātimajjhe sobhāya, sugatigamanassa, ciraṃ sukhaṭṭhānassa, vaṭṭadukkhamocanassapi
analyzed: visoka bhāvassa ñāti majjhe sobhāya sugati gamanassa ciram sukha ṭṭhānassa vaṭṭa dukkha mocanassa pi
translated: the beauty in the midst of relatives, the going to a good destination, the long-lasting happiness, and the release from the suffering of the cycle of existence🔽are

original: aññāsādhāraṇaṃ hotīti vuttamevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: añña a sādhāraṇam hoti iti vuttam eva ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: and it is said that it is not shared with others.

original: Sabbhisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sabbhi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sabbhisutta is finished.

original: 2. Maccharisuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Maccharisutta

original: 32. Pamajjanākārena pavattā anupaladdhi pamādo. Tena ekantato satirahitā hontīti
analyzed: pamajjana ākārena pavattā pamādaḥ tena ekantataḥ sati rahitāḥ honti iti
translated: Negligence is the non-acquisition that occurs by way of negligence. By that they are entirely without mindfulness.

original: vuttaṃ “sativippavāsalakkhaṇenā”ti. Diṭṭhivicikicchādayo cettha pamādeneva saṅgahitā.
analyzed: vuttam sati vippavāsa lakkhaṇena ati diṭṭhi vicikicchā ādayaḥ ca ittha pamādena iva saṅgahitā
translated: Therefore it is said that it has the characteristic of the absence of mindfulness. Here, however, views, doubt, etc., are included by negligence itself.

original: Idāni yathā macchariyanimittañca pamādanimittañca dānaṃ na dīyati, taṃ dassetuṃ “ekacco🔽hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Parikkhayaṃ gamissatīti bhogaparihāniṃ gamissati. Khiḍḍādīti ādi-saddena🔽maṇḍanavibhūsanachaṇanakkhattakiccabyasanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Yasadāyakanti kittiyasassa
analyzed: idāni yathā macchariya nimittam ca pamāda nimittam ca dānam na dīyati tam dassetum ekaccaḥ  hi itiādi vuttam parikkhayam gamissati iti bhoga parihānim gamissati khiḍḍa ādi iti ādi saddena  maṇḍana vibhūsana chaṇa nakkhatta kicca vyasana ādim saṅgaṇhāti yasa dāyakam ti kitti yasassa
translated: Now, in order to show how generosity is not given because of the cause of stinginess and the cause of negligence, it is said: “One who is stingy, thinking: ‘My wealth will be exhausted,’ does not give a gift.🔽He thinks: ‘I will be without wealth.’ He is negligent, thinking: ‘I will give a gift at a time of play, etc.,’ and he does not give a gift.

original: parivārayasassa ca dāyakaṃ. Sirīdāyakanti sobhaggadāyakaṃ. Sampattidāyakanti kulabhogarūpabhogasampadāhi
analyzed: ca dāyakam sirī dāyakanti sobhagga dāyakanti sampatti dāyakanti
translated: He thinks: ‘I will give a gift at a time of play, laughter, amusement, and merry-making, at a time of dancing, singing, and music, at a time of seeing a fair, at a time of business, at a time of making a journey, at a time of illness, at a time of old age.’ By this method he does not give a gift at any time.🔽He thinks: ‘I will give a gift at a time of death.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and gone.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is gone.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is destroyed.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is burned.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is scattered.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is gone.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is destroyed.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I am dead and my body is burned.’ He does not give a gift, thinking: ‘I will give a gift when I

original: sampattidāyakaṃ. Puññanti vā idha puññaphalaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ “evamidaṃ puññaṃ pavaḍḍhatī”tiādīsu
analyzed: sampatti dāyakam puññanti vā idha puñña phalam daṭṭhabbam evam idam puññam pavaḍḍhati itiādīsu
translated: Or else here “merit” should be regarded as the fruit of merit, as in such passages as “Thus does merit grow” .

original: viya. Atthi dānassa phalanti ettha deyyadhammassa anavaṭṭhitataṃ bahulasādhāraṇataṃ,🔽taṃ pahāya gamanīyataṃ, tabbisayāya pītiyā sāvajjataṃ, dānadhammassa anaññasādhāraṇataṃ
analyzed: viya atthi dānassa phalanti ettha deyya dhammassa anavaṭṭhita taṃ bahula sādhāraṇa taṃ  tam pahāya gamanīya tam tad visayāya pītiyā sāvajja tam dāna dhammassa an añña sādhāraṇa tam
translated: As to “There is fruit of giving”: the non-restraint of the gift-object, the fact that it is shared by many,🔽the fact that it is to be gone away from, the blameableness of the happiness based on that, the fact that the gift-idea is not shared by others,

original: anugāmikataṃ, tabbisayāya pītiyā anavajjataṃ, lobhādipāpadhammānaṃ vinodanaṃ, sesapuññānaṃ
analyzed: anugāmika tam tad visayāya pītiyāḥ anavajja tam lobha ādi pāpa dhammānam vinodanam sesa puññānam
translated: the fact that it is to be followed, the blamelessness of the happiness based on that, the removal of such evil ideas as greed,

original: upanissayañca jānantenāti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: upanissayam ca jānantena ati vattabbam
translated: and the conditionality of the remaining kinds of merit should be stated.

original: Taṃyeva bālanti yo maccharī, tameva. Adānasīlā bālā. Ekacco dhanassa paribhogaparikkhayabhayena attanāpi na paribhuñjati atilobhaseṭṭhi viyāti āha “idhalokaparalokesū”ti.
analyzed: tam yeva bālam ti yaḥ mad śarī tam eva a dāna sīlāḥ bālāḥ ekaccaḥ dhanassa paribhoga parikkhaya bhayena attanā api na paribhuñjati ati lobha seṭṭhi viya iti āha idha loka para lokesu iti
translated: “The fool” is the miser. “The fool who has the habit of not giving” is the fool who has the habit of not giving. Because of fear of the exhaustion of his wealth through using it up, some man does not use it up himself, like the miserly money-lender. That is why “in this world and the next” is said.

original: Yasmā ekacco adānasīlo puriso addhike disvā passantopi na passati, tesaṃ kathaṃ suṇantopi
analyzed: yasmai ekaccaḥ a dāna sīlaḥ purisaḥ addhike disvā passantaḥ api na passati tesam katham suṇantaḥ api
translated: Because some man who has the habit of not giving does not see even though he looks, does not hear even though he listens to the talk of those who have a surplus,

original: na suṇoti, sayaṃ kiñci na katheti, adātukamyatāthambhe baddho hoti, tasmā tattha
analyzed: na suṇoti sayam kiñci na katheti a dātu kamyatā āthambhe baddhaḥ hoti tasmā
translated: He does not hear, he does not say anything himself, he is bound by the fetter of miserliness. Therefore

original: mataliṅgāni upalabbhantiyevāti āha “adānasīlatāya maraṇena matesū”ti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: mata liṅgāni āha adāna sīla tāya maraṇena matesu iti aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: the characteristics of the dead are found there. Therefore it is said: “In the dead through the habit of not giving.”🔽But in the commentary,

original: pana dānamattameva gahetvā matenassa samataṃ dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Dānasīlassa
analyzed: pana dāna mattam eva gahetvā matena assa samatam dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam dāna sīlassa
translated: having taken only giving, it is said: “As it is said,” in order to show the equality of the dead. But the characteristics of the living

original: pana amataliṅgāni vuttavipariyāyato veditabbāni. Vajanti puthutte ekavacanaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: pana amata liṅgāni vutta vipariyāyataḥ veditabbāni vajanti puthutte ekavacanam tasmā
translated: should be understood in the opposite way to the dead. The word “vajanti” is singular in the plural. Therefore

original: vacanavipallāsena vuttanti āha “saha vajantā”ti. Dānasīlādidhammo purātano, na ajjatanoti
analyzed: vacana vipallāsena vuttanti āha saha vajantā ati dāna sīla ādi dhammo purātanaḥ na ajjatano ti
translated: it is said: “Together with the living.” The Dhamma of giving, virtue, etc. is ancient, not new.

original: sanantano, so etesu atthīti sanantanā, paṇḍitā, tesaṃ dhammāti tesaṃ vasenapi dhammo
analyzed: sanantanaḥ saḥ etesu atthi iti sanantanā paṇḍitā tesam dhammā ati tesam vasena api dhammo
translated: Therefore it is eternal. It exists in them, therefore they are eternal. The wise. The Dhamma is

original: sanantanoti āha “sanantanānaṃ vā paṇḍitānaṃ esa dhammo”ti. Appasmimpi deyyadhamme
analyzed: sanantanaḥ iti āha sanantanānam vā paṇḍitānam esa dhammo ti appasmim pi deyya dhamme
translated: according to them. Therefore it is said: “This is the Dhamma of the eternal wise.”🔽Even when there is little property to be given,🔽some give, some do not give due to miserliness. Even one offering is like a thousand

original: sati eke dānaṃ dadanti, eke na dadanti maccharibhāvā. Sahassadānasadisāti ekāpi dakkhiṇā
analyzed: sati eke dānam dadanti eke na dadanti macchari bhāvā sahassa dāna sadisā iti ekā api dakkhiṇā
translated: offerings.

original: pariccāgacetanāya uḷārabhāvato sahassadānasadisā hoti.
analyzed: pariccāga cetanāya uḷāra bhāvataḥ sahassa dāna sadisā hoti
translated: The thought of giving is superior, like a thousand gifts.

original: Duranugamanoti asamaṅginā anugantuṃ dukkaro. Ananugamanañcassa dhammassa apūraṇamevāti
analyzed: duranugamanaḥ ti asamaṅginā anugantum dukkaraḥ ananugamanam ca sassa dhammassa a pūraṇam eva ati
translated: Hard to follow: difficult to follow for one who is not perfect. And his not following is just his not fulfilling the Dhamma.

original: āha “duppūro”ti. “Dhammaṃ care”ti ayaṃ dhammacariyā gahaṭṭhassa vasena āraddhāti
analyzed: āha duppūro ti dhammam cara iti ayam dhamma cariyā gahaṭṭhassa vasena āraddhā ati
translated: So it is said, “Hard to fulfill.” “To practice the Dhamma”: this practice of the Dhamma is begun with reference to the householder.

original: āha “dasakusalakammapathadhammaṃ caratī”ti. Tenāha “dārañca posa”nti. Samuñjakanti
analyzed: āha dasa kusala kammapatha dhammam carati iti tena āha dārañca posanti
translated: So it is said, “He practices the Dhamma of the ten wholesome courses of action.” Therefore it is said, “And to support one’s dependents.”

original: kassakehi attanā kātabbaṃ katvā visaṭṭhadhaññakaraṇato khale uñchācariyavasena samuñjaniādinā
analyzed: kassakehi attanā kātabbam katvā visaṭṭha dhañña karaṇataḥ khale uñchā cariya vasena samuñjani ādinā
translated: To glean: having done what has to be done by the farmers, to gather the grain that is left behind by the reapers, by the method of gleaning, etc.

original: chaḍḍitadhaññasaṃharaṇaṃ. Tenāha “yo api…pe… samuñjakaṃ caratī”ti. Etenāti satasahassasahassayāgiggahaṇena
analyzed: chaḍḍita dhañña saṃharaṇam tena āha yaḥ apipe samuñjakam carati iti etena ati sata sahassa sahassa yāgi ggahaṇena
translated: So it is said, “He who practices gleaning, etc.” By this: by the taking of a hundred thousand and a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand.

original: dasannampi bhikkhukoṭīnaṃ piṇḍapāto dassito hoti. “Dinno”ti padaṃ ānetvā yojanā.
analyzed: dasannam pi bhikkhu koṭīnam piṇḍapātaḥ dassitaḥ hoti dinnaḥ iti padam ānetvā yojanā
translated: The alms-food of ten koṭis of bhikkhus is shown. The word “given” is to be supplied.

original: Dasannaṃ vā kahāpaṇakoṭīnaṃ piṇḍapātoti dasannaṃ kahāpaṇakoṭīnaṃ viniyuñjanavasena
analyzed: dasannam vā kahā paṇa koṭīnam dasannam kahā paṇa koṭīnam viniyuñjana vasena
translated: The alms-food of ten koṭis of kahāpaṇas: by the method of using ten koṭis of kahāpaṇas.

original: sampāditapiṇḍapāto. Tayidaṃ satasahassaṃ sahassayāgīnaṃ dānaṃ ettakaṃ hotīti katvā
analyzed: sampādita piṇḍapātaḥ tayidam sata sahassam sahassa yāgīnam dānam ettakam hoti iti katvā
translated: and he has completed his alms-round. And this is said in terms of the gift of a hundred thousand of those who give a thousand.

original: vuttaṃ. Samuñjakaṃ carantopīti samuñjakaṃ caritvāpi, samuñjakacaraṇahetūti attho.
analyzed: vuttam samuñjakam carantaḥ api iti samuñjakam caritvā api samuñjaka caraṇa hetū ti attho
translated: Even though he goes on all-around alms round: even though he goes on all-around alms round, the meaning is, on account of going on all-around alms round.

original: Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Dāraṃ posentopi dhammaṃ carati, appakasmiṃ dadantopi
analyzed: sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayaḥ dāram posentaḥ api dhammam carati appakasmim dadantaḥ api
translated: The same method applies to the other two clauses. Even though he supports a wife he lives the life of one who has right in the Dhamma, and even though he gives little he lives the life of one who has right in the Dhamma.🔽The construction is this. Even though he supports a wife he lives the life of one who has right in the Dhamma, and even though he gives little he lives the life of one who has right in the Dhamma.

original: dhammaṃ caratīti yojanā. Tathāvidhassāti tādisassa tathādhammacārino yā dhammacariyā,
analyzed: dhammam carati iti yojanā tathāvidhassa ati tādisassa tathā dhamma cārinaḥ yā dhamma cariyā
translated: The life of one who has right in the Dhamma of such a one as that,🔽is not worth a fraction of the life of one who has right in the Dhamma of such a one as that, of those who give a thousand.

original: tassā kalampi nagghanti ete sahassayāgino attano sahassayāgitāya. Yaṃ tena daliddenātiādi
analyzed: tassā ete sahassa yāginaḥ sahassa yāgi tāya yam tena daliddena atiādi
translated: What he gives in a single day, etc.,🔽is an elucidation of the same matter.

original: tassevatthassa vivaraṇaṃ. Sabbesampi tesanti “sataṃsahassānaṃ sahassayāgina”nti vuttānaṃ
analyzed: tassa iva atthassa vivaraṇam sabbesam pi tesanti sataṃsahassānam sahassa yāginanti vuttānam
translated: Of all those: of all those referred to in the passage “a hundred thousand of those who give a thousand.”

original: tesaṃ sabbesampi. Itaresanti “tathāvidhassā”ti vuttapurisato aññesaṃ. Dasakoṭisahassadānanti
analyzed: tesam sabbesam pi itaresanti tathāvidhassa ati vutta purisataḥ aññesam dasa koṭi sahassa dānam ti
translated: Of the rest: of those other than the man referred to in the passage “of such a one as that.”

original: dasakoṭisaṅkhātaṃ tato anekasahassabhedatāya sahassadānaṃ.
analyzed: dasa koṭi saṅkhātam tatas aneka sahassa bheda tāya sahassa dānam
translated: The giving of ten thousand millions: the giving of ten times a hundred thousand millions, which is of many thousands of kinds.

original: “Kalaṃ nagghatī”ti idaṃ tesaṃ dānato imassa dānassa uḷāratarabhāvena vipulatarabhāvena
analyzed: kalam nagghati iti idam tesam dānataḥ imassa dānassa uḷāratara bhāvena vipulatara bhāvena
translated: “He is outshining the other gifts” : this is said because this gift is more excellent and more extensive than those gifts,

original: vipulataraphalatāya vuttanti āha “kathaṃ nu kho etaṃ mahapphalataranti jānanattha”nti.
analyzed: vipulatara phala tāya vuttanti āha katham nu kho etam mahapphalataranti jānana atthanti
translated: and because it has a more extensive fruit. Therefore he said, “in order to know how it is more fruitful.”

original: Paccayavisesena mahattaṃ gatoti mahaggato, uḷāroti attho. Tenāha “vipulassetaṃ vevacana”nti.
analyzed: paccaya visesena mahattam gataḥ ti mahaggataḥ uḷāraḥ ti attho tena āha vipulassa etam vevacanam ti
translated: “Magnificent” : it has gone to greatness through the excellence of its conditions. The meaning is: “excellent.” Therefore he said, “this is a synonym for ‘extensive.’“

original: Samenāti ñāyena, dhammenāti attho. Visameti na same macchariyalakkhaṇappatte. Chetvāti
analyzed: samena ati ñāyena dhammena ati atthaḥ visame iti na same macchariya lakkhaṇa ppatte chetvā ati
translated: “By the standard” : by the norm. The meaning is: “by the rule.” “By the irregular” : by what has become characterized by stinginess, not by what is regular. “Having cut” :

original: pīḷetvā. Taṃ pana pīḷanaṃ pothananti dassento “pothetvā”ti āha. Assumukhāti tintaassumukhasammissā
analyzed: pīḷetvā tam pana pīḷanam pothananti dassento pothetvā iti āha assumukhā iti tinta assumukha sammissā
translated: having oppressed. But showing that oppression to be grinding, he said “having ground.” “With the mouth of a millstone” : having mixed it with the mouth of a millstone that is smeared with saliva,

original: paraṃ rodāpetvā. Mahādānanti yathāvuttaṃ bahudeyyadhammassa pariccajanena mahantadānaṃ.
analyzed: param rodāpetvā mahā dānam ti yathāvuttam bahu deyya dhammassa pariccajanena mahanta dānam
translated: having made another cry. “Great gift” : a great gift by the relinquishing of the many things to be given as mentioned.

original: Uppattiyā aparisuddhatāyāti ajjhāsayassa deyyadhammagavesanāya ca suddhatāya malīnattā.
analyzed: uppattiyāḥ a parisuddha tāya ati ajjhāsayassa deyya dhamma gavesanāya ca suddha tāya malīna ttā
translated: “Because of the impurity of its origin” : because of the impurity of the intention and of the search for things to be given.

original: Itaraṃ dhammacariyāya nibbattitadānaṃ. Parittadānanti parittassa deyyadhammassa vasena
analyzed: itaram dhamma cariyāya nibbattita dānam paritta dānam ti parittassa deyya dhammassa vasena
translated: The other is the giving of what is produced by Dhamma-practice.🔽Limited giving: giving by means of limited things to be given.

original: parittadānaṃ. Attano uppattiyā parisuddhatāyāti ajjhāsayassa deyyadhammagavesanāya
analyzed: paritta dānam attanaḥ uppattiyā parisuddha tāya ati ajjhāsayassa deyya dhamma gavesanāya
translated: Purity of his own origination: purity of his intention in seeking things to be given.

original: ca visuddhatāya. Evantiādimāhāti “evaṃ sahassānaṃ sahassayāgina”nti avoca. Tattha
analyzed: ca visuddha tāya evanti ādim āha ati evam sahassānam sahassa yāginam ti avoca tattha
translated: Thus, etc.: he said, “Thus a thousand givers of a thousand” .

original: sahassānanti sataṃsahassānaṃ. Gāthābandhasukhatthaṃ sataggahaṇaṃ na kataṃ. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: sahassānam ti satam sahassānam gāthā bandha sukha attham sata gahaṇam na katam sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: Herein, a thousand is a hundred thousand. The hundred is not mentioned for the sake of euphony in the verse. The rest is in the way already stated.

original: Maccharisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: macchari sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Macchariyasutta is ended.

original: 3. Sādhusuttavaṇṇanā🔽33. Udānaṃ udānesīti pītivegena uggiritabbatāya udānaṃ uggiri uccāresi. Tayidaṃ yasmā🔽pītisamuṭṭhāpitaṃ vacanaṃ, tasmā vuttaṃ “udāhāraṃ udāharī”ti. Yathā pana taṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: sādhu sutta vaṇṇanā  udānam udānesi iti pīti vegena uggiritabbatāya udānam uggiri uccāresi tayidam yasmai  pīti samuṭṭhāpitam vacanam tasmai vuttam udāhāram udāhari iti yathā pana tam vacanam
translated: The Sādhu Sutta🔽He uttered an exalted utterance: udāna means what is uttered with a surge of joy. This is said because it is spoken with the arising of joy.🔽But in order to show how that speech is called “an exalted utterance” he said, “For just as,” etc.

original: “udāna”nti vuccati, taṃ dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Saddhāyāti ettha ya-kāro
analyzed: udānam ti vuccati tam dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam saddhāya ati ettha yakāraḥ
translated: With faith: here the ya is a particle in the sense of a conjunction.

original: hetuattho. Pariccāgacetanāya hi saddhā visesapaccayo assaddhassa tadabhāvato. Pi-saddo
analyzed: hetu atthaḥ pariccāga cetanāya hi saddhā visesa paccayaḥ assaddhassa tad abhāvataḥ pisaddaḥ
translated: The meaning of cause. For faith is a special cause for the volition of giving, since the faithless are devoid of it. The word “and”

original: vuttatthasampiṇḍanattho. “Sāhū”ti padaṃ sādhusaddena samānatthaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kathanti
analyzed: vutta ttha sampiṇḍana tthaḥ sāhu iti padam sādhu saddena samāna attham daṭṭhabbam katham ti
translated: has the meaning of including what has been stated. The word “good” should be seen as having the same meaning as the word “good”. The word “but”

original: dānayuddhānaṃ vipakkhasabhāvāti adhippāyo. Etaṃ ubhayanti dānaṃ yuddhanti idaṃ dvayaṃ.
analyzed: dāna yuddhānam vipakkha sabhāvā ati adhippāyaḥ etam ubhayanti dānam yuddhanti idam dvayam
translated: has the meaning of a contrast between giving and fighting. The intention is that they are of opposite natures. “These two” means giving and fighting.

original: Jīvitabhīrukoti jīvitavināsabhīruko. Khayabhīrukoti bhogakkhayassa bhīruko. Vadantoti
analyzed: jīvita bhīrukaḥ iti jīvita vināsa bhīrukaḥ khaya bhīrukaḥ oti bhoga khayassa bhīrukaḥ vadanto ti
translated: “Cowardly” means afraid of the destruction of life. “Afraid of loss” means afraid of the loss of wealth. “Saying”

original: jīvite sālayataṃ, tato eva yujjhane asamatthataṃ pavedento. Chejjanti hatthapādādichedo.
analyzed: jīvite eva yujjhane a samattha tam chejjanti hattha pāda ādi chedo
translated: means declaring his attachment to life and his inability to fight because of that. “Cutting off” means the cutting off of hands, feet, etc.

original: Ussahantoti vīriyaṃ karonto. Evaṃ bhoge rakkhissāmīti tathā bhoge aparikkhīṇe karissāmīti.
analyzed: ussahantaḥ ti vīriyam karontaḥ evam bhoge rakkhissāmi iti tathā bhoge aparikkhīṇe karissāmi iti
translated: “Striving” means making effort. “Thus” means “I will protect my wealth in this way”. “Thus” means “I will make my wealth inexhaustible in this way”.

original: Vadantoti idha bhogesu lobhaṃ, tato eva dātuṃ asamatthataṃ pavedento. Evanti evaṃ
analyzed: vadantaḥ iti bhogesu lobham tatas eva dātum evam
translated: “Saying” means declaring his greed for wealth and his inability to give because of that. “Thus” means “in this way”.

original: jīvitabhoganirapekkhatāya dānañca yuddhañca samaṃ hoti. Saddhādisampannoti saddhādhammajīvitāvīmaṃsāsīlādiguṇasamannāgato.
analyzed: jīvita bhoga nirapekkha tāya dānañca yuddhañca samam hoti saddhā ādi sampanno ti saddhā dhamma jīvita a vīmaṃsā sīla ādi guṇa samannāgataḥ
translated: Giving and fighting are the same in that neither of them cares about life and property. “Endowed with faith, etc.,” means endowed with the qualities of faith, virtue, generosity, wisdom, and so on.

original: So hi deyyavatthuno parittakattā appakampi dadanto attano pana cittasampattiyā khettasampattiyā
analyzed: so hi deyya vatthuno paritta kattā appakam pi dadantaḥ attanaḥ pana citta sampattiyā khetta sampattiyā
translated: For one who has little to give, even a small gift, because of the excellence of his faith, etc.,

original: ca bahuṃ uḷārapuññaṃ pavaḍḍhento bahuvidhaṃ lobha-dosa-issā-macchariya-diṭṭhivicikicchādibhedaṃ
analyzed: ca bahum uḷāra puññam pavaḍḍhentaḥ bahuvidham
translated: and because of the excellence of the field, increases much merit, which is superior to the merit of the gift. It overcomes the many kinds of greed, hatred, envy, stinginess, views, doubts, etc.,

original: tappaṭipakkhaṃ abhibhavati, tato eva ca taṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: tad paṭipakkham abhibhavati tatas eva ca tam mahapphalam hoti mahā nisaṃsam aṭṭhakathāyam
translated: which are its opposites. Therefore it is fruitful and beneficial. But in the commentary

original: pana “maccheraṃ maddati”cceva vuttaṃ, tassa pana ujuvipaccanīkabhāvato.
analyzed: pana maccheram madda ticca iva vuttam tassa pana uju vipaccanīka bhāvato
translated: it is said: “It overcomes stinginess.” This is because stinginess is its direct opposite.

original: Paratthāti paraloke. Ekasāṭakabrāhmaṇavatthu anvayavasena, aṅkuravatthu byatirekavasena vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: paratthā ati para loke eka sāṭaka brāhmaṇa vatthu anvaya vasena aṅkura vatthu byatireka vasena vitthāretabbam
translated: “For the sake of others” means for the sake of the next world. The story of the brahmin who wore a single garment and the story of the sprout should be elaborated in detail by the method of identity and the method of difference, respectively.

original: Dhammo laddho etenāti dhammaladdho, puggalo. Aggiāhitapadassa viya saddasiddhi daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: dhammaḥ laddhaḥ etena ati dhamma laddhaḥ puggalaḥ aggi āhita padassa viya sadda siddhi daṭṭhabbā
translated: “One who has obtained the Dhamma” is a person who has obtained the Dhamma. The derivation of the word should be understood as in the case of the word “agni” .

original: “Uṭṭhānanti kāyikaṃ vīriyaṃ, vīriyanti cetasika”nti vadanti. Uṭṭhānanti bhoguppāde🔽yuttapayuttatā. Vīriyanti tajjo ussāho. Yamassa āṇāpavattiṭṭhānaṃ. Vetaraṇimpi itare🔽niraye ca atikkamma. Te pana abbudādīnaṃ vasena avīciṃ dasadhā katvā avasesamahāniraye🔽sattapi āyuppamāṇabhedena tayo tayo katvā ekatiṃsāti vadanti. Sañjīvādinirayasaṃvattanassa
analyzed: uṭṭhānanti kāyikam vīriyam vīriyanti cetasikanti vadanti uṭṭhānanti bhoga uppāde  yutta payutta tā vīriyanti tad jaḥ ussāhaḥ yamassa āṇā pavatti ṭṭhānam itare  niraye ca atikkamma te pana abbuda ādīnam vasena avīcim dasadhā katvā avasesa mahāniraye  āyu ppamāṇa bhedena tayo tayo katvā ekatiṃsā iti vadanti sañjīva ādi niraya saṃvattanassa
translated: “Uprightness” is bodily energy; “energy” is mental energy, they say. “Uprightness” is the state of being occupied with and engaged in the means of livelihood. “Energy” is the endeavour that is appropriate to that. It is the place where the power of Yama is exercised. The other hells are crossed by the Vetaraṇi River.🔽But they say that Avīci is tenfold according to the Abbudas, etc., and that the remaining great hells are threefold each according to the measure of life. Thus they make thirty-one altogether.🔽The hells of Sañjīva, etc., are the places for the exercise of the power of Yama.

original: kammassa tikkhamajjhamudubhāvena tassa āyuppamāṇassa tividhatā vibhāvetabbā. Apare🔽pana “aṭṭha mahānirayā soḷasa ussadanirayā ādito cattāro sitaniraye ekaṃ katvā satta🔽sitanirayāti evaṃ ekatiṃsa mahānirayā”ti vadanti. Mahānirayaggahaṇato ādito cattāro🔽sitanirayā eko nirayo katoti.
analyzed: kammassa tikkha majjha mudu bhāvena tassa āyu ppamāṇassa tividha tā vibhāvetabbā apare 🔽pana aṭṭha mahānirayā soḷasa ussada nirayā ādito cattāro sitaniraye ekam katvā satta 🔽evam ekatiṃsa mahānirayā iti vadanti mahāniraya ggahaṇato āditas cattāro 🔽ekaḥ nirayaḥ
translated: “Uttāṇa” is bodily energy, “vīriya” is mental energy, they say. “Uttāṇa” is the state of being occupied with the means of livelihood. “Vīriya” is the enthusiasm for that. It is the place of the operation of Yama’s orders. The other hells are crossed over. But they are divided into ten by means of the abbudi and so on. The remaining great hells are divided into three by means of the measure of life. They say that there are thirty-one. The threefoldness of that measure of life should be shown by means of the deed that leads to the Sañjīva hell, etc., being strong, medium, or weak. But others say: “There are thirty-one great hells: eight great hells, sixteen adjacent hells, and the four cold hells counted as one at the beginning.” They say this because the four cold hells are counted as one hell by the expression “great hells.”

original: Tesanti vicinitvā gahitapaccayānaṃ. Pañcanavutipāsaṇḍabhedā papañcasūdanisaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ🔽vuttanayena veditabbā. Tatthāti tesu dvīsu vicinanesu. Dakkhiṇāvicinanaṃ āha, upamānāni
analyzed: vicinitvā gahita paccayānam  vutta nayena veditabbā tattha ati tesu dvīsu vicinanesu dakkhiṇā vicinanam āha upamānāni
translated: “Those” refers to the conditions that have been examined. The ninety-five kinds of heresy should be understood in the way stated in the Papañcasūdanī commentary on the Majjhima Nikāya.🔽“There” refers to the two kinds of examination. The examination of the field of merit is stated.🔽For similes are given only for the purpose of clarifying the meaning of the simile.

original: hi nāma yāvadeva upameyyatthavibhāvanatthāni. Etena sukhettagahaṇatopi dakkhiṇeyyavicinanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi nāma yāvat eva upameyya ttha vibhāvana tthāni etena su khetta gahaṇataḥ pi dakkhiṇeyya vicinanam daṭṭhabbam
translated: By this it should be understood that the examination of the worthy recipient is also to be done by taking a good field.

original: Pāṇesu saṃyamoti iminā dasavidhampi kusalakammapathadhammaṃ dasseti. Yathā hi “pāṇesu🔽saṃyamo”ti iminā sattānaṃ jīvitāvoropanato saṃyamo vutto, evaṃ tesaṃ sāpateyyāvahārato
analyzed: pāṇesu saṃyamaḥ ti iminā dasavidham pi kusala kammapatha dhammam dasseti yathā hi pāṇesu  saṃyamo ti iminā sattānam jīvita avoropanato saṃyamo vutto evam tesam sāpateyya avahārato
translated: “Restraint in regard to the faculties” shows the tenfold profitable action.

original: paradārāmasanato visaṃvādanato aññamaññabhedanato pharusavacanena saṅghaṭṭanato niratthakavippalapanato
analyzed: para dāra āmasanataḥ visaṃvādanataḥ aññamañña bhedanataḥ pharusa vacanena saṅghaṭṭanataḥ niratthaka vippalapanataḥ
translated: For just as “restraint in regard to the faculties” is said to be the restraint of living beings from taking life, so it is also the restraint of them from taking what is not given, from sexual misconduct, from false speech, from malicious speech, from harsh speech, from gossip,

original: parasantakābhijjhānato ucchedacintanato micchābhinivesanato ca saṃyamo hotīti. Tenāha
analyzed: uccheda cintanataḥ micchā abhinivesanataḥ ca saṃyamaḥ hoti iti tena āha
translated: from covetousness, from ill will, and from wrong view. Therefore it is said:🔽“Restraint in regard to the faculties is the root of all profitable things.

original: “sīlānisaṃsaṃ kathetumāraddhā”ti. Pharusavacanasaṃyamo panettha sarūpeneva vutto.
analyzed: sīla anisaṃsam kathetum āraddhā ati pharusa vacana saṃyamaḥ pana ittha sarūpena iva vutto
translated: “They have begun to expound the benefits of virtue.” The restraint of harsh speech is stated here in its own form.

original: Parassa upavādabhayenāti pāpakiriyahetu parena attano vattabbaupavādabhayena. Upavādabhayāti
analyzed: parassa upavāda bhayena ati pāpa kiriya hetu parena attanaḥ vattabba aupavāda bhayena upavāda bhayā ati
translated: Out of fear of blame by others: out of fear of blame by others that might be expressed by them as a reason for one’s evil conduct. Out of fear of blame:

original: upavādabhayanimittaṃ. “Kathaṃ nu kho amhe pare na upavadeyyu”nti āsīsantā pāpaṃ na
analyzed: upavāda bhaya nimittam katham nu khalu amhe pare naḥ upavadeyyunti pāpam na
translated: out of fear of blame as a reason . “How can others not blame us?” thinking thus, they do not commit evil.

original: karonti. Dhammapadamevāti asaṅkhatadhammakoṭṭhāso eva seyyo seṭṭho. Yasmā sabbasaṅkhataṃ
analyzed: karonti dhamma padam evā ati asaṅkhata dhammakoṭṭhāsaḥ eva seyyaḥ seṭṭhaḥ yasmā sabba saṅkhatam
translated: The Dhamma-word: the category of the unformed element is better, best. Since all that is formed

original: aniccaṃ khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammaṃ, tasmā tadadhigamāya
analyzed: aniccam khaya dhammam vaya dhammam virāga dhammam nirodha dhammam tasmai tad adhigamāya
translated: is impermanent, subject to destruction, subject to vanishing, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, he shows that effort should be made to attain that . The word “before” :

original: ussāho karaṇīyoti dasseti. Pubbasaddo kālavisesavisayoti āha “pubbe ca kassapabuddhādikālepī”tiādi.
analyzed: ussāhaḥ karaṇīyaḥ ti dasseti pubba saddaḥ kāla visesa visayaḥ ti āha pubbe ca kassapa buddha ādi kāle pi itiādi
translated: the distinction of time is the province of the word “before.” Therefore it is said: “Before, in the time of Kassapa Buddha, etc.”

original: Puna akālaviseso apāṭiyekko bhummatthavisayovāti āha “sabbepi vā”tiādi. Tattha sabbepi
analyzed: puna a kāla visesaḥ apāṭiyekkaḥ bhumma ttha visayaḥ vā ti āha sabbe pi vā atiādi tattha sabbe pi
translated: Again, the distinction of time is not separate from the meaning of the word. It is the province of the meaning of the word. Therefore it is said: “Or all” , etc. Herein, all

original: vāti ete sabbepi kassapabuddhādayo lokanāthā santo nāma vūpasantasabbakilesasantāpā
analyzed: vā ti ete sabbe pi kassapa buddha ādayaḥ lokanāthāḥ santaḥ nāma vūpasanta sabba kilesa santāpā
translated: All these Lords of the World, beginning with Kassapa Buddha, are called “peaceful” because they have calmed all the fever of defilement and all the suffering of existence.

original: santasabbhūtaguṇattā.
analyzed: santa sat bhūta guṇa ttā
translated: They are “peaceful” because they have the special qualities of all that is peaceful.

original: Sādhusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sādhu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sādhusutta is finished.

original: 4. Nasantisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nasanti sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Nasantisutta

original: 34. Kamanīyānīti kantāni. Tato eva etāni iṭṭhārammaṇāni sukhārammaṇāni rūpādīni,
analyzed: kamanīyāni iti kantāni tatas eva etāni iṭṭha ārammaṇāni sukha ārammaṇāni rūpa ādīni
translated: is pleasing, desirable, because of that they are objects of pleasure, objects of happiness, visible forms, etc.

original: te pana vatthukāmā, tadārammaṇakilesakāmā vā. “Na santi kāmā manujesū”ti desanāsīsametaṃ,
analyzed: te pana vatthu kāmā tad ārammaṇa kilesa kāmā vā na santi kāmā manujesu iti
translated: But these are sensual desires as objects, or sensual desires as defilements with those as object. “There are no sensual desires among men” is the climax of the teaching.

original: nicchayena kāmā aniccāyeva. Maccu dhīyati etthāti maccudheyyaṃ. Na puna āgacchati
analyzed: nicchayena kāmāḥ aniccāya iva maccu dhīyati etthā ati maccudheyyam na punar āgacchati
translated: Sensual desires are certainly impermanent. “Death is overcome here” : death is overcome here, not elsewhere.

original: ettha taṃ apunāgamanaṃ. Apunāgamanasaṅkhātaṃ nibbānaṃ anupagacchanato. Nibbānaṃ hītiādi
analyzed: ettha tam apunāgamanam apunāgamana saṅkhātam nibbānam an upagacchanataḥ nibbānam hi itiādi
translated: It is not reborn here. Because it does not go to Nibbāna, which is called “non-rebirth.” “Nibbāna is here” , etc.,

original: vuttassevatthassa vivaraṇaṃ. Baddhoti paṭibaddhacitto. Pamattoti vossaggapamādaṃ āpanno.
analyzed: vuttassa iva atthassa vivaraṇam baddhaḥ ti paṭibaddha cittaḥ pamattaḥ ti vossagga pamādam āpannaḥ
translated: is a description of the meaning stated above. “Bound” : his mind is bound. “Negligent” : he has fallen into the negligence of giving up .

original: Taṇhāchandato jātaṃ tassa visesapaccayattā. Icchitaṃ hanatīti aghaṃ, dukkhaṃ. Idha
analyzed: taṇhā chandataḥ jātam tassa visesa paccaya ttā icchitam hanati iti agham dukkham idha
translated: It is born of craving and will, because it is a special condition for that. “Evil” is suffering, which kills what is desired.

original: pana anavasesapariyādānavasena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhanti. Chandavinayā aghavinayoti🔽hetunirodhena hi phalanirodho, evaṃ saupādisesanibbānaṃ vatvā aghavinayā dukkhavinayoti
analyzed: pana anavasesa pariyādāna vasena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ chanda vinayāḥ agha vinayaḥ ti  hetu nirodhena hi phala nirodhaḥ evam sa aupādisesa nibbānam vatvā agha vinayā dukkha vinayā ti
translated: but the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering in the sense of being inexhaustibly subject to cankers. “By the removal of lust, by the removal of hatred” :

original: anupādisesanibbānaṃ vadati.
analyzed: anupādisesa nibbānam vadati
translated: for when the cause ceases, the fruit ceases. Having thus stated the Nibbāna element with a residue left, he now states the Nibbāna element without residue left, “By the removal of delusion, by the removal of suffering” .🔽“The various kinds” : sensual desires as defilements are of different kinds according to whether they are associated with feeling, etc., and according to their different modes.

original: Citrānīti kilesakāmāpi vedanādiṭṭhisampayogabhedena honti, ākārabhedena ca atthi🔽savighātāvighātāti tato visesetuṃ “ārammaṇacittānī”ti vuttaṃ. Saṅkappitarāgoti subhādivasena
analyzed: citrāni iti vedanā diṭṭhi sampayoga bhedena honti ākāra bhedena ca atthi  sa vighāta avighātā ti tatas visesetum ārammaṇa cittāni iti vuttam saṅkappita rāgaḥ ti subha ādi vasena
translated: “The various kinds of objects” : sensual desires as objects are of different kinds according to whether they are visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of consciousness” : sensual desires as consciousness are of different kinds according to whether they are eye-consciousness, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of perception” : sensual desires as perception are of different kinds according to whether they are perceptions of visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of volition” : sensual desires as volition are of different kinds according to whether they are volitions associated with eye-contact, etc., and according to their different modes.

original: saṅkappitavatthumhi rāgo. Kilesakāmo kāmoti vutto tassevidha visesato kāmabhāvasiddhito.🔽Pasūrasuttena vibhāvetabbo “na te kāmā”tiādinā tassa vatthumhi āgatattā. Idāni tamatthaṃ
analyzed: saṅkappita vatthumhi rāgaḥ kilesa kāmo kāmo ti vuttaḥ visesataḥ kāma bhāva siddhito  pasūra suttena vibhāvetabbaḥ na te kāmā ti ādinā tassa vatthumhi āgata ttā idāni tam attham
translated: “The various kinds of craving” : sensual desires as craving are of different kinds according to whether they are craving for visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of affection” : sensual desires as affection are of different kinds according to whether they are affection for visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.

original: saṅkhepeneva vibhāvento “pasūraparibbājako hī”tiādimāha. Na te kāmā yāni citrāni
analyzed: saṅkhepena iva vibhāventaḥ pasūra paribbājakaḥ hi iti ādim āha na te kāmāḥ yāni citrāni
translated: “The various kinds of attachment” : sensual desires as attachment are of different kinds according to whether they are attachment to visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of underlying tendencies” : sensual desires as underlying tendencies are of different kinds according to whether they are underlying tendencies to lust for visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of obsessions” : sensual desires as obsessions are of different kinds according to whether they are obsessions by lust for visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of fevers” : sensual desires as fevers are of different kinds according to whether they are fevers of lust for visible forms, etc., and according to their different modes.🔽“The various kinds of thoughts” : sensual desires as thoughts are of

original: loketi te ce kāmā na honti, yāni loke citrāni rūpādiārammaṇāni. Vedesīti kevalaṃ🔽saṅkapparāgañca kāmaṃ katvā vadesi ce. Hehintīti bhaveyyunti attho. Suṇanto saddāni
analyzed: loka iti te ce kāmāḥ na honti yāni loke citrāni rūpa ādi ārammaṇāni vedesi iti kevalam  saṅkappa rāgam ca kāmam katvā vadesi ce hehinti iti attho suṇantaḥ saddāni
translated: “If these are not your desires, then you speak of the various things in the world, the objects of form, etc., as if you were a connoisseur.🔽If you speak of them after having made a mere conceptual attachment to desire, then they will be yours.

original: manoramāni, satthāpi te hehiti kāmabhogīti paccekaṃ gāthā, idha pana saṃkhipitvā
analyzed: manoramāni satthā api te kāma bhogī iti paccekam gāthāḥ idha pana saṃkhipitvā
translated: Listening to delightful sounds, the Teacher also says to you, ‘Enjoy your desires,’ each verse separately, but here they are shown in brief.

original: dassitā. Dhīrā nāma dhitisampannāti āha “paṇḍitā”ti.
analyzed: dassitā dhīrā nāma dhiti sampannā ati āha paṇḍitā ati
translated: ‘The wise’ are those endowed with steadfastness, therefore he said ‘the sagacious.’

original: Tassāti yo pahīnakodhamāno sabbaso saṃyojanātigo nāmarūpasmiṃ asajjanto rāgādikiñcanarahito,
analyzed: tassa ati yaḥ pahīna kodha māno sabbaso saṃyojana atigaḥ nāma rūpasmim a sajjantaḥ rāga ādi kiñcana rahitaḥ
translated: ‘His’ refers to the one who has completely abandoned anger and conceit, who has gone beyond all the fetters, who is not attached to name-and-form, who is free from all the defilements of desire, etc.

original: tassa. Mogharājā nāma thero bāvarībrāhmaṇassa paricārakānaṃ soḷasannaṃ aññataro.
analyzed: tassa mogharājā nāma theraḥ bāvarī brāhmaṇassa paricārakānam soḷasannam aññataraḥ
translated: The Elder Mogharāja was one of the sixteen attendants of the brahmin Bāvari.

original: Yathānusandhiṃ appatto sāvasesa-attho, kiñci vattabbaṃ atthīti adhippāyo. Sabbaso
analyzed: yathā anusandhim appattaḥ sa avasesa attho kiñci vattabbam atthi iti adhippāyaḥ sabbaso
translated: The meaning is not complete, as it is not connected in the proper sequence. The intention is that there is something more to be said.

original: vimuttattāva devamanussā namassanti, ye taṃ paṭipajjanti. Tesaṃ kiṃ hoti? Kiñcipi
analyzed: deva manussāḥ namassanti ye tam paṭipajjanti tesam kim hoti kiñcipi
translated: Because of being completely liberated, gods and humans pay homage to him, and those who practice accordingly. What happens to them? What is there for them?

original: na siyāti ayamettha atthaviseso? Dasabalaṃ sandhāyevamāha ukkaṭṭhaniddesena. Anupaṭipattiyāti
analyzed: na siyā iti ayam ettha attha visesaḥ dasa balam sandhāya ivam āha ukkaṭṭha niddesena anupaṭipattiyā ti
translated: “Not so” is the special meaning here. He says this with reference to the Ten Powered One by way of the highest description. “Not in practice”:

original: paṭipattiṃ anugantvā paṭipajjanena. Namassanti taṃ pūjenti.
analyzed: paṭipattim anugantvā paṭipajjanena namassanti tam pūjenti
translated: by way of practice following practice. “They honor him”: they worship him.

original: Catusaccadhammaṃ jānitvāti tena paṭividdhaṃ catusaccadhammaṃ paṭivijjhitvā. Tathā
analyzed: catusacca dhammam jānitvā ati tena paṭividdham catusacca dhammam paṭivijjhitvā tathā
translated: “Having known the Dhamma of the Four Truths”: having penetrated the Dhamma of the Four Truths that he has penetrated. Thus

original: ca buddhasubuddhatāya nibbematikā hontīti āha “vicikicchaṃ pahāyā”ti. Tato paraṃ
analyzed: ca buddha su buddha tāya nibbematikāḥ honti iti āha vicikiccham pahāya ati tatas param
translated: they are free from doubt. Therefore it is said: “having abandoned doubt.” After that,

original: pana anukkamena aggamaggādhigamena saṅgātigāpi honti. Asekkhadhammapāripūriyā pasaṃsiyā
analyzed: pana anukkamena agga magga adhigamena saṅga atigā api honti asekkha dhamma pāripūriyā pasaṃsiyā
translated: however, they also go beyond the fetters by way of the attainment of the highest path in due course. By way of the fulfillment of the training rules they are

original: viññūnaṃ pasaṃsāpi hontīti.
analyzed: viññūnam pasaṃsā api honti iti
translated: praised by the wise.

original: Nasantisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nasanti sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Santisutta is finished.

original: 5. Ujjhānasaññisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ujjhāna saññi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Ujjhānasaññisutta

original: 35. Ujjhānavasena pavattā saññā etesaṃ atthi, ujjhānavasena vā sañjānantīti ujjhānasaññī.
analyzed: ujjhāna vasena pavattā saññā etesam atthi ujjhāna vasena vā sañjānanti iti ujjhāna saññī
translated: They have perception that occurs by way of contempt, or they perceive by way of contempt, thus they are ujjhānasaññī.

original: Kārayeti katānaṃ pariyantaṃ kārayeti attho. Pariyantakāritanti paricchinnakāritaṃ
analyzed: kārayā iti katānam pariyantam kārayā iti paricchinna kāritam
translated: “To make”: the meaning is: to make an end to what has been done. “Having made an end”: having made a limit.

original: parimitavacananti attho. Paṃsukūlādipaṭipakkhanayena pattuṇṇadukulādi vuttaṃ. Nāmaṃ
analyzed: parimita vacanam ti attho paṃsukūla ādi paṭipakkha nayena pattuṇṇa dukula ādi vuttam nāmam
translated: the meaning is, “limited in speech.” “Cloth from the rag-heap” is said by way of contrast to “cloth from a clean cloth.”🔽“Name”

original: gahitanti etena “ujjhānasaññikā”ti ettha ka-saddo saññāyanti dasseti.
analyzed: gahitanti etena ujjhāna saññikā ati ettha ka saddo saññāyanti dasseti
translated: The k-element in “ujjhānasaññikā” shows that the k-element is a name.

original: Aññenākārena bhūtanti attanā pavediyamānākārato aññena asuddhena ākārena vijjamānaṃ
analyzed: aññena ākārena bhūtanti attanā pavediyamāna ākārataḥ aññena asuddhena ākārena vijjamānam
translated: “In another way” means that the self is found, is discovered, in another way, in an impure way, than the way in which it is declared by oneself.

original: upalabbhamānaṃ attānaṃ. Vañcetvāti palambhetvā. Tassa kuhakassa. Taṃ catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ
analyzed: upalabbhamānam attānam vañcetvā ati palambhetvā tassa kuhakassa tam catunnam paccayānaṃ
translated: “Having deceived” means having cheated. “That hypocrite” means that one who is not a true ascetic. “The use of the four requisites” means the use of the requisites of robe-material, almsfood, lodging, and medicine for support in sickness.

original: paribhuñjanaṃ. Parijānantīti tassa paṭipattiṃ paricchijja jānanti. Kārakoti sammāpaṭipattiyā🔽kattā, sammāpaṭipajjitāti attho.🔽Idanti liṅgavipallāsena vuttaṃ, ayanti attho. Dhammānudhammapaṭipadāti nibbānadhammassa
analyzed: paribhuñjanam parijānanti iti tassa paṭipattim paricchijja jānanti kārako ti sammā paṭipattiyā  kattā sammāpaṭipajjitā ti attho  idam ti liṅga vipallāsena vuttam ayam ti attho dhamma anudhamma paṭipadā ti nibbāna dhammassa
translated: “They know” means they know by discerning his practice. “The doer” means the one who does by right practice; the meaning is, the one who practices rightly.🔽“This” is said by way of a change in gender; the meaning is, “that.”

original: anucchavikatāya anudhammabhūtā paṭipadā. Paṭipakkhavidhamane asithilatāya daḷhā.
analyzed: anucchavika tāya anudhamma bhūtā paṭipadā paṭipakkha vidhamane a sithila tāya daḷhā
translated: “Practice in conformity with the True Idea” is practice that is in conformity with the True Idea of extinction because it is in accordance with it. It is “firm” because it is not slow in overcoming its opposite.

original: Bhāsitamattena ca savanamattena cāti ettha ca-saddo visesanivattiattho. Tena bhāsitassa🔽sutassa ca sammāpaṭipattivisesaṃ nivatteti. Lokapariyāyanti lokassa parividhamanaṃ
analyzed: bhāsita mattena ca savana mattena ca ati ettha ca saddo visesa nivatti attho tena bhāsitassa  sutassa ca sammā paṭipatti visesam nivatteti loka pariyāyanti lokassa parividhamanam
translated: And by mere speaking and mere hearing: the word “and” has the sense of “distinction.” Therefore it excludes the distinction of right practice of what is spoken and heard.

original: uppādanirodhavasena saṅkhārānaṃ parāvuttiṃ. Tenāha “saṅkhāralokassa udayabbaya”nti.
analyzed: uppāda nirodha vasena saṅkhārānam parāvuttim tena āha saṅkhāra lokassa udaya bbayanti
translated: The world’s round: the world’s distribution, the occurrence of formations by way of arising and passing away. Hence he said: “The rise and fall of the world of formations.”

original: Svāyamattho saccapaṭivedheneva hotīti āha “catusaccadhammañca aññāyā”ti. Evaṃ na🔽kubbantīti attani vijjamānampi guṇaṃ anāvīkaronto “yathā tumhe vadatha, evaṃ na kubbantī”ti
analyzed: svāyam attho sacca paṭivedhena iva hoti iti āha catu sacca dhammam ca evam na  kubbanti iti attani vijjamānam pi guṇam anāvīkarontaḥ yathā tumhe vadatha evam na kubbanti iti
translated: This meaning comes about only through the penetration of the truths. Therefore he said: “Having known the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths.”

original: avijjamānataṃ byākarotīti attho.
analyzed: a vijjamāna tam byākaroti iti
translated: Thus they do not: the meaning is that he declares non-existence by saying: “They do not act as you say,” without revealing the virtue that exists in himself.

original: Akārakamevāti dosaṃ akārakameva. Accayassa paṭiggaṇhanaṃ nāma adhivāsanaṃ, evaṃ so desakena desiyamāno tato vigato nāma hoti. Tenāha “paṭiggaṇhātūti khamatū”ti.
analyzed: akārakam eva ati dosam akārakam eva accayassa paṭiggaṇhanam nāma adhivāsanam evam saḥ desakena desiyamānaḥ tatas vigataḥ nāma hoti tena āha paṭiggaṇhātu uti khamatu iti
translated: Without making a reason: without making a reason for the fault. Acceptance of the apology is acquiescence. Thus it is said to be “gone away” when it is confessed in this way. Hence he said: “Let him accept it. Let him forgive.”

original: Sabhāvenāti sabhāvato. Ekasadisanti paresaṃ cittācāraṃ jānantampi ajānantehi saha
analyzed: sabhāvena ati sabhāvataḥ paresam citta ācāram jānantam pi a jānantehi saha
translated: “By nature”: by their individual natures. “As if they were the same”: as if they were the same as those who know the mental behavior of others but pretend not to know.

original: ekasadisaṃ karontā. Paratoti pacchā. Kathāya uppannāyāti “kassaccayā na vijjantī”tiādikathāya
analyzed: eka sadisam karontā paratas ti pacchā kathāya uppannāya ati kassaccayā na vijjanti iti ādi kathāya
translated: “Afterward”: later. “When a discussion has arisen”: when a discussion is going on such as “Whose fault is it that the light is not burning?”

original: pavattamānāya “tathāgatassa buddhassā”tiādinā buddhabalaṃ buddhānubhāvaṃ dīpetvā.
analyzed: pavattamānāya tathāgatassa buddhassa ati ādinā buddha balam buddha anubhāvam dīpetvā
translated: “The Buddha’s power, the Buddha’s majesty.”

original: Khamissāmīti accayadesanaṃ paṭiggaṇhissāmi. Tappaṭiggaho hi idha khamananti adhippetaṃ,
analyzed: khamissāmi iti accaya desanam paṭiggaṇhissāmi tad paṭiggahaḥ hi idha khamananti adhippetam
translated: “I will forgive”: I will accept the confession. For here “forgiveness” is intended to mean “acceptance of the confession.”

original: satthā pana sabbakālaṃ khamo eva.
analyzed: satthā pana sabbakālam khamaḥ eva
translated: But the Teacher is always forgiving.

original: Kopo antare citte etassāti kopantaro. Doso garu garukātabbo assāti dosagaru. “Paṭimuccatī”ti
analyzed: kopaḥ antare citte etassa ati kopa antaraḥ dosaḥ garu garu kātabbo assa ati dosa garu paṭimuccati iti
translated: “One who has no anger within”: one who has no anger in his mind. “One who is not heavy with anger”: one who is not heavy with anger, who should be treated with respect. The reading is “paṭimuñcati,”

original: vā pāṭho, ayameva attho. Accāyikakammanti sahasā anupadhāretvā kiriyā. No cidhāti
analyzed: vā pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ sahasā an upadhāretvā kiriyā no
translated: which has the same meaning. “An urgent duty”: an action done without reflection. “If I am not”:

original: no ce idha. Idhāti nipātamattaṃ. Apagataṃ apanītaṃ. Doso no ce siyā, tena pariyāyena
analyzed: no ce idha idha ati nipāta mattam apagatam apanītam dosaḥ no ce siyā tena pariyāyena
translated: if I am not. “Here”: this is merely a particle. “Anger has gone away, has been removed”: if anger has gone away. By this method,

original: yadi aparādho nāma na bhaveyyāti. Na sammeyyuṃ na vūpasameyyuṃ. Kusaloti anavajjo.
analyzed: yadi aparādhaḥ nāma na bhaveyyāti na sammeyyum na vūpasameyyum kusalaḥ iti anavajjaḥ
translated: If there were no such thing as an offence, they would not come together and would not make amends. ‘Skilled’ means ‘blameless’.🔽The two words ‘wise’ and ‘mindful’ refer to one who cuts off the round of rebirths. ‘Who is it that is always called wise?’ is the meaning. ‘Whose is the blame?’ is the question.

original: Dhīro satoti padadvayena vaṭṭachindaṃ āha. Ko niccameva paṇḍito nāmāti atthoti “kassaccayā”tiādikāya🔽pucchāgāthāya attho. Dīghamajjhimasaṃvaṇṇanāsu tathāgata-saddo vitthārato saṃvaṇṇitoti🔽āha “evamādīhi kāraṇehi tathāgatassā”ti. Buddhattādīhīti ādi-saddena “bodhetā pajāyā”tiādinā🔽niddese āgatakāraṇāni saṅgayhanti. Vimokkhaṃ vuccati ariyamaggo, tassa anto aggaphalaṃ,
analyzed: dhīraḥ sato iti pada dvayena vaṭṭachindam āha kaḥ niccam eva paṇḍitaḥ nāma ati attho ti kassaccayā ati ādikāya  pucchā gāthāya atthaḥ dīgha majjhima saṃvaṇṇanāsu tathāgata saddo vitthārato saṃvaṇṇito ti  āha evamādīhi kāraṇehi tathāgatassa ati buddhatta ādīhi iti ādi saddena pajāya atiādinā  niddese āgata kāraṇāni saṅgayhanti vimokkham vuccati ariya maggo tassa antaḥ agga phalam
translated: The word ‘thus’ refers to the explanation of the long and medium-length recitations. The word ‘thus’ refers to the explanation of the long and medium-length recitations.

original: tattha bhavā paṇṇatti, tassā vasena. Evaṃ buddhabalaṃ dīpeti. Idāni khittaṃ saṅkhepena🔽saṃharāpitaṃ hotīti dasseti.🔽Ujjhānasaññisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Saddhāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tattha bhavā paṇṇatti tassā vasena evam buddha balam dīpeti idāni khittam saṅkhepena 🔽saṃharāpitam hoti iti 🔽ujjhāna saññi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽saddhā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The word ‘thus’ refers to the explanation of the long and medium-length recitations. The word ‘thus’ refers to the explanation of the long and medium-length recitations. The word ‘thus’ refers to the explanation of the long and medium-length recitations. The word ‘thus’ refers to the explanation of the long and medium-length recitations.
