translated: Such as that: such as that, similar to the mere semblance of the virtue of one who has taken a wrong view.🔽Defiled: defiled by the defilement of craving.

original: Saṃkiliṭṭhameva taṇhāsaṃkilesaupakkiliṭṭhattā. Āsaṅkitaparisaṅkitantiādito samantatopi
analyzed: saṃkiliṭṭham eva samantataḥ pi
translated: With misgiving and doubt: misgiving and doubt from the beginning right round.

original: parehi saṅkitaṃ. Brahmacariyassa ādi ādibrahmacariyaṃ, tattha niyuttāti ādibrahmacariyikā,🔽maggabrahmacariyassa pubbabhāgapaṭipadāti attho. Tenāha “maggabrahmacariyassa ādibhūtā”ti.
analyzed: parehi saṅkitam brahmacariyassa ādi ādibrahmacariyam tattha niyuttā ati ādibrahmacariyikā  magga brahmacariyassa pubba bhāga paṭipadā ti attho tena āha magga brahmacariyassa ādi bhūtā ati
translated: Contaminated by others: contaminated by others from the beginning.🔽The beginning of the life of purity is the first life of purity. Those who are devoted to that are devoted to the first life of purity.

original: Pubbapadhānabhūtāti paṭhamārambhabhūtā.
analyzed: pubba padhāna bhūtā ati paṭhama ārambha bhūtā
translated: The meaning is that it is the practice that is the forerunner of the path life of purity. Hence it is said, “It is the beginning of the path life of purity” .

original: Tāyanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tāyana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The first effort: the first beginning.

original: 9. Candimasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: 9. The explanation of the Moon Discourse

original: 90. Vimāne gahite taṃnivāsīpi gahito hotīti vuttaṃ “candavimānavāsī devaputto”ti.
analyzed: vimāne gahite tad nivāsī ipi gahitaḥ hoti iti vuttam canda vimāna vāsī deva putto ti
translated: When the mansion is seized, the one who lives there is also seized. Thus it is said: “The devaputta who lives in the Moon Mansion.”

original: Sabbadhīti sabbasmā duggaṭṭhānā vippamuttosi bhagavā tvaṃ, tasmā mayhampi ito sambādhaṭṭhānato
analyzed: sabbadhi iti sabbasmā duggaṭṭhānā vippamuttaḥ asi bhagavā tvam tasmā mayham pi itas sambādha ṭṭhānato
translated: “In every way”: O Blessed One, you are free from all difficult situations. Therefore, please free me from this narrow place.

original: vippamokkhaṃ karohīti adhippāyo. Tenāha “tassa me saraṇaṃ bhavā”ti. Lokānukampakāti
analyzed: vippamokkham karohi iti adhippāyaḥ tena āha tassa me saraṇam bhavāti loka anukampakā ati
translated: This is the intention. Therefore it is said: “Be my refuge.” “Out of compassion for the world”:

original: sabbassa lokassa anuggahā, tasmā tuyhampi etassapi candassa. Tādisā evāti samānā
analyzed: sabbassa lokassa anuggahā tasmā tuyham pi etassa api candassa tādisā eva ati samānā
translated: Out of compassion for the whole world. Therefore, for you and for this moon. Being like this, being the same,

original: eva. Pamuñcasīti pamuñcittha. Tenāha “atītatthe vattamānavacana”nti.
analyzed: eva pamuñcasi iti tena āha atīta atthe vattamāna vacanam ti
translated: you release. Therefore it is said: “The present tense is used for the past.”

original: Candimasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: candima sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Moon Discourse is finished.

original: 10. Sūriyasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: 10. The explanation of the Sun Discourse

original: 91. Andhabhāvakaraṇeti lokassa andhakaraṇetipi apare. Tenāha “tamasī”ti. Virocatīti
analyzed: andha bhāva karaṇā iti apare tena āha tamasi iti virocati iti
translated: “Causing blindness”: making the world blind, some say. Therefore it is said: “Darkness.” “Shining”:

original: vijjotati. Kāmaṃ devaputtavasena paṭhamaṃ devatā uddhaṭā, rāhuno pana payogo tassa
analyzed: vijjotati kāmam deva putta vasena paṭhamam devatā uddhaṭā rāhuno pana payogo tassa
translated: it shines. Indeed, the deities were first mentioned as devaputtas, but the application of Rahu

original: vimāneti āha “maṇḍalīti maṇḍalasaṇṭhāno”ti. Vadati tadā mukhena gahitattā. Mukhena🔽gahaṇañcettha “gilī”ti adhippetaṃ, na ca ajjhoharaṇanti āha “gilīti vadatī”ti. Idāni🔽tassa mukhena gahaṇasamatthataṃ dassetuṃ “rāhussa hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sotiādi tassa
analyzed: vimāna iti āha maṇḍalī iti maṇḍala saṇṭhānā iti vadati tadā mukhena mukhena  gahaṇam ca ittha gili iti adhippetam na ca ajjhoharaṇam ti āha gili iti vadati iti idāni  tassa mukhena gahaṇa samattha tam dassetum rāhussa hi itiādi vuttam so tiādi tassa
translated: “He says ‘round’ ”: he says “round” because of the round shape. He says it because he has taken it into his mouth.

original: candimasūriyānaṃ gahaṇakāraṇadassanaṃ. Adhivatthā devatāti candimasūriyānaṃ paricārakadevatā.🔽Veganti javaṃ. So hi kenaci abhimukhaṃ atidunnivāro kammaniyāmasiddho. Matthakanti
analyzed: candima sūriyānam gahaṇa kāraṇa dassanam adhivatthā devatā ati candima sūriyānam paricāraka devatā  javam saḥ hi kenaci abhimukham ati dunnivāraḥ kamma niyāma siddho
translated: Here “swallowed” is what is intended, not “eaten”. Therefore it is said, “He says ‘swallowed’ ” . Now, in order to show that he is able to take it into his mouth, it is said, “For Rahu’s head is … ” . “He” , etc., shows the reason for his taking the moon and sun. “The deity that resides there” is the deity who attends on the moon and sun.

original: kaṇṭhassa uparimadesaṃ. Keci “sīsamatthakamevā”ti vadanti. Nikkhameyya vegassa tikkhasīghathāmabhāvato.
analyzed: kaṇṭhassa uparima desam keci sīsamatthakam eva ti vadanti nikkhameyya vegassa tikkha sīgha thāma bhāvato
translated: “Force” is speed. For that is irresistible when it is directed towards something, and it is established by the law of kamma. “Throat” is the upper part of the throat. Some say it is the top of the head. “It would come out” because of the sharpness and speed of the force.

original: Ākaḍḍhitvāti attano gamanadisābhimukhaṃ ākaḍḍhitvā. Nanti rāhuṃ. Uddhaṃ ullaṅghetukāmampi
analyzed: ākaḍḍhitvā iti gamana disa abhimukham ākaḍḍhitvā rāhum uddham ullaṅghetu kāmam pi
translated: “Having seized it” : having seized it facing in the direction of his own going. “He” : Rahu. Although he wants to lift it up,

original: onameyya. Padadvayenapi so mahāsarīro mahābalo, candimasūriyānaṃ pana gamanavego
analyzed: saḥ mahā sarīraḥ mahā balaḥ gamana vegaḥ
translated: he would not be able to do so. And by the two-foot measure he is of great body and great strength. But the speed of the sun and moon’s going

original: tena sabbathāpi dunnivāriyovāti dasseti. Vimānenāti candaggahe candavimānena, sūriyaggahe
analyzed: tena sabbathā api dunnivāriyā uvā ati dassa iti vimānena ati canda ggahe canda vimānena sūriya ggahe
translated: shows that he is hard to resist in every way. With the celestial palaces: with the celestial palace of the moon in the case of the moon’s appearance,

original: sūriyavimānena ubhinnampi vimānena saheva. Amāvāsiyañhi dve vimānāni yojanamattantaritāni
analyzed: sūriyavimānena vimānena saha iva dve vimānāni
translated: with the celestial palace of the sun in the case of the sun’s appearance. Both celestial palaces move together. On the new-moon day the two celestial palaces are a league apart,

original: hutvā saheva pavattanti. Yadi dvepi devaputtā sotāpattiphalaṃ pattā, atha kasmā sūriyasutte
analyzed: hutvā saha iva pavattanti yadi dve api deva puttā sotāpatti phalam pattā atha kasmā sūriyasutte
translated: and they move together. If the two gods have attained the fruit of stream-entry, then why is it said in the Discourse on the Sun

original: eva “pajaṃ mama”nti vuttaṃ, na candasutteti? “So ca kira na cirasseva tato cavitvā🔽aññattha nibbatto, aññā eva ca devatā tattha vasi, yasmiṃ candaggahe bhagavā taṃ
analyzed: eva vuttam na candasutta iti so ca kira na cirassa iva tatas cavitvā  aññattha nibbattaḥ aññāḥ eva ca devatā tattha vasi yasmin canda ggahe bhagavā tam
translated: “my people” and not in the Discourse on the Moon? “It seems that he died not long after that,

original: gāthaṃ abhāsi, na tathā sūriyo, aparabhāge pana tatthapi kālena kālaṃ rāhuggaho hotī”ti vadanti.
analyzed: gātham abhāsi na tathā sūriyaḥ aparabhāge pana tattha api kālena kālam rāhu gaho hoti iti vadanti
translated: and another god was reborn there. The god in whose appearance the Blessed One spoke that verse was not the same as the god in the sun’s appearance. Later on, however, there is a lunar eclipse there from time to time.”

original: Sūriyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sūriya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Discourse on the Sun is finished.

original: Paṭhamavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first chapter is finished.

original: 2. Anāthapiṇḍikavaggo
analyzed: anāthapiṇḍika vaggo
translated: The Chapter on Anāthapiṇḍika

original: 1. Candimasasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The explanation of the Discourse on the Moon and the Sun

original: 92. Pabbatataṭā sandamāno tathārūpo nadīnivattanapadesopi sambādhaṭṭhānatāya kaccho
analyzed: pabbata taṭā sandamānaḥ tathārūpaḥ nadī nivattana padesaḥ api sambādha ṭṭhāna tāya kaccho
translated: A mountain torrent is a place where a river turns back upon itself and is confined within a narrow space, and so it is a difficult place to cross.🔽Thus it is said to be “in a mountain cleft.”

original: viyāti āha “pabbatakacchepī”ti. Paṭipakkhadūrībhāvena seṭṭhaṭṭhena ca eko udetīti
analyzed: viyā ti āha pabbata kacchepī iti paṭipakkha dūrībhāvena seṭṭha aṭṭhena ca ekaḥ udeti iti
translated: It rises up alone in the sense of being the best by reason of its being far removed from its opposite.🔽Thus “alone” is the same as “one-pointedness.”🔽Those who are devoted to that are “one-pointed” here.

original: ekodi, ekaggatā. Tasmiṃ yogato ekaggacittā idha ekodī. Paṭipakkhato attānaṃ nipayanti
analyzed: ekodi ekagga tā tasmin yogataḥ ekagga cittāḥ idha ekodī paṭipakkhataḥ attānam nipayanti
translated: They are “vigilant” because they ward off and purify themselves of their opposite.🔽Thus he says, “those who are concentrated” and so on.

original: visodhentīti nipakā, paññavanto. Tenāha “ekaggacittā cevā”tiādi. Kāyādibhedaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: visodhenti iti paññavanto tena āha ekagga cittā ca iva atiādi kāya ādi bhedam ārammaṇam
translated: They “remember” the object classified as body, and so on, by means of the heightened mindfulness.🔽Thus they are “mindful.” Thus he says, “those who possess mindfulness.”

original: sātisayāya satiyā sarantīti satā. Tenāha “satimanto”ti. Sotthiṃ gamissantīti yathāvuttapadese
analyzed: sa atisayāya satiyā saranti iti satā tena āha satimantaḥ ti sotthim gamissanti iti yathāvutta padese
translated: They will “go in safety” in the sense that they will proceed without mishap in the path that has been described.

original: magā sotthimanupaddavena vattissanti, evaṃ jhānalābhino sotthiṃ kilesehi anupaddutā
analyzed: magāḥ sotthim anupaddavena vattissanti evam jhāna lābhinaḥ sotthim kilesehi anupaddutā
translated: In the same way, those who have attained jhāna will proceed without mishap by the defilements.

original: vattissanti. Ayaṃ kira devaputto brahmaloke nibbānasaññī, tasmā evamāha. Bhagavā
analyzed: vattissanti ayam kira deva puttaḥ brahma loke nibbāna saññī tasmai evam āha bhagavā
translated: It seems that this devaputta had the idea of nibbāna in the Brahmā-world. That is why he said this.

original: “ayaṃ devaputto anibbānagāmī samāno nibbānagāmisaññī, handassa nibbānagāmino dassemī”ti
analyzed: ayam deva putto a nibbāna gāmī samānaḥ nibbāna gāmi saññī handassa nibbāna gāminaḥ dassemi iti
translated: “This god, though not bound for extinction, thinks he is bound for extinction. Let me show him the way to extinction.”

original: dutiyaṃ gāthamāha. Catunnaṃ oghānaṃ, saṃsāramahoghasseva vā paratīrabhāvato paratīranti🔽nibbānaṃ. Ambuni jāto ambujo, maccho. Suttajālaṃ chinditvā macchā viya kilesajālaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam gātham āha catunnam oghānam saṃsāra mahā oghassa iva vā para tīra bhāvataḥ  nibbānam ambuni jātaḥ ambujaḥ macchaḥ sutta jālam chinditvā macchā viya kilesa jālam
translated: The second stanza was spoken by the Exalted One. The “other shore” is Nibbāna, because it is beyond the four floods or the great flood of saṃsāra.

original: bhinditvā gamissantīti.
analyzed: bhinditvā gamissanti iti
translated: The “fish” is the one born in the water. Having cut through the net of the discourses, they will go forth, having broken the net of defilements.

original: Candimasasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: candimasa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Moon and Sun Discourse is finished.

original: 2. Veṇḍusuttavaṇṇanā🔽93. Payirupāsiyāti payirupāsahetu. Sikkhantīti tissopi sikkhā sikkhanti. Siṭṭhipadeti
analyzed: veṇḍu sutta vaṇṇanā  payirupāsiyā ti payirupāsa hetu sikkhanti iti tissaḥ api sikkhā sikkhanti siṭṭhi pade iti
translated: The Veṇḍu Discourse

original: kilesānaṃ sāsanato vaṭṭadukkhaparittāsanato ca siṭṭhisaññite yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjitabbato
analyzed: kilesānam sāsanataḥ vaṭṭa dukkha paritta āsanataḥ ca siṭṭhi saññite yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjitabbato
translated: “Paying homage” means for the purpose of paying homage. “They train” means they train in the three trainings. “In the instruction” means in the stage of training, which is called the true Dhamma, because it instructs in the abandoning of defilements and in the protection from the suffering of the round.

original: pade, saddhammeti attho. Tenāha “anusiṭṭhipade”ti. Tattha anusiṭṭhīti saddhammo.
analyzed: pade saddhamma iti atthaḥ tena āha anusiṭṭhi pade iti tattha anusiṭṭhī iti saddhammaḥ
translated: This is the meaning. Therefore it is said: “in the instruction.” Herein, the instruction is the true Dhamma.

original: Kāleti yuttapattakāle. Appamādonāma samathavipassanābhāvanā.
analyzed: kāle ti yutta patta kāle appamādaḥ nāma samatha vipassanā bhāvanā
translated: “In due course” means at the time when they are ready. “In heedfulness” means in the development of serenity and insight.

original: Veṇḍusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: veṇḍu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Veṇḍu Discourse is finished.

original: 3. Dīghalaṭṭhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dīghalaṭṭhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 3. The Discussion of the Long-Rib-Trait Thread

original: 94. Tatheva paññāyīti dīghalaṭṭhitveva paññāyi, tathāsamaññā eva ahosi.
analyzed: tathā iva paññāyi iti paññāyi tathāsamaññā eva ahosi
translated: He was known as Long-Rib, and that was how he came to be known.

original: Dīghalaṭṭhisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dīghalaṭṭhi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Discussion of the Long-Rib Thread is ended.

original: 4. Nandanasuttavaṇṇanā🔽95. Natthi etassa āvaṭṭaṃ āvaraṇanti anāvaṭaṃ. Rukkho vā pabbato vāti sattānaṃ pakaticakkhussa
analyzed: nandana sutta vaṇṇanā  na atthi etassa āvaṭṭam āvaraṇanti anāvaṭam rukkhaḥ vā pabbataḥ vā ati sattānam pakati cakkhussa
translated: The Discussion of the Thread about Nandana

original: āvaraṇabhūto rukkho viya pabbato viya ca abhibhavituṃ samattho ñeyyāvaraṇo natthi.
analyzed: āvaraṇa bhūtaḥ rukkhaḥ viya pabbataḥ viya ca abhibhavitum samatthaḥ ñeyya āvaraṇaḥ natthi
translated: It has no turning, no obstruction, thus it is unturned. It is not possible to overpower it by any obstruction to what is to be known, as a tree or a rock is possible to overpower by a tree or a rock that is a physical obstruction to the eye’s seeing of creatures.

original: Kathaṃvidhanti kathaṃsaṇṭhitaṃ, kathaṃpakāraṃ vā. Dukkhanti vaṭṭadukkhaṃ.
analyzed: kathaṃvidhanti kathaṃsaṇṭhitam kathaṃpakāram vā dukkhanti vaṭṭa dukkham
translated: What kind? What sort, what kind of structure? Suffering: the suffering of the round.

original: Nandanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nandana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Discussion of the Thread about Nandana is ended.

original: 5. Candanasuttavaṇṇanā🔽96. Heṭṭhāti kāmabhave. Tattha hi paribbhamantassa patiṭṭhā dullabhā yebhuyyena tattha
analyzed: candana sutta vaṇṇanā  heṭṭhā ati kāma bhave tattha hi paribbhamantassa patiṭṭhā dullabhā yebhuyyena tattha
translated: The Discussion of the Thread about Chanda

original: sattā nimuggā eva honti, tasmā heṭṭhā appatiṭṭho saṃsāro. Uparīti mahaggatabhave.
analyzed: sattāḥ nimuggāḥ eva honti tasmā heṭṭhā appatiṭṭhaḥ saṃsāraḥ upari iti mahaggata bhave
translated: Below: in the sense-desire world. For one who wanders there finds no footing, and for the most part creatures there are submerged. That is why the round has no footing below. Above: in the exalted world.

original: Tattha hi nibbattassa nibbānaṃ āruhituṃ ālambanā dullabhā, jhānābhiratiyā tattheva
analyzed: tattha hi nibbattassa nibbānam āruhitum ālambanā dullabhā jhāna abhiratiyā tattha eva
translated: For it is hard to find a support for climbing out of it, and the delight in jhāna is strong in them,

original: nikanti tesaṃ balavatī hoti, tasmā upari anālambano saṃsāro. Pesitattoti nibbānaṃ
analyzed: nikanti tesam balavatī hoti tasmā upari anālambanaḥ saṃsāro pesita tto ti nibbānam
translated: so their rebirth is in the same place. That is why there is no support for the round of rebirths above. ‘With the mind bent on that’: with the mind bent on Nibbāna.

original: pati pesitacitto. Tayo kammābhisaṅkhārāti puññābhisaṅkhārādayo tayo abhisaṅkhārā.
analyzed: tayo kamma abhisaṅkhārā ati puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādayo tayo abhisaṅkhārā
translated: ‘Three kinds of formations’: the three kinds of formations consisting in merit, etc.

original: Tena “nandīpubbako kammabhavo”ti vatvā “nandiṃ janetvā”ti vutto. Kāmasaññāsīsena🔽kāmacchandassa gahaṇaṃ, kāmacchandapamukhāni ca orambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni gahitānīti
analyzed: tena nandī pubbakaḥ kamma bhavaḥ ti vatvā nandim janetvā iti vuttaḥ kāma saññā sīsena  kāmacchandassa gahaṇam kāmacchanda pamukhāni ca orambhāgiya saṃyojanāni gahitāni iti
translated: So after saying ‘with the delight as condition, becoming,’ he said ‘having generated the delight.’🔽The inclusion of sense desire is by the heading of perception of sensual desires.🔽And the five lower fetters are included by the inclusion of sense desire, which is why he said ‘by the inclusion of perception of sensual desires, the five lower fetters.’

original: āha “kāmasaññāgahaṇena pañcorambhāgiyasaṃyojanānī”ti. Rūpabhavo rūpaṃ bhavapadalopena.
analyzed: āha kāma saññā gahaṇena pañca orambhāgiya saṃyojanāni iti rūpa bhavaḥ rūpam bhava pada lopena
translated: ‘The becoming of the fine-material sphere’ is the fine-material sphere of becoming, omitting the word ‘sphere.’🔽And by the inclusion of that, the rest of the spheres of becoming are included.

original: Rūpabhavaggahaṇena cettha sesabhavassapi gahaṇaṃ. Tassa saṃyojanaggahaṇena pañca
analyzed: rūpa bhava ggahaṇena ca ittha sesa bhavassa api gahaṇam tassa saṃyojana ggahaṇena pañca
translated: And by the inclusion of the fetters, the five higher fetters are included.

original: uddhambhāgiyasaṃyojanāni gahitāni. Mahogheti saṃsāramahoghe. Tesanti kāmabhavādīnaṃ
analyzed: uddhambhāgiya saṃyojanāni mahā ogha iti saṃsāra mahā oghe
translated: ‘The great flood of the round’: the great flood of the round of rebirths. ‘Those’: of the becoming of the sensual-desire sphere, etc.

original: gahaṇena bhavabhāvena tadekalakkhaṇatāya. Arūpabhavo gahito lakkhaṇahāranayena. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: gahaṇena bhava bhāvena tad eka lakkhaṇa tāya arūpa bhavaḥ gahitaḥ lakkhaṇa hāra nayena sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: by the act of grasping and by the existence of becoming, because they have that as their individual essence. The existence of the immaterial world is included by the method of individual essence. The rest is quite clear.

original: Candanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: candana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Candana Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Vāsudattasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vāsudatta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Vāsudatta Sutta

original: 97. Chaṭṭhaṃ heṭṭhā devatāsaṃyuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: chaṭṭham heṭṭhā devatā saṃyutta vaṇṇanāyam vutta ttham eva
translated: The meaning of the sixth sutta is the same as that of the Devata Samyutta given below.

original: Vāsudattasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vāsudatta sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Vāsudatta Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Subrahmasuttavaṇṇanā🔽98. Subrahmāti tassa devaputtassa nāmaṃ. Tassa satthu santikūpasaṅkamanassa kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: subrahmā ati tassa deva puttassa nāmam tassa satthu santikūpa saṅkamanassa kāraṇam
translated: The commentary on the Subrahma Sutta

original: dassento “so kirā”tiādimāha. Tadeva sokaṃ tassa devaputtassa aṭṭhuppatti. Accharāsaṅghaparivutoti
analyzed: dassento so kirāti ādim āha tat eva sokam tassa deva puttassa aṭṭhuppatti accharā saṅgha parivuto ti
translated: Subrahma is the name of that deity. Showing the reason for his coming to that teacher, he says, “He is said to have been a pupil of the teacher.” That very grief was the cause for that deity’s coming. Surrounded by a group of celestial nymphs means

original: sahassamattena accharāsaṅghena parivuto. Nandanakīḷikanti nandanavanakīḷikaṃ. Hatthaṃ
analyzed: sahassa mattena accharā saṅghena parivutaḥ nandana kīḷikam ti nandana vana kīḷikam hattham
translated: surrounded by a group of a thousand celestial nymphs. In the Nandana Grove means in the Nandana Grove. When he extended his hand means

original: āgacchatīti hatthagayhupago hoti. Ganthentīti ettha mālāveṭhanampi khiḍḍāpasutatāyāti
analyzed: āgacchati iti hattha gayhupagaḥ hoti ganthenti iti ettha mālā veṭhanam pi khiḍḍa apasuta tāya āti
translated: when he extended his hand. They bound him means they bound him with a garland.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aññathā pupphāniyeva tāya tāya cittassa vasena mālābhāvena hatthaṃ upagacchantīti.🔽Upacchedakakammavasenāti tasmiṃ devaloke āyusese sati eva tassa pana upaghātakassa
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam aññathā pupphāniyā iva tāya tāya cittassa vasena mālā bhāvena hattham upagacchanti iti  upacchedaka kamma vasena ati tasmin deva loke āyu sese sati eva tassa pana upaghātakassa
translated: It should be seen thus. Otherwise it would be necessary to say that the flowers themselves, by virtue of the various states of consciousness, come into the hand as a garland.🔽By the power of the kamma that interrupts: while there is still a remainder of life in that divine world, by the power of that evil kamma which has found an opportunity to strike him.

original: laddhokāsassa pāpakammassa vasena. “Pahāro”ti divasassa tatiyo bhāgo vuccati, tasmā
analyzed: laddha ukāsassa pāpa kammassa vasena pahāro ti divasassa tatiyaḥ bhāgo vuccati tasmā
translated: “A blow” is said to be a third of a day, therefore

original: ekappahārenevāti ekavelāyamevāti attho.
analyzed: eka ppahārena iva ati eka velāyam eva ati attho
translated: in one blow: the meaning is, in one period.

original: Piyavatthukasokenāti piyavatthunimittakena sokena. Ruppamānoti pīḷiyamāno. Sattame
analyzed: piya vatthuka sokena ati piya vatthu nimittakena sokena ruppamānaḥ ti pīḷiyamānaḥ sattame
translated: By the grief that has its source in a dear object: by the grief that has its source in a dear object. He was afflicted: he was tormented.

original: divaseti manussagaṇanāya sattame divase. Tatthevāti tasmiṃyeva niraye nibbattitabbaṃ
analyzed: divase iti manussa gaṇanāya sattame divase tattha iva ati tasmin yeva niraye nibbattitabbam
translated: On the seventh day: on the seventh day by human reckoning.🔽There itself: because he had previously done that evil kamma together with them, he was reborn there itself in that hell.

original: iminā tāhi ca saheva pubbe tassa pāpakammassa katattā. Ruppīti cittasantāsaṃ āpajji.🔽Niddhamitunti nīharituṃ apanetuṃ. Satthu santikaṃ gantvāti tāhi pañcasatāhi accharāhi
analyzed: iminā tāhi ca saha eva pubbe tassa pāpa kammassa kata ttā citta santāsam āpajji  niddhamitum ti nīharitum apanetum satthu santikam gantvā ati tāhi pañca satāhi accharāhi
translated: He was afflicted: he was overwhelmed with mental anguish.🔽To be expelled: to be removed, to be taken away.

original: saddhiṃ bhagavato santikaṃ gantvā.
analyzed: saddhim bhagavataḥ santikam gantvā
translated: Having gone into the presence of the Teacher: having gone into the presence of the Blessed One together with those five hundred celestial nymphs.

original: Idanti attano cittaṃ dasseti āsannapaccakkhabhāvato. Niccanti sadā. Svāyaṃ niccattho
analyzed: idam ti attanaḥ cittam dasseti āsanna paccakkha bhāvataḥ niccanti sadā svāyam niccattho
translated: This meaning of “permanence” should be taken by way of intention.

original: adhippāyavasena gahetabboti tattha pahātabbaṃ gahetabbañca dassento “devaloke”tiādimāha.
analyzed: adhippāya vasena gahetabbaḥ ti tattha pahātabbam gahetabbañca dassentaḥ deva loka itiādim āha
translated: Therefore, showing what should be abandoned and what should be taken up, he said, “In the deva world” , etc.

original: Na gahetabbo hetupavattito pubbe tassa utrāsassa abhāvato. Tesūti dukkhesu. Tāni
analyzed: na gahetabbaḥ hetu pavattitaḥ pubbe tassa utrāsassa abhāvataḥ tesu uti dukkhesu tāni
translated: What should not be taken up is the fear that arose earlier, because it arose by way of cause. “Among these” : among the sufferings.🔽For these are called “difficulties” in the verse because they are to be done by way of cause and condition.

original: hi hetupaccayehi kattabbato gāthāyaṃ “kicchesū”ti vuttāni. Kicchesūti vā kicchanimittaṃ.
analyzed: hi hetu paccayehi kattabbataḥ gāthā ayam kicchesu iti vuttāni kicchesu iti vā kiccha nimittam
translated: Or, “difficulties” is a reason for difficulty.

original: Yāsañhi payogavipattīnaṃ vasenassa tāni dukkhāni uppajjeyyuṃ, taṃnimittanti attho.
analyzed: yāsam hi payoga vipattīnam vasena assa tāni dukkhāni uppajjeyyum taṃnimittam ti attho
translated: For the meaning is that these sufferings would arise for him by way of the failure of his efforts.

original: Tā hi assa payogavipattiyo gativipattiyo satthu santikaṃ upagamanena hāyeyyuṃ. Nibbattānaṃ
analyzed: tāḥ hi assa payoga vipattiyaḥ gati vipattiyaḥ satthu santikam upagamanena hāyeyyum nibbattānam
translated: For his failures of effort and his failures of destiny would be removed by his going into the presence of the Teacher.🔽“Seen” : seen by way of what has arisen.🔽Among the sufferings that have arisen.

original: diṭṭhānīti nibbattānaṃ vasena diṭṭhāni dukkhāni. Tesu ca dukkhesu. Sabbattha nimittatthe
analyzed: diṭṭhāni iti nibbattānam vasena diṭṭhāni dukkhāni tesu ca dukkhesu sabbattha nimitta atthe
translated: And among those sufferings. Everywhere the locative case🔽is in the sense of reason.

original: bhummaṃ. Ḍayhamāno viya cittasantāpena.
analyzed: bhummam ḍayhamānaḥ viya citta santāpena
translated: As if burning with the fever of his mind.

original: Cattāripi saccāni bujjhati paṭivijjhatīti bodhi, satiādidhammasāmaggī, tasmā bojjhā
analyzed: cattāri pi saccāni bujjhati paṭivijjhati iti bodhi sati ādi dhamma sāmaggī tasmai bojjhā
translated: The word bodhi is derived from the verb budh, to awaken, to penetrate. It is the fire of understanding consisting of mindfulness, etc., and so on.🔽The word bodhi is derived from the verb budh, to awaken, to penetrate. It is the fire of understanding consisting of mindfulness, etc., and so on.

original: bodhito. Sā pana bodhi bhāvanākāreneva pavattati, aññatrasaddayogena ca “bojjhā”ti🔽nissakkavacananti tadatthaṃ dassento muñcitvāpadaṃ apekkhitvā “bojjhaṅgabhāvana”nti🔽āha. Tapoguṇanti dhutadhammamāha. So hi taṇhāloluppassa tapanato tapo, sayaṃ guṇasabhāvattā🔽guṇasannissayato ca guṇanti. Tenāha “dhutaṅgasaṅkhātaṃ tapoguṇa”nti. Sabbe saṅkhāragatā
analyzed: bodhitaḥ sā pana bodhi bhāvanā ākārena iva pavattati aññatra sadda yogena ca  nissakka vacanam ti tad attham dassento muñcitvā āpadam apekkhitvā bojjhaṅga bhāvanam ti  āha tapaḥ guṇam ti dhuta dhammam āha saḥ hi taṇhā loluppassa tapanataḥ tapo sayam guṇa sabhāvattā  guṇa sannissayato ca guṇanti tena āha dhutaṅga saṅkhātam tapaḥ guṇanti sabbe saṅkhāra gatā
translated: The word bodhi is derived from the verb budh, to awaken, to penetrate. original: pana paṭipattikkamaṃ dassetuṃ “indriyasaṃvare hī”tiādimāha. Nippariyāyato maggapariyāpannā
analyzed: pana paṭipatti kkamam dassetum indriya saṃvare hi iti ādim āha nippariyāyataḥ magga pariyāpannā
translated: The word bodhi is derived from the verb budh, to awaken, to penetrate. It is the fire

original: eva bojjhaṅgāti āha “sahavipassanāya bojjhaṅge”ti. Tassāti tathābhāvena tassa yogino.
analyzed: eva bojjhaṅgā ti āha saha vipassanāya bojjhaṅgā iti tassa ati tathābhāvena tassa yogino
translated: “His” : of the meditator of that kind.

original: Yasmā devaputtassa satthā taṃ gāthaṃ vatvā upari ca saccāni pakāsesi, tasmā vuttaṃ
analyzed: yasmai devaputtassa satthā tam gātham vatvā upari ca saccāni pakāsesi tasmai vuttam
translated: Since the Teacher spoke this verse to the godling and then revealed the Truths to him, it was said:

original: “bhagavā catusaccavasena desanaṃ vinivattesī”ti. Devaputto sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahīti
analyzed: bhagavā catu sacca vasena desanam vinivattesi iti devaputto sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi iti
translated: “The Blessed One concluded his teaching with the four noble Truths.” The godling was established in the fruit of stream-entry.

original: kāmaṃ tasseva visesādhigamo idhāgato, pañcasatamattāhi pana accharāhi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale
analyzed: kāmam tassa iva visesa adhigamaḥ idha āgataḥ pañca sata mattāhi pana accharāhi saddhim sotāpatti phale
translated: Although it was his own attainment that was referred to here, it should be understood that he was established in the fruit of stream-entry together with five hundred celestial nymphs.

original: patiṭṭhahīti veditabbaṃ. Tenāha mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ “so desanāpariyosāne
analyzed: patiṭṭhahi iti veditabbam tena āha mahāsati paṭṭhāna sutta vaṇṇanā ayam saḥ desanā pariyosāne
translated: Therefore it is said in the commentary to the Maha-satipatthana Sutta: “At the conclusion of the teaching

original: pañcahi accharāsatehi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya taṃ sampattiṃ thāvaraṃ katvā
analyzed: pañcahi accharāsatehi saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya tam sampattim thāvaram katvā
translated: he was established in the fruit of stream-entry together with five hundred celestial nymphs. Making that attainment firm,

original: devalokameva agamāsī”ti.
analyzed: deva lokam eva agamāsi iti
translated: he went to the deva world.”

original: Subrahmasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: subrahma sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary to the Subrahma Sutta is finished.

original: 8. Kakudhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kakudha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Kakudha Sutta

original: 99. “Nandāmī”ti vutte nandī nāma pabbajitassa malanti codetukāmo devaputto “nandasī”ti
analyzed: nandāmi iti vutte nandī nāma pabbajitassa malanti codetu kāmo devaputto nandasi iti
translated: When “I delight” is said, the godling who wanted to reproach the monk named Nanda said “You delight” .

original: pucchi. Athassa bhagavā taṃ paṭikkhipanto “kiṃ laddhā”ti? Āha. Tena “tayā mama adhippetanandiyā
analyzed: pucchi athassa bhagavā tam paṭikkhipantaḥ kim laddhā iti āha tena tayā mama adhippeta nandiyā
translated: asked him. Then the Blessed One, in order to refute him, said: “What have you gained?”🔽🔽

original: idha paccayo eva natthi, kuto sā nandī”ti dasseti. Tenāha “tuṭṭhi nāmā”tiādi. Atha🔽devaputto nandiyā asati sokena bhavitabbaṃ, soko ca pabbajitassa malanti codento
analyzed: idha paccayaḥ eva natthi kutas sā nandī iti dasseti tena āha tuṭṭhi nāma atiādi atha  devaputto nandiyāḥ asati sokena bhavitabbam sokaḥ ca pabbajitassa codento
translated: He asked. Then the Blessed One, in order to refute him, said: “What have you gained?” By that he shows: “Here there is no condition for the delight that you have chosen for me. How can there be that delight?” Therefore he said: “Delight is called … ” Then

original: āha “tena hi, samaṇa, socasī”ti. Bhagavā tampi paṭikkhipanto “kiṃ jīyitthā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: āha tena hi samaṇa socasi iti bhagavā tam pi paṭikkhipantaḥ kim jīyittha atiādim āha
translated: the devaputta, in order to accuse the recluse of being sorrowful because of the non-existence of delight, said: “Well then, recluse, you are sorrowful.” The Blessed One, in order to refute that, said: “What have you lost?”

original: Kiṃ maṃ jinātīti attho?
analyzed: kim mama jināti iti attho
translated: What have I lost? – is the meaning.

original: Yadi te nandisokā na santi hāsavatthuno lābhassa jāniyā ca abhāvato, ekavihārino🔽pana aratiyā bhavitabbanti āha – “kacci taṃ ekamāsīnaṃ, aratī nābhikīratī”ti. Tasmimpi
analyzed: yadi te nandi sokāḥ na santi hāsa vatthunaḥ lābhassa jāniyā ca abhāvataḥ eka vihārino  pana aratiyā bhavitabbanti āha kacci tam ekam āsīnam aratī na abhikīrati iti tasmim pi
translated: If you have neither delight nor sorrow, because of the non-existence of the cause for laughter and the non-existence of the cause for weeping, then, as a recluse who lives alone, you should be discontented.

original: bhagavatā paṭikkhitte atha nesampi nandisokāratīnaṃ abhāve kāraṇaṃ pucchanto “kathaṃ
analyzed: bhagavatā paṭikkhitte atha nesam pi nandi soka aratīnam abhāve kāraṇam pucchanto katham
translated: Therefore he said: “But surely, as you sit alone, discontent does not overpower you?” When that was refuted by the Blessed One, then, in order to ask the reason for the non-existence of delight, sorrow and discontent, he said: “How is it, recluse, that you are neither sorrowful nor discontented?”

original: tva”nti gāthamāha? Athassa bhagavā taṃ kāraṇaṃ pavedento “aghajātassā”ti gāthamāha.
analyzed: tvanti gātham āha atha assa bhagavā tam kāraṇam pavedentaḥ agha jātassa ati gātham āha
translated: and why did you say this verse? ” Then the Blessed One, explaining the reason for that, said the verse “Aghajātassā” .

original: Tattha aghajātassāti aghe jātassa. Tenāha “vaṭṭadukkhe ṭhitassā”ti. Jātataṇhassa
analyzed: tattha agha jātassa ati aghe jātassa tena āha vaṭṭa dukkhe ṭhitassa ati jāta taṇhassa
translated: Herein, aghajātassā means born in the burden . Therefore it is said: “Standing in the suffering of the round of rebirths” .🔽For one who has not abandoned craving, the suffering of the round of rebirths has come about, because the cause has not been abandoned.

original: appahīnataṇhassa vaṭṭadukkhaṃ āgatameva kāraṇassa appahīnattā. Tasseva hi kāraṇassa
analyzed: appahīna taṇhassa vaṭṭa dukkham āgatam eva kāraṇassa a pahīna ttā tassa iva hi kāraṇassa
translated: For the non-abandonment of that very cause,

original: appahīnataṃ dassento “dukkhī sukhaṃ patthayatīti hi vutta”nti āha. Dukkhappavattiyā
analyzed: appahīna tam dassentaḥ dukkhī sukham patthayati iti hi vuttan ti āha dukkha ppavattiyā
translated: it is said: “The suffering one seeks happiness” . By the occurrence of suffering,

original: sāpi taṇhāppavatti tena dassitā. Itītiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ nigamanavasena dasseti.
analyzed: sā api taṇhā appavatti tena dassitā iti iti ādinā vuttam eva attham nigamana vasena dasseti
translated: the occurrence of craving is also shown. “Thus” and so forth, he shows the meaning already stated by way of conclusion.

original: Kakudhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Uttarasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kakudha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  uttara sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Kakudha Sutta is finished.🔽The Uttarā Sutta

original: 100. Navamanti uttarasuttaṃ heṭṭhā devatāsaṃyuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: navamanti uttara suttam heṭṭhā devatā saṃyutta vaṇṇanāyam vuttattham eva
translated: The ninth, the Uttarā Sutta, has the same meaning as that stated in the commentary on the Devata Samyutta below.

original: Uttarasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uttara sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Uttarā Sutta is finished.

original: 10. Anāthapiṇḍikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anāthapiṇḍika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Anāthapiṇḍika Sutta

original: 101. Dasame kāmaṃ devatāsaṃyuttepi “idaṃ hi taṃ jetavana”ntiādinā imā eva gāthā āgatā.
analyzed: dasame kāmam devatā saṃyutte api idam hi tam jetavana nti ādinā imāḥ eva gāthāḥ āgatā
translated: In the tenth, in the Kāma Devata Samyutta, these same verses beginning with “This is that Jeta’s Grove” are found.

original: Tattha “aññatarā devatā”ti nidānaṃ āropitaṃ. Heṭṭhā āgatanayattā eva hi potthakesu🔽na likhitaṃ, idha pana devaputtasaṃyutte “anāthapiṇḍiko devaputto”ti nidāne nigame🔽ca āgataṃ, tattha devaputtena satthu vuttappakāraguṇapavedanavasena vuttaṃ. Satthā🔽pana bhikkhūnaṃ tamatthaṃ pavedento “aññataro devaputto”ti āha. Tathā pavedane pana
analyzed: tattha aññatarā devatā iti nidānam āropitam heṭṭhā āgata naya ttā eva hi potthakesu  na likhitam idha pana devaputta saṃyutte anāthapiṇḍikaḥ devaputto ti nidāne nigame  ca āgatam tattha devaputtena satthu vutta ppakāra guṇa pavedana vasena vuttam satthā  pana bhikkhūnam tam attham pavedentaḥ aññataraḥ deva putto ti āha tathā pavedane pana
translated: Here the words “a certain deity” are added to the nidāna. For in the books it is not written in the way it is given below. But here in the Devaputta Samyutta the nidāna is given as “the devaputta Anāthapiṇḍika,” and in the Nigama Samyutta it is given as “the devaputta Nigrodha.” There the devaputta spoke in terms of the qualities of the Teacher as he had experienced them. But the Teacher,🔽when he told the bhikkhus what had happened, said: “A certain devaputta.”🔽And when he told it in this way,

original: kāraṇaṃ dassento “ānandattherassā”tiādimāha. Anumānabuddhiyāti anumānañāṇassa. Ānubhāvappakāsanatthanti baladīpanatthaṃ.🔽Anāthapiṇḍikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Dutiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽3. Nānātitthiyavaggo🔽1. Sivasuttavaṇṇanā🔽102. Tatiyavaggassa paṭhamanti tatiyavagge paṭhamasuttaṃ. Vuttatthameva heṭṭhā satullapakāyikavagge paṭhamasutte.🔽Sivasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāraṇam dassentaḥ ānanda therassa ati ādim āha anumāna buddhiyā iti anumāna ñāṇassa ānubhāva ppakāsana ttham ti bala dīpana ttham 🔽anāthapiṇḍika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽dutiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽nānā titthiya vaggaḥ 🔽      🔽tatiya vaggassa paṭhamanti tatiya vagge paṭhama suttam vutta ttham eva heṭṭhā satulla pakāyika vagge paṭhama sutte 🔽siva sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Herein, “a certain deity” is the introduction. For it is not written in the books in the way it occurs below. But here it is given in the introduction to the Devaputta Samyutta as “the devaputta Anāthapiṇḍika” and in the Nidāna Samyutta. There it is said by the devaputta in terms of the qualities of the Master as he remembered them. But the Master said “a certain devaputta” when he announced the matter to the bhikkhus. And in announcing it in this way, he said “of the Elder Ānanda” in order to show the reason for doing so. In the knowledge of inference : in the knowledge of inference. In order to show his power : in order to show his strength. The commentary on the Anathapindika Sutta is ended. The commentary on the second vagga is ended. The vagga of the adherents of other sects The Sīvaka Sutta The first sutta of the third vagga. Its meaning has already been given in the first sutta of the Satullapakāyika Vagga. The commentary on the Sīvaka Sutta is ended.

original: 2. Khemasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: khema sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 2. The explanation of the Khema Sutta🔽. Even from the very beginning: even from the time of aging and death, etc.

original: 103. Paṭhamaṃyevāti jarāmaraṇādibhāvato pageva. Balavacintanaṃ cintetīti yathā sākaṭiko🔽ajānitvā visame magge sakaṭaṃ pājento akkhe chinne patikātuṃ avisahanto dukkhī dummano
analyzed: balava cintanam cintā iti iti yathā  a jānitvā visame magge sakaṭam pājentaḥ akkhe chinne patikātum a visahantaḥ dukkhī dummanaḥ
translated: He thinks a strong thought: just as a cart-driver,🔽not knowing the uneven road, when the axle breaks, is unable to continue, and thinks a strong thought, suffers, and is disconsolate,

original: balavacintanaṃ cinteti, mahantaṃ cittasantāpaṃ pāpuṇāti, evaṃ adhammavādī maccumukhaṃ
analyzed: balava cintanam cintā iti mahantam citta santāpam pāpuṇāti evam adhamma vādī maccu mukham
translated: so the proponent of unrighteousness, having fallen into the mouth of death,

original: patto balavacittasantāpaṃ pāpuṇāti, tasmā dhammacariyāya nappamajjitabbanti.
analyzed: pattaḥ balava citta santāpam pāpuṇāti tasmā dhamma cariyāya na ppamajjitabbanti
translated: suffers a strong mental anguish. Therefore, one should not be negligent in righteous conduct.

original: Khemasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khema sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Khema Sutta is finished.

original: 3. Serīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: serī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Serisaka Sutta

original: 104. Yaṃ dānaṃ demīti yaṃ deyyadhammaṃ parassa demi. Tassa pati hutvāti tabbisayaṃ
analyzed: yam dānam demi iti yam deyya dhammam parassa demi tassa pati hutvā ati tad visayam
translated: . What gift I give: whatever gift, whatever thing to be given, I give to another.

original: lobhaṃ suṭṭhu abhibhavanto tassa adhipati hutvā demi tena anākaḍḍhanīyattā. “Na dāso
analyzed: lobham suṭṭhu abhibhavantaḥ tassa adhipati hutvā demi tena an ākaḍḍhanīya ttā na dāsaḥ
translated: Having become his master: having well overcome the greed that has him as its object, having become his lord, I give, because he cannot be led by me.🔽“He is neither a slave nor a friend” is said in order to show both of these by way of the positive and negative concomitance.

original: na sahāyo”ti vatvā tadubhayaṃ anvayato byatirekato dassetuṃ “yo hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na sahāyaḥ iti vatvā tat ubhayam anvayataḥ byatirekataḥ dassetum yaḥ hi itiādi vuttam
translated: “For he who” is said.

original: Dāso hutvā deti taṇhāya dāsabyassa upagatattā. Sahāyo hutvā deti tassa piyabhāvāvissajjanato.
analyzed: dāsaḥ hutvā deti taṇhāya dāsa byassa upagata ttā sahāyaḥ hutvā deti tassa piya bhāva avissajjanato
translated: He gives as a slave, because he has come under the slavery of craving. He gives as a friend, because he gives up his dear state.

original: Sāmī hutvā deti taṇhādāsabyato attānaṃ mocetvā abhibhuyya pavattanato. Sāmiparibhogasadisā
analyzed: sāmī hutvā deti taṇhā dāsabyataḥ attānam mocetvā abhibhuyya pavattanataḥ sāmi paribhoga sadisā
translated: He gives as a master, because he gives after freeing himself from the slavery of craving and after mastering it.

original: hetassāyaṃ pavattatīti.
analyzed: ha itassa ayam pavattati iti
translated: This is the reason why he gives as a master.

original: Atha vā yo dānasīlatāya dāyako puggalo, so dāne pavattibhedena dānadāso dānasahāyo🔽dānapatīti tippakāro hotīti dasseti. Tadassa tippakārataṃ vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “yo
analyzed: atha vā yaḥ dāna sīla tāya dāyako puggalo so dāne pavatti bhedena dāna dāsaḥ dāna sahāyo  dānapati iti tippakāraḥ hoti iti dasseti tat assa tippakāratam vibhajitvā dassetum yaḥ
translated: Or else, the person who gives by means of generosity and virtue is threefold: he gives as a slave of generosity, as a friend of generosity, and as a master of generosity.🔽This is how the author shows the threefold nature of the giver. In order to analyze and show his threefold nature, the following is said:

original: hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Dātabbaṭṭhena dānaṃ, annapānādi. Tattha yaṃ attanā paribhuñjati
analyzed: hi itiādi vuttam dātabba ṭṭhena dānam anna pāna ādi tattha yam attanā paribhuñjati
translated: “He gives as a slave of generosity, etc.” Generosity is that which is to be given, such as food, drink, etc. Therein, that which he himself enjoys,

original: taṇhādhipannatāya, tassa vase vattanato dāso viya hoti. Yaṃ paresaṃ dīyati, tatthapi
analyzed: taṇhā adhipanna tāya tassa vase vattanataḥ dāsaḥ viya hoti yam paresam dīyati tattha api
translated: because he is overcome by craving, he gives as a slave, because he acts under its sway. That which he gives to others,

original: annapānasāmaññena idaṃ vuttaṃ “dānasaṅkhātassa deyyadhammassa dāso hutvā detī”ti.
analyzed: anna pāna sāmaññena idam vuttam dāna saṅkhātassa deyya dhammassa dāsaḥ hutvā deti iti
translated: in that case also, this is said: “He gives as a slave of the gift to be given, which is called generosity, and which is similar to food and drink.”

original: Sahāyo hutvā deti attanā paribhuñjitabbassa paresaṃ dātabbassa ca samasamaṭṭhapanena.
analyzed: sahāyaḥ hutvā deti attanā paribhuñjitabbassa paresam dātabbassa ca sama samaṭṭhapanena
translated: He gives as a friend by giving others what is equal to what he himself consumes.

original: Pati hutvā deti sayaṃ deyyadhammassa vase avattitvā tassa attano vase vattāpanato.
analyzed: pati hutvā deti sayam deyya dhammassa vase tassa attanaḥ vase
translated: He gives as a slave by giving others what is under his own control, by making himself subject to them.

original: Aparo nayo – yo attanā paṇītaṃ paribhuñjitvā paresaṃ nihīnaṃ deti, so dānadāso nāma
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ yaḥ attanā paṇītam paribhuñjitvā paresam nihīnam deti saḥ dānadāsaḥ nāma
translated: Another method: he who himself consumes what is choice and gives others what is inferior is called a “slave of giving.”

original: tannimittanihīnabhāvāpattito. Yo yādisaṃ attanā paribhuñjati, tādisameva paresaṃ
analyzed: tad nimitta nihīna bhāva āpattitaḥ yaḥ yādisam attanā paribhuñjati tādisam eva paresam
translated: Because he has fallen into an inferior state by that cause. He who gives others what is equal to what he himself consumes

original: deti, so dānasahāyo nāma tannimittanihīnādhikabhāvavissajjanena sadisabhāvāpattito.
analyzed: deti saḥ dāna sahāyaḥ nāma tad nimitta nihīna adhika bhāva vissajjanena sadisa bhāva āpattitaḥ
translated: is called a “friend in giving” because he has fallen into an equal state by that cause.

original: Yo attanā nihīnaṃ paribhuñjitvā paresaṃ paṇītaṃ deti, so dānapati nāma tannimittaseṭṭhabhāvappattito.
analyzed: yaḥ attanā nihīnam paribhuñjitvā paresam paṇītam deti saḥ dānapati nāma tad nimitta seṭṭha bhāva ppattitaḥ
translated: He who himself consumes what is inferior and gives others what is choice is called a “master of giving” because he has attained an excellent state by that cause.

original: Kammasarikkhako hi vipāko, tasmā devaputto “dānapatī”ti vadanto “ahaṃ tādiso ahosi”nti dasseti.
analyzed: kamma sarikkhakaḥ hi vipākaḥ tasmā deva putto dānapatī iti vadantaḥ aham tādisaḥ ahosin ti dasseti
translated: For the result is similar to the cause. Therefore, the devaputta, saying “I was a master of giving,” shows that he was such.

original: “Catūsu dvāresu dānaṃ dīyitthā”ti pāḷiyaṃ saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vitthāretvā dassetuṃ
analyzed: catūsu dvāresu dānam dīyittha ati pāḷiyam saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vitthāretvā dassetum
translated: The meaning stated in brief in the text, “He gave gifts at the four city gates,” is set out in detail in the following passage.

original: “tassa kirā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Dānanti yiṭṭhaṃ, tañca kho sabbasādhāraṇavasena katanti
analyzed: tassa kirāti ādi vuttam dānanti tat ca kho sabba sādhāraṇa vasena katanti
translated: “It is said that he” : he gave gifts, and he gave them to all alike.🔽Therefore it is said: “to ascetics, brahmans, paupers, wayfarers, beggars.”🔽“Those who had gone forth” : those who had gone forth in any way.

original: āha “samaṇa …pe… yācakāna”nti. Pabbajjūpagatāti yaṃ kiñci pabbajjaṃ upagatā. Bhovādinoti
analyzed: āha samaṇa pe yācakānam ti pabbajjūpagatā ati yam kiñci pabbajjam upagatāḥ bho vādinaḥ iti
translated: “Sir-addressees” : he spoke to brahmans merely because of their birth.🔽He did not get it because the world was then devoid of a Buddha.

original: jātimattabrāhmaṇe vadati. Nālattha buddhasuññattā tadā lokassa. Duggatāti dukkhajīvikakappakā
analyzed: jātimatta brāhmaṇe vadati na alattha buddha suññattā tadā lokassa duggatā ati dukkha jīvika kappakā
translated: “Poor people” : those who had a miserable livelihood.

original: kasiravuttikā. Tenāha “daliddamanussā”ti. Kasivāṇijjādijīvikaṃ anuṭṭhātuṃ asamatthā
analyzed: kasira vuttikā tena āha dalidda manussā ati kasi vāṇijja ādi jīvikam anuṭṭhātum asamatthā
translated: “Paupers” : those who were unable to work at agriculture, trade, etc.🔽Here “paupers” is meant.

original: idha “kapaṇā”ti adhippetāti āha “kāṇakuṇiādayo”ti. Pathāvinoti addhikā. Vanibbakāti
analyzed: idha kapaṇā ati adhippetā iti āha kāṇa kuṇi ādayaḥ ti pathāvinaḥ ti addhikāḥ vanibbakā ati
translated: “Cripples, hunchbacks, etc.” : “Pathāvino” means “addhikā” .

original: dāyakānaṃ guṇakittanakammaphalakittanavasena yācakā seyyathāpi naggādayo. Tenāha
analyzed: dāyakānam guṇa kittana kamma phala kittana vasena seyyathā api nagga ādayaḥ tena āha
translated: “Beggars” : those who beg by praising the virtues of donors and the fruits of giving, like the naggas, etc.🔽Therefore it is said:

original: “iṭṭhaṃ dinna”ntiādi. Pasatamattanti vīhitaṇḍulādivasena vuttaṃ. Sarāvamattanti yāgubhattādivasena.
analyzed: iṭṭham dinna ntiādi pasatamattanti vīhi taṇḍula ādi vasena vuttam sarāvamattanti yāgu bhatta ādi vasena
translated: “The desirable was given” and so on. “Just a mouthful” is said with reference to cooked rice, etc., that is, just a mouthful of cooked rice, etc. “Just a ladleful” is said with reference to curry, rice, etc., that is, just a ladleful of curry, rice, etc.

original: Yathā gāmalābho gāme uppajjanako āyalābho, evaṃ tattha dvāralābhoti āha “tattha uppajjanakasatasahasse”ti.🔽Mahantataraṃ dānaṃ adaṃsu aññassapi dhanassa viniyogaṃ gatattā. Taṃ sandhāyāti taṃ
analyzed: yathā gāma lābhaḥ gāme uppajjanakaḥ āya lābhaḥ evam tattha dvāra lābhaḥ iti āha tattha uppajjanaka sata sahassa iti  mahantataram dānam adaṃsu aññassa api dhanassa viniyogam gatattā tam sandhāya ati tam
translated: Just as the village-gain is the gain that arises in the village, so too the gate-gain is the gain that arises there.🔽They gave a greater gift, because it was used for the purpose of another’s wealth. “With reference to that” means with reference to that greater gift that was given.

original: mahantataraṃ dānaṃ kataṃ sandhāya. Rañño hi tattha dānaṃ itthāgārassa dānena mahatā
analyzed: mahantataram dānam katam sandhāya raññaḥ hi tattha dānam itthāgārassa dānena mahatā
translated: For the king’s gift there was the gift of the harem, which was greater than his gift.

original: abhibhūtaṃ viya paṭinivattaṃ hotīti āha “paṭinivattī”ti. Kocīti bhummatthe paccattavacanaṃ.
analyzed: abhibhūtam viya paṭinivattam hoti iti āha paṭinivatti iti koci iti bhumma atthe paccatta vacanam
translated: It was as if it was overcome and turned back. Therefore it is said, “it turned back.” “Kocī” is a first-person singular pronoun in the locative case.

original: Tenāha “katthacī”ti. Anekavassasahassāyukakāle tassa uppannattā asītivassasahassāni
analyzed: tena āha katthaci iti aneka vassa sahassa āyuka kāle tassa uppanna ttā asīti vassa sahassāni
translated: Therefore it is said, “katthaci.” Because it arose at a time when people had a life-span of many thousands of years, for eighty-four thousand years

original: so rājā dānamadāsīti.
analyzed: saḥ rājā dānam adāsi iti
translated: that king gave a gift.

original: Serīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: serī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Serī Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Ghaṭīkārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ghaṭīkāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Ghaṭīkāra Sutta

original: 105. Catutthaṃ heṭṭhā devatāsaṃyuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: catuttham heṭṭhā devatā saṃyutta vaṇṇanāyam vuttattham eva
translated: The fourth sutta is of the same meaning as stated in the commentary on the Devatāsaṃyutta below.

original: Ghaṭīkārasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ghaṭīkāra sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Ghaṭīkāra Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Jantusuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Jantu Sutta

original: 106. Ye vinaye apakataññuno saṃkilesikesu vodāniyesu dhammesu na kusalā yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: ye vinaye apakata ññunaḥ saṃkilesikesu vodāniyesu dhammesu na kusalāḥ yam kiñci
translated: Those who are ungrateful in the Discipline, who are unskilled in the defilement and cleansing of things, who do anything, who are full of remorse,

original: na kārino vippaṭisārabahulā. Tesaṃ anuppannañca uddhaccaṃ uppajjati, uppannañca bhiyyobhāvaṃ
analyzed: na kārinaḥ vippaṭisāra bahulā tesam anuppannam ca uddhaccam uppajjati uppannam ca bhiyyobhāvam
translated: for whom agitation that has not arisen comes to arise and that has arisen increases and expands—

original: vepullaṃ āpajjatīti āha “akappiye kappiyasaññitāya…pe… uddhaccapakatikā”ti. Sārābhāvena
analyzed: vepullam āpajjati iti āha akappiye kappiya saññita āyape uddhacca pakatikā ati sāra abhāvena
translated: he said, “Because of the perception of what is not allowable as allowable … they are of agitated temperament.”

original: tucchattā ca naḷo viyāti naḷo, mānoti āha “unnaḷāti uggatanaḷā”ti. Tenāha “uṭṭhitatucchamānā”ti.
analyzed: tuccha ttā ca naḷaḥ viyāti naḷaḥ māno ti āha unnaḷā ati uggata naḷā iti tena āha uṭṭhita tuccha mānā iti
translated: But because of the state of being empty, like a reed, it is a reed; a “conceit” is a māna. He said, “They are conceited” , meaning “They are conceited with a conceited reed.” Hence he said, “They are conceited with an empty conceit.”

original: Māno hi seyyassa seyyoti sadisoti ca pavattiyā visesato tuccho. Cāpallenāti capalabhāvena,🔽taṇhāloluppenāti attho. Mukhakharāti mukhena pharusā, pharusavādinoti attho. Vikiṇṇavācāti
analyzed: mānaḥ hi seyyassa seyyo ti sadisaḥ ti ca pavattiyā visesataḥ tucchaḥ cāpallena ati capala bhāvena  taṇhā loluppena ti atthaḥ mukha kharā ati mukhena pharusā pharusa vādino ti atthaḥ vikiṇṇa vācā iti
translated: For conceit is empty in the sense of being distinguished as “better” and “equal.”🔽“Because of fickleness” means because of the state of being fickle,🔽the meaning being because of craving and greed. “They are harsh-spoken” means they are harsh in their speech; the meaning is, they are abusive. “They are loose-spoken” means

original: visaṭavacanā, samphappalāpatāya apariyantavacanā. Tenāha “asaṃyatavacanā”tiādi. Caṇḍasote
analyzed: visaṭa vacanā apariyanta vacanā tena āha asaṃyata vacanā ati ādi caṇḍa sote
translated: they are loose in their speech; they are unrestrained in their speech because of gossip. Hence he said, “They are unrestrained in speech,” and so on. “They are in a dangerous place” means

original: baddhanāvāsadisāti etena anavaṭṭhitakiriyataṃ dasseti. Yena samannāgatā sattā ekasmiṃ
analyzed: baddha nāvāsa disā iti etena anavaṭṭhita kiriya tam dasseti yena samannāgatā sattā ekasmin
translated: ‘Like a tied-up boat’ shows that they are not fixed in their actions. Those who possess this quality

original: ṭhāne ṭhātuṃ vā nisīdituṃ vā na sakkonti, ito cito ca vicaranti. Anavaṭṭhitacittāti
analyzed: ṭhāne ṭhātum vā nisīditum vā na sakkonti itas citas ca vicaranti anavaṭṭhita cittā ati
translated: cannot stay or sit in one place but wander about here and there. ‘Their minds are not fixed’

original: ekasmiṃ ārammaṇe na avaṭṭhitacittā. Vivaṭaindriyāti asaṃvutacakkhādiindriyā.
analyzed: ekasmin ārammaṇe na avaṭṭhita cittā vivaṭa aindriyā ati asaṃvuta cakkha ādi indriyā
translated: means that their minds are not fixed on one object. ‘Their faculties are uncontrolled’ means that their eye-faculty, etc., are uncontrolled.

original: Guṇakathāya saddhiṃ kathiyamāno nigguṇassa aguṇo pākaṭo hoti jātimaṇisamīpe ṭhitassa
analyzed: guṇa kathāya saddhim kathiyamānaḥ nigguṇassa aguṇaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti jāti maṇi samīpe ṭhitassa
translated: When a discussion is held about good qualities, the bad qualities of one who has no good qualities become evident,

original: viya kācamaṇino doso. Sukhajīvinoti sukhe ṭhitā. Yathā dāyakānaṃ subharaṃ hoti, evaṃ
analyzed: kācamaṇinaḥ dosaḥ sukha jīvinaḥ ti sukhe ṭhitāḥ yathā dāyakānam subharam evam
translated: just as the defects of a glass gem become evident when it is placed next to a genuine gem. ‘They live comfortably’ means that they are established in comfort. Just as it is easy for donors,

original: sukhena akicchena pavattajīvikā. Tenāha “pubbe bhikkhū”tiādi.
analyzed: sukhena akicchena pavatta jīvikā tena āha pubbe bhikkhu iti ādi
translated: so they live their lives easily and without difficulty. Therefore it is said, ‘Formerly the bhikkhus’ and so on.

original: Attano rucivasena gāmakiccaṃ netīti gāmaṇi, te pana hīḷento vadati “gāmaṇikā”ti.
analyzed: attanaḥ ruci vasena gāma kiccam na iti iti gāmaṇi te pana hīḷentaḥ vadati gāmaṇikā ati
translated: A ‘village headman’ is one who leads the village affairs according to his own wishes. But he says ‘village headmen’ in the plural.

original: Vissajjetvāti sativossaggavasena vissajjetvā kilesamucchāyāti mahicchāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: vissajjetvā iti sati vossagga vasena vissajjetvā kilesa mucchāya ati mahicchā saṅkhātāya
translated: ‘Having given up’: having given up by means of the relinquishment of mindfulness. ‘Greedy for sensual pleasures’: having great desires.

original: taṇhāmucchāya. Sīlavantānaṃyeva hi duppaṭipattiṃ sandhāya devaputto vadati. Vattabbayuttakeyevāti
analyzed: taṇhām ucchāya sīlavantānam yeva hi duppaṭipattim sandhāya deva puttaḥ vadati
translated: Worthy of being told:

original: ovādena mayā anuggahetabbameva. Chaḍḍitakāti pariccattā ācariyupajjhāyādīhi. Tato
analyzed: ovādena mayā anuggahetabbam eva chaḍḍitakā ati pariccattāḥ ācariya upajjhāya ādīhi tatas
translated: Worthy of being helped by me with advice. Abandoned: given up by teachers, preceptors, etc.🔽Hence helpless, without support. Dead: departed, deceased.

original: eva anāthā appatiṭṭhā. Petāti vigatajīvitā matā. Yathā petā, tatheva honti attahitāsamatthatāya
analyzed: eva anāthāḥ appatiṭṭhā petā ati vigata jīvitāḥ matāḥ yathā petā tathā iva honti atta hita a samattha tāya
translated: Just as the dead are, so are they, because they are unable to benefit themselves

original: viññūnaṃ jigucchitabbatāya ca.
analyzed: viññūnam jigucchitabba tāya ca
translated: and because they are despised by the wise.

original: Jantusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jantu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Jantu Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Rohitassasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rohitassa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Rohitassa Sutta🔽In one place: in one place thought of as the end of the world.

original: 107. Ekokāseti cakkavāḷassa pariyantasaññite ekasmiṃ okāse. Bhummanti “yatthā”ti
analyzed: eka okāse ti cakkavāḷassa pariyanta saññite ekasmin okāse yattha ati
translated: In the place where: this is a locative case,

original: idaṃ bhummavacanaṃ, sāmaññato vuttampi “so lokassa anto”ti vacanato visiṭṭhavisayameva
analyzed: idam bhumma vacanam sāmaññataḥ vuttam pi so lokassa anto ti vacanataḥ visiṭṭha visayam eva
translated: though it is stated in a general way. But because of the words “That is the end of the world,”🔽it has a specific meaning.

original: hoti. “Na jāyati na mīyatī”ti vatvā puna “na cavati na upapajjatī”ti kasmā vuttanti
analyzed: hoti na jāyati na mīyati iti vatvā puna na cavati na upapajjati iti kasmā vuttanti
translated: After saying “is not born, does not die,” why is it said again, “does not pass away, does not reappear”?🔽He says, “This is taken … in the sense of successive becoming.”

original: āha “idaṃ aparāparaṃ…pe… gahita”nti. Padagamanenāti padasā gamanena. Saṅkhāralokassa
analyzed: āha idam pada gamanena ati gamanena saṅkhāra lokassa
translated: By walking: by walking on foot.

original: antaṃ sandhāya vadati upari saccāni pakāsetukāmo. Saṅkhāralokassa hi anto nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: antam sandhāya vadati upari saccāni pakāsetu kāmo saṅkhāra lokassa hi antaḥ nibbānam
translated: He speaks with reference to the end, desiring to reveal the higher truths, for Nibbāna is the end of the world of formations.

original: Daḷhaṃ thiraṃ dhanu etassāti daḷhadhanvā. So eva daḷhadhammoti vutto. Tenāha “daḷhadhanū”ti.
analyzed: daḷham thiram dhanu etassa ati daḷhadhanvā so eva daḷhadhammo ti vutto tena āha daḷhadhanu iti
translated: He is a firm bowman because his bow is firm and strong. He is called a firm bowman because of his firm bow. Therefore it is said: “A firm bowman.”

original: Uttamappamāṇenāti sahassathāmappamāṇena. Dhanusippasikkhitatāya dhanuggaho, na dhanuggahamattenāti
analyzed: uttama ppamāṇena ati sahassa thāma ppamāṇena dhanu sippa sikkhita tāya dhanuggahaḥ na dhanuggaha mattena ati
translated: With the highest measure: with the measure of a thousand. He is a skilled archer because he is trained in archery, not merely because he is an archer.

original: āha “dhanuggahoti dhanuācariyo”ti. “Dhanuggaho”ti vatvā “sikkhito”ti vutte dhanusikkhāya
analyzed: āha dhanuggaho ti dhanu ācariyo ti dhanuggaho ti vatvā sikkhito ti vutte dhanu sikkhāya
translated: Therefore it is said: “A skilled archer is a teacher of archery.” When it is said “a skilled archer,” it is understood that he is trained in archery.

original: sikkhitoti viññāyati, sikkhā ca ettake kāle samatthassa ukkaṃsagato hotīti āha “dasa
analyzed: sikkhito ti viññāyati sikkhā ca ettake kāle samatthassa ukkaṃsa gataḥ hoti iti āha dasa
translated: And the training is completed in a certain time. Therefore it is said: “trained for ten or twelve years.”

original: dvādasa vassāni dhanusippaṃ sikkhito”ti. Usabhappamāṇepīti vīsatiyaṭṭhiyo usabhaṃ,
analyzed: dvādasa vassāni dhanu sippam sikkhito ti usabha ppamāṇe pi iti usabham
translated: In the space of an ox: an ox has twenty-four cubits.

original: tasmiṃ usabhappamāṇe padese. Vālagganti vāḷakoṭiṃ. Katahatthoti paricitahattho. Katasarakkhepoti
analyzed: tasmin usabha ppamāṇe padese vā ālagganti vāḷakoṭim kata hattho ti paricita hattho kata sarakkhepo ti
translated: In that space of an ox, at the end of the arrow’s trajectory. He is a man of practiced hand: he has practiced his hand.

original: vivaṭasarakkhepapadesadassanavasena sarakkhepakatāvī. Tenāha “dassitasippo”ti. “Katasippo”ti
analyzed: vivaṭa sara khepa padesa dassana vasena sara kkhepaka tāvī tena āha dassita sippā iti kata sippā iti
translated: He is a master of the art of teaching, in the sense of showing the way to one who asks, “How is Nibbāna entered?” Thus it is said of him: “He is a master of the art of teaching.”🔽Some read “katasippo” .

original: keci. Asanti etenāti asanaṃ, kaṇḍo. Tālacchāyanti tālacchādiṃ, sā pana ratanamattā,
analyzed: keci asanti etena ati asanam tālacchādim sā pana ratana mattā
translated: A seat is a place to sit on, a mat. A palm-leaf sunshade is a sunshade made of palm leaves. But that is only a simile;

original: vidatthicaturaṅgulā vā.🔽Puratthimasamuddāti ekasmiṃ cakkavāḷe puratthimasamuddā. Samuddasīsena puratthimacakkavāḷamukhavaṭṭiṃ🔽vadati. Pacchimasamuddoti etthāpi eseva nayo. Nippapañcatanti adandhakāritaṃ. Sampatteti🔽tādisena javena gacchantena sampatte. Anotatteti etthāpi “sampatte”ti padaṃ ānetvā🔽sambandho, tathā “nāgalatādantakaṭṭhaṃ khāditvā”ti etthāpi. Tadāti yadā so lokantagavesako
analyzed: vidatthi catur aṅgulāḥ vā  puratthima samuddā iti ekasmin cakkavāḷe puratthima samuddā samudda sīsena puratthima cakkavāḷa mukha vaṭṭim  vadati pacchima samuddaḥ ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ adandhakāritam sampattā iti  tādisena javena gacchantena sampatte ettha api sampatte iti padam ānetvā  tathā nāga latā danta kaṭṭham khāditvā ati ettha api tadā ati yadā saḥ
translated: it is a sunshade of any kind.

original: ahosi, tadā. Dīghāyukakāloti anekavassasahassāyukakālo. Cakkavāḷalokassāti sāmaññavasena
analyzed: ahosi tadā dīgha āyuka kālo ti aneka vassa sahassa āyuka kālo cakkavāḷa lokassa ati sāmañña vasena
translated: The eastern ocean: the eastern ocean in one world-sphere. By the eastern ocean he means the eastern rim of the world-sphere. The western ocean: the same method applies here. Without confusion: without causing confusion. Reached: reached by going with such speed. Anotatta: here too the word “reached” should be supplied. So too in the case of “having eaten the trunk of the nāḷa tree.” Then: when he was searching for the end of the world. The time of long life: the time when the life span was many thousands of years. The world-sphere: the world-sphere in general,

original: ekavacanaṃ, cakkavāḷalokanti attho. Imasmiṃyeva cakkavāḷe nibbatti pubbaparicariyasiddhāya🔽nikantiyā. Sasaññimhi samanaketi na rūpadhammamattake, atha kho pañcakkhandhasamudāyeti🔽dasseti. Samitapāpoti samucchinnasaṃkilesadhammo.🔽Rohitassasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽7-8. Nandasuttanandivisālasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: eka vacanam cakkavāḷa lokanti atthaḥ imasmin yeva cakkavāḷe nibbatti pubba paricariya siddhāya  nikantiyā sa saññimhi samanake iti na rūpa dhamma mattake atha kho pañca kkhandha samudāya iti  dasseti samita pāpo ti samucchinna saṃkilesa dhammo  rohitassa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: the singular number refers to the world-sphere of one world-sphere. The word “here” shows that the rebirth is in this very world-sphere, not elsewhere. The phrase “in the world of men” shows that the rebirth is not among the gods but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not among the gods but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. The phrase “in the human world” shows that the rebirth is not in the hells, etc., but among human beings. original: 108-109. Nandasuttavisālasuttāni sattamaaṭṭhamāni heṭṭhā saṃvaṇṇitarūpattā vuttatthāneva.🔽Nandasuttanandivisālasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Susimasuttavaṇṇanā🔽110. Tuyhampi noti tuyhampi nu, nu-saddo pucchāyaṃ, tasmā vaṇṇaṃ kathetukāmo pucchatīti🔽adhippāyo. Na vaṭṭatīti na yujjati, kathitoti kathetuṃ āraddho, tenāha “matthakaṃ
analyzed: nanda sutta visāla suttāni sattama aṭṭhamāni heṭṭhā saṃvaṇṇita rūpattā vutta tthānā iva 🔽nanda sutta nandivisāla sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽susima sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽tuyham pi no ti tuyham pi nu nu saddo puccha ayam tasmā vaṇṇam kathetu kāmo pucchati iti 🔽adhippāyaḥ na vaṭṭati iti na yujjati kathitaḥ iti kathetum āraddhaḥ tena āha matthakam
translated: The meaning is: in this very world-sphere. The word “here” is used to show that the Buddha’s birth was in this world-sphere, not elsewhere, and that it was due to the fulfilment of his previous practice of the perfections. The words “in the world of men” show that he was born not in the Brahma-world, etc., but in the human world, and that he was not born in the form of a material or immaterial being, but in the form of a being consisting of the five aggregates. The words “in the land of the Magadhans” show that he was born in the Magadha country, not elsewhere. The words “in the village of Senāni” show that he was born in the village of Senāni, not in the city of Rājagaha. The words “in the family of the Sakyas” show that he was born in the Sakya family, not in any other family. The words “in the family of Suddhodana” show that he was born in the family of Suddhodana, not in the family of any other Sakyan. The words “in the family of the Buddha” show that he was born in the family of the Buddha, not in the family of any other teacher. The words “in the family of the Conqueror” show that he was born in the family of the Conqueror, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Enlightened One” show that he was born in the family of the Enlightened One, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Sambuddha” show that he was born in the family of the Sambuddha, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Buddha” show that he was born in the family of the Buddha, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Enlightened One” show that he was born in the family of the Enlightened One, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Sambuddha” show that he was born in the family of the Sambuddha, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Buddha” show that he was born in the family of the Buddha, not in the family of any other person. The words “in the family of the Enlightened One”

original: na pāpuṇātī”ti. Tameva matthakāpāpuṇanaṃ dassetuṃ “so hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Satisampajaññāyogato
analyzed: na pāpuṇāti iti tam eva matthaka a pāpuṇanam dassetum saḥ hi itiādi vuttam sati sampajaññā yogato
translated: and he does not reach the end of it. ” To show that very reaching of the end, it is said: “He would not reach the end of it. ”

original: gorūpasīlo, mūḷho khalitapañño, gorūpassa viya sīlaṃ etassāti hi gorūpasīlo. Sabhāgo🔽ekarūpacittatāya. Ariyānaṃ sabhāgatā nāma guṇavantavasenāti āha “aññamaññassa guṇesu
analyzed: go rūpa sīlaḥ mūḷhaḥ khalita paññaḥ go rūpassa viya sīlam etassa ati hi go rūpa sīlaḥ sabhāgaḥ  eka rūpa citta tāya ariyānam sabhāgatā nāma guṇavanta vasena iti āha aññamaññassa guṇesu
translated: He is a person of virtue like a cow, confused, his wisdom defective. He has virtue like a cow, thus he is a person of virtue like a cow.🔽A person of the same kind,

original: pasīditvā”ti. Soḷasavidhaṃ paññanti mahāpaññādikā cha, nava anupubbavihārasamāpattipaññā,
analyzed: pasīditvā ti soḷasavidham paññanti mahāpaññā ādikā cha nava anupubba vihāra samāpatti paññā
translated: because of the same form and mind. The similarity of the Noble Ones is said to be by way of possessing good qualities. Therefore it is said: “Having confidence in each other’s good qualities. ” The sixteen kinds of wisdom are the six beginning with great wisdom, the nine kinds of wisdom of the successive attainments,

original: āsavakkhayapaññāti imaṃ soḷasavidhaṃ paññaṃ. Tesaṭṭhi sāvakasādhāraṇañāṇānipi ettheva
analyzed: āsava khaya paññā ti imam soḷasavidham paññam sāvaka sādhāraṇa ñāṇāni pi ettha iva
translated: and the wisdom of the destruction of the cankers. These sixteen kinds of wisdom. The thirty-eight kinds of knowledge shared by disciples also

original: saṅgahaṃ samosaraṇaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: saṅgaham samosaraṇam gacchanti
translated: come under this heading.

original: Ānandāti theraṃ āha. Ācāroti cārittasīlamāha. Gocaroti gocarasampatti. Vihāroti samāpattivihāro.
analyzed: ānandāti theram āha ācāro ti cāritta sīlam āha gocaro ti gocara sampatti vihāro ti samāpatti vihāro
translated: He said to the Elder Ānanda: “Ānanda” means the Elder. “Practice” means the virtue of conduct. “Range” means the excellence of the range. “Abiding” means the abiding of attainment.

original: Abhikkamotiādinā iriyāpathavihāraṃ. Tuyhampīti pi-saddena bhagavatā attānaṃ ādiṃ
analyzed: abhikkama iti ādinā iriyāpatha vihāram tuyham pi iti pi saddena bhagavatā attānam ādiṃ
translated: “Going forth” and so on refer to the abiding of deportment. “Yours too” means by the word “too” the Blessed One made himself the beginning.

original: katvā tadaññesaṃ viññūnaṃ sabbesaṃ therassa ruccanasabhāvo dīpitoti dassento “mayhaṃ
analyzed: katvā tad aññesam viññūnam sabbesam therassa ruccana sabhāvaḥ dīpitaḥ iti dassentaḥ mayham
translated: and he said “It is pleasing to me” in order to show that the approval of all the other wise Elders was implied in the Elder’s approval.

original: ruccatī”tiādimāha. Tattha satipi ānandattherassapi asītiyā mahātherānaṃ antogadhabhāve
analyzed: ruccati itiādim āha tattha sati pi ānanda therassa api asītiyā mahā therānam antogadha bhāve
translated: Herein, although the Elder Ānanda was included among the eighty great Elders,

original: “asītiyā mahātherānaṃ ruccatī”ti vatvā “tuyhampi ruccatī”ti vacanaṃ tena dhammasenāpatino
analyzed: asītiyā mahātherānam ruccati iti vatvā tuyham pi ruccati iti vacanam tena dhamma senāpatino
translated: nevertheless, after saying “It is pleasing to the eighty great Elders,” he said “It is pleasing to you” in order to have the General of the Dhamma’s praise spoken.

original: vaṇṇaṃ kathāpetukāmatāyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vaṇṇam kathā petu kāma tāya ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: It should be regarded as the desire to have him praise the General of the Dhamma.

original: Sāṭakantareti nivatthavatthantare. Laddhokāsoti nibbuddhaṃ karonto sāṭakantare laddhaṃ
analyzed: sāṭaka antare iti nivattha vattha antare laddha ukāsaḥ iti nibbuddham karontaḥ sāṭaka antare laddham
translated: In the interval of the robe: in the interval of the robe that he was wearing. Opportunity to take: having made a space, he had the opportunity to take it.

original: gahetuṃ laddhāvasaro. Labhissāminoti labhissāmi vata. Dīpadhajabhūtanti satayojanavitthiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: gahetum laddha avasaraḥ labhissāminā uti labhissāmi vata sata yojana vitthiṇṇam
translated: I shall obtain: I shall certainly obtain. Banner of the light: a banner of the Rose-Apple Island , which extends for a thousand leagues in breadth.

original: jambudīpassa dhajabhūtaṃ. Puggalapalāpeti antosārābhāvato palāpabhūte puggale haranto.
analyzed: jambudīpassa dhaja bhūtam puggala palāpe ti antosāra abhāvataḥ palāpa bhūte puggale harantaḥ
translated: He carried off a person who was like a straw, because he had no inner substance.

original: Bālatāyāti rucikhantiādiabhāvatāya. Dosatāyāti dussakabhāvena. Mohenāti mahāmūḷhatāya.
analyzed: bāla tāya ati ruci khanti ādi abhāva tāya dosa tāya ati dussaka bhāvena mohena ati mahā mūḍha tāya
translated: Because of his foolishness: because of his lack of desire, lack of faith, etc. Because of his wickedness: because of his unsuitability. Because of his delusion: because of his great delusion.

original: Keci pana “bālo bālatāyāti mūḷhatāya pakatibālabhāvena na jānāti. Mūḷho mohenāti
analyzed: keci pana bālaḥ bāla tāya ati mūḍha tāya pakati bāla bhāvena na jānāti mūḍhaḥ mohena ati
translated: Some say that the first phrase means that a fool does not know through his natural foolishness, through his being deluded,

original: sayaṃ abālo samānopi yadā mohena pariyuṭṭhito hoti, tadā mohena na jānāti, ayaṃ padadvayassa
analyzed: sayam abālaḥ samānaḥ pi yadā mohena pariyuṭṭhitaḥ hoti tadā mohena na jānāti ayam pada dvayassa
translated: while the second phrase means that even though he is not a fool by nature, when he is overcome by delusion he does not know through delusion. This is the difference between the two phrases.

original: viseso”ti vadanti. Vipallatthacittoti yakkhummādena pittummādena vā viparītacitto.
analyzed: viseso ti vadanti vipallattha citto ti yakkhummādena pittummādena vā viparīta citto
translated: “With a mind distorted” : with a mind distorted by the madness of spirits or the madness of bile.

original: “Catūsu kosallesū”ti vuttaṃ catubbidhaṃ kosallaṃ pāḷiyā eva dassetuṃ “vuttaṃ heta”ntiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha yo aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo samudayato atthaṅgamato assādato ādīnavato nissaraṇato
analyzed: catūsu kosallesu iti vuttam catubbidham kosallam pāḷiyā eva dassetum vuttam hetat tiādi  vuttam tattha aṭṭhārasa dhātuyo samudayataḥ atthaṅgamataḥ assādataḥ ādīnavataḥ nissaraṇato
translated: “It is said” : this is said in order to show the four kinds of skillfulness mentioned in the passage “In the four domains of skillfulness” .

original: ca yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ayaṃ dhātukusalo. Vuttanayena āyatanesu kusalo āyatanakusalo.🔽Avijjādīsu dvādasapaṭiccasamuppādaṅgesu kusalo paṭiccasamuppādakusalo. “Idaṃ imassa
analyzed: ca yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dhātu kusalaḥ vutta nayena āyatanesu kusalaḥ āyatana kusalaḥ  avijjā ādīsu dvādasa paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgesu kusalaḥ paṭiccasamuppāda kusalaḥ idam imassa
translated: Herein, one who understands the eighteen elements as they really are in terms of origination, in terms of passing away, in terms of their satisfaction, in terms of their danger, and in terms of the escape from them is skilled in the elements. One who understands the twelve bases in the same way is skilled in the bases.

original: phalassa ṭhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ, idaṃ aṭṭhānaṃ akāraṇa”nti evaṃ ṭhānañca ṭhānato, aṭṭhānañca
analyzed: phalassa ṭhānam kāraṇam idam aṭṭhānam akāraṇam ti evam ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānam ca
translated: One who understands the twelve factors of dependent origination beginning with ignorance is skilled in dependent origination. “This is the basis, the cause, the origin, the condition for this,” and “This is not the basis, the cause, the origin, the condition for this” — thus one who understands the basis and the non-basis as they really are is skilled in the proper and the improper.

original: aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānato ṭhānāṭṭhānakusalo. Yo pana imesu dhātuādīsu pariññābhisamayādivasena
analyzed: aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam pajānataḥ ṭhāna aṭṭhāna kusalaḥ yaḥ pana imesu dhātu ādīsu pariññā abhisamaya ādi vasena
translated: He is skilled in the possible and the impossible in that he understands the possible and the impossible in the world and in the Dhamma.

original: nissaṅgagatiyā paṇḍāti laddhanāmena ñāṇena ito gato pavatto, ayaṃ paṇḍito nāma.🔽Mahantānaṃ atthānaṃ pariggaṇhanato mahatī paññā etassāti mahāpañño. Sesapadesupi🔽eseva nayoti āha “mahāpaññādīhi samannāgatoti attho”ti. Nānattanti yāhi mahāpaññādīhi
analyzed: nissaṅga gatiyā paṇḍā ati laddha nāmena ñāṇena itas gataḥ pavattaḥ ayam paṇḍitaḥ nāma  mahantānam atthānam pariggaṇhanataḥ mahatī paññā etassa ati mahāpañño sesa padesu pi  esā iva nayo ti āha mahāpaññā ādīhi samannāgatoti attho ti nānattam ti yāhi mahāpaññā ādīhi
translated: He is gone to the end of discernment in that he has gone to the end of discernment by means of the knowledge called “gone beyond,” which is gone beyond these elements, etc.,🔽by way of full understanding, penetration, etc.,🔽He is of great understanding in that he has great understanding because he grasps great matters. The meaning of the other terms is to be given in the same way.🔽He is of great understanding, etc., in that he is praised by the wise as “of great understanding,” etc., because he is endowed with great understanding, etc.

original: samannāgatattā thero “mahāpañño”tiādinā kittito, tāsaṃ mahāpaññādīnaṃ idaṃ nānattaṃ
analyzed: samannāgata ttā theraḥ mahā paññā ti ādinā kittitaḥ tāsam mahā paññā ādīnam idam nānattam
translated: This is the diversity of the great understanding, etc.🔽This is the variety.

original: ayaṃ vemattatā. Yassa kassaci visesato arūpadhammassa mahattaṃ nāma kiccasiddhiyā
analyzed: ayam vematta tā yassa kassaci visesataḥ arūpa dhammassa mahattam nāma kicca siddhiyā
translated: The greatness of any visible matter, etc., should be understood as success in its function.

original: veditabbanti tadassa kiccasiddhiyā dassento “mahante sīlakkhandhe pariggaṇhātī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: veditabbam ti tat assa kicca siddhiyā dassentaḥ mahante sīlakkhandhe pariggaṇhāti itiādim āha
translated: In order to show that success in its function, he said: “He grasps the great aggregate of virtue” , etc.

original: Tattha hetumahantatāya paccayamahantatāya nissayamahantatāya pabhedamahantatāya kiccamahantatāya
analyzed: tattha hetu mahanta tāya paccaya mahanta tāya nissaya mahanta tāya pabheda mahanta tāya kicca mahanta tāya
translated: Herein, the aggregate of virtue is great in the sense of cause-greatness, in the sense of condition-greatness, in the sense of support-greatness, in the sense of variety-greatness, in the sense of function-greatness,

original: phalamahantatāya ānisaṃsamahantatāya ca sīlakkhandhassa mahantabhāvo veditabbo. Tattha🔽hetū alobhādayo. Paccayā hirottappasaddhāsativīriyādayo. Nissayā sāvakabodhipaccekabodhisammāsambodhiniyatatā,
