analyzed: phala mahanta tāya ānisaṃsa mahanta tāya ca sīlakkhandhassa mahanta bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha  hetū alobha ādayaḥ paccayāḥ hira uttappa saddhā sati vīriya ādayaḥ nissayā sāvaka bodhi pacceka bodhi sammāsambodhi niyata tā
translated: The greatness of the virtue aggregate should be understood as the greatness of its fruit and the greatness of its benefit. Herein,🔽the cause is non-greed, etc.,🔽the condition is conscience, shame, faith, mindfulness, energy, etc., the support is the determination for the enlightenment of a disciple, the enlightenment of a paccekabuddha, or the supreme enlightenment,

original: taṃsamaṅgino ca purisavisesā. Pabhedo cārittādivibhāgo. Kiccaṃ tadaṅgādivasena paṭipakkhassa
analyzed: ca purisa visesāḥ pabhedaḥ cāritta ādi vibhāgo kiccam tad aṅga ādi vasena paṭipakkhassa
translated: and the distinction is the classification of virtue as virtue of conduct, etc. Its function is to dispel the opposing states by means of the factors that counteract them.

original: vidhamanaṃ. Phalaṃ saggasampadā nibbānasampadā ca. Ānisaṃso piyamanāpatādi. Ayamettha🔽saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge ākaṅkheyyasuttādīsu ca āgatanayena veditabbo.🔽Iminā nayena samādhikkhandhādīnampi mahantatā yathārahaṃ niddhāretvā veditabbā. Ṭhānāṭṭhānādīnaṃ
analyzed: vidhamanam phalam sagga sampadā nibbāna sampadā ca ānisaṃsaḥ ayam ettha  saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge ākaṅkheyya sutta ādīsu ca āgata nayena veditabbo  iminā nayena samādhi khandha ādīnam pi mahanta tā yathāraham niddhāretvā veditabbā ṭhāna aṭṭhāna ādīnam
translated: Its proximate cause is the attainment of heaven and the attainment of nibbāna. Its benefit is the absence of remorse, etc. This, in brief,🔽is the method of explaining the greatness of the virtue aggregate. The detailed explanation should be understood according to the method given in the Visuddhimagga in the chapter on the virtue of the trainee and in the commentaries in such places as the commentary on the Ākaṅkheyya-sutta .

original: pana mahantabhāvo mahāvisayatāya veditabbo. Tattha ṭhānāṭṭhānānaṃ mahāvisayatā bahudhātukasuttādīsu
analyzed: pana mahanta bhāvaḥ mahā visaya tāya veditabbo tattha ṭhāna aṭṭhānānam mahā visaya tā bahudhātuka sutta ādīsu
translated: The greatness of the concentration aggregate, etc., should be understood in the appropriate way by the same method. But the greatness of the bases of spiritual success, etc., should be understood as the greatness of their domain. Herein, the greatness of the domain of the bases of spiritual success is shown in the Bahudhātuka Sutta ,🔽etc.

original: āgatanayena, vihārasamāpattīnaṃ samādhikkhandhe niddhāritanayena veditabbā. Ariyasaccānaṃ
analyzed: āgata nayena vihāra samāpattīnam samādhi kkhandhe niddhārita nayena veditabbāḥ ariya saccānam
translated: The method of exposition should be understood here in the way already given in the case of the jhānas, etc., in the Description of the Jhānas .

original: sakalasāsanasaṅgaṇhanato saccavibhaṅge taṃsaṃvaṇṇanāsu āgatanayena; satipaṭṭhānādīnaṃ🔽satipaṭṭhānavibhaṅgādīsu taṃsaṃvaṇṇanādīsu ca āgatanayena; sāmaññaphalānaṃ mahato
analyzed: sakala sāsana saṅgaṇhanataḥ sacca vibhaṅge tad saṃvaṇṇanāsu āgata nayena sati paṭṭhāna ādīnam  sati paṭṭhāna vibhaṅga ādīsu tad saṃvaṇṇanā ādīsu ca āgata nayena sāmañña phalānam mahataḥ
translated: The method of exposition should be understood here in the way already given in the case of the four noble truths in the Description of the Four Noble Truths , and in the case of the four foundations of mindfulness, etc., in the Description of the Foundations of Mindfulness , and so on.🔽The method of exposition should be understood here in the way already given in the case of the fruits of asceticism in the Description of the Fruits of Asceticism .

original: hitassa mahato sukhassa mahato atthassa mahato yogakkhemassa nipphattibhāvato santapaṇītanipuṇaatakkāvacarapaṇḍitavedanīyabhāvato🔽ca; abhiññānaṃ mahāsambhārato mahāvisayato mahākiccato mahānubhāvato mahānipphattito
analyzed: hitassa mahataḥ sukhassa mahataḥ atthassa mahataḥ yogakkhemassa nipphatti bhāvato santa paṇīta nipuṇa a takkāvacara paṇḍita vedanīya bhāvato  ca abhiññānam mahā sambhārataḥ mahā visayataḥ mahā kiccataḥ mahā anubhāvataḥ mahā nipphattito
translated: The method of exposition should be understood here in the way already given in the case of the kinds of direct knowledge in the Description of Direct Knowledge .

original: ca; nibbānassa madanimmadanādimahatthasiddhito mahantatā veditabbā. Pariggaṇhātīti
analyzed: ca nibbānassa mada nimmadana ādi mahattha siddhitaḥ mahanta tā veditabbā pariggaṇhāti iti
translated: The method of exposition should be understood here in the way already given in the case of Nibbāna in the Description of Nibbāna .🔽“He comprehends”: he grasps, he knows, he penetrates, is the meaning.

original: sabhāvādito paricchijja gaṇhāti jānāti paṭivijjhatīti attho. Sā panāti mahāpaññatā.
analyzed: sabhāva āditaḥ paricchijja gaṇhāti jānāti paṭivijjhati iti attho sā pana ati mahā paññatā
translated: “That” is the great understanding.

original: Puthupaññāti ettha nānākhandhesu ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti ayaṃ rūpakkhandho nāma…pe… ayaṃ
analyzed: puthu paññā ti ettha nānā khandhesu ñāṇam pavattati iti ayam rūpa kkhandho nāmape ayam
translated: As to ‘wide-awake’: his knowledge occurs in the various categories. This is the material form category, this is the feeling category …

original: viññāṇakkhandho nāmāti evaṃ pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati.
analyzed: viññāṇakkhandho nāma ati evam pañcannam khandhānam nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati
translated: As to ‘wide-awake understanding’: the knowledge occurs thus ‘This is called the materiality aggregate… This is called the consciousness aggregate’ in terms of the different aspects of the five aggregates.

original: Tesu ekavidhena rūpakkhandho, ekādasavidhena rūpakkhandho, ekavidhena vedanākkhandho,
analyzed: tesu ekavidhena rūpa kkhandho ekādasavidhena rūpa kkhandho ekavidhena vedanā kkhandho
translated: In the case of these, the materiality aggregate is of one kind, the materiality aggregate is of eleven kinds, the feeling aggregate is of one kind,

original: bahuvidhena vedanākkhandho, ekavidhena saññākkhandho, saṅkhārakkhandho, viññāṇakkhandhoti
analyzed: bahuvidhena vedanā kkhandhaḥ ekavidhena saññā kkhandhaḥ saṅkhāra kkhandhaḥ viññāṇa kkhandho ti
translated: the feeling aggregate is of many kinds, the perception aggregate is of one kind, the formations aggregate is of one kind, the consciousness aggregate is of one kind.

original: evaṃ ekekassa khandhassa ekavidhādivasena atītādivasenapi nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ🔽pavattati. Tathā idaṃ cakkhāyatanaṃ nāma…pe… idaṃ dhammāyatanaṃ nāmaṃ. Tattha dasāyatanā🔽kāmāvacarā, dve catubhūmakāti evaṃ āyatanānaṃ nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati.
analyzed: evam ekekassa khandhassa ekavidha ādi vasena atīta ādi vasena api nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam  pavattati tathā idam cakkhāyatanam nāma pe idam dhammāyatanam nāmaṃ tattha dasa āyatanā  kāmāvacarā dve evam āyata nānam nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati
translated: So the knowledge occurs in terms of the different aspects of each of the aggregates in this way, and also in terms of the past, etc.,🔽as follows: ‘This is the eye base … This is the mental-data base.’ Herein, ten bases are of the sense sphere, two are of four planes. So the knowledge occurs in terms of the different aspects of the bases.

original: Nānādhātūsūti ayaṃ cakkhudhātu nāma…pe… ayaṃ manoviññāṇadhātu nāma. Tattha soḷasa
analyzed: nānā dhātūsu iti ayam cakkhu dhātu nāma pe ayam manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu nāma tattha soḷasa
translated: As to ‘in the various elements’: this is the eye element … this is the mind-consciousness element. Herein, sixteen

original: dhātuyo kāmāvacarā, dve catubhūmakāti evaṃ dhātunānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati,🔽taṃ upādiṇṇadhātuvasena vuttanti veditabbaṃ paccekabuddhānañhi dvinnaṃ aggasāvakānañca
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ kāma avacarā dve evam dhātu nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati  tat upādiṇṇa dhātu vasena vuttan ti veditabbam paccekabuddhānam hi dvinnam aggasāvakānam ca
translated: “The elements are of the sense sphere, two are of four planes” — such knowledge occurs in him contingent upon the diversity of elements.

original: upādiṇṇadhātūsu eva nānākaraṇaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati. Tañca kho ekadesamattato,
analyzed: upādiṇṇa dhātūsu eva nānākaraṇam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati tat ca kho eka desa mattato
translated: This should be understood as said with reference to clung-to elements. For the knowledge of the Paccekabuddhas and chief disciples occurs contingent upon the diversity of elements only in the case of clung-to elements.🔽And that occurs only in part, not in all aspects.

original: na nippadesato, anupādiṇṇakadhātūnaṃ pana nānākaraṇaṃ na jānanti eva. Itarasāvakesu
analyzed: na nippadesataḥ anupādiṇṇaka dhātūnam pana nānākaraṇam na jānanti eva itara sāvakesu
translated: They do not know the diversity of unclung-to elements. As for other disciples,

original: vattabbameva natthi, sabbaññubuddhānaṃyeva pana imāya nāma dhātuyā ussannattāva imassa🔽rukkhassa khandho seto hoti, imassa kāḷo, imassa maṭṭho, imassa bahalattaco, imassa🔽tanuttaco, imassa pattaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena evarūpaṃ; imassa pupphaṃ nīlaṃ pītakaṃ
analyzed: vattabbam eva natthi sabbaññu buddhānam yeva pana imāya nāma dhātuyā imassa  rukkhassa khandhaḥ setaḥ hoti imassa kāḷaḥ imassa maṭṭhaḥ imassa bahalattacaḥ imassa  imassa pattam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena evarūpam imassa puppham nīlam pītakam
translated: there is nothing to be said. But in the case of the omniscient Buddhas, the knowledge occurs in them contingent upon the diversity of all elements.🔽“In this tree the trunk is white, in this it is black, in this it is mottled, in this the bark is thick, in this it is thin,🔽in this the leaves are of such and such a colour, shape, etc., in this the flowers are blue, yellow, red, white, fragrant, odourless,

original: lohitakaṃ odātaṃ, sugandhaṃ duggandhaṃ; phalaṃ khuddakaṃ mahantaṃ dīghaṃ vaṭṭaṃ susaṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: lohitakam odātam sugandham duggandham phalam khuddakam mahantam dīgham vaṭṭam su saṇṭhānam
translated: in this the fruit is small, large, long, round, well-shaped,

original: maṭṭhaṃ pharusaṃ sugandhaṃ madhuraṃ tittakaṃ ambilaṃ kaṭukaṃ kasāvaṃ; kaṇṭako tikhiṇo🔽atikhiṇo ujuko kuṭilo tambo lohito odāto hotīti dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca ñāṇaṃ pavattati.
analyzed: maṭṭham pharusam sugandham madhuram tittakam ambilam kaṭukam kasāvam kaṇṭakaḥ tikhiṇaḥ  ati khiṇaḥ ujukaḥ kuṭilaḥ tambaḥ lohitaḥ odātaḥ hoti iti dhātu nānattam paṭicca ñāṇam pavattati
translated: sharp-pointed, very sharp-pointed, straight, crooked, round, red, white.

original: Atthesūti rūpādīsu ārammaṇesu. Nānāpaṭiccasamuppādesūti ajjhattabahiddhābhedato ca
analyzed: atthesu ti rūpa ādīsu ārammaṇesu nānā paṭiccasamuppādesu iti ajjhatta bahiddhā bhedato ca
translated: “In the various existent objects” means in the objects of perception such as visible forms, etc.🔽“In the various dependent originations” means in the various factors of the dependent origination, which are of various kinds because of the distinction of internal and external,

original: saṇṭhānabhedato ca nānappabhedesu paṭiccasamuppādaṅgesu. Avijjādiaṅgānañhi paccekaṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhāna bhedato ca nānā ppabhedesu paṭiccasamuppāda aṅgesu avijjā ādi aṅgānam hi paccekam
translated: and because of the distinction of the various modes of existence. For each factor of the dependent origination, such as ignorance,

original: paṭiccasamuppādasaññitāti. Tenāha saṅkhārapiṭake “dvādasa paccayā dvādasa paṭiccasamuppādā”ti.
analyzed: paṭicca samuppāda saññitā ti tena āha saṅkhāra piṭake dvādasa paccayāḥ dvādasa paṭicca samuppādā ti
translated: is itself a dependent origination. Therefore it is said in the Saṅkhyāpiṭaka: “There are twelve conditions and twelve dependent originations.”

original: Nānāsuññatamanupalabbhesūti nānāsabhāvesu niccasārādivirahato suññasabhāvesu, tato
analyzed: nānā suññatama anupalabbhesu ti nānā sabhāvesu nicca sāra ādi virahataḥ suñña sabhāvesu tatas
translated: “In the various voidnesses and non-apprehensions” means in the various kinds of voidness, which is void of permanence, substantiality, etc.,

original: eva itthipurisaattaattaniyādivasena anupalabbhesu sabhāvesu. Ma-kāro hettha padasandhikaro.
analyzed: eva itthi purisa atta atta niya ādi vasena anupalabbhesu sa bhāvesu makāraḥ ha ittha pada sandhi karaḥ
translated: and in the various kinds of non-apprehensions, which are not apprehended as a woman, a man, a soul, a person, etc. The letter m is used here to connect the words.

original: Nānāatthesūti atthapaṭisambhidāvisayesu paccayuppannādibhedesu nānāvidhesu atthesu.
analyzed: nānā atthesu ti attha paṭisambhidā visayesu paccayuppanna ādi bhedesu nānāvidhesu atthesu
translated: “In the various meanings” means in the various kinds of meanings, such as the meaning of conditionality, etc., which are the domain of the discernment of meaning.

original: Dhammesūti dhammapaṭisambhidāvisayesu paccayādinānādhammesu. Niruttīsūti tesaṃyeva🔽atthadhammānaṃ niddhāraṇavacanasaṅkhātāsu niruttīsu. Paṭibhānesūti atthapaṭisambhidādīsu
analyzed: dhammesu ti dhamma paṭisambhidā visayesu paccaya ādi nānā dhammesu niruttīsu uti tesam yeva  attha dhammānam niddhāraṇa vacana saṅkhātāsu niruttīsu paṭibhānesu uti attha paṭisambhidā ādīsu
translated: In ideas : in the ideas of the various conditions, etc., which are the province of the discrimination of perspicuity.🔽In the phrasing : in the phrasing which is the verbal expression of those ideas and meanings.

original: visayabhūtesu “imāni idamatthajotakānī”ti tathā tathā paṭibhānato patiṭṭhānato paṭibhānānīti🔽laddhanāmesu ñāṇesu. Puthu nānāsīlakkhandhesūtiādīsu sīlassa puthuttaṃ nānattañca
analyzed: visaya bhūtesu imāni idam attha jotakāni iti tathā tathā paṭibhānato patiṭṭhānato paṭibhānāni iti  laddha nāmesu ñāṇesu puthu nānā sīla kkhandhesu tiādīsu sīlassa puthuttam nānattam ca
translated: In the modes of expression : in the knowledges called “modes of expression” because they are the means of expression in such and such a way of the meanings of such and such ideas, which are the province of the discrimination of meaning, etc.🔽In the various aggregates of virtue : the virtue’s variousness and diversity are stated.🔽But the rest are quite clear since their meaning can be known by the method stated.

original: vuttameva. Itaresaṃ pana vuttanayānusārena suviññeyyattā pākaṭameva. Yaṃ pana abhinnaṃ🔽ekameva nibbānaṃ, tattha upacāravasena puthuttaṃ gahetabbanti āha “puthu janasādhāraṇe
analyzed: vuttam eva itaresam pana vutta naya anusārena su viññeyya ttā pākaṭam eva yam pana abhinnam  ekam eva nibbānam tattha upacāra vasena puthuttam gahetabban ti āha puthu jana sādhāraṇe
translated: But the Unformed Element, which is undivided and single, can be taken as various by way of the access to it.🔽So he said “Having surmounted the ideas shared by ordinary men” .

original: dhamme samatikkammā”ti. Tenassa idha madanimmadanādipariyāyena puthuttaṃ dīpitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: dhamme samatikkamma ati tena assa idha mada nimmadana ādi pariyāyena puthuttam dīpitam hoti
translated: So its variousness here is shown by the way of surmounting intoxication, etc.

original: Evaṃ visayavasena paññāya mahattaṃ puthuttañca dassetvā idāni sampayuttadhammavasena
analyzed: evam visaya vasena paññāya mahattam puthuttañca dassetvā idāni sampayutta dhamma vasena
translated: Having thus shown the greatness and the variousness of understanding by way of its province, he now shows it by way of the associated states.

original: hāsabhāvaṃ, pavattiākāravasena javanabhāvaṃ, kiccavasena tikkhādibhāvañca dassetuṃ
analyzed: hāsa bhāvam pavatti ākāra vasena javana bhāvam kicca vasena tikkha ādi bhāvañca dassetum
translated: In order to show the state of laughter, the state of impulsion by way of the mode of its occurrence, and the states of sharpness, etc., by way of its function,

original: “katamā hāsapaññā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha hāsabahuloti pītibahulo. Sesapadāni tassa🔽vevacanāni. Sīlaṃ paripūretīti haṭṭhapahaṭṭho udaggudaggo hutvā pītisahagatāya paññāya
analyzed: katamā hāsa paññā iti ādi vuttam tattha hāsa bahulo ti pīti bahulo sesa padāni tassa  vevacanāni sīlam paripūreti iti haṭṭha pahaṭṭhaḥ udagga udaggaḥ hutvā pīti sahagatāya paññāya
translated: “What is laughing wisdom?” and so on is said. Herein, having much laughter means having much joy. The other terms are synonyms for that.🔽He fulfills virtue means that being elated, uplifted, and joyful, he fulfills the other three kinds of virtue with the wisdom accompanied by joy.

original: pātimokkhasīlaṃ ṭhapetvā hāsanīyatarasseva visuṃ gahitattā itaraṃ tividhaṃ sīlaṃ🔽paripūreti. Pītisomanassasahagatā hi paññā abhirativasena tadārammaṇe phullitā vikasitā
analyzed: pātimokkha sīlam ṭhapetvā hāsanīyatarassa iva visum itaram tividham sīlam  paripūreti pīti somanassa sahagatā hi paññā abhirati vasena tad ārammaṇe phullitā vikasitā
translated: The virtue consisting in the precepts is taken separately as the most laughable of all, because it is the most laughable.

original: viya vattati, na upekkhāsahagatā. Sīlakkhandhaṃ samādhikkhandhantiādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: viya vattati na upekkhā sahagatā sīla kkhandham samādhi kkhandha nti ādīsu pi esa eva nayo
translated: For wisdom accompanied by joy and gladness occurs in regard to its object as if it were expanded and developed by over-overflowing, not so wisdom accompanied by equanimity. The same method applies in the case of the aggregates of concentration and of understanding.

original: Therotiādinā abhinīhārasiddhā therassa hāsapaññatāti dasseti.
analyzed: thera uti ādinā abhinīhāra siddhā therassa hāsa pañña tā ti dasseti
translated: By the words “The elder” and so on he shows that the elder’s wisdom was laughing because it was successful in its aspiration.

original: Sabbaṃ rūpaṃ aniccalakkhaṇato khippaṃ javatīti rūpakkhandhaṃ aniccanti sīghavegena
analyzed: sabbam rūpam anicca lakkhaṇato khippam javati iti rūpa kkhandham aniccanti sīgha vegena
translated: All form impels quickly because it has the characteristic of impermanence. Therefore the aggregate of form impels quickly. He sees that the aggregate of form is impermanent with swift speed.

original: pavattiyā paṭipakkhadūrībhāvena pubbābhisaṅkhārassa sātisayattā indena visaṭṭhavajiraṃ🔽viya lakkhaṇaṃ paṭivijjhantī adandhāyantī rūpakkhandhe aniccalakkhaṇaṃ vegena paṭivijjhati,
analyzed: pavattiyā paṭipakkha dūrībhāvena pubba abhisaṅkhārassa sa atisaya ttā indena visaṭṭha vajiram  viya lakkhaṇam paṭivijjhantī adandhāyantī rūpa kkhandhe anicca lakkhaṇam vegena paṭivijjhati
translated: The characteristic of the materiality aggregate is penetrated by the quickness of the insight, which is due to the remoteness of the opposite of occurrence, and to the excess of the prior volition, like a door that is easily opened by a strong push.

original: tasmā sā javanapaññā nāmāti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāvasena
analyzed: tasmā sā javana paññā nāma ati attho sesa padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ evam lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā vasena
translated: Therefore the meaning is that the javana insight is called “the insight that penetrates the characteristics.” The same method applies to the other three aggregates.

original: javanapaññaṃ dassetvā balavavipassanāvasena dassetuṃ “rūpa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: javana paññam dassetvā balava vipassanā vasena dassetum rūpa nti ādi vuttam tattha
translated: Having thus shown the javana insight by way of insight that has the characteristics as its object, he shows it by way of powerful insight, saying, “Materiality” and so on.

original: khayaṭṭhenāti yattha yattha uppajjati, tattha tattheva khaṇeneva bhijjanato khayasabhāvato.🔽Bhayaṭṭhenāti bhayānakato. Asārakaṭṭhenāti attasāravirahato niccasārādivirahato ca.
analyzed: khaya ṭṭhena ati yattha yattha uppajjati tattha tattha iva khaṇena iva bhijjanato khaya sabhāvato  bhaya ṭṭhena ati bhayānakataḥ asāraka ṭṭhena ati atta sāra virahataḥ nicca sāra ādi virahato ca
translated: Herein, as to the meaning of destruction: because it is destroyed in each instance where it arises, by its very nature of destruction.🔽As to the meaning of terror: because it is terrifying. As to the meaning of insubstantiality: because it is devoid of self and substance, of the substance of permanence, and so on.

original: Tulayitvāti tulābhūtāya vipassanāya tulayitvā. Tīrayitvāti tāya eva tīraṇabhūtāya
analyzed: tulayitvā ati tulā bhūtāya vipassanāya tulayitvā tīrayitvā ati tāya eva tīraṇa bhūtāya
translated: Having weighed: having weighed by means of the insight that is like a balance. Having measured: having measured by means of the insight that is like a measuring rod.

original: tīretvā. Vibhāvayitvāti yāthāvato pakāsetvā pañcakkhandhaṃ vibhūtaṃ katvā pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: tīretvā vibhāvayitvā ati yāthāvataḥ pakāsetvā pañcakkhandham vibhūtam katvā pākaṭam
translated: Having discerned: having made manifest, having made evident, having made clear the five aggregates by revealing them as they are.

original: katvā. Rūpanirodheti rūpakkhandhassa nirodhabhūte nibbāne ninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena.
analyzed: katvā rūpa nirodha iti rūpakkhandhassa nirodha bhūte nibbāne ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena
translated: and having done so, in nibbana, which is the cessation of materiality, by way of the state of being a low-lying plain that flows out and spreads over.

original: Idāni sikhāppattavipassanāvasena javanapaññaṃ dassetuṃ puna “rūpa”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni sikhāppatta vipassanā vasena javana paññam dassetum puna rūpa ntiādi vuttaṃ
translated: Now, in order to show the wisdom of impulsion by way of insight that has reached the peak, “materiality” and so on are stated again.

original: “Vuṭṭhānagāminivipassanāvasenā”ti keci.🔽Ñāṇatikkhabhāvo nāma savisesaṃ paṭipakkhasamucchindane veditabboti “khippaṃ kilese
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanā vasena ati keci  ñāṇa tikkha bhāvaḥ nāma sa visesam paṭipakkha samucchindane veditabbaḥ ti khippam kilese
translated: “By way of the insight that leads to emergence,” say some.

original: chindatīti tikkhapañño”ti vatvā te pana kilese vibhāgena dassento “uppannaṃ kāmavitakka”ntiādimāha.🔽Tikkhapañño khippābhiñño hoti, paṭipadā cassa na calatīti āha “ekasmiṃ āsane cattāro🔽ca ariyamaggā adhigatā hontī”tiādi. Thero cātiādinā dhammasenāpatino tikkhapaññatā
analyzed: chindati iti tikkha pañño ti vatvā te pana kilese vibhāgena dassentaḥ uppannam kāma vitakka nti ādim āha  tikkha paññaḥ khippa abhiññaḥ hoti paṭipadā cassa na calati iti āha ekasmim āsane cattāro  ca ariya maggāḥ adhigatāḥ honti itiādi thero ca atiādinā dhammasenāpatino tikkha pañña tā
translated: The state of being keen in the penetration of knowledge should be understood as the severing of the opposite by way of distinction. Therefore, after saying, “He is quick in severing defilements,” he shows those defilements by way of a distinction, saying, “When a thought of sensual desire has arisen in him” and so on.

original: sikhāppattāti dasseti.
analyzed: sikhā appattā iti dasseti
translated: He is quick in the penetration of knowledge and he is quick in direct-knowledge, and his practice does not waver. Therefore it is said: “The four noble paths were reached by him in a single seat” and so on. The Elder and so on show the keenness in the penetration of knowledge of the General of the Dhamma.🔽“Having reached the peak”

original: “Sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā aniccāḥ dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khaya dhammā
translated: All formations are impermanent, painful, subject to change, conditioned, dependently arisen, subject to destruction,

original: vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā”ti yāthāvato dassanena saccasampaṭivedho ijjhati,🔽na aññathāti kāraṇamukhena nibbedhikapaññaṃ dassetuṃ “sabbasaṅkhāresu ubbegabahulo
analyzed: vaya dhammāḥ virāga dhammāḥ nirodha dhammāḥ ti yāthāvataḥ dassanena sacca sampaṭivedho ijjhati  na aññathā ti kāraṇa mukhena nibbedhika paññam dassetum sabba saṅkhāresu ubbega bahulo
translated: The penetration of the truths by means of right seeing is successful in this way, not otherwise.

original: hotī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ubbegabahuloti vuttanayena sabbasaṅkhāresu abhiṇhappavattasaṃvego.
analyzed: hoti itiādi vuttam tattha ubbega bahulaḥ ti vutta nayena sabba saṅkhāresu abhiṇha pavatta saṃvegaḥ
translated: In order to show penetrating understanding by means of a reason, it is said: “He is one who frequently feels a sense of urgency about all formations” , and so on. Herein, he is one who frequently feels a sense of urgency about all formations: he frequently feels a sense of urgency about all formations in the way already stated.

original: Uttāsabahuloti ñāṇuttāsavasena sabbasaṅkhāresu bahuso utrastamānaso. Tena ādīnavānupassanamāha.
analyzed: uttāsa bahulaḥ ti ñāṇa uttāsa vasena sabba saṅkhāresu bahusas utrasta mānasaḥ tena ādīnava anupassanam āha
translated: He is one who frequently feels a sense of dread: he is one whose mind frequently trembles with fear in regard to all formations because of the dread of knowledge. He thus shows the contemplation of danger.

original: Ukkaṇṭhanabahuloti iminā pana nibbidānupassanamāha, aratibahulotiādinā tassā eva🔽aparāparuppattiṃ. Bahimukho sabbasaṅkhārato bahibhūtaṃ nibbānaṃ uddissa pavattañāṇamukho,
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhana bahulaḥ ti iminā pana nibbida anupassanam āha arati bahulaḥ ti ādinā tassāḥ eva  apara apara uppattim bahimukhaḥ sabba saṅkhārataḥ bahi bhūtam nibbānam uddissa pavatta ñāṇa mukho
translated: He is one who frequently feels a sense of revulsion: by this he shows the contemplation of dispassion. He is one who frequently feels a sense of dissatisfaction, and so on.🔽He is one who frequently feels a sense of dissatisfaction: by this he shows the contemplation of dispassion. He is one who frequently feels a sense of dissatisfaction, and so on.🔽He is one whose mind is turned outward: his mind is turned outward to Nibbāna, which is outside all formations.

original: tathā vā pavattitavimokkhamukho. Nibbijjhanaṃ nibbedho, so etissā atthi, nibbijjhatīti
analyzed: tathā vā pavattita vimokkha mukhaḥ nibbijjhanam nibbedhaḥ saḥ etissā atthi nibbijjhati iti
translated: He is one whose mind is turned to the outlet: his mind is turned to the outlet, which is Nibbāna.🔽He is one who is disgusted: he is disgusted.

original: vā nibbedhā, sā eva paññā nibbedhikā. Yaṃ panettha atthato na vibhattaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā
analyzed: vā nibbedhā sā eva paññā nibbedhikā yam pana ittha atthataḥ na vibhattam tam heṭṭhā
translated: and the understanding that penetrates is penetrating understanding. But what has not been explained here in the sense of the meaning has been explained in the Description of the Aggregates.

original: vuttanayattā suviññeyyameva.🔽Appicchoti santaguṇaniguhanatāti attani vijjamānānaṃ bāhusaccadhutadhammasīlādiguṇānañceva
analyzed: vutta naya ttā su viññeyyam eva  appiccho ti attani vijjamānānam bāhu sacca dhuta dhamma sīla ādi guṇānam ca iva
translated: Or it is penetrative understanding itself. What has not been explained here has been explained in the way already stated in the Description of the Meditations.

original: paṭivedhaguṇassa ca niguhanaṃ, paṭiggahaṇe ca mattaññutāti eteneva pariyesanaparibhogamattaññutāpi
analyzed: paṭivedha guṇassa ca niguhanam paṭiggahaṇe ca mattaññu tā ati etena iva pariyesana paribhoga mattaññu tā api
translated: He is content with any kind of alms: he conceals the special qualities of fewness of wishes, etc., that are found in him, and he is also moderate in accepting. And by this it is also shown that he is moderate in seeking and in using.

original: vuttā hoti. Tīhi santosehīti catūsu paccayesu paccekaṃ tīhi santosehi, sabbe pana
analyzed: vuttā hoti tīhi santosehi iti catūsu paccayesu paccekam tīhi santosehi sabbe pana
translated: With three kinds of contentment: with each of the four requisites he has three kinds of contentment, thus there are altogether twelve.

original: dvādasa. Paṭisallīnena vivekaṭṭhakāyānaṃ na saṅgaṇikārāmānaṃ. Nekkhammābhiratānanti
analyzed: dvādasa paṭisallīnena viveka ṭṭhakāyānam na saṅgaṇikā ārāmānam
translated: He is secluded: he is not in the habit of associating with the crowd, of going in the train of the great.🔽He delights in abandonment: he has gone forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: pabbajjaṃ upagatānaṃ. Parisuddhacittānaṃ vigatacittasaṃkilesānaṃ. Paramavodānappattānaṃ
analyzed: pabbajjam upagatānam parisuddha cittānam vigata citta saṃkilesānam parama vodāna ppattānam
translated: His mind is pure: his mind is free from defilements.

original: aṭṭhasamāpattisamadhigamena ativiya vodānaṃ visuddhiṃ pattānaṃ. Kilesupadhiādīnaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti samadhigamena ativiya vodānam visuddhim pattānam kilesa upadhi ādīnam
translated: He has attained to the supreme development: he has reached the supreme development by attaining the eight attainments.🔽He is free from the underlying tendency to lust, hate, and delusion: he is free from the underlying tendency to lust, hate, and delusion that have the four kinds of physical nutriment as their object.

original: abhāvato nirupadhīnaṃ. Phalasamāpattivasena sabbasaṅkhāravinissaṭattā visaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: abhāvataḥ nirupadhīnam phala samāpatti vasena sabba saṅkhāra vinissaṭa ttā visaṅkhāram
translated: and because of non-existence, it is without substratum. It is without formations because of the cessation of all formations by means of the attainment of fruition.

original: nibbānaṃ. Upagatānaṃ, imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ vivekānaṃ lābhī pavivitto “pakārehi vivitto”ti🔽katvā. Samāsajjanaṃ parisinehuppādo saṃsaggo, savanavasena uppajjanakasaṃsaggo savanasaṃsaggo.
analyzed: nibbānam upagatānam imesam tiṇṇam vivekānam lābhī pavivitto pakārehi vivitto ti  katvā samāsajjanam parisineha uppādo saṃsaggo savana vasena uppajjanaka saṃsaggo savana saṃsaggo
translated: Nibbana is the attainment of these three kinds of seclusion. He is secluded by nature because he is secluded by the factors of seclusion.🔽Association is the arising of affection by means of intimacy. Association by hearing is the association that arises by means of hearing.

original: Esa nayo sesesupi. Samullapanaṃ ālāpasallapanaṃ. Saṃsaggavatthunā iminā tassa paribhogo paribhogasaṃsaggo.
analyzed: esa nayo sesesu pi samullapanam ālāpa sallapanam saṃsagga vatthunā iminā tassa paribhogaḥ paribhoga saṃsaggo
translated: The same method applies to the rest. Talking is the exchanging of greetings. The enjoyment of that by means of the topic of association is association by enjoyment.

original: Āraddhavīriyoti ettha vīriyārambho nāma vīriyassa paggaṇhanaṃ paripuṇṇakaraṇaṃ. Taṃ🔽pana sabbaso kilesānaṃ niggaṇhananti dassento “tatthā”tiādimāha. Odhunanavattāti
analyzed: āraddha vīriyo ti ettha vīriya ārambhaḥ nāma vīriyassa paggaṇhanam paripuṇṇa karaṇam taṃ  pana sabbaso kilesānam niggaṇhananti dassento tattha atiādim āha odhunana vattā iti
translated: Herein, the arousing of energy is the exertion and fulfilment of energy.🔽But showing that that is the complete suppression of all defilements, he said “therein” , etc. The practice of shaking off is the practice of shaking off any kind of blameworthy thing.

original: kilesānaṃ yassa kassaci sāvajjassa odhunanavasena vattā. Tenāha “bhikkhūna”ntiādi.
analyzed: kilesānam yassa kassaci sāvajjassa odhunana vasena vattā tena āha bhikkhūnaṃ tiādi
translated: Hence he said “with bhikkhus” , etc.

original: Otiṇṇaṃ nāma vajjaṃ ajjhācaritanti ārocitaṃ. Anotiṇṇaṃ anārocitaṃ. Tantivasenāti
analyzed: otiṇṇam nāma vajjam ajjhācaritanti ārocitam an otiṇṇam an ārocitam tanti vasena ati
translated: Blame that has been incurred is misconduct that has been confessed. Blame that has not been incurred is misconduct that has not been confessed. By the method of “that” , etc.

original: pāḷidhammavasena, yuttasaddassa vasenāti attho. Pāpe lāmake puggale dhamme ca garahati
analyzed: pāḷi dhamma vasena yutta saddassa vasena ati atthaḥ pāpe lāmake puggale dhamme ca garahati
translated: by the Dhamma of the texts, by the meaning of the word yutta . He censures and despises evil and bad people and the Dhamma.

original: jigucchatīti pāpagarahī. Tenāha “pāpapuggale”tiādi. Ekadassīti ekabhavadassī, idhalokamattadassī
analyzed: jigucchati iti pāpa garahī tena āha pāpa puggala itiādi eka dassī iti eka bhava dassī idhaloka matta dassī
translated: Therefore he is called pāpagarahī . Ekadassī means one who sees only one state, one who sees only this world,

original: diṭṭhadhammikasukhamattāpekkhī. Samantāti samantato, parito me katthaci mā ahūti yojanā.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammika sukha matta apekkhī samantā iti samantataḥ paritas me katthaci mā ahū ti yojanā
translated: one who looks only for happiness in this world. Samantā means all round, all about. The construction is: May there be nothing for me anywhere.

original: Soḷasahi padehīti soḷasahi koṭṭhāsehi. Akuppanti kenaci akopanīyaṃ. Ayaṃ dhammasenāpatino
analyzed: soḷasahi padehi iti soḷasahi koṭṭhāsehi akuppanti kenaci a kopanīyam ayam dhamma senāpatino
translated: Soḷasahi padehīti means in the sixteen parts. Akuppanti means that which cannot be disturbed by anyone. This story of the Elder Saṅgāmaji’s

original: guṇakathā satthu vacanānusārena dasasahassacakkavāḷabyāpinī ahosi, taṃ dassetuṃ “eva”ntiādi
analyzed: guṇa kathā satthu vacana anusārena dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa byāpinī ahosi tam dassetum evam tiādi
translated: virtues, which spread through the ten-thousand world-element by the word of the Teacher, was told by the Master while dwelling in Jetavana, and referring to a certain monk who censured the good.

original: vuttaṃ. Catubbidhā vaṇṇanibhā pātubhavi uḷārapītisomanassasamuṭṭhānattā. Suṭṭhu obhāsatīti
analyzed: vuttam catubbidhā vaṇṇa nibhā pātubhavi uḷāra pīti somanassa samuṭṭhāna ttā suṭṭhu obhāsati iti
translated: To show this, the Master said, “Evaṃ me sutaṃ. ” The Elder Saṅgāmaji’s body was radiant with a fourfold radiance, which arose from the great joy and happiness of his mind. It shone forth well.

original: subho. Obhāsasampattiyā maṇino bhaddakatāti āha “subhoti sundaro”ti. Jātimā parisuddhaākarasamuṭṭhitattā.
analyzed: subhaḥ obhāsa sampattiyā maṇino bhaddaka tā ti āha subhaḥ ti sundarā ti jātimā parisuddha ākara samuṭṭhita ttā
translated: Therefore he was called subho . Because of his radiance, he was called bhadda . He was born in a good family. He was pure in his conduct.

original: Kuruvindajātiādijātivisesopi maṇi ākaraparisuddhamūlako evāti āha “jātisampanno”ti.
analyzed: kuruvinda jāti ādi jāti visesaḥ api maṇi ākara parisuddha mūlakaḥ eva iti āha jāti sampannaḥ iti
translated: The gem’s excellence of origin, etc., is due to its being of pure origin, etc., as well.

original: Dhovanādiparikammenāti catūsu pāsāṇesu dhovanadosanīharaṇatāpanasaṇhakaraṇādiparikammena.🔽Rattakambalassa vasena sabhāvavaṇṇasiddhiyā veḷuriyamaṇi ativiya sobhatīti āha “paṇḍukambale
analyzed: dhovana ādi parikammena ati catūsu pāsāṇesu dhovana dosa nīharaṇa tāpana saṇha karaṇa ādi parikammena  ratta kambalassa vasena sabhāva vaṇṇa siddhiyā sobhati iti āha paṇḍu kambale
translated: By the process of washing, etc.: by the process of washing, rubbing, heating, and polishing on the four kinds of whetstones.

original: nikkhitto”ti. Nikkhanti bhaṇḍamāha. Tañca appakena suvaṇṇena kataṃ bhaṇḍaṃ na sobhati
analyzed: nikkhittaḥ ti nikkhanti bhaṇḍam āha tat ca appakena suvaṇṇena katam bhaṇḍam na sobhati
translated: The cat’s-eye gem shines most brilliantly when it is set in white cloth. Therefore it is said: “set in white cloth.” “Set” is a term for an ornament made of a small amount of gold. It does not shine🔽when it is set in an ornament made of a small amount of gold.

original: sobhāvipulenāti āha “atirekapañcasuvaṇṇena katapiḷandhana”nti. Suvaṇṇanti pañcadharaṇassa
analyzed: sobhā vipulena ati āha atireka pañca suvaṇṇena kata piḷandhanam ti suvaṇṇam ti pañca dharaṇassa
translated: It shines most brilliantly when it is set in an ornament made of a large amount of gold. Therefore it is said: “set in an ornament made of more than five suvaṇṇas.” “Suvaṇṇa” is a term for the five metals.

original: samaññā, tasmā pañcavīsatisuvaṇṇasāriyā vicittaābharaṇaṃ idha “nikkha”nti adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: samaññā tasmā pañcavīsati suvaṇṇa sāriyā vicitta ābharaṇam idha nikkhanti adhippetam
translated: Therefore a variegated ornament made of twenty-five suvaṇṇas is what is intended here by “set.”

original: Tañhi vipulaṃ na parittakaṃ. Mahājambusākhāya pavattanadiyanti mahājambusākhāya heṭṭhā
analyzed: tat hi vipulam na parittakam mahā jambu sākhāya mahā jambu sākhāya heṭṭhā
translated: For that is extensive, not limited. “The branch of the great rose-apple tree”:

original: sañjātanadiyaṃ. Taṃ kira ratanaṃ rattaṃ. Sukusalena…pe… sampahaṭṭhanti suṭṭhu kusalena🔽suvaṇṇakārena ukkāya tāpetvā sammā pahaṭṭhaṃ majjanādivasena sukataparikammaṃ. Dhātuvibhaṅgeti
analyzed: tam kira ratanam rattam su kusalena pe sampahaṭṭhanti suṭṭhu kusalena  suvaṇṇakārena ukkāya tāpetvā sammā pahaṭṭham majjana ādi vasena su kata parikammam dhātu vibhaṅga iti
translated: Well-skilled, etc. : well-skilled by a very skilled goldsmith, etc.🔽The element analysis: in the Element Analysis Discourse .

original: dhātuvibhaṅgasutte. Katabhaṇḍanti ābharaṇabhāvena kataṃ bhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅga sutte ābharaṇa bhāvena katam bhaṇḍam
translated: Made object: made into an object for adornment.

original: Nātiucco nātinīco taruṇasūriyo nāma. Satthārā ābhatavaṇṇo ubbhataguṇoti attho. Neva
analyzed: na atiuccaḥ na atinīcaḥ taruṇasūriyaḥ nāma satthārā ābhata vaṇṇo ubbhata guṇo ti attho na iva
translated: Not too high, not too low: the sun at dawn. The meaning is: the colour and the qualities of the sun as it is rising.

original: maraṇaṃ abhinandatīti attanopi maraṇaṃ neva abhinandati attavinipātassa sāvajjabhāvato.
analyzed: maraṇam abhinandati iti maraṇam na iva abhinandati atta vinipātassa sāvajja bhāvato
translated: Does not delight in death: does not delight in his own death, because self-destruction is blameworthy.

original: Bodhisatto pana paresaṃ atthāya attano attabhāvaṃ pariccajati karuṇāvasena, evaṃ
analyzed: bodhisatto pana paresam atthāya attanaḥ atta bhāvam pariccajati karuṇā vasena evam
translated: But the Bodhisatta gives up his own life for the sake of others out of compassion, and

original: vosajjanaṃ paramatthapāramīpāripūriṃ gacchatīti sāvakā na tathā kātuṃ sakkā sikkhāpadato.
analyzed: vosajjanam paramattha pāramī pāripūrim gacchati iti sāvakāḥ na tathā kātum sakkā sikkhāpadato
translated: such a sacrifice fulfils the perfection of relinquishment in the ultimate sense. But disciples cannot do so, because it would be a transgression of the training precepts.🔽Does not seek life: does not seek life, because the desire for life has been cut off.

original: Na jīvitaṃ pattheti jīvitāsāya samucchinnattā. Divasasaṅkhepanti ajja tvaṃ idaṃ nāma
analyzed: na jīvitam pattha iti jīvita āsāya ajja tvam idam nāma
translated: The day’s extent: today you should do this,

original: kammaṃ karohi, idaṃ te vetananti divasabhāgena paricchinnaṃ vetanaṃ. Tādiso hi bhatako
analyzed: kammam karohi idam te vetanam ti divasa bhāgena paricchinnam vetanam tādisaḥ hi bhatakaḥ
translated: “Do the work; this is your wage” means wage fixed by the day. For such a hired man

original: divasakkhayameva udikkhati, na kammaniṭṭhānaṃ. Nibbisaṃ bhatako yathāti vetanaṃ bhatiṃ
analyzed: divasa kkhayam eva udikkhati na kamma niṭṭhānam nibbisam bhatakaḥ yathā ati vetanam bhatim
translated: looks only to the end of the day, not to the completion of the work. “The hired man who is paid by the job” means a hired man who,

original: icchanto kālakkhayaṃ udikkhanto bhatakapuriso viya.
analyzed: icchantaḥ kāla khayam udikkhantaḥ bhataka purisaḥ viya
translated: wanting his wage, looks to the end of the job.

original: Susimasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: susima sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Susima Sutta is finished.

original: 10. Nānātitthiyasāvakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nānā titthiya sāvaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Sutta on the Disciples of Different Sects

original: 111. Nānātitthiyasāvakāti puthutitthiyānaṃ sāvakā. Chinditeti hatthacchedādivasena
analyzed: nānā titthiya sāvakā ati puthu titthiyānam sāvakā chinditā iti hattha cheda ādi vasena
translated: “Disciples of different sects” means disciples of different teachers. “In cutting” means in cutting off hands, etc.

original: chede. Māriteti māraṇe. Na pāpaṃ samanupassatīti kiñci pāpaṃ atthīti na passati,
analyzed: chede māritā iti māraṇe na pāpam samanupassati iti kiñci pāpam atthi iti na passati
translated: “In killing” means in killing. “Does not see any evil” means does not see that there is any evil,

original: paresañca tathā pavedeti. Vissāsanti vissatthabhāvaṃ. “Katakammānampi vipāko natthī”ti
analyzed: paresam ca tathā pavedeti vissāsanti vissattha bhāvam kata kammānam pi vipākaḥ natthi iti
translated: and he proclaims it to be so to others. “Trust” means confidence. Saying, “There is no result even of deeds done,”

original: vadanto katapāpānaṃ akatapuññānañca vissatthataṃ nirāsaṅkataṃ janeti.
analyzed: vadantaḥ kata pāpānam a kata puññānam ca vissattha tam nirāsaṅka tam janeti
translated: he generates confidence, lack of fear, in those who have done evil and not done good.

original: Tapojigucchāyāti tapasā acelavatādinā pāpato jigucchanena, “pāpaṃ virājayāmā”ti acelavatādisamādānenāti
analyzed: tapaḥ jigucchāya ati tapasā acelavat ādinā pāpataḥ jigucchanena pāpam virājayāma ati acelavat ādi samādānena ati
translated: ‘By austerity and by disgust with evil’: by austerity, by the naked life, etc., and by disgust with evil. The meaning is: ‘by the undertaking of the naked life, etc., he has put away evil.’🔽For one who has undertaken that is called ‘one who has covered himself’

original: attho. Tasmiñhi samādāne ṭhitena saṃvarena saṃvutacitto samannāgato pihito ca nāma
analyzed: attho tasmin hi samādāne ṭhitena saṃvarena saṃvuta citto samannāgataḥ pihitaḥ ca nāma
translated: by the restraint in which he stands. He is also called ‘one who has closed himself in’

original: hotīti “susaṃvutatto”tiādi vuttaṃ. Cattāro yāmā bhāgā catuyāmā, catuyāmā eva cātuyāmā.
analyzed: hoti iti vuttam cattāraḥ yāmā bhāgā catu yāmā catu yāmāḥ eva cātuyāmā
translated: by the restraint in which he stands. The four watches are the parts, thus the four watches are ‘the four-watched’ .

original: Bhāgattho hi idha yāma-saddo yathā “rattiyaṃ paṭhamo yāmo”ti. So panettha bhāgo saṃvaralakkhaṇoti🔽āha “cātuyāmena susaṃvuto”ti, catukoṭṭhāsena saṃvarena suṭṭhu saṃvutoti attho. Paṭikkhittasabbasītodakoti🔽paṭikkhittasabbasītudakaparibhogo. Sabbena pāpavāraṇena yuttoti sabbappakārena saṃvaralakkhaṇena
analyzed: bhāga atthaḥ hi idha yāma saddaḥ yathā rattiyam paṭhamaḥ yāmaḥ ti so pana ittha bhāgaḥ saṃvara lakkhaṇaḥ ti  āha cātuyāmena su saṃvutaḥ ti catu koṭṭhāsena saṃvarena suṭṭhu saṃvutaḥ ti attho paṭikkhitta sabba sīta udako ti  paṭikkhitta sabba sītudaka paribhogaḥ sabbena pāpa vāraṇena yuttaḥ ti sabba ppakārena saṃvara lakkhaṇena
translated: For the word yāmika here has the meaning of part, as in the passage, ‘The first watch of the night’ . And that part here is of the nature of restraint,🔽so it is said, ‘Well restrained by the four-watched’ . The meaning is: well restrained by the restraint consisting of the four parts. ‘Who has rejected all cold water’: who has rejected the use of all cold water. ‘Who is endowed with all the warding off of evil’: who is endowed with all the warding off of evil that has the characteristic of restraint.

original: pāpavāraṇena samannāgato. Dhutapāpoti sabbena nijjaralakkhaṇena pāpavāraṇenapi dhutapāpo.
analyzed: pāpa vāraṇena samannāgataḥ dhuta pāpo ti sabbena nijjara lakkhaṇena pāpa vāraṇena api dhuta pāpo
translated: ‘Who is one who has shaken off evil by the shaking-off of all evil’: who is one who has shaken off evil by the shaking-off of all evil that has the characteristic of wearing away.

original: Phuṭṭhoti aṭṭhannampi kammānaṃ khepanena vikkhepappattiyā kammakkhayalakkhaṇena sabbena
analyzed: phuṭṭhaḥ ti aṭṭhannam pi kammānam khepanena vikkhepa ppattiyā kamma kkhaya lakkhaṇena sabbena
translated: ‘Touched’ means touched by all the ten courses of action, by the characteristic of the defilement of action, by the occurrence of the scattering of the throwing out of the courses of action.

original: pāpavāraṇena phuṭṭho, taṃ phusitvā ṭhito. Na niguhantoti na niguhanahetu diṭṭhasute tatheva kathento.
analyzed: pāpa vāraṇena phuṭṭhaḥ tam phusitvā ṭhitaḥ na niguhanto iti na niguhana hetu diṭṭha sute tathā iva kathento
translated: ‘Not concealing’ means not speaking of what is seen and heard as it really is because of the desire to conceal.

original: Nānātitthiyānaṃyeva upaṭṭhākoti paravādīnaṃ sabbesaṃyeva titthiyānaṃ upaṭṭhāko, tesu sādhāraṇavasena abhippasanno. Koṭippattāti mokkhādhigamena samaṇadhamme pattabbamariyādappattā.
analyzed: nānā titthiyānam yeva upaṭṭhāko ti paravādīnam sabbesam yeva titthiyānam upaṭṭhāko tesu sādhāraṇa vasena abhippasanno koṭi pattā ati mokkha adhigamena samaṇa dhamme pattabba mariyāda pattā
translated: ‘Attendant on various sectarians’ means attendant on all the sectarians of other views, devoted to them in the sense of being in common with them. ‘Attained the peak’ means attained the noble state that can be attained by the attainment of release.

original: Sahacaritamattenāti sīhanādena saha vassakaraṇamattena. Sīhena sīhanādaṃ nadantena
analyzed: sahacarita mattena ati sīha nādena saha vassakaraṇa mattena sīhena sīha nādam nadantena
translated: ‘In the mere act of companionship’ means in the mere act of the making of the rains residence together with the lion’s roar,

original: saheva siṅgālena attano siṅgālaravakaraṇamattena. Kotthukoti khuddakakotthu. Āsaṅkitasamācāroti
analyzed: saha iva siṅgālena siṅgāla rava karaṇa mattena kotthuko ti khuddaka kotthu āsaṅkita samācāro ti
translated: in the mere act of the making of the jackal’s howl together with the lion’s roar. ‘In the mere act of the jackal’s howl’ means in the mere act of the jackal’s howl. ‘In the mere act of the little howl’ means in the mere act of the little howl. ‘In the mere act of the suspicious conduct’ means

original: attanā ca parehi ca āsaṅkitabbasamācāro. Sappurisānanti buddhādīnaṃ.
analyzed: attanā ca parehi ca āsaṅkitabba samācāraḥ buddha ādīnam
translated: in the mere act of the conduct that is suspicious to oneself and to others. ‘In the mere act of the conduct that is not suspicious to good people’ means in the mere act of the conduct that is not suspicious to Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and Buddhas’ disciples.

original: Tassāti vegabbharissa devaputtassa. Sarīre anuāvisīti sarīre anupavisitvā viya āvisi.
analyzed: tassa ati vegabbharissa devaputtassa sarīre anuāvisi iti sarīre anupavisitvā viya āvisi
translated: ‘To him’: to the godling Vegajja. ‘Entered into his body’: as if entering into his body.

original: Adhimuccīti yathā gahitassa vasena cittaṃ na vattati, attano eva vase vattati, evaṃ
analyzed: adhimuccī iti yathā gahitassa vasena cittam na vattati attanaḥ eva vase vattati evam
translated: ‘He resolved’: he resolved thus: ‘My mind shall not be subject to what I have grasped, but shall be subject to me alone.’

original: adhiṭṭhahi. Āyuttāti dassanena saṃyuttā. Pavivekiyanti kappakavatthabhuñjanasenāsanehi
analyzed: āyuttā ati dassanena saṃyuttā pavivekiyanti kappaka vattha bhuñjana senāsanehi
translated: ‘United with’: united with the seeing. ‘Solitary’: the state of being solitary by means of the robe, alms food, resting place, and medicinal requisites.

original: pavivittabhāvaṃ. Tenāha “te kirā”tiādi. Rūpe niviṭṭhāti cakkhurūpadhamme abhiniviṭṭhā.
analyzed: pavivitta bhāvam tena āha te kirāti ādi rūpe niviṭṭhā ati cakkhu rūpa dhamme abhiniviṭṭhā
translated: Hence he said ‘They are called’ . ‘Fixed on form’: fixed on the eye and visible-form element.

original: Tenāha “taṇhādiṭṭhīhi patiṭṭhitā”ti. Devalokapatthanakāmāti devalokasseva abhipatthanakāmā.
analyzed: tena āha taṇhā diṭṭhīhi patiṭṭhitā iti deva loka patthana kāmā ati deva lokassa iva abhipatthana kāmā
translated: Hence he said ‘Established by craving and views.’ ‘Desiring the heavenly world’: desiring the heavenly world alone.

original: Maraṇadhammatāya mātiyā. Tenāha “mātiyāti maccā”ti. Paralokatthāyāti parasampattibhāvāya lokassa atthāya.
analyzed: maraṇa dhamma tāya mātiyā tena āha mātiyā ati maccā ati para loka tthāya ati para sampatti bhāvāya lokassa atthāya
translated: ‘Subject to death’: subject to death because of the nature of death. Hence he said ‘Those who die are called mortal.’ ‘For the sake of the world beyond’: for the sake of the world of the other side, i.e. for the sake of the other’s excellence.

original: Pabhāsavaṇṇāti pabhāya samānavaṇṇā. Kesaṃ pabhāyāti āha “candobhāsā”tiādi. Sajjhārāgapabhāsavaṇṇā
analyzed: pabhāsa vaṇṇā iti pabhāya samāna vaṇṇā kesam pabhāya iti āha candaḥ bhāsā ati ādi sajjhā rāga pabhāsa vaṇṇā
translated: ‘Having the colour of light’: having the colour of the same light. ‘Whose light?’ He said ‘The light of the moon’ . Having the colour of the light of the glow-worm.

original: indadhanupabhāsavaṇṇāti paccekaṃ yojanā. Āmo āmagandho etassa atthīti āmisaṃ. Vadhāyāti
analyzed: inda dhanu pabhāsa vaṇṇā ti paccekam yojanā āmaḥ āma gandho etassa atthi iti āmisam vadhāya ati
translated: The colour of the sun and moon’s light, etc., are to be construed separately. It has the smell of raw flesh, thus it is raw flesh . To kill is to

original: viddhaṃsituṃ. Rūpāti rūpāyatanādirūpidhammā.🔽Rājagahasamīpappavattīnaṃ rājagahiyānaṃ. “Seto”ti kelāsakūṭo adhippetoti āha “setoti
analyzed: vid haṃsitum rūpā ati rūpa āyatana ādi rūpi dhammā  rājagaha samīpa ppavattīnam rājagahiyānam seto ti kelāsa kūṭaḥ adhippeto ti āha seto ti
translated: destroy. Form is the form element, etc., which are material phenomena.

original: kelāso”ti. Kenaci na ghaṭṭetīti aghaṃ, antalikkhanti āha “aghagāmīnanti ākāsagāmīna”nti.
analyzed: kelāso ti kenacid na ghaṭṭeti iti agham āha agha gāmīnanti ākāsa gāmīnanti
translated: The Rājagaha people who lived near Rājagaha. “White” is the peak of Kelāsa, thus he says “White is Kelāsa.” It does not collide with anything, thus it is non-colliding . Through the sky, thus he says “Through the non-colliding, through the sky.”

original: Udakaṃ dhīyati etthāti udadhi, mahodadhi. Vipuloti vepullapabbato. Himavantapabbatānanti
analyzed: udakam dhīyati ettha ati udadhi mahodadhi vipulaḥ iti vepulla pabbataḥ himavanta pabbatānam ti
translated: Water is collected here, thus it is the ocean, the great ocean. Vipula is the mountain Ve-pulla. The mountain parts of the Himalayas, thus

original: himavantapabbatabhāgānaṃ. Buddho seṭṭho sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttivimuttiñāṇadassanādīhi sabbaguṇehi.
analyzed: himavanta pabbata bhāgānam buddho seṭṭhaḥ sīla samādhi paññā vimutti vimutti ñāṇa dassana ādīhi sabba guṇehi
translated: he says “The mountain parts of the Himalayas.” The Buddha is the best through all good qualities such as virtue, concentration, wisdom, liberation, and knowledge and vision of liberation.

original: Nānātitthiyasāvakasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nānā titthiya sāvaka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sutta on the Disciples of Various Sects is finished.

original: Tatiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third section is finished.

original: Sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: In the commentary on the Connected Discourses

original: Devaputtasaṃyuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the Connected Discourses with the Gods is finished.

original: 3. Kosalasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: kosalasaṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with the Kosalans

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggo
analyzed: paṭhama vaggo
translated: 1. The First Chapter

original: 1. Daharasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dahara sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the First Discourse

original: 112. Bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodīti bhagavato guṇe ajānanto kosalarājā attano khattiyamānena
analyzed: bhagavatā saddhim sammodi iti bhagavataḥ guṇe a jānantaḥ kosala rājā attanaḥ khattiya mānena
translated: He exchanged greetings with the Exalted One: not knowing the Exalted One’s virtues, the king of Kosala, out of his own pride as a khattiya,

original: kevalaṃ bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. Paṭhamāgate hi satthari tassa sammoditākāraṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: kevalam bhagavatā saddhim sammodi paṭhama āgate hi satthari tassa sammodita ākāram dassetuṃ
translated: simply exchanged greetings with the Exalted One. For when the Teacher first arrived,

original: “yathā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yathā khamanīyādīni pucchantoti yathā bhagavā “kacci te, mahārāja,
analyzed: yathā atiādi vuttam yathā khamanīya ādīni pucchanto ti yathā bhagavā kacci te mahā rāja
translated: “As” and so on are said to show the way in which he exchanged greetings. As he asked about what was to be forgiven and so on,🔽so the Exalted One first exchanged greetings with the king, saying: “I hope, great king, that things are going well for you,

original: khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīya”ntiādinā tena raññā saddhiṃ paṭhamaṃ pavattamodo ahosi
analyzed: khamanīyam kacci yāpanīya nti ādinā tena raññā saddhim paṭhamam pavatta modaḥ ahosi
translated: that you are getting by, that you are comfortable.”

original: pubbabhāsitāya, tadanukaraṇena evaṃ sopi rājā bhagavatā saddhiṃ samappavattamodo🔽ahosīti yojanā. Taṃ pana samappavattamodanaṃ upamāya dassetuṃ “sītodakaṃ viyā”tiādi
analyzed: pubba bhāsitāya tad anukaraṇena evam saḥ api rājā bhagavatā saddhim sama ppavatta modaḥ  ahosi iti yojanā tam pana sama ppavattam odanam upamāya dassetum sīta udakam viya ātiādi
translated: Following the other’s lead, the king also exchanged greetings with the Exalted One in the same way.🔽To show this exchange of greetings by means of a simile,

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha sammoditanti saṃsanditaṃ ekībhāvanti sammodanakiriyāya samānataṃ ekarūpataṃ,
analyzed: vuttam tattha sammoditanti saṃsanditam ekībhāvanti sammodana kiriyāya samāna tam eka rūpa tam
translated: “like cool water” and so on are said. Herein, “he exchanged greetings” means he made contact, he became one, he became of the same form,

original: khamanīyanti “idaṃ catucakkaṃ navadvāraṃ sarīrayantaṃ dukkhabahulatāya sabhāvato🔽dussahaṃ, kacci khamituṃ sakkuṇeyya”nti pucchati. Yāpanīyanti paccayāyattavuttikaṃ🔽cirapabandhasaṅkhātāya yāpanāya kacci yāpetuṃ sakkuṇeyyaṃ. Sīsarogādiābādhābhāvena🔽kacci appābādhaṃ. Dukkhajīvikābhāvena kacci appātaṅkaṃ. Taṃtaṃkiccakaraṇe uṭṭhānasukhatāya
analyzed: idam catu cakkam nava dvāram sarīrayantam dukkha bahula tāya sabhāvataḥ  dussaham kacci khamitum sakkuṇeyyanti pucchati yāpanīya nti paccaya āyatta vuttikam  cira apabandha saṅkhātāya yāpanāya kacci yāpetum sakkuṇeyyam sīsa roga ādi ābādha abhāvena  kacci appa ābādham dukkha jīvikā bhāvena kacci appa ātaṅkam taṃtaṃ kicca karaṇe uṭṭhāna sukha tāya
translated: ‘Bearable’? ‘This body, with its four sides, its nine openings, and its many hundreds of worms, is hard to bear because of the great amount of suffering it has in its very nature. I wonder if he can bear it.’ ‘Endurable’? ‘It is to be endured because it is bound to last a long time. I wonder if he can endure it.’ ‘With little illness’? ‘I wonder if he has little illness due to the absence of such ailments as those of wind, bile, phlegm, etc.,’ ‘With little trouble’? ‘I wonder if he has little trouble due to the absence of difficulty in getting almsfood, etc.,’ ‘Is he vigorous’? ‘I wonder if he is happy to rise up to do his duties here and there.’

original: kacci lahuṭṭhānaṃ. Tadanurūpabalayogato kacci balaṃ. Sukhavihārasambhavena kacci🔽phāsuvihāro atthīti tattha tattha kacci-saddaṃ yojetvā attho veditabbo. Balavappattā🔽pīti pītiyeva. Taruṇapīti pāmojjaṃ. Sammodanaṃ janeti karotīti sammodanīyaṃ. Sammoditabbato🔽sammodanīyanti imaṃ pana atthaṃ dassento “sammodituṃ yuttabhāvato”ti āha. Saritabbabhāvatoti
analyzed: kacci lahu ṭṭhānam tad anurūpa bala yogato kacci balam sukha vihāra sambhavena kacci 🔽phāsu vihāraḥ atthi iti tattha tattha kacci saddam yojetvā atthaḥ veditabbaḥ balava pattā 🔽pīti pītiyā iva taruṇa pīti pāmojjam sammodanam janeti karoti iti sammodanīyam sammoditabbataḥ 🔽sammodanīyanti imam pana attham dassentaḥ sammoditum yutta bhāvato ti āha saritabba bhāvato ti
translated: ‘Bearable’ : ‘This body, which is a machine with four wheels and nine doors, is hard to bear because of the great amount of suffering in its very nature. I wonder if you can bear it? ‘ ‘Manageable’ : ‘It is managed by conditions. I wonder if you can manage it, which is to say, keep it going, by managing its keeping-going, which is called “long endurance” ? ‘ ‘With little affliction’ : ‘I wonder if you have little affliction by way of such sicknesses as head-disease, etc.? ‘ ‘With little fever’ : ‘I wonder if you have little fever by way of suffering in livelihood, etc.? ‘ ‘Promptly-rising’ : ‘I wonder if you are promptly rising by reason of the ease of rising for the doing of such duties as are to be done? ‘ ‘Strength’ : ‘I wonder if you have strength by reason of the possession of strength appropriate to that? ‘ ‘Pleasant abiding’ : ‘I wonder if you have pleasant abiding by reason of the possession of the kind of abiding that is pleasant? ‘ The meaning should be understood in this way by supplying the word ‘I wonder’ in each case. ‘Joy’ is just the joy that has reached strength. ‘Gladness’ is tender joy. ‘Agreeable’ is that which causes gladness, which makes it. But showing the meaning of this word ‘agreeable’ in the way beginning ‘Because of being fit for gladness’ he said ‘Because of being fit for gladness’ . ‘Because of being fit for being spoken to’ .

original: anussaritabbabhāvato. “Saraṇīya”nti vattabbe dīghaṃ katvā “sāraṇīya”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: anussaritabba bhāvataḥ saraṇīyanti vattabbe dīgham katvā sāraṇīyanti vuttam
translated: The word “sāraṇīya” is formed by lengthening the vowel of the word “saraṇīya” which is the correct form.

original: Suyyamānasukhatoti āpāthamadhurataṃ āha, anussariyamānasukhatoti vimaddaramaṇīyataṃ.
analyzed: āha anussariyamāna sukhatā iti vimadda ramaṇīya tam
translated: “Easy to listen to” means that it is pleasant to hear, and “easy to remember” means that it is pleasant to reflect upon.

original: Byañjanaparisuddhatāyāti sabhāvaniruttibhāvena tassā kathāya vacanacāturiyamāha,
analyzed: byañjana parisuddha tāya ati sabhāva nirutti bhāvena tassā kathāya vacana cāturiyam āha
translated: “Purity of expression” means the fourfold purity of the Buddha’s speech, namely, purity of voice, purity of language, purity of syllables, and purity of articulation.🔽“Purity of meaning” means that the meaning is free from defilements.

original: atthaparisuddhatāyāti atthassa nirupakkilesataṃ. Anekehi pariyāyehīti anekehi kāraṇehi.
analyzed: attha parisuddha tāya ati atthassa nirupakkilesa tam anekehi pariyāyehi iti anekehi kāraṇehi
translated: “By many approaches” means by many reasons.🔽“Not having seen” means not having seen him by approaching him.

original: Adiṭṭhattāti upasaṅkamanavasena adiṭṭhattā. Guṇāguṇavasenāti guṇavasena gambhīrabhāvaṃ
analyzed: a diṭṭha ttā ati upasaṅkamana vasena a diṭṭha ttā guṇa a guṇa vasena ati guṇa vasena gambhīra bhāvam
translated: “By way of good qualities and bad qualities” means by way of good qualities, which are profound,🔽or by way of bad qualities, which are obvious.

original: vā aguṇavasena uttānabhāvaṃ vā. Ovaṭṭikasāraṃ katvāti ovaṭṭikāya gahetabbasāravatthuṃ
analyzed: vā aguṇa vasena uttāna bhāvam vā ovaṭṭika sāram katvā ati ovaṭṭikāya gahetabba sāra vatthum
translated: “As if extracting the essence from the center of a reed” means as if taking the essence that can be grasped from the center of a reed.

original: katvā. Lokanissaraṇabhavokkantipañhanti lokato nissaṭabhāvapañhañceva ādito bhavokkamanapañhañca.
analyzed: katvā loka nissaraṇa bhava ukkanti pañhanti lokataḥ nissaṭa bhāva pañhan ca iva āditas bhava ukkamana pañhan ca
translated: “The question about the escape from the world and the emergence from existence” means the question about the escape from the world and the emergence from existence at the beginning.

original: Satthu sammāsambuddhataṃ pucchanto hi “kiṃ bhavaṃ gotamo sabbalokato nissaṭo, sabbasattehi
analyzed: satthu sammāsambuddha tam pucchantaḥ hi kim bhavam gotamaḥ sabba lokataḥ nissaṭaḥ sabba sattehi
translated: For one who asks about the Buddha’s perfect enlightenment asks whether the Blessed One has escaped from the whole world and from all beings,

original: ca jeṭṭho”ti? Pucchati nāma. Yathā hi satthu sammāsambuddhatāya lokato nissaṭatā
analyzed: ca jeṭṭhaḥ iti pucchati nāma yathā hi satthu sammāsambuddha tāya lokataḥ nissaṭa tā
translated: and the elder?” He asks, “How is it known that the Exalted One is fully enlightened? For it is known in the world that he has renounced the world,

original: viññāyati, evaṃ sabbasattehi jeṭṭhabhāvato seṭṭhabhāvato. Svāyamattho aggapasādasuttādīhi
analyzed: viññāyati evam sabba sattehi jeṭṭha bhāvato seṭṭha bhāvato svāyam atthaḥ agga pasāda sutta ādīhi
translated: just as it is known that he is the elder and the best of all beings by virtue of his preeminence and excellence. This meaning should be elucidated by the Aggap satisutta and other suttas.

original: vibhāvetabbo. Kathaṃ pana sambuddhatā viññāyatīti? Aviparītadhammadesanato. Ayamettha
analyzed: vibhāvetabbo katham pana sambuddha tā viññāyati iti aviparīta dhamma desanato ayam ettha
translated: But how is his full enlightenment known? By virtue of his teaching the Dhamma without distortion. This is the

original: saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimaggasaṃvaṇṇanādīsu vuttanayena veditabbo.
analyzed: saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magga saṃvaṇṇanā ādīsu vutta nayena veditabbaḥ
translated: meaning in brief. The detailed explanation should be understood in the way given in the Visuddhimagga commentary, etc.

original: Rājā satthu aviparītadhammadesanaṃ ajānanto tato evassa sammāsambodhiṃ asaddahanto🔽“vuḍḍhataresupi cirapabbajitesu sammāsambuddhabhāve alabbhamāne tabbiparīte kathaṃ
analyzed: rājā satthu a viparīta dhamma desanam a jānantaḥ tatas evassa sammāsambodhim a saddahantaḥ  vuḍḍhataresu pi cira pabbajitesu sammāsambuddha bhāve a labbhamāne tad biparīte katham
translated: Not knowing that the Exalted One’s teaching of the Dhamma is without distortion, the king, who does not believe in his full enlightenment,

original: labbheyyā”ti maññamāno “kiṃ pana bhavaṃ gotamo”tiādiṃ vakkhati. Rājā attano laddhiyā
analyzed: labbheyya ati maññamāno kim pana bhavam gotama utiādim vakkhati rājā attanaḥ laddhiyā
translated: thinks: “If the state of full enlightenment is not found in those who have gone forth in the past and who are senior to him, how could it be found in one who is the opposite of them?” Thinking thus, he says: “But, Master Gotama, is it possible that an ascetic or brahmin should find such a path and way of practice?” The king does not ask this question out of his own conviction,

original: na pucchati attano sammukhā tehi asammāsambuddhabhāvasseva paṭiññātattā. Yasmā te
analyzed: na pucchati attanaḥ sammukhā tehi asammāsambuddha bhāvassa iva paṭiññāta ttā yasmā te
translated: but because he has heard that they have declared themselves to be fully enlightened.

original: musāvāditāya attano upaṭṭhākādīnaṃ “buddhā maya”nti paṭijāniṃsu, tasmā vuttaṃ “loke
analyzed: musāvāditāya attanaḥ upaṭṭhāka ādīnam buddhāḥ mayanti paṭijāniṃsu tasmai vuttam loke
translated: They claimed to be Buddhas before their own attendants and so on, because of their lying. Therefore it is said, “he asks in accordance with the belief of the world.”

original: mahājanena gahitapaṭiññāvasena pucchatī”ti. Svāyamattho āgamissati. Buddhasīhanādanti🔽buddhānaṃ eva āveṇikaṃ sīhanādaṃ. Kāmaṃ maggañāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, sambodhiñāṇe
analyzed: mahājanena gahita paṭiññā vasena pucchati iti svāyam atthaḥ āgamissati buddha sīha nādanti  buddhānam eva āveṇikam sīhanādam kāmam magga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānam sabbaññuta ññāṇam sambodhi ñāṇe
translated: This matter will come up later. The lion’s roar of the Enlightened One:

original: pana gahite taṃ atthato gahitameva hotīti vuttaṃ “sabbaññutaññāṇasaṅkhātaṃ sammāsambodhi”nti.
analyzed: pana gahite tam atthataḥ gahitam eva hoti iti vuttam sabbaññu ta ññāṇa saṅkhātam sammāsambodhin ti
translated: the unique lion’s roar of the Buddhas. The knowledge of omniscience has the path-knowledge as its proximate cause. But when the knowledge of enlightenment is mentioned, that is included in meaning. Therefore it is said, “the supreme enlightenment called omniscience.”

original: Pabbajjūpagamanenāti yāya kāyaci pabbajjāya upagamanamattena samaṇā, na samitapāpatāya.
analyzed: pabbajja upagamanena ati yāya kāyaci pabbajjāya upagamana mattena samaṇāḥ na samita pāpa tāya
translated: By going forth: by going forth in any sect, they are ascetics, not by the quieting of defilements.

original: Jātivasenāti jātimattena brāhmaṇā, na bāhitapāpatāya. Pabbajitasamūhasaṅkhāto saṅghoti
analyzed: jāti vasena ati jātimattena brāhmaṇāḥ na bāhita pāpa tāya pabbajita samūha saṅkhāto saṅghaḥ ti
translated: By birth: by mere birth they are brahmans, not by the casting out of defilements. The community: the community is a collection of those gone forth,

original: pabbajitasamūhatāmattena saṅgho, na niyyānikadiṭṭhivisuddhasīlasāmaññavasena saṃhatattāti
analyzed: pabbajita samūha tā mattena saṅghaḥ na niyyānika diṭṭhi visuddha sīla sāmañña vasena saṃhata ttā ti
translated: not a unity by virtue of the purity of view that leads out , or by virtue of the common practice of virtue.

original: adhippāyo. Etesaṃ atthīti etesaṃ sabbaññupaṭiññātānaṃ parivārabhūto atthi. Svevāti
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ etesam atthi iti etesam sabbaññu paṭiññātānam parivāra bhūtaḥ atthi su eva ati
translated: The word “they” refers to those who claim to be omniscient.

original: pabbajitasamūhasaṅkhāto eva. Keci pana “pabbajitasamūhavasena. Saṅghino, gahaṭṭhasamūhavasena
analyzed: pabbajita samūha saṅkhātaḥ eva keci pana pabbajita samūha vasena saṅghinaḥ gahaṭṭha samūha vasena
translated: Some say: “They are called ‘monks’ in the sense of a community of monks, and ‘ascetics’ in the sense of a community of householders.”

original: gaṇino”ti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ gaṇe eva loke saṅghasaddassa niruḷhattā.
analyzed: gaṇinaḥ iti vadanti tam tesam matimattam gaṇe eva loke saṅgha saddassa niruḷha ttā
translated: But this is mere conjecture on their part, since the word “saṅgha” is well known in the world to mean a community.🔽In the sense of teaching the training in good conduct: in the sense of teaching the training in good conduct such as the practice of the naked ascetics.

original: Ācārasikkhāpanavasenāti acelakavatacariyādi-ācārasikkhāpanavasena. Pākaṭāti saṅghīādibhāvena
analyzed: ācāra sikkhāpana vasena ati acelakavata cariyā ādi ācāra sikkhāpana vasena pākaṭā ati saṅghī ādi bhāvena
translated: Well known: made known by the state of being a saṅgha, etc.

original: pakāsitā. “Appicchā”ti vatvā tattha labbhamānaṃ appicchataṃ dassetuṃ “apicchatāya
analyzed: pakāsitā appicchā ati vatvā tattha labbhamānam appicchatam dassetum appicchatāya
translated: After saying “few in their desires,” in order to show the kind of fewness of desires found in them, he says, “they do not even object to a robe-cloth.”

original: vatthampi na nivāsentī”ti vuttaṃ. Na hi tesu sāsanikesu viya santaguṇaniguhanā appicchā🔽labbhatīti. Yasoti kittisaddo. Taranti etena saṃsāroghanti evaṃ sammatattā titthaṃ
analyzed: vattham pi na nivāsenti iti vuttam na hi tesu sāsanikesu viya santa guṇa niguhanā appicchā  labbhati iti yasoti kitti saddo taranti etena evam sammata ttā tittham
translated: For among them, as among the teachers of the Dispensation, fewness of desires is not found in the form of concealing one’s good qualities.🔽A ford: it is called a “ford” because people are thought to cross the flood of saṃsāra by means of it.🔽The word “ford” is a designation for a method.

original: vuccati laddhīti āha “titthakarāti laddhikarā”ti. Sādhusammatāti “sādhū”ti sammatā,
analyzed: vuccati laddhi iti āha titthakarā ati laddhi karā ati sādhu sammatā ati sādhu uti sammatā
translated: Well-regarded: regarded as “good.”

original: na sādhūhi sammatāti āha “santo…pe… puthujjanassā”ti.
analyzed: na sādhūhi sammatā ati āha santope puthujjanassa ati
translated: “Not approved by the good” : he says “the good are those who are … and the ordinary man is not.”

original: Kappakolāhalanti kappato kolāhalaṃ, “kappuṭṭhānaṃ bhavissatī”ti devaputtehi ugghositamahāsaddo.
analyzed: kappa kolāhalanti kappataḥ kolāhalam kappu ṭṭhānam bhavissati iti devaputtehi ugghosita mahā saddaḥ
translated: “The uproar of the kappas” : the uproar of the kappas, the great noise proclaimed by the gods, “There will be a kappuṭṭhāna.”

original: Imeti pūraṇādayo. Buddhakolāhalanti devatāhi ghositaṃ buddhakolāhalaṃ. Payirupāsitvāti
analyzed: imāḥ iti pūraṇa ādayaḥ buddha kolāhalanti devatāhi ghositam buddha kolāhalam payiḥ upāsitvā ati
translated: “These” : Pūraṇa and the others. “The uproar of the Buddha” : the uproar of the Buddha proclaimed by the gods. “Having paid homage” :

original: purisasutiparamparāya sutvā. Cintāmaṇivijjā nāma paracittajānāpanavijjā. Sā kevaṭṭasutte
analyzed: purisa suti paramparāya sutvā cintāmaṇi vijjā nāma para citta jānāpana vijjā sā kevaṭṭa sutte
translated: having heard by a succession of men. “The thought-gem knowledge” : the knowledge of reading the thoughts of others. That is called “maṇikā” in the Kevaṭṭa Sutta.

original: “maṇikā”ti āgatā, ādi-saddena gandhārisambhavavijjādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Tattha gandhāriyā
analyzed: āgatā ādi saddena gandhāri sambhava vijjā ādim saṅgaṇhāti tattha gandhāriyā
translated: By the word “etc.” he includes the knowledge of the origin of the Gandhāri, etc. There the Gandhāri

original: vikubbanaṃ dasseti. Attabhāveti sarīre. Rājusmāti rājatejo.🔽Sukkadhammoti anavajjadhammo nikkilesatā. Idaṃ gahetvāti idaṃ parammukhā “mayaṃ buddhā”ti
analyzed: vikubbanam dasseti atta bhāvā iti sarīre  sukka dhammaḥ ti anavajja dhammaḥ nikkilesa tā idam gahetvā ati idam parammukhāḥ mayam buddha ati
translated: shows the transformation of his body. “The body” : the physical frame. “The royal splendor” : the splendor of a king.

original: vatvā attano sammukhā “na mayaṃ buddhā”ti tehi vuttavacanaṃ gahetvā. Evamāhāti “yepi
analyzed: vatvā attanaḥ sammukhāḥ na mayam buddhā ati tehi vutta vacanam gahetvā evam āha ati ye pi
translated: “The good state” : the blameless state, the state of being free from defilements. “Having taken this” : having taken this statement of theirs, which they said to his face, “We are Buddhas,” but which they said behind his back, “We are not Buddhas.” “Thus he said” : “Those who

original: te, bho gotama…pe… navo ca pabbajjāyā”ti evaṃ avoca. Attano paṭiññaṃ gahetvāti “na🔽mayaṃ buddhā”ti tesaṃ attano purato pavattitaṃ paṭiññaṃ gahetvā. Īdise ṭhāne kiṃ-saddo🔽paṭisedhavācako hotīti vuttaṃ “kinti paṭikkhepavacana”nti, kasmā paṭijānātīti attho?🔽Na uññātabbāti na garahitabbā. Garahattho hi ayaṃ u-saddo. “Daharo”ti adhikatattā🔽vakkhamānattā ca “khattiyoti rājakumāro”ti vuttaṃ. Urasā gacchatīti urago, yo koci🔽sappo, idha pana adhippetaṃ dassetuṃ “āsīviso”ti āha. Sīlavantaṃ pabbajitaṃ dasseti
analyzed: te bho gotama pe navaḥ ca pabbajjāya ati evam avoca attanaḥ paṭiññam gahetvā ati na  mayam buddhā ti tesam attanaḥ puratas pavattitam paṭiññam gahetvā īdise ṭhāne kiṃsaddaḥ  paṭisedha vācakaḥ hoti iti vuttam kinti paṭikkhepa vacananti kasmā paṭijānāti iti atthaḥ  na uññātabbā ati na garahitabbā garaha atthaḥ hi ayam usaddaḥ daharaḥ ti adhikata ttā  ca khattiyo ti rāja kumāro ti vuttam urasā gacchati iti uragaḥ yo koci  sappaḥ idha pana adhippetam dassetum āsīvisaḥ ti āha sīlavantam pabbajitam dasseti

original: sāmaññato “bhikkhū”ti vadanto. Idha pana yasmā “bhavampi no gotamo”tiādinā bhagavantaṃ🔽uddissa kathaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi, tasmā bhagavā attānaṃ abbhantaraṃ akāsi. Yadipi viseso
analyzed: sāmaññataḥ bhikkhū ti vadantaḥ idha pana yasmai no gotama iti ādinā bhagavantam 🔽uddissa katham samuṭṭhāpesi tasmai bhagavā attānam abbhantaram akāsi yadi api viseso
translated: “We are not ascetics, Master Gotama, we are naked ascetics.” He said: “But, sirs, you are called ‘naked ascetics’ by Master Gotama.” “We are called ‘naked ascetics’ by Master Gotama, and we are called ‘ascetics’ by others. We are called ‘naked ascetics’ by Master Gotama, and we are called ‘ascetics’ by others.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and an ascetic?” “We do not know, Master Gotama, we do not know, Master Gotama.” “But, sirs, what is the difference between a naked ascetic and

original: sāmaññajotanāya vibhāvito hoti, saṃsayuppattidīpakaṃ noti vuttaggahaṇaṃ pana taṃ🔽paricchijjatīti. Tenāha “desanākusalatāyā”tiādi. Idāni avaññāparibhave payogato vibhāvetuṃ
analyzed: sāmañña jotanāya vibhāvitaḥ hoti saṃsaya uppatti dīpakam no ti vutta ggahaṇam pana tam  paricchijjati iti tena āha desanā kusala tāya atiādi idāni avaññā paribhave payogataḥ vibhāvetum
translated: and it is elucidated by the light of the True Ideal. The words “and it is the source of the arising of doubt” are said in order to show that.

original: “ettha cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha acittīkatākāravasena avaññāya pākaṭabhāvo, vambhanavasena
analyzed: ettha ca atiādi vuttam tattha acittīkata ākāra vasena avaññāya pākaṭa bhāvaḥ vambhana vasena
translated: It is discerned thus. Hence he said “because of lack of skill in teaching” . Now, in order to elucidate the abuse and contempt by way of application he said “And here” . Herein, the manifestation of abuse is by the mode of non-esteeming,🔽and the manifestation of contempt is by the mode of disparaging.

original: paribhavassāti adhippāyena kāyapayogavasena avaññā dassitā, vacīpayogavasena paribhavo,
analyzed: paribhavassa ati adhippāyena kāya payoga vasena avaññā dassitā vacī payoga vasena paribhavo
translated: Thus it is intended that abuse is shown by bodily application and contempt by verbal application.🔽But both are taken by way of the division in both instances.

original: ubhayaṃ pana ubhayatthāpi pabhedato gahitaṃ, avaññaparibhavānaṃ dvinnampi ubhayattha
analyzed: ubhayam pana ubhayattha api pabhedataḥ gahitam avañña paribhavānam dvinnam pi ubhayattha
translated: The inclusion of both abuse and contempt in both instances is all this.

original: pariggaho. Taṃ sabbampīti taṃ avaññādi sabbampi. Catūsupi taṃ na kātabbameva sampati
analyzed: pariggahaḥ tam sabbam pi iti tam avaññā ādi sabbam pi catūsu pi tam na kātabbam eva sampati
translated: All this abuse, etc., is not to be done by one who is wise,

original: āyatiñca anatthāvahattā.
analyzed: āyatiḥ ca
translated: because it brings misfortune in the present and in the future.

original: Tadatthadīpanāti tassa ādito vuttassa atthassa dīpanā. Visesatthadīpanāti tato visiṭṭhatthadīpanā.
analyzed: tad attha dīpanā ti tassa āditas vuttassa atthassa dīpanā visesa ttha dīpanā ti tatas visiṭṭha ttha dīpanā
translated: The elucidation of its meaning is the elucidation of the meaning stated at the beginning. The elucidation of the special meaning is the elucidation of the meaning that is distinguished from that.

original: Khettānaṃ adhipatīti khattiyoti niruttinayena saddasiddhi veditabbā. Khettato vivādā
analyzed: khettānam adhipati iti khattiyaḥ ti nirutti nayena sadda siddhi veditabbā khettataḥ vivādā
translated: The derivation of the word “warrior” should be understood as follows: “He is the lord of fields” (khettam adhipati) .🔽The worldlings say: “He protects beings from danger” (satte tāyati) .

original: satte tāyatīti khattiyoti lokiyā kathayanti. “Mahāsammato, khattiyo, rājā”ti evamāgatesu
analyzed: satte tāyati iti khattiyaḥ iti lokiyā kathayanti mahāsammataḥ khattiyaḥ rājā ati evam āgatesu
translated: In the passage: “The Great Elect, the warrior, the king” (mahāsammato khattiyo rājā) ,🔽the second is a word of common usage (akkharanti samaññā) .

original: imesu dutiyaṃ. Akkharanti samaññā. Sā hi udayabbayābhāvato “na kadāci kharatīti akkhara”nti
analyzed: imesu dutiyam akkharanti samaññā sā hi udaya bbaya abhāvataḥ na kadāci kharati iti akkharanti
translated: It is called “akkharā” because it is never worn out (na kadāci kharatīti akkharā) , since it has no beginning or end.🔽Therefore it is said: “Name and clan do not grow old” (nāmagottaṃ na jīrati) .

original: vuttā. Tenāha “nāmagottaṃ na jīratī”ti. Jātisampannanti sampannajātiṃ ativisuddhajātiṃ.
analyzed: vuttā tena āha nāma gottam na jīrati iti jāti sampannam ati sampanna jātim ati visuddha jātim
translated: “Possessed of a good birth” (jātisampannā) means having a good birth, a very pure birth.🔽“Three clans” (tīṇi kulāni) means the clans of brahmins, merchants, and workers.

original: Tīṇi kulānīti brāhmaṇavessasuddakulāni. Atikkamitvāti attano jātisampattiyā abhibhavitvā.
analyzed: tīṇi kulāni iti brāhmaṇa vessa sudda kulāni atikkamitvā ati attanaḥ jāti sampattiyāḥ abhibhavitvā
translated: “Having surpassed” (atikkanta) means having overcome by his own good birth.🔽The word “name” (nāma) is stated as a mere name (nāmapadaṃ vuttaṃ) ; it requires a word of explanation (ākhyātapadaṃ apekkhateva) .

original: Kevalaṃ nāmapadaṃ vuttaṃ ākhyātapadaṃ apekkhatevāti āha “ṭhānaṃ hīti kāraṇaṃ vijjatī”ti.
analyzed: kevalam nāma padam vuttam ākhyāta padam apekkhatā iva ati āha ṭhānam hi iti kāraṇam vijjati iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “There is a reason, there is a cause” (ṭhānaṃ hīti kāraṇaṃ vijjati) .

original: Uddhaṭadaṇḍenāti samantato ubbhatena daṇḍena sāsanena, balavaṃ upakkamaṃ garukaṃ
analyzed: uddhaṭa daṇḍena ati samantataḥ ubbhatena daṇḍena sāsanena balavam upakkamam garukam
translated: “With uplifted rod” (uddhṭṭadaṇḍā) means with a rod of punishment uplifted all around, with a strong attack, a heavy🔽king.

original: rājānampi. Taṃ khattiyaṃ parivajjeyyāti khattiyaṃ avaññāparibhavakaraṇato vajjeyya.
analyzed: rājānam pi tam khattiyam parivajjeyya ati khattiyam a vaññā paribhava karaṇataḥ vajjeyya
