translated: “One should avoid that warrior” (taṃ khattiyaṃ parivajjeyya) means one should avoid that warrior by not despising and humiliating him.

original: Tenāha “na ghaṭṭeyyā”ti.🔽Uragassa ca nānāvidhavaṇṇaggahaṇe kāraṇaṃ vadati “yena yena hī”tiādinā. Bahubhakkhanti🔽mahābhakkhaṃ sabbabhakkhakhādakaṃ. Pāvakaṃ sodhanatthena asuddhassapi dahanena. Soti
analyzed: tena āha na ghaṭṭeyya iti  uragassa ca nānāvidha vaṇṇa ggahaṇe kāraṇam vadati yena yena hi iti ādinā  mahābhakkham sabba bhakkha khādakam pāvakam sodhana tthena a suddhassa api dahanena soti
translated: Hence he said, “He should not strike it.”

original: maggo. Kaṇho vattanī imassāti kaṇhavattanī. Mahanto aggikkhandho hutvā. Yāvabrahmalokappamāṇoti
analyzed: maggaḥ kaṇhaḥ vattanī imassa ati kaṇha vattanī mahantaḥ aggi kkhandhaḥ hutvā yāva brahmaloka ppamāṇaḥ iti
translated: He explains the reason for the serpent’s taking up various colours thus: “By whatever colour” , etc. “Many-eater” is a great eater, an eater of all. “Fire” is in the sense of burning, of burning even the impure. “That” is the path. “Black-travelled” is that which has a black path. “A great mass of fire” is a great mass of flames. “As far as the world of Brahmā” is as far as the world of Brahmā.

original: kappavuṭṭhānakāle araññe agginā gahite kālantare eva kaṭṭhatiṇarukkhādisambhavoti🔽dassetuṃ “jāyanti tattha pārohā”ti pāḷiyaṃ vuttanti dassento “tatthā”tiādimāha.🔽Ḍahituṃ na sakkoti paccakkosanādinā. Vinassanti samaṇatejasā vināsitattā. “Na tassā”ti
analyzed: kappa vuṭṭhāna kāle araññe agginā gahite kāla antare eva kaṭṭha tiṇa rukkha ādi sambhavaḥ ti  dassetum jāyanti tattha pāroha ati pāḷiyam vuttanti dassentaḥ tattha atiādim āha  ḍahitum na sakkoti paccakkosana ādinā vinassanti samaṇa tejasā vināsita ttā na tassa ati
translated: When the world is destroyed at the end of the aeon, the trees, grass, etc., which have arisen in the meantime are consumed by the forest fire.🔽In order to show this, he says “There the creepers grow” , etc., showing that it is said in the text thus.

original: ettha na-kāraṃ “vindare”ti ettha ānetvā sambandhitabbanti āha “na vindantī”ti. Vatthumattāvasiṭṭhoti
analyzed: ettha nakāram ettha ānetvā sambandhitabbanti āha na vindanti iti vatthumattā avasiṭṭhā ti
translated: It cannot burn because of the suppression of the fire, etc. They are destroyed because they are destroyed by the power of the ascetics. “Not his” is to be connected with “they find” . Hence he says “they do not find” . “Only the bare site remains” is

original: ṭhānameva nesaṃ avasissati, sayaṃ pana sabbaso saha dhanena vinassantīti attho.
analyzed: ṭhānam eva nesam avasissati sayam pana sabbaso saha dhanena vinassanti iti attho
translated: the place alone will remain, but they themselves will all be destroyed together with their wealth.

original: “Sammadeva samācare”ti ettha yathā rājādīsu sammā samācareyya, taṃ vibhāgena dassento
analyzed: sammat eva samācara iti ettha yathā rāja ādīsu sammā samācareyya tam vibhāgena dassento
translated: “One should conduct oneself properly”: here, just as one should conduct oneself properly towards kings, etc., so too one should conduct oneself properly towards all beings.🔽“A khattiya, to start with”: this is easy to understand.

original: “khattiyaṃ tāvā”tiādimāha. Taṃ suviññeyyameva. Tisso kulasampattiyoti khattiya-brāhmaṇagahapati-mahāsālakulāni
analyzed: khattiyam tāva ātiādim āha tam su viññeyyam eva tissaḥ kula sampattiyaḥ ti khattiya brāhmaṇa gahapati mahāsāla kulāni
translated: “Three kinds of excellence of family”: he refers to the families of the khattiyas, brahmins, and householders.

original: vadati. Pañca rūpibrahmaloke, cattāro arūpībrahmaloketi evaṃ nava brahmaloke kammabhavavibhāgena,
analyzed: vadati pañca rūpi brahmaloke cattāraḥ arūpī brahmaloka iti evam nava brahmaloke kamma bhava vibhāgena
translated: “Five in the form realm and four in the formless realm”: thus he refers to the nine brahmalokas.

original: sesānaṃ gaṇanānaṃ upapattibhavavibhāgena.
analyzed: sesānam gaṇanānam upapatti bhava vibhāgena
translated: The rest of the enumerations are divided according to the rebirth-process.🔽“Excellent”: very lovely.🔽Its loveliness is due to its being very desirable, to its nourishing the mind,

original: Abhikkantanti ativiya kamanīyaṃ. Sā panassā kantatā ativiya iṭṭhatāya manavaḍḍhanatāya
analyzed: abhikkantanti ativiya kamanīyam sā panassā kanta tā ativiya iṭṭha tāya manavaḍḍhana tāya
translated: and to its being beautiful.

original: sobhanatāyāti āha “atiiṭṭhaṃ atimanāpaṃ atisundaranti attho”ti. “Abhikkanta”nti vacanaṃ
analyzed: sobhana tāya iti āha ati iṭṭham ati manāpam ati sundaram ti attho ti abhikkantam ti vacanam
translated: “Excellent” is a neuter noun,

original: apekkhitvā napuṃsakaniddeso, vacanaṃ pana bhagavato dhammadesanāti tathā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: apekkhitvā napuṃsaka niddesaḥ vacanam pana bhagavataḥ dhamma desanā ti tathā vuttam
translated: but the word of the Blessed One is the Blessed One’s teaching.

original: Atthamattadassanaṃ vā etaṃ, tasmā atthavasena liṅgavibhattivipariṇāmo veditabbo.
analyzed: attham atta dassanam vai etam tasmai attha vasena liṅga vibhatti vipariṇāmaḥ veditabbo
translated: Or else it is a mere indication of the meaning, so the change of the case-ending and the change of the gender should be understood according to the meaning.

original: Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: dutiya pade pi esa iva nayo
translated: The same method applies in the second case.

original: Adhomukhaṭhapitanti kenaci adhomukhaṃ ṭhapitaṃ. Heṭṭhāmukhajātanti sabhāveneva heṭṭhāmukhaṃ🔽jātaṃ. Ugghāṭeyyāti vivaṭaṃ kareyya. Hatthe gahetvāti “puratthābhimukho uttarābhimukho
analyzed: adhomukha ṭhapitanti kenaci adhomukham ṭhapitam heṭṭhāmukha jātanti sabhāvena iva heṭṭhāmukham  jātam ugghāṭeyya ati vivaṭam kareyya hatthe gahetvā iti purattha abhimukhaḥ uttara abhimukhaḥ
translated: Turned upside down: placed upside down by someone. Turned face downwards: naturally turned face downwards.

original: vā gacchā”tiādīni avatvā hatthe gahetvā nissandehaṃ katvā “esa maggo”ti evaṃ vatvā🔽“gacchā”ti vadeyya. Kāḷapakkhacātuddasīti kāḷapakkhe cātuddasī. Nikkujjitaṃ ukkujjeyyāti
analyzed: vā gaccha ati ādīni a vatvā hatthe gahetvā nissandeham katvā esa maggo ti evam vatvā  gaccha ati vadeyya kāḷapakkha cātuddasī iti kāḷapakkhe cātuddasī nikkujjitam ukkujjeyya ati
translated: He should turn it face upwards: he should make it open. He should take hold of it with his hand: without saying “Go eastwards or go northwards,” he should take hold of his hand, make him go without hesitation, saying “This is the path,”🔽and say “Go.” The fourteenth of the dark fortnight: the fourteenth day of the waning fortnight. He should turn it face upwards: he should turn it face upwards in order to make a vessel that is not a support a support for what is to be placed on it.

original: ādheyyassa anādhārabhūtaṃ bhājanaṃ tassa ādhārabhāvāpādanavasena ukkujjeyya. Aññāṇassa
analyzed: ādheyyassa an ādhāra bhūtam bhājanam tassa ādhāra bhāva āpādana vasena ukkujjeyya aññāṇassa
translated: Because of ignorance,

original: abhimukhattā heṭṭhāmukhajātatāya saddhammavimukhaṃ, tato eva adhomukhabhāvena asaddhamme
analyzed: abhimukha ttā heṭṭhā mukha jāta tāya saddhamma vimukham tatas eva adhomukha bhāvena asat dhamme
translated: it is turned face downwards, turned away from the true Dhamma, and because of that it is turned upside down, turned towards the untrue Dhamma.

original: patitanti evaṃ padadvayaṃ yathārahaṃ yojetabbaṃ, na yathāsaṅkhayaṃ. Kāmaṃ kāmacchandādayopi
analyzed: evam pada dvayam yathāraham yojetabbam na yathāsaṅkhayam kāmam kāmacchanda ādayaḥ api
translated: The two terms “fallen” and “fallen away” should be construed as appropriate, not according to the sequence of the words.

original: paṭicchādakā, micchādiṭṭhi pana savisesaṃ paṭicchādikāti āha “micchādiṭṭhigahanapaṭicchanna”nti.
analyzed: paṭicchādakā micchādiṭṭhi pana sa visesam paṭicchādikā ti āha micchādiṭṭhi gahana paṭicchannan ti
translated: Although sensual desire, etc., are also concealers, wrong view is a concealer in a special sense, thus it is said: “concealed by the thicket of wrong view.”

original: Tenāha bhagavā – “micchādiṭṭhiparamāhaṃ, bhikkhave, vajjaṃ vadāmī”ti. Sabbāpāyagāmimaggo
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā micchādiṭṭhi paramā aham bhikkhave vajjam vadāmi iti sabba apāya gāmi maggo
translated: Hence the Exalted One said: “Bhikkhus, I say that wrong view is the most obstructive of these obstructive things” .

original: kummaggo “kucchito maggo”ti katvā. Sammādiṭṭhiādīnaṃ ujupaṭipakkhatāya micchādiṭṭhiādayo
analyzed: kummaggaḥ kucchitaḥ maggo ti katvā sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam uju paṭipakkha tāya micchādiṭṭhi ādayaḥ
translated: The wrong path is the path that leads to all the states of deprivation; it is called “the wrong path” because it is a bad path.

original: aṭṭha micchattadhammā micchāmaggo. Teneva hi tadubhayapaṭipakkhataṃ sandhāya “saggamokkhamaggaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha micchatta dhammā micchāmaggo tena iva hi tad ubhaya paṭipakkha tam sandhāya sagga mokkha maggaṃ
translated: Because they are the direct opposites of right view, etc., the eight things that are wrong are called the wrong path.🔽It is precisely because of this opposition that it is said: “revealing the path to heaven and release” .

original: āvikarontenā”ti vuttaṃ. Sappiādisannissayo padīpo na tathā ujjalo, yathā telasannissayoti
analyzed: āvi karontena ati vuttam sappi ādi sannissayaḥ padīpaḥ na tathā ujjalaḥ yathā tela sannissayaḥ ti
translated: The lamp that depends on ghee, etc., is not as bright as the one that depends on oil, thus🔽the expression “the light of oil” is used.

original: telapajjotaggahaṇaṃ. Etehi pariyāyehīti etehi nikkujjitukkujjanapaṭicchannavivaraṇādiupamopamitabbappakārehi.
analyzed: tela pajja uta gahaṇam etehi pariyāyehi iti etehi nikkujji tukkujjana paṭicchanna vivaraṇa ādi upamā upamitabba ppakārehi
translated: By these similes: by these similes of overturning, righting, concealing, revealing, etc.

original: Pasannākāranti pasannehi kātabbaṃ sakkāraṃ. Saraṇanti paṭisaraṇaṃ parāyaṇaṃ. Ajjatāti🔽ajjāti padassa vaḍḍhanamattaṃ hettha tā-saddo yathā “devatā”ti. Pāṇehi upetanti pāṇehi
analyzed: pasanna ākāram ti pasannehi kātabbam sakkāram saraṇam ati paṭisaraṇam parāyaṇam ajjata ati  ajja iti padassa vaḍḍhana mattam ha ittha tā saddaḥ yathā devatā ati pāṇehi upetanti pāṇehi
translated: Pasannākāraṃ means the respect that should be done by those who have confidence. Saraṇaṃ means a refuge, a support. Ajjatā means today.

original: saha saraṇaṃ upetaṃ. “Yāva me pāṇā dharanti, tāva saraṇaṃ gatameva maṃ dhāretū”ti🔽āpāṇakoṭikaṃ attano saraṇagamanaṃ pavedeti. Tenāha “yāva me”tiādi. Yaṃ panettha atthato
analyzed: saha saraṇam upetam yāva me pāṇāḥ dharanti tāva saraṇam gatam eva mam dhāretu uti  āpāṇakoṭikam saraṇa gamanam tena āha yāva mā itiādi yam pana ittha atthato
translated: The word ajja is extended here by the word tā, as in the word devatā. Pāṇehi upetanti means having approached the refuge with one’s life. “As long as my life lasts, may you hold me as one gone for refuge”

original: avibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: a vibhattam tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: he declares his going for refuge to the end of his life. Therefore he says “yāva me” and so on. But what here is not distinguished in meaning, that is easy to understand.

original: Daharasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dahara sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Dāḷha Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Purisasuttavaṇṇanā🔽113. Purimasutteti purimasuttadesanāyaṃ. Tattha hi upasaṅkamantavelāya satthu guṇe
analyzed: purisa sutta vaṇṇanā  purima sutta iti purima sutta desanāyam tattha hi guṇe
translated: The commentary on the Purisa Sutta

original: ajānanto kevalaṃ sammodanaṃ karoti. Desanaṃ sutvā pana satthu guṇe ñatvā saraṇaṅgatattā
analyzed: a jānantaḥ kevalam sammodanam karoti desanam sutvā pana satthu guṇe ñatvā saraṇaṅga tattā
translated: In the previous sutta means in the teaching of the previous sutta. For there, not knowing the virtues of the Teacher at the time of approaching, he merely exchanged greetings. But having heard the teaching, and knowing the virtues of the Teacher, and having gone for refuge,

original: idha imasmiṃ samāgame abhivādesi pañcapatiṭṭhitena vandi. Attānaṃ adhi ajjhattaṃ,
analyzed: idha imasmin samāgame abhivādesi pañca patiṭṭhitena vandi attānam adhi ajjhattam
translated: here in this assembly he paid homage with the five-point prostration. Adhi ajjhattaṃ means in oneself.

original: avijahena attānaṃ adhikicca uddissa pavattadhammā ajjhattaṃ ekajjhaṃ gahaṇavasena,🔽bhummatthe cetaṃ paccattavacanaṃ. Kāmañcāyaṃ ajjhattasaddo gocarajjhattavisayajjhattaajjhattajjhattesu🔽pavattati. Te panettha na yujjantīti vuttaṃ “niyakajjhatta”nti, niyakasaṅkhātaajjhattadhammesūti
analyzed: avijahena attānam adhikicca uddissa pavatta dhammā ajjhattam ekajjham gahaṇa vasena  bhumma tthe ca itam paccatta vacanam kāmam ca ayam ajjhatta saddaḥ gocara jjhatta visaya jjhatta ajjhatta ajjhattesu  pavattati te pana ittha na yujjanti iti vuttam niyaka jjhattanti niyaka saṅkhāta ajjhatta dhammesu ti
translated: The dhammas that occur in one’s own continuity, excluding the life faculty, are included in the internal base.🔽The word “internal” is a demonstrative pronoun in the sense of “ground.” And although this word “internal” is used in the sense of “sphere of activity,” “object,” and “one’s own,”🔽these senses are not appropriate here. Therefore it is said: “in one’s own continuity.”

original: attho. Tenāha “attano santāne”ti. Lubbhanalakkhaṇoti gijjhanalakkhaṇo, ārammaṇe daḷhaggahaṇasabhāvoti🔽attho. Dussanalakkhaṇoti kujjhanalakkhaṇo, byāpajjanasabhāvoti attho. Muyhanalakkhaṇoti
analyzed: attho tena āha attano santāne ti lubbhana lakkhaṇo ti gijjhana lakkhaṇo ārammaṇe daḷha ggahaṇa sabhāvaḥ ti  atthaḥ dussana lakkhaṇo ti kujjhana lakkhaṇaḥ byāpajjana sabhāvaḥ ti atthaḥ muyhana lakkhaṇo ti
translated: The characteristic of lust is that of delighting, the nature of firm grasping of an object.🔽The characteristic of hatred is that of annoyance, the nature of aversion. The characteristic of delusion is that of unknowing, the nature of confusion about the real nature of an object.

original: aññāṇalakkhaṇo, ārammaṇe sabhāvasammohabhāvoti attho. Viheṭhentīti atthanāsanaanatthuppādanehi
analyzed: aññāṇa lakkhaṇaḥ ārammaṇe sa bhāva sammoha bhāvo ti atthaḥ viheṭhenti iti attha nāsana anattha uppādanehi
translated: They afflict by causing harm and suffering.

original: vibādhenti. Tato eva yathā saggamaggesu na dissati, evaṃ karontīti āha “nāsenti vināsentī”ti.
analyzed: vibādhenti tatas eva yathā sagga maggesu na dissati evam karonti iti āha nāsenti vināsenti iti
translated: Therefore they are called “corrupters” and “destroyers” because they prevent one from seeing the path to heaven.

original: Attani sambhūtāti santāne nibbattā.
analyzed: attani sambhūtā ati santāne nibbattā
translated: Arisen in oneself means arisen in one’s own continuity.

original: Purisasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: purisa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Commentary on the Purisa Sutta is finished.

original: 3. Jarāmaraṇasuttavaṇṇanā🔽114. Aññatra jarāmaraṇāti jarāmaraṇena vinā. Jarāmaraṇavirahito jāto nāma atthi nu
analyzed: jarāmaraṇa sutta vaṇṇanā  aññatra jarā maraṇā ti jarā maraṇena vinā jarā maraṇa virahitaḥ jātaḥ nāma atthi nu
translated: Commentary on the Jara-maraṇa Sutta

original: khoti pucchati. Pāḷiyaṃ jātassāti paccatte sāmivacanaṃ. Mahāsālāti iminā ra-kārassa
analyzed: kho ti pucchati pāḷiyam jātassa ati paccatte sāmi vacanam mahāsālā iti iminā rakārassa
translated: Aññatra jarāmaraṇāti jarāmaraṇena vinā. Jarāmaraṇavirahito jāto nāma atthi nu khoti pucchati. Pāḷiyaṃ jātassāti paccatte sāmivacanaṃ. Mahāsālāti iminā ra-kārassa

original: la-kāraṃ katvā “mahāsālā”ti vuttanti dasseti yathā “puratthiyoti pulatthiyo”ti. Mahāsārappattāti
analyzed: lakāram katvā mahāsālā ati vuttanti dasseti yathā puratthiyā iti pulatthiyā iti mahā sāra ppattā ati
translated: la-kāraṃ katvā “mahāsālā”ti vuttanti dasseti yathā “puratthiyoti pulatthiyo”ti. Mahāsārappattāti

original: mahantaṃ vibhavasāraṃ pattā. Koṭisataṃ dhanaṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho. “Kumbhaṃ nāma dasa
analyzed: mahantam vibhava sāram pattā koṭi satam dhanam ayam eva vā pāṭho kumbham nāma dasa
translated: mahantaṃ vibhavasāraṃ pattā. Koṭisataṃ dhanaṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho. “Kumbhaṃ nāma dasa

original: ambaṇānī”ti vadanti. Issarāti vibhavissariyena issarā. Suvaṇṇarajatabhājanādīnanti
analyzed: ambaṇāni iti vadanti issarā ati vibha vissariyena issarā
translated: ambaṇānī”ti vadanti. Issarāti vibhavissariyena issarā. Suvaṇṇarajatabhājanādīnanti

original: ādi-saddena vatthaseyyāvasathādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Asādhāraṇadhanānaṃ nidhānagatattā “anidhānagatassā”ti
analyzed: ādi saddena vattha seyya āvasatha ādim saṅgaṇhāti asādhāraṇa dhanānam nidhāna gata ttā a nidhāna gatassa ati
translated: ādi-saddena vatthaseyyāvasathādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Asādhāraṇadhanānaṃ nidhānagatattā “anidhānagatassā”ti

original: vuttaṃ. Tuṭṭhikaraṇassāti pāsādasivikādisukhasādhanassa.
analyzed: vuttam tuṭṭhi karaṇassa āti pāsāda sivikā ādi sukha sādhanassa
translated: vuttaṃ. Tuṭṭhikaraṇassāti pāsādasivikādisukhasādhanassa.

original: Ārakā kilesehīti niruttinayena saddasiddhimāha. Ārakāti ca sabbaso samucchinnattā🔽tehi dūreti attho. Rāgādīnaṃ hatattā, pāpakaraṇe rahābhāvato, anuttaradakkhiṇeyyatādipaccayā
analyzed: ārakā kilesehi iti nirutti nayena sadda siddhim āha ārakā ati ca sabbaso  tehi dūrā iti atthaḥ rāga ādīnam hata ttā pāpa karaṇe raha abhāvataḥ anuttara dakkhiṇeyya tā ādi paccayā
translated: “Far from defilements” : he states the derivation of the word “arahant” in the sense of “one who has gone far away” . And “far” means “completely cut off” from them.🔽He is “worthy” because he has destroyed greed, etc., because he is not a place of concealment for evil, and because he is worthy of the highest offerings, etc.

original: ca arahaṃ. Kāmañcāyaṃ saṃyuttavaṇṇanā, abhidhammanayo eva pana nippariyāyoti āha
analyzed: ca araham kāmañca ayam saṃyutta vaṇṇanā abhidhamma nayaḥ eva pana nippariyāyaḥ ti āha
translated: This is the commentary on the word “arahant” in the sense of “worthy” .🔽“The four taints” : the four taints of sensual pleasure, etc.

original: “cattāro āsavā”ti brahmacariyavāsanti maggabrahmacariyavāsaṃ. Vuṭṭhāti vuṭṭhavanto.
analyzed: cattāro brahmacariya vāsanti magga brahmacariya vāsam vuṭṭhāti vuṭṭhavanto
translated: “The four floods” : the four floods of sensual desire, etc.🔽“The four bonds” : the four bonds of sensual desire, etc.

original: Catūhi maggehi karaṇīyanti paccekaṃ catūhi maggehi kattabbaṃ pariññāpahānasacchikiriyabhāvanābhisamayaṃ.🔽Evaṃ gataṃ soḷasavidhaṃ hoti. Osīdāpanaṭṭhena bhārā viyāti bhārā. Tenāha “bhārā have🔽pañcakkhandhā”tiādi. Attapaṭibaddhatāya attano avijahanato paramatthadesanāya ca
analyzed: catūhi maggehi karaṇīyanti paccekam catūhi maggehi kattabbam pariññā apahāna sacchikiriya bhāvanā abhisamayam  evam gatam soḷasavidham hoti osīdāpana ṭṭhena bhārāḥ viyāti bhārā tena āha bhārāḥ have  pañca kkhandha ati ādi atta paṭibaddha tāya attanaḥ paramattha desanāya ca
translated: “The four clingings” : the four clingings of sensual desire, etc.🔽“The four ties” : the four ties of sensual desire, etc.🔽“The four perversions” : the four perversions of perception, etc.

original: paramattho arahattaṃ. Kāmañcāyamattho sabbasamiddhisasantatipariyāpanno anavajjadhammo
analyzed: paramatthaḥ arahattam kāmañca ayam atthaḥ sabba samiddhi sa santati pariyāpanno anavajja dhammo
translated: “The four perversions” : the four perversions of perception, etc.🔽“The four perversions” : the four perversions of perception, etc.

original: sambhavati akuppasabhāvā, aparihānadhammesu pana aggabhūte arahatte sātisayo, na
analyzed: sambhavati akuppa sabhāvā a parihāna dhammesu pana agga bhūte arahatte sa atisayaḥ na
translated: In the case of the other fruitions it is not.

original: itaresūti “arahattasaṅkhāto”tiādi vuttaṃ. Orambhāgiyuddhambhāgiyavibhāgaṃ dasavidhampi
analyzed: itaresu iti arahatta saṅkhāta itiādi vuttam orambhāgiya uddhambhāgiya vibhāgam dasavidham pi
translated: The distinction between the fetters pertaining to the lower and higher worlds is tenfold.

original: bhavesu saṃyojanaṃ kilesakammavipākavaṭṭapaccayo hutvā nissarituṃ appadānavasena🔽bandhatīti bhavasaṃyojanaṃ. Satipi hi aññesaṃ tappakkhiyabhāvena vinā saṃyojanāni
analyzed: bhavesu saṃyojanam kilesa kamma vipāka vaṭṭa paccayaḥ hutvā nissaritum appadāna vasena  bandhati iti bhava saṃyojanam sati api hi aññesam tad pakkhiya bhāvena vinā saṃyojanāni
translated: The fetters in the various kinds of becoming bind beings to becoming by becoming the conditions for defilements, kamma, and becoming.🔽  Although the other fetters are also conditions for becoming, they are called fetters pertaining to becoming because they are the principal conditions for it.

original: tesaṃ tappaccayabhāvo atthi, bhavaniyāmo orambhāgiyuddhambhāgiyasaṅgahitoti taṃtaṃbhavanibbattakakammaniyāmo
analyzed: tesam tad paccaya bhāvaḥ atthi bhava niyāmaḥ orambhāgiya uddhambhāgiya saṅgahitaḥ ti taṃ taṃ bhava nibbattaka kamma niyāmaḥ
translated: The regularity of becoming is the regularity of the kamma that produces the various kinds of becoming.

original: ca hoti, na ca upacchinnasaṃyojanassa katānipi kammāni bhavaṃ nibbattentīti tesaṃyeva
analyzed: ca hoti na ca upacchinna saṃyojanassa katāni api kammāni bhavam nibbattenti iti tesam yeva
translated: The kamma of one whose fetters have been severed does not produce becoming.🔽  Therefore the meaning of fetter should be understood in this way.

original: saṃyojanaṭṭho daṭṭhabbo. Sammā kāraṇehi jānitvāti ñāyena dukkhādīsu so yathā jānitabbo;🔽tathā jānitvā, pubbakālakiriyāvimuttā hi aparakālakiriyā ca yathā sambhavati, taṃ
analyzed: saṃyojana ṭṭho daṭṭhabbo sammā kāraṇehi jānitvā ati ñāyena dukkha ādīsu saḥ yathā jānitabbaḥ 🔽tathā jānitvā pubba kāla kiriyā vimuttā hi apara kāla kiriyā ca yathā sambhavati tam
translated: Having known by right means: having known by the method stated in the following way: “The wise one should know suffering, etc.”

original: dassetuṃ “maggapaññāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassetum magga paññāya itiādi vuttam
translated: and so he said, “in the path-understanding” and so on.🔽The state of being broken up is due to its being dependent on the moment ; the state of being laid down is due to its being subject to death.

original: Bhijjanasabhāvo khaṇāyattattā. Nikkhipitabbasabhāvo maraṇadhammattā. Ayaṃ kāyo usmāyuviññāṇāpagamo
analyzed: bhijjana sabhāvaḥ khaṇa āyatta ttā nikkhipitabba sabhāvaḥ maraṇa dhamma ttā ayam kāyaḥ usmāyu viññāṇa apagamaḥ
translated: This body is subject to the loss of heat and consciousness,

original: chaḍḍanīyadhammo, yasmiṃ yaṃ patiṭṭhitaṃ, taṃ tassa santānagatavippayuttanti katvā
analyzed: chaḍḍanīya dhammaḥ yasmin yam patiṭṭhitam tam tassa santāna gata vippayuttan ti katvā
translated: and it is subject to being laid down, and so it is proper to say that what is established in it is dissociated from its continuity, taking it as “his” in the sense of “what belongs to him.”🔽So he said: “For the one whose cankers are destroyed there is what is subject to indigestion too.”

original: vattabbataṃ arahatīti āha “khīṇāsavassa hi ajīraṇadhammopi atthī”tiādi. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: vattabba tam arahati iti āha khīṇāsavassa hi ajīraṇa dhammaḥ api atthi itiādi tena āha bhagavā
translated: And that is why the Blessed One said:

original: “imasmiṃyeva byāmamatte kaḷevare sasaññimhi samanake lokañca paññapemi lokasamudayañca
analyzed: imasmin yeva byāma matte kaḷevare sa saññimhi samanake lokañca paññapemi loka samudayañca
translated: “In this fathom-long physical frame with its perceptions and mind, I declare the world, the origin of the world, the cessation of the world, and the way leading to the cessation of the world” .

original: lokanirodhañcā”tiādi. Assa khīṇāsavassa, “jīraṇadhamma”nti yathāvuttaṃ ajīraṇadhammaṃ🔽ṭhapetvā jīraṇadhammaṃ dassento “tesaṃpāyaṃ kāyo bhedanadhammo”ti evamāha. Jaraṃ🔽pattasseva hissa bhedananikkhipitabbatāniyate atthe suttadesanā pavattā. Atthassa
analyzed: loka nirodham ca atiādi assa khīṇa āsavassa jīraṇa dhammam ti yathāvuttam a jīraṇa dhammam 🔽ṭhapetvā jīraṇa dhammam dassento kāyaḥ bhedana dhammo ti evam āha jaram 🔽pattassa iva hissa bhedana nikkhipitabba tā a niyate atthe sutta desanā pavattā atthassa
translated: And when he said “the world” he meant what is subject to indigestion, as already stated, and when he said “the world’s origin” he meant what is subject to indigestion too, and when he said “the world’s cessation” he meant what is subject to indigestion too, and when he said “the way leading to the cessation of the world” he meant what is subject to indigestion too.🔽But when he said “the world” he meant what is subject to indigestion and what is subject to digestion too, and when he said “the world’s origin” he meant what is subject to indigestion and what is subject to digestion too, and when he said “the world’s cessation” he meant what is subject to indigestion and what is subject to digestion too, and when he said “the way leading to the cessation of the world” he meant what is subject to indigestion and what is subject to digestion too.

original: uppatti aṭṭhuppatti, sā etassa atthīti aṭṭhuppattiko. Kira-saddo anussavattho, tena
analyzed: uppatti aṭṭhuppatti sā etassa atthi iti aṭṭhuppattikaḥ kira saddaḥ anussava atthaḥ tena
translated: The meaning is that it has a source in the tradition. The word kira is a term for “tradition.”🔽The meaning is that it comes from the tradition, not from the commentaries.

original: anussavāgatoyamattho, na aṭṭhakathāgatoti dīpeti. Tenāha “vadantī”ti. Yenāyaṃ attho
analyzed: anussava āgataḥ ayam attho na aṭṭhakathā gataḥ ti dīpeti tena āha vadanti iti yena ayam attho
translated: He says “vadanti,” meaning that this is the source of the meaning.

original: hetunā aṭṭhuppattiko, taṃ dassetuṃ “sivikasālāyaṃ nisīditvā kathita”nti vuttaṃ. “Viharati
analyzed: hetunā aṭṭhuppattiko tam dassetum sivika sālāyam nisīditvā kathitam ti vuttam viharati
translated: In order to show the reason why it has a source in the tradition, it is said: “spoken while sitting in the Sivi hut.”

original: jetavane”ti nidānavacanena yathā na virujjhati, tathā veditabbaṃ. Nanu imassa suttassa
analyzed: jetavana iti nidāna vacanena yathā na virujjhati tathā veditabbam nanu imassa suttassa
translated: “He lives in Jeta’s Wood” should be understood as not contradicting the introduction.

original: pucchāvasiko nikkhepoti? Saccametaṃ, suttekadesaṃ pana sandhāya aṭṭhuppattikatāvacanaṃ.
analyzed: pucchāvasikaḥ nikkhepaḥ ti saccam etam sutta ekadesam pana sandhāya aṭṭhuppattika tā vacanam
translated: But isn’t the introduction to this sutta a question? That is so, but the statement that it has a source in the tradition refers to a part of the sutta.

original: Keci pana “yānaṃ āruhitvā rājā āgato, rañño ārohanīyarathaṃ dassetvā vutta”ntipi vadanti.🔽Sarīre pheṇapiṇḍasame kiṃ vattabbaṃ? Sabbhi saddhinti sādhūhi saha pavedayanti. Na
analyzed: keci pana yānam āruhitvā rājā āgataḥ raññaḥ ārohanīya ratham dassetvā vutta nti pi vadanti  sarīre pheṇa piṇḍa same kim vattabbam sabbhi saddhinti sādhūhi saha pavedayanti na
translated: But some say that it was said after showing the king the chariot to be mounted on, the king having come after mounting a chariot.🔽What can be said about the body, which is like a lump of froth? They proclaim it together with all that is good,

original: hi kadāci sādhūnaṃ sādhūhi saha kattabbā honti, tasmā sīdanasabhāvānaṃ kilesānaṃ
analyzed: hi kadāci sādhūnam sādhūhi saha kattabbāḥ honti tasmā sīdana sabhāvānam kilesānam
translated: for it is never to be done with what is good by those who are good. Therefore,

original: bhijjanappattattā nibbānaṃ sabbhīti vuccati. Purimapadassāti “satañca dhammo na jaraṃ
analyzed: bhijjana ppatta ttā nibbānam sabbhi iti vuccati purima padassa ati satam ca dhammo na jaram
translated: Nibbāna is called “the good” because it is the state of being unbreakable.🔽“Of the first word”: of the word “the good” in the phrase “The good, the Dhamma that is not subject to break up” .

original: upetī”ti padassa. Kāraṇaṃ dassento byatirekavasena. Sataṃ dhammo nibbānaṃ kilesehi
analyzed: upeti iti padassa kāraṇam dassentaḥ byatireka vasena satam dhammaḥ nibbānam kilesehi
translated: Showing the reason by way of the distinction, he says, “The good, the Dhamma that is not subject to break up” .

original: saṃsīdanabhijjanasabhāvo na hoti, tasmā taṃ āgamma jaraṃ na upeti. Kilesā pana tannimittakā,
analyzed: na hoti tasmā tam āgamma jaram na upeti kilesā pana tad nimittakā
translated: The good, the Dhamma that is Nibbāna, is not of the nature of breaking up by way of the defilements; therefore it is not subject to break up by way of that .🔽But the defilements are the cause of that .

original: evamayaṃ vuttakāraṇato jaraṃ na upetīti. Tenāha “ida”ntiādi. Sundarādhivacanaṃ vā
analyzed: evam ayam vutta kāraṇataḥ jaram na upeti iti tena āha idam tiādi sundara adhivacanam vā
translated: Thus it is not subject to break up by way of that , for the reason stated.

original: etaṃ “sabbhī”ti padaṃ apāpatādīpanato, sabbhidhammabhūtanti attho. Tenāha “virāgo
analyzed: etam sabbhi iti padam apāpa tā dīpanato sabbhidhamma bhūtanti atthaḥ tena āha virāgaḥ
translated: Or the word “the good” is a term for the beautiful, because it shows the absence of danger; the meaning is, it is the Dhamma that is the good.

original: tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati, na tena dhammena samatthi kiñcī”ti ca.
analyzed: tesam aggam akkhāyati na tena dhammena samatthi kiñci iti ca
translated: Therefore it is said: “The fading away of lust is declared to be the best of them; there is no comparison even with the best of the Dhamma” .

original: Jarāmaraṇasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽4. Piyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jarāmaraṇa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  piya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Jarāmaraṇa Sutta is ended.🔽The commentary on the Piya Sutta is ended.

original: 115. Rahasi gatassāti janasambādhato apakkantassa. Nilīnassa teneva janavivekena
analyzed: rahasi gatassa ati jana sambādhataḥ a pakkantassa nilīnassa tena iva jana vivekena
translated: “Gone into seclusion”: gone away from the crowd of people.

original: ekamantaṃ nisajjāya ekībhāvena paṭisallīnassa viya. Tenāha “ekībhūtassā”ti. Sabbaññubhāsitaṃ
analyzed: ekamantam nisajjāya ekībhāvena paṭisallīnassa viya tena āha ekībhūtassa iti sabbaññu bhāsitam
translated: and sat down on one side, as if he were alone in seclusion. Hence he said, “When he was alone in seclusion” .

original: karonto āha tassa vacanaṃ “evameta”nti sampaṭicchitvā tassa vacanaṃ tathāpaccanubhāsanto.
analyzed: karontaḥ āha tassa vacanam evam etat ti sampaṭicchitvā tassa vacanam tathāpaccanubhāsanto
translated: He said, “So it is, friend,” approving his words, and then he repeated them,

original: Antakenādhipannattā eva khettavatthuhiraññasuvaṇṇādi mānusaṃ bhavaṃ jahato. Anuganti
analyzed: antakena adhipanna ttāḥ eva khetta vatthu hirañña suvaṇṇa ādi mānusam bhavam jahataḥ anuganti
translated: because he had to leave behind all human possessions such as fields, land, gold, and silver, since he had fallen into the mouth of death.

original: anugataṃ, tameva anugāmīti attho. Nicayanti uparūpari vaḍḍhiyā nicitabhūtaṃ. Samparāyikanti samparāya hitaṃ.
analyzed: anugatam tam eva anugāmī iti atthaḥ nicayanti upari upari vaḍḍhiyā nicita bhūtam samparāyikam ti samparāya hitam
translated: “What follows him” is what is followed by him; the meaning is that he follows it. “What is stored up” is what is stored up by being added to again and again. “For the next world” is what is beneficial for the next world.

original: Piyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: piya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Piya sutta is finished.

original: 5. Attarakkhitasuttavaṇṇanā🔽116. Pīdahananti saṃyamanaṃ. Kammapathabhedaṃ appattassāti supinakālo viya pavattimattatāya🔽kammapathavisesaṃ agatassa. Kammassāti akusalakammassa. Saṃvaranti saṃvarabhāvaṃ
analyzed: attarakkhita sutta vaṇṇanā  saṃyamanam kamma patha bhedam appattassa āti supina kālaḥ viya pavatti matta tāya  kamma patha visesam a gatassa kammassa ati akusala kammassa saṃvaranti saṃvara bhāvam
translated: The Sutta on Protection of Self🔽“Oppression” is restraint. “Who has not yet reached the division of the courses of kamma” is one who has not yet reached the distinction of the courses of kamma, because his occurrence is like the time of a dream.

original: dasseti, itarassa pana saṃvarabhāvo purimehi tīhi padehi dassitovāti. Ottappampi
analyzed: dasseti itarassa pana saṃvara bhāvaḥ purimehi tīhi padehi dassitaḥ uvāti ottappam pi
translated: “Of kamma” is of unwholesome kamma. “Restraint” he shows the state of restraint. But the state of restraint of the other is shown by the first three terms. “Shame”

original: gahitameva tadavinābhāvato. Na hi pāpajigucchanaṃ pāpautrāsarahitaṃ, utrāso vā pāpajigucchanarahito atthīti.
analyzed: gahitam eva tad avinābhāvataḥ na hi pāpa jigucchanam pāpa otrāsa rahitam utrāsaḥ vā pāpa jigucchana rahitaḥ atthi iti
translated: because of the invariable concomitance. For there is no shame in evil without fear of it, nor is there fear of it without shame in it.

original: Attarakkhitasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: attarakkhita sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Attarakkhita Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Appakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: appaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Fewness of Wishes

original: 117. Uḷārasaddo seṭṭhe bahuke ca dissatīti āha “paṇīte ca bahuke cā”ti. Mānamajjanenāti mānavasena madappattiyā. Atikkamanti sādhumariyādavītikkamalakkhaṇaṃ dosaṃ. Kūṭo pāso.
analyzed: uḷāra saddo seṭṭhe bahuke ca dissati iti āha paṇīte ca bahuke ca ati māna majjanena ati māna vasena mada ppattiyā atikkamanti sādhu mariyāda vītikkama lakkhaṇam dosam kūṭaḥ pāsaḥ
translated: The word “great” is found in the sense of excellent and in the sense of numerous. That is why the commentator says “in the excellent and in the numerous.” “By the sinking of conceit”: by the attainment of intoxication through conceit. “They transgress”: they transgress hate, which is characterized by the non-transgression of good people. “A trap”: a snare.

original: Appakasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: appaka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Appamaññha Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Aḍḍakaraṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aḍḍakaraṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Court

original: 118. Yasmā kāmanimittaṃ satto sampajānamusā bhāsati, tasmā kāmā tassa patiṭṭhā paccayo
analyzed: yasmai kāma nimittam sattaḥ sampajāna musā bhāsati tasmai kāmā tassa patiṭṭhā paccayaḥ
translated: Since a being speaks a deliberate lie for the sake of sensual desires, sensual desires are his support, his condition,

original: kāraṇanti āha “kāmahetū”tiādi. Bhadramukhasīsena viṭaṭubhaṃ bhadropacārena upacaratīti
analyzed: āha kāma hetu utiādi bhadra mukha sīsena viṭaṭubham bhadra upacārena upacarati iti
translated: his reason. That is why the commentator says “because of sensual desires.” “He serves with a pleasant face”: the meaning is that he serves with a pleasant manner, with a pleasant appearance.

original: attho, vinicchayo karīyati etthāti aḍḍakaraṇaṃ, vinicchayaṭṭhānaṃ. Khippanti kūṭaṃ,
analyzed: atthaḥ vinicchayaḥ ettha ati aḍḍakaraṇam vinicchaya ṭṭhānam khippanti kūṭam
translated: “A court”: a place where a decision is made. “A trap”: a snare.

original: macchakhippantipi vaṭṭati. Oḍḍitanti oḍḍanavasena phalaṃ pāpitaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭati oḍḍita nti oḍḍana vasena phalam pāpitam
translated: and also “fish-hook” is allowable. “Harvested” : the fruit is harvested by harvesting.

original: Aḍḍakaraṇasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aḍḍakaraṇa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Aḍḍakaraṇa Sutta is finished.

original: 8. Mallikāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Mallikā Sutta

original: 119. “Kasmā pucchatī”ti? Pucchākāraṇaṃ codetvā samudayato paṭṭhāya dassetuṃ “ayaṃ🔽kira mallikā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Mālārāmaṃ gantvāti attano pitu mālārāmaṃ rakkhaṇatthañceva🔽avasesapupphaggahaṇatthañca gantvā. Kāsigāmeti kāsiraṭṭhassa gāme. So kira gāmo mahākosalarājena
analyzed: kasmai pucchati iti pucchā kāraṇam codetvā samudayataḥ paṭṭhāya dassetum ayaṃ  kira mallikā iti ādi vuttam mālārāmam gantvā iti attanaḥ pitu mālārāmam rakkhaṇa attham ca eva  avasesa puppha ggahaṇa attham ca gantvā kāsi gāma iti kāsi raṭṭhassa gāme saḥ kira gāmaḥ mahākosala rājena
translated: “Why did he ask?”: after reproving him for the reason for asking, he said “This Mallikā” in order to show it from the beginning.🔽After going to the Flower Garden: after going to his father’s Flower Garden in order to protect it🔽and in order to gather the remaining flowers. In the Kāsi country: in a village in the Kāsi country. It seems that the village was given by the Great King of Kosala

original: attano dhītuyā patigharaṃ gacchantiyā pupphamūlatthāya dinno, taṃnimittaṃ. Bhāgineyyena🔽ajātasattunā. Tassāti rañño pasenadissa. Sāti mallikā. Nivattitunti tassā dhammatāya
analyzed: attanaḥ dhītuyā pati gharam gacchantiyā puppha mūla atthāya dinnaḥ taṃnimittam bhāgineyyena  ajātasattunā tassa ati raññaḥ pasenadissa sā ati mallikā nivattitunti tassāḥ dhamma tāya
translated: to his daughter when she went to her husband’s house for the sake of flowers. The reason was that she was the daughter of the King of Kāsi.🔽By her nephew

original: nivattituṃ tassā vacanaṃ paṭikkhipituṃ. Nevajjhagāti vattamānatthe atītavacananti
analyzed: nivattitum tassāḥ vacanam paṭikkhipitum vattamāna atthe atīta vacanam ti
translated: Ajātasattu. “His” : the King of Kosala, Pasenadi. “Her” : Mallikā. “To turn back” : to turn back from her, to reject her words. “Did not reach” : the present tense is used in the sense of the past.

original: āha “nādhigacchatī”ti. Puthu attāti tesaṃ sattānaṃ attā.
analyzed: āha na adhigacchati iti puthu attā ati tesam sattānam attā
translated: “Did not understand” is what is said. “Many a self” : the self of those beings.

original: Mallikāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mallikāsutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Mallikā Sutta is finished.

original: 9. Yaññasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: yañña sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sacrifice Sutta🔽The post: the post for the sacrifice.

original: 120. Thūṇanti yaññūpatthambhaṃ. Upanītāni yaññaṃ yajituṃ ārambhāya. Ettāvatāti “idha,
analyzed: thūṇanti yaññūpatthambham upanītāni yaññam yajitum ārambhāya ettāvatā ati idha
translated: The preparations: the preparations for the sacrifice.

original: bhante…pe… rudamānā parikammāni karontī”ti ettakena pāṭhena. Sanniṭṭhānanti “naṃ
analyzed: rudamānā parikammāni karonti iti ettakena pāṭhena
translated: So far: with the words “Here, venerable sir, the brahmin brahmin women, with their own hands, served and satisfied the company of brahmins with milk-rice mixed with ghee” .

original: itthiṃ labhissāmi nu kho, na nu kho labhissāmī”ti nicchayaṃ avindanto na ñāyanto.
analyzed: itthim labhissāmi nu kho na nu kho labhissāmi iti nicchayam a vindantaḥ na ñāyantaḥ
translated: The agreement: the decision “I will get this woman or I won’t” without finding or knowing her.

original: Pheṇuddehakanti yathā yattha kuthite pheṇaṃ uddehati na upadhīyati, evaṃ anekavāraṃ
analyzed: yathā kuthite pheṇam uddehati na upadhīyati evam aneka vāram
translated: The foam-swallowing: just as foam rises up and does not stick where it is churned, so he rose up foam many times and swallowed it.

original: pheṇaṃ uṭṭhāpetvā. Taṃ divasanti tasmiṃ raññā niddaṃ alabhitvā dukkhaseyyadivase.
analyzed: pheṇam uṭṭhāpetvā tam tasmin raññā niddam a labhitvā dukkhaseyya divase
translated: That day: on that day when the king could not sleep and had a bad night.

original: Ālokaṃ oloketvāti lohakumbhimukhavaṭṭisīse patte tattha mahantaṃ ālokaṃ oloketvā.
analyzed: ālokam oloketvā ti loha kumbhimukha vaṭṭi sīse patte tattha mahantam ālokam oloketvā
translated: Looking at the light: looking at the great light in the pan on the top of the door-frame of the iron house.🔽He did so in order to inform the king of what was happening.

original: Attāno vacanaṃ rañño pavattiñāpanatthaṃ. Mahāsaddo udapādi “evarūpaṃ yaññaṃ rājā
analyzed: attānaḥ vacanam raññaḥ pavatti ñāpana attham mahā saddaḥ udapādi evarūpam yaññam rājā
translated: A great noise arose: “The king is performing such-and-such a sacrifice.

original: kārāpetī”ti. Vattukāmo ahosi, vattuñca pana avisahanto “sa” iti vatvā lohakumbhiyaṃ
analyzed: kārāpeti iti vattu kāmaḥ ahosi vattum ca pana a visahantaḥ saḥ iti vatvā lohakumbhiyam
translated: “He has it made.” He wanted to say, “He has it made,” but being unable to say it, he said, “Sa,” and fell into the copper cauldron.

original: nimuggo. Imaṃ gāthaṃ vattukāmo ahosīti ayaṃ panettha sambandho. Esa nayo sesapadadvayepi.
analyzed: nimuggaḥ imam gātham vattu kāmaḥ ahosi iti ayam pana ittha sambandhaḥ esa nayo sesa pada dvaye pi
translated: and had it made.” He wanted to say this, but being unable to say it, he said “sa” and was swallowed up in the copper pot. He wanted to say this verse. This is the connection here. The same method applies to the other two lines.

original: Dhammabheriṃ carāpesuṃ “koci kañci pāṇaṃ mā hanatū”ti. So itthisāmiko puriso sotāpattiphale
analyzed: dhamma bherim cara apesum koci kañci pāṇam mā hanatu uti so itthi sāmiko puriso sotāpatti phale
translated: They beat the drum of the Dhamma, saying: “Let no one kill any living being.” The man, the husband of the woman,

original: patiṭṭhahi attano upanissayasampattiyā sattu ca desanāvilāsasampattiyā, rājā pana
analyzed: patiṭṭhahi attanaḥ upanissaya sampattiyā sattu ca desanā vilāsa sampattiyā rājā pana
translated: was established in the fruit of stream-entry, by his own possession of the supporting conditions and by the teacher’s skill in teaching. But the king,

original: mahābodhinirujjhanasabhāvattā kiñci visesaṃ nādhigacchi.
analyzed: mahā bodhi nirujjhana sabhā vat tā kiñci visesam nā adhigacchi
translated: because of the nature of the Great Bodhi Tree’s non-ceasing, did not attain any distinction.

original: Saṅgahavatthūnīti lokassa saṅgahakāraṇāni. Nipphannasassato navabhāge kassakassa
analyzed: saṅgaha vatthūni iti lokassa saṅgaha kāraṇāni nipphanna sassataḥ nava bhāge kassakassa
translated: The bases of accumulation are the causes of the world’s accumulation. After giving the new portion of the harvest to the farmer,

original: datvā raññaṃ ekabhāgaggahaṇaṃ dasamabhāgaggahaṇaṃ. Evaṃ kassakā haṭṭhatuṭṭhā sassāni
analyzed: datvā raññam eka bhāga ggahaṇam dasama bhāga ggahaṇam evam kassakā haṭṭha tuṭṭhā sassāni
translated: the king took one portion and took the tenth portion. In this way the farmers, being pleased and satisfied,

original: sampādentīti āha “sassasampādane medhāvitāti attho”ti. Tato orabhāge kira chabhāgaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: sampādenti iti āha sassa sampādane medhāvitā ati attho ti tatas ora bhāge kira cha bhāga ggahaṇam
translated: brought the crops to completion. Therefore it is said: “The meaning is that he was skillful in bringing the crops to completion.” After that, in the autumn, it is said that he took six portions🔽and gave four portions to the farmers.

original: jātaṃ. Chamāsikanti channaṃ channaṃ māsānaṃ pahonakaṃ. Pāsetīti pāsagate viya karoti.
analyzed: jātam chamāsikanti channam channam māsānam pahonakam pāsā iti iti pāsa gate karoti
translated: ‘Chamāsika’ means enough for six months. ‘He makes it his own’ means he makes it his own as if it were in his own house.

original: Vācāya piyassa piyakarassa kammaṃ vācāpeyyaṃ. Sabbaso raṭṭhassa iddhādibhāvato khemaṃ.
analyzed: vācāya piyassa piya karassa kammam vācāpeyyam sabbasas raṭṭhassa iddha ādi bhāvataḥ khemam
translated: ‘By speech’ means by the speech of one who is dear and does what is pleasing. ‘Safe’ means safe in every way, in terms of the prosperity, etc., of the country.

original: Nirabbudaṃ coriyābhāvato. Idañhi raṭṭhaṃ acoriyaṃ niraggaḷanti vuccati apārutagharabhāvato.
analyzed: nirabbudam coriya abhāvato idam hi raṭṭham a coriyam niraggaḷam ti vuccati a pāruta ghara bhāvato
translated: ‘Free from danger’ means free from thieves. For this country, being free from thieves, is called ‘free from danger’ and ‘free from thieves.’

original: Uddhaṃmūlakaṃ katvāti ummūlaṃ katvā. Dvīhi pariyaññehīti mahāyaññassa pubbabhāge
analyzed: uddhaṃmūlakam katvā ati ummūlam katvā dvīhi pariyaññehi iti mahāyaññassa pubba bhāge
translated: ‘Having uprooted’ means having pulled out by the roots. ‘With two sacrifices’ means with the two preliminary sacrifices

original: pacchā ca pavattetabbehi dvīhi parivārayaññehi. Sattavīsati…pe… nassāti sattavīsādhikānaṃ
analyzed: pacchā ca pavattetabbehi dvīhi sattavīsati pe sattavīsā adhikānam
translated: and the two concluding sacrifices. ‘Twenty-seven’ means twenty-seven hundred.

original: tiṇṇaṃ pasusatānaṃ dvāvīsatiyā assādīhi ca saṭṭhiadhikadvisataāraññakapasūhi ca saddhiṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam pasu satānam dvāvīsatiyā assa ādīhi ca saṭṭhi adhika dvisata āraññaka pasūhi ca saddhim
translated: ‘Cattle’ means twenty-two hundred horses, etc., and two hundred and sixty wild cattle.

original: sampiṇḍitānaṃ pana navādhikachasatapasūnaṃ māraṇena bheravassa pāpabhīrukānaṃ bhayāvahassa. Tathā hi vadanti –
analyzed: sampiṇḍitānam pana māraṇena bheravassa pāpa bhīrukānam bhaya āvahassa tathā hi vadanti
translated: But when they are combined, there are nine hundred and twenty-four cattle. ‘Terrible’ means fearful to those who are afraid of evil. ‘Frightful’ means causing fear. For they say:

original: “Chasatāni niyujjanti, pasūnaṃ majjhime hani,
analyzed: chasatāni niyujjanti pasūnam majjhime hani
translated: “Nine hundred and twenty-four cattle are slaughtered🔽in the middle of the sacrifice,

original: Assamedhassa yaññassa, adhikāni navāpi cā”ti.
analyzed: assamedhassa yaññassa adhikāni nava api ca ati
translated: and the nine-day sacrifice of the horse-sacrifice.”

original: Sammanti yugacchidde pakkhipitabbadaṇḍakaṃ. Pāsentīti khipanti. Saṃhārimehīti sakaṭehi🔽vahitabbehi yūpehi. Pubbe kira eko rājā sammāpāsaṃ yajanto sarassatinadītīre pathaviyā
analyzed: yuga chidde pakkhipitabba daṇḍakam pāsenti iti khipanti saṃhārimehi iti sakaṭehi  vahitabbehi yūpehi pubbe kira ekaḥ rājā sammāpāsam yajanto sarassati nadī tīre pathaviyā
translated: The stick is to be put in the hole of the yoke-pin. “They send” means they throw. “They bring together” means with the sacrificial posts that are to be carried by carts.

original: vivare dinne nimuggoyeva ahosi. Andhabālabrāhmaṇā gatānugatigatā “ayaṃ tassa saggagamanamaggo”ti
analyzed: vivare dinne ahosi andha bāla brāhmaṇāḥ gata anugati gatāḥ ayam tassa sagga gamana maggo ti
translated: Formerly, it seems, a certain king, while performing the sacrifice of the Sammāpasa, was swallowed up in a hole that was made in the earth on the bank of a lake and a river. The blind foolish brahmins, following the crowd, thinking “This is the way to heaven for him,”

original: saññāya tattha sammāpāsayaññaṃ paṭṭhapenti. Tena vuttaṃ “nimuggokāsato pabhutī”ti.🔽Ayūpo appakadivaso yāgo, sayūpo bahudivasaṃ sādheyyo satrayāgo. Mantapadābhisaṅkhatānaṃ
analyzed: saññāya tattha sammāpāsa yaññam paṭṭhapenti tena vuttam nimugga ukāsataḥ pabhuti iti  a yūpaḥ appaka divasaḥ yāgaḥ sa yūpaḥ bahu divasam sādheyyaḥ satra yāgaḥ manta pada abhisaṅkhatānam
translated: set up the Sammāpasa sacrifice there. Therefore it is said: “From the place where he was swallowed up.”🔽The sacrifice of the Ayūpa is a one-day sacrifice; the sacrifice of the Sayūpa is to be performed on many days. The term vāja is the name for the ghee and honey that are consecrated with the formulas.

original: sappimadhūnaṃ vājamiti samaññā, hiraññasuvaṇṇagomahiṃ sādisattarasakadakkhiṇassa.
analyzed: sappi madhūnam vājam iti samaññā hirañña suvaṇṇa go mahim sādi satta rasaka dakkhiṇassa
translated: The term dakkhiṇa is the name for the seventeen kinds of gifts such as gold, silver, cows, oxen, etc.

original: Sāragabbhakoṭṭhāgārādīsu natthettha aggaḷanti niraggaḷo. Tattha kira yaññe attano
analyzed: sāragabbha koṭṭhāgāra ādīsu nattha ittha aggaḷanti niraggaḷaḥ tattha kira yaññe attano
translated: “There is no bolt there” means it is without a bolt. It seems that in that sacrifice the king’s

original: sāpateyyaṃ anavasesato anigūhitvā niyyātīyati. Mahārambhāti bahupasughātakammā. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: sāpateyyam anavasesataḥ a nigūhitvā niyyātīyati bahu pasu ghāta kammā
translated: and he does not conceal the property but hands it over. ‘Great undertakings’: the killing of many living beings. But in the Commentary

original: pana “vividhā yattha haññare”ti vakkhamānattā “mahākiccā”ti attho vutto, idha “mahārambhāti
analyzed: pana vividhā yattha mahā kiccā ati attho vuttaḥ idha mahā ārambhā ati
translated: the meaning is given as ‘great business’ because it is said there, ‘Where many🔽are killed’. Here the meaning is given as ‘the killing of many living beings’

original: papañcavasena ajeḷakā”tiādi vuttanti “bahupasughātakammā”ti attho vutto. Nirārambhāti🔽etthāpi vuttanayena attho veditabbo. Anugataṃ kulanti anukulaṃ, kulānugatanti attho
analyzed: ajeḷaka ātiādi vuttanti bahu pasu ghāta kammā ati atthaḥ vuttaḥ nirārambhā ti  ettha api vutta nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ anugatam kulanti anukulam kula anugatanti atthaḥ
translated: because it is said, ‘Great undertakings are the breeding of cattle, etc., for the🔽sake of the extension of the business’. ‘No undertakings’: the meaning should🔽be understood here in the way already stated. ‘A family that is in favour’: a🔽family that is in favour of the bhikkhu. The meaning should be understood

original: veditabbo. Tenāha “yaṃ niccabhattādi…pe… attho”ti.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ tena āha yam niccabhatta ādipe attho ti
translated: as ‘a family that follows the bhikkhu’. Hence it is said, ‘A family that is in favour🔽is one that gives regular meals, etc., and is favourable to the bhikkhu’s aims’ .

original: Yaññasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: yañña sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Yajñavagga is finished.

original: 10. Bandhanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bandhana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Bondage Sutta🔽‘Here’: the statement beginning, ‘Venerable sir, here’ . ‘They reported to

original: 121. Idanti “idha, bhante”tiādikaṃ vacanaṃ. Te bhikkhū ārocesunti sambandho. Tesūti
analyzed: idam ti idha bhante ti ādikam vacanam te bhikkhū ārocesun ti sambandhaḥ tesu iti
translated: the bhikkhus’: the construction is this. ‘Among them’: among those men🔽imprisoned by the king. ‘The reason for their imprisonment’: they reported

original: tesu raññā bandhāpitamanussesu. Sukatakāraṇanti sukāraṇakiriyaṃ ārocesuṃ, na kevalaṃ
analyzed: tesu raññā bandhāpita manussesu su kata kāraṇam ti su kāraṇa kiriyam ārocesuṃ na kevalam
translated: the reason for their imprisonment.

original: tesaṃ manussānaṃ bandhāpitabhāvaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ vitthārato dassetuṃ “rañño kirā”tiādi
analyzed: tesam manussānam bandhāpita bhāvam idāni tam attham vitthārataḥ dassetum raññaḥ kirāti ādi
translated: Now, in order to show that matter in detail, the following is said:🔽“It is said that the king had the eight-limbed army imprisoned.”🔽The eight-limbed army is the eight-part army.🔽The householders are the residents of the inner palace.

original: vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhavaṅkoti aṭṭhaṃso. Antogharacārinoti antepuravāsino.
analyzed: vuttam aṭṭhavaṅko ti aṭṭhaṃso antoghara cārino ti antepura vāsinaḥ
translated: The king had them imprisoned in the battle.🔽The wise are those who know the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.

original: Ukkaṭṭheti yuddhe. Mantīsūti guttamantīsu. Akutūhalanti saññataṃ. Piyanti piyāyitabbaṃ.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha iti yuddhe mantīsu iti gutta mantīsu akutūhalanti saññatam piyanti piyāyitabbam
translated: The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.

original: Annapānamhi madhure abhutte uppanne. Attheti atthe kicce jāte thiranti na kathenti
analyzed: anna pānamhi madhure abhutte uppanne attheti atthe kicce jāte thiranti na kathenti
translated: The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.

original: kāyabalamattena apanetuṃ sakkuṇeyyattā. Suṭṭhu rattarattāti ativiya rattā eva hutvā
analyzed: kāya bala mattena apanetum suṭṭhu ratta rattā ati ativiya rattāḥ eva hutvā
translated: The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.

original: rattā. Sārattenāti sārabhāvena sārabhāvasaññāya. Ohārinanti heṭṭhā haraṇasīlanti
analyzed: rattā sārattena ati sāra bhāvena sāra bhāva saññāya heṭṭhā haraṇa sīlanti
translated: The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.

original: āha “catūsu apāyesu ākaḍḍhanaka”nti. Sithilanti sithilākāraṃ, na pana sithilaṃ. Tenāha🔽bhagavā “duppamuñca”nti.🔽Bandhanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Paṭhamavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āha catūsu apāyesu sithilanti sithila ākāram na pana sithilam tena āha  bhagavān  bandhana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  paṭhama vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.🔽The king had them imprisoned in the secret counsel.

original: 2. Dutiyavaggo
analyzed: dutiya vaggo
translated: The king had them imprisoned in

original: 1. Sattajaṭilasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattajaṭila sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Sutta on the Seven Matted-Hair Ascetics

original: 122. Pubbārāmasaṅkhāteti sāvatthinagarassa pubbadisāya katattā pubbārāmeti saṅkhaṃ🔽gate. Tatrāti “migāramātuyā pāsāde”ti tasmiṃ saṃkhittavacane. Ayaṃ idāni vuccamānā
analyzed: pubba ārāma saṅkhātā iti sāvatthi nagarassa pubba disāya kata ttā pubba ārāmā iti saṅkham  gate tatra ati migāra mātuyā pāsāda iti tasmin saṃkhitta vacane ayam idāni vuccamānā
translated: In the Eastern Park: it is called the Eastern Park because it was built in the east of the city of Sāvatthī. There: in the brief

original: anupubbikathā ādito paṭṭhāya anukkamakathā. Patthanaṃ akāsi tassa bhagavato aggupaṭṭhāyikaṃ
analyzed: anupubbi kathā āditaḥ paṭṭhāya anukkama kathā patthanam akāsi tassa bhagavato aggupaṭṭhāyikam
translated: statement, “in the Migāra Mātā’s Pāsāda,” this is the detailed statement. This is the progressive talk that is being spoken now, the talk in order from the beginning. She made a wish for the position of chief attendant to that Blessed One,

original: ekaṃ upāsikaṃ disvā taṃ ṭhānantaraṃ ākaṅkhantī. Meṇḍakaputtassāti meṇḍakaseṭṭhiputtassa.
analyzed: ekam upāsikam disvā tam ṭhāna antaram ākaṅkhantī meṇḍaka puttassa ati meṇḍaka seṭṭhi puttassa
translated: seeing a female lay follower who was the chief attendant. Meṇḍaka’s son: the son of the merchant Meṇḍaka.

original: Mātiṭṭhāne ṭhapesi tassā upakāraṃ garubhāvañca disvā. Tāya kārite pāsādeti tāya mahāupāsikāya
analyzed: mātiṭṭhāne ṭhapesi tassāḥ upakāram garu bhāvañca disvā tāya kārite pāsāde ti tāya mahā upāsikāya
translated: She placed her in the position of mother, seeing her service and importance. In the Pāsāda built by her: the female lay follower Mahāpajāpatī

original: mahālatāpasādhanaṃ vissajjetvā navahi koṭīhi karīsamatte bhūmibhāge kārite sahassagabbhapaṭimaṇḍite pāsāde.
analyzed: mahā latā apasādhanam vissajjetvā navahi koṭīhi karīsa matte bhūmi bhāge kārite sahassa gabbha paṭimaṇḍite pāsāde
translated: Gotamī, having given a great gift of creepers, had a Pāsāda built on a site of land the size of a bushel of grain with a thousand rooms,

original: Parūḷhakacchāti parūḷhakacchalomā. Kamaṇḍalughaṭikādiṃ pabbajitaparikkhāraṃ. Naggabhogganissirikānanti
analyzed: parūḷha kacchā ati parūḍha kaccha lomā kamaṇḍalu ghaṭikā ādim pabbajita parikkhāram
translated: with hair and body hair grown long. The requisites of a renunciant, such as a water pot and a bowl. The most excellent and wealthy of the Nāgas:

original: naggānañceva bhoggānañca nissirikānañca. Te hi anivatthavatthatāya naggā ceva, acelakavatādinā
analyzed: naggānam ca iva bhoggānam ca nissirikānam ca te hi a nivattha vattha tāya naggā ca iva a celakavat ādinā
translated: and naked, and unclothed, and unadorned. For they are naked because they are without clothes to cover the parts to be covered;🔽they are unclothed because they go about with their bodies covered with grass, etc.; they are unadorned because they are without the adornment of the asoke flower, etc.

original: bhoggasarīratāya bhoggā, sobhārahitatāya nissirikā ca. Attanā diṭṭhasutaṃ paṭicchādetvā
analyzed: bhogga sarīra tāya bhoggā sobhā rahita tāya nissirikā ca attanā diṭṭha sutam paṭicchādetvā
translated: If he had seen or heard that they did not speak of what they had seen or heard after concealing it,

original: na katheyyunti akāraṇametaṃ tesaṃ raññā payuttacarapurisabhāvato. Evaṃ kate pana
analyzed: na katheyyunti akāraṇam etam tesam raññā payutta cara purisa bhāvato evam kate pana
translated: this would be no reason for the king to send spies to them. But if it were done in this way,

original: te “aññepi pabbajitā atthīti ayaṃ jānātī”ti maññeyyunti kohaññacitto evaṃ akāsīti
analyzed: te aññe pi pabbajitāḥ atthi iti ayam jānāti iti maññeyyun ti kohañña cittaḥ evam akāsi iti
translated: they might think, “He knows that there are other bhikkhus too,” and so he did it with the intention of deceiving them.

original: sakkā viññātuṃ. Tathā hi tenatthena aparitosamāno “apicā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: sakkā viññātum tathā hi tena atthena a paritosamānaḥ apica iti ādim āha
translated: This is how it should be understood. Since he was not satisfied with that reason, he said “Besides” , etc.

original: Kāsikacandananti ujjalacandanaṃ. Taṃ kira vaṇṇavasena samujjalaṃ hoti pabhassaraṃ,
analyzed: kāsika candanam ti ujjala candanam tam kira vaṇṇa vasena samujjalam hoti pabhassaram
translated: Kāsika sandalwood: bright sandalwood. It is said that it is bright, shining,

original: tadatthameva naṃ saṇhataraṃ karonti. Tenāha “kāsikacandananti saṇhacandana”nti. Vaṇṇagandhatthāyāti
analyzed: tad attham eva nam saṇhataram karonti tena āha kāsika candana nti saṇha candana nti vaṇṇa gandha tthāya ati
translated: and they make it even denser for that purpose. Hence it is said, “Kāsika sandalwood is dense sandalwood” . For the sake of colour and scent:

original: vaṇṇasobhatthañceva sugandhabhāvatthañca. Vaṇṇagandhatthāyāti chavirāgakaraṇatthañceva
analyzed: vaṇṇa sobha ttham ca iva sugandha bhāva ttham ca vaṇṇa gandha tthāya ati chavi rāga karaṇa ttham ca iva
translated: for the sake of beauty of colour and for the sake of the state of being fragrant. For the sake of colour and scent: for the sake of removing the skin,

original: sugandhatthāya ca. “Gihinā”tiādīhi padehi evaṃ pamādavihārinā tayā arahanto duviññeyyāti dasseti.
analyzed: sugandha tthāya ca gihinā ati ādīhi padehi evam pamāda vihārinā tayā arahantaḥ duviññeyyā ati dasseti
translated: and for the sake of fragrance. By the words “a householder” and so on he shows that you who live negligently cannot understand the Arahants.

original: Saṃvāso nāma idha kālena upasaṅkamananti dassento “upasaṅkamantenā”ti āha. Kāyavācāhi
analyzed: saṃvāsaḥ nāma idha kālena upasaṅkamananti dassento upasaṅkamantena ati āha
translated: “Approaching” means approaching at the proper time.

original: asaṃyatenapi saṃyatākāro, asaṃvutindriyenapi saṃvutindriyākāro. Pariggahessāmīti
analyzed: a saṃyatena api saṃyata ākāraḥ a saṃvuta indriyena api saṃvuta indriya ākāraḥ pariggahessāmi iti
translated: Though undisciplined in body and speech, he should show himself to be disciplined; though his faculties are uncontrolled, he should show them to be controlled.

original: vīmaṃsissāmi “parisuddhaṃ nu kho, no”ti. Sappaññenāti sīlapariggaṇhanapaññāya sappaññena.
analyzed: vīmaṃsissāmi parisuddham nu kho no ti sappaññena ati sīla pariggaṇhana paññāya sappaññena
translated: “I will investigate”: I will examine whether it is pure or not. “The wise”: the wise one who has the wisdom to investigate virtue.

original: Jānituṃ na sakkoti sabhāvassa sato sīlassa anupadhāraṇato.
analyzed: jānitum na sakkoti sabhāvassa sataḥ sīlassa an upadhāraṇato
translated: He cannot know because he does not consider virtue which exists by nature.

original: Kathanenāti aparāparaṃ kathanena. Tathā hi vakkhati “ekaccassa hī”tiādi. Ariyavohāroti
analyzed: kathanena ati apara aparam kathanena tathā hi vakkhati ekaccassa hi itiādi ariya vohāraḥ ti
translated: “By means of discussion”: by means of discussion back and forth. For he says: “In the case of one person it is seen that … “

original: diṭṭhādilakkhaṇena voharito “diṭṭhaṃ adiṭṭha”ntiādinā pavuttasaddavohāro. Tassa pana
analyzed: diṭṭha ādi lakkhaṇena voharitaḥ diṭṭham a diṭṭham ti ādinā pavutta sadda vohāro tassa pana
translated: “The noble way of speaking”: the way of speaking that is expressed by the words “seen, unseen” and so on, which is characterized by the noble path.

original: kāraṇameva gaṇhanto “ettha cetanā”ti āha. Esa nayo anariyavohārepi. Paramatthato
analyzed: kāraṇam eva gaṇhantaḥ ettha cetanā ti āha esa nayaḥ anariya vohāre pi paramatthato
translated: But taking only the reason, he says: “Here the intention is … “ The same method applies to the ignoble way of speaking.

original: hi saccavācādayo musāvādādayo cetanālakkhaṇāti. Paññattivohāro tathā tathā voharitabbato
analyzed: hi sacca vācā ādayaḥ musāvāda ādayaḥ cetanā lakkhaṇā ti paññatti vohāro tathā tathā voharitabbato
translated: The mode of expression is the mode of expression in such and such a way.

original: evamāha “saṃvohārena kho, mahārāja, soceyyaṃ veditabba”nti.
analyzed: evam āha saṃvohārena kho mahā rāja soceyyam veditabbanti
translated: He said thus: “By the mode of expression, sire, purity is to be known.”

original: Ñāṇathāmoti ñāṇaguṇabalaṃ, yena ṭhānuppattikapaṭibhānādinā accāyikakiccakaraṇīyāni
analyzed: ñāṇa thāmaḥ ti ñāṇa guṇa balam yena ṭhān uppattika paṭibhāna ādinā accāyika kicca karaṇīyāni
translated: The fire of knowledge is the quality and strength of knowledge by which one accomplishes the most important duties such as the spontaneous utterance of the truths.

original: niṭṭhāpeti. Saṃkathāyāti atthavīmaṃsanavasena pavattāya sammākathāya. Uppilavati
analyzed: niṭṭhāpeti saṃkathāya ati attha vīmaṃsana vasena pavattāya sammākathāya uppilavati
translated: By discussion is by right discussion that proceeds by way of the investigation of the meaning.🔽The discussion is light because of its lightness.

original: lahukabhāvato. Heṭṭhācarakāti avacarakā. Ye anupavisitvā paresaṃ rahassavīmaṃsanavasena
analyzed: lahuka bhāvataḥ heṭṭhācarakā ati avacarakāḥ ye an upavisitvā paresam rahassa vīmaṃsana vasena
translated: The lower discussion is the discussion of those who, without having investigated, proceed by way of the investigation of the secrets of others.

original: pavattā, tesu ocarakavohāroti vuttaṃ “carā hī”tiādi.
analyzed: pavattā tesu ocaraka vohāro ti vuttam carā hi itiādi
translated: Among them, the discussion of the lower discussion is said to be “the discussion of those who are low.”

original: Vaṇṇasaṇṭhānenāti vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā vaṇṇapokkharatāya vā saṇṭhānasampattiyā
analyzed: vaṇṇa saṇṭhānena ati vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā vaṇṇa pokkharatāya vā saṇṭhāna sampattiyā
translated: By the form and the figure is by the form or by the figure or by the excellence of the form or by the perfection of the figure.

original: vā. Sujāno pesalo vissaseti yojanā. Lahukadassanenāti parittadassanena vijjukena
analyzed: vā su jānaḥ pesalaḥ vissasā iti yojanā lahuka dassanena ati paritta dassanena vijjukena
translated: The meaning is: “One who is well-born, good, and trustworthy.” By the light of vision is by the limited vision of lightning.

original: viya. Parikkhārabhaṇḍakenāti pabbajitaparikkhārabhūtena bhaṇḍakena. Lohaḍḍhamāsoti
analyzed: viya parikkhāra bhaṇḍakena ati pabbajita parikkhāra bhūtena bhaṇḍakena lohaḍḍha māso ti
translated: and so on. With a bundle of requisites: with a bundle of requisites belonging to one gone forth. A half-month’s supply of iron:

original: lohamayo upaḍḍhagghanakamāso.
analyzed: loha mayaḥ upaḍḍhagghanaka māsaḥ
translated: an iron half-month’s supply of coins.

original: Sattajaṭilasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sattajaṭila sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Satta-Jatila Sutta is finished.

original: 2. Pañcarājasuttavaṇṇanā🔽123. Rūpāti rūpasaṅkhātā kāmaguṇā. Te pana nīlādivasena anekabhedabhinnāpi rūpāyatanattā
analyzed: rūpā ati rūpa saṅkhātā kāma guṇā te pana nīla ādi vasena aneka bheda bhinnā api
translated: The Commentary on the Pañca-Rāja Sutta🔽Form is the five strands of sensual desire called “form.” Although they are divided into many kinds as blue, etc., they do not exceed the range of the eye’s sensitivity as visible data.

original: cakkhuviññeyyataṃ nātivattantīti āha “nīlapītādibhedaṃ rūpārammaṇa”nti. To-saddopi
analyzed: cakkhu viññeyya tam na ativattanti iti āha nīla pīta ādi bhedam rūpa ārammaṇam ti tosaddaḥ api
translated: That is why it is said: “The object of eye-consciousness, classed as blue, yellow, and so on” .

original: dā-saddo viya kālattho hotīti āha “yatoti yadā”ti. Manaṃ āpayati vaḍḍhetīti manāpaṃ,🔽manoramaṃ. Manāpanipphattitanti tassa puggalassa manasā piyāyitaṃ, tassa aggabhāvena
analyzed: dāsaddaḥ viya kālatthaḥ hoti iti āha yatas iti yadā ati manam āpayati vaḍḍheti iti manāpam  manoramam manāpa nipphatti tanti tassa puggalassa manasā piyāyitam tassa agga bhāvena
translated: The word to is a temporal word like the word da . That is why it is said: “When” is the same as “if” .🔽What is pleasing is what is agreeable, delightful.

original: pariyantaṃ paramaṃ koṭiṃ katvā pavattitanti attho. Puggalamanāpanti ārammaṇasabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pariyantam paramam koṭim katvā ārammaṇa sabhāvam
translated: What is produced by what is pleasing is what is produced by that person’s mind as dear. The meaning is that it occurs with that person’s mind as its extreme, its limit, its climax.🔽What is pleasing to people is what is agreeable by virtue of its mere being dear to people, regardless of its nature as an object.

original: acintetvā puggalassa vasena manāpabhāveneva iṭṭhatāya iṭṭhanti. Sammutīti samaññā.
analyzed: a cintetvā puggalassa vasena manāpa bhāvena iva iṭṭha tāya iṭṭhanti sammutī iti samaññā
translated: Convention is a common usage.

original: Puggalamanāpaṃ nāma saññāvipallāsavasena viparītampi gaṇhāti itarasabhāvatoti āha
analyzed: puggala manāpam nāma saññā vipallāsa vasena viparītam pi gaṇhāti itara sabhāvato ti āha
translated: What is disagreeable to a person is an object that is taken as the opposite by the perversion of perception, though it is not so in reality. Hence he said:

original: “yaṃ ekassa…pe… iṭṭhaṃ kanta”nti. Idāni taṃ jivhāviññeyyavasena yojetvā dassento🔽“paccantavāsīna”ntiādimāha. Idaṃ puggalamanāpanti idaṃ yathāvuttaṃ jivhāviññeyyaṃ
analyzed: yam ekassape iṭṭham kantanti idāni tam jivhā viññeyya vasena yojetvā dassento  paccanta vāsīna ntiādim āha idam puggala manāpam ti idam yathā vuttam jivhā viññeyyam
translated: “What is agreeable to one person … is disagreeable to another.” Now, showing this by applying it to what is sensed by the tongue, he said:

original: viya aññampi evaṃjātikaṃ tena tena puggalena manāpanti gahetabbārammaṇaṃ puggalamanāpaṃ nāma.🔽Loke paṭivibhattaṃ natthi, vibhajitvā dassanena lokena madhurajātenapi paṭivibhattaṃ
analyzed: viya aññam pi evaṃjātikam tena tena puggalena manāpanti gahetabba ārammaṇam puggala manāpam nāma  loke paṭivibhattam natthi vibhajitvā dassanena lokena madhura jātena api paṭivibhattam
translated: “What is agreeable to one’s enemies.” This is what is disagreeable to a person: any object that is to be taken as agreeable to a certain person in the way already stated, as well as any other object of the same kind.🔽There is nothing in the world that is not shared, that is, that cannot be taken as shared by showing it to the world.

original: katvā gahetuṃ na sakkuṇeyyāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “vibhajitvā pana dassetabba”nti.
analyzed: katvā gahetum na sakkuṇeyya ati adhippāyaḥ tena āha vibhajitvā pana dassetabbam ti
translated: The intention is that it cannot be taken as shared by showing it to the world, even by the sweet-toothed. Hence he said: “But it can be shown by dividing it up.”

original: Dibbakappampīti devalokapariyāpannasadisampi amanāpaṃ upaṭṭhāti uḷārapaṇītārammaṇaparicayato.
analyzed: dibba kappam pi iti deva loka pariyāpanna sadisam pi amanāpam upaṭṭhāti uḷāra paṇīta ārammaṇa paricayato
translated: Even the divine delicacy: even what is disagreeable appears as agreeable because of the abundance of choice objects.

original: Majjhimānaṃ pana…pe… vibhajitabbaṃ tesaṃ manāpassa manāpato, amanāpassa amanāpato
analyzed: majjhimānam panape vibhajitabbam tesam manāpassa manāpataḥ a manāpassa a manāpataḥ
translated: But what is agreeable to some is disagreeable to others. … It should be divided up as follows: what is agreeable to some is disagreeable to others, what is disagreeable to some is agreeable to others.

original: upaṭṭhānato. Tatthapi iṭṭhāniṭṭhaparicchedo nippariyāyato evaṃ veditabboti dassento
analyzed: upaṭṭhānataḥ tattha api iṭṭha aniṭṭha paricchedaḥ nippariyāyataḥ evam veditabbaḥ ti dassento
translated: and from the service. And here the delimitation of the desirable and the undesirable should be understood in the ultimate sense thus.

original: āha “tañca paneta”ntiādi. Tañca panetaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhabhūtaṃ ārammaṇaṃ kāmāvacarajavanesu
analyzed: āha tat ca pana itantiādi tat ca pana itanti ādi iṭṭha aniṭṭha bhūtam ārammaṇam kāmāvacara javanesu
translated: and from the object. Showing how the delimitation of the desirable and undesirable should be understood literally in the case of the first, he said, “And that too” , etc. And that desirable and undesirable object occurs in the impulsions of the sense sphere,

original: akusalassa vasena yebhuyyena pavattatīti katvā tattha “rajjati dussatī”ti akusalasseva🔽pavatti dassitā. Sesakāmāvacarassapi vasena pavatti labbhateva. Tathā hi taṃ appaṭikūlepi
analyzed: akusalassa vasena yebhuyyena pavattati iti katvā tattha rajjati dussati iti akusalassa iva  pavatti dassitā sesa kāmāvacarassa api vasena pavatti labbhateva tathā hi tam a paṭikūle pi
translated: for the most part, by way of the unprofitable. So it is said that “it is attached and averse” there only by way of the unprofitable.🔽But it does occur by way of the rest of the sense sphere too. For that occurs in the unrepulsive as if it were repulsive, and in the repulsive as if it were unrepulsive.

original: paṭikūlākārato, paṭikūlepi appaṭikūlākārato pavattatīti. Vipākacittaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ🔽paricchindati, na sakkā vipākaṃ vañcetunti. Kusalakammaṃ hi ekantato iṭṭhameva, akusalakammañca
analyzed: paṭikūla ākārataḥ paṭikūle pi appaṭikūla ākārataḥ pavattati iti vipāka cittam iṭṭha aniṭṭham  paricchindati na sakkā vipākam vañcetun ti kusala kammam hi ekantataḥ iṭṭham eva akusala kammam ca
translated: The resultant consciousness delimits the desirable and undesirable, but it is impossible to deceive the resultant.

original: aniṭṭhameva, tasmā tattha uppajjamānaṃ vipākacittaṃ yathāsabhāvato pavattatīti.
analyzed: aniṭṭham eva tasmā tattha uppajjamānam vipāka cittam yathā sabhāvataḥ pavattati iti
translated: For profitable kamma is entirely desirable, and unprofitable kamma is entirely undesirable, so the resultant consciousness that arises there occurs according to its individual essence.🔽But in the answer given in the Description of the Kinds of Bondage, “There is no undesirable fruit of profitable kamma,”

original: Yaṃ pana sammohavinodaniyaṃ “kusalakammajaṃ aniṭṭhaṃ nāma natthī”ti ettakameva vuttaṃ,
analyzed: yam pana sammoha vinodaniyam kusala kamma jam aniṭṭham nāma natthi iti ettakam eva vuttam
translated: only this much is said,

original: taṃ pana nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tena sobhanaṃ akusalakammajampi ekaccānaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: tam pana nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam tena sobhanam akusala kamma jam pi ekaccānam sattānam
translated: But that should be regarded as merely an illustration. Consequently it may be admitted that what is beautiful, though produced by unprofitable kamma, is desirable to some beings,

original: iṭṭhanti anuññātaṃ siyā. Kusalakammajaṃ pana sabbesaṃ iṭṭhamevāti vadanti. Tiracchānagatānaṃ
analyzed: iṭṭham ti anuññātam siyā kusala kamma jam pana sabbesam iṭṭham eva ati vadanti tiracchāna gatānam
translated: but what is produced by profitable kamma is desirable to all.

original: kesañci manussarūpaṃ amanāpaṃ, yato te disvāva palāyanti. Manussā ca devatānaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: kesañci manussa rūpam amanāpam yatas te disvā ava palāyanti manussā ca devatānam rūpam
translated: But some animals find the human form repulsive, since they run away on seeing a human being. And humans are afraid on seeing the forms of deities.

original: disvā bhāyanti, tesampi vipākaviññāṇaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ ārabbha kusalavipākameva uppajjati,🔽tādisassa pana puññassa abhāvā na tesaṃ tattha abhirati hotīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kusalakammajassa
analyzed: disvā bhāyanti tesam pi vipāka viññāṇam tam rūpam ārabbha kusala vipākam eva uppajjati  tādisassa pana puññassa abhāvā na tesam tattha abhirati hoti iti daṭṭhabbam kusala kamma jassa
translated: And in their case too only profitable kamma-resultant consciousness arises in the eye-door adverting to that form.

original: pana aniṭṭhassa abhāvo viya akusalakammajassa sobhanassa iṭṭhassa abhāvo vattabbo.
analyzed: pana aniṭṭhassa abhāvaḥ viya akusala kamma jassa sobhanassa iṭṭhassa abhāvaḥ vattabbo
translated: But it should be regarded that they have no delight in it because they have no such kind of merit. And just as there is no undesirable kind of profitable kamma-result, so too there is no desirable kind of unprofitable kamma-result.

original: Hatthiādīnampi hi akusalakammajaṃ manussānaṃ akusalavipākasseva ārammaṇaṃ, kusalakammajaṃ
analyzed: hatthi ādīnam pi hi akusala kamma jam manussānam akusala vipākassa iva ārammaṇam kusala kamma jam
translated: For the elephant, etc., too, that are produced by unprofitable kamma are objects only for unprofitable kamma-resultant consciousness in humans,🔽and those produced by profitable kamma are objects for profitable kamma-resultant consciousness.

original: pana pavatte samuṭṭhitaṃ kusalavipākassa, iṭṭhārammaṇena vomissakattā appakaṃ akusalakammajaṃ
analyzed: pana pavatte samuṭṭhitam kusala vipākassa iṭṭha ārammaṇena vomissaka ttā appakam akusala kamma jam
translated: but the profitable kamma-resultant is small because it is interrupted by a desirable object.

original: bahulaṃ akusalavipākuppattiyā kāraṇaṃ na bhavissatīti sakkā vattuṃ. Idāni tameva🔽vipākavasena iṭṭhāniṭṭhārammaṇavavatthānaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “kiñcāpi hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tayidaṃ
analyzed: bahulam akusala vipāka uppattiyā kāraṇam na bhavissati iti sakkā vattum idāni tam eva  vipāka vasena iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇa vavatthānam vibhāvetum kiñcā api hi itiādi vuttam tayā idam
translated: But it can be said that the unwholesome kamma generated by the occurrence of the unwholesome consciousness is small, because it is mixed with the desirable object, and it will not be a cause for the production of much unwholesome result.

original: sammutimanāpasaṃvibhāgatthaṃ vuttaṃ, idha pana na tathā vibhattanti āha “bhagavā panā”tiādi.
analyzed: sammuti manāpa saṃvibhāga attham vuttam idha pana na tathā vibhattan ti āha bhagavā pana atiādi
translated: Now, in order to show the distinction of desirable and undesirable objects in terms of result, it is said: “And again, though a man does a desirable deed, etc.” This is said for the purpose of distinguishing conventional and spiritual beauty. But here it is not distinguished in that way. Therefore it is said: “But the Blessed One, etc.”

original: So upāsako candanaṅgalagāme jātattā “candanaṅgaliko”ti paññāyati, “candanavilāso”ti
analyzed: so upāsako candanaṅgala gāme jāta ttā candanaṅgaliko ti paññāyati candanavilāso ti
translated: This lay follower is known as “Candanaṅgalika” because he was born in the village of Candanaṅgala. Some say he was called “Candanavilāsa.”🔽The construction is: “The lay follower’s inspiration arose.”

original: keci. Tassa upāsakassa paṭibhānaṃ udapādīti yojanā. Te rājāno hatappabhe hatasobhe
analyzed: keci tassa upāsakassa paṭibhānam udapādi iti yojanā te rājānaḥ hata ppabhe hata sobhe
translated: The construction is: “The kings, seeing that their hands were burned and their beauty destroyed.”

original: disvāti sambandho. Udakābhisitteti udakena abhisiñcite. Aṅgāre viyāti aṅgārakkhaṇe viya.
analyzed: disvā iti sambandhaḥ udaka abhisittā iti udakena abhisiñcite aṅgāre viya ati aṅgāra kkhaṇe viya
translated: “Was sprinkled with water”: was sprinkled with water. “As if with embers”: as if with a handful of embers.

original: Kālassevāti pageva. Avigatagandhaṃ taṅkhaṇavikasitatāya. Īdisaṃ vacananti “acchādesī”ti evarūpaṃ vacananti.
analyzed: kālassa iva ati pagā iva avigata gandham taṅkhaṇa vikasita tāya īdisam vacananti acchādesi iti evarūpam vacananti
translated: And all the more so if it is at the proper time. Unmixed with other scents: because it is fully developed at that moment. Such words: such words as “acchādesī.”

original: Pañcarājasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
translated: The commentary on the Pañcarājasutta is finished.

original: 3. Doṇapākasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: doṇapāka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Doṇapākasutta

original: 124. “Doṇapākakura”nti ettha vibhattilopaṃ katvā niddesoti āha “doṇapākaṃ kura”nti.
analyzed: doṇa pāka kuranti ettha vibhatti lopam katvā niddeso ti āha doṇa pākam kuranti
translated: Herein, the word doṇapāka is a noun formed by dropping the case-ending of the locative of the phrase doṇassa pāko.🔽Doṇassa means of the four pots, that is, of the sixteen ladings.

original: Doṇassāti catunnaṃ āḷhakānaṃ, soḷasanāḷīnanti attho. Tadupiyanti tadanurūpaṃ, tassa
analyzed: doṇassa ati catunnam āḷhakānam soḷasa nāḷīnam ti attho tad upiyanti tad anurūpam tassa
translated: Tadupiya means suitable to that,🔽that is, to the measure stated.

original: vuttaparimāṇassa anucchavikanti attho. Pubbeti taṃdivasato purimataradivasesu. Balavāti
analyzed: vutta parimāṇassa anucchavikanti attho pubbā iti tad divasataḥ purimatara divasesu balavā ati
