translated: She went to the middle of the market, to the middle of the street, thinking, “I will bring back a piece of wood and a vegetable for half a penny.”

original: Siddhatthakanti sāsapaṃ. Sālāyanti anāthasālāyaṃ. Khuraggeyevāti khurasikhe eva, kesorohanakkhaṇe evāti attho.
analyzed: siddhatthakanti sāsapam sālāyanti anāthasālāyam khuraggeya iva ati khura sikhe eva kesaḥ rohanakkhaṇe eva ati attho
translated: Mustard seed: white mustard. In the hall: in the hall of the helpless. At the very edge of the razor: at the very edge of the razor blade. The meaning is: at the moment of the hair growing again.

original: Ekamāsīti ettha ma-kāro padasandhikaro. Saṃhitāvasena ca purimapade vā rassattaṃ.
analyzed: eka māsi iti ettha makāro pada sandhi karaḥ saṃhitā vasena ca purima pade vā
translated: One month: here the syllable ma is a ligature. And in the compound of the preceding word it is short by position.

original: Parapade vā dīghattanti āha “ekā āsī”ti. Bhāvanapuṃsakametaṃ “ekamantaṃ nisīdī”tiādīsu
analyzed: para pade vā āha ekā āsi iti bhāva napuṃsakam etam ekam antam nisīdi iti ādīsu
translated: Or it is long in the following word by quantity. Therefore it is said: “one month.” This is a neuter singular.

original: viya. Puttamaraṇaṃ antaṃ atītaṃ idāni puttamaraṇassa abhāvato. Tenevāha “puttamaraṇaṃ
analyzed: viya putta maraṇam antam atītam idāni putta maraṇassa abhāvato tena iva āha putta maraṇam
translated: The death of her child was the end, the extreme point, because there was no more death of a child after that.

original: nāma natthī”ti. Purisaṃ gavesitunti yathā mayhaṃ purisagavesanā nāma sabbaso natthi,
analyzed: nāma na atthi iti purisam gavesitum ti yathā mayham purisa gavesanā nāma sabbaso natthi
translated: “There is no such thing as a search for a man.”

original: tathā eva puttagavesanāpi natthi, tasmā me puttamaraṇaṃ etadantaṃ, sabbesu khandhādīsu
analyzed: tathā eva putta gavesanā api na atthi tasmā me putta maraṇam etad antam sabbesu khandha ādīsu
translated: Just as there is no search for a man, so too there is no search for a son. Therefore, the death of my son is at an end. In all the aggregates, etc.,

original: bhavādīsu ca taṇhānandiyā abhāvakathanena sabbasattesu taṇhā sabbaso visositā, tassāyeva
analyzed: bhava ādīsu ca taṇhā nandiyāḥ abhāva kathanena sabba sattesu taṇhā sabbasas visositā
translated: and in all the kinds of becoming, etc., she shows that craving and delight are absent. Thus craving for all beings is completely squeezed out by her,

original: kārakaavijjākkhandho padālitoti attano nikkilesataṃ pavedentī therī sīhanādaṃ nadīti.
analyzed: kāraka avijjā kkhandho padālito ti therī sīha nādam nadī iti
translated: and the ignorance that causes it is crushed. Thus the elder nun proclaims her own purity by her lion’s roar.

original: Kisāgotamīsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kisāgotamī sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Kisāgotamī Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Vijayāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vijayā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Vijayā Sutta

original: 165. Pañca aṅgāni etassāti pañcaṅgaṃ, pañcaṅgameva pañcaṅgikaṃ, tena pañcaṅgikena.🔽Ātatantiādīsu ātataṃ nāma cammapariyonaddhesu bheriādīsu ekatalaṃ tūriyaṃ. Vitataṃ
analyzed: pañca aṅgāni etassa ati pañcaṅgam pañcaṅgam eva pañcaṅgikam tena pañcaṅgikena  ātatanti ādīsu ātatam nāma camma pariyonaddhesu bheri ādīsu eka talam tūriyam vitatam
translated: The five factors are its limbs, thus it is a five-limbed instrument, and it is a five-limbed instrument because of the five limbs.

original: nāma ubhayatalaṃ. Ātatavitataṃ nāma tantibaddhavīṇādi. Susiraṃ vaṃsādi. Ghanaṃ sammādi.
analyzed: nāma ubhayatalam ātatavitatam nāma tanti baddha vīṇā ādi susiram vaṃsa ādi ghanam sammādi
translated: In the passage beginning “When it is stretched” , a one-sided musical instrument such as a tabor is called “stretched.” A two-sided instrument such as a drum is called “stretched out.” A stringed instrument such as a lute is called “stretched and stretched out.” A wind instrument such as a flute is called “a wind instrument.” A musical instrument such as a cymbal is called “a percussion instrument.”

original: Tataādivisesopi ātatamevāti “cammapariyonaddhesū”ti visesanaṃ. Ekatalaṃ kumbhathūṇadaddarādi.🔽Ubhayatalaṃ bherimudiṅgādi. Cammapariyonaddhaṃ sesaṃ tantibaddhaṃ sabbaṃ ātatavitataṃ
analyzed: tata ādi visesaḥ api ātatam eva ati camma pariyonaddhesu iti visesanam eka talam kumbha thūṇa daddara ādi  ubhaya talam bheri mudiṅga ādi camma pariyonaddham sesam tanti baddham sabbam ātata vitatam
translated: The distinction “covered with skin” is stated because the distinction of being “stretched out” is already understood. A single surface is a drum, a water-pot, a post-hole, etc.

original: nāma, gomukhīādīnampi ettheva saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Vaṃsādīti ādisaddena saṅkhasiṅgānampi🔽saṅgaho. Sammatāḷa-kaṃsatāḷa-silātāḷa-salākatāḷādi sammādi nāma. Tattha sammatāḷaṃ
analyzed: nāma gomukhī ādīnam pi ettha iva saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ vaṃsa ādi iti ādi saddena  saṅgahaḥ samma tāḷa kaṃsa tāḷa silā tāḷa salāka tāḷa ādi samma ādi nāma tattha samma tāḷam
translated: Both surfaces are a tabor, a kettledrum, etc. All that is covered with skin and bound with strings is called “stretched out.” The mouth-organ, etc., should be understood as included here too. The words “bamboo, etc.”

original: nāma daṇḍamayatāḷaṃ, kaṃsamayatāḷaṃ kaṃsatāḷaṃ, silāyaṃ ayopattena ca tāḷanatāḷaṃ.
analyzed: nāma daṇḍa maya tāḷam kaṃsa maya tāḷam kaṃsa tāḷam silāyam ayopattena ca tāḷana tāḷam
translated: include conches and horns. A “cymbal” is a cymbal made of bronze, a cymbal made of stone, a cymbal made of wood, etc. Herein, a cymbal made of wood is a cymbal made of a stick. A cymbal made of bronze is a cymbal made of bronze. A cymbal made of stone is a cymbal made by striking with an iron plate.

original: Sabbe kāmaguṇe. Uggharitapaggharitaṭṭhenāti upari gharaṇena ca vissandanena ca. Evanti
analyzed: sabbe kāma guṇe uggharita paggharita ṭṭhena ati upari gharaṇena ca vissandanena ca evanti
translated: All the strands of sensual desire. “By the oozing out and trickling down”: by the oozing out above and the trickling down. “Thus”:

original: “iminā pūtikāyenā”ti. Arūpaṭṭhāyinoti sattādhiṭṭhānenāyaṃ dhammadesanāti āha “sabbatthāti
analyzed: iminā pūti kāyena ati arūpa ṭṭhāyino ti satta adhiṭṭhānena ayam dhamma desanā ti āha sabbattha iti
translated: “with this foul body.” “For those who have no regard for the body”: this teaching of the Dhamma is based on the beings. Therefore it is said: “everywhere.”

original: sabbesu rūpārūpabhavesū”ti. Tesaṃ dvinnaṃ rūpārūpabhavānaṃ gahitattā. Bhavabhāvasāmaññato,
analyzed: sabbesu rūpa arūpa bhavesu ti tesam dvinnam rūpa arūpa bhavānam gahita ttā bhava bhāva sāmaññato
translated: and all the kinds of becoming in the form and formless worlds.🔽and the sensual-desire becoming is included by the inclusion of the two kinds of becoming in the form and formless worlds.

original: tadadhiṭṭhānato gahite kāmabhave. Avijjātamo vihato aggamaggena samugghātitattā.
analyzed: tad adhiṭṭhānataḥ gahite kāma bhave avijjātamaḥ vihataḥ aggamaggena samugghātita ttā
translated: and the darkness of ignorance is dispelled by the supreme path, which has uprooted it.

original: Vijayāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vijayā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Vijaya Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Uppalavaṇṇāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Uppalavaṇṇā Sutta🔽“From the top”: from the top of the tree right down to the roots.

original: 166. Aggato paṭṭhāyāti sabbaaggato pabhuti yāva mūlā antarāyuttaṃ sammadeva pupphitaṃ
analyzed: aggataḥ paṭṭhāya ati sabba aggataḥ pabhuti yāva mūlāḥ antara āyuttam sammat eva pupphitam
translated: “A tree in full flower”: a sāla tree in full flower.

original: sālarukkhaṃ. Vaṇṇadhātusīsena vaṇṇadhātusampannaṃ dutiyaṃ bhikkhuniṃ vadatīti āha
analyzed: sāla rukkham vaṇṇa dhātu sīsena vaṇṇa dhātu sampannam dutiyam bhikkhunim vadati iti āha
translated: “A nun who is second to you in looks”: a nun who is second to you in the possession of the physical beauty of the primary elements.

original: “tayā sadisā aññā bhikkhunī natthī”ti. Pakhumasīsena akkhibhaṇḍaṃ vuccatīti āha “pakhumantarikāyanti🔽dvinnaṃ akkhīnaṃ majjhe”ti. Nāsavaṃseti nāsavaṃsamūle. “Na passasī”ti vatvā adassane
analyzed: tayā sadisā aññā bhikkhunī natthi iti pakhuma sīsena akkhibhaṇḍam vuccati iti āha  dvinnam akkhīnam majjheti na āsa vaṃseti nāsa vaṃsa mūle na passasi iti vatvā adassane
translated: “There is no other nun like you”: there is no other nun who is your equal.🔽“The space between the eyebrows”: the space between the two eyes is called the “space between the eyebrows.”🔽“The base of the nose”: the base of the nose-cone.

original: kāraṇaṃ āha “vasībhūtamhī”ti.
analyzed: kāraṇam āha
translated: “You do not see”: after saying “You do not see,” she gives the reason for not seeing: “I have become the master.”

original: Uppalavaṇṇāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: uppalavaṇṇā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Uppalavaṇṇā Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Cālāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cālā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Cālā Sutta

original: 167. Idanti idaṃ dassanaṃ. Gāhāpesīti samādāpesi “jātiṃ mā rocā”ti. Aññanti bandhavadhato aññaṃ chedanādiṃ. Nivesesīti pavisāpesi.
analyzed: idam ti idam dassanam gāhāpesi iti samādāpesi jātim mā rocāti aññanti bandha vadhataḥ aññam chedana ādim nivesesi iti pavisāpesi
translated: ‘This’: this view. ‘Had them take up’: had them undertake. ‘Another’: another than the bondage of birth. ‘Had them enter’: had them enter into.

original: Cālāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cālā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Cālā Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Upacālāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upacālā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Upacālā Sutta

original: 168. Punappunaṃ…pe… āgacchanti kāraṇassa asamūhatattā. Santāpito kilesasantāpehi. Agatīti avisayo.
analyzed: punappunaṃpe āgacchanti kāraṇassa a samūhatattā santāpitaḥ kilesa santāpehi agatī iti avisayaḥ
translated: … come again and again … because the cause has not been uprooted. ‘Tormented’: tormented by the defilements. ‘No way out’: no way out.

original: Upacālāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: upacālā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Upacālā Sutta is finished.

original: 8. Sīsupacālāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīsupacālā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sīsupacālā Sutta

original: 169. Samaṇisadisāti samaṇaliṅgassa dhāraṇena samaṇisadisā, kassacipi pāsaṇḍassa aruccanato
analyzed: sa maṇi sadisā ati samaṇa liṅgassa dhāraṇena sa maṇi sadisā kassacipi pāsaṇḍassa a ruccanato
translated: ‘Like an ascetic’: by bearing the ascetic’s emblem they are like an ascetic, but because of their lack of faith in the Blessed One’s Dispensation

original: monamaggassa appaṭipajjanato tava samaṇibhāvaṃ nānupassāmīti adhippāyo. Pāsaṃ ḍentīti🔽pāsaṃ sajjenti, yathā tattha diṭṭhipāse sattānaṃ cittaṃ paṭimukkaṃ hoti, evaṃ sajjentīti
analyzed: mona maggassa appaṭipajjanataḥ tava samaṇi bhāvam na anupassāmi iti adhippāyaḥ pāsam ḍenti iti  pāsam sajjenti yathā tattha diṭṭhi pāse sattānam cittam paṭimukkam hoti evam sajjenti iti
translated: and their failure to follow the path of the monastics, I do not see that you are an ascetic. The meaning is that they set their snares.🔽They set their snares so that the minds of beings may be caught in the snares of views.🔽That is the meaning. And they are like arrows shot into the minds of beings.

original: attho. Tathābhūtā ca te sattānaṃ citte khittā viya hontīti āha “cittesu diṭṭhipāsaṃ
analyzed: attho tathābhūtā ca te sattānam citte khittāḥ viya honti iti āha cittesu diṭṭhi pāsam
translated: ‘In the minds’ means in the minds of beings.

original: khipantīti attho”ti. Pāse mocetīti diṭṭhipāse sattānaṃ cittasantānato nīharati dhammasudhammatāya.
analyzed: khipanti iti attho ti pāse moceti iti diṭṭhi pāse sattānam citta santānataḥ nīharati dhamma su dhamma tāya
translated: He releases from the snare: he removes beings from the snare of views by means of the true nature of dhammas.

original: Tasmāti pāsamocanato pāsaṇḍoti na vuccati. “Ito bahiddhāyeva pāsaṇḍā hontī”ti vuttassa🔽atthassa nigamanaṃ. Evañca katvā sabbepi bāhirakasamaye sandhāya cūḷasīhanādasutte
analyzed: tasmā ati pāsa mocanato pāsaṇḍaḥ ti na vuccati itas bahiddhā yeva pāsaṇḍāḥ honti iti vuttassa  atthassa nigamanam evam ca katvā sabbe api bāhiraka samaye sandhāya cūḷasīhanāda sutte
translated: Therefore, because he releases from the snare, he is not called a ‘Pāsaṇḍa.’ The meaning of the words ‘Pāsaṇḍas are only outside this Dispensation’ is concluded.🔽And when it is taken thus, all the outsiders are referred to in the Cūḷa-Sihanāda Sutta when it is said, ‘ninety-six kinds of Pāsaṇḍa’ .

original: “channavuti pāsaṇḍā”ti vuttaṃ. Pasīdantīti diṭṭhipaṅke saṃsārapaṅke ca pakārehi agādhā osīdanti.
analyzed: channavuti pāsaṇḍā ti vuttam pasīdanti iti diṭṭhi paṅke saṃsāra paṅke ca pakārehi agādhāḥ osīdanti
translated: They sink: they sink in the mud of views and in the mud of the round of rebirths by means of the kinds of mud.

original: Abhibhavitvāti sabbasaṃkilesappahānena abhibhuyya atikkamitvā. Ajitoti ajini avijayattā.
analyzed: abhibhavitvā iti sabba saṃkilesa ppahānena abhibhuyya atikkamitvā ajitā iti ajini a vijaya tā
translated: Having overcome: having overcome, having surmounted, by abandoning all defilements. Ajita: because he has conquered, because he has overcome.

original: Sabbāni akusalakammāni kusalakammāni ca khīṇāni etthāti sabbakammakkhayo, arahattaṃ.
analyzed: sabbāni akusala kammāni kusala kammāni ca khīṇāni ettha ati sabba kamma kkhayaḥ arahattam
translated: All bad actions and all good actions are destroyed here, thus it is the destruction of all actions , arahatship.

original: Upadhayo sammadeva khīyanti etthāti upadhisaṅkhayo, nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: upadhayaḥ sammad eva khīyanti ettha ati upadhi saṅkhayaḥ nibbānam
translated: The attachments are completely destroyed here, thus it is the destruction of attachments , Nibbāna.

original: Sīsupacālāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sīsupacālā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Sīsupacālā Sutta is finished.

original: 9. Selāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: selā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Selā Sutta

original: 170. Kenidaṃ pakataṃ bimbanti idaṃ attabhāvasaññitaṃ bimbaṃ brahmā-visaṇupurisa-pajāpatiādīsu
analyzed: kena idam pakatam bimbanti idam atta bhāva saññitam bimbam brahma avi saṇu purisa pajāpati ādīsu
translated: “By whom was this created, this image?” — this image called “self” in the case of Brahmā, the Visanu-man, Pajāpati, and so on.

original: kena kataṃ nimmitaṃ nibbattitanti kattabbamohaṃ nāma kātukāmo pucchati. Aghanti aghavatthu.
analyzed: kena katam nimmitam nibbattitanti kattabba moham nāma kātu kāmo pucchati agham agha vatthu
translated: “By whom was it made, created, produced?” — he asks, thinking that there must be a maker. “Evil” — the basis of evil.

original: Tenāha “dukkhapatiṭṭhānattā”ti. Hetunirodhenāti taṇhāsaṅkhatassa hetuno anuppādanirodhena.
analyzed: tena āha dukkha patiṭṭhāna ttā ati hetu nirodhena ati taṇhā saṅkhatassa hetuno anuppāda nirodhena
translated: Therefore it is said: “because it is the basis of suffering.” “By the cessation of the cause” — by the cessation of the non-arising of the cause consisting of craving.

original: Paccayavekallenāti tadavasiṭṭhakilesābhisaṅkhārādipaccayassa vekallabhāvena, apaccayabhāvūpagamanenāti attho.
analyzed: paccaya vekallena āti tad avasiṭṭha kilesa abhisaṅkhāra ādi paccayassa vekalla bhāvena a paccaya bhāva upagamanena ati attho
translated: “By the absence of conditions” — by the absence of the remaining conditions such as defilements and formations, etc. The meaning is: by the acceptance of the state of non-conditionality.

original: Selāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: selā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sela Sutta is concluded.

original: 10. Vajirāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vajirā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Vajira Sutta

original: 171. Suddhasaṅkhārapuñjeti rūpārūpavibhāge kilesasaṅkhārasamūhe. Paramatthatoti sabhāvena.
analyzed: suddha saṅkhāra puñja iti rūpa arūpa vibhāge kilesa saṅkhāra samūhe sabhāvena
translated: “A mere heap of formations”: a mass of formations called “living being.” “In the ultimate sense”: by way of individual essence.

original: Yathā na hi sattasaññitasaṅkhārapuñjo nāma paramatthato upalabbhati, evaṃ tabbinimutto
analyzed: yathā na hi satta saññita saṅkhāra puñjaḥ nāma paramatthataḥ upalabbhati evam tad vinimuttaḥ
translated: Just as a mass of formations called “living being” is not found in the ultimate sense, so too, that which is separate from the mass of formations called “living being” —

original: nāma koci na upalabbhati avijjamānattā. Vijjamānesūti yathāpaccayasampattiyā labbhamānesu.
analyzed: nāma koci na upalabbhati a vijjamāna ttā vijjamānesu ati yathā paccaya sampattiyā labbhamānesu
translated: No one is found, because he does not exist. “In what exists”: in what is obtained through the concurrence of conditions.

original: Tenākārenāti itthipurisādiākārena. Vavatthitesūti paccekaṃ paccayavisesasamuṭṭhitaṃ🔽saṇṭhānavisesaṃ upādāya “puriso hatthī asso”tiādinā abhisaṅgato pavattesu. Sammutīti
analyzed: tena ākārena ati itthi purisa ādi ākārena vavatthitesu iti paccekam paccaya visesa samuṭṭhitam  saṇṭhāna visesam upādāya purisaḥ hatthī assa iti ādinā abhisaṅgataḥ pavattesu sammuti iti
translated: “In that form”: in the form of a woman, man, etc. “Defined”: defined by the individual differences in shape produced by the different conditions.🔽“In what is agreed upon”: in the designation “living being.”

original: sattoti vohāro. Tenāha “samaññāmattamevā”ti. Pañcakkhandhadukkhanti pañcakkhandhasaññitaṃ🔽dukkhaṃ. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ bhagavatā “saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā”ti añño neva
analyzed: satto ti vohāro tena āha samaññā mattam eva iti pañca kkhandha dukkham ti pañca kkhandha saññitam  dukkham vuttam ha etam bhagavatā saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ati aññaḥ na iva
translated: “Mere concept”: the mere concept of the five aggregates of clinging.🔽For this is said by the Blessed One: “In brief, the five aggregates of clinging are suffering” .

original: sambhoti yathāvuttadukkhato aññassa saṅkhatadhammassa abhāvato. Na nirujjhatīti tato
analyzed: yathā vutta dukkhataḥ aññassa saṅkhata dhammassa abhāvataḥ na nirujjhati iti tatas
translated: No other conditioned thing is possible apart from the suffering already mentioned, because no other conditioned thing exists apart from that.

original: aññaṃ na nirujjhati, uppādato hoti nirodhoti.
analyzed: aññam na nirujjhati uppādataḥ hoti nirodhaḥ ti
translated: “It does not cease”: nothing else ceases apart from that. “Its arising is its cessation”: its arising is its cessation.

original: Vajirāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Sāratthappakāsiniyā saṃyuttanikāya-aṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: vajirā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  sārattha ppakāsiniyā saṃyutta nikāya aṭṭhakathāya
translated: The commentary on the Vajira Sutta is finished.🔽The commentary on the Bhikkhunī Samyutta is finished.

original: Bhikkhunīsaṃyuttavaṇṇanāya līnatthappakāsanā samattā.
analyzed: bhikkhunī saṃyutta vaṇṇanāya līna ttha ppakāsanā samattā
translated: The explanation of the meaning of the brief account is finished.

original: 6. Brahmasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: brahmasaṃyuttam
translated: 6. The Connected Discourses with Brahmā

original: 1. Paṭhamavaggo
analyzed: paṭhama vaggo
translated: . The First Chapter

original: 1. Brahmāyācanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahmāyācana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse on the Request of Brahmā

original: 172. Parivitakko udapādīti dhammagambhīratāpaccavekkhaṇahetuko dhammadesanāya appossukko
analyzed: parivitakkaḥ udapādi iti dhamma gambhīra tā paccavekkhaṇa hetukaḥ dhamma desanāya appa ussukkaḥ
translated: “A thought arose in him” : he became disinclined to teach the Dhamma because of his reflection on the profundity of the Dhamma.

original: uppajji. Ayaṃ parivitakko kasmā udapādi? Kattha ca udapādīti taṃ sabbaṃ vibhāvetuṃ
analyzed: uppajji ayam parivitakko kasmai udapādi kattha ca udapādi iti tam sabbam vibhāvetum
translated: Why did this thought arise in him? And where did it arise? In order to explain all this,

original: “sabbabuddhāna”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha āciṇṇasamāciṇṇoti ācarito ceva ācarantehi
analyzed: sabba buddha ananti ādi āraddham tattha āciṇṇa samāciṇṇaḥ ti ācaritaḥ ca iva ācarantehi
translated: the following is stated: “In the case of all Buddhas, etc.” Herein, “practised” means practised by those who practise,

original: ca sammadeva ācaritoti attho. Etena ayaṃ parivitakko sabbabuddhānaṃ paṭhamābhisambodhiyaṃ
analyzed: ca sammadeva ācarito ti attho etena ayam parivitakko sabba buddhānam paṭhama abhisambodhiyam
translated: and “well practised” means well practised by those who practise well. By this he shows that this thought arises in the case of all Buddhas at the time of their enlightenment,

original: uppajjatevāti ayamettha dhammatāti dasseti. Tattha aṭṭhame sattāheti idaṃ sattamasattāhato
analyzed: uppajjate iva ati ayam ettha dhamma tā ti dasseti tattha aṭṭhame sattāhe iti idam sattama sattāhato
translated: and that this is the nature of things here. Herein, “in the eighth week” is said because it arose in the eighth week after the fifth week.

original: paraṃ sattāhabbhantare uppannattā vuttaṃ, na pana itaresaṃ viya aṭṭhamassa nāma sattāhassa
analyzed: param satta aha bbhantare uppanna ttā vuttam na pana itaresam viya aṭṭhamassa nāma satta ahassa
translated: But it is not the nature of the eighth week by name,

original: pavattitassa sabbhāvā. Sapaccaggheti mahagghe. “Paccagghe”ti vā pāṭho, abhinaveti
analyzed: pavattitassa sabbhāvā sa paccagghā iti mahagghe paccagghā iti vā pāṭhaḥ abhinavā iti
translated: as in the case of the others. “Costly” means valuable. “Costly” is also a reading. “To be desired” means

original: attho. Selamayeti muggavaṇṇasilāmaye.
analyzed: sela mayā iti mugga vaṇṇa silā maye
translated: Meaning. Of crystal: of crystal-coloured stone.

original: Paṭividdhoti sayambhuñāṇena “idaṃ dukkha”ntiādinā paṭimukhaṃ nibbijjhanavasena patto,
analyzed: paṭividdhaḥ ti sayambhu ñāṇena idam dukkham ti ādinā paṭimukham nibbijjhana vasena patto
translated: Realized: attained by means of the knowledge of the Enlightened One himself by penetrating it face to face by way of the disillusionment of it thus “This is suffering,” etc.;

original: yāthāvato avabuddhoti attho. Dhammoti catusaccadhammo tabbinimuttassa paṭivijjhitabbadhammassa
analyzed: yāthāvataḥ avabuddhaḥ ti atthaḥ dhammo ti catu sacca dhammo tad vinimuttassa paṭivijjhitabba dhammassa
translated: the meaning is, understood in accordance with actuality. Dhamma: the Dhamma of the Four Truths. Because there is no Dhamma to be penetrated that is separate from the four truths.

original: abhāvato. Gambhīroti mahāsamuddo viya makasatuṇḍasūciyā aññatra samupacitaparipakkañāṇasambhārehi
analyzed: abhāvataḥ gambhīraḥ ti mahā samuddaḥ viya makasa tuṇḍa sūciyā aññatra samupacita paripakka ñāṇa sambhārehi
translated: Deep: like the ocean, it has a footing that cannot be reached by any knowledge other than the knowledge that has been accumulated and matured by the tusk-like exertion of the thirty-three faculties.

original: aññesaṃ ñāṇena alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭho. Tenāha “uttānapaṭikkhepavacanameta”nti. Yo alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭho,
analyzed: aññesam ñāṇena alabbhaneyya patiṭṭho tena āha uttāna paṭikkhepa vacanam etat ti yaḥ alabbhaneyya patiṭṭho
translated: Therefore it is said, “This is a statement that rejects the obvious.” That which has a footing that cannot be reached

original: so ogāhituṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya sarūpato visesato ca passituṃ na sakkāti āha “gambhīrattāva🔽duddaso”ti. Dukkhena daṭṭhabboti kicchena kenaci kadācideva daṭṭhabbo. Yaṃ pana daṭṭhumeva
analyzed: saḥ ogāhitum a sakkuṇeyya tāya sarūpataḥ visesataḥ ca passitum na sakkā iti āha gambhīra ttā va  duddaso ti dukkhena daṭṭhabbo ti kicchena kenaci kadācid eva daṭṭhabbaḥ yam pana daṭṭhum eva
translated: is incapable of being fathomed, and therefore it cannot be seen either in its general or specific nature. Thus it is said, “Because of its profundity it is hard to see” .

original: na sakkā, tassa ogāhetvā anu anu bujjhanako kadāci natthīti āha “duddasattāva duranubodho”ti.
analyzed: na sakkā tassa ogāhetvā anu anu bujjhanakaḥ kadāci natthi iti āha duddasa ttāva duranubodhaḥ ti
translated: Hard to see: to be seen with difficulty. It is to be seen only by some at some time with difficulty. But that which cannot be seen at all cannot be fathomed and cannot be penetrated by way of gradual understanding. Thus it is said, “Because of its difficulty to see it is hard to awaken to” .

original: Dukkhena avabujjhitabbo avabodhassa dukkarabhāvato. Imasmiṃ ṭhāne “taṃ kiṃ maññatha,
analyzed: dukkhena avabujjhitabbaḥ avabodhassa dukkara bhāvataḥ imasmin ṭhāne tam kim maññatha
translated: It should be penetrated with difficulty, because penetration is difficult.🔽At this point, “What do you think, bhikkhus,

original: bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho dukkarataraṃ vā durabhisambhavataraṃ vā”ti suttapadaṃ vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhave katamam nu kho dukkarataram vā durabhisambhavataram vā ti sutta padam vattabbam
translated: It is to be penetrated with difficulty because of the difficulty of penetrating it. Herein, the passage from the sutta beginning, “What do you think, bhikkhus? Which is more difficult to do or to attain, the difficult or the very difficult?” should be quoted.

original: Santārammaṇatāya vā santo. Nibbutasabbapariḷāhatāya nibbuto. Attano paccayehi padhānabhāvaṃ
analyzed: santa ārammaṇa tāya vā santaḥ nibbuta sabba pariḷāha tāya nibbutaḥ attanaḥ paccayehi padhāna bhāvam
translated: Or alternatively, it is peaceful because it is the object of peace. It is sublime because it has reached the state of being the most excellent of all its conditions.

original: nītoti vā paṇīto. Atittikaraṇaṭṭhena atappako sādurasabhojanaṃ viya. Tattha ca nirodhasaccaṃ
analyzed: nītaḥ iti vā paṇītaḥ a tittikaraṇa ṭṭhena atappako sādu rasa bhojanam viya tattha ca nirodha saccam
translated: Or it is sublime because it has been brought to the state of being the most excellent by its own conditions. It is unsurpassed because it cannot be surpassed by anything else, like food that is too hot to eat.

original: santaṃ ārammaṇanti santārammaṇaṃ, maggasaccaṃ santaṃ santārammaṇañcāti santārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: santam ārammaṇanti santa ārammaṇam magga saccam santam santa ārammaṇam ca ati santa ārammaṇam
translated: Herein, the truth of cessation is peaceful because it is the object of peace. The truth of the path is peaceful and the object of peace.

original: anupasantasabhāvānaṃ kilesānaṃ saṅkhārānañca abhāvato santo. Nibbutasabbapariḷāhattā🔽nibbuto. Santapaṇītabhāveneva tadatthāya asecanakatāya atappakatā daṭṭhabbā. Tenāha
analyzed: anupasanta sabhāvānam kilesānam saṅkhārānam ca abhāvataḥ santaḥ nibbuta sabba pariḷāha ttā  nibbutaḥ santa paṇīta bhāvena iva tad atthāya asecanakatāya atappaka tā daṭṭhabbā tena āha
translated: It is peaceful because it is the absence of defilements and of formations that are not peaceful. It is sublime because it is the absence of all the burning of the fevers of defilement.🔽It is unsurpassed because it cannot be surpassed by anything else, like food that is too hot to eat. Herein, the words “This pair is stated only in the sense of the supramundane” should be understood to refer to the words “peaceful” and “sublime.”

original: “idaṃ dvayaṃ lokuttarameva sandhāya vutta”nti. Uttamañāṇassa visayattā na takkena
analyzed: idam dvayam lokuttaram eva sandhāya vuttan ti uttama ñāṇassa visaya ttā na takkena
translated: It is the object of the highest knowledge, not of the knowledge of the worlds.

original: avacaritabbo. Tato eva nipuṇañāṇagocaratāya saṇhasukhumasabhāvattā ca nipuṇo. Bālānaṃ
analyzed: avacaritabbo tatas eva nipuṇa ñāṇa gocara tāya saṇha sukhuma sabhāvattā ca nipuṇaḥ bālānam
translated: and is to be penetrated. It is subtle because it is the domain of subtle knowledge and because it has a nature that is delicate and fine.

original: avisayattā yathāvuttehi paṇḍitehi eva veditabboti paṇḍitavedanīyo. Ālīyanti abhiramitabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: a visaya ttā yathā vuttehi paṇḍitehi eva veditabbaḥ ti paṇḍita vedanīyaḥ ālīyanti abhiramitabba ṭṭhena
translated: and it is to be penetrated by the wise. It is subtle because it is the domain of subtle knowledge and because it has a subtle and fine nature. It is to be known by the wise alone because it is not the province of fools.

original: sevīyantīti ālayā, pañca kāmaguṇā. Ālayanti allīyanti abhiramaṇavasena sevantīti🔽ālayā, taṇhāvicaritāni. Ramantīti ratiṃ vindanti kīḷanti laḷanti. Ālayaratāti ālayaniratā.
analyzed: pañca kāma guṇāḥ ālayanti allīyanti abhiramaṇa vasena sevanti iti  ālayā taṇhā vicaritāni ramanti iti ratim vindanti kīḍanti laḷanti ālaya ratā ati ālaya niratā
translated: The five strands of sensual desire are “the attachments” because one clings to them by way of delighting in them.🔽The activities of craving are “the attachments” because one clings to them by way of delighting in them and enjoying them.🔽They delight, find delight, play, and sport. They are attached to the attachments.

original: Ṭhānaṃ sandhāyāti ṭhānasaddaṃ sandhāya, atthako pana ṭhānanti ca paṭiccasamuppādo
analyzed: ṭhānam sandhāya ati ṭhāna saddam sandhāya atthakaḥ pana ṭhānam ti ca paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: “Referring to the state”: referring to the word “state.” But the meaning of “state” is simply dependent origination.

original: eva adhippeto. Tiṭṭhati phalaṃ tadāyattavuttitāyāti hi ṭhānaṃ, saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccayabhūtā
analyzed: eva adhippetaḥ tiṭṭhati phalam tad āyatta vutti tāya ati hi ṭhānam saṅkhāra ādīnam paccaya bhūtā
translated: For a state is that on which a fruit depends for its occurrence. Ignorance, etc., which are the conditions for formations, etc.,

original: avijjādayo. Imesaṃ saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccayā idappaccayā, avijjādayo. Idappaccayā eva
analyzed: avijjā ādayaḥ imesam saṅkhāra ādīnam paccayāḥ idappaccayāḥ avijjā ādayaḥ idappaccayāḥ eva
translated: are the “specific condition” of these formations, etc. The specific condition is

original: idappaccayatā yathā “devo eva devatā”. Idappaccayānaṃ vā avijjādīnaṃ attano phalaṃ
analyzed: idappaccaya tā yathā devaḥ eva devatā idappaccayānam vā avijjā ādīnam attanaḥ phalam
translated: the specific state. Just as “devatā” is the state of “deva.” Or the specific state is of ignorance, etc., which are the specific conditions.🔽The fruit of these specific conditions, ignorance, etc., is

original: pati paccayabhāvo uppādanasamatthatā idappaccayatā. Tena paramatthapaccayalakkhaṇo
analyzed: paccaya bhāvaḥ uppādana samattha tā idappaccaya tā tena paramattha paccaya lakkhaṇo
translated: Thus the dependent origination is shown to have the characteristic of the ultimate condition.

original: paṭiccasamuppādo dassito hoti. Paṭicca samuppajjati phalaṃ etasmāti paṭiccasamuppādo.
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādaḥ dassitaḥ hoti paṭicca samuppajjati phalam etasma ati paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: The fruit originates in dependence on this, thus it is dependent origination.

original: Padadvayenapi dhammānaṃ paccayaṭṭho eva vibhāvito. Tenāha “saṅkhārādipaccayānaṃ etaṃ
analyzed: pada dvayena api dhammānam paccaya ṭṭhaḥ eva vibhāvito tena āha saṅkhāra ādi paccayānam etam
translated: By the two words “dependent” and “origination” the state of being a condition of dhammas is also shown. Therefore it is said: “This is a designation for the conditions of formations, etc.”

original: adhivacana”nti. Saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccayā saṅkhārādipaccayā, avijjādayo. Tesaṃ saṅkhārādipaccayānaṃ.
analyzed: adhivacanam ti saṅkhāra ādīnam paccayā saṅkhāra ādi paccayāḥ avijjā ādayo tesam saṅkhāra ādi paccayānam
translated: The conditions of formations, etc., are ignorance, etc.

original: Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimaggasaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayena veditabbo.
analyzed: ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magga saṃvaṇṇanāyam vutta nayena veditabbaḥ
translated: This is the brief explanation here. The detailed explanation should be understood by the method stated in the Visuddhimagga commentary.

original: Sabbasaṅkhārasamathotiādi sabbanti sabbasaṅkhārasamathādiabhidheyyaṃ sabbaṃ atthato
analyzed: sabba saṅkhāra samatha uti ādi sabbanti sabba saṅkhāra samatha ādi abhidheyyam sabbam atthataḥ
translated: All is the whole of the object of expression beginning with the stilling of all formations. In fact, all is only nibbana.

original: nibbānameva. Idāni assa nibbānabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “yasmā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tanti nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam eva idāni assa nibbāna bhāvam dassetum yasmā hi itiādi vuttam tat ti nibbānam
translated: Now, in order to show that it is nibbana, it is said: “Because, etc.” That is nibbana.

original: Āgammāti paṭicca ariyamaggassa ārammaṇapaccayahetu. Sammantīti paṭippassaddhivūpasamavasena
analyzed: āgamma ti paṭicca ariya maggassa ārammaṇa paccaya hetu sammanti iti paṭippassaddhi vūpasama vasena
translated: By coming to it, by depending on it, by the condition of being the object of the noble path, by the cause. It is stilled means it is stilled by the state of complete cessation and by the state of peace.

original: sammanti. Tathā santā ca savisesaṃ upasantā nāma hontīti āha “vūpasammantī”ti. Etena
analyzed: sammanti tathā santā ca savisesam upasantāḥ nāma honti iti āha vūpasammanti iti etena
translated: They are stilled. And being stilled, they are stilled in a special way. Thus it is said: “They are stilled, stilled” .🔽By this he shows that the cessation of all formations is Nibbāna, since all formations are stilled there.

original: sabbe saṅkhārā sammanti etthāti sabbasaṅkhārasamatho, nibbānanti dasseti. Sabbasaṅkhāravisaṃyutte🔽hi nibbāne sabbasaṅkhāravūpasamapariyāyo aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vutto eva. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.🔽Upadhīyati ettha dukkhanti upadhi, khandhādayo. Paṭinissaṭṭhāti samucchedavasena🔽pariccattā honti. Sabbā taṇhāti aṭṭhasatappabhedā sabbāpi taṇhā. Sabbe kilesarāgāti🔽kāmarāgarūparāgādibhedā sabbepi kilesabhūtā rāgā, sabbepi vā kilesā idha “kilesarāgā”ti
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā ettha ati sabba saṅkhāra samathaḥ nibbānam ti dasseti sabba saṅkhāra visaṃyutte  hi nibbāne sabba saṅkhāra vūpasama pariyāyaḥ aṭṭhakathāyam vuttaḥ eva sesa padesu pi esā iva nayo  upadhīyati ettha dukkhanti upadhi khandha ādayo paṭinissaṭṭhā ati samuccheda vasena  pariccattāḥ honti sabbā taṇhā ati aṭṭha sata ppabhedā sabbā api taṇhā sabbe kilesa rāgā ati  kāma rāga rūpa rāga ādi bhedā sabbe api kilesa bhūtā rāgā sabbe api vā kilesā idha kilesa rāgā ati
translated: For in Nibbāna, which is dissociated from all formations, the method of the cessation of all formations is stated in the commentary. The same method applies to the other terms as well.

original: adhippetā, na lobhavisesā eva cittassa pariḷāhabhāvāpādanato. Yathāha “rattampi cittaṃ
analyzed: adhippetāḥ na lobha visesāḥ eva cittassa pariḷāha bhāva āpādanataḥ yathā āha rattam pi cittam
translated: “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to lust is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to lust for the five aggregates as objects of clinging is abandoned. “The underlying tendency to aversion is abandoned” : the underlying tendency to aversion towards the five aggregates as objects of clinging

original: vipariṇataṃ, duṭṭhampi cittaṃ vipariṇataṃ, mūḷhampi cittaṃ vipariṇata”nti. Virajjantīti
analyzed: vipariṇatam duṭṭham pi cittam vipariṇatam mūḷham api cittam vipariṇatanti virajjanti iti
translated: “It fades away”: it falls away, by suppression, through being completely dissociated from it.

original: palujjanti vikkhambhanato sabbaso tena visaṃyuttabhāvato. Sabbaṃ dukkhanti jarāmaraṇādibhedaṃ🔽sabbaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ. Bhavena bhavanti tena tena bhavena bhavantaraṃ bhavanikantibhāvena
analyzed: palujjanti vikkhambhanato sabbaso tena visaṃyutta bhāvato sabbam dukkhanti jarā maraṇa ādi bhedam  sabbam vaṭṭa dukkham bhavena bhavanti tena tena bhavena bhavantaram bhava nikanti bhāvena
translated: “All suffering”: all the suffering of the round of rebirths, classed as aging-and-death, etc.,

original: saṃsibbati. Phalena vā saddhiṃ kammaṃ sataṇhasseva āyatiṃ punabbhavabhāvato. Tato🔽vānato nikkhantaṃ tattha tassa sabbaso abhāvato. Ciranisajjācirabhāsanehi piṭṭhiāgilāyanatālugalasosādivasena
analyzed: saṃsibbati phalena vā saddhim kammam āyatim punabbhava bhāvataḥ tatas  vānataḥ nikkhantam tattha tassa sabbasas abhāvataḥ cira nisajja a cira bhāsanehi piṭṭhiā gilāyana tālu gala sosa ādi vasena
translated: “It is through being that it is” : it is through this or that kind of being that it is bound to the next becoming by the bond of being, or else it is through the kamma that has craving for its condition that it is bound to the future by the fruit of that kamma.🔽“From that it is free”: it is free from that, since it is completely absent in him.

original: kāyakilamatho ceva kāyavihesā ca veditabbā. Sā ca kho desanāya atthamajānantānaṃ
analyzed: kāya kilamatho ca iva kāya vihesā ca veditabbā sā ca kho desanāya attham a jānantānam
translated: The bodily exhaustion and bodily affliction should be understood as the fatigue of the back, etc., and the pain in the palate, etc., respectively, due to the long sitting and the long standing.🔽And that is only in the case of those who do not understand the meaning of the teaching and do not practice it;

original: apaṭipajjantānañca vasena, jānantānaṃ pana paṭipajjantānañca desanāya kāyaparissamopi
analyzed: a paṭipajjantānam ca vasena jānantānam pana paṭipajjantānam ca desanāya kāya parissamaḥ pi
translated: but in the case of those who understand it and practice it, the bodily affliction due to the teaching

original: satthu aparissamoyeva. Tenāha bhagavā – “na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesesī”ti.
analyzed: satthu tena āha bhagavā na ca mama dhamma adhikaraṇam vihesesi iti
translated: and the Master had no concern about it. Hence the Blessed One said: “You will not find me concerned about a legal question. ”

original: Tenevāha – “yā ajānantānaṃ desanā nāma, so mama kilamatho assā”ti. Ubhayanti cittakilamatho
analyzed: tena iva āha yā a jānantānam desanā nāma saḥ mama kilamathaḥ assa ati citta kilamatho
translated: Hence he said: “That teaching of those who do not know is my weariness. ”

original: cittavihesā cāti ubhayampetaṃ buddhānaṃ natthi bodhimūle eva samucchinnattā. Anubrūhanaṃ
analyzed: citta vihesā ca ati ubhayampetam buddhānam natthi bodhi mūle eva anubrūhanam
translated: Both: both weariness of mind and concern of mind. This is not found in the Enlightened Ones because it was cut off at the root at the foot of the Tree of Enlightenment.🔽The prolonging is the compounding.

original: sampiṇḍanaṃ. Soti apissūti nipāto. Vuddhippattā vā acchariyā anacchariyā, vuddhiatthopi
analyzed: sampiṇḍanam saḥ ti apissu iti nipātaḥ vuddhi pattā vā acchariyā an acchariyā vuddhi atthaḥ api
translated: So: the particle apisu is used in the sense of “even.” Or it is used in the sense of “having reached growth” . For the -ka suffix is used in the sense of “having reached” ,🔽as in “asekkha-dhammā” .

original: hi -kāro hoti yathā “asekkhā dhammā”ti. Kappānaṃ satasahassaṃ cattāri ca asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: hi kāraḥ hoti yathā asekkhāḥ dhammā ati kappānam sata sahassam cattāri ca asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: Having fulfilled the perfections for a hundred thousand aeons and four incalculables

original: sadevakassa lokassa dhammasaṃvibhāgakaraṇatthameva pāramiyo pūretvā idāni samadhigatadhammarajjassa
analyzed: sa devakassa lokassa dhamma saṃvibhāga karaṇa attham eva pāramiyaḥ pūretvā idāni samadhigata dhamma rajjassa
translated: in order to share the True Idea with the world with its gods, he has now attained sovereignty over the True Idea.

original: tattha appossukkatāpattidīpanatā gāthatthassa ca acchariyatā tassa vuddhippattīti
analyzed: tattha appossukka tā āpatti dīpana tā gāthatthassa ca acchariya tā tassa vuddhi ppatti iti
translated: The meaning of the verse is that he has no concern about it. And it is wonderful that he has reached growth.

original: veditabbaṃ. Atthadvārena hi gāthānaṃ anacchariyatā. Gocarā ahesunti upaṭṭhahiṃsu.
analyzed: veditabbam attha dvārena hi gāthānam gocarāḥ ahesun ti upaṭṭhahiṃsu
translated: “They attended on him” means they served him.

original: Upaṭṭhānañca vitakketabbatāvāti āha “parivitakkayitabbataṃ pāpuṇiṃsū”ti.
analyzed: upaṭṭhānam ca vitakketabba tā vā iti āha parivitakkayitabba tam pāpuṇiṃsu iti
translated: “They came to be thought about” means they came to be attended on.

original: Yadi sukhāpaṭipadāva, kathaṃ kicchatāti āha “pāramīpūraṇakāle panā”tiādi. Evamādīni🔽duppariccajāni dentassa. Ha-iti vā byattanti etasmiṃ atthe nipāto. “Ekaṃsatthe”ti
analyzed: yadi katham āha pāramī pūraṇa kāle evamādīni  duppariccajāni dentassa ha eti vā byattanti etasmin atthe nipātaḥ ekaṃsatthā iti
translated: If the way is pleasant, why is it difficult? He says, “But at the time of fulfilling the pāramīs” and so on.🔽“It is difficult to give” means it is difficult to give to those who are difficult to serve.🔽“Ha” is an indeclinable expressing approval.🔽“In the sense of one-sidedness” means in the sense of being one-sidedly sufficient, in the sense of being sufficient without any need for further effort.🔽“To reveal” means to teach.

original: keci. Ha byattaṃ, ekaṃsena vā alaṃ nippayojanaṃ evaṃ kicchena adhigatassa pakāsituṃ🔽desitunti yojanā. Halanti vā alanti iminā samānatthapadaṃ “halanti vadāmī”tiādīsu
analyzed: keci ha byattam ekaṃsena vā alam nippayojanam evam kicchena adhigatassa pakāsitum  yojanā vā alanti iminā samāna attha padam vadāmi itiādīsu
translated: “Ha” is an indeclinable expressing approval.

original: viya. Rāgadosaphuṭṭhehīti phuṭṭhavisena viya sappena rāgena dosena ca phuṭṭhehi abhibhūtehi.
analyzed: rāga dosa phuṭṭhehi iti phuṭṭha visena sappena rāgena dosena ca phuṭṭhehi abhibhūtehi
translated: “They were covered with greed and hate” means they were overcome by greed and hate as if covered with a covering of greed and hate.

original: Rāgadosānugatehīti rāgadosehi anubandhehi.
analyzed: rāga dosa anugatehi iti rāga dosehi anubandhehi
translated: “They were followed by greed and hate” means they were pursued by greed and hate.

original: Niccādīnanti niccādīnaṃ catunnaṃ vipallāsānaṃ. Evaṃgatanti evaṃ aniccantiādinā ākārena🔽pavattaṃ bujjhitabbaṃ. Kāmarāgarattā ca bhavarāgarattā ca nīvaraṇehi nivutacittatāya
analyzed: nicca ādīnam catunnam vipallāsānam evaṃgatanti evam anicca nti ādinā ākārena  pavattam bujjhitabbam kāma rāga rattā ca bhava rāga rattā ca nīvaraṇehi nivuta citta tāya
translated: ‘The four perversions’: the four perversions of permanence, etc. ‘In this way’: in the mode of impermanence, etc.

original: diṭṭhirāgarattā viparītābhinivesena na dakkhanti yāthāvato dhammaṃ na paṭivijjhissanti.
analyzed: diṭṭhi rāga rattāḥ viparīta abhinivesena na dakkhanti yāthāvataḥ dhammam na paṭivijjhissanti
translated: ‘They will not see’: they will not see the Dhamma as it really is, will not penetrate it, because their minds are covered by the hindrances, being infatuated with sensual lust and lust for existence, and because they are infatuated with views, being attached to distorted convictions.

original: Sabhāvenāti aviparītasabhāvena. Evaṃ gāhāpetunti aniccantiādinā sabhāvena yāthāvato
analyzed: sabhāvena ati aviparīta sabhāvena evam sabhāvena
translated: ‘In its intrinsic nature’: in its undistorted intrinsic nature. ‘In this way’: by means of the intrinsic nature of impermanence, etc.

original: dhammaṃ jānāpetuṃ. Rāgadosaparetatāpi nesaṃ sammūḷhabhāvenevāti āha “tamokhandhena āvuṭā”ti.
analyzed: dhammam rāga dosa pareta tā api na īsam sammūḍha bhāvena iva ati āha tamaḥ khandhena
translated: ‘They will not know’: they will not know the Dhamma as it really is. ‘Infatuated with lust and hatred’: because of their confusion. ‘Enveloped in the mass of darkness’:

original: Dhammadesanāya appossukkatāpattiyā kāraṇaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “kasmā panā”tiādinā sayameva
analyzed: dhamma desanāya appossukka tā āpattiyāḥ kāraṇam vibhāvetum kasmā pana ati ādinā sayam eva
translated: ‘Why is it so?’—in order to show the reason for the Buddha’s lack of enthusiasm for teaching the Dhamma, he himself raises the question.

original: codanaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Aññātavesenāti imassa bhagavato sāvakabhāvūpagamanena aññātavesena.
analyzed: codanam samuṭṭhāpeti aññāta vesena ati imassa bhagavato sāvaka bhāva upagamanena aññāta vesena
translated: ‘Because of their unknown status’: because of their unknown status as disciples of the Exalted One.

original: “Aññataratāpasavesenā”ti keci, so panassa arahattādhigamaneneva vigaccheyya. Tividhaṃ
analyzed: aññatara tāpasa vesena ati keci so pana assa arahatta adhigamanena iva vigaccheyya tividham
translated: Some say: ‘Because of their unknown status as ascetics of another sect.’ But that would be removed by their attainment of arahatship.

original: kāraṇaṃ appossukkatāpattiyā paṭipakkhassa balavabhāvo, dhammassa gambhīratā, tattha🔽ca bhagavato sātisayaṃ gāravanti taṃ dassetuṃ “tassa hī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha paṭipakkhā🔽nāma rāgādayo kilesā sammāpaṭipattiyā antarāyakarattā. Tesaṃ balavabhāvato ciraparibhāvanāya🔽sattasantānato dubbisodhiyatāya te satte mattahatthino viya dubbalapurisaṃ adhibhavitvā
analyzed: kāraṇam appossukka tā āpattiyāḥ paṭipakkhassa balava bhāvaḥ dhammassa gambhīra tā tattha  ca bhagavato sa atisayam gāravanti tam dassetum tassa hi itiādi āraddham tattha paṭipakkhā  nāma rāga ādayo kilesā sammā paṭipattiyā antarāya karattā tesam balava bhāvataḥ cira paribhāvanāya  satta santānataḥ te satte matta hatthinaḥ viya dubbala purisam adhi bhavitvā
translated: The reason is the strength of the opposite of heedlessness, the profundity of the Dhamma, and the Blessed One’s special veneration for it. In order to show this, the text is stated thus: “For the Blessed One … .” Herein, the opposite is the defilements of lust, etc., which are called the opposite because they obstruct the right practice. Because of their strength, because of their long cultivation in the continuity of beings, and because of their difficulty of purification, they overcome beings as a strong man overcomes a weak man, and they carry them off as a flood does the weak.🔽

original: ajjhottharitvā anayabyasanaṃ āpādentā anekasatayojanāyāmavitthāraṃ sunicitaṃ ghanasannivesaṃ🔽kaṇṭakaduggampi adhisenti. Dūrapabhedaducchejjatāhi dubbisodhiyataṃ pana dassetuṃ
analyzed: ajjhottharitvā anaya byasanam āpādentāḥ aneka sata yojana āyāma vitthāram su nicitam ghana sannivesam  kaṇṭaka duggam pi adhisenti dūra pabheda ducchejja tāhi pana dassetum
translated: The reason is the strength of the opposite of heedfulness, the profundity of the Dhamma, and the Blessed One’s special veneration for it. In order to show this, the text is stated thus: “For he … ” Herein, the opposite is the defilements of lust, etc., which obstruct right practice. Because of their strength, because of their long cultivation in the continuity of beings, and because of their difficulty of purification, they overwhelm beings as a strong man does a weak man, and they overpower them, bringing them to ruin and destruction. They overpower even the sunicita, the ghanasannivesa, the kaṇṭakaduggā, which is a hundred thousand leagues in height and breadth. In order to show their difficulty of purification because of their far-reaching, manifold, and hard-to-eradicate nature,

original: “athassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ca anto amaṭṭhatāya kañjiyapuṇṇā lābu, cirapārivāsikatāya
analyzed: athassa iti ādi vuttam tattha ca antaḥ a maṭṭha tāya kañjiya puṇṇā lābu cira pārivāsika tāya
translated: “Then, as to the simile of the gourd” is said. Herein, a gourd filled with chaff is a gourd that is not cleaned out inside. Because of its long storage,

original: takkabharitā cāṭi, snehatintadubbalabhāvena vasāpītapilotikā, telamissitatāya añjanamakkhitahattho🔽dubbisodhanīyā vuttā. Hīnūpamā cetā rūpapabandhabhāvato acirakālikattā ca malīnatāya,
analyzed: takka bharitā ca aṭi sneha tinta dubbala bhāvena vasā pīta pilotikā tela missita tāya añjana makkhita hattho  dubbisodhanīyā vuttā hīnūpamā cetā ca malīna tāya
translated: A cloth soaked in oil is difficult to clean because of the oil’s softness and stickiness. A hand smeared with ointment is difficult to clean because of the ointment’s oiliness.🔽These are said to be inferior similes because the continuum of materiality is short-lived and because of its impurity.

original: kilesasaṃkileso eva pana dubbisodhanīyataro anādikālikattā arūpanissitattā ca. Tenāha “atisaṃkiliṭṭhā”ti.🔽Yathā ca dubbisodhanīyataratāya, evaṃ gambhīraduddasaduranubodhānampi vuttaupamā
analyzed: kilesa saṃkilesaḥ eva pana dubbisodhanīyataraḥ anādi kālika ttā arūpa nissita ttā ca tena āha ati saṃkiliṭṭhā ti  yathā ca vuttā aupamā
translated: But defilement and its stains are more difficult to clean because they are beginningless and because they are based on the immaterial. Therefore it is said: “They are very soiled.”🔽And just as they are more difficult to clean, so too they are more profound, obscure, and hard to fathom than the similes stated.

original: hīnūpamāva. Gambhīropi dhammo paṭipakkhavidhamanena ñāṇena visadabhāvaṃ āpannena
analyzed: gambhīraḥ api dhammaḥ paṭipakkha vidhamanena ñāṇena visada bhāvam āpannena
translated: Even though the Dhamma is profound, it becomes quite clear to one who has attained lucidity by removing its opposite.

original: supākaṭo bhaveyya, paṭipakkhavidhamanaṃ pana sammāpaṭipattipaṭibaddhaṃ, sā saddhammassavanādhīnā,
analyzed: su pākaṭaḥ bhaveyya paṭipakkha vidhamanam pana sammāpaṭipatti paṭibaddham sā saddhamma ssavana adhīnā
translated: But the removal of its opposite is bound up with right practice, which depends on hearing the true Dhamma,

original: taṃ satthari dhamme ca pasādāyattaṃ. So garuṭṭhāniyānaṃ ajjhesanahetukoti paṇālikāya
analyzed: tam satthari dhamme ca pasāda āyattam saḥ garuṭṭhā niyānam ajjhesana hetukaḥ ti paṇālikāya
translated: which in turn depends on confidence in the Teacher and the Dhamma. That confidence is due to the request of those worthy of respect.

original: sattānaṃ dhammasampaṭipattiyā brahmāyācanānimittanti taṃ dassento “apicā”tiādimāha.🔽Upakkilesabhūtaṃ appaṃ rāgādirajaṃ etassāti apparajaṃ, apparajaṃ akkhi paññācakkhu
analyzed: sattānam dhamma sampaṭipattiyā brahma āyācanā nimittanti tam dassentaḥ apica iti ādim āha  upakkilesa bhūtam appam rāga ādi rajam etassa ati appa rajam appa rajam akkhi paññācakkhu
translated: The reason for the Exalted One’s request to Brahmā is the proper practice of the Dhamma by beings. Showing this, the Exalted One says, “And further,” etc.

original: yesaṃ te taṃsabhāvāti katvā apparajakkhajātikāti imamatthaṃ dassento “paññāmaye”tiādimāha.
analyzed: yesam te taṃsa bhāvā ti katvā appara jakkha jātikā ti imam attham dassento paññā maya iti ādim āha
translated: The eye of wisdom is called “having little dust” because it has little dust of lust, etc., which is a defilement. Showing the meaning of “having little dust,” the Exalted One says, “The eye of wisdom,” etc.

original: Appaṃ rāgādirajaṃ yesaṃ taṃsabhāvā apparajakkhajātikāti evamettha attho veditabbo.🔽Assavanatāti “sayaṃ abhiññā”tiādīsu viya karaṇe paccattavacananti āha “assavanatāyā”ti.🔽Dasapuññakiriyavasenāti dānādidasavidhapuññakiriyavatthūnaṃ vasena. Tenāha “katādhikārā”tiādi.
analyzed: appam rāga ādi rajam yesam taṃsa bhāvāḥ apparajakkha jātikā ti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo  assavana tā ti sayam abhiññā ti ādīsu viya karaṇe paccatta vacananti āha assavana tāya ati  dasa puñña kiriya vasena ati dāna ādi dasavidha puñña kiriya vatthūnam vasena tena āha kata adhikārā atiādi
translated: The meaning should be understood as follows: “Having little dust” means having the nature of little dust of lust, etc.🔽“Not hearing” is a locative of the objective case, as in the passage, “having directly known it himself” .🔽“By means of the ten bases of meritorious activity” : by means of the ten bases of meritorious activity such as giving, etc. Therefore the Exalted One says, “having fulfilled their duties,” etc.

original: Papañcasūdaniyaṃ pana “dvādasapuññakiriyavasenā”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ dānādīsu saraṇagamana-parahitapariṇāmanādipakkhipanavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: papañcasūdaniyam pana dvādasa puñña kiriya vasena ati vuttam tam dāna ādīsu saraṇa gamana para hita pariṇāmana ādi pakkhipana vasena vuttam
translated: But in the Papañcasūdani, it is said: “by means of the twelve bases of meritorious activity.” This is said by including the going for refuge and the dedication of merit for the benefit of others among the bases of meritorious activity.

original: Rāgādimalena samalehi pūraṇādīhi chahi satthārehi satthupaṭiññehi kabbaracanāvasena
analyzed: rāga ādi malena sa malehi pūraṇa ādīhi chahi satthārehi satthu paṭiññehi kabba racanā vasena
translated: The six teachers, Pūraṇa and the rest, who were defiled by the stain of lust, etc., and who claimed to be Buddhas, taught the doctrine of chance combinations,

original: cintākaviādibhāve ṭhatvā takkapariyāhataṃ vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃpaṭibhānaṃ cintito.
analyzed: cintā kavi ādi bhāve vīmaṃsā anucaritam sayaṃpaṭibhānam
translated: having become poets who compose by thought, etc., and having arrived at their own conclusions by reasoning and investigation.

original: Te kira buddhakolāhalānussavena sañjātakutūhalaṃ lokaṃ vañcentā kohaññe ṭhatvā sabbaññutaṃ
analyzed: te kira buddha kolāhala anussavena sañjāta kutūhalam lokam vañcentā kohaññe ṭhatvā sabbaññu tam
translated: They deceived the people who were curious because of the talk about the Buddha, claiming omniscience while standing in the midst of a crowd.

original: paṭijānantā yaṃ kañci adhammameva “dhammo”ti dīpesuṃ. Tenāha “te hi puretaraṃ uppajjitvā”tiādi.
analyzed: paṭijānantāḥ yam kañci adhammam eva dhammo ti dīpesum tena āha te hi puretaram uppajjitvā itiādi
translated: They taught only what was contrary to the Dhamma, calling it the Dhamma. Therefore it is said: “They had appeared before, etc.”

original: Apāpuretanti etaṃ kassapassa bhagavato sāsanantaradhānato pabhuti pihitaṃ nibbānamahādvāraṃ
analyzed: apāpuḥ etat ti etam kassapassa bhagavato sāsana antaradhānataḥ pabhuti pihitam nibbāna mahādvāram
translated: They opened the great door to Nibbāna, which had been closed since the time of the passing away of the Master Kassapa,

original: ariyamaggaṃ saddhammadesanāhatthena apāpura vivara.🔽Selo pabbato ucco hoti thiro ca, na paṃsupabbato missakapabbato cāti āha “sele yathā
analyzed: ariya maggam saddhamma desanā hatthena apāpura vivara  selaḥ pabbataḥ uccaḥ hoti thiraḥ ca na paṃsu pabbataḥ missaka pabbataḥ ca ati āha sele yathā
translated: by the hand of the Dhamma teaching, by the path of the noble ones.

original: pabbatamuddhanī”ti. Dhammamayaṃ pāsādanti lokuttaradhammamāha. So hi sabbaso pasādāvaho,
analyzed: pabbata muddhani iti dhamma mayam pāsādam ti lokuttara dhammam āha saḥ hi sabbaso pasāda āvahaḥ
translated: The mountain of rock is high and firm, not a mountain of sand or a mountain of clay. Therefore it is said: “Like the peak of a rock mountain, etc.” The palace of Dhamma is the supramundane Dhamma. It is the cause of all kinds of confidence.

original: sabbadhamme atikkamma abbhuggataṭṭhena pāsādasadiso ca. Paññāpariyāyo vā idha dhamma-saddoti
analyzed: sabba dhamme atikkamma abbhuggata ṭṭhena pāsāda sadiso ca paññā pariyāyaḥ vā idha dhamma saddo ti
translated: and it is like a palace in being exalted above all ideas.🔽Or else the word dhamma here is in the sense of understanding.🔽For that is called a “palace” in the sense of being exalted, according to the Abhidhamma.

original: vuttaṃ “paññāmaya”nti. Sā hi abbhuggataṭṭhena pāsādoti abhidhamme āgatā. Tathā cāha –
analyzed: vuttam paññāmayanti sā hi abbhuggata ṭṭhena pāsādaḥ iti abhidhamme āgatā tathā ca āha
translated: And so it is said:

original: “Paññāpāsādamāruyha, asoko sokiniṃ pajaṃ;
analyzed: paññāpāsādam āruyha asokaḥ sokinim pajam
translated: “Having mounted the palace of understanding, the sorrowless one looks upon the sorrowing people,

original: Pabbataṭṭhova bhūmaṭṭhe, dhīro bāle avekkhatī”ti. ;🔽Yathā hītiādīsu yathā ca pabbate ṭhatvā andhakāre heṭṭhā olokentassa purisassa khettakedārapāḷikuṭikāyo
analyzed: pabbata aṭṭhaḥ uva bhūma aṭṭhe dhīraḥ bāle avekkhati iti  yathā hi itiādīsu yathā ca pabbate ṭhatvā andhakāre heṭṭhā olokentassa purisassa khetta kedāra pāḷi kuṭikāyo
translated: As one on a mountain top looks upon those on the ground, so the wise one looks upon fools” .🔽As, when a man stands on a mountain top and looks down into the darkness below, he does not see the fields, the threshing floors, the houses, the huts,

original: tattha sayitamanussā ca na paññāyanti anujjalabhāvato, kuṭikāsu pana aggijālā paññāyati
analyzed: tattha sayita manussā ca na paññāyanti anujjala bhāvato kuṭikāsu pana aggi jālā paññāyati
translated: or the people lying there, but he sees the flames of the forest fires if there are any,

original: samujjalabhāvato, evaṃ dhammapāsādamāruyha sattalokaṃ olokayato bhagavato ñāṇassa
analyzed: samujjala bhāvataḥ evam dhammapāsādam āruyha satta lokam olokayataḥ bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa
translated: because they are manifest, so too, when the Blessed One looks down upon the world of beings from the palace of Dhamma,🔽unsuccessful beings do not come within the range of his knowledge,

original: āpāthaṃ nāgacchanti akatakalyāṇā sattā, ñāṇagginā anujjalabhāvato anuḷārabhāvato
analyzed: āpātham na āgacchanti a kata kalyāṇā sattā ñāṇa agginā anujjala bhāvataḥ anuḷāra bhāvataḥ
translated: because they are unmanifest, because they are not manifest to the fire of his knowledge.

original: ca rattiṃ khittā sarā viya honti, katakalyāṇā pana bhabbapuggalā dūre ṭhitāpi bhagavato
analyzed: ca rattim khittā sarāḥ viya honti kata kalyāṇāḥ pana bhabba puggalāḥ dūre ṭhitā api bhagavataḥ
translated: and the good people who have done good deeds, though they may be far away, come within the range of the Blessed One’s knowledge,

original: āpāthaṃ āgacchanti paripakkañāṇaggitāya samujjalabhāvato uḷārasantānatāya himavantapabbato
analyzed: āpātham āgacchanti paripakka ñāṇaggi tāya samujjala bhāvataḥ uḷāra santāna tāya himavanta pabbataḥ
translated: like the rays of the sun. And because his knowledge is like a mountain of snow in that it is a great mass of knowledge that is fully matured by the fire of his enlightenment,

original: viya cāti evaṃ yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: viya ca ati evam yojanā veditabbā
translated: this is how the simile should be understood.

original: Garuṭṭhānīyaṃ payirupāsitvā garutaraṃ payojanaṃ uddissa abhipatthanā ajjhesanā, sāpi🔽atthato yācanāva hotīti āha “ajjhesananti yācana”nti. Padesavisayaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ
analyzed: garuṭṭhānīyam payis upāsitvā garutaram payojanam uddissa abhipatthanā ajjhesanā sā api  atthataḥ yācanā ava hoti iti āha ajjhesanam ti yācanam ti padesa visayam ñāṇa dassanam
translated: The request is the asking after paying respect with the thought of a very great purpose in mind. That too is in fact a request.

original: ahutvā buddhānaṃyeva āveṇikabhāvato idaṃ ñāṇadvayaṃ “buddhacakkhū”ti vuccatīti āha🔽“imesañhi dvinnaṃ ñāṇānaṃ ‘buddhacakkhū’ti nāma”nti. Tiṇṇaṃ magggañāṇānanti heṭṭhimānaṃ
analyzed: a hutvā buddhānam yeva āveṇika bhāvataḥ idam ñāṇa dvayam buddha cakkhu iti vuccati iti āha  imesam hi dvinnam ñāṇānam buddha cakkhu iti nāman ti tiṇṇam magga ñāṇānam ti heṭṭhimānam
translated: The knowledge and vision that is limited to the Buddhas is called the “Buddha-eye” because it is not shared by disciples and others.

original: tiṇṇaṃ maggañāṇānaṃ “dhammacakkhū”ti nāmaṃ catusaccadhammadassanamattabhāvato. Yato
analyzed: tiṇṇam magga ñāṇānam dhammacakkhu iti nāmam catu sacca dhamma dassana matta bhāvataḥ yatas
translated: The knowledge of the three paths is called the “Dhamma-eye” because it is the seeing of the three truths, namely, the truths of suffering, origin, and the way,

original: tāni ñāṇāni vijjūpamabhāvena vuttāni, aggamaggañāṇaṃ pana ñāṇakiccassa sikhāppattiyā
analyzed: tāni ñāṇāni vijju upama bhāvena vuttāni aggamagga ñāṇam pana ñāṇa kiccassa sikhā appattiyā
translated: These kinds of knowledge are called “like lightning” . But the knowledge of the path of Arahantship is not called “the eye of Dhamma” because it is not merely seeing, since it is the culmination of the function of knowledge.

original: dassanamattaṃ na hotīti “dhammacakkhū”ti na vuccati, yato taṃ vajirūpamabhāvena vuttaṃ.🔽Vuttanayenāti “apparajakkhajātikā”ti ettha vuttanayena. Yasmā mandakilesā “apparajakkhā”ti
analyzed: dassana mattam na hoti iti dhammacakkhu iti na vuccati yatas tam vaji rūpam abhāvena vuttam  vutta nayena ati apparajakkha jātikā ati ettha vutta nayena yasmā manda kilesā apparajakkhā ti
translated: Therefore it is called “like a diamond” .🔽“In the way stated” : in the way stated in the passage, “They are of little dust” .

original: vuttā, tasmā bahalakilesā “mahārajakkhā”ti veditabbā. Paṭipakkhavidhamanasamatthatāya
analyzed: vuttā tasmā bahala kilesā mahārajakkhā ati veditabbā paṭipakkha vidhamana samattha tāya
translated: Since those of little defilement are called “of little dust,” those of much defilement should be understood as “of much dust” .🔽They are sharp, keen, and clear, and dull in the opposite sense.

original: tikkhāni sūrāni visadāni, vuttavipariyāyena mudūni. Saddhādayo ākārāti saddahanādippakāre🔽vadati. Sundarāti kalyāṇā. Sammohavinodaniyaṃ pana “yesaṃ āsayādayo koṭṭhāsā sundarā,
analyzed: tikkhāni sūrāni visadāni vutta vipariyāyena mudūni saddhā ādayaḥ ākārā ti saddahana ādi ppakāre  vadati kalyāṇā sammoha vinodaniyam pana yesam āsaya ādayo koṭṭhāsā sundarā
translated: The aspects of faith, etc., are the modes of faith, and so on.

original: te svākārā”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ imāya atthavaṇṇanāya aññadatthu saṃsandatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: te su ākārā iti vuttam tam imāya attha vaṇṇanāya añña datthu saṃsandati iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Beautiful means good. In the Sammohavinodani, however, it is said: “Those whose parts, such as the abode, are beautiful are of good aspects” . This should be understood to agree with the commentary.

original: Kāraṇaṃ nāma paccayākāro, saccāni vā. Paralokanti samparāyaṃ. Taṃ dukkhāvahaṃ vajjaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇam nāma paccaya ākāraḥ saccāni vā para lokanti samparāyam tam dukkha āvaham vajjam
translated: The cause is the mode of conditionality or the four noble truths. The other world is the next existence. That which brings suffering is blameworthy.

original: viya bhayato passitabbanti vuttaṃ “paralokañceva vajjañca bhayato passantī”ti. Sampattibhavato
analyzed: viya bhayataḥ passitabbanti vuttam para lokañca iva vajjam ca bhayataḥ passanti iti sampatti bhavato
translated: and he sees danger in the world beyond and in what is blameworthy.

original: vā aññattā vipattibhavo paralokoti vuttaṃ “para…pe… passantī”ti.
analyzed: vā aññattā vipatti bhavo para loko ti vuttam para pe passanti iti
translated: Or alternatively, the world beyond is called “the world of misfortune” because it is different from the “world of success” .🔽This is the text here:

original: Ayaṃ panettha pāḷīti ettha “apparajakkhā”ti padānaṃ atthavibhāvane ayaṃ tassa tathābhāvasādhanapāḷi.🔽Saddhādīnañhi vimuttaparipācakadhammānaṃ balavabhāvo tappaṭipakkhānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ🔽dubbalabhāve sati hoti. Tesañca balavabhāvo saddhādīnaṃ dubbalabhāveti vimuttiparipācakadhammānaṃ
analyzed: ayam pana ittha pāḷi iti ettha apparajakkhā ati padānam attha vibhāvane ayam tassa tathābhāva sādhana pāḷi  saddhā ādīnam hi vimutta paripācaka dhammānam balava bhāvaḥ tad paṭipakkhānam pāpa dhammānam  dubbala bhāve sati hoti tesam ca balava bhāvaḥ saddhā ādīnam dubbala bhāva iti vimutti paripācaka dhammānam
translated: This is the text showing how the words “with little dust on the eyes” are to be established as having that meaning.🔽For the strength of the factors that ripen liberation, such as faith, is only when the opposing bad factors are weak.

original: savisesaṃ atthitānatthitāvasena apparajakkhā mahārajakkhātiādayo pāḷiyaṃ vibhajitvā
analyzed: sa visesam atthita anatthitā vasena apparajakkhāḥ mahārajakkha ati ādayo pāḷiyam vibhajitvā
translated: And the strength of those factors is only when faith, etc., are weak. So the factors that ripen liberation are shown in the text as “with little dust on the eyes” and “with much dust on the eyes” according to whether they are present in a weak or strong form.

original: dassitā “saddho puggalo apparajakkho”tiādinā. Khandhādayo eva lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena
analyzed: dassitā saddhaḥ puggalaḥ apparajakkho ti ādinā khandha ādayaḥ eva lujjana palujjana aṭṭhena
translated: The text shows this by the words “A faithful person has little dust on his eyes” and so on.

original: loko sampattibhavabhūto loko sampattibhavaloko, sugatisaṅkhāto upapattibhavo. Sampatti
analyzed: lokaḥ sampatti bhava bhūtaḥ lokaḥ sampatti bhava lokaḥ sugati saṅkhātaḥ upapatti bhavaḥ sampatti
translated: The aggregates, etc., are the world in the sense of being subject to destruction and dispersion.

original: bhavati etenāti sampattisambhavaloko, sugatisaṃvattaniyo kammabhavo. Duggatisaṅkhātaupapattibhava-duggatisaṃvattaniyakammabhavā
analyzed: bhavati etena ati sampatti sambhava lokaḥ sugati saṃvattaniyaḥ kamma bhavaḥ duggati saṅkhāta aupapatti bhava duggati saṃvattaniya kamma bhavā
translated: “The world of the origin of failure” is the kind of becoming that leads to an unhappy destiny, the kind of becoming that leads to a bad destination.

original: vipattibhavaloka-vipattisambhavalokā. Puna ekakadukādivasena lokaṃ vibhajitvā dassetuṃ🔽“eko loko”tiādi vuttaṃ. Āhārādayo viya hi āhāraṭṭhitikā saṅkhārā sabbe lujjanaṭṭhena🔽lokoti. Tattha eko loko sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikāti yāyaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānāya kathāya
analyzed: vipatti bhava loka vipatti sambhava lokā punar ekaka duka ādi vasena lokam vibhajitvā dassetum  ekaḥ lokaḥ iti ādi vuttam āhāra ādayaḥ viya hi āhāra ṭṭhitikā saṅkhārā sabbe lujjana ṭṭhena  loko ti tattha ekaḥ loko sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati yā ayam puggala adhiṭṭhānāya kathāya
translated: Again, in order to show the world by dividing it into single, double, etc.,🔽“One world” is said, etc. For just as nutriment, etc., are called “the world” because they are the support for the maintenance of formations, so too all formations are called “the world” because they are subject to abrasion.🔽Herein, “One world: all beings are maintained by nutriment”: this is a statement based on persons, by which the dependence on conditions of all formations is stated.

original: sabbesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ paccayāyattavuttitā vuttā, tāya sabbo saṅkhāraloko eko ekavidho🔽pakārantarassa abhāvato. Dve lokātiādīsupi iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Nāmaggahaṇena
analyzed: sabbesam saṅkhārānam paccaya āyatta vutti tā vuttā tāya sabbaḥ saṅkhāra lokaḥ ekaḥ ekavidhaḥ  pakāra antarassa abhāvataḥ dve loka ati ādīsu pi iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nāma ggahaṇena
translated: By this the whole world of formations is one, of one kind,🔽because there is no other world apart from this. The meaning should be understood in this way in the case of “Two worlds,” etc., too.

original: cettha nibbānassa aggahaṇaṃ tassa alokasabhāvattā.
analyzed: ca ittha nibbānassa aggahaṇam tassa a loka sabhāva ttā
translated: But by mentioning the name “world” here, Nibbāna is not mentioned, because it does not have the nature of a world.

original: Nanu ca “āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti ettha paccayāyattavuttitāya maggaphalānampi lokatā āpajjatīti?
analyzed: nanu ca āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati ettha paccaya āyatta vutti tāya magga phalānam pi loka tā āpajjati iti
translated: But is not the path and fruit also included in the world by this statement “maintained by nutriment,” since they exist in dependence on conditions?

original: Nāpajjati, pariññeyyānaṃ dukkhasaccadhammānaṃ idha “loko”ti adhippetattā. Atha vā
analyzed: na āpajjati pariññeyyānam dukkha sacca dhammānam idha loko ti adhippeta ttā atha vā
translated: “He does not fall into the world” because the things that should be fully understood, the things of the truth of suffering, are intended here by “world.” Or else

original: na lujjati na palujjatīti yo gahito tathā na hoti, so lokoti taṃgahaṇarahitānaṃ lokuttarānaṃ🔽natthi lokatā. Upādānānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtā khandhā upādānakkhandhā. Anurodhādivatthubhūtā
analyzed: na lujjati na palujjati iti yaḥ gahitaḥ tathā na hoti saḥ tad gahaṇa rahitānam  natthi lokatā upādānānam ārammaṇa bhūtā khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ anurodha ādi vatthu bhūtā
translated: “he does not fall” means that what is grasped does not become so. That is the world. For the supramundane dhammas, which are free from that grasping,🔽there is no worldliness. The aggregates that are the objects of clinging are the clinging-aggregates. The eight worldly dhammas, such as gain, etc., are the bases for compliance, etc.

original: lābhādayo aṭṭha lokadhammā. Dasāyatanānīti dasa rūpāyatanāni. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: lābha ādayaḥ aṭṭha loka dhammāḥ dasa āyatanāni iti dasa rūpāyatanāni sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The ten bases are the ten form bases. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Vivaṭṭajjhāsayassa adhippetattā tassa ca sabbaṃ tebhūmakakammaṃ garahitabbaṃ vajjitabbañca
analyzed: vivaṭṭa jhāsayassa adhippeta ttā tassa ca sabbam tebhūmaka kammam garahitabbam vajjitabbam ca
translated: Because the one who has opened up the mind is intended, and because all his kamma of the three planes should be deprecated and avoided,

original: hutvā upaṭṭhātīti vuttaṃ “sabbe abhisaṅkhārā vajjā, sabbe bhavagāmikammā vajjā”ti.🔽Apparajakkhatādīsu pañcasu dukesu ekekasmiṃ dasa dasa katvā “paññāsāya ākārehi imāni
analyzed: hutvā upaṭṭhāti iti vuttam sabbe abhisaṅkhārāḥ vajjā sabbe bhava gāmi kammāḥ vajjā ti  pañcasu dukesu ekekasmin dasa dasa katvā ākārehi imāni
translated: it is said: “All formations are to be deprecated, all kamma leading to becoming is to be deprecated.”🔽In the five pairs beginning with “not long after,” there are ten in each pair. Thus it is said that “he knows these five faculties

original: pañcindriyāni jānātī”ti vuttaṃ. Atha vā anvayato byatirekato ca saddhādīnaṃ indriyānaṃ
analyzed: pañca indriyāni jānāti iti vuttam atha vā anvayataḥ byatirekataḥ ca saddhā ādīnam
translated: by fifty aspects.” Or else, by way of concomitance and by way of separation, he knows the faculties of faith, etc.,

original: paropariyattaṃ jānātīti katvā tathā vuttaṃ. Ettha ca apparajakkhādibhabbādivasena
analyzed: jānāti iti katvā tathā vuttam ettha ca appara jakkha ādi bhabba ādi vasena
translated: “He knows the higher and lower faculties of others” is said because he knows the higher and lower faculties of others.

original: āvajjentassa bhagavato te sattā puñjapuñjāva hutvā upaṭṭhahanti, na ekekā.🔽Uppalāni ettha santīti uppalinī. Uppalagacchopi jalāsayopi ca. Idha pana jalāsayo
analyzed: āvajjentassa bhagavataḥ te sattā puñja puñjā ava hutvā upaṭṭhahanti na ekekā  uppalāni ettha santi iti uppalinī uppalagacchā upi ca idha pana jalāsayo
translated: And here, when the Blessed One adverts to beings according to their ability to be trained, etc., they appear to him as heaps, not individually.🔽“A place where there are lotuses is a lotus pond. It is both a lotus plant and a body of water. But here a body of water is intended.

original: adhippetoti āha “uppalavane”ti. Yāni hi udakassa anto nimuggāneva hutvā pusanti vaḍḍhanti,
analyzed: adhippetaḥ iti āha uppala vane ti yāni hi udakassa antar nimuggāna eva hutvā pusanti vaḍḍhanti
translated: So it is said, ‘in a lotus pond.’ For those that bloom and grow submerged in the water are called ‘submerged bloomers.’

original: tāni antonimuggaposīni. Dīpitānīti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pakāsitāni, idheva vā “aññānipī”tiādinā🔽dassitāni. Ugghaṭitaññūti ugghaṭanaṃ nāma ñāṇugghaṭanaṃ, ñāṇena ugghaṭitamatteneva
analyzed: tāni antonimugga posīni dīpitāni iti aṭṭhakathā ayam pakāsitāni idhā iva vā aññāni pi iti ādinā  dassitāni ugghaṭita ññū ti ugghaṭanam nāma ñāṇa ugghaṭanam ñāṇena ugghaṭita mattena iva
translated: ‘Are shown’ are revealed in the commentary, or are shown here itself by the words ‘and other such beings.’🔽‘One of quick understanding’: the meaning is, he understands merely by the opening up of the knowledge, for the opening up is the opening up of the knowledge.

original: jānātīti attho. Vipañcitaṃ vitthāritameva atthaṃ jānātīti vipañcitaññū. Niddesādīhi
analyzed: jānāti iti atthaḥ vipañcitam vitthāritam eva attham jānāti iti vipañcita ññū niddesa ādīhi
translated: ‘One of slow understanding’: he understands the meaning that is spread out, extended.

original: dhammābhisamayāya netabboti neyyo. Pajjati attho etenāti padaṃ, pajjate ñāyateti
analyzed: dhamma abhisamayāya netabbaḥ iti neyyaḥ pajjati atthaḥ etena ati padam pajjate ñāyate iti
translated: ‘One to be trained’: he is to be led to the penetration of the Dhamma by means of the niddesa, etc.🔽‘A word’: the meaning is that by this the meaning is spread out, extended.

original: vā padaṃ, tadattho. Padaṃ paramaṃ etassa, na saccābhisambodhoti padaparamo.
analyzed: vā padam tad atthaḥ padam paramam etassa na sacca abhisambodho ti pada paramaḥ
translated: or the meaning of the words, is the supreme word. He has the supreme word in that his supreme word is not the realization of the truths.

original: Udāhaṭavelāyāti udāhāre dhammassa uddese udāhaṭamatteyeva. Dhammābhisamayoti catusaccadhammassa🔽ñāṇena saddhiṃ abhisamayo. Ayaṃ vuccatīti ayaṃ “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”tiādinā nayena🔽saṃkhittena mātikāya ṭhapiyamānāya desanānusārena ñāṇaṃ pesetvā arahattaṃ gaṇhituṃ
analyzed: udāhaṭa velāya ati udāhāre dhammassa uddese catusacca dhammassa  ñāṇena saddhim abhisamayaḥ ayam vuccati iti ayam cattāro sati paṭṭhānā iti ādinā nayena  saṃkhittena mātikāya ṭhapiyamānāya desanā anusārena ñāṇam pesetvā arahattam gaṇhitum
translated: At the time of the recitation: at the time of the recitation of the Dhamma, at the time of the teaching of the Dhamma, at the time of the mere recitation of the Dhamma. Realization of the Dhamma:

original: samattho puggalo “ugghaṭitaññū”ti vuccati. Ayaṃ vuccatīti saṃkhittena mātikaṃ ṭhapetvā🔽vitthārena atthe vibhajiyamāne arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ samattho puggalo “vipañcitaññū”ti🔽vuccati. Uddesatoti uddesahetu. Uddisantassa uddisāpentassa vāti attho. Paripucchatoti
analyzed: samatthaḥ puggalaḥ ugghaṭita ññū ti vuccati ayam vuccati iti saṃkhittena mātikam ṭhapetvā  vitthārena atthe vibhajiyamāne arahattam pāpuṇitum samatthaḥ puggalaḥ  vuccati uddesato ti uddesa hetu uddisantassa uddisāpentassa vā attho paripucchato ti
translated: realization together with the knowledge of the four noble truths. He is called: he who is able to attain arahatship by sending forth knowledge in accordance with the teaching when the summary is being recited in the way beginning, “Four foundations of mindfulness” is called one “with ready knowledge.” He is called: he who is able to reach arahatship when the meaning is being analyzed in detail after the summary has been recited in brief is called one “with analyzed knowledge.”

original: atthaṃ paripucchantassa. Anupubbena dhammābhisamayo hotīti anukkamena arahattappatti
analyzed: attham paripucchantassa anupubbena dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti iti anukkamena arahatta ppatti
translated: By way of recitation: because of the recitation. The meaning is: for one who recites, for one who causes to recite. By way of questioning: for one who questions about the meaning. Realization of the Dhamma gradually: the gradual attainment of arahatship.

original: hoti. Na tāya jātiyā dhammābhisamayo hotīti tena attabhāvena maggaṃ vā phalaṃ vā
analyzed: hoti na tāya jātiyā dhamma abhisamayaḥ hoti iti tena atta bhāvena maggam vā phalam vā
translated: but there is no penetration of the Dhamma through that kind of rebirth.🔽

original: antamaso jhānaṃ vā vipassanaṃ vā nibbattetuṃ na sakkoti. Ayaṃ vuccati padaparamoti
analyzed: antamasaḥ jhānam vā vipassanam vā nibbattetum na sakkoti ayam vuccati pada paramaḥ ti
translated: and there is no penetration of the Dhamma by that kind of rebirth. He is called “one with words as his highest” because he is unable to generate the path, fruit, jhāna, or insight, even in that existence.

original: ayaṃ puggalo chabbidhaṃ byañjanapadaṃ chabbidhaṃ atthapadanti idaṃ padameva paramaṃ
analyzed: ayam puggalo chabbidham byañjana padam chabbidham attha padam ti idam padam eva paramam
translated: This person has only the words, namely, the six kinds of verbal expression and the six kinds of meaning.

original: assāti padaparamoti vuccatīti attho.
analyzed: assa ati pada paramaḥ ti vuccati iti attho
translated: He is called “one with words as his highest” because he has only the words.

original: Vāsanā hotīti desanā phalavohārena vāsanā hotīti vuttā. Na hi kāci buddhānaṃ desanā
analyzed: vāsanā hoti iti desanā phala vohārena vāsanā hoti iti vuttā na hi kāci buddhānam desanā
translated: “There is a residue” is said because the teaching is a residue in the sense of a fruit. For there is no teaching of the Buddhas that is fruitless.🔽“The two kinds of persons” are the two kinds of persons mentioned in the Vibhaṅga.

original: niratthakā. Yeti ye duvidhe puggale. Vibhaṅge kammāvaraṇenāti pañcavidhena ānantariyakammena.🔽Vipākāvaraṇenāti ahetukapaṭisandhiyā. Yasmā pana duhetukānampi ariyamaggapaṭivedho
analyzed: niratthakāḥ ye ti ye duvidhe puggale vibhaṅge kamma āvaraṇena ati pañcavidhena ānantariya kammena  vipāka āvaraṇena ati ahetuka paṭisandhiyā yasmā pana du hetukānam pi ariya magga paṭivedho
