translated: “By the hindrance of kamma” means by the five kinds of heinous kamma.🔽“By the hindrance of result” means by the rebirth-linking of one without root-cause. But since there is no penetration of the noble path by those with two root-causes,

original: natthi, tasmā duhetukā paṭisandhipi vipākāvaraṇamevāti veditabbā. Kilesāvaraṇenāti
analyzed: natthi tasmā du hetukā paṭisandhi pi vipāka āvaraṇam eva ati veditabbā kilesa āvaraṇena ati
translated: it should be understood that rebirth-linking with two root-causes is also a hindrance of result. “By the hindrance of defilement” means

original: niyatamicchādiṭṭhiyā. Assaddhāti buddhādīsu saddhārahitā. Acchandikāti kattukamyatāchandarahitā.
analyzed: niyatam icchā diṭṭhiyā assaddhā ati buddha ādīsu saddhā rahitā acchandikā ati kattu kamyatā chanda rahitā
translated: and fixed wrong view. Lack of faith is the absence of faith in the Buddha, etc. Lack of conscience is the absence of conscience.🔽The people of Uttarakuru are devoid of conscience. Lack of shame is the absence of shame.

original: Uttarakurukā manussā acchandikaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā. Duppaññāti bhavaṅgapaññāya parihīnā.🔽Bhavaṅgapaññāya pana paripuṇṇāyapi yassa bhavaṅgacalanaṃ lokuttarassa paccayo na
analyzed: uttarakurukāḥ manussāḥ acchandika ṭṭhānam paviṭṭhāḥ duppaññā ati bhavaṅga paññāya parihīnā  bhavaṅga paññāya pana yassa bhavaṅga calanam lokuttarassa paccayaḥ na
translated: The people of Uttarakuru are devoid of shame. Lack of wisdom is the absence of the life-continuum consciousness.🔽But even though the life-continuum consciousness is complete, if it is not a condition for the arising of the supramundane state, it is called “lack of wisdom.”

original: hoti, sopi duppañño eva nāma. Abhabbā niyāmaṃ okkamituṃ kusalesu dhammesu sammattanti
analyzed: hoti saḥ api duppaññaḥ eva nāma abhabbāḥ niyāmam okkamitum kusalesu dhammesu
translated: They are incapable of entering into the certainty of rightness in profitable states.

original: kusalesu dhammesu sammattaniyāmasaṅkhātaṃ maggaṃ okkamituṃ adhigantuṃ abhabbā. Na🔽kammāvaraṇenātiādīni vuttavipariyāyena veditabbāni. Rāgacaritādiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu sammatta niyāma saṅkhātam maggam okkamitum adhigantum abhabbāḥ na  kamma āvaraṇena ati ādīni vutta vipariyāyena veditabbāni rāga carita ādi ādīsu yam vattabbam
translated: They are incapable of entering into, of attaining, the path called “certainty of rightness” in profitable states.🔽They are not hindered by the hindrance of kamma.

original: taṃ paramatthadīpaniyaṃ visuddhimaggasaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tam paramattha dīpaniyam visuddhi magga saṃvaṇṇanāyam vutta nayena veditabbam
translated: The rest should be understood in the opposite sense. As to the “charactered by lust” , etc., what should be said has been said in the Visuddhimagga commentary in the description of the “exposition of the ultimate sense” .

original: Nibbānassa dvāraṃ pavisanamaggo vivaritvā ṭhapito mahākaruṇūpanissayena sayambhuñāṇena
analyzed: nibbānassa dvāram pavisana maggaḥ vivaritvā ṭhapitaḥ mahā karuṇūpanissayena sayambhu ñāṇena
translated: The door to Nibbāna is the path that is opened and set up by the knowledge of the Enlightened One, which is the support of great compassion.

original: adhigatattā. Saddhaṃ pamuñcantūti attano saddhaṃ dhammasampaṭicchanayogyaṃ katvā
analyzed: adhigata ttā saddham pamuñcantu uti attanaḥ saddham dhamma sampaṭicchana yogyam katvā
translated: because he had already attained it. Let them release their faith: let them make their faith fit for the acceptance of the True Idea.

original: vissajjentu, saddahanākārena naṃ upaṭṭhapentūti attho. Sukhena akicchena pavattanīyatāya
analyzed: vissajjentu saddahana ākārena nam upaṭṭhapentu uti attho sukhena akicchena pavattanīya tāya
translated: The meaning is: let them attend to it by way of having faith in it. It is well set rolling because it can be set rolling easily and without difficulty.

original: suppavattitaṃ. Na bhāsiṃ na bhāsissāmīti cintesiṃ.
analyzed: su pavattitam na bhāsim na bhāsissāmi iti cintesim
translated: I thought: “I will not speak, I will not speak.”

original: Satthu santikaṃ upagatānaṃ devānaṃ brahmānañca tassa purato antaradhānaṃ nāma atiṭṭhananti
analyzed: satthu santikam upagatānam devānam brahmānam ca tassa puratas antaradhānam nāma atiṭṭhananti
translated: The devas and Brahmās who approached the Teacher’s presence and disappeared in his presence did so because they were unable to bear the sight of the Blessed One’s face when he was thinking thus.🔽He said: “He went to his own place” . The faith faculty, etc., and the right view, etc., are the True Idea in the sense of what should be penetrated.

original: āha “sakaṭṭhānameva gato”ti. Saddhindriyādi sammādiṭṭhiādiko dhammo eva vineyyasantāne🔽pavattanaṭṭhena cakkanti dhammacakkaṃ. Atha vā cakkanti āṇā. Dhammanti desanā. Atha🔽vā atthadhammato anapetattā dhammañca taṃ pavattanaṭṭhena cakkañcāti dhammacakkaṃ.
analyzed: āha saka ṭṭhānam eva gataḥ ti saddhi indriya ādi sammādiṭṭhi ādiko dhammaḥ eva vineyya santāne  pavattana ṭṭhena cakkanti dhammacakkam atha vā cakkanti āṇāḥ dhammanti desanāḥ atha  vā attha dhammataḥ an apeta ttā dhammañca tam pavattana ṭṭhena cakkam ca ati dhammacakkam
translated: They are the Wheel in the sense of what is set rolling in the disciple’s mental continuity. Or alternatively, the Wheel is the command. The True Idea is the teaching.

original: Dhammena ñāyena cakkantipi dhammacakkaṃ. Yathāha “dhammañca pavatteti cakkañcāti
analyzed: dhammena ñāyena cakkam tipi dhammacakkam yathā āha dhammam ca pavatteti cakkam ca ati
translated: Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or the True Idea is the meaning and the True Idea is the teaching. Or

original: dhammacakkaṃ, cakkañca pavatteti dhammañcāti dhammacakkaṃ, dhammena pavattetīti dhammacakkaṃ,
analyzed: dhamma cakkam ca pavatteti dhammañca ati dhamma cakkam dhammena pavatteti iti dhamma cakkam
translated: the Wheel of the True Idea, and he sets the Wheel rolling and the True Idea, thus it is the Wheel of the True Idea. He sets it rolling by means of the True Idea, thus it is the Wheel of the True Idea,

original: dhammacariyāya pavattetīti dhammacakka”ntiādi. Pavattesīti paṭṭhapesi.🔽Brahmāyācanasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽2. Gāravasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhamma cariyāya pavatteti iti dhamma cakkanti ādi pavattesi iti paṭṭhapesi  brahmāyācana sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  gārava sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Wheel of the Dhamma is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the Dhamma, because it is set in motion as the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the manner of the Dhamma, because it is set in motion for the sake of the Dhamma, and because it is set in motion by the Dhamma.

original: 173. Ayaṃ vitakkoti ayaṃ “kintāhaṃ vihareyya”nti evaṃ pavattitavitakko. Aññasminti🔽parasmiṃ. Attā na hotīti hi añño, paro. So panettha na yo koci adhippeto, atha kho🔽garuṭṭhānīyo. Tenāha “kañci garuṭṭhāne aṭṭhapetvā”ti. Patissavati garuno “āmā”ti🔽sampaṭicchatīti patisso, na patissoti appatisso. Patissayarahito garupassayarahitoti attho.
analyzed: ayam ayam kintā aham vihareyyanti evam pavattita vitakkaḥ aññasmin ti  parasmim attā na hoti iti hi aññaḥ paraḥ so pana ittha na yaḥ koci adhippetaḥ atha kho  tena āha kañci garu ṭṭhāne aṭṭhapetvā ati patissavati garuno  sampaṭicchati iti patissaḥ na patissaḥ ti appatissaḥ patissaya rahitaḥ garu passaya rahitaḥ ti attho
translated: It is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the Dhamma, because it is set in motion as the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the manner of the Dhamma, because it is set in motion for the sake of the Dhamma, and because it is set in motion by the Dhamma.🔽It is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the Dhamma, because it is set in motion as the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the manner of the Dhamma, because it is set in motion for the sake of the Dhamma, and because it is set in motion by the Dhamma.🔽It is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the Dhamma, because it is set in motion as the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the manner of the Dhamma, because it is set in motion for the sake of the Dhamma, and because it is set in motion by the Dhamma.🔽It is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the Dhamma, because it is set in motion as the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the manner of the Dhamma, because it is set in motion for the sake of the Dhamma, and because it is set in motion by the Dhamma.

original: Sadevaketi avayavena viggaho samudāyo samāsattho. Sadevakaggahaṇena pañcakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: sa devaka iti avayavena viggahaḥ samudāyo samāsa attho sa devaka ggahaṇena pañca kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam
translated: It is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the Dhamma, because it is set in motion as the Dhamma, because it is set in motion in the manner of the Dhamma, because it is set in motion for the sake of the Dhamma, and because it is set in motion by the Dhamma.🔽It is the wheel of the Dhamma because it is set in motion by

original: pārisesañāyena itaresaṃ padantarehi saṅgahitattā, samārakaggahaṇena chaṭṭhakāmāvacaradevaggahaṇaṃ🔽paccāsattiñāyena. Tattha hi māro jāto tannivāsī ca hoti. Sabrahmakavacanena brahmakāyikādibrahmaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: pārisesa ñāyena itaresam pada antarehi saṅgahita ttā sa māraka ggahaṇena chaṭṭha kāmāvacara deva ggahaṇam  paccāsatti ñāyena tattha hi māraḥ jātaḥ tad nivāsī ca hoti sabrahmaka vacanena brahmakāyika ādi brahma ggahaṇam
translated: and by the method of the remainder, the rest are included by the other terms. The phrase “with Mara and with Brahma” includes the gods of the six sense-sphere heavens.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.

original: paccāsattiñāyeneva. “Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāyā”ti sāsanassa paccatthikasamaṇabrāhmaṇaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: paccāsatti ñāyena iva sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāyāti sāsanassa paccatthika samaṇa brāhmaṇa ggahaṇam
translated: By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.

original: Nidassanamattañcetaṃ apaccatthikānaṃ asamitapāpānaṃ abāhitapāpānañca samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ
analyzed: nidassana mattam ca itam a paccatthikānam a samita pāpānam a bāhita pāpānam ca samaṇa brāhmaṇānam
translated: By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.

original: teneva vacanena gahitattā. Kāmaṃ “sadevake”tiādivisesanānaṃ vasena sattavisayo lokasaddoti🔽viññāyati tulyayogavisayattā tesaṃ. “Salomako sapakkhako”tiādīsu pana atulyayogepi
analyzed: tena iva vacanena gahita ttā kāmam sa devaka iti ādi visesa nānam vasena satta visayaḥ loka saddo ti  viññāyati tulya yoga visaya ttā tesam salomako sapakkhako ti ādīsu pana atulya yoge pi
translated: By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.

original: ayaṃ samāso labbhatīti byabhicāradassanato pajāgahaṇanti pajāvacanena sattalokaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ayam samāsaḥ labbhati iti byabhicāra dassanato pajā gahaṇanti pajā vacanena satta loka ggahaṇam
translated: By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there and he resides there. The phrase “with Brahma” includes the gods of the Brahma-world.🔽By the method of the opposite, for Mara is born there

original: Devabhāvasāmaññena mārabrahmesu gahitesupi itarehi tesaṃ labbhamānavisesadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: deva bhāva sāmaññena māra brahmesu gahitesu pi itarehi tesam labbhamāna visesa dassana attham
translated: And he mentions them separately in order to show the difference between them, though they are included among Māra and Brahmā by the general statement about the divine world.

original: visuṃ gahaṇanti dassento “māro nāmā”tiādimāha. Māro brahmānampi vicakkhukammāya pahotīti
analyzed: visum gahaṇanti dassentaḥ māraḥ nāma atiādim āha māraḥ brahmānam pi vicakkhu kammāya pahoti iti
translated: He says, “Māra is able to overpower even Brahmās”🔽and so he says “all.”

original: āha “sabbesa”nti. Uparīti uparibhāve. Brahmāti dasasahassibrahmānaṃ sandhāyāha. Tathā
analyzed: āha upari iti upari bhāve brahmā ati dasa sahassi brahmānam sandhāya āha tathā
translated: “Above” means in the higher world. By “Brahmā” he means the Brahmās of the ten thousandfold world system.🔽And so he says, “with the ten fingers,” and so on.

original: cāha “dasahi aṅgulīhī”tiādi. Idha dīghanikāyādayo viya bāhirakānampi ganthanikāyo
analyzed: ca āha dasahi aṅgulīhi itiādi dīgha nikāya ādayaḥ gantha nikāyaḥ
translated: Here, as in the case of the Dīgha Nikāya, etc., the outsiders also have a collection of texts.

original: labbhatīti āha “ekanikāyādivasenā”ti.🔽Vatthuvijjādīti ādi-saddena vijjāṭṭhānāni saṅgahitāni. Yathāsakaṃ kammakilesehi pajātattā
analyzed: labbhati iti āha eka nikāya ādi vasena ati  vatthu vijjā ādi iti ādi saddena vijjāṭṭhānāni saṅgahitāni yathāsakam kamma kilesehi pajāta ttā
translated: And so he says “according to the one collection, etc.”🔽By the word “etc.” in “geomancy, etc.,” the eight branches of knowledge are included.🔽The world of beings is so called because it is born, i.e., produced, by kamma and defilements.

original: nibbattattā pajā, sattanikāyo. Tassā pajāya. Sadevamanussāyāti vā iminā sammutidevaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: nibbatta ttā pajā satta nikāyaḥ tassā pajāya sa deva manussāya ati vā iminā sammuti deva ggahaṇam
translated: The phrase “with its gods, its Māras, and its Brahmās” should be understood to include the gods of popular mythology and the rest of the world of human beings that remains after the gods of popular mythology have been excluded.

original: tadavasiṭṭhamanussalokaggahaṇañca daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ bhāgaso lokaṃ gahetvā yojanaṃ
analyzed: tad avasiṭṭha manussa loka ggahaṇam ca daṭṭhabbam evam bhāgasas lokam gahetvā yojanam
translated: Having thus taken the world in part, he now takes it in its entirety.

original: dassetvā idāni abhāgaso lokaṃ gahetvā yojanaṃ dassetuṃ “apicetthā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Lokavasena
analyzed: dassetvā idāni abhāgasaḥ lokam gahetvā yojanam dassetum api ca itthā atiādi vuttam loka vasena
translated: Having shown the meaning of the word “world” in the first part of the sutta, the Exalted One now takes up the word “world” in the second part of the sutta and shows its meaning by the word “yojana.” The word “world” is used in the sense of the world of beings,

original: vuttāni “lokīyanti ettha kammakammaphalānī”ti katvā, pajāvasena “hetupaccayehi pajāyatī”ti🔽katvā. Sīlasampannataranti ettha paripuṇṇasampannatā adhippetā “sampannaṃ sālikedāra”ntiādīsu
analyzed: vuttāni lokīyanti ettha kamma kamma phalāni iti katvā pajā vasena hetu paccayehi pajāyati iti  katvā ettha paripuṇṇa sampanna tā adhippetā sampannam sālikedāranti ādīsu
translated: in the sense of the world of kamma and its fruits, and in the sense of the world of causes and conditions.🔽The word “more” in the phrase “more perfect in virtue” is used in the sense of “more complete.”

original: viya. Tenāha “adhikataranti attho”ti. Paripuṇṇampi “adhikatara”nti vattabbatamarahati.🔽Sesesūti “samādhisampannatara”ntiādīsu.
analyzed: viya tena āha adhikataram iti attho ti paripuṇṇam pi adhikataram iti vattabbatam arahati  sesesu iti
translated: The word “more” is used in the sense of “more complete” in the phrase “more perfect in concentration,” etc.

original: Kāraṇantiādīsu kāraṇanti yuttiṃ. Atthanti aviparītatthaṃ. Vuḍḍhinti abhivuḍḍhinimittaṃ.
analyzed: kāraṇanti ādīsu kāraṇanti yuttim atthanti aviparīta attham vuḍḍhinti abhivuḍḍhi nimittam
translated: The word “reason” in the phrase “for a reason” means a logical reason. The word “meaning” in the phrase “for a meaning” means the true meaning. The word “increase” in the phrase “for increase” means the cause of increase.🔽The word “these” in the phrase “by these words” refers to the words immediately preceding the passage quoted.

original: Iminā vacanenāti imasmiṃ sutte anantaraṃ vuttavacanena. Na kevalaṃ imināva, suttantarampi
analyzed: iminā vacanena ati imasmin sutte anantaram vutta vacanena na kevalam sutta antaram pi
translated: The Exalted One does not only refer to the words of the sutta, but also to the suttas of other texts.

original: ānetvā paṭibāhitabboti dassento “na me ācariyo atthī”tiādimāha. Ettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: ānetvā paṭibāhitabbaḥ ti dassentaḥ na me ācariyaḥ atthi itiādim āha ettha yam vattabbam
translated: The Exalted One says: “I have no teacher, for I have no equal.”

original: taṃ sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāya vuttameva. Saranti karaṇe etaṃ paccattavacananti
analyzed: tam sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathāya vuttam eva saranti karaṇe etam paccatta vacanam ti
translated: This is stated in the Sumangalavilāsini Commentary on the Long Division.🔽The word saraṇa is a reflexive pronoun.

original: āha “sarantenā”ti, saranti vā saraṇahetūti attho.
analyzed: āha sarantena ati saranti vā saraṇa hetu uti attho
translated: The meaning is: they go for refuge by themselves.

original: Gāravasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gārava sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Commentary on the Discourse on Going for Refuge is finished.

original: 3. Brahmadevasuttavaṇṇanā🔽174. Ekakoti vivekaṭṭhitatāya nissaṭo. Gaṇasaṅgaṇikābhāvo tassānena dīpito, kilesasaṅgaṇikābhāvo
analyzed: brahmadeva sutta vaṇṇanā  ekako ti viveka ṭṭhita tāya nissaṭaḥ gaṇa saṅgaṇikā bhāvo tassa anena dīpitaḥ kilesa saṅgaṇikā bhāvaḥ
translated: Commentary on the Discourse to Brahmadeva🔽Alone: secluded, withdrawn. This shows his absence of association with a crowd. His absence of association with the defilements is shown by the words “energetic” and so on.

original: pana “appamatto”tiādīhi pakāsito. Pesitattoti nibbānaṃ pati pesitacitto. Sammadevāti🔽ñāyeneva. So pana yadi āgamanato paṭṭhāya labbhati, vattabbameva natthi, atha paṭipadārambhato
analyzed: pana appamattaḥ ti ādīhi pakāsito pesita tto ti nibbānam pati pesita citto sammat eva ati  ñāyena iva so pana yadi āgamanataḥ paṭṭhāya labbhati vattabbam eva natthi atha paṭipad ārambhato
translated: His mind is bent on Nibbana.🔽By the right way.🔽If this is taken to mean that he is so only from the time of his coming to the Buddha, then there is nothing to be said. But if it is taken to mean that he was so from the time of his undertaking the practice of the path, then it is correct.

original: paṭṭhāya labbhati, evampi vaṭṭatevāti dassetuṃ “yathā vā tathā vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Aggamaggādhigamena
analyzed: paṭṭhāya labbhati evam pi vaṭṭatā iva āti dassetum yathā vā tathā vā itiādi vuttam agga magga adhigamena
translated: To show this, the text says “in whatever way” and so on.

original: asammohapaṭivedhassa sikhāppattattā maggadhammesu viya phaladhammesupi sātisayo asammohoti
analyzed: asammoha paṭivedhassa sikhā appatta ttā magga dhammesu viya phala dhammesu pi sa atisayaḥ asammoho ti
translated: Because the penetration of the path by non-delusion has reached its culmination with the attainment of the supramundane path, there is a very great absence of delusion in the states of fruition just as there is in the states of the path.

original: “sayaṃ abhiññā”ti vuttanti āha “sāmaṃ jānitvā”ti. Yathā jānanā panassa sacchikaraṇaṃ🔽attapaccakkhakiriyāti “sacchikatvā”ti vuttanti āha “paccakkhaṃ katvā”ti. Tathā sacchikiriyā
analyzed: sayam abhiññā iti vuttanti āha sāmam jānitvā ti yathā jānanā pana assa sacchikaraṇam  atta paccakkha kiriyā iti sacchikatvā iti vuttan ti āha paccakkham katvā iti tathā sacchikiriyā
translated: “By his own super-knowledge” is said in the text. “Having known by himself” is said in the commentary. But his knowing is his realization.🔽“Having realized” is said in the text. “Having made it manifest” is said in the commentary. His realization in this way

original: cassa vipassanāpaṭilābhoti “upasampajjā”ti vuttanti āha “paṭilabhitvā”ti. Etenāti🔽“khīṇā jātī”tiādivacanena.
analyzed: cassa vipassanā paṭilābhaḥ ti upasampajja ati vuttanti āha paṭilabhitvā iti etena ati  khīṇā jātī iti ādi vacanena
translated: is his acquisition of insight. “Having attained” is said in the text. “Having obtained” is said in the commentary. “By this”🔽is said in the text.

original: Jāti khīṇāti ettha jātisīsena tabbikāravanto khandhā vuttā. Pubbeva khīṇattāti maggādhigamanato🔽pageva atītabhāveneva khīṇattā. Tattha anāgatesu. Vāyāmābhāvatoti avijjamānattā.
analyzed: jāti khīṇā ti ettha jāti sīsena tad bikāravantaḥ khandhāḥ vuttā pubbā iva khīṇa ttā ti magga adhigamanato  pagā iva atīta bhāvena iva khīṇa ttā tattha anāgatesu vāyāma abhāvato ti a vijjamāna ttā
translated: “Birth is destroyed” is said in the text. “Already destroyed” is said in the commentary. Herein, the aggregates with their functions are called “birth” in the sense of the beginning of the next becoming. “Already destroyed” means destroyed by the mere passing away of the past state,🔽before the attainment of the path. “Because there is no more practice” is said because there is no more practice in the future.

original: Anāgatabhāvasāmaññaṃ gahetvā lesena vuttaṃ. Na paccuppannā vijjamānattāti saṃkiliṭṭhā
analyzed: anāgata bhāva sāmaññam gahetvā lesena vuttam na paccuppannā vijjamāna ttā ti saṃkiliṭṭhā
translated: The future is mentioned by way of similarity of state. “Not present” is said because they are defiled.🔽“Because of the development of the path” is the remainder of the text. Just as when the root of a tree that bears fruit every year is cut down, what should arise in the future

original: ca maggabhāvanāti siyāti vacanaseso. Yathā ajātaphalataruṇarukkhamūle chinne āyatiuppajjanārahāni
analyzed: ca magga bhāvanā ti siyā iti vacana sesaḥ yathā ajāta phala taruṇa rukkha mūle chinne āyati uppajjana arahāni
translated: is destroyed.

original: phalāni chedanapaccayā anuppajjamānāni naṭṭhāni nāma honti, evameva bhāvanāya asati
analyzed: phalāni chedana paccayā anuppajjamānāni naṭṭhāni nāma honti evam eva bhāvanāya asati
translated: The fruits, not arising because of the cutting off, are called “destroyed.” So too, when there is no development of the path,

original: uppajjanārahā kilesā tappaccayā jāti ca maggabhāvanāya sati na uppajjamānā pahīnāti
analyzed: uppajjana arahā kilesā tad paccayā jāti ca magga bhāvanāya sati na uppajjamānā pahīnā ati
translated: the defilements that are due to arise are called “abandoned” because of the non-arising of the defilements that are due to arise because of the path.🔽This is the meaning he shows with the words “But as to the path.”

original: vuccantīti imamatthaṃ dasseti “maggassa panā”tiādinā. Anuppādadhammataṃ āpajjanena
analyzed: vuccanti iti imam attham dasseti maggassa pana āti ādinā anuppāda dhamma tam āpajjanena
translated: By the knowledge that has reached the state of non-arising,

original: ñāṇena khīṇarāgavasena.🔽Soḷasakiccabhāvāyāti soḷasakiccatāya, soḷasavidhassa vā kiccassa bhāvāya uppādanāya.
analyzed: ñāṇena khīṇa rāga vasena  soḷasa kicca bhāvāya ati soḷasa kiccatāya soḷasavidhassa vā kiccassa bhāvāya uppādanāya
translated: in the sense of being free from lust.🔽For the sake of the sixteenfold function: for the sake of the sixteenfoldness of the function, or for the sake of the arising of the function of the sixteen kinds.

original: Pāḷiyaṃ sapadānanti sapadānacāro vutto bhāvanapuṃsakaniddesenāti āha “sapadānacāra”nti.🔽Anukkammāti anatikkamitvā. Āhutipiṇḍanti juhitabbapiṇḍaṃ, juhanavasena aggimhi pakkhipitabbapāyāsapiṇḍanti
analyzed: pāḷiyam sa padānam ti sa padāna cāraḥ vuttaḥ bhāva napuṃsaka niddesena ati āha sa padāna cāram ti  anukkamma ati an atikkamitvā āhuti piṇḍam juhitabba piṇḍam juhana vasena aggimhi pakkhipitabba pāyāsa piṇḍam ti
translated: In the text the word “in detail” is said to be “in detail” .🔽In due course: without transgressing. The oblation-ball: the ball to be offered, the ball of boiled rice to be put into the fire by the act of offering.

original: adhippāyo. Bhūtabalikammanti tathā pakkhipitvā balikammakaraṇaṃ. Haritupalittanti
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ bhūta bali kammanti tathā pakkhipitvā bali kamma karaṇam harita upalittam ti
translated: This is the intention. The act of offering to the elementals: the act of making an offering after putting it there. The green grass-blade:

original: allagomayena kataparibhaṇḍaṃ. Vanamālaparikkhittanti manoharāhi vanapupphamālāhi
analyzed: alla gomayena kata paribhaṇḍam vana māla parikkhittanti manoharāhi vana puppha mālāhi
translated: a bedstead made of fresh cowdung. Surrounded by a garland of trees: by garlands of flowering trees.

original: parikkhittaṃ. Dhūmakaṭacchūti dhūmapānaṃ. Sīlagandhanti sīlaṃ paṭicca uppannakittigandhaṃ.
analyzed: parikkhittam dhūma kaṭacchu iti dhūma pānam sīla gandhanti sīlam paṭicca uppanna kitti gandham
translated: A bedstead made of fresh cowdung. Surrounded by a garland of forest: surrounded by a garland of beautiful forest flowers. Smoke-hole: the place where the smoke comes out. Virtue-scent: the scent of fame that arises in dependence on virtue.

original: Ghāyamānassāti upagataṃ gaṇhantassa.
analyzed: ghāyamānassa iti upagatam gaṇhantassa
translated: Smelling: taking it by going to it.

original: Imamhā ṭhānāti imasmā manussānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānā, mahāpathavitalatoti adhippāyo. Sabbaheṭṭhimoti
analyzed: imamhā ṭhānā ti imasmā manussānam vasana ṭṭhānā mahā pathavi talataḥ ti adhippāyo sabbaheṭṭhimaḥ ti
translated: From this place: from this place where human beings live, the great earth, is what is meant. The lowest:

original: brahmapārisajjānaṃ vāsabrahmalokamāha. Brahmapatho nāma cattāri kusalajjhānāni brahmalokamaggabhāvato.
analyzed: brahmapārisajjānam vāsabrahmalokam āha brahmapathaḥ nāma cattāri kusala jjhānāni brahmaloka magga bhāvato
translated: the world of Brahmā, the abode of the Brahmapārisajya gods, is called. The path to Brahmā is the four wholesome jhānas, because they are the path to the world of Brahmā.

original: Jīvitapatho nāma jīvitapavattiupāyabhāvato. “Bhuñjatu bhavaṃ mahābrahmā”ti vacanaṃ
analyzed: jīvitapathaḥ nāma jīvita pavatti upāya bhāvataḥ bhuñjatu bhavam mahābrahmā ati vacanam
translated: The path of life is the means of maintaining life. “Let the great Brahmā eat,”

original: sandhāyāha “kiṃ jappasī”tiādi. Tiṇabījānīti sālitaṇḍulādīni. Goyūsanti khīraṃ jigucchanto
analyzed: sandhāya āha kim tiṇa bījāni iti sāli taṇḍula ādīni khīram
translated: with reference to this statement, he said “What are you muttering?” and so on. Grass seeds: rice, etc., with the husk. Cow’s milk: he says this with disgust.

original: vadati. Ayampi attho “netādiso brahmabhakkho”ti vadantena dīpitoti.
analyzed: vadati ayam pi atthaḥ netādiso brahma bhakkho ti vadantena dīpitaḥ ti
translated: This meaning is also shown by the statement “Brahmā does not eat like this.”

original: Atidevapattopi pañcakhandhūpadhīnaṃ atthitāya kilesūpadhiādīnaṃyeva virahitabhāvo🔽gahito. Aññatra hi bhāvapaccayaṃ tadattho viññāyatīti āha “atidevabhāvaṃ patto”ti.
analyzed: ati deva patto pi virahita bhāvaḥ  gahitaḥ aññatra hi bhāva paccayam tad attho viññāyati iti āha atideva bhāvam patto ti
translated: The phrase “he has attained the state of being a god above the gods” means that he is free from the defilements of the five aggregates, etc.🔽For the meaning of the word “above” is understood in relation to the meaning of the word “god.”

original: Yasmā brahmānopi devagatipariyāpannattā devā eva, tasmā vuttaṃ “atibrahmabhāvaṃ patto”ti.
analyzed: yasmā brahmānaḥ api deva gati pariyāpanna ttāḥ devāḥ eva tasmā vuttam ati brahma bhāvam patto ti
translated: The phrase “he has attained the state of being a Brahma above the Brahmas” means that he is free from the defilements of the Brahma-world, etc.

original: Attānaṃ bhāvetvāti sīlādīhi guṇehi attānaṃ vaḍḍhetvā paribrūhitvā ṭhito.🔽Puthujjanā tasā taṇhāmānadiṭṭhiparittāsavasena tāsanato. Khīṇāsavā thāvarā nāma sabbaso
analyzed: attānam bhāvetvā iti sīla ādīhi guṇehi attānam vaḍḍhetvā paribrūhitvā ṭhitaḥ  puthujjanā tasā taṇhā māna diṭṭhi paritta āsa vasena khīṇa āsavā thāvarā nāma sabbaso
translated: “Having developed himself” means that he has developed himself by means of the virtues of morality, etc., and has become established.🔽The phrase “the world with its gods, etc.” refers to the world of beings, which is afflicted by the defilements of craving, conceit, and views.🔽The world of beings is called “the world with its gods” because the gods are included in the world of beings.

original: gatīsu sañcaraṇābhāvato. Tathā hi catunnaṃ saccānaṃ sabbaso adiṭṭhattā bhavadāyajjassa🔽taṇhādāsabyassa bhāvato ekaccāsu gatīsu sañcaraṇasabhāvato sekkhā thāvarā na honti.
analyzed: gatīsu sañcaraṇa abhāvataḥ tathā hi catunnam saccānam sabbasas a diṭṭha ttā bhava āyajjassa  taṇhā dāsabyassa bhāvataḥ ekaccāsu gatīsu sañcaraṇa sabhāvataḥ sekkhāḥ thāvarāḥ na honti
translated: The world of beings is called “the world with its Maras” because Mara is included in the world of beings.🔽The world of beings is called “the world with its Brahmas” because the Brahmas are included in the world of beings.

original: Bhajamānāti bhajāpiyamānā. Thāvarapakkhameva bhajanti sabbaseṭṭhapakkhaṃ ekantapasaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: bhajamānā iti thāvara pakkham eva bhajanti sabba seṭṭha pakkham ekanta pasaṭṭham
translated: The world of beings is called “the world with recluses and brahmins” because recluses and brahmins are included in the world of beings.🔽The world of beings is called “the world with its gods, etc.” because the world of beings is included in the world of beings.🔽The world of beings is called “the world with its gods, etc.” because the world of beings is included in the world of beings.🔽The world of beings is called “the world with its gods, etc.” because the world of beings is included in the world of beings.

original: bhajamānabhāvaṃ upādāya.
analyzed: bhajamāna bhāvam upādāya
translated: because of the state of being enjoyed.

original: Pahīnakileso khīṇāsavo viseno. Sukhaṃ āyati sukhāyati, tassa kārakaṃ sukhāyatikaṃ.
analyzed: pahīna kilesaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ visenaḥ sukham āyati sukhāyati tassa kārakam sukhāyatikam
translated: One whose defilements are abandoned, whose cankers are destroyed, is a “poisonless one.” He “makes for happiness” in the future, and that which makes for his happiness is “the happiness-maker.”

original: Brahmadevasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: brahmadeva sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Brahmadeva Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Bakabrahmasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bakabrahmasutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Bakabrahma Sutta

original: 175. “Sassato attā ca loko cā”ti evaṃ pavattā diṭṭhi sassatadiṭṭhi. Saha kāyenāti
analyzed: sassataḥ attā ca loko ca ati evam pavattā diṭṭhi sassata diṭṭhi saha kāyena ati
translated: The view that occurs thus: “The self and the world are eternal” is the eternalist view. Together with the body:

original: saha tena brahmattabhāvena. Brahmaṭṭhānanti attano brahmavatthuṃ. Aniccaṃ “nicca”nti🔽vadati aniccatāya attano apaññāyamānattā. Thiranti daḷhaṃ, vināsābhāvato sārabhūtanti
analyzed: saha tena brahmatta bhāvena brahmaṭṭhānanti attanaḥ brahmavatthum aniccam niccanti  vadati anicca tāya attanaḥ a paññāyamāna ttā daḷham vināsā bhāvato
translated: together with that divine selfhood. The divine station: his own divine abode. Impermanent:🔽he says it is permanent because of his own non-perishing. It stands firm: the meaning is, it is solid because of its non-disappearance.

original: attho. Uppādavipariṇāmābhāvato sadā vijjamānaṃ. Kevalanti paripuṇṇaṃ. Tenāha “akhaṇḍa”nti.🔽Kevalanti vā jātiādīhi asammissaṃ, virahitanti adhippāyo. Uppādādīnaṃ abhāvato eva
analyzed: atthaḥ uppāda vipariṇāma abhāvataḥ sadā vijjamānam kevalanti paripuṇṇam tena āha akhaṇḍanti  kevalanti vā jāti ādīhi asammissam virahitanti adhippāyaḥ uppāda ādīnam abhāvataḥ eva
translated: It exists always because of the absence of arising and change. It is complete: it is perfect. Hence he says “without a break.”🔽Or the meaning of “complete” is “unmixed,” “unaccompanied” by birth, etc., because of the absence of arising, etc.

original: acavanadhammaṃ. Koci jāyanako…pe… upapajjanako vā natthi niccabhāvato ṭhānena saddhiṃ
analyzed: a cavana dhammam koci jāyana kope upapajjanakaḥ vā natthi nicca bhāvataḥ ṭhānena saddhim
translated: There is no one who is born, who grows old, who dies, who falls into another existence, because of its eternality. It stands firm together with the place

original: tannivāsīnaṃ. Niccabhāvañhi so paṭijānāti. Tisso jhānabhūmiyoti dutiyatatiyacatutthajjhānabhūmiyo.
analyzed: tad nivāsīnam nicca bhāvañhi so paṭijānāti tissaḥ jhāna bhūmiyo ti dutiya tatiya catuttha jjhāna bhūmiyo
translated: The three jhāna-levels are the second, third, and fourth jhāna-levels.

original: Catutthajjhānabhūmivisesā hi asaññasuddhāvāsāruppabhavā. Nibbānanti vā ettha iti-saddo
analyzed: catuttha jhāna bhūmi visesāḥ hi asañña suddhāvāsa āruppa bhavā nibbānanti vā ettha iti saddo
translated: For the Pure Abodes of the Non-percipient Beings are a special case of the fourth jhāna-level.🔽Or the word “and” in the text can be construed as meaning “or” instead of “and,” so that the words “or in Nibbāna” can be taken as the second alternative.

original: ādiattho, na parisamāpanattho, tasmā “sabba”nti iminā “asañña…pe… bhavā”ti vuttaṃ
analyzed: ādi atthaḥ na parisamāpana atthaḥ tasmā sabbanti iminā a saññape bhava ati vuttam
translated: The word “all” includes what is stated in the words “in the Non-percipient …” and “in existence.”🔽“Denies” : not knowing that there is, he denies it, saying “There is not.”

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Paṭibāhatīti santaṃyeva samānaṃ ajānantova “natthī”ti paṭikkhipati. Eke uttaravihāravāsino.🔽Heṭṭhūpapattikoti heṭṭhā bhūmīsu uppannaupapattiko. Idāni tamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “anuppanne”tiādi
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti paṭibāhati iti santam yeva samānam a jānantaḥ iva natthi iti paṭikkhipati eke uttaravihāra vāsinaḥ  heṭṭhūpapattikaḥ ti heṭṭhā bhūmīsu uppanna aupapattikaḥ idāni tam attham vivaritum anuppanna itiādi
translated: Some residents of the Upper Monastery.🔽“Who have been reborn in a lower place” : who have been reborn in the lower planes.🔽Now, in order to explain that meaning, the words “When the fourth jhāna” are stated.

original: vuttaṃ. Heṭṭhupapattikaṃ katvāti yathāṭhitabhūmito heṭṭhā tatiyajjhānabhūmiyaṃ upapattijhānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam heṭṭhupapattikam katvā iti yathā ṭhita bhūmitaḥ heṭṭhā tatiya jhāna bhūmiyam upapatti jhānam
translated: Having made rebirth in a lower place: having made the jhāna of rebirth in the third jhāna-level below the plane where he is standing,🔽the meaning intended is that it is not merely a wish for a higher jhāna.

original: katvā, na uparijhānassa viya patthanāmattanti adhippāyo. Paṭhamakāleti tasmiṃ bhave
analyzed: katvā na upari jhānassa viya patthanā mattanti adhippāyaḥ paṭhama kāle ti tasmim bhave
translated: “The first maker” : in that existence

original: paṭhamakāle. Aññāsi āsannabhāvato. Ubhayanti taṃ taṃ attanā katakammañceva nibbattaṭṭhānañcāti
analyzed: paṭhama kāle āsanna bhāvato ubhayanti tam tam attanā kata kammam ca iva nibbatta ṭṭhānam ca ati
translated: At the first time. He knew by way of proximity. Both: both his own action and the place of rebirth.

original: ubhayaṃ. Pamussitvā nibbattiṃ anupadhārento.
analyzed: ubhayam pamussitvā nibbattim an upadhārentaḥ
translated: Having forgotten, he was reborn.

original: Avijjāya gatoti avijjāya saha pavatto. Sahayoge hi idaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Tenāha “samannāgato”ti.
analyzed: avijjāya gataḥ ti avijjāya saha pavattaḥ saha yoge hi idam karaṇa vacanam tena āha samannāgataḥ iti
translated: Gone with ignorance: occurred together with ignorance. For this is a verbal expression in the compound sahayoge. Therefore he said “endowed with.”

original: Aññāṇīti avidvā. Paññācakkhuvirahato andhībhūto, andhabhāvaṃ āpannoti attho. Anāgate
analyzed: aññāṇi iti a vidvā paññā cakkhu virahataḥ andhībhūtaḥ andha bhāvam āpannaḥ ti atthaḥ anāgate
translated: Ignorant: not knowing. Having become blind through the absence of the eye of wisdom, he has reached the state of blindness, is the meaning. In the future

original: saddo hotāyaṃ “vakkhatī”ti yatrasaddapayogena, attho pana vattamānakāliko. Tenāha
analyzed: saddaḥ hotā ayam vakkhati iti yatra sadda payogena attho pana vattamāna kālikaḥ tena āha
translated: The word “will say” is used with the word yattha, but the meaning is in the present tense. Therefore he said

original: “bhaṇatī”ti. Tenāha “yatrā”tiādi.
analyzed: bhaṇati iti tena āha yatra atiādi
translated: “says.” Therefore he said “yattha,” etc.

original: Maggacoroti maggaparibundhakacoro. Santajjiyamānoti “avijjāgato vata, bho, bako brahmā”tiādinā
analyzed: magga coro ti magga paribundhaka coro santajjiyamāno ti avijjā gataḥ vata bho bakaḥ brahmā ati ādinā
translated: A highwayman: a highway robber. Being reproved: being reproved thus, “Baka Brahma is gone with ignorance,” etc.

original: santajjiyamāno. Satiṃ labhitvāti teneva santajjanena yoniso ummujjitvā purimajātivisayaṃ
analyzed: santajjiyamānaḥ satim labhitvā ati tena iva santajjanena yonisaḥ ummujjitvā purima jāti visayam
translated: Having gained mindfulness: having risen up by means of that very reproof by means of right reflection, and having made the object of his former life

original: satiṃ labhitvā. Nippīḷitukāmoti ghaṃsetukāmo dosaṃ dassetukāmo “idaṃ passa yāvañca
analyzed: satim labhitvā nippīḷitu kāmaḥ iti ghaṃsetu kāmaḥ dosam dassetu kāmaḥ idam passa yāvañca
translated: Having regained mindfulness. Desiring to oppress: desiring to crush, desiring to show anger, thinking “See how far you have transgressed!”

original: te aparaddha”nti. Puññakammāti puññakārino. Vedehi ñāṇehi gatattā pavattattā. Antimā
analyzed: te aparaddhanti puña kammā ati puñña kārinaḥ vedehi ñāṇehi gata ttā pavatta ttā antimā
translated: Meritorious deeds: meritorious actions. Because of the penetration of knowledge, because of the occurrence of knowledge.🔽The last divine birth: the last divine existence.

original: brahmupapattīti sabbapacchimā brahmabhāvappatti. Asmābhijappantīti asme abhijappanti.🔽Āyuvaṇṇādivasena brūhitaguṇattā brahmā. Aññehi mahantā brahmā mahābrahmā. Abhibhūti
analyzed: brahmupapattī iti sabba pacchimā brahma bhāva ppatti asmā abhijappanti iti asme abhijappanti  āyu vaṇṇā ādi vasena brahmā aññehi mahantā brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhūti
translated: They praise us: they praise us.

original: taṃ brahmalokaṃ jeṭṭhakabhāvena abhibhavitvā ṭhito. Anabhibhūtoti aññehi na abhibhūto.🔽Aññadatthūti ekaṃsavacanametaṃ. Dassanavasena daso, sabbaṃ passatīti adhippāyo. Vasavattīti
analyzed: tam brahma lokam jeṭṭhaka bhāvena abhibhavitvā ṭhitaḥ anabhibhūto ti aññehi na abhibhūto  añña datthu iti ekaṃsa vacanam etam dassana vasena dasaḥ sabbam passati iti adhippāyaḥ vasa vattī iti
translated: Brahmā is so called because of his expanded qualities such as life-span, beauty, etc. Mahābrahmā is the great Brahmā, greater than others. Abhibhū means he stands, having surpassed that Brahmā world by seniority. Anabhibhū means he is not surpassed by others.

original: sabbajanaṃ vase vatteti. Issaroti loke issaro. Kattā nimmātāti lokassa kattā nimmātā.
analyzed: sabba janam vase vatteti issaro ti loke issaraḥ kattā nimmātā ati lokassa kattā nimmātā
translated: Aññadatthu means “in one way.” Daso means “ten,” in the sense of seeing. The intention is that he sees everything. Vasavattī means he controls all people. Issaro means he is the lord of the world. Kattā nimmātā means he is the maker and creator of the world.

original: Seṭṭho sajitāti ayaṃ lokassa uttamo saṃvibhajitā ca. Vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānanti āciṇṇavasittā
analyzed: seṭṭhaḥ sajitā ati ayam lokassa uttamaḥ saṃvibhajitā ca vasī pitā āciṇṇa vasittā
translated: Seṭṭho sajitā means he is the best and the distributor of the world. Vasī pitā bhūtabhabyān means he is the lord of the past and the future, because of his habitual mastery.

original: vasī, ayaṃ pitā bhūtānaṃ nibbattānaṃ bhabyānaṃ sambhavesīnanti patthenti vikatthenti pihenti mānenti.🔽Etanti viparītasaññāvasena “idaṃ niccaṃ idaṃ dhuvaṃ idaṃ sassata”ntiādinā vuttaṃ
analyzed: vasī ayam pitā bhūtānam nibbattānam bhabyānam sambhavesīnam ti patthenti vikatthenti pihenti mānenti  etat ti viparīta saññā vasena idam niccam idam dhuvam idam vuttam
translated: and they are powerful, they are the Father of beings, of those born and of those to be born. ’🔽This is what they say, what they proclaim, what they announce, what they make known.

original: etaṃ appaṃ parittakanti taṃ bhagavā paricchinditvā dasseti. Taṃ pana “ekasmiṃ kosalake
analyzed: etam appam parittakanti tam bhagavā paricchinditvā dasseti tam pana ekasmin kosalake
translated: The Blessed Lord has defined it thus: ‘This is trifling, insignificant, a mere pittance. ’🔽In one Kosalan kosha of sesame

original: tilavāhe vassasate vassasate ekekatiluddhāre kayiramāne tilāni parikkhayaṃ gacchanti,
analyzed: tila vāhe vassa sate vassa sate ekeka tila uddhāre kayiramāne tilāni parikkhayam gacchanti
translated: if at the end of every hundred years a single sesame seed were to be removed, that heap of sesame would sooner be exhausted

original: na tveva abbude āyū”ti evaṃ vutto abbudo, taṃvasena vīsatiguṇaṃ nirabbudo, tesaṃ🔽nirabbudānaṃ vasena nirabbudasatasahassaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato pana padume
analyzed: na tu eva abbude evam vuttaḥ abbudaḥ tad vasena vīsatiguṇam nirabbudaḥ tesam  nirabbudānam vasena nirabbuda sata sahassam ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana padume
translated: than the life-span of one who has attained the Abhuta life-span.🔽Twenty times that is the life-span of one who has attained the Nirabbuda life-span,

original: āyuno vassagaṇanā imasmiṃyeva saṃyutte parato āgamissati. Anantadassīti anantassa
analyzed: āyunaḥ vassa gaṇanā imasmin yeva saṃyutte paratas āgamissati ananta dassī iti anantassa
translated: and a hundred thousand times that is the life-span of one who has attained the Nirabbudaniraya life-span. This is a brief account of it. But the calculation of the life-span in padumas🔽will be given later in this sutta.🔽The ‘Infinite Seer’ is one who sees the infinite knowable without exception.

original: ñeyyassa anavasesato dassī. Vatasīlavattanti samādānavasena vatabhūtaṃ cārittasīlavasena
analyzed: ñeyyassa anavasesataḥ dassī samādāna vasena vata bhūtam cāritta sīla vasena
translated: ‘The practice of virtue and the practice of good conduct’ is the practice of virtue as a vow, and the practice of virtue as good conduct.

original: samāciṇṇattā sīlavattaṃ. Taṃ pana ekamevāti āha “sīlamevā”ti.
analyzed: sīlavattam tam pana ekam eva ati āha sīlam eva ati
translated: “The practice of virtue” is the practice of virtue that is the result of the habit of practicing virtue in the past. But that is one only, thus he said “virtue alone.”

original: Apāyesīti ettha yadā so pipāsite manusse pānīyaṃ pāyesi, taṃ samudāgamato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: apāyesi iti ettha yadā saḥ pipāsite manusse pānīyam pāyesi tam samudāgamataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “He led them away from the evil states”: here, when he gave water to drink to the thirsty people,🔽in order to show the beginning of that,

original: dassetuṃ “tatrā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Pubbeti purimajātiyaṃ. Esa brahmā “jarāmaraṇassa
analyzed: dassetum tatra atiādi āraddham pubba iti purima jātiyam esa brahmā jarā maraṇassa
translated: he said “there” and so on. “In the past” means in a previous birth. That Brahmā,🔽with the intention “I will make an end of birth and death,”

original: antaṃ karissāmī”ti ajjhāsayavasena jhānaṃ nibbattetvā brahmaloke nibbatti, so tattha
analyzed: antam karissāmi iti ajjhāsaya vasena jhānam nibbattetvā brahma loke nibbatti saḥ tattha
translated: after producing jhāna, was reborn in the Brahmā-world, and there

original: nibbānasaññī ahosi. Jhānaratiyā vītināmetīti tadā tassā kiriyāya avicchedato pavattiṃ🔽upādāya vattamānapayogo. Rattandhakāre purato purato gacchantassa sakaṭassa anussaraṇavasena
analyzed: nibbāna saññī ahosi jhāna ratiyā vītināmeti iti tadā tassā kiriyāya avicchedato pavattim  upādāya vattamāna payogaḥ ratta ndhakāre puratas puratas gacchantassa sakaṭassa anussaraṇa vasena
translated: he had the perception of nibbāna. “He spent his time in the delight of jhāna” is the present participle used in the sense of the occurrence

original: gacchantānaṃ sakaṭānaṃ nivattanaṃ hotīti “sabbasakaṭāni tatheva nivattitvā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: gacchantānam sakaṭānam nivattanam hoti iti sabba sakaṭāni tathā iva nivattitvā iti vuttam
translated: of the action from the time of its beginning. “All the carts turned back in the same way” is said because the turning back of the carts🔽was by way of the recollection of the cart that was going on in front in the darkness of the night.

original: Kammasajjāti yuddhasajjā. Vilopanti viluttabhaṇḍaṃ. Eṇikūlasminti ettha “panihatāya
analyzed: yuddha sajjā eṇi kūlasmin ti ettha
translated: “Ready for work” means ready for battle. “Plunder” means stolen goods. “In the Eṇijaṅgha River” means in the Eṇijaṅgha River.

original: niccagaṅgāya nāma”nti keci. “Eṇimigabahulatāya so gaṅgāya tīrappadeso eṇikūlanti
analyzed: niccagaṅgāya nāmanti keci so gaṅgāya tīra ppadeso
translated: Some say: “It is the river that always flows.”🔽Others say: “That place on the bank of the Ganges is called Eṇikūpa because it is frequented by the Eṇī deer.”

original: vutta”nti apare. Gaṅgeyyakoti gaṅgāsannivāsī.
analyzed: vuttanti apare gaṅgeyyako ti gaṅgā sannivāsī
translated: Gaṅgeyyaka: one who lives on the Ganges.🔽Baddhacariya: one who has a bound life, a dependent. Thus he said: “a pupil.”

original: Baddhacaroti paṭibaddhacariyo. Tenāha “antevāsiko”ti. Yasmā buddho sabbaññū, tasmā
analyzed: baddha caro ti paṭibaddha cariyaḥ tena āha antevāsikaḥ iti yasmai buddhaḥ sabbaññū tasmai
translated: Since the Buddha is omniscient, therefore🔽he knew. The intention is: “You know all that I have forgotten.”

original: aññāsi, idha mayhaṃ pamuṭṭhañca sabbaṃ jānāsīti adhippāyo. Sabbaṃ brahmalokaṃ obhāsayanto
analyzed: aññāsi idha mayham pamuṭṭhañca sabbam jānāsi iti adhippāyaḥ sabbam brahma lokam obhāsayanto
translated: Illuminating the whole Brahma-world

original: sabbampimaṃ brahmalokaṃ bhagavā obhāsaṃ abhibhavitvā anaññasādhāraṇaṃ attano obhāsaṃ obhāsento tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: sabbam pi imam brahma lokam bhagavā obhāsam abhibhavitvā anañña sādhāraṇam attanaḥ obhāsam obhāsento tiṭṭhati
translated: the Blessed One stands, outshining the light of the whole Brahma-world, with a light that is not shared by others.

original: Bakabrahmasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bakabrahma sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Bakabrahma Sutta is finished.

original: 5. Aññatarabrahmasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aññatara brahma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Aññatarabrahma Sutta

original: 176. Tejokasiṇaparikammaṃ katvāti “tejokasiṇaparikammajjhānaṃ samāpajjissāmī”ti cittuppādo
analyzed: tejaḥ kasiṇa parikammam katvā ati tejaḥ kasiṇa parikamma jhānam samāpajjissāmi iti cittuppādaḥ
translated: Having done the preliminary work on the kasiṇa of fire: having had the thought: “I shall attain jhāna by means of the preliminary work on the kasiṇa of fire,”

original: evettha tejokasiṇaparikammaṃ. Na hi buddhānaṃ aññesaṃ viya tattha jhānasamāpajjanena
analyzed: eva ittha tejo kasiṇa parikammam na hi buddhānam aññesam viya tattha jhāna samāpajjanena
translated: this is the preliminary work on the kasiṇa of fire here. For the Buddhas do not attain jhāna by means of the jhāna attainment as others do,

original: parikammapapañco atthi sabbattheva ciṇṇavasībhāvassa paramukkaṃsabhāvappattattā.🔽Tassa kira brahmuno “yathāhaṃ evaṃ mahānubhāvo añño natthī”ti laddhi, yaṃ sandhāya🔽vuttaṃ – “natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā, yo idha āgaccheyyā”ti. Bhagavā tassa taṃ
analyzed: parikamma papañcaḥ atthi sabbattha iva ciṇṇavasībhāvassa paramukkaṃsa bhāva ppatta ttā  tassa kira brahmunaḥ yathā aham evam mahā anubhāvaḥ aññaḥ natthi iti laddhi yam sandhāya  vuttam na atthi saḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā yaḥ idha āgaccheyya ati bhagavā tassa tam
translated: The elaboration of the preliminary work is present in all cases, since he has already attained mastery in the development of the meditation subject.

original: laddhiṃ vissajjetuṃ tejodhātuṃ samāpajjitvā tassa upari ākāse nisīdi. Tena vuttaṃ🔽“tejodhātuṃ…pe… tathāgataṃ disvā”ti. Aṭṭhivedhaṃ viyaṃ vijjhitabbo aṭṭhivedhī, yathā🔽aṭṭhiṃ vijjhitvā aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati, evaṃ vijjhitabboti attho. Ayaṃ pana
analyzed: laddhim vissajjetum tejodhātum samāpajjitvā tassa upari ākāse nisīdi tena vuttam  tejodhātuṃpe tathāgatam disvā ati aṭṭhi vedham viyam vijjhitabbaḥ aṭṭhi vedhī yathā  aṭṭhim vijjhitvā aṭṭhimiñjam āhacca tiṭṭhati evam vijjhitabbaḥ iti atthaḥ ayam pana
translated: It seems that this Brahmā had the view that there was no one equal to him in power and influence, as is stated in the passage beginning, “There is no ascetic or brahman who is equal to me in this world with its gods, men, and Asuras” . The Blessed One sat down in the air above him in order to refute his view. That is why it is said that he sat down “having attained a state of concentration characterized by the fire kasiṇa” .

original: aṭṭhivedhī viya aṭṭhivedhī, yathā so laddhiṃ vissajjeti, evaṃ paṭipajjitabboti attho.
analyzed: aṭṭhi vedhī viya aṭṭhi vedhī yathā saḥ laddhim vissajjeti evam paṭipajjitabbaḥ iti attho
translated: The “bone-piercer” is one who can pierce a bone as if it were a reed. The meaning is that he can pierce a bone and come to rest in the bone-marrow. But this “bone-piercer” is like the other one in that he can pierce the view of the Brahmā and come to rest in the marrow of his view.

original: Sesānanti mahākassapamahākappinaanuruddhattherānaṃ.
analyzed: sesānam ti mahākassapa mahākappina anuruddhattherānam
translated: “The rest”: the Elder Mahā Kassapa, the Elder Mahā Kappina, and the Elder Anuruddha.

original: Aññabrahmasarīravimānālaṅkārādīnaṃ pabhāti brahmānaṃ sarīrappabhā vimānappabhā alaṅkāravatthādīnaṃ
analyzed: añña brahma sarīra vimāna alaṅkāra ādīnam pabhāti brahmānam sarīra ppabhā vimāna ppabhā alaṅkāra vattha ādīnam
translated: The radiance of the bodies, mansions, ornaments, etc., of other Brahmas is outshone by the radiance of the body of this Brahma.

original: pabhāti imasmiṃ brahmaloke imā sabbā pabhā attano pabhassarabhāvena abhibhavantaṃ.🔽Natthi me sāti idāni me sā diṭṭhi natthi, “natthi so samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā, yo idha
analyzed: pabhā ati imasmin brahmaloke imā sabbā pabhā attanaḥ pabhassara bhāvena abhibhavantam  natthi me sā ati idāni me sā diṭṭhi natthi natthi so samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā yaḥ idha
translated: The radiance of all these in the Brahma world is outshone by the radiance of his own body.🔽“I have no such view now,” he says, “that there is no recluse or brahmin who comes here.” This is the conviction he has. Therefore he says, “Therein, friend, I was thus instructed … abandoned.”

original: āgaccheyyā”ti ayaṃ laddhi natthi. Tenāha “tatrāssa…pe… pahīnā”ti. Etthāti etasmiṃ
analyzed: āgaccheyya iti ayam laddhi natthi tena āha pahīnā iti ettha iti etasmin
translated: “Therein” means in that assembly.

original: samāgame. Yathā tassa brahmuno sabbaso diṭṭhigataṃ vimuccati dhammacakkhu uppajjati,
analyzed: samāgame yathā tassa brahmunaḥ sabbasas diṭṭhi gatam vimuccati dhamma cakkhu uppajjati
translated: As the Brahma’s entire view was liberated and the Dhamma eye arose,

original: evaṃ mahantaṃ dhammadesanaṃ desesi.
analyzed: evam mahantam dhamma desanam desesi
translated: he taught the great Dhamma discourse in this way.

original: “Ajjāpi te, āvuso”tiādinā vuttena tattakeneva. Sarūpena vuttāti paṭhamena pādena
analyzed: ajjā api te āvuso ti ādinā vuttena tattakena iva sarūpena vuttā ati paṭhamena pādena
translated: “Friend, even today” and so on is said in the same way as before. “In its own form” means that by the first line

original: catasso, dutiyena ekanti evaṃ pañca abhiññā sarūpena vuttā. Kasmā ettha dibbasotaṃ
analyzed: catasso dutiyena ekam ti evam pañca abhiññā sarūpena vuttā kasmai ettha dibba sotam
translated: four and by the second one, making five, the higher knowledges are said in their own form. Why is the divine ear

original: nāgatanti? Āha “tāsaṃ vasena āgatamevā”ti. Yena imā lokuttarā abhiññā adhigatā, na
analyzed: na āgatam iti āha tāsam vasena āgatam eva ati yena imāḥ lokuttarāḥ abhiññāḥ adhigatāḥ na
translated: “Come”: he said, “come by means of them.” For one who has attained these supramundane kinds of direct knowledge,

original: tassa dibbasotasampādanaṃ bhāriyaṃ paṭipakkhavigamena sukheneva ijjhanato.
analyzed: tassa dibba sota sampādanam bhāriyam paṭipakkha vigamena sukhena iva
translated: it is not difficult to accomplish the divine ear element, since it succeeds easily by the mere abandoning of its opposite.

original: Aññatarabrahmasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aññatara brahma sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Aññatarabrahma Sutta is finished.

original: 6. Brahmalokasuttavaṇṇanā🔽177. Paccekaṃ dvārabāhanti paccekaṃ dvārabāhaṃ. Pacceka-saddo cettha āvuttivasena
analyzed: brahmaloka sutta vaṇṇanā  paccekam dvāra bāhanti paccekam dvāra bāham pacceka saddo ca ittha āvutti vasena
translated: The Brahmaloka Sutta🔽“At each doorpost”: at each doorpost of the pavilion. The word “each” should be understood here as meaning “individually”;

original: veditabbo; “paccekaṃ pacceka”nti āha “ekeko ekeka”nti. Tesu hi eko paccekabrahmā🔽gandhakuṭiyā ekadvārabāhaṃ nissāya ṭhito, aparo aññaṃ. Paccekabrahmāti ca ekacārī🔽brahmā, na parisacārī brahmāti attho. Samiddhi nāma sagge sukhupakaraṇehi, brahmānañca
analyzed: veditabbaḥ paccekam paccekam ti āha ekekaḥ ekekam ti tesu hi ekaḥ paccekabrahmā  gandhakuṭiyāḥ eka dvāra bāham nissāya ṭhitaḥ aparaḥ aññam paccekabrahmā ati ca ekacārī  brahmā na parisacārī brahmā ati attho samiddhi nāma sagge sukha upakaraṇehi brahmānañca
translated: he said “each at each” meaning “one at one.” For one of those individual Brahmas stood at each doorpost of the pavilion,

original: jhānaṃ sukhupakaraṇanti jhānasukhena samiddhoti. Sampattiyā vepullappattatā brahmānañca
analyzed: jhānam sukha upakaraṇam ti jhāna sukhena samiddhaḥ ti sampattiyāḥ vepulla ppatta tā brahmānam ca
translated: and another at another. “Individual Brahmas” means Brahmas who go about singly, not Brahmas who go about in a crowd, is the meaning. “Samiddhi” is a name. “Brahma’s bliss” is the bliss of jhana. He is “endowed with” that bliss,🔽that is, he has reached the fullness of his prosperity.

original: abhiññāguṇehi vepullappattīti āha “phītoti abhiññāpupphehi supupphito”ti. Asahantoti
analyzed: abhiñā guṇehi vepulla ppatti iti āha phītaḥ iti abhiññā pupphehi su pupphitaḥ ti asahanto ti
translated: “Unable to bear” means

original: nasahanto narocento.
analyzed: nasahantaḥ narocentaḥ
translated: unable to endure, unable to tolerate.🔽“A hundred-footed”: the word “hundred” is “satam.”

original: Satapadanti satasaddo. Rūpavasenāti rūpasaddavasena, rūpasaddena saddhinti attho.
analyzed: sata padam ti sata saddaḥ rūpa vasena ati rūpa sadda vasena rūpa saddena saddhinti attho
translated: “In the sense of form”: in the sense of the word “form.” The meaning is: together with the word “form.”🔽“In the sense of such”: here too.

original: Tathā pantivasenāti etthāpi. Ekacceti eke migārī, tesaṃ byagghīnisārūpakānaṃ pañcasatānīti
analyzed: tathā pantivasena ati ettha api ekaccā iti eke migārī tesam byagghīnisārūpakānam pañca satāni iti
translated: “Some”: certain. “Five hundred”: the meaning is: five hundred of those deer, leopards, and bears.

original: attho. “Kassa aññassa upaṭṭhānaṃ gamissāmī”ti vimānasampattiyaṃ vimhayakkhiko ahaṅkāravasena
analyzed: attho kassa aññassa upaṭṭhānam gamissāmi iti vimāna sampattiyam vimhayakkhikaḥ ahaṅkāra vasena
translated: “Whose attendance shall I go to?” In the attainment of the divine mansion, he speaks out of conceit, as if he were the one who is asked.🔽“Quarrels”: quarrels are quarrels, disputes, and arguments.

original: vadati. Raṇanti nindanti etehīti raṇā, dosā. Virodhipaccayasannipāte vikāruppatti
analyzed: vadati raṇanti nindanti etehi iti raṇāḥ dosāḥ virodhi paccaya sannipāte vikāra uppatti
translated: “The arising of change”: the arising of the manifestation of change in the coming together of the conditions of opposition.

original: ruppanaṃ rūpassa pavedhananti āha “sītādīhi ca niccaṃ pavedhita”nti. Sumedho sundarapañño
analyzed: ruppanam rūpassa pavedhananti āha sīta ādīhi ca niccam pavedhitanti sumedhaḥ sundara pañño
translated: “The manifestation of form”: the manifestation of form. Therefore he says, “constantly manifested by cold and so on.”🔽“The wise one”: the one with beautiful wisdom.

original: so satthā rūpe na ramati, kiṃ pana mandapañño rūpe saraṇañca pavedhitañca apassanto ramasīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: so satthā rūpe na ramati kim pana manda paññaḥ rūpe saraṇañca pavedhitañca a passantaḥ ramasi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “The Teacher does not delight in form”: what is the intention? “How is it that you, with dull wisdom, not seeing the refuge and the manifestation in form, delight in it?”

original: Brahmalokasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: brahmaloka sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Brahmaloka Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Kokālikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kokālika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 7. The explanation of the Kokālika Sutta

original: 178. Pamāṇakarānaṃ rāgādīnaṃ abhāvato khīṇāsavo rāgādivasena na sakkā imaṃ pamātunti
analyzed: rāga ādīnam abhāvataḥ khīṇa asavaḥ rāga ādi vasena na sakkā imam pamātum ti
translated: Because he has no lust, etc., that can be measured, he cannot be measured by lust, etc.

original: appameyyo, appameyyāni vā cattāri ariyasaccāni vijjhitvā ṭhitattā pamitaṃ pameyyaṃ
analyzed: appameyyaḥ appameyyāni vā cattāri ariya saccāni vijjhitvā ṭhita ttā pamitam pameyyam
translated: He is immeasurable. Or alternatively, he is immeasurable because he has penetrated and found the four noble truths that are immeasurable.🔽There is no measuring of him. Hence it was said: “The lust-free bhikkhu, etc., shows up the immeasurable.”

original: tassa kato parimeyyo natthi. Tenāha “khīṇāsavo…pe… dīpetī”ti. Tanti khīṇāsavaṃ. Pametuṃ
analyzed: tassa kataḥ parimeyyaḥ na atthi tena āha khīṇāsava upe dīpeti iti khīṇāsavam pametum
translated: He: the lust-free bhikkhu.

original: randhagavesī hutvā vajjato paricchindituṃ. Yathāsabhāvato tassa minane nihīnapaññatāya avakujjapaññaṃ.
analyzed: randha gavesī hutvā vajjataḥ paricchinditum yathā sabhāvataḥ tassa minane nihīna pañña tāya avakujja paññam
translated: To measure: to seek out a flaw in him, to define him by a fault. He is of low understanding because he is unable to find out his true nature.

original: Kokālikasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kokālika sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Kokālika Sutta is ended.

original: 8. Katamodakatissasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: katamā udakatissa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Katamorakatissaka Sutta

original: 179. Kiṃ kusalagavesitāya “kiṃ kusalaṃ akusala”ntiādinā kinti suṇāti etāyāti kissa vā vuccati paññā.
analyzed: kim kusala gavesitāya kim kusalam akusalam ti ādinā kinti suṇāti etāya ati kissa vā vuccati paññā
translated: What is called wisdom is what hears the question “What is profitable? What is unprofitable? “ , etc., in order to seek out what is profitable.

original: Katamodakatissasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: katamodakatissa sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the Katamorakatissaka Sutta is ended.

original: 9. Turūbrahmasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Tundilovada Sutta

original: 180. Ābādho etassa atthīti ābādhiko. Anantarasutteti anāgatānantare sutte. Varākoti
analyzed: ābādhaḥ etassa atthi iti ābādhikaḥ anantara sutta iti anāgata anantare sutte varākaḥ ti
translated: One who has affliction is afflicted. In the next sutta: in the next following sutta. A contemptible man: a contemptible person.

original: anuggahavacanameva, na nippariyāyena vuttavacanaṃ. Piyasīlāti iminā etasmiṃ atthe🔽niruttinayena “pesalā”ti padasiddhīti dasseti. Kabarakkhīnīti byādhibalena paribhinnavaṇṇatāya🔽kabarabhūtāni akkhīni. Yattakanti yaṃ tvaṃ bhagavato vacanaṃ aññathā karosi, tattakaṃ🔽tayā aparaddhaṃ, tassa pamāṇaṃ natthīti attho. Yasmā anāgāmino nāma kāmacchandabyāpādā
analyzed: anuggaha vacanam eva na nippariyāyena vutta vacanam piya sīlā ti iminā etasmin atthe  nirutti nayena pesalā ati pada siddhi iti dasseti byādhi balena paribhinna vaṇṇa tāya  kabara bhūtāni akkhīni yattakanti yam tvam bhagavataḥ vacanam aññathā karosi tattakam  tayā aparaddham tassa pamāṇam natthi iti atthaḥ yasmai anāgāminaḥ nāma kāmacchanda byāpādā
translated: and it is a term of endearment, not a term used in the sense of the original meaning. ‘Dears of virtue’ : by this he shows that the word ‘good’ is established in the sense of this meaning by the method of derivation. ‘With eyes like a hare’s’ : because of the colour of their eyes being changed by the power of the disease, they are like a hare. ‘As much as’ : as much as you have made the Blessed One’s word otherwise, that much is your fault, there is no measure of it, is the meaning. Because non-returners are free from lust and malice

original: pahīnā honti, tvañca diṭṭho kāmacchandabyāpādavasena idhāgato, tasmā yāva te idaṃ🔽aparaddhanti ayamevettha attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Adiṭṭhippattoti appattadiṭṭhinimitto. Gilaviso viya visaṃ gilitvā ṭhito viya. Kuṭhārisadisā
analyzed: pahīnāḥ honti tvam ca diṭṭhaḥ kāma chanda byāpāda vasena idha āgataḥ tasmai yāva te idam  aparaddham ti ayam eva ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  a diṭṭhi ppatto ti appatta diṭṭhi nimittaḥ gilavisaḥ viya visam gilitvā ṭhitaḥ viya kuṭhāri sadisā
translated: and it is a term of endearment, not a statement of fact. ‘Well-disciplined’ : by this he shows that the word ‘well-behaved’ is grammatically correct in this sense. ‘With eyes sunken in their sockets’ : because of the discoloration due to the force of the disease, his eyes had become like dried-up ponds. ‘As much as’ : as much as you have misrepresented the Blessed One’s word, there is no measure to the extent of your transgression. ‘Because non-returners have abandoned sensual desire and ill will’ : since sensual desire and ill will have been abandoned by non-returners, and you have come here because of sensual desire and ill will, therefore ‘as much as’ should be understood to mean ‘to that extent.’

original: mūlapacchindanaṭṭhena. Uttamattheti arahatte. Khīṇāsavoti vadati sunakkhatto viya
analyzed: mūla pacchindana ṭṭhena uttama ttha iti arahatte khīṇa āsavaḥ ti vadati sunakkhatto viya
translated: ‘Not having attained the view’ : not having reached the sign of the view. ‘Like a poisoned dart’ : like a poison that has entered the body and remains there. ‘Like an axe’ : in the sense of cutting the root. ‘In the supreme goal’ : in arahatship. ‘As one who is free from cankers’ : as Sunakkhatta.

original: acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ. Yo aggasāvako viya pasaṃsitabbo khīṇāsavo, taṃ “dussīlo aya”nti
analyzed: acelam korakkhattiyam yaḥ aggasāvako viya pasaṃsitabbaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ tam dussīlaḥ ayanti
translated: He who should be praised as one whose cankers are destroyed, as if he were the chief disciple, and who is called “immoral”🔽or “a thief” by one who speaks thus, has the same result as the praise.

original: yo vā vadati. Samakova vipākoti pasaṃsiyanindā vijjamānaguṇaparidhaṃsanavasena pavattā
analyzed: yaḥ vā vadati pasaṃsiya nindā vijjamāna guṇa paridhaṃsana vasena pavattā
translated: Praise and blame, which occur by way of concealing and revealing good qualities that exist,

original: yāva mahāsāvajjatāya kaṭukataravipākā, tāva nindiyapasaṃsāpi mahāsāvajjatāya samavipākā
analyzed: yāva mahā sāvajja tāya kaṭukatara vipākā tāva nindiya pasaṃsā api mahā sāvajja tāya sama vipākā
translated: are of the same result as the blame, because they are equally reprehensible and have a bitterer ripening.

original: tattha avijjamānaguṇasamāropanena attano paresaṃ micchāpaṭipattihetubhāvato pasaṃsiyena
analyzed: tattha avijjamāna guṇa samāropanena paresam micchā paṭipatti hetu bhāvataḥ
translated: Herein, praise is the cause of one’s own and others’ wrong practice by superimposing on oneself or others good qualities that do not exist,🔽and it is the cause of making them equal by making them equal to one who is being blamed.

original: tassa samabhāvakaraṇato ca. Lokepi hi ayaṃ pure samaṇagārayho hoti, pageva duppaṭipannaduppaṭipannoti samaṃ karontīti.
analyzed: tassa sama bhāva karaṇato ca loke pi hi ayam pure samaṇa gārayhaḥ hoti pagā iva duppaṭipanna duppaṭipannaḥ ti samam karonti iti
translated: For in the world too one who is to be blamed is made equal to one who is well behaved, much more so one who is badly behaved.

original: Sakenāti attano sāpateyyena. Ayaṃ appamattako aparādho diṭṭhadhammikattā sappatikārattā ca tassa. Ayaṃ mahantataro kali katūpacitassa samparāyikattā appatikārattā ca.
analyzed: sakena ati attanaḥ sāpateyyena ayam appamattakaḥ aparādhaḥ diṭṭhadhammika ttā sappatikāra ttā ca tassa ayam mahantataraḥ kali katu upacitassa samparāyika ttā appatikāra ttā ca
translated: “With his own property” : this is a slight offence because it is visible and has a remedy. This is a great offence because it is not visible and has no remedy.

original: “Nirabbudo”ti gaṇanāviseso ekoti āha “nirabbudagaṇanāyā”ti, satasahassaṃ nirabbudānanti🔽attho. Nirabbudaparigaṇanaṃ pana heṭṭhā vuttameva. Yamariyagarahī nirayaṃ upetīti🔽ettha yathāvuttaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ pākatikena ariyūpavādinā vuttanti veditabbaṃ. “Aggasāvakānaṃ
analyzed: nirabbudaḥ ti gaṇanā visesaḥ ekaḥ ti āha nirabbuda gaṇanāya ati sata sahassam nirabbudānam ti  atthaḥ nirabbuda parigaṇanam pana heṭṭhā vuttam eva yam ariya garahī nirayam upeti iti  ettha yathāvuttam āyu ppamāṇam pākatikena ariyūpa vādinā vuttan ti veditabbam aggasāvakānam
translated: “Without a hundred thousand” : he says “without a hundred thousand” in order to show the difference in the number . The meaning is: “without a hundred thousand”. But the calculation without a hundred thousand has already been explained above.🔽“He who reviles the Noble Ones goes to hell” .🔽Herein, the measure of life stated as above should be understood as spoken by an ordinary person who reviles the Noble Ones.🔽“The two chief disciples

original: pana guṇamahantatāya tatopi ativiya mahantatarā evā”ti vadanti.🔽Turūbrahmasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽10. Kokālikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽181. Dve kokālikanāmakā bhikkhū, tato idha adhippetaṃ niddhāretvā dassetuṃ – “ko🔽ayaṃ kokāliko”ti? Pucchā. Suttassa aṭṭhuppattiṃ dassetuṃ – “kasmā ca upasaṅkamī”ti?🔽Pucchā. Ayaṃ kirātiādi yathākkamaṃ tāsaṃ vissajjanaṃ. Vivekavāsaṃ vasitukāmattā appicchatāya🔽ca mā kassaci…pe… vasiṃsu.
analyzed: guṇa mahantatāya tatas pi mahantatarāḥ eva ati vadanti 🔽turūbrahma sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽kokālika sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽dve kokālika nāmakā bhikkhū tatas idha adhippetam niddhāretvā dassetuṃ 🔽ayam kokāliko ti pucchā suttassa aṭṭhuppattim dassetuṃ kasmā ca upasaṅkamīti 🔽pucchā ayam kirāti ādi yathākkamam tāsam vissajjanam viveka vāsam vasitu kāma ttā appiccha tāya 🔽ca mā kassacipe vasiṃsu
