original: 5. Sānusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sānu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sānusutta

original: 239. Yakkhena gahito hotīti yakkhena anupaviṭṭho hoti. Tassa yakkhagahaṇassa kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: yakkhena gahitaḥ hoti iti yakkhena anupaviṭṭhaḥ hoti tassa yakkha gahaṇassa kāraṇam
translated: He was seized by a spirit: he was possessed by a spirit. The reason for his being seized by a spirit

original: mūlato pabhuti vitthārato dassetuṃ “so”tiādimāha. Tassa antimabhavikattā ādito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: mūlataḥ vitthārataḥ dassetum saḥ ti ādim āha tassa antimabhavika ttā āditaḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: is shown in detail from the beginning with the words “He” . Since he was in his last existence,🔽he fulfilled the training in the higher virtue well from the very beginning,

original: adhisīlasikkhāya sakkaccaṃ pūraṇanti dasseti “so pabbajitakālato”tiādinā. Paccāhāranti
analyzed: adhi sīla sikkhāya sakkaccam pūraṇanti dasseti so pabbajita kālato tiādinā paccāhāranti
translated: as shown by the words “from the time of his going forth” . The next day means the following day.

original: paṭikkhepaṃ. Imasmiṃ sarabhaññeti imasmiṃ mama dhammabhaṇane. Pattinti pattidānaṃ.🔽Piyā honti, tenāha bhagavā “ākaṅkheyya ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo
analyzed: paṭikkhepam imasmim sarabhañña iti imasmim mama dhamma bhaṇane pattim ti patti dānam  piyāḥ honti tena āha bhagavā ākaṅkheyya ce bhikkhave bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnam piyaḥ
translated: In this discourse on the Dhamma means in this discourse on the Dhamma by me. He gave me a boon means he gave me a boon.🔽He is dear and beloved to his companions in the holy life,

original: ca assaṃ manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā’ti, sīlesvevassa paripūrakārī”ti. Tathā cāha
analyzed: ca assam manāpaḥ ca garu ca bhāvanīyaḥ ca ati sīlesu eva assa paripūra kārī iti tathā ca āha
translated: and they in turn are dear and beloved to him. Therefore the Blessed One said: “If a bhikkhu should wish: ‘May I be dear and beloved to my companions in the holy life, respected and esteemed by them,’ let him perfect the virtues” . And he said:

original: “tasmiṃ sāmaṇere”tiādi.
analyzed: tasmin sāmaṇeḥ itiādi
translated: “To that novice monk” , etc.

original: Vuḍḍhimanvāyāti yobbanappattiyā aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ parivuḍḍhimāgamma. Kāmasambhogasamatthatāvasena
analyzed: vuḍḍhim anvāyāti yobbana ppattiyā aṅga paccaṅgānam parivuḍḍhim āgamma kāma sambhoga samattha tā vasena
translated: Having attained growth means having attained growth of the limbs and secondary limbs by attaining youthfulness. Having attained growth in the sense of being able to enjoy sensual pleasures,

original: paripakkindriyo. Anuyojetvāvāti vissajjetvāva, gihibhāve vā anuyojetvāva. “Pubbe🔽tuyhaṃ putto sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo lajjī kukkuccako sikkhākāmoti sambhāvito, idāni
analyzed: paripakka indriyaḥ anuyojetvā avāti vissajjetvā ava gihi bhāve vā anuyojetvā ava pubbe  tuyham putto sīlavā kalyāṇa dhammo lajjī kukkuccako sikkhā kāmo ti sambhāvitaḥ idāni
translated: and his faculties are mature. Having advised him: having dismissed him, having advised him about the life of a householder. “Formerly🔽you were a son who was virtuous, of good character, conscientious, scrupulous, and desirous of training. You were respected, now🔽

original: tato aññathā jāto”ti ghosanāvasena devatānaṃ antare māheva me lajjaṃ uppādeyya.🔽Pāṭihāriyapakkhañcāti cātuddasīpañcadasīaṭṭhamīnaṃ yathākkamaṃ ādito antato ādiantato
analyzed: tatas aññathā jātaḥ iti ghosanā vasena devatānam antare mā āha iva me lajjam uppādeyya  pāṭihāriya pakkham ca ati cātuddasī pañcadasī aṭṭhamīnam yathākkamam āditaḥ antataḥ ādi antataḥ
translated: He should send them away, i.e., dismiss them, or send them away from the state of a layman. “Formerly your son was virtuous, of good character, conscientious, scrupulous, and desirous of training. He was respected. Now he is different from that.” In this way, lest he should arouse shame in the gods by his proclamation,

original: ca pavesananikkhamanavasena uposathasīlassa paṭi paṭi abhimukhaṃ paccāvahitabbapakkhañca.
analyzed: ca pavesana nikkhamana vasena uposatha sīlassa paṭi paṭi abhimukham paccāvahitabba pakkham ca
translated: And the fortnight of miracles: the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth days of the half-month, respectively, are the beginning, the end, and the beginning and end of the observance-day precepts. The fortnight should be faced by turning toward it.

original: Terasiyāpīti paraṃ sattamīnavamīsupīti attho. Pavesabhūtañhi uposathasīlassa sattamīsu🔽samādinnaṃ sīlaṃ paṭipadaṃ, navamīsu nikkhamabhūtanti ācariyā. Porāṇaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: terasiyā api iti param sattamī navamīsu pi iti attho pavesa bhūtam hi uposatha sīlassa sattamīsu  samādinnam sīlam paṭipadam navamīsu ācariyā
translated: And the thirteenth: the meaning is, the seventh and the ninth days of the half-month as well. For the observance-day precepts are entered upon on the seventh days,🔽and the precepts taken up are the practice. On the ninth days they are exited from, say the teachers. But in the old commentaries it is said that they are stated by way of the return and the following.

original: pana paccuggamanānugamanapariyāyena vuttanti āha “manussā”tiādi. Aḍḍhamāsanti sakalakālapakkhaṃ.
analyzed: pana paccuggamana anugamana pariyāyena vuttanti āha manussa atiādi aḍḍha māsam ti sakala kālapakkham
translated: A half-month: the whole fortnight.

original: Evañhi vassavāsassa anugamanaṃ gataṃ hoti. Suṭṭhu samāgatanti suparisuddhaṃ sampannaṃ
analyzed: evam hi vassa vāsassa anugamanam gatam hoti suṭṭhu samāgatam ti su parisuddham sampannam
translated: Well-gathered: well-purified, well-completed,

original: katvā attano santānaṃ āgataṃ. Taṃ pana attano cittena samaṃ pakārehi yuttaṃ hotīti
analyzed: katvā attano santānam āgatam tam pana attano cittena samam pakārehi yuttam hoti iti
translated: having come to his own continuity. But that is associated with his own cognizance in the sense of being in association with the same object.🔽Therefore it is said, “Associated.” The best conduct by imitation of the Arahants.

original: āha “sampayutta”nti. Arahantānaṃ anukaraṇena seṭṭhacariyaṃ. “Na te hi yakkhā kīḷantī”ti
analyzed: āha sampayuttam ti arahantānam anukaraṇena seṭṭha cariyam na te hi yakkhāḥ kīḷanti iti
translated: “For they are not demons playing”

original: attano puttassa kāye adhimuccanaṃ attano kīḷanaṃ viya hotīti katvā āha.
analyzed: attano puttassa kāye adhimuccanam attano kīḷanam viya hoti iti katvā āha
translated: means that the obsession of his own son’s body is like his own playing.🔽The laywoman is virtuous by the virtue of the Uposatha as stated, but the novice is virtuous by his own novice’s virtue.

original: Upāsikā yathāvuttauposathasīlena sīlavatī, sāmaṇero pana attano sāmaṇerasīlena sīlavā. Uppatitvāti ākāse uppatitvā. Mokkho natthi dukkhāvahassa kammassa katūpacitattā.
analyzed: upāsikā yathā vutta uposatha sīlena sīlavatī sāmaṇeraḥ pana attano sāmaṇera sīlena sīlavā uppatitvā ati ākāse uppatitvā mokkhaḥ natthi dukkha āvahassa kammassa kata upacita ttā
translated: Having flown up: having flown up in the air. There is no escape because of the action that has been done and stored up.

original: Duvidhepi kāmeti vatthukāmakilesakāme. Kilesakāmaṃ pariccajanto eva hi vatthukāme
analyzed: duvidhe api kāmeti vatthu kāma kilesa kāme kilesa kāmam pariccajantaḥ eva hi vatthu kāme
translated: In both kinds of sensual desires: sensual desires as objects and sensual desires as defilements. For it is when he abandons sensual desires as defilements that he abandons sensual desires as objects.

original: pariccajati nāma. Vibbhamanavasena āgacchati bhikkhāya āhiṇḍanādipabbajitakiccato.
analyzed: pariccajati nāma vibbhamana vasena āgacchati bhikkhāya āhiṇḍana ādi pabbajita kiccato
translated: He comes by the way of vibration, because of the duties of one gone forth such as wandering for alms.

original: Uppabbajitvā vigatasīlassa jīvato ānāpānamattena jīvantopi so matakova. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: uppabbajitvā vigata sīlassa jīvataḥ āna apāna mattena jīvantaḥ pi so matakaḥ va vuttam ha etam
translated: and after going forth, he lives with his virtue decayed, even if he lives on alms given in faith, he is as good as dead. For this is said:

original: “maraṇañhetaṃ, sunakkhatta, ariyassa vinaye, yo sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattatī”ti.
analyzed: maraṇam ha etam sunakkhatta ariyassa vinaye yaḥ sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya avattati iti
translated: “Sunakkhatta, in the Noble One’s Discipline this is death, namely, the lapse of one who has gone forth and returns to the lower life after giving up the training.”

original: Uṇhaṭṭhenāti sapariḷāhaṭṭhena. Abhidhāvathāti abhidhāvatīti imasmiṃ abhidhāvanakicce
analyzed: uṇha aṭṭhena ati sa pariḷāha aṭṭhena abhidhāvatha ati abhidhāvati iti imasmim abhidhāvana kicce
translated: “With a fever” means with a fever of remorse. “Run back” means run back to the lay state.

original: bhaddaṃ te hotūti vatvā gihibhāvāya abhidhāvatha. Nīharitvāti nikkhāmetvā. Ekādasahi🔽aggīhi ādittattā mahāḍāhasadise. Sallakkhetvāti gihibhāve ādīnavaṃ, pabbajjāya ānisaṃsañca
analyzed: bhaddam te hotu uti vatvā gihi bhāvāya abhidhāvatha nīharitvā ati nikkhāmetvā ekādasahi  aggīhi āditta ttā mahā ḍāha sadise sallakkhetvā ati gihi bhāve ādīnavam pabbajjāya ānisaṃsam ca
translated: “Good luck to you” means “May you be fortunate.” “Take him away” means “Remove him.”🔽because of the eleven fires. “Consider” means consider the danger in the lay life and the benefits in the life of a bhikkhu.

original: sallakkhetvā. Hirottappaṃ paṭilabhitvā “mama uppabbajitukāmataṃ sabrahmacārino jānissantī”ti.
analyzed: sallakkhetvā hirottappam paṭilabhitvā mama uppabbajitu kāma tam sabrahmacārinaḥ jānissanti iti
translated: and after obtaining shame and fear of wrongdoing, “My companions in the life of purity will know that I want to go forth.”

original: Catunnaṃ parisānaṃ cittasaṅkhobhavasena sakalajambudīpaṃ khobhetvā.
analyzed: catunnam parisānam citta saṅkhobha vasena sakala jambudīpam khobhetvā
translated: and he shook the whole of India, with its four principal continents and its eight subsidiary continents, by disturbing the minds of the four assemblies.

original: Sānusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sānu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sānusutta is finished.

original: 6. Piyaṅkarasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: piyaṅkara sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Piyaṅkarasutta🔽is finished.

original: 240. Paccanteti pariyante. Pāṭiyekkanti saṅgītikāle visuṃ. Yamakavaggādikā brāhmaṇavaggapariyosānā
analyzed: paccanta iti pariyante pāṭiyekkam ti saṅgīti kāle visum yamaka vagga ādikā brāhmaṇa vagga pariyosānā
translated: The twenty-six sections beginning with the Twin Verses and ending with the Brahmajāla Sutta🔽are called the twenty-six sections. The text: the text of the sutta.

original: chabbīsati vaggā etissāti chabbīsativaggā, tantīti pāḷi. Uccārapassāvādi evarūpaṃ
analyzed: chabbīsati vaggā etissa ati chabbīsati vaggā tantī iti uccāra passāva ādi evarūpam
translated: Bad food: such food as vomiting, etc.,

original: dubbhojanaṃ, “asucijegucchabhāvena duṭṭhu bhojana”nti katvā, dubbhojanaggahaṇena🔽vā vantagabbhamalādīni atidisati. Chaviādīni chetvāti chaviādīni ativijjha ativiya
analyzed: dubbhojanam asuci jeguccha bhāvena duṭṭhu bhojanan ti katvā dubbhojana ggahaṇena  vā vanta gabbha mala ādīni atidisati chavi ādīni chetvā ati chavi ādīni ativijjha
translated: is called “bad food” because it is bad owing to its repulsiveness and uncleanness. Or the mention of “bad food”🔽also includes the contents of the stomach, the womb’s discharge, and so on.🔽Having cut through the skin, etc.: having pierced through the skin, etc.,

original: pavisitvā. Aṭṭhimiñjaṃ āhacca aṭṭhāsi pītisamuṭṭhānauḷāroḷārarūpappavattiyā. Tenāha
analyzed: pavisitvā aṭṭhimiñjam āhacca aṭṭhāsi pīti samuṭṭhāna oḷāra uḷāra rūpa ppavattiyā tena āha
translated: and penetrated them thoroughly, it stood touching the bone and marrow, by the occurrence of the material instances of rapture. Hence it is said:

original: “hadayaṅgamanīyo hutvā”ti.
analyzed: hadayaṅgamanīyaḥ hutvā ati
translated: “It went to the heart.”

original: Dhammatāya samādiṇṇanti kassaci santike aggahetvā sayameva tasmiṃ khaṇe saṃyatā homāti
analyzed: dhammatāya samādiṇṇanti kassaci santike aggahetvā sayam eva tasmin khaṇe saṃyatāḥ homa ati
translated: By nature: they were self-controlled at that moment without having taken it from anyone else.

original: yathāsaṃyatā. Tatiyapadenāti “sikkhema susīlya”nti iminā padena. Sesāti vuttāvasesā.
analyzed: yathā saṃyatā tatiya padena ati sikkhema su sīlyanti iminā padena sesā ati vuttā avasesā
translated: Thus they were self-controlled. By the third line: by the line “You are well trained, well disciplined.” The rest: the rest of what was said.

original: Tisso adinnādānamicchācārasurāpānaviratiyo. Gahitā gobalībaddañāyena. Chātakaṃ dubbhikkhañca
analyzed: tissaḥ adinnādāna micchācāra surā pāna viratiyaḥ gahitāḥ go balī baddañāyena chātakam dubbhikkham ca
translated: The three abstinences from taking what is not given, from sexual misconduct, and from liquor, wine, and besotting drink are included by the rule of the ox and the rope.🔽In the phrase “in the famine of the seven-leaf tree” (Chātaka-dubbukkha), the word “famine” (dubbukkha) is a famine of hunger (jighacchā-dubbukkha).

original: etthāti chātakadubbhikkhā, jighacchādubbhikkhābahulāyāti attho. Pisācayakkhayoniyāti
analyzed: ettha ati chātaka dubbhikkhā jighacchā dubbhikkhā bahulāya ati attho pisāca yakkha yoniyā ti
translated: The meaning is that there was much hunger and famine. In the phrase “in the realm of the ghosts and the realm of the yakkhas” (pisāca-yakkha-yoni),

original: pettivisayasadisayakkhayoniyā api nāma muccemāti yojanā.
analyzed: api nāma muccema ati yojanā
translated: the realm of the yakkhas is similar to the realm of the ghosts. The construction is: “I will be released even from there.”

original: Piyaṅkarasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: piyaṅkara sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Piyaṅkara Sutta is finished.

original: 7. Punabbasusuttavaṇṇanā🔽241. Vasanaṭṭhānaggahaṇena rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānādayo saṅgaṇhāti. Dvādasahatthamattameva
analyzed: punabbasu sutta vaṇṇanā  vasana ṭṭhāna ggahaṇena ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāna ādayo saṅgaṇhāti dvādasa hattha mattam eva
translated: The commentary on the Punabbasu Sutta🔽By mentioning the place of residence, he includes the night quarters, the day quarters, and so on. He takes only twelve handspans,

original: gaṇhāti pakatisañcaraṇūpacāramattabyāpanato. Yathāparisanti parisānurūpaṃ, yattha
analyzed: gaṇhāti pakati sañcaraṇa upacāra matta byāpanataḥ yathā parisanti parisā anurūpam
translated: because the space is just enough for the normal movement of the body. As much as the assembly: in accordance with the assembly,

original: yattha parisā tiṭṭhati, taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ gacchati parisapariyantikattā. Satthu mukhavikārābhāvato
analyzed: yattha parisā tiṭṭhati tam tam ṭhānam gacchati parisa pariyantika ttā satthu mukha vikāra abhāvato
translated: he goes to that place where the assembly is, because the assembly is the limit. Since there is no change in the face of the Teacher,

original: pavesānuññaṃ sallakkhentī “nūna ayaṃ katādhikārā bhavissatī”ti anumānasiddhaṃ upanissayaṃ
analyzed: sallakkhentī nūna ayam kata adhikārā bhavissati iti anumāna siddham upanissayam
translated: he considers the permission to enter and infers: “Surely she must have finished her duties.”

original: disvā. Ekībhāvagamanenāti hatthapāsūpagamanena parisāya missībhāvappattiyā. Puttakāti
analyzed: disvā ekībhāva gamanena ati hattha pāsu upagamanena parisāya missībhāva ppattiyā puttaka ati
translated: and seeing them, he went to them, and they became mixed up with the assembly by going to the same place as the hand.

original: puttaputtiyo. Anukampāyañhi ka-saddo.
analyzed: putta puttiyaḥ anukampāyan hi ka saddaḥ
translated: Sons and daughters: the word “and” is used out of compassion.

original: Nibbānārammaṇena ariyamaggena muñciyamānā ganthā “nibbānaṃ āgamma pamuccantī”ti vuttā.
analyzed: nibbāna ārammaṇena ariya maggena muñciyamānāḥ ganthāḥ nibbānam āgamma pamuccanti iti vuttā
translated: The bonds are said to be “released by reaching Nibbāna” because they are being released by the noble path, which has Nibbāna as its object.

original: Velātikkantāti pamāṇato paricchindituṃ na sakkāti āha “pamāṇātikkantā”ti. Piyāyanāti
analyzed: velā atikkantā iti pamāṇataḥ paricchinditum na sakkā iti āha pamāṇa atikkantā iti piyāyanā iti
translated: Having gone beyond the limit: he says “having gone beyond the measure” because they cannot be limited by measure.🔽Seeking what is dear:

original: āsīsanā. Āsīsanaṃ pemavasena pemavatthuno esanā patthanāva hotīti āha “magganā patthanā”ti.
analyzed: āsīsanā āsīsanam pema vasena pema vatthuno esanā patthanā ava hoti iti āha magganā patthanā ti
translated: seeking is the seeking of a loved object out of love. He says “seeking, longing” because longing is the mere wish for a loved object.🔽From that: from the loved sons and so on.

original: Tatoti piyaputtādito. Pāṇīnanti sāmiatthe puthuvacanaṃ dukkhasaddāpekkhaṃ. Ke mocetīti
analyzed: tatas ti piya putta āditaḥ pāṇīnam ti sāmi atthe puthuvacanam dukkha sadda apekkham ke moceti iti
translated: Hands: the word “hands” is a plural in the sense of ownership, expecting the word “pain.” Who will release?

original: mocanakiriyāya kammaṃ pucchati? Ibharo pana atthavasena vibhattivipariṇāmoti “pāṇineti
analyzed: mocana kiriyāya kammam pucchati ibharaḥ pana attha vasena vibhatti vipariṇāmo ti pāṇinā iti
translated: He asks about the action in the act of releasing. But the word “hands” is a change of case for the sake of meaning, he says.

original: āharitvā vattabba”nti āha. Abhisambudhanti abhisambudhanto. Tenāha “abhisambuddho”ti.
analyzed: āharitvā vattabbanti āha abhisambudhanti abhisambudhanto tena āha abhisambuddhaḥ iti
translated: Having fully awakened: he says “fully awakened” because he is fully awakening.

original: Saddhammassāti upayogatthe sāmivacananti āha “saddhammameva ajānitvā”ti.
analyzed: saddhammassa ati upayoga atthe sāmi vacanam iti āha saddhammam eva a jānitvā iti
translated: ‘The True Idea’ is the Master, in the sense of what is used, thus he said ‘without knowing the True Idea’ .

original: Puttassa anumodanaṃ karontīti puttassa paṭipattianumodanaṃ karontī. Uggatāti ettha🔽kalale vaṭṭadukkhe nimujjamānā tato sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃ asakkonti ajja buddhānubhāvena
analyzed: puttassa anumodanam karonti iti puttassa paṭipatti anumodanam karontī uggatā ati ettha  kalale vaṭṭa dukkhe nimujjamānā tatas sīsam ukkhipitum asakkonti ajja buddha anubhāvena
translated: ‘She was rejoicing in her son’s approval’: she was rejoicing in her son’s approval of his practice. ‘Uggata’ :

original: paññāsīsaṃ ukkhipitā uggatā. Puna vinipātābhāvato sammadeva uggatattā samuggatā.🔽Tathābhūtā sāsanepi uggatā samuggatā jātā. Catusaccapaṭivedhabhāvanti catusaccapaṭivedhassa
analyzed: paññāsīsam ukkhipitā uggatā puna vinipāta abhāvato sammat eva uggata ttā samuggatā  tathābhūtā sāsane pi uggatā samuggatā jātā catu acca paṭivedha bhāvanti catu acca paṭivedhassa
translated: she was submerged in the suffering of the round of rebirths in the kalala stage, and today she has raised her head through the Blessed One’s influence, thus she is ‘Uggata’. And because she has raised her head properly, without falling back again, she is ‘Samuggatā’.🔽And she has raised her head and raised her head properly in the Dispensation too. ‘The existence of the penetration of the four truths’ :

original: atthibhāvaṃ. Kaṇḍukacchuādīti ādi-saddena jegucchaasātādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Dibbasampattiṃ
analyzed: atthi bhāvam kaṇḍu kacchu ādi iti ādi saddena jeguccha asāta ādim saṅgaṇhāti dibba sampattim
translated: the existence of the penetration of the four truths. ‘Itch, scab, and so on’ : the word ‘and so on’ includes loathsomeness, disagreeableness, and so on. ‘Divine attainments’ :

original: paṭilabhati pavattiyaṃ sampattidāyino kammassa katokāsattā. Tuṇhī uttarike hohīti
analyzed: paṭilabhati pavattiyam sampatti dāyino kammassa kata ukāsattā tuṇhī uttarike hohi iti
translated: he obtains divine attainments because there is an opportunity for the occurrence of the profitable action that gives the attainment of the divine world. ‘Be silent, Uttara’ :

original: mātu-vacanaṃ sampaṭicchitvā tassa visesādhigamassa avibandhakaraṇasammāpayogena yathāladdhavisesāya
analyzed: mātu vacanam sampaṭicchitvā tassa visesa adhigamassa a vibandha karaṇa sammā apayogena yathā laddha visesāya
translated: having agreed with her mother’s words, he was silent by rightly applying himself to the non-obstruction of the special attainment of that , and by the special attainment that he had already got.

original: mātuyā vasena yasmā dhītā diṭṭhadhammikasampattilābhī, tasmā vuttaṃ “mātu ānubhāvenevā”ti.
analyzed: mātuyā vasena yasmai dhītā diṭṭhadhammika sampatti lābhī tasmai vuttam mātu ānubhāvena iva ati
translated: Since the daughter had attained the excellence of the visible world through the mother, it is said: “through the mother’s influence alone.”

original: Punabbasusuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: punabbasu sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Punabbasu Sutta is finished.

original: 8. Sudattasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sudatta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sudatta Sutta

original: 242. Karaṇīyenāti ettha karaṇīyanti vāṇijjakammaṃ adhippetanti taṃ vivaranto “anāthapiṇḍiko🔽cā”tiādimāha. Vikkīyatīti vikkayaṃ gacchati. Tatheva karotīti yathā rājagahaseṭṭhinā
analyzed: karaṇīyena ati ettha karaṇīyanti vāṇijja kammam adhippetanti tam vivarantaḥ anāthapiṇḍiko  ca ati ādim āha vikkīyati iti vikkayam gacchati tathā iva karoti iti yathā rājagahaseṭṭhinā
translated: Here, “business” refers to the trade. Explaining that, he says: “Anāthapiṇḍika

original: sāvatthiṃ gantvā kataṃ, tatheva rājagahaṃ gantvā karoti. Svāyanti anāthapiṇḍiko.
analyzed: sāvatthim gantvā katam tathā iva rājagaham gantvā karoti anāthapiṇḍikaḥ
translated: went to Sāvatthī.” “Is sold” means it is sold. “He did just that” means just as he did it after going to Sāvatthī, he did it after going to Rājagaha. “They are his” means they are Anāthapiṇḍika’s.

original: Taṃ divasanti yaṃ divasaṃ anāthapiṇḍiko, gahapati, rājagahasamīpaṃ upagato, taṃ divasaṃ.
analyzed: tam yam divasam anāthapiṇḍikaḥ gahapatiḥ rājagaha samīpam tam divasam
translated: “That day” means the day on which the householder Anāthapiṇḍika approached Rājagaha.

original: Paṇṇanti sāsanaṃ. Na suṇīti asuṇanto “paṇṇaṃ na suṇī”ti vutto. Dhammagāravena hi
analyzed: paṇṇanti sāsanam na suṇīti a suṇantaḥ paṇṇam na suṇīti vuttaḥ dhamma gāravena hi
translated: “A message” means a message. “He did not hear” means he did not hear the message. “He did not hear the message” is said. For out of respect for the Dhamma,

original: so seṭṭhi aññaṃ kiccaṃ tiṇāyapi na maññi. Tenāha “dhammassavanatthāyā”tiādi. Dārakarūpānanti
analyzed: so seṭṭhi aññam kiccam na maññi tena āha dhamma ssavana tthāya ati ādi
translated: that merchant did not consider any other task even as grass. Therefore he says: “for the sake of hearing the Dhamma,” and so on. “The form of a child” means

original: dārakānaṃ. Anatthantarakaro hi rūpa-saddo yathā “gorūpāna”nti. Pañcavaṇṇanti khuddikādibhedaṃ🔽pañcappakāraṃ pītiṃ paṭilabhi. Anukkamena hi tā etassa sambhavanti. “Sīsena uṭṭhāya…pe…
analyzed: dārakānam anattha antara karaḥ hi rūpa saddaḥ yathā khuddika ādi bhedam  pañca ppakāram pītim anukkamena hi tāḥ etassa sambhavanti sīsena
translated: for the children. For the sound of form is not harmful, as in the case of the form of cows.🔽He obtained the fivefold happiness, which is of five kinds, beginning with the minor kind.

original: gacchatī”ti padaṃ pītisamuṭṭhānarūpavasena lakkhetvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: gacchati iti padam pīti samuṭṭhāna rūpa vasena lakkhetvā vuttam
translated: For these arise in him in due order. The words “he rose up with his head, … and he went” are said by way of the material form originated by happiness.

original: Sivathikāya vasatīti sivathikāya samīpe vasati. Susānassāsannaṭṭhāne hi so vihāro.
analyzed: sivathikāya vasati iti sivathikāya samīpe vasati susānassa āsanna ṭhāne hi so vihāro
translated: He lived near the charnel ground: he lived near the charnel ground. For that dwelling was near the charnel ground.

original: Athassāti athassa anāthapiṇḍikassa “akālo…pe… upasaṅkamissāmī”ti etaṃ ahosi. Buddhagatāya
analyzed: athassa ati athassa anāthapiṇḍikassa a kāla ope upasaṅkamissāmi iti etam ahosi buddha gatāya
translated: Then: then, to Anathapindika, it occurred: “It is not the right time to visit the Lord … I will go to visit him tomorrow.”

original: satiyāti aññaṃ kiñci acintetvā buddhagatāya eva satiyā sayanavaragato nipajji. Tena
analyzed: satiyā iti aññam kiñci a cintetvā buddha gatāya eva satiyā sayana vara gataḥ nipajji tena
translated: With mindfulness of the Buddha: without thinking of anything else, he went to bed with mindfulness of the Buddha only.

original: vuttaṃ “taṃ divasa”ntiādi.
analyzed: vuttam tam divasa nti ādi
translated: Therefore it was said: “On that day” and so on.

original: Balavappasādoti buddhārammaṇā balavatī saddhā. Pītiālokoti purimabuddhesu cirakālaṃ
analyzed: balava pasādaḥ ti buddha ārammaṇā balavatī saddhā pīti ālokā iti purima buddhesu cira kālam
translated: Strong confidence: strong faith with the Enlightened One as object. The light of happiness: the happiness of one who has long had acquaintance with the Enlightened Ones of the past, which is strong.

original: paricayaṃ gatassa balavato pasādassa vasena “buddho”ti nāmaṃ savanamattena uppannāya
analyzed: paricayam gatassa balavato pasādassa vasena buddhaḥ iti nāmam savana mattena uppannāya
translated: By the mere hearing of the name “Enlightened One” there arose in him

original: uḷārāya pītiyā samuṭṭhāpito vipassanobhāsasadiso sātisayo āloko hoti cittapaccayautusamuṭṭhāno.
analyzed: uḷārāya pītiyā samuṭṭhāpitaḥ vipassanā bhāsa sadiso sa atisayaḥ ālokaḥ hoti citta paccaya otu samuṭṭhāno
translated: The light is of the kind called “arisen with consciousness as its condition” and is like the radiance of insight arisen with exalted happiness.

original: Tenāha “sabbatamaṃ vigacchī”tiādi. “Devatā hi katā”tipi vadanti, purimo evettha yutto.
analyzed: tena āha sabbatamam vigacchi itiādi devatāḥ hi katā atipi vadanti purimaḥ evā ittha yuttaḥ
translated: Hence it is said, “The darkness disappeared” , etc. Some say that it was deities that did this, but the former explanation is the right one here.

original: Amanussāti adhigatavisesā devatā. Tā hi seṭṭhissa sampattiṃ paccakkhato passiṃsu.
analyzed: amanussā ati adhigata visesā devatā tāḥ hi seṭṭhissa sampattim paccakkhataḥ passiṃsu
translated: “Non-human beings” are deities who have attained distinction. For they saw the treasurer’s prosperity with their own eyes.

original: Tenāha “ayaṃ mahāseṭṭhī”tiādi. Allasarīranti tāvadeva chaḍḍitaṃ acchinnaṃ vā kaḷevaraṃ.
analyzed: tena āha ayam mahā seṭṭhī iti ādi tāvat eva chaḍḍitam acchinnam vā kaḷevaram
translated: Hence it is said, “This great treasurer” , etc. A “fresh corpse” is a dead body that has been thrown away or left unburied for just one day.

original: Aparampīti mataṃ kuthitakuṇapaṃ. Parikiriṃsūti samantato osaritā ahesuṃ. Āloko antaradhāyipītivegassa
analyzed: aparam pi iti matam kuthita kuṇapam parikiriṃsu iti samantataḥ osaritāḥ ahesuṃ ālokaḥ antaradhāyi pīti vegassa
translated: “Another” is a dead body that is swollen and festering. “They surrounded it” : they came right up to it. “The light disappeared” because the force of the light

original: mandabhāvena taṃsamuṭṭhānarūpānaṃ dubbalabhāvato.🔽Imināvāti adhikārena sahassapadena eva sambandhitabbāni. Padaṃ vītiharati etthāti
analyzed: manda bhāvena dubbala bhāvataḥ  iminā ava ati adhikārena sahassa padena eva sambandhitabbāni padam vītiharati ettha iti
translated: was weakened by the weakness of the materiality originated by the corpses.

original: padavītihāro, padavītihāraṭṭhānaṃ. Samagamaneti dutavilambitaṃ akatvā samagamane.
analyzed: padavī tihāro padavī tihāra ṭṭhānam sama gamana iti a katvā sama gamane
translated: “For this reason” : for this reason of the thousand verses. “A place for a step” : a place for a step is a place where a step is taken. “In meeting” : without delay.

original: Tatoti tesu soḷasabhāgesu. Eko koṭṭhāsoti yathāvuttaṃ padavītihārapadesaṃ soḷasadhā
analyzed: tatas ti tesu soḷasa bhāgesu eko koṭṭhāso ti yathāvuttam padavī tihāra padesam soḷasadhā
translated: ‘Then’: among those sixteen parts. ‘One part’: the place of a step as described, divided into sixteen.

original: bhinnassa eko bhāgo. Pavattacetanāti yathāvuttakalāsaṅkhātassa padesassa laṅghanadhāvanapavattacetanā.🔽Padaṃ vā vītiharati etenāti padavītihāro, tathāpavattā kusalacetanā. “Tassā phalaṃ
analyzed: bhinnassa ekaḥ bhāgaḥ pavatta cetanā ati yathā vutta kalā saṅkhātassa padesassa laṅghana dhāvana pavatta cetanā  padam vā vītiharati etena ati padavītihāraḥ tathā pavattā kusala cetanā tassā phalam
translated: ‘From that’: from those sixteen parts. ‘One part’: one of the sixteen parts into which the area of the step is divided as already described. ‘The volition that occurs’: the volition that occurs in the act of jumping over and running across the area described as the ‘basin’.

original: soḷasadhā katvā”ti vadanti. Patiṭṭhahantassa vasena gahitanti yojanā. Vivaṭṭanissitāya
analyzed: soḷasadhā katvā iti vadanti patiṭṭhahantassa vasena gahitanti yojanā vivaṭṭa nissitāya
translated: ‘He crosses the step with it’: the profitable volition that occurs in that way. ‘Having divided the fruit of that into sixteen parts’—so they say. The construction is: ‘in the sense of being taken as the basis for one who is established’.

original: eva ratanattayapūjāya dhammassavanassa sikkhāpadasamādānassa saraṇagamanassa ca atthāya🔽gacchatopi vasena vaṭṭati. Paṭhamaṃ vuttagamanaṃ lokuttaravisesādhigamassa ekantikaṃ,
analyzed: eva ratanattaya pūjāya dhamma ssavanassa sikkhāpada samādānassa saraṇa gamanassa ca atthāya  gacchataḥ api vasena vaṭṭati paṭhamam vutta gamanam lokuttara visesa adhigamassa ekantikam
translated: It is ‘applicable’ in the sense of going for the purpose of paying homage to the Three Jewels, listening to the Dhamma, undertaking the training precepts, and going for refuge, which are dependent on the turning round .

original: dutiyaṃ anekantikanti “vaṭṭatiyevā”ti sāsaṅkavacanaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam anekantikanti vaṭṭatiyā iva iti sa āsaṅka vacanam
translated: The first kind of going mentioned is certain to lead to the attainment of the supramundane distinction; the second is not certain. So the statement ‘it is applicable’ is made with reservation.

original: Soti anāthapiṇḍiko seṭṭhi. Anuyuttāti anugāmino sahāyā. Teva sandhāya vadati. “Sivako
analyzed: so ti anāthapiṇḍiko seṭṭhi anuyuttā ati anugāmino sahāyā sandhāya vadati sivako
translated: ‘So’: the householder Anāthapiṇḍika. ‘Attendants’: companions who follow after. He said this referring to them.

original: amanusso”ti apare. Na kevalaṃ “anuyuttāpi me atthi, kasmā bhāyāmī”ti evaṃ sūro ahosi?
analyzed: amanussaḥ ti apare na kevalam anuyuttā api me atthi kasmai bhāyāmi iti evam sūraḥ ahosi
translated: Not only was he brave in the sense that he thought, “I have devoted myself to the Buddha, why should I be afraid?”

original: Atha kho buddhagatāya tikkhavisadasabhāvena sabbaṃ parissayaṃ madditvāpi agamāsīti
analyzed: atha kho buddha gatāya tikkha visadasa bhāvena sabbam parissayam madditvā api agamāsi iti
translated: but he went forward after crushing all fear by means of the sharp, clear, and penetrating nature of his faith in the Buddha.

original: dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pakkhandanalakkhaṇā hi saddhā, tāya yuttako sappurisopi
analyzed: dassetum apica itiādi vuttam pakkhandana lakkhaṇā hi saddhā tāya yuttakaḥ sappurisaḥ api
translated: To show this, the commentator says, “Moreover,” etc. For faith has the characteristic of confidence; and a person who is endowed with it

original: saddhammaguṇavasena sabbaṃ parissayaṃ madditvā pakkhandatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Sabbakāmasamiddhatā pariccāgasīlatā uḷārajjhāsayatā paradukkhāpanayakāmatā paresaṃ
analyzed: saddhamma guṇa vasena sabbam parissayam madditvā pakkhandati iti daṭṭhabbam  sabba kāma samiddha tā pariccāga sīla tā uḷāra ajjhāsaya tā para dukkha apanaya kāma tā paresam
translated: goes forward after crushing all fear by means of the special qualities of the true Dhamma.🔽The special qualities referred to are such as the following: the perfection of all wishes, the virtue of renunciation, the high aspiration, the desire to remove the suffering of others,

original: hitesitā parasampattipamodanāti evamādīnaṃ mahāguṇānaṃ vasena niccakālaṃ anāthānaṃ
analyzed: evamādīnam mahā guṇānam vasena niccakālam anāthānam
translated: the will to benefit others, and the sympathetic joy over the success of others.🔽Because he was always giving alms to those who had no one to look after them by reason of these special qualities, he came to be called Anāthapiṇḍika, “Alms-food for the helpless.”

original: piṇḍadāyakattā “anāthapiṇḍiko”ti evaṃ uppannaṃ nāmaṃ. Evamāhāti “ehi sudattā”ti evaṃ āha.🔽Kilesaparinibbānenāti sabbaso rāgādikilesavūpasamena. Kilesavūpasamanti sabbaso sabbesaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍa dāyaka ttā anāthapiṇḍiko ti evam uppannam nāmam evam āha ati ehi sudattā iti evam āha 🔽kilesa parinibbānena ati sabbasas rāga ādi kilesa vūpasamena kilesa vūpasamanti sabbasas sabbesam
translated: “Come, Sudatta,” he said.

original: kilesānaṃ vūpasamaṃ aggamaggena patvā. Anupubbikathanti dānādikathaṃ. Sā hi anupubbena
analyzed: kilesānam vūpasamam agga maggena patvā anupubbi katham ti dāna ādi katham sā hi anupubbena
translated: and he attained the stilling of all the defilements by the supreme path.🔽The talk in due order: the talk on giving, etc. For that is called “talk in due order” because it should be given in due order. And it is said with reference to that:

original: kathetabbattā “anupubbikathā”ti vuccati. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “atha kho bhagavā🔽anupubbiṃ kathaṃ kathesi. Seyyathidaṃ – dānakathaṃ sīlakathaṃ saggakathaṃ kāmānaṃ
analyzed: kathetabba ttā anupubbi kathā iti vuccati tam sandhāya vuttam atha kho bhagavā  anupubbim katham kathesi seyyathidam dāna katham sīla katham sagga katham kāmānam
translated: “Then the Exalted One gave him talk in due order,

original: ādīnavaṃ okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesī”ti. Matthaketi anupubbikathāya🔽upari parato. Cattāri saccāni pakāsesīti yathā mahāseṭṭhi sahassanayapaṭimaṇḍite
analyzed: ādīnavam okāram saṃkilesam nekkhamme ānisaṃsam pakāsesi iti matthake iti anupubbi kathāya  upari paratas cattāri saccāni pakāsesi iti yathā mahāseṭṭhi sahassanayapaṭimaṇḍite
translated: that is to say, talk on giving, talk on virtue, talk on heaven, and he explained the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures and the blessings of renunciation” .🔽At the end: after the talk in due order.

original: sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāti, evaṃ pavattinivattiyo saha hetunā vibhajanto cattāri ariyasaccāni pakāsesīti.
analyzed: sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāti evam pavatti nivattiyaḥ saha hetunā vibhajanto cattāri ariya saccāni pakāsesi iti
translated: He revealed the four noble truths: he analysed the four noble truths with their causes in such a way that the great merchant was established in the fruit of stream-entry.

original: Sudattasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sudatta sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Sudatta Sutta is ended.

original: 9. Paṭhamasukkāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The first Sukkāsutta

original: 243. Rathikanti racchaṃ. Gahetvāti gantvā. Siṅghāṭakanti aññattha tikoṇā racchā vuccati.
analyzed: rathikam ti raccham gahetvā ati gantvā siṅghāṭakam ti aññattha ti koṇā racchā vuccati
translated: A chariot road: a carriage road. Having gone: having reached. A triangular junction: elsewhere a triangular junction is called a “racchā.”

original: Idha pana “catukka”nti vuttaṃ. “Madhupīkā”ti ettha madhu-saddena madhuviseso vuccatīti
analyzed: idha pana catukkan ti vuttam madhupīkā ati ettha madhu saddena madhu viseso vuccati iti
translated: Here, however, it is said “a set of four.” As to “honey-drinkers”: the word “honey” here signifies a particular kind of honey.

original: āha “gandhamadhupānaṃ pītā viyā”ti. Sāmaññajotanā hi visese tiṭṭhatīti gandhamadhūti
analyzed: āha gandha madhu pānam pītā viyāti sāmañña jotanā hi visese tiṭṭhati iti gandha madhu iti
translated: So it is said: “as if they had drunk fragrant honey.” For the simile is based on a particular.

original: ca ativiya madhuro madaniyo eko madhuviseso. Tenāha “asaññī hutvā sayatevā”ti.
analyzed: ca madhuraḥ madaniyaḥ ekaḥ madhu viseso tena āha asaññī hutvā sayatā iva ati
translated: Fragrant honey is a particular kind of honey that is very sweet and intoxicating. Hence it is said: “as if they were lying unconscious.”

original: Na paṭivānīyaṃ na apanetabbanti appaṭivānīyaṃ. Tenāha “bāhirakañhī”tiādi. Yaṃ kiñci
analyzed: na paṭivānīyam na apanetabbanti appaṭivānīyam tena āha bāhirakam hi itiādi yam kiñci
translated: What is not to be rejected or discarded is “not to be rejected.” Hence it is said: “the heretic’s drink.”🔽What does not cause the flow of water is “not causing the flow of water” .

original: santapaṇītabhāvāvahaṃ na secananti asecanakaṃ. Tato eva anāsittakaṃ. Ojavantanti
analyzed: santa paṇīta bhāva āvaham na asecanakam tatas eva an āsittakam
translated: Because of that, it is “not causing the flow of water.” It is “full of vigor”🔽because it is like the vigor of one who is highly esteemed. Hence it is said: “Just as … ”

original: bahusammataojavantasadisatāya ojavantaṃ. Tenāha “yathā hī”tiādi. Dhammatāyāti attano
analyzed: bahu sammata ojavanta sadisa tāya ojavantam tena āha yathā hi itiādi dhamma tāya ati attano
translated: “By nature” means by its own nature.🔽It is sweet and desirable.

original: sabhāveneva. Madhuro iṭṭho. Pivantī viyāti sukkāya bhikkhuniyā upanīyamānaṃ saddhammāmatarasaṃ
analyzed: sabhāvena iva madhuraḥ iṭṭhaḥ pivantī viyāti sukkāya bhikkhuniyā upanīyamānam saddhamma amata rasam
translated: As if they were drinking, the dry bhikkhunī, having filled her ear-vessel with the taste of the true Dhamma,

original: attano sotañjaliṃ pūretvā odahantīva. Valāhakato āgataṃ valāhakaṃ.
analyzed: sotañjalim pūretvā odahanti iva valāhakataḥ āgatam valāhakam
translated: as if she were pouring it in.

original: Paṭhamasukkāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama sukkā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the first dry-goods discourse is finished.

original: 10. Dutiyasukkāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya sukkā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 10. Description of the Second Discourse on Sukkā

original: 244. Bahuṃ vata puññaṃ pasavati sabbaganthavimuttiyā sīlasamannāgatena aggadakkhiṇeyyāya sukkāya theriyā bhojanassa dinnattā.
analyzed: bahum vata puññam pasavati sabba gantha vimuttiyā sīla samannāgatena aggadakkhiṇeyyāya sukkāya theriyā bhojanassa dinnattā
translated: . He generates much merit, by giving a meal to the Elder Nun Sukkā, who is endowed with virtue and is the most worthy of offerings, for the sake of the complete liberation from all bondage.

original: Dutiyasukkāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya sukkā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Second Discourse on Sukkā is finished.

original: 11. Cīrāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cīrā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Description of the Discourse on the Rag-robe

original: 245. Ekādasamaṃ uttānameva dasamena sadisattā. Tattha hi bhojanaṃ upāsakassa ābhataṃ, idha cīvaradānanti ayameva viseso.
analyzed: ekādasamam uttānam eva dasamena sadisa ttā tattha hi bhojanam upāsakassa ābhatam idha cīvara dānam ti ayam eva visesaḥ
translated: . The eleventh is clear, like the tenth, because it is similar to the tenth. For there the meal was brought by a lay devotee, here the gift of the robe is the only difference.

original: Cīrāsuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cīrā sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the Discourse on the Rag-robe is finished.

original: 12. Āḷavakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āḷavaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Description of the Discourse on Āḷavaka

original: 246. Āḷaviyanti itthiliṅgavasena taṃ raṭṭhampi nagarampi vuccati. Raṭṭhe adhippetepi
analyzed: itthi liṅga vasena tam raṭṭham pi nagaram pi vuccati raṭṭhe adhippete pi
translated: . Āḷavī is said to be the country and the city by the feminine gender. In the country, even though the lord is

original: na ettha bahuvacanaṃ tathāruḷhiyā abhāvato. Tañca bhavananti tañca āḷavakassa yakkhassa
analyzed: na ettha bahuvacanam tathā āruḷhiyāḥ abhāvataḥ tat ca bhavananti tat ca āḷavakassa yakkhassa
translated: not here, the plural is not because of the absence of the mode of that. And that is his abode, and that is the abode of the ogre Āḷavaka.

original: bhavanaṃ. Tatthāti āḷavakassa bhavane. “Atha kho āḷavako yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamī”ti
analyzed: bhavanam tattha ati āḷavakassa bhavane atha kho āḷavakaḥ yakkhaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami iti
translated: There means in the abode of Āḷavaka. “Then the ogre Āḷavaka approached the Fortunate One”🔽.

original: ettha tasmiṃ pāṭhapadese. Ayamanupubbikathāti ayaṃ idāni vuccamānā anupubbato āgatā
analyzed: ettha tasmin pāṭha padese ayam anupubbi kathā ati ayam idāni vuccamānā anupubbataḥ āgatā
translated: Herein, in that place where the recitation was being done. This is the successive talk: this talk that is now being told has come in successive order.

original: kathā. Āḷaviyā issaroti āḷavo, āḷavakoti ca rājā vutto. Kadāci corapaṭibāhanatthaṃ,
analyzed: kathā āḷaviyā issaraḥ ti āḷavaḥ āḷavakaḥ ti ca rājā vuttaḥ kadāci cora paṭibāhana attham
translated: The lord of Āḷavi is called Āḷavaka, and the king is called Āḷavaka. Sometimes for the purpose of warding off thieves,

original: kadāci ussāhasattivibhāvanavasena paṭirājanisedhanatthaṃ, kadāci lakkhayogyaviniyogavasena
analyzed: kadāci ussāha satti vibhāvana vasena paṭirāja nisedhana attham kadāci lakkha yogya viniyoga vasena
translated: sometimes for the purpose of restraining rival kings by showing his own prowess, sometimes for the purpose of making an effort by employing those who are fit for the axe,

original: byāyāmakaraṇatthañca. Migānaṃ vananato vasanato vānato vā “migavā”ti laddhasamaññaṃ
analyzed: byāyāma karaṇa attham ca migānam vananataḥ vasanataḥ vānataḥ vā miga vāti laddha samaññam
translated: the king went hunting. The forest where deer live, either because they live in a forest or because they live in a wood, is called “the deer park.”

original: migavaṃ. Tassevāti rañño eva. Migoti eko eṇimigo. Tiyojananti accantasaṃyoge upayogavacanaṃ.
analyzed: migavam tassa iva ati raññaḥ eva migo ti ekaḥ eṇi migo ti yojanam ti acc anta saṃyoge upayoga vacanam
translated: The king went to the deer park. The king himself: the king alone. The deer: a certain black antelope. Three leagues: the word “leagues” is used in the sense of the utmost extent.

original: Udakaṃ viya pavisitvā ṭhitanti yathā parissamappatto udakaṃ pavisitvā ṭhito nirassāso
analyzed: udakam viya pavisitvā ṭhitanti yathā parissama ppattaḥ udakam pavisitvā ṭhitaḥ nirassāsaḥ
translated: Having entered as if into water and stood: just as one who has entered and stood in water that has reached him is breathless,

original: hoti, evaṃ viya ṭhitaṃ. Mūlanti samīpaṃ. Yakkhaṃ disvāva rañño bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ
analyzed: hoti evam viya ṭhitam samīpam yakkham disvā ava raññaḥ bhayam chambhita ttam
translated: so he stood. The root: the vicinity. Having seen the ogre, fear and trembling

original: ūrutthambhaṃ ahosi, tasmā rājā palāyituṃ nāsakkhi. Tena vuttaṃ “khādituṃ upagato”ti.
analyzed: ūru thambham ahosi tasmā rājā palāyitum na asakkhi tena vuttam khāditum upagataḥ iti
translated: arose in the king’s thighs, and therefore the king was unable to flee. Therefore it is said, “he went to eat him.”

original: Atha rājā dvidhā chinnaṃ migaṃ datvā attānaṃ mocetukāmo ahosi. Yakkho “nanu mama🔽hatthagatakālato paṭṭhāya migopi mama santako, tattha kinnāma te kerāṭiyamidaṃ datvā🔽attano mocana”nti rājānaṃ na muñci. Atha rājā tassa tādisaṃ paṭiññātaṃ akāsi. Tena
analyzed: atha rājā dvidhā chinnam migam da tvā attānam mocetu kāmaḥ ahosi yakkhaḥ nanu mama  hattha gata kālataḥ paṭṭhāya migopi mama santako tattha kinnāma te kerāṭiyam idam da tvā  attanaḥ mocananti rājānam na muñci atha rājā tassa tādisam paṭiññātam akāsi tena
translated: Then the king, wishing to save himself, gave the deer to the Yakkha, who said, “Since the deer is in my power, he is mine; why do you give him to me and try to save yourself?” and he would not let the king go. Then the king made a promise to him.

original: vuttaṃ “rājā tena saddhi”ntiādi. Bhavanaṃ anupagatanti idaṃ mama bhavanaṃ anupagataṃ.🔽Ananuññātanti upagatena sāmibhūtena ananuññātañca. Etena upagataṃ taṃ, idāni tādisena
analyzed: vuttam rājā tena saddhi nti ādi bhavanam anupagatanti idam mama bhavanam anupagatam  an anuññātam ti upagatena sāmi bhūtena an anuññātam ca etena upagatam tam idāni tādisena
translated: Then the king, wishing to save himself, gave the deer in two parts. The spirit said, “Is not the deer mine from the time I took it in my hand? What do you mean by giving me this old woman and trying to save yourself?” And he did not let the king go. Then the king made a promise to him in the same way. Therefore it is said: “The king with him” and so on. “Not come to my house” means not come to my house.

original: anuññātañca khādituṃ labhāmīti dasseti.
analyzed: anuññātam ca khāditum labhāmi iti dasseti
translated: “Not permitted” means not permitted by the owner who has come. By this he shows that he has come, and now he can eat it if it is permitted in the same way.

original: Maccupatheti maccugocare. Āsannamaraṇatāya evamāhaṃsu.
analyzed: mad cu patha iti mad cu gocare āsanna maraṇa tāyai evam āhaṃsu
translated: “On the path of death” means in the domain of death. They said this because of the nearness of death.

original: Taṃ āḷavakakumāraṃ ādāya pakkamiṃsūti yojanā. Tassa rañño mahesī āḷavakakumārassa mātāti vuttā. Devisahassānaṃ vippalapantīnanti vacanaṃ pariṇāmetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tam āḷavaka kumāram ādāya pakkamiṃsu iti yojanā tassa raññaḥ mahesī āḷavaka kumārassa mātā ati vuttā devi sahassānam vippalapantīnam ti vacanam pariṇāmetabbam
translated: “Taking the prince Āḷavaka” means they went out. The chief queen of that king is called the mother of prince Āḷavaka. The words of the thousand queens should be changed.

original: Desanāpariyosāneti yakkhaṃ dametvā paccāgantvā nagaradvārasamīpe rukkhamūle nisinnena🔽bhagavatā sarājikāya mahatiyā parisāya desitadesanāya pariyosāne. Soti bhagavā. Bhavane
analyzed: desanā pariyosānā iti yakkham dametvā paccāgantvā nagara dvāra samīpe rukkha mūle nisinnena  bhagavatā sa rājikāya mahatiyā parisāya desita desanāya pariyosāne saḥ ti bhagavā bhavane
translated: At the conclusion of the teaching: after taming the spirit, he returned and sat down at the foot of a tree near the city gate.

original: evāti vimāne eva. Bhagavāpi passati pakaticakkhunāva nigrodhassa upari nibbattattā.
analyzed: eva ati vimāne eva bhagavā api passati pakati cakkhunā āva nigrodhassa upari nibbatta ttā
translated: At the conclusion of the teaching given by the Blessed One to a great assembly with the king at its head. He: the Blessed One. In his abode: in the mansion. The Blessed One saw it with his own eyes, because it was created above the banyan tree.

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ “rosetukāmatāyā”ti vacane. Tesanti sātāgirihemavatānaṃ. Kāladīpadesakulajanettiāyuppamāṇavisayaṃ
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin rosetu kāma tāyā ati vacane sātāgiri hemavatānam kāla dīpa desa kula jana itti āyu ppamāṇa visayam
translated: There: in the words “desire to copulate.” They: the Sātāgira and Hemavata spirits. The five great surveys: of time, direction, country, family, and woman,

original: pañcamahāvilokitaṃ. “Sītaṃ byapagataṃ hoti, uṇhañca upasammatī”tiādinā āgatāni dvattiṃsa
analyzed: pañcamahāvilokitam āgatāni dvattiṃsa
translated: and of life span and measure. The thirty-two

original: pubbanimittāni. Kaṭippadesavatthikosakaṇṇato tidhā. Saddoti āḷavakassa ugghositasaddo.
analyzed: pubba nimittāni kaṭi ppadesa vatthi kosa kaṇṇataḥ tidhā saddo ti āḷavakassa ugghosita saddo
translated: premonitory signs: “The cold disappears, and the heat is appeased,” etc. The sound: the sound of Āḷavaka’s roar.

original: Iminā pasaṅgena sakalajambudīpaṃ byāpetvā pavatte aparepi tayo sadde yathā ete, evaṃ āḷavakassa ugghositasaddopīti dassetuṃ “cattāro”tiādi vuttaṃ. Osakkanteti parihāyamāne.🔽Cuṇṇentāti cuṇṇetuṃ samatthataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, na pana cuṇṇanavasena vuttaṃ. Tenāha “mā kassacī”tiādi. Ussāvabindumattampīti ussāvapatanamattampi. Khurappaṃ sallaṃ.
analyzed: iminā pasaṅgena sakala jambudīpam byāpetvā pavatte apare pi tayo sadde yathā ete evam āḷavakassa ugghosita saddaḥ api iti dassetum cattāro ti ādi vuttam osakkantā iti parihāyamāne  cuṇṇentā iti cuṇṇetum samattha tam sandhāya vuttam na pana cuṇṇana vasena vuttam tena āha mā kassaci itiādi ussāva bindu mattam pi iti ussāva patana mattam pi khurappam sallam
translated: In order to show that the other three sounds that arose after the first three sounds had spread all over the Rose-Apple Island were also like the sound of Āḷavaka’s cry, the Exalted One said, “Four sounds, bhikkhus.”🔽“Disappearing” means “waning.”🔽“Crushing” is said with reference to the ability to crush, not with reference to the act of crushing. Therefore the Exalted One said, “Let no one say,” and so forth. “A drop of dew” means a drop of water fallen from the sky. “A dart” means a weapon.

original: Seṭṭhānīti ajeyyena appaṭihatabhāvena uttamāni. Dussāvudhanti āvudhakiccakaraṃ uttariyaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭhāni iti ajeyyena appaṭihata bhāvena uttamāni āvudha kicca karam uttariyam
translated: “The best” means the highest, the unsurpassed, the unobstructed. “A fine weapon” means a fine cloth.

original: dussaṃ. Imāni kira sakkādīnaṃ puññānubhāvena nibbattāni appaṭihatappabhāvāni paṭipakkhavidhamanayuttāni
analyzed: dussam imāni kira sakka ādīnam puñña anubhāvena nibbattāni appaṭihata ppabhāvāni paṭipakkha vidhamana yuttāni
translated: It is said that these weapons, which are produced by the power of the merit of Sakka and the other gods, are unobstructed in their power, are suitable for destroying enemies,

original: avajjhāni āvudhāni. Tenāha “yadi hī”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha yadi hi itiādi
translated: and are blameless. Therefore the Exalted One said, “If anyone,” and so forth.

original: Asanivicakkaṃ viyāti asanimaṇḍalaṃ viya.
analyzed: asani vicakkam viyāti asani maṇḍalam viya
translated: “Like a circle of fire” means like a circle of fire-brands.

original: Pittanti alagaddapittaṃ. Bhindeyyāti āsiñceyya. Sukhanti sukaraṃ. Mudubhūtacittavavatthānakaraṇatthanti mudubhūtaṃ attano citte vavatthānassa karaṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: pittam ti alagadda pittam bhindeyya ati āsiñceyya sukham iti sukaram mudu bhūta citta vavatthāna karaṇa ttham ti mudu bhūtam attano citte vavatthānassa karaṇa ttham
translated: Pittanti alagaddapittaṃ. Bhindeyyāti āsiñceyya. Sukhanti sukaraṃ. Mudubhūtacittavavatthānakaraṇatthanti mudubhūtaṃ attano citte vavatthānassa karaṇatthaṃ.

original: Evaṃ vutteti “na khvāha”nti evaṃ vutte. Bhagavato sāsane ṭhite payirupāsitvā uggahitaṃ
analyzed: evam vuttā iti na khvā aham ti evam vutte bhagavataḥ sāsane ṭhite payirupāsitvā uggahitam
translated: Evaṃ vutteti “na khvāha”nti evaṃ vutte. Bhagavato sāsane ṭhite payirupāsitvā uggahitaṃ

original: bhagavantaṃ payirūpāsitvā uggahitameva nāmāti āha “kassapaṃ…pe... uggahesu”nti. Puṭṭhapañhāti
analyzed: bhagavantam payirūpāsitvā uggahitam eva nāma ati āha kassapaṃpe uggahesun ti puṭṭha pañhā iti
translated: bhagavantaṃ payirūpāsitvā uggahitameva nāmāti āha “kassapaṃ…pe... uggahesu”nti. Puṭṭhapañhāti

original: sammāsambuddhena puṭṭhapañhā. Yasmā buddhavisaye puṭṭhapañhā, tasmā buddhavisayāva honti.
analyzed: sammāsambuddhena puṭṭha pañhā yasmai buddha visaye puṭṭha pañhā tasmai buddha visayāḥ ava honti
translated: sammāsambuddhena puṭṭhapañhā. Yasmā buddhavisaye puṭṭhapañhā, tasmā buddhavisayāva honti.

original: Paṭisedhetvāti vācāya asakkuṇeyyabhāveneva paṭisedhetvā. “Yadākaṅkhasī”ti padasandhivasena
analyzed: paṭisedhetvā iti vācāya asakkuṇeyya bhāvena iva paṭisedhetvā yadā ākaṅkhasi iti pada sandhi vasena
translated: Paṭisedhetvāti vācāya asakkuṇeyyabhāveneva paṭisedhetvā. “Yadākaṅkhasī”ti padasandhivasena

original: niddesoti āha “yadi ākaṅkhasī”ti. Tena tuyhaṃ pucchaṃ tāva sutvā vissajjessanti dasseti.
analyzed: niddeso ti āha yadi ākaṅkhasi iti tena tuyham puccham tāva sutvā vissajjessanti dassa iti
translated: niddesoti āha “yadi ākaṅkhasī”ti. Tena tuyhaṃ pucchaṃ tāva sutvā vissajjessanti dasseti.

original: Tenāha “na me”tiādi. Dutiyavikappe da-kāro padasandhikaroti āha “yaṃ ākaṅkhasī”ti.
analyzed: tena āha na mā iti ādi dutiya vikappe dakāro āha yam ākaṅkhasi iti
translated: Tenāha “na me”tiādi. Dutiyavikappe da-kāro padasandhikaroti āha “yaṃ ākaṅkhasī”ti.

original: “Puccha, āvuso, sutvā jānissāmī”ti avatvā sabbaññubuddhassa aniyametvā vacanaṃ sabbavisayaṃ
analyzed: pucche āvuso sutvā jānissāmi iti a vatvā sabbaññu buddhassa a niyametvā vacanam sabba visayam
translated: “Ask, friend, and having heard you will understand” .

original: hotīti āha “sabbaṃ te”tiādi.
analyzed: hoti iti āha sabbam te itiādi
translated: “All to you” : the word of the Omniscient Buddha is not restricted in scope.

original: Kiṃ sūti ettha kinti pucchāyaṃ, sūti saṃsaye, kiṃ nūti attho? Idhāti imasmiṃ loke.
analyzed: kim su iti ettha kinti pucchā ayam su iti saṃsaye kim nu iti idha ati imasmin loke
translated: “What?” : here “what?” is a question word; “how?” is a word of doubt; the meaning is “what is it?” “Here” : in this world.

original: Tasmā vittanti yasmā vittikaraṇato vittaṃ. Sukatanti suṭṭhu sakkaccaṃ kataṃ. Sukhanti
analyzed: tasmai vittanti yasmai vitti karaṇataḥ vittam su katanti suṭṭhu sakkaccam katam sukhanti
translated: “Therefore ‘wealth’ ” : because it is made by effort, it is wealth. “Well-done” : well, thoroughly, done. “Happiness” :

original: iṭṭhaphalaṃ. Tattha yaṃ padhānaṃ, taṃ dassetuṃ “kāyikacetasikaṃ sāta”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: iṭṭha phalam tattha yam padhānam tam dassetum kāyika cetasikam sāta nti ādi vuttaṃ
translated: a desirable fruit. Therein, in order to show what is the striving, it is said: “bodily and mental pleasure” .

original: Nissandaphalañhi taggahaṇena gahitameva hoti. Appetīti pāpeti. Atisayatthajotano🔽tara-saddoti āha “atisayena sādū”ti. Rasasaññitāya iṭṭhānaṃ rāgādidhammānaṃ. Kena
analyzed: nissanda phalam hi tad gahaṇena gahitam eva hoti appeti iti pāpa iti  tara saddo ti āha atisayena sādu iti rasa saññitāya iṭṭhānam rāga ādi dhammānam kena
translated: For the fruit of outcome is included by the inclusion of the fruit of separation. “He causes to taste” : he causes to experience. The word “moreover”

original: pakārenāti kathaṃ-saddassa atthamāha. Kathaṃjīvinti yadi samāsapadametaṃ, “katha”nti
analyzed: pakārena ati kathaṃsaddassa attham āha kathaṃjīvin ti yadi samāsa padam etam katham ti
translated: indicates a special meaning. Therefore it is said: “moreover, it is very sweet” . “By means of which” : he explains the meaning of the word “how?” . “How does he live?” : if this is a compound word, “how”

original: sānunāsikā katāti āha “gāthābandhasukhattha”ntiādi.
analyzed: sā anunāsikā katā iti āha gāthā bandha sukhattha ntiādi
translated: is nasalized. Therefore it is said: “for the sake of ease in the composition of the verse” , etc.

original: Saddhīdha vittanti ekadesena samudāyadassanaṃ samuddapabbatanidassanaṃ viya. Iti-saddo
analyzed: eka desena samudāya dassanam samudda pabbata nidassanam viya iti saddaḥ
translated: “Faith is wealth here” : the seeing of the collection as a whole is like the seeing of the ocean and the mountain as a whole. The word “iti”

original: ādiattho daṭṭhabbo. “Vittikaraṇato vitta”nti vuttamatthaṃ sandhāya hetūpamāhi yojetvā
analyzed: ādi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ vitti karaṇataḥ vittam ti vuttam attham sandhāya hetu upamāhi yojetvā
translated: should be regarded as having the meaning of “ekadesena” . The meaning stated thus: “Because of the making of faith, it is wealth” is illustrated by the simile of the cause,

original: dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tena sukhāvahanato, dukkhapaṭibāhanato, dāliddiyūpasamanato,
analyzed: dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam tena sukha āvahanataḥ dukkha paṭibāhanataḥ dāliddi yūpa samanataḥ
translated: in order to show it thus: “As, indeed, etc.” . Accordingly, because of the bringing of happiness, because of the warding off of suffering, because of the removal of poverty,

original: ratanapaṭilābhahetuto, lokasantatiāvahanato ca saddhā vittaṃ yathā taṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇādīni.
analyzed: ratana paṭilābha hetutaḥ loka santati āvahanataḥ ca saddhā vittam yathā tam hirañña suvaṇṇa ādīni
translated: because of the cause of the acquisition of the treasure, and because of the bringing of the continuity of the world, faith is wealth, just as gold, silver, etc. are.

original: Tenāha “eva”ntiādi. Nanu cetanā sammādiṭṭhiādayo ca sātisayaṃ vipākasukhaṃ āvahanti,
analyzed: tena āha evam tiādi nanu cetanā sammādiṭṭhi ādayo ca sa atisayam vipāka sukham āvahanti
translated: Therefore it is said: “Just as, etc.” . But do not the volition and right view, etc. bring about the happiness of result in a special way?

original: taṃ kathaṃ saddhā āvahatīti? Saddhādhurabhāvasabhāvato. Tenāha “saddhādhurena paṭipannāna”nti.
analyzed: tam katham saddhā āvahati iti tena āha saddhā dhurena
translated: How then does faith bring it? —By the nature of the state of being the burden of faith. Therefore it is said: “For those who have faith as their burden” .

original: Tassa ca sesapadesupi yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tassa ca sesa padesu pi yojetabbam
translated: And this should be applied to the remaining passages also.

original: Idāni yaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇādi saddhāvittassa opammaṃ, taṃ hīnaṃ, saddhāvittameva uttamanti
analyzed: idāni yam hirañña suvaṇṇa ādi saddhā vittassa opammam tam hīnam saddhā vittam eva uttaman ti
translated: Now, that gold, silver, etc. is the simile for the wealth of faith, and that is inferior, while the wealth of faith is superior.

original: pāḷiyaṃ seṭṭhaggahaṇaṃ katanti dassetuṃ “yasmā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Paralokaṃ gataṃ
analyzed: pāḷiyam seṭṭha gahaṇam katan ti dassetum yasmā pana iti ādi vuttam para lokam gatam
translated: The words “But because it is the best” are said to show that the word “best” in the text is used in the sense of “chief.”🔽It is “after-growth” because it grows after the other kinds of wealth.

original: anugacchatīti anugāmikaṃ. Aññehi na sādhāraṇanti anaññasādhāraṇaṃ. Sabbasampattihetūti
analyzed: anugacchati iti anugāmikam aññehi na sādhāraṇan ti anañña sādhāraṇam sabba sampatti hetu uti
translated: It is “not shared with others” because it is not shared with others.

original: sabbāsaṃ sīlasampadādīnaṃ lokiyalokuttarānaṃ sampattīnaṃ hetu. Anatthāya hoti anupāyapaṭipattito.
analyzed: sabbāsam sīla sampad ādīnam lokiya lokuttarānam sampattīnam hetu anatthāya hoti an upāya paṭipattito
translated: It is the cause of all success because it is the cause of all kinds of success, mundane and supramundane, beginning with the success consisting in virtue.🔽It is not for harm because it is not the way to harm.

original: Tasmā anugāmikattā. Anaññasādhāraṇattā sabbasampattihetubhāvato hiraññādivittanidānattā
analyzed: tasmā anugāmika ttā anañña sādhāraṇa ttā sabba sampatti hetu bhāvataḥ hirañña ādi vitta nidāna ttā
translated: Therefore it is the best because it is after-growth, because it is not shared with others, and because it is the cause of all success.

original: ca saddhāvittameva seṭṭhaṃ. Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedadesanā yathā “satthā devamanussāna”nti.
analyzed: ca saddhā vittam eva seṭṭham ukkaṭṭha pariccheda desanā yathā satthā deva manussānam ti
translated: The words “The best” are a statement of the highest number.

original: “Dasakusaladhammo”ti iminā ekaccānaṃyeva dānādidhammānaṃ saṅgaho, na sabbesanti asaṅgahitasaṅgaṇhanatthaṃ
analyzed: dasa kusala dhammaḥ ti iminā ekaccānam yeva dāna ādi dhammānam saṅgahaḥ na sabbesan ti a saṅgahita saṅgaṇhana attham
translated: The words “the ten profitable courses of action” include only some of the things such as giving, etc., and not all of them. So in order to include all of them,🔽the text adds “the things consisting in giving, virtue, and meditation.”

original: “dānasīlabhāvanādhammo vā”ti vuttaṃ. “Sukha”nti tividhassapi sukhassa sādhāraṇaggahaṇametanti
analyzed: dāna sīla bhāvanā dhammaḥ vā ati vuttam sukhanti tividhassa api sukhassa sādhāraṇa ggahaṇam etat ti
translated: The words “happiness” include all the three kinds of happiness.

original: taṃ savisesaladdhaṃ puggalavasena dassento “soṇaseṭṭhi…pe… āvahatī”ti āha. Yo so
analyzed: tam sa visesa laddham puggala vasena dassento soṇa seṭṭhipe āvahati iti āha yaḥ so
translated: and he shows that it is obtained with distinction by way of the person, saying, “The merchant Sonuttara … obtains the happiness of extinction.”

original: padumavatiyā deviyā putto mahāpadumo nāma rājā dibbasukhasadisaṃ rajjasukhamanubhavitvā
analyzed: padumavatiyā deviyā puttaḥ mahāpadumaḥ nāma rājā dibba sukha sadisam rajja sukham anubhavitvā
translated: The king named Mahapaduma, who was the son of the queen Padumavati, after experiencing the happiness of kingship, which was like the happiness of the gods,

original: pacchā paccekabuddho hutvā nibbānasukhamanubhavi, taṃ nidassanabhāvena gahetvā āha
analyzed: pacchā paccekabuddhaḥ hutvā nibbāna sukham anubhavi tam nidassana bhāvena gahetvā āha
translated: later became a Paccekabuddha and experienced the happiness of extinction. Taking that as an example, he said

original: “mahāpadumādīnaṃ viya nibbānasukhañca āvahatī”ti.🔽Atthuddhāranayena saccasaddaṃ saṃvaṇṇento “anekesu atthesu dissatī”ti āha. Vācāsacce🔽dissati saccasaddo “bhaṇe”ti vuttattāti adhippāyo. Viratisacce dissati. Veramaṇīsu🔽hi patiṭṭhitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā “sacce ṭhitā”ti vuccanti. Attākārampi vatthuṃ idameva
analyzed: mahāpaduma ādīnam viya nibbāna sukham ca āvahati iti  attha uddhāra nayena sacca saddam saṃvaṇṇentaḥ anekesu atthesu dissati iti āha vācāsacce  dissati sacca saddaḥ bhaṇa iti vutta ttā ti adhippāyaḥ virati sacce dissati veramaṇīsu  hi patiṭṭhitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā sacce ṭhitā ati vuccanti attā ākāram pi vatthum idam eva
translated: “and it brings the happiness of extinction, like that of Mahapaduma and others.”🔽Explaining the word “truth” by way of the meaning, he said, “It is seen in many meanings.” The intention is this: The word “truth” is seen in the truth of speech, because it is said, “Speak the truth.” It is seen in the truth of virtue.

original: saccaṃ moghamaññanti pavattiyākāraṃ upādāya diṭṭhi eva saccanti diṭṭhisaccaṃ, tasmiṃ
analyzed: saccam moghamaññanti pavattiyā ākāram upādāya diṭṭhi eva saccanti diṭṭhi saccam tasmin
translated: For ascetics and brahmins who are established in the precepts are said to be “established in truth.” The view itself is the truth of view, because of the occurrence of the statement, “This alone is the truth, other views are false,” taking the form of the self and the form of the occurrence as the basis.

original: diṭṭhisacce dissatīti yojanā. Brāhmaṇasaccānīti paramatthabrahmānaṃ saccāni, yāni
analyzed: diṭṭhi sacce dissati iti yojanā brāhmaṇa saccāni iti paramattha brahmānam saccāni yāni
translated: The construction is: “The truth of view is seen.” The brahmin’s truths: the truths of the ultimate brahmin, which are the four truths stated in the Catukkanipāta of the Dhammapada thus:

original: “sabbe pāṇā avajjhā, sabbe kāmā aniccā, sabbe bhavā aniccā, nāhaṃ kvacani kassaci🔽kiñcanatasmi”ntiādinā catukkanipāte āgatāni. Paramatthabhūtaṃ saccaṃ nibbānaṃ. Abbhantaraṃ
analyzed: sabbe pāṇāḥ avajjhāḥ sabbe kāmāḥ aniccāḥ sabbe bhavāḥ aniccāḥ na aham kvacani kassaci  kiñcana tasmin ti ādinā catukka nipāte āgatāni paramattha bhūtam saccam nibbānam abbhantaram
translated: “All beings shun death, all love the pleasures of sense; Having known this nature of beings, I would kill no being, nor cause another to kill.🔽All beings shun pain, all love pleasure; Having known this nature of beings, I would not cause pain to another.🔽All beings love life, all fear death; Having known this nature of beings, I would kill no being, nor cause another to kill.🔽All beings love life, all fear death; Having known this nature of beings, I would not cause pain to another” . The ultimate truth is Nibbāna.

original: katvāti antogadhameva katvā, tehi saddhinti attho paramatthasaccānampi sādutarattā.
analyzed: katvā iti antogadham eva katvā tehi saddhinti
translated: Having made it his own: having made it his own, having taken it as his own. Together with them: together with the four truths. The ultimate truth is more excellent than the other four.

original: Yassānubhāvenāti yassa vācāsaccassa ānubhāvena.🔽Udakamhi dhāvatīti udakapiṭṭhiyaṃ abhijjamānāyaṃ pathaviyā viya dhāvati gacchati
analyzed: yassa anubhāvena ati yassa vācā asaccassa ānubhāvena  udakamhi dhāvati iti udaka piṭṭhiyam abhijjamānā ayam pathaviyā viya dhāvati gacchati
translated: By the power of: by the power of the truth of his speech.

original: mahākappinarājā viya. Visampi saccena hananti paṇḍitāti kaṇhadīpāyanādayo viya. Saccenāti
analyzed: mahākappina rājāḥ saccena hananti paṇḍitā ati kaṇha dīpāyana ādayaḥ saccena ati
translated: He runs on the water: he runs on the water as though on the earth’s surface, like the king of the great garuḍas. The wise destroy fire by truth: like Kaṇhadīpāyana and others. By truth:

original: macchajātake bodhisattassa viya saccena devo thanayaṃ pavassati. Sacce ṭhitāti viratisacce
analyzed: maccha jātake bodhisattassa viya saccena devaḥ thanayam pavassati sacce virati sacce
translated: the rain-cloud pours rain by the truth of the Bodhisatta in the Macchajāt. Standing on truth: standing on the truth of abstinence.

original: vācāsacce ca ṭhitā tayopi bodhisattā. Nibbutinti nibbānaṃ patthayanti. Sādutaranti🔽sātataraṃ iṭṭhataravipākadānato.🔽Rasānanti niddhāraṇatthe sāmivacanaṃ. Niddhāraṇañca koci kutoci kenaci imanti kassaci🔽vacanaṃ na sādhetīti dassento “ye ime”tiādimāha. Tena hi nibbānaṃ rasasamudāyato
analyzed: vācāsacce ca ṭhitā tayaḥ api bodhisattāḥ nibbutinti nibbānam patthayanti sādutaranti  sātataram iṭṭhatara vipāka dānato  niddhāraṇa atthe sāmi vacanam niddhāraṇam ca koci kutoci kenaci imanti kassaci  vacanam na sādheti iti dassentaḥ ye ime iti ādim āha tena hi nibbānam rasa samudāyato
translated: and they are all established in truth of speech. They seek for the extinction : they seek for Nibbāna. More delectable : more delectable because they give a more desirable ripening.🔽Flavours : the word “flavours” is a genitive of source. And in order to show that some do not establish the word of anyone from anywhere by any means, he said “Those that are called” .

original: sādutaratāvisesena niddhārīyati. Tattha ye ime vuccantīti yojanā. Sāyanīyadhammāti
analyzed: sādutara tā visesena niddhārīyati tattha ye ime vuccanti iti yojanā sāyanīya dhammā ti
translated: Thus Nibbāna is established by a distinction of being more delectable than the aggregate of flavours. Herein, the construction is “those that are called” .

original: jivhāya sāyitabbā dhammā. Rasāyatanaṃ rasoti āha “mūlaraso khandharaso”tiādi. Phalarasanti
analyzed: jivhāya sāyitabbā dhammā rasa āyatanam rasaḥ ti āha mūla rasaḥ khandha rasaḥ utiādi phala rasanti
translated: Flavours of the day : dhammas to be tasted by the tongue. The flavour base is called “flavour” . He said “root flavour, trunk flavour” , and so on. Fruit flavour :

original: phalassa rasaṃ, phalaṃ pīḷetvā tāpetvā gahetabbarasanti attho. Arasarūpoti ācārarahitasabhāvo.
analyzed: phalassa rasam phalam pīḷetvā tāpetvā gahetabba rasanti atthaḥ arasa rūpaḥ ti ācāra rahita sabhāvaḥ
translated: the flavour of the fruit. The meaning is: the flavour to be got by squeezing and heating the fruit. Flavourless in nature : devoid of the nature of flavour.

original: Rūpassa assādanavasena uppajjanakasukhadhammā rūparasā. Esa nayo saddarasādīsu. Saddarasoti
analyzed: rūpassa assādana vasena uppajjanaka sukha dhammā rūpa rasāḥ esa nayo sadda rasa ādīsu sadda rasaḥ ti
translated: Flavour of form : the profitable dhammas that arise by way of enjoyment of form. The same method applies to the flavours of sound, and so on. Flavour of sound :

original: byañjanasambhūto raso. Vimuttirasoti vimuttisampattiko raso. Attharasoti atthassa
analyzed: byañjana sambhūtaḥ rasaḥ vimutti rasaḥ ti vimutti sampattikaḥ rasaḥ attha rasaḥ ti atthassa
translated: The taste of the letter is the taste of the letter as the source of the meaning. The taste of freedom is the taste of the perfection of freedom. The taste of the meaning is the taste of the meaning as the source of the letter.

original: paṭivijjhanavasena uppajjanakasukhaṃ attharaso, tathā dhammaraso veditabbo. Rūpācārātiādīsu🔽rasaggahaṇena phalarasaṃ vadati. So hi phalassa rūpo ca, rasitabbato āsādetabbato
analyzed: paṭivijjhana vasena uppajjanaka sukham attha rasaḥ tathā dhamma rasaḥ veditabbaḥ  rasa ggahaṇena phala rasam vadati saḥ hi phalassa ca rasitabbataḥ āsādetabbataḥ
translated: Taste born of the syllables is the taste of the syllables. The taste of freedom is the taste consisting in the perfection of freedom. The taste of the meaning is the taste of the pleasure arisen by the penetration of the meaning. The taste of the Dhamma should be understood in the same way. In the passage beginning “The taste of form” ,🔽he speaks of the taste of the fruit by the word “taste.” For the fruit is “the taste of form” because it is the form of the fruit and because it is the taste to be savored, the enjoyment.

original: raso cāti “rūparaso”ti vuccati. Ācāro pana sāmaggīrasahetutāya “raso”ti vutto. Saccaṃ
analyzed: raso ca ati rūpa rasaḥ ti vuccati ācāro pana sāmaggī rasa hetutāya rasaḥ ti vutto saccam
translated: But the taste of concord is called “taste” because it is the cause of the taste of concord.

original: haveti ettha haveti ekaṃsatthe nipāto, ekaṃsattho ca avadhāraṇamevāti āha “saccameva🔽sādutara”ntiādi. Sarīramupabrūhenti, na cittaṃ. Nanu ca sukhuppattipayojanattā cittampi
analyzed: hava iti ettha hava iti ekaṃsa tthe nipātaḥ ca avadhāraṇam eva ati āha saccam eva  na cittam nanu ca sukha uppatti payojana ttā cittam pi
translated: In the passage beginning “The truth, indeed” , the word indeed is a particle in the sense of singleness, and singleness is the same as emphasis.🔽Therefore the commentator says, “The truth, indeed, is the most excellent taste” , and so on. They nourish the body, not the mind.🔽But isn’t it true that they nourish the mind too, since they are the cause for the arising of pleasure?

original: upabrūhentīti? Na, sukhassa sarīrabrūhanaṃ paṭicca uppannattā. Viratisaccavācāti
analyzed: upabrūhenti iti na sukhassa sarīra brūhanam paṭicca uppanna ttā virati sacca vācā ti
translated: No, because pleasure arises in dependence on the nourishment of the body. The words “the truth of cessation”

original: saccavisesena sampajjanaṃ vadati. Cittamupabrūheti padālikāya virativācāya saccarase
analyzed: sacca visesena sampajjanam vadati cittam upabrūha iti padālikāya virati vācāya sacca rase
translated: he speaks of the attainment by means of a particular truth. They nourish the mind by the words of the truth of renunciation.

original: sati samathavipassanādīhi cittaparibrūhanassa sambhavato maggaphalānisaṃsaṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: sati samatha vipassanā ādīhi citta paribrūhanassa sambhavataḥ magga phala anisaṃsam gaṇhāti
translated: and because it is possible to expand the mind by means of serenity, insight, and so on, it takes the fruit of the path as its relish.

original: Asaṃkilesikañca sukhamāvahati vivaṭṭasannissitattā. Vimuttirasoti phalasukhaṃ vadati
analyzed: asaṃkilesikam ca sukham āvahati vivaṭṭa sannissita ttā vimutti rasaḥ iti phala sukham vadati
translated: And it conveys untarnished bliss because it is based on the revolution of the support. The “flavour of deliverance” is the bliss of fruition,

original: nibbānasukhampi vā. Paramatthasaccaraso nāma nibbānaraso. Tathā hi taṃ “accutirasaṃ
analyzed: nibbāna sukham pi vā paramattha sacca rasaḥ nāma nibbāna rasaḥ tathā hi tam accuti rasam
translated: or it is the bliss of Nibbāna. The “flavour of ultimate truth” is the flavour of Nibbāna,

original: assāsakaraṇarasa”ntipi vuccati. Tena paribhāvitattāti vimuttirasassa sādutarabhāvadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: vuccati tena paribhāvita ttā ati vimutti rasassa sādutara bhāva dassana ttham
translated: for that is called “the flavour of deathlessness” and “the flavour of confidence” . “Because it is suffused with that” is said in order to show that the flavour of deliverance is more refined.

original: Evaṃ santepi “vimuttirasaparibhāvitattā”ti etena kāmaṃ vimuttiraso vā paramatthasaccaraso
analyzed: evam sante pi vimutti rasa paribhāvita ttā ti etena kāmam vimutti rasaḥ vā paramattha sacca rasaḥ
translated: But even so, by the words “because it is suffused with the flavour of deliverance” he shows that the flavour of ultimate truth,

original: vā sādutararasāti dasseti. Tadadhigamūpāyabhūtanti tassa paramatthasaccassa adhigamūpāyabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: vā dassa iti tad adhigama upāya bhūtam ti tassa paramattha saccassa adhigama upāya bhūtam
translated: or the flavour of deliverance, is a more refined flavour. “The means to its attainment”: the means to the attainment of that ultimate truth.

original: Atthañca dhammañcāti phalañca kāraṇañca nissāya pavattito attharasā dhammarasā ca
analyzed: atthañca dhammañca ati phalañca kāraṇañca nissāya pavattitaḥ attha rasā dhamma rasā ca
translated: “Meaning and Dhamma”: the flavour of meaning and the flavour of Dhamma occur respectively in relation to the fruit and the cause.

original: sādū, tatopi paramatthasaccameva sādurasanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: sādū tatas pi paramattha saccam eva sādu rasanti adhippāyo
translated: They are sweet, but the ultimate truth is sweeter still. This is the intention.

original: Lokuttaraṃ lokiyañca atthaṃ ajānanto andho, lokiyatthameva jānanto ekacakkhu, ubhayaṃ🔽jānanto dvicakkhu. Parahitaṃ attahitañca ajānanto andho, attahitameva jānanto ekacakkhu,
analyzed: lokuttaram lokiyam ca attham a jānantaḥ andhaḥ lokiya ttham eva jānantaḥ eka cakkhu ubhayaṃ  jānantaḥ dvi cakkhu para hitam atta hitañca a jānantaḥ andhaḥ atta hitam eva jānantaḥ eka cakkhu
translated: One who does not know the supramundane and mundane meanings is blind; one who knows only the mundane meanings is one-eyed; one who knows both is two-eyed. One who does not know the benefit for others and the benefit for oneself is blind; one who knows only the benefit for oneself is one-eyed;

original: ubhayatthaṃ jānanto dvicakkhu. So dvicakkhupuggalo paññājīvī. Taṃ pana gahaṭṭhapabbajitavasena
analyzed: ubhayattham jānantaḥ dvi cakkhu so dvi cakkhu puggalo paññājīvī tam pana gaha ṭṭha pabbajita vasena
translated: One who does not know the supramundane and mundane meanings is blind. One who knows only the mundane meaning is one-eyed. One who knows both is two-eyed. One who does not know the benefit for others and for oneself is blind. One who knows only the benefit for oneself is one-eyed. One who knows both is two-eyed. That two-eyed person is one who lives by wisdom. But in order to show that by dividing it into the house-life and the homeless life,

original: vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “gahaṭṭho vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gahaṭṭhapaṭipadaṃ ārādhetvā cāti yojanā.
analyzed: vibhajitvā dassetum gahaṭṭhaḥ vā itiādi vuttam gahaṭṭha paṭipadam ārādhetvā ca ati yojanā
translated: it is tenfold, he said, “either as a layman or as a homeless one.” The construction is: having fulfilled the practice of the layman.

original: Ārādhetvāti ca sādhetvāti attho.
analyzed: ārādhetvā ati ca sādhetvā ati attho
translated: “Having fulfilled” means having accomplished.

original: Purimanayenevāti kassapasammāsambuddhavissajjitanayeneva. Kiñcāpīti anujānanasandassanatthe🔽nipāto. Kiṃ anujānātīti? Gāthāya catūhi padehi vuttesu atthesu ekassa atthassa siddhiyaṃ
analyzed: purima nayena iva āti kassapa sammāsambuddha vissajjita nayena iva kiñcā api iti anujānana sandassana atthe  nipātaḥ kim anujānāti iti gāthāya catūhi padehi vuttesu atthesu ekassa atthassa siddhiyam
translated: “In the same way as before” means in the same way as was explained in the case of Kassapa, the Fully Enlightened One. The word “also” is a particle indicating permission.🔽What does he permit? When one of the four meanings stated in the verse is accomplished,🔽he permits the accomplishment of the others as well. Therefore he said: “When one of the four kinds of failure is purified, etc.”

original: itaresampi siddhiṃ anujānāti. Tenāha “yo catubbidhamoghaṃ…pe… parisujjhatī”ti. Kiṃ
analyzed: itaresam pi siddhim anujānāti tena āha yaḥ catubbidha moghaṃpe parisujjhati iti kim
translated: What is the fourfold failure?

original: sandassetīti? Yesaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ balavabhāvena oghataraṇādi na sijjhati, tesaṃ paṭipakkhānaṃ
analyzed: sandasseti iti yesam pāpa dhammānam balava bhāvena ogha taraṇa ādi na sijjhati tesam paṭipakkhānam
translated: What does it reveal?🔽It reveals the opposite of those evil states by the power of which the crossing of the flood, etc., is not successful.

original: nissandehavasena sandassanaṃ. Tenāha “evaṃ santepī”tiādi. Oghataraṇanti oghataraṇapaṭipattiṃ.🔽Asaddahantoti evaṃ paṭipajjanto imāya paṭipattiyā oghaṃ taratīti na saddahanto. Na🔽pakkhandatīti pakkhandanalakkhaṇāya saddhāya na ugghāṭīyatīti na otarati. Cittavossaggenāti
analyzed: nissandeha vasena sandassanam tena āha evam sante pi itiādi ogha taraṇam ti ogha taraṇa paṭipattim  a saddahantaḥ iti evam paṭipajjantaḥ imāya paṭipattiyāḥ ogham tarati iti na saddahantaḥ na  pakkhandati iti pakkhandana lakkhaṇāya saddhāya na ugghāṭīyati iti na otarati citta vossaggena ati
translated: “To show” : to show by way of the opposite of those bad qualities whose power prevents the crossing of the flood, etc. Therefore it is said: “Even though this is so, etc.” “Crossing of the flood” : the practice for crossing the flood.

original: yathākāmācāravasena cittassa vossajjanena. Pamatto pamādaṃ āpanno. Tatthevāti kāmesu🔽eva. Visattattā laggattā. Vokiṇṇoti visevito. Tasmāti vuttassa catubbidhassapi atthassa
analyzed: yathākāma ācāra vasena cittassa vossajjanena pamattaḥ pamādam āpanno tattha eva ati kāmesu  eva visatta ttā lagga ttā vokiṇṇaḥ ti visevito tasmā iti vuttassa catubbidhassa api atthassa
translated: “Without confidence” : not confident that by practising thus one will cross the flood by this practice. “Does not plunge in” : is not drawn in by confidence, which has the characteristic of plunging in. “By surrendering his mind” : by surrendering his mind to the practice of his own will. “Negligent” : fallen into negligence. “Right there” : in sensual pleasures.

original: hetubhāvena paccāmasanaṃ. Tappaṭipakkhanti assaddhiyādīnaṃ paṭipakkhaṃ saddhādīnaṃ okāsattā.
analyzed: hetu bhāvena paccāmasanam tad paṭipakkham ti assaddhiyā ādīnam paṭipakkham saddhā ādīnam okāsa ttā
translated: “Because of his attachment” : because of his clinging. “Mixed up” : mixed. “That” : the reason for the fourfold meaning stated. “The opposite of that” : the opposite of lack of confidence, etc., because of the opportunity for confidence, etc.

original: Etāyāti gāthāyaṃ iminā padenāti sambandho. Sappurisasaṃsevo saddhammassavanaṃ yonisomanasikāro
analyzed: etāya iti gāthā ayam iminā padena ati sambandhaḥ sappurisa saṃsevaḥ saddhamma ssavanam yoni so manasikāraḥ
